annotations.text: (I'm at bat)
annotations.annotation:
Cam’s team The Diplomats (also known as Dipset) is an American hip hop group formed in 1997 by childhood friends Cam'ron and Jim Jones in Harlem, New York.

The group was originally composed of Cam'ron, Jim Jones (Jim) and Freekey Zekey (Zeke), all of whom grew up together in Harlem. Juelz Santana joined the group later in 1999.

annotations.text:
She like, "Damn, this the realest since 'Kumbaya'"
 Bomaye, Killa Cam, my Lord (My Lord)
annotations.annotation:
The woman (actually man, but whatever..) singing in the background is saying that this is the best singalong song since “Kumbaya”, a campfire classic. The phrase “my Lord” is very prominent in the lyrics of “Kumbaya”, and Cam uses this phrase to end the line.

“Bomaye” means “kill him!” in Lingala; the term was popularized in America during the Rumble in the Jungle – the much publicized fight between Muhammad Ali and George Foreman in Kinshasa, Zaire (now Democratic Republic of the Congo) – where Ali supporters would chant “Ali Bumaye!”



Cam is using the word here as an African synonym for “Killa” (also it rhymes internally with ‘Kumbaya’)

annotations.text: Still the man with the pan,
annotations.annotation: A pan to cook crack in. Also a play on the phrase “Man with the plan”.

annotations.text: Scrilla, fam, on board
annotations.annotation: Jim Jones and Juelz are cookin' it up too!

annotations.text: Now bitches, they want to neuter me
annotations.annotation:
This could mean a number of different things:


Cam’s women want him to commit to a relationship
Cam’s sex drive is too intense for most of his women
Cam’s women want to feminize him
Cam’s women want to castrate him, possibly for cheating.

annotations.text: The hooligan in Houlihan's, maneuvering's nothing new to me
annotations.annotation: Houlihan’s is a chain of restaurants and bars in the Midwest, the region where Cam'ron purportedly sold a lot of drugs.

annotations.text: Doggy, I'm from the land of grind,
annotations.annotation: He either means Harlem, or it’s just a way to say he’s a “grinder”/hard worker (i.e., wherever he’s from would be the land of grind because he was from there)

annotations.text: Pan-pan: gram or dime?
annotations.annotation:
Pan Pan Hard Times Diner is a famous soul food restaurant chain. The flagship location in Harlem – which was located at 135th st. and Lenox ave. – burned down in 2004

Cam'ron is imitating himself as a young man, selling cocaine in front of the Pan Pan diner: a gram of yayo is $50, a dime is $10 (hence “dime”)

annotations.text: Not toes or MC when I say "hammer time"
annotations.annotation:
A “hammer” is a gun. When Cam'ron declares “hammer time” he doesn’t mean what MC Hammer means or the foot condition known as hammer toe (called “hammer time” in the Eddie Murphy movie Boomerang); he means his gun.

Also a reference to Arm & Hammer baking soda, which is used to make crack. This follows directly the gram or dime line mentioned just before

annotations.text: Beef: I hammer mine, when I get my hands on nines
annotations.annotation: A double entendre: a butcher “hammers” ground beef; Cam'ron settles “beef” – disagreements – with his “hammer” – his – in this case nine milimeter – gun

annotations.text: If I had on 'Bama line, Corduroys, Cam'll shine
annotations.annotation:
“Bama” is D.C. derogatory slang for a person from the Deep South (short for “Alabama”)

Even if Cam'ron were dressed like one these tramps – in tattered corduroys and suspenders – his jewelry alone (as well as his healthy skin) would still make him gleam

In other words, Cam'ron is paraphrasing the popular phrase: “Clothes don’t make a man.. jewelry does”

annotations.text: Canary burgundy: I call it "Lemon Red" (Red)
annotations.annotation: Canary diamonds are diamonds with a very rare structure (that make up less than .1% of all known diamonds) that are either yellow or brown; he’s saying he has a burgundy canary diamond (which I believe is so rare it doesn’t even exist)

annotations.text: Yellow diamonds in my ear, call 'em "Lemonheads"
annotations.annotation:
Cam'ron compares his diamond earrings to the popular “Lemonheads” candy. Such junk food analogies are signature Cam (cf. “Range look like laffy taffy” a few lines down). This is a precursor to Gucci Mane’s famous paean to “all yellow everything.”

This isn’t mere boasting, though — Cam can back it up, given that he actually owns a pair:

annotations.text:
Lemonhead, end up dead, ice like Winnipeg
 Gemstone, Flintstones,
annotations.annotation:
Ice is cleverly used in two ways

Act stupid and you’ll end up dead (“iced”) like Winnipeg, a notoriously cold Canadian city

Also, he has a lot of diamonds (“ice”, “stones”)

annotations.text: You could say I'm friends with Fred
annotations.annotation: In reference to the previous “Flintstones” line, Cam says that he has so many diamonds or Flintstones in this case, that you could say he is friends with Fred Flintstones, from the famous Hanna – Barbera cartoon of the 60s.

annotations.text: You unhappy, scrappy? (What's going on, Scrappy?)
annotations.annotation:
You think YOU have problems? Cam'ron has the Gubernator on his ass!

Furthermore, Scrappy-Doo is another Hanna-Barbera character, this keeps the play on words/theme going, seeing as how Fred Flintstone was mentioned right before this line.

annotations.text: I got Pataki at me
annotations.annotation: George Pataki was a New York Governor known for his tough stance on drug dealers

annotations.text: Bitches say I'm "Tacky Daddy," Range look like Laffy Taffy
annotations.annotation:
Another candy metaphor

Also, in the video to the song he is driving a distinctly Laffy Taffy custom-colored Range Rover when this line plays…how tacky is that, right ladies?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F4zCt0pRcLo

annotations.text: Yo, I'm from where Nicky Barnes got rich as fuck
annotations.annotation: Leroy “Nicky” Barnes aka Mr. Untouchable aka The Teflon Don is a famous drug dealer who made his fortune selling heroin in Harlem (Cam is from there as well, and he also sells drugs)

annotations.text: Rich and A hit the kitchens then were pitchin' up
annotations.annotation:
“Rich and A” are Rich Porter and Alpo, two flamboyant New York drug kingpins of the 80s. Alpo killed Rich in 1990 over (you guessed it) yayo

The movie Paid in Full, which Cam'ron starred in, was based on Rich and A (Cam'ron suavely portrayed Rico)

annotations.text:
Rob Base, Mase, Doug E Fresh switched it up
 I do both, who am I to fuck tradition up?
annotations.annotation:
The founding fathers of Harlem rap; Cam'ron both sells crack and raps, following in the tradition of the great men who came before him

Doug E Fresh still lives in Harlem, and is now a prominent scientologist

annotations.text:
So I parked in a tow-away zone
 Chrome...I don't care
 That car a throwaway, homes
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron parks his car illegally, with full knowledge that it could easily be towed. While this reckless treatment of his vehicle (especially one decked out with chrome) might seem counter-intuitive, Cam points out that the car means nothing to him — he lives lavish enough to easily replace it, if need be.

annotations.text: Welcome to Harlem, where you welcome to problems
annotations.annotation: Harlem is one of Manhattan’s poorest communities, and has a murder rate that is about six times higher than New York City’s average.

annotations.text: Off of furlough, fellow felons get pardons
annotations.annotation: Tru thugs use their prison furlough (or, sometimes, law firm fulough) as an excuse to do thuggish things; they act like they’ve been granted a temporary pardon

annotations.text:
Them niggas knew we bang
 Stood out like Pootie Tang
annotations.annotation: Pootie Tang, the protagonist of the 2001 Louis C.K.-directed film of the same name, was a multi-national celebrity who got overwhelming attention, including for his over-the-top, bizarre outfits (including furs and chains much like those Cam enjoys).

annotations.text:
Soon as the stoolie sings
 That when the toolie sing!
annotations.annotation: Soon as the stool pigeon gives the cops information, Cam will shoot him

annotations.text:
Bang! Bang!
 Came from that movie ring
 Snap, crack jewelry bling
 Flapjack, ooh he bring
 Clack-clack, "ooh he ring!"
 Bad rap, cuties cling
annotations.annotation:
This is a typical example of Cam'ron cutting the rhyme of the verse in half, resulting in elusive lyrics.

The gunshots (from killing the stool pigeon in the line above) were like a movie soundtrack.

Or they killed/scared a person like in the movie The Ring?

“Snap crack” is a reference to Rice Krispies as well as a description of the visual sound his diamonds make when they glisten. “Flapjack” is a stand in for crack. “Clack clack” is the sound of flipping open his cell phone to call a girl…who claims that he has a bad rap for cheating on girls

annotations.text:
Ass cap, put them in the river
 I'm the sushi king
annotations.annotation:
“Ass cap” inverts “put a cap in their ass” (slang for “shoot them”) and throw them in the river so that the fish – Cam’s humble sushi subjects – have something to nibble on

Also, ASCAP (stands for “American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers”) is an association that monitors radio broadcasts to ensure that recording artists get paid. There’s no record of beef between Cam and ASCAP, but he does have a reputation for being contentious about royalties, so maybe there’s something there..

annotations.text: And I'ma keep ya fresh
annotations.annotation:
In order to uphold his reputation as “sushi king,” Cam needs to keep his victims fresh before he serves them up, just like sushi-grade fish.

It could also mean that before he tosses you in the river, he’ll grab all of your “fresh” (cool/expensive) jewelry, shoes, clothes, etc.

annotations.text: Let the fish eat ya flesh
annotations.annotation:
Once upon a time, you ate sashimi.

Now, sashimi eats you.

annotations.text: Teach you how to rope a chick
annotations.annotation:
Wordplay on ‘'roping of chickens’‘. This activity is similar to the roping of a calf in a rodeo, though it is done on a smaller scale with chicken. Cam means that he’ll teach you how to catch a girl, or a chick.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tu5gKvv25Qg

annotations.text:
What you want: coke or piff?
 Got it all, smoke or sniff?
annotations.annotation:
Cam’s got all sorts of drugs, whether you want cocaine or marijuana, he’s got it.

Notice the double rhyme: coke and smoke, and piff and sniff.

annotations.text:
And you know my drift
 Used to figures, dough and shit
annotations.annotation: He’s talking about how he can get money off the same customer hence “and you know my drift” refers to the previous four lines. The lines also show that he is an experienced drug dealer, hence ‘used to figures, dough and shit.’

annotations.text:
You a rooster nigga, just a roaster, bitch
 And I roast ya bitch
annotations.annotation:
You are a “rooster” (i.e. you’re a loser / you cooperate with the cops)
So I’m going to pick your girl up in my “roaster” (short for Ferarri Testarossa, as explained in the background: “TESTarossa!”)
And “roast” her (have sex, maybe kill)
Roaster (or heater, or burner) is a gun.

annotations.text: Go get their coochie cleansed
annotations.annotation: References to Cam'ron’s high standards for female hygiene are a theme in his raps; he has a skit on Killa Season where he kicks a Jamaican girl out of his hotel room because she refuses to wash up before sex

annotations.text:
We the moody Gucci, Louis and Pucci men
 Escada, Prada
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron’s favorite European designers! (The reference to the AK-47 in the next line serve to remasculate after this departure)

annotations.text: The chopper it got the Uzi lens
annotations.annotation: A “chopper” is an AK-47, and “Uzi lens” is a gun scope.

annotations.text:
Bird's-eye view
 The birds I knew flip birds
 Bird gangs, it was birds I flew
annotations.annotation:
Plays on birds are frequent in Cam'ron songs. Both here and elsewhere, “bird” can mean:


His view from his Uzi gun scope (“bird’s-eye view”)
A house in the hills (“bird’s-eye view”)
Girls (like when British people say it)
A kilo of coke (“flip birds” = sell drugs)
The Diplomats aka the “bird gang” (Cam'ron’s posse’s symbol is a bejeweled eagle)
A Ford Thunderbird automobile
Flip birds could also mean giving the middle finger

annotations.text:
I would serve on stoops
 Now swerve in coupes
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron used to sell drugs in the hood, but now he drives around in fast cars (presumably still selling drugs)

"I suggest you call my lawyer, I know the procedure."
Lock my body, can't trap my mind

I'd rather die enormous than live dormant, that's how we on it

This way no Fraud Willies present gamblin' they re-up

Ge-ge-ge-yeahhh

My mind is infested with sick thoughts that circle
Like a Lexus, if driven wrong it's sure to hurt you

True this, the streets school us to spend our money foolish
Bond with jewelers and watch for intruders

"Let's do this," it gets tedious
So I keep one eye open like CBS — you see me stressed, right?

[Chorus]
Can I live?
Can I live?
Can I live?
Can I live?

annotations.text: [Produced by Irv Gotti]
annotations.annotation:
This classic track features a sample of Isaac Hayes‘ “The Look of Love.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0IzxHKI8PJE

Check out Hova and Irv Gotti speaking on the inspiration behind this track here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPAFgrSZhYQ

annotations.text:
Well, we hustle out of a sense of hopelessness
 Sort of a desperation
 Through that desperation, we become addicted
 Sort of like the fiends we accustomed to servin'
 But we feel we have nothin' to lose
 So, we offer you, well, we offer our lives, right?
 What do you bring to the table?
annotations.annotation:
Hopelessness and desperation is what you’re supposed to feel in poverty. The drive to escape that hopelessness is, for the hustler, the same thing that drives a drug addict to get high-a need to escape. So here, and in other rhymes, I’m identifying with addicts. An addict doubles down on his pain, and like the hustler feels death or jail couldn’t be much worse than the pain of poverty. So when we come to the table to gamble, it’s with our very lives.

—Jay-Z, Decoded

annotations.text: [Verse 1]
annotations.annotation:
This track was originally meant to be a collaboration between Jay, a member of the group Original Flavor, and Nas—but when producer Ski Beatz heard this first verse they gave the song to Hov to record by himself.

What happened was, I was doing that song with someone else, and they heard the first verse and they was like, ‘Man, you take that song. Finish it, 'cause it sounds like you got a lot more to say.’

annotations.text:
While I'm watchin' every nigga watchin' me closely
 My shit is butter for the bread, they wanna toast me
annotations.annotation:
This opening couplet is one of Jay’s most iconic, and has two possible meanings:


Drug dealer – his enemies are watching him, waiting for him to make a mistake. Since his drugs (“shit”) make him a lot of money (“butter for the bread”), they want to kill him (continuing the carbs metaphor – “toast” him). Jay subtly lets us know that he is on top of the drug game–he is aware that people are out to get him, and is keeping tabs on the people who are keeping tabs on him, effectively turning the hunter into the hunted.
Rapper – he’s on stage, his fans are watching him at a concert (or otherwise keeping track of his song releases). His music (“shit”) makes him money, and his fans want to “toast” (honour) him.



In Decoded he said:

In this line, I turn a noun, bread (meaning “money”) into a verb, toast (meaning “shoot”), which draws out the relationship between money and danger.

annotations.text:
I keep my head, both of them, where they supposed to be
 Hoes'll get you sidetracked, then clapped from close feet
annotations.annotation:
His brain and his penis, both of which could lead him down dangerous path’s if he keeps them unchecked.

Relationships are more complicated for those involved in the hustle: You never know if the girl you’re with isn’t just a decoy that your enemies use to get you into a vulnerable position (or may cause trouble for you because she was involved with another hustler before you that might catch feelings).

Jay has explored the topic regularly over the years, most notably in “D'Evils,” during the second verse when he uses an enemies girl to smoke him out and extract retribution.

Note the wordplay with “track” and “feet,” and “clapped,” all having roots in sport (running the track in front of an audience).

annotations.text: A brother gotta admire me from four fiends away
annotations.annotation:
From Decoded:

Sleeplessness, weariness, and adrenaline are symptoms of paranoia, of engaging in illegal activity in plain sight. “Four fiends away” indicates the distance between me and the street-level action. The implication is that I’m a boss, to some degree buffered from low-level workers who can be easily urged to cooperate with authorities.

A similar situation was described in “Coming of Age”:

life could be better
Like my man reclined in plush leather seats
He’s selling weight, I’m selling eight balls

Memphis Bleek is explaining this exact line, but from a different perspective. He’s the the “brother” admiring Jay from four fiends away.

annotations.text:
My pain, wish it was quick to see
 From sellin' 'caine 'til brains was fried to a fricassee
annotations.annotation:
A “fricassee” is a meal of diced or minced meat. Outwardly, Jay appears calm and at ease, but his brain is turned to mush from the anxiety and paranoia he experiences daily in his chosen profession.

It’s another example of Jay equating selling drugs to taking them. The way drugs scramble a fiends brains is equal to that of the stress a hustler deals with.

“Fried to a fricassee” may have inspired this Cam'ron line.



A better tasting fricassee

annotations.text:
Can't lie, at the time it never bothered me
 At the bar, gettin' my thug on properly
 My squad and me lack of respect for authority
 Laughin' hard, happy to be escapin' poverty, however brief
annotations.annotation:
This is a time to look back, to reminisce on his earlier days. The thrill was more important than the pain. As he said in Decoded:

The rewards – the money, the girls, the excitement… I wanted to tell stories and boast, to entertain and to dazzle… Balled ridiculously in Vegas, I went dead broke and got hood rich on those streets.

Jay’s “squad” was his drug-dealing crew, and the key is “escaping poverty.” During “Money, Cash, Hoes” he explained:

Yea I rap now, fast money, dun slowed up

The fast money on the streets is just that: fast. It comes and it goes, but when you’re living in the moment and not worrying about the consequences it can be beautiful.

annotations.text: I know this game got valleys and peaks
annotations.annotation:
Another example of Jay’s premise on Reasonable Doubt, to explain both the good and the bad (or the gift and the curse) of selling drugs. It can also be flipped into commentary on the drug game, and you could argue Jay was in one of his only valleys when he released this record.

As Jay said on “Dead Presidents”:

I’m here to tell n—s it ain’t all swell
There’s heaven, and then there’s hell n—s
One day you’re cruising in your 7, next day you’re sweating, forgetting your lies

annotations.text:
Expectation for dips, for precipitation we stack chips, hardly
 The youth I used to be, soon to see a mill'in
annotations.annotation:
This may be directly influenced by a story Jay told in Decoded (page 90):

One day at the end of school I got arrested by the school cop for trespassing; I had crack in my pockets, but since it was my first arrest and I had no prior offenses, they released me on my own recognizance. But the damage was done – They confiscated the work I was holding. Suddenly we were in a hole… When we got back, we worked even harder, determined to never be in a position where a loss would set us that far back.

He also addresses it in “A Week Ago”:

Told you put away some cheddar now you crying for bail
Seventeen and I’m holding on to around a mill
I could bail out and blow trial and come around on appeal

annotations.text:
No more Big Willie, my game has grown
 Prefer you call me William
annotations.annotation:
Willies wanna rub shoulders, your money’s too young
See me when it gets older, ya bank account grow up

“Big Willie” is slang for a street cat who is making big money and living large. Jay feels he has outgrown this group of people he once admired, as he has graduated from making his money through illegal drug dealing to becoming a legitimate businessman.

From wanting to be a “Big Willie,”



To becoming “William:”

annotations.text:
Illin' for revenues, Rayful Edmond-like
 Channel 7 News,
annotations.annotation:
Rayful Edmond is the notorious drug dealer who introduced crack into the D.C. area in the ‘80s.



In Decoded Jay notes that Edmond once appeared on the news getting out of his own helicopter.

In an interview with Juan Epstein, {TIMESTAMP NEEDED} engineer Young Guru said that this reference was what intrigued him enough to start his collaborative relationship with Jay Z.

annotations.text: Round seven jewels,
annotations.annotation:
In Jay-Z’s book, Decoded  he cites this line as “round seven jewels.” (page 106).

Jewels also makes sense because at the time, Rayful Edmond was the face of hustlers' wealth and street bourgeois.

annotations.text:
Head dead in the mic
 Forgettin' all I ever knew, convenient amnesia
 "I suggest you call my lawyer, I know the procedure."
annotations.annotation:
He is conveniently feigning amnesia, telling the police that “he doesn’t remember” in response to questioning about his drug business

By asking for his lawyer, he is also invoking his 5th Amendment Miranda rights, which demonstrates his familiarity with criminal procedure.

At the time, Jay’s lawyer was none other than Combat Jack, Reggie Ossé.

annotations.text: Lock my body, can't trap my mind
annotations.annotation:
There’s a triple meaning to this line. First, Jay speaks on being physically locked up in jail. He revisited this very line on his tribute to Emory Jones, “Do U Wanna Ride?”

They caught your body they can’t trap your mind
Keep your spirit alive read your books
Matter of fact, let me take you somewhere
Vibe with me, c'mon

It also refers to the crack game he’s stuck in. During his long nights selling drugs, he would right rhymes as a form of escapism, so even though he feels locked into the hustlers way of life, he’s still mentally free.

Finally, it refers to the poverty that project housing enforces upon it’s occupants. He also tackled this topic on “Do U Wanna Ride?”

You know why they call The Projects a project, because it’s a project!
An experiment, we’re in it, only as objects
And the object for us to explore our prospects
And sidestep cops on the way to the top – yes!
As kids we would daydream, sittin on our steps
Pointin at cars like yeah that’s our sex
Hustlers profits made our eyes stretch

annotations.text:
Easily explain why we adapt to crime
 I'd rather die enormous than live dormant, that's how we on it
annotations.annotation:
This line resonates deeply with my listeners. It’s a take on the “Live Free or Die Trying,” “Liberty or Death” spirit that’s woven into the fabric of what it means to be American. But it’s also about great ambition, and the alternative, which is stagnation. The risk is death, so the reward should have equal gravity, a life lived to the fullest.

— Jay-Z, in Decoded



Kendrick Lamar might have alluded to these lines on “M.A.A.D. City”:

We adapt to crime, pack a van with four guns at a time

annotations.text:
Live at the main event, I bet a trip to Maui on it
 Presidential suites my residential for the weekend
annotations.annotation:
He bet (I’m guessing the cash-equivalent of) a trip to Maui on the main event (of a boxing match)

“The main event” refers to the reward, the spoils, and literally, a fight in Vegas. But main event could mean life as much as it means a staged fight. Presidential suites is that Big Willy is grown up – call him William.
— Jay-Z, Decoded.

annotations.text: The NSX rental, don't be fooled, my game is mental
annotations.annotation:
The car he’s rented for his little weekend getaway is an Acura NSX (rice rocket – but impressive)



Driving rental cars is a recurring theme in raps about selling crack, since it was a smart way for dealers not to be tracked when moving around the city

The way “NSX” is pronounced also sounds like “in excess”, which is a clever play on the lavish lifestyle as a hustler Jay espouses on this track.

But he also advises his adversaries, or anyone else, not to be fooled- based on the flash that he shows; he is both substance and style.

annotations.text:
Viva Las Vegas, see ya later at the crap tables
 Meet me by the one that starts a G up
 This way no Fraud Willies present gamblin' they re-up
annotations.annotation:
During his Rap Radar Podcast episode, Kareem Burke shed some light on this line, explaining that the scene from the “Dead Presidents” video in which they’re playing monopoly features real money (“200 or something thousand dollars”),  and unopened bottles of Cristal to prove they were really living that life (no Fraud Willies present).



Biggs also explained this line was born during a trip to Vegas in 1995, saying that Emory Jones received his nickname “Vegas” at the craps table during the Tyson vs McNeely fight:

Probably around in about ’95 and we went to the first Tyson fight when he just came home from jail to fight McNeeley and that’s actually where the song “Can I Live”  came from. And that’s where Emory got his name Vegas, Vegas Jones, during that same trip. That’s where the line started getting a lot of notoriety at that time and Jay would put it in songs after that.



They stayed at the MGM Grand, the same hotel where the fight was held on August 19, 1995. Emory spent most of the week gambling; and at one point he was $20,000 up at the crap tables, meaning the whole trip became “free” for the Roc-A-Fella crew.

annotations.text: And we can have a pleasant time, sippin' margaritas
annotations.annotation: Between margaritas and Mai Tais, Jay is drinking plenty of cocktails!

annotations.text:
Can I live?
 Can I live?
annotations.annotation:
A simple question, but what’s the answer?

Throughout his whole life Jay has been hustling to make the money he needs to get out of the hood. He’s wondering if he can continue to live despite all of the stresses of life and seeing people get shot, overdose, and living in poverty every day.

Not only that, but all that money he made in the drug game was just for living off of, but the government is trying to take it away, why won’t they just leave him alone and let him live his life?

Well, it’s almost two decades later and it looks like the answer is yes, as Jay is living just fine:

annotations.text: [Verse 2]
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z has identified this verse as the last verse he ever wrote down, and the track’s producer suggests Nas nearly ended up with this verse.

As Hov told MTV:

What happened was, I was doing that song with someone else, and they heard the first verse and they was like, ‘Man, you take that song. Finish it, ’cause it sounds like you got a lot more to say,’ ” Jay explained in a lengthy interview in which he discussed lyrics and songwriting. “You know, that type of thing. So I just wanted to get it down quick, I didn’t want to keep going over it. It was like [the album’s] mastering time, so I just sat down in the booth and wrote that [verse].”

Per Irv Gotti in the August 2006 issue of XXL:

Jay actually wanted Nas on it. He just did one verse, and we was leavin' the second verse for Nas. But the Nas thing didn’t happen. So we came back in, and he did the second verse.

And here’s more, from MTV in 2007:


According to Irv Gotti, who produced the track, the song was supposed to be a collaboration between Jay and a member of the rap group Original Flavor. Gotti mentioned he believed Nas was also set to appear on the track. But after the OF member passed on the guest appearance, Jay got to work finishing the song.

From what I remember, he actually didn’t write the full verse,” Gotti wrote in an e-mail to MTV News. “But since the verse was so long, he wrote a few words down, and that made him remember the whole verse.

annotations.text: My mind is infested with sick thoughts that circle
annotations.annotation:
This is about the the interior of my mind. Constantly checking thoughts, separating what’s real from what’s fear and paranoia, what’s a part of the plan and what’s reckless. Before I learned the Law of Attraction I was aware of the power of my thoughts, staying focused, weeding out thoughts that sabotage.

Jay’s own explanation in Decoded.

annotations.text: Like a Lexus, if driven wrong it's sure to hurt you
annotations.annotation:
If a Lexus is driven wrong, it will hurt or kill you in its path. Much like Jay’s mind.



He is also referring to the circle that wraps around the “L” in the Lexus logo; the sick thoughts are the circle, wrapping around this Luxurious but dangerous Life (the L) that, if steered wrong, will lead to certain doom.

annotations.text: Platinum Rolex'd it
annotations.annotation:
A “Masterpiece.”

Following this line when Jay says “You guessed it, manifested in tangible goods”, he was referring to how the “atrocities” that he and his crew were committing were manifested in material (tangible goods,) such as platinum Rolexes..

annotations.text: We don't lease, we buy the whole car, as you should
annotations.annotation:
Hov officially retracted this advice in Decoded, writing:

Advising to buy a car rather than lease one speaks to my naïveté at the time. Cars lose value the minute they leave the lot.

In the August 2006 issue of XXL, Dame Dash says:

Biggs [Kareem Burke, fellow Roc-A-Fella co-owner with Jay and Dame] came up with that line, “We don’t lease, we buy the whole car.” It was like a collaboration. At the time, Jay was like the ambassador of our life, of our movement. He was the spokesperson for everything that we were doing.

Ask any accountant and they will tell you leasing is the way to go. It’s up to a 100% tax deductible right off especially if you lease through your business. In these days cars lose value so rapidly and only a small portion can be written off on buys. Obviously Jay-Z is explaining that he has illegal drug money so I doubt he pays much in taxes, but the real life Jay-Z could have leased the car instead and written it off through Roc-A-Fella records. Ended up with the tax write off and a new car in 3 years.

annotations.text:
My confederation, dead a nation
 Explode on detonation, overload the mind of a said patient
annotations.annotation:
On the surface, Jay merely comments on a dream that his drug crew is going to rise to the highest echelon of money in America, basically overthrowing the establishment and the stigma that black people don’t amount to anything.

However, when you look deeper, “confederation” alludes to the “Confederacy” in the Civil War, which like Jay’s crew tried to “dead a nation,” i.e. secede from the Union thus breaking up the country (incidentally, the Confederate States of America is a dead nation).  But the Confederacy was ultimately beaten by the Union.  And what’s more, it stood for a morally disgusting cause simply because it sustained the southern economy.

The Confederacy and Jay’s confederation are thus directly compared, forcing us to ask ourselves how similar or different they really are/were.

“explode!/On detonation” can also apply to the nation Jay’s crew is trying to overthrow, or to Jay’s mind which earlier in the verse is depicted as “infested with sick thoughts” and is “dual levels.”

Also note the world play on the homophonic ‘dead-a-nation’ and ‘detonation’, and also Jay’s masterful use of internal rhyme: ‘confederation’, ‘dead a nation’, ‘detonation’, ‘said patient’.

annotations.text:
When it boils to steam, it comes to it
 We all fiends, gotta do it: even righteous minds go through this
annotations.annotation:
Hov echo this sentiment on “Public Service,”  rapping:

Hope you don’t think users are the only abusers
Niggas getting high within the game

His explanation of that line in *Decoded is applicable here as well.

And it’s not just the material spoils that keep you going: You start getting addicted to the thrill of it, the adrenaline rush of going to see your connect in a small building in Harlem in a lobby that you’ve never been in, where you go in with a bag of money and come out with a bag of work. Or the feeling when you come around the corner back home and all eyes turn to you because everyone knows who you are — you represent something successful and free and dangerous, all at once. You have the best car, the best jewelry, the whole package. You taste a strange kind of fame. It’s as addictive as the shit you’re selling, and just as deadly.

—Jay-Z, Decoded (p31)



He is suggesting throughout the whole album how his own doubt about life, turned into a drive to succeed. Here he implies that even “righteous” minds go through doubt.

 Also, he could be saying that when you get fed up enough with your circumstances (growing up in the mean streets of NYC), that hustling is what it comes down to. The second line is saying while he isn’t the drug addict, he’s a fiend in his own right for money, and even righteous people get addicted to making dough.

annotations.text:
True this, the streets school us to spend our money foolish
 Bond with jewelers and watch for intruders
annotations.annotation:
Jay claims that black culture has been corrupted: people feel compelled to blow their money on frivolous purchases like expensive jewelry and feel the need to always be paranoid and wary of the other people in their community

If you notice he said “bond with jewelers” and “watch” as a piece of jewelry from the jeweler. Sly double entendre. Sick!

annotations.text:
I stepped it up another level, meditated like a Buddhist
 Recruited lieutenants with ludicrous dreams of gettin' cream
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z avoids the trap his neighborhood has set for him: instead of being bogged down in a self-defeating approach toward life, Jay-Z takes a breath – Ommmm – and tries to accumulate “cream” (wealth) with his like-minded employees

 The Buddhist reference is about stillness, a break from the spending and buying, a retreat to reveal jay’s ultimate goals.

The use of the term “cream” originates with the Wu-Tang classic from 3 years before RD.

annotations.text: So I keep one eye open like CBS — you see me stressed, right?
annotations.annotation:
Like the CBS logo:



(You see him stressed, right?)

Additionally, Jay might have used CBS as a homophone as a way to say “See BS”, which also ties in the next line where he says “You see me stressed right?” Jay is saying that since he is able to see through the lies and the mimicry, he is not going to stress out unlike other people.

Check out Hova and Irv Gotti speaking about this lyric here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPAFgrSZhYQ#t=115

annotations.annotation:

Throughout his whole life Jay has been hustling to make the money he needs to get out of the hood. He’s wondering if he can continue to live despite all of the stresses of life and seeing people get shot, overdose, and living in poverty every day.

Not only that, but all that money he made in the drug game was just for living off of, but the government is trying to take it away, why won’t they just leave him alone and let him live his life?

Well, it’s almost two decades later and it looks like the answer is yes, as Jay is living just fine:

annotations.text: [Produced by Kanye West and Brian Miller]
annotations.annotation:
Although this track appeared at #16 on Complex’s list of top Ye beats produced for other artists, Ye stated that he didn’t make the beat – Brian Miller did. Regardless of who made the beat, though, it was a definite classic. Check out the sample used – William Bell and Mavis Staple’s “Strung Out.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fJYo--RxG2c#t=95

annotations.text: Kanye, this that 1970s Heron flow, huh?
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron is confirming with Kanye West, the song’s putative producer, that the sampled beat is an example of 1970s heroin influenced soul music.  The track from which the beat is sampled is titled “Strung Out”–a slang expression describing the psychoactive effects of heroin.  Hence Cam’s reference to the “heron flow.” (In his 1971 song “Lady Day and John Coltrane,” Gil Scott-Heron asks if you’re down and out and don’t know what to do.)

annotations.text:
Drinking sake on a Suzuki; we in Osaka Bay
 Playing soccer, stupid, stay in a sucker's place
annotations.annotation:
This extended alliteration results in absurd lyrics, although they still come together to form an evocative image of Cam'ron in Japan, playing some “futbol”, living in the lap of luxury, and fucking your girlfriend’s mouth (also an internal play on “sucker” meaning loser vs. suck-suck)

Killa keeps it so real, by not only indulging in the Japanese beverage but supporting Japanese motors and their travel industry.

annotations.text:
But got caught up with the juxes
 You would've thought I was from Brooklyn
annotations.annotation:
The Jooks were a crew from Brooklyn responsible for robberies. (cf. Biggie’s “Niggaz Bleed”)

Brooklyn is notoriously famous for robbery – “Manhattan keep on makin' it, Brooklyn keep on takin' it”

Cam'ron is all the way Uptown in Harlem, but if the price is right, he’ll take the Subway to the “BK Broiler”..

“Jux” is also slang for robbery.

annotations.text: Did like Bill Cosby, pouring in the pudding
annotations.annotation:
A reference to Bill Cosby’s ads in the 1980’s for Jello Pudding (“Pudding” also means money)



Cam'ron also frequently likens cooking drugs to baking pies and cakes; he was bored just watching other people make money, so he got into the drug business.

This also ties into the earlier Brooklyn reference. Brooklyn is the main setting of The Cosby Show, where the Huxtable family resides in a two-story brownstone at 10 Stigwood Avenue.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Kanye West & (Syleena Johnson)]
annotations.annotation:
On this hook, Kanye seems to be emulating Cam’s flow on “Get ‘Em Girls” in which he employs the same da-DUH-da-da-DUH-DUH meter and long oo sound rhymes (“I get boosters boosting/I get computer’s 'puting”).
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2m2K0CD0UQI

annotations.text:
I treat bitches straight up, like Simon Says
 Open vagina; put your legs behind your head
annotations.annotation:
Simon Says is a children’s game for three or more players. One player takes the role of “Simon” and issues instructions to the other players, which should be followed only when prefaced with the phrase “Simon says”.
However,Cam uses this for sex

annotations.text:
You got pets? Me too: mines are dead, doggy
 Fox, minks, gators, that's necessary
 Accessories, my closet's Pet Sematary
 I get approached by animal activists
annotations.annotation:
Reference to the classic Stephen King novel as Cam'ron lists the dead animals he’s got in his closet (as items of clothing)



Anything buried in the “Pet Sematary” comes back a little “different” than before, too; Camron’s wardrobe diverged wildly from the norm at the time this song was written.

annotations.text: I live in a zoo,
annotations.annotation:
Since his closet is nothing but animal hide, that basically makes his house a zoo.



This jacket alone broke 5 anti-poaching laws.

Living in a zoo could also refer to people acting like savages. Animals do what they can to survive, same with humans. New York City aka Concrete Jungle.

annotations.text:
I go to war, old Timbs, battered boots
 Hand grenade, goggles and a parachute
annotations.annotation: “Go to war” is a banality that rappers throw around; here, Cam takes it literally and goes off on a list of WWII soldier gear

annotations.annotation:
A reference to R&B singer Case’s song “Touch Me, Tease Me”; the song is old, so he’s saying that girls were “touching [him] and teasing [him]” since long ago, when that song was popular.

annotations.text:
Harlem shake? Nah, I'm in Harlem shaking the weight
 Shaking to bake, shaking the Jakes
 Kill you, shoot the funeral up and Harlem Shake at your wake
annotations.annotation:
The “Harlem Shake” is a dance. But Cam'ron is not dancing; he is in Harlem, shaking nervous in a cold sweat because he’s worried about his crack deals and “shaking” (avoiding) the “Jakes” (cops)…once he kills you and shoots up your funeral, then he can do the dance

“Shaking to bake” (means “itching to get back to the stove and cook more crack!”) is a slight allusion to popular bread-crumb coating Shake ‘n Bake

Harlem Shake demo:

annotations.text:
Just your picture, though; you still taped in a lake
 I'm laughing;
annotations.annotation:
There’s an empty casket at the wake since they couldn’t find the body, so only a picture is present to represent the deceased.
Meanwhile, Cam knows where the body is since he duct taped the guy’s mouth then threw the body in a lake (does little dance)

Similar theme in Jay-Z’s 22 Two’s:

At your wake as I peek in
Look in your casket feeling sarcastic
“Look at him, still sleepin”

annotations.text: [Chorus: Kanye West & (Syleena Johnson)]
annotations.annotation:
On this hook, Kanye seems to be emulating Cam’s flow on “Get ‘Em Girls” in which he employs the same da-DUH-da-da-DUH-DUH meter and long oo sound rhymes (“I get boosters boosting/I get computer’s 'puting”).
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2m2K0CD0UQI

annotations.text:

annotations.annotation: Cam is giving a shout out to the midwest as well as mentioning some cities located in that area that have been inhabited by popular rappers. These cities include Detroit, Indianapolis (often referred to as “Naptown”), St. Louis, and, of course, Chicago.

annotations.text:
You know what else I do:
 Dayton, Youngstown, Cleveland, Cincinnati
annotations.annotation:
4 Ohio cities where Cam'ron claims he supplied coke from his perch on the East Coast (one of several shoutouts to his “adopted home”)

Peep it on the Rap Map

He also used this line from Bout It Bout It Part 3 feat Master P.

annotations.text: [Intro]
annotations.annotation:
This intro is based off it’s prequel, “Walk In” from Tha Carter, which starts:

Yeah yeah yeah it’s the Carter motherfucker I came back around
It’s the Carter motherfucker I came back around
It’s the Carter motherfucker
Let me show you my building man, it’s the Carter
I'mma show y'all the ins the outs, the ups the down, know what I’m talking ‘bout
This is me, fourth solo album baby, I came back around

The concept of welcoming everyone into his “house” was inspired by the gangster movie New Jack City, where they ran a crack house called “The Carter.”

annotations.text:
So they ask me
 "Young boy
 What you gon' do the second time around?
 How you gon' come back?"
 I tried told 'em
 "I come back like 32
 I jump back like 33"

annotations.annotation:
After Tha Carter sold over a million copies, you may be wondering if Wayne can match the success. He did! Tha Carter II sold over 2 million copies!

Magic Johnson (jersey #32) famously came back to the NBA in 1992 after testing positive for HIV in 1991 and retiring. Larry Bird (jersey #33) is known for his legendary fadeaway shot. Magic and Larry—Larry part of the Celtics, and Magic on the Lakers—were historic rivals.

Welcome to Tha Carter II !

annotations.text:
They call me Mr. Carter, I kissed the daughter
 Of the dead's forehead, I killed the father
annotations.annotation: Wayne kicks off the track with an interesting chain of events.  The first line makes it sound like he’s just giving a girl a kiss.  However, in the second line we find out that the girl’s father is dead…and Wayne’s actually the one who killed her father.  These first two lines introduce listeners to the gangster side of Weezy and set the tone for the album.

annotations.text:
Spilled the heart of a mildew hater
 I will put them body on chill like glaciers
annotations.annotation:
“Mildew hater” seems to imply that his victim was quite crisp and clean – a boss of some sort perhaps

When you kill someone, you “put the body on chill” since the corpse turns cold – similar to “icing someone”

annotations.text: I'm crazy, yes, it's obvious
annotations.annotation:
It’s no secret that Wayne maybe on the crazy side, his mother has always told him this, and even he himself knows.

Wayne embraces his insanity however, and uses it to his creative advantage.

annotations.text: Going against me is atheist
annotations.annotation:
Double Entendre


Wayne is calling himself the god of rap, therefore if you defy him or go against him, it’s like not believing in god and going against scriptural principles like an atheist.
It is a common belief to many Christians that atheists will go to hell and have no hope. Wayne has even expressed this notion before. Therefore, any rapper that goes against Wayne will receive hell and will have no hope for survival if they try Wayne.



Regardless of which interpretation you go with, one thing is for sure, Wayne is extremely confident that he is an immense rapper who can’t be competed against.

annotations.text: I got my angels on my shoulder
annotations.annotation:
In contrast to the previous line, “Going against me is Atheist”, he feels safe through the violent and drug related hardships of living in the hood, because of the Angels on his shoulders. Guardian angels are often thought of as family and /or friends, living or dead, that are watching your back on God’s behalf.

Also used as a defense mechanism against the stress of danger. Leaving his wellbeing in God’s hands, he is watched over by angels.

annotations.text: And a quarter of that angel dust
annotations.annotation:
PCP in powder form, sprinkled on weed, mint, or basil leaves then smoked, leading to unpredictable results – some people act mellow, and others act crazy.

For example, Rapper Big Lurch murdered an acquaintance and ate her lungs while on PCP

annotations.text: You ain't tryna see how far that black back lane go, no
annotations.annotation:
He’s making a threat to defend himself: “you don’t want to test the dark dangerous black alleys in the hood, or in Lil Wayne’s mind”

Interestingly enough, the term “backlane” is used primarily to describe streets in medieval villages

annotations.text: Call me Pac-Man, your ghost is blue
annotations.annotation:
In the video game Pac-Man, when Pac-Man eats a power pellet, the ghosts that normally chase and kill him turn blue for a period of time during which Pac-Man can kill them instead.

So he’s saying that he’s coming after you, like this:



This is a play on the gang he represents – Bloods. Since Crips (who wear the color blue) are their opposition, he’d leave them dead, therefore their ghosts would be blue.

annotations.text: I got my Red River rubies and my ocean blue jewelry
annotations.annotation:
In this part of the verse Wayne is using some clever word play. Not only is he showing love for his native southern roots, he is also flaunting over you, his outrageous wealth he’s earned from rapping. By using geographic marks that the south is known for to describe his expensive taste in colorful jewelry.



Red River Rubies – The Red River is the river known for dividing Texas and Oklahoma. The river then flows through Louisiana and into the lower Mississippi River.
http://youtu.be/VQxTIybKnI4

Ocean Blue Jewelry – Wayne’s home state of Louisiana lies on America’s southern coast against the Gulf of Mexico.

This isn’t the only time Weezy uses colorful descriptions to talk about his jewels, in ‘I’m Blooded’ he has a pretty sweet line.

annotations.text: I'm so 504, you got to kill me here
annotations.annotation: 504 is the area code of Hollygrove, New Orleans, Lil Wayne’s home town.

annotations.text: If you ever looking for me, bitch, I will be here
annotations.annotation:
Wayne will never abandon his hometown, so if you’re looking for him, you know where to find him.

Even after becoming famous, Wayne goes back to his own neighborhood every now and then; most notably to help out with rebuilding the city after Hurricane Katrina.

He also shot his recent music video for the song God Bless Amerika in his old neighborhood.

annotations.text: Cash Money is an army, Navy Seal me here
annotations.annotation: In 1999 fellow Cash Money rapper BG released the song “Cash Money is an Army”.

annotations.text: Crack the Phil', crack the roof, and roll up the windows
annotations.annotation:
Cracking a “Phil” (Philly cigar) in order to replace the tobacco with weed and make a blunt.

After rolling the blunt, he ventilates his car by cracking the sunroof, but he rolls up the (presumably tinted) windows for privacy.

annotations.text:
And my hood love me, they tell me bring it home
 That's why I holler Hollygrove on each and every song
annotations.annotation:
Wayne’s hood Hollygrove loves him for making it big and his friends and family from there supported him since day one; therefore it’s only right that Wayne represents them whenever he can.

He even payed homage to his hometown by shooting his recent music video for his song God Bless Amerika in his old neighborhood.

annotations.text:
You leaping at a dog, a dog with no bark
 Just a bite like an old shark
annotations.annotation:
On a run using animals to convey his thought, Wayne hints like he’s gonna go in with a “You feelin froggy, then leap.” type of line. This is a common expression saying that unless you act, your thoughts don’t mean jack.

There is a similar expression, A Barking Dog never Bites. This is literal and figurative. Literally, if a dog is barking his mouth is too busy to bite you, or he isn’t going to attack but just try to scare you off. Figuratively it is a lot like the frog line. You can bark (talk) all you want but don’t make a difference until you act (bite).

He then changed direction, he’s a dawg. A real n*gga from the streets. A literal frog wouldn’t stand a chance going against a dog.

Wayne doesn’t bark on the streets because talk is worthless, he bites, acts, shoots, jumps, etc.. Not just a little dog bite though, a bite like a old shark.

annotations.text: And all you rich niggas know Pa, I'm talking 'bout Stunna
annotations.annotation:
Wayne is referring to Birdman here. “5 Star Stunna” is one of his nicknames, and since Wayne looks up to him as a father figure, he refers to Baby as his “Pa”.



With a new worth of over $170 million and being a well-known CEO and businessman, Birdman sure does know all the richest people in the industry.

annotations.text:
No homo (Young Mula, baby!)
 I say, he's so sweet, make her wanna lick the wrapper
annotations.annotation:
The central motif; there are a few things going on:


You lick the wrapper after enjoying a particularly delicious treat (e.g., a lollipop or a stick of gum)
The “wrapper” / “rapper” double meaning
“Wrapper” is slang for condom



A triple entendre.

annotations.text: Lollipop, lollipop, breastses just like Dolly Parton
annotations.annotation:
Kanye starts his verse with “lollipop, lollipop”, an homage to the “Lollipop” by The Chordettes whose chorus also begins with these two words.

Yeezy introduces this gold-digging girl by comparing her tits to those of world-renowned country star Dolly Parton.

annotations.text: She ride my spaceship 'til she hit the top
annotations.annotation:
Continuing with the phallic symbolism, Kanye says the girl rides his “spaceship” (dick) till she “hits the top/goes to space” (achieves orgasm). That’s very Freudian of you Yeezy.

And of course Kanye also has a song called “Spaceship”.

annotations.text:
That hit the spot
 'Til she ask, "How many li-i-li-i-licks do it take" 'til she get to shop?
annotations.annotation:
Kanye was having a good time until the girl revealed she was only blowing him so that he’d spend money on her. He seems to have an affinity for the subject of gold-diggers. This is also a reference to the classic advertisement for Tootsie-Pops that asked “how many licks does it take to get to the tootsie-roll center of a tootsie-pop?”
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LZ0epRjfGLw

annotations.text: Don't worry why my wrists got so freeze
annotations.annotation: Yeezy tells this girl to stop worrying about his wealth and continue having sex with him without expecting anything in return. His wrists are “freeze” because they are covered with so much “ice” (slang for jewelry).

annotations.text: Tell a girl, "Like Doritos, that's not 'cho cheese"
annotations.annotation: Nacho Cheese is a flavor of Doritos. But Yeezy wants this girl to know that his “cheese” (money) is not for her. “Nacho cheese” can be heard as “not yo cheese”, which explains the Doritos reference

annotations.text:
Tell her friends, "Like Fritos, I'm tryin' to lay"
 I can't only have one, and I ain't trying to wait
annotations.annotation:
More chips based wordplay. Ye plays on the name of the brand Frito-Lay, as “lay” can also mean to have sex with.

Frito-Lay is known for their “Bet you can’t eat just one” ad campaign. Like the chips, Kanye doesn’t want to sleep with just one woman.

annotations.text: This a song with Wayne, so you know it's gon' melt
annotations.annotation: Ye plays on the literal meaning of the word hot here. In the sense of the rap game, hot means successful and popular. Both Wayne and Kanye were really hot back when this song came out. But literally, hot means of high temperature and able to melt things.

annotations.text: But you ain't finna murder me like everybody else
annotations.annotation:
There was a perception for a while that Kanye usually got outshone when he was on a track with another rapper. And Lil Wayne was killing most of his collaborations at the time this song came out. So Kanye knows that he had to bring the heat for this verse or risk getting shown up once again. “Finna” is short for “fixing to”; which basically just means “going to”.

Should also be noted that Kanye and Wayne have performed together 7 times (this song, Barry Bonds, See You In My Nightmares, Maybach Music II, Swagga Like Us, Forever and the All Of The Lights (Remix). And discounting one song which Kanye wasn’t actually on (the remix to his All of the Lights), Kanye has held his own against Wayne every time. It’s also interesting to note that this is the only time Wayne features Kanye, as opposed to the other way around or them both featuring with someone else.

annotations.text: I don't do it for my health, man, I do it for the belt
annotations.annotation: Kanye is only concerned with being the best; that’s why he raps. The “belt” is a reference to the WWE belt that is given to the heavy weight champion each year.

annotations.text: Man, I do it to the death, 'til the roof get melt
annotations.annotation: Many scientists speculate that the end of the world will come when our atmosphere dissipates, and the sun’s rays will shine down on the planet harder than ever, making it impossible for the planet to sustain life after a short time. Thus, this line means that Kanye will be rapping until the end of time, when the planet’s temperature is too hot for life (‘til the roof get melt is just an example of what life will be like during this scenario)

annotations.text: Man, the flow so cold, chicken soup won't help
annotations.annotation: Chicken soup is a traditional cold remedy. But Kanye’s flow is so “cold” (tough, menacing) that chicken soup isn’t going to be enough.

annotations.text: We balling too serious, and you out of bounds
annotations.annotation:
“Ballin” means being successful; it’s a basketball metaphor

Here, Kayne is painting an image of himself and Weezy sitting – just hardly out of bounds – in “baller” courtside seats

annotations.text: You're now fucking with the best in the world
annotations.annotation: With one of the most consistent discographies in music, along with a string of Grammys, along with a thousand other awards and a shitload of money ($100 million to be exact), Kanye is one of the only artists with the right to this claim.

annotations.text:

 Your lovely lady lumps, lumps, lumps (Shawty wanna)

 And she gonna lick the rapper

annotations.text: I Anita-bake her; now, she caught up in that "Rapture"
annotations.annotation:
Anita Baker is an R&B artist; one of her most famous songs is called “Caught Up in the Rapture”

“Anita Bake-her” is a play on her name, meaning he makes her smoke weed (a plant which makes us feel rapturous)

annotations.text: I got so much chips, I swear, they call me "Hewlett Packard"
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne is so rich that people might call him by the multinational computer manufacturer.
He’s comparing himself with the company because they make chips (ex: motherboards) and chips is also another word for “money”.

annotations.text: I got so much chips, you can have a bag if you're a snacker
annotations.annotation:
Chips as money and snack food

This follows nicely after Kanye’s references to Doritos and Frito Lays

annotations.text: Greedy mother-fudge cake; now, tell me how that fudge tastes
annotations.annotation:
Could be a diss: “Greedy mother fudge-cake (5th grader diss), tell me how my ass tastes!”

Or a brag: “I’m a Hedonistic bon vivant, greedy for life – and also quite the foodie! – would you like to have a taste of this flourless German chocolate cake?”

This line most likely inspired Shaquille O'Neal’s 2008 invitation to Kobe Bryant to taste his Shaq-ass

annotations.text: I do it for Bloods' sake—soo-woo!
annotations.annotation:
Kanye raps “for the belt”, Wayne raps “for bloods' sake,” which is a double entendre meaning


That it’s in his nature, and
That he raps on behalf of The Bloods, a gang that he is affiliated with

annotations.text: Think it's voodoo how that roof do di-di-dissipate
annotations.annotation:
“Soo-woo” is a call used by members of the Bloods to express their affiliation. It is also used to warn people that the police are coming (the term may have originated as onomatopoeia for a siren)

Lately Wayne has been repping the Bloods hard; he even has “soo-woo” tatooed on his neck



Usually Wayne uses the term as a general reference to Bloods. For example on the hook of the song “I’m Blooded” he raps:

And I’m blooded soowoo and I’m blooded soowoo
I got bloods on stage bloods at my shows
Fuck with my bloods got blood on your clothes
And I’m blooded soooowooo

Soo-woo could also mean “cop”: the cops think it’s magic when his convertible top disappears (when it retracts). The cops are so stupid / beneath Wayne that they can’t even figure out how his convertible roof works, let alone catch him

This line also parallels Kanye’s line about retracting the roof of his convertible (above)

Unfortunately Lil Wayne is too busy (having sex with other girls, etc) to have the time for her (i.e., get in line, ladies!)

annotations.annotation:
You don’t want to get a text message from your girl telling you her period’s late (i.e., she’s potentially pregnant).  So wear a condom (“latex”)!



Also, it’s hard not to notice Wayne’s amazing wordplay skills: latex, late text, and “I think I’m late” text. The last use of the homophone could even double for “I think I’m late, Tex.”

annotations.text: Haha! So wrap it up!
annotations.annotation:
This Public Service Announcement brought to you by: Lil Wayne

It’s another play on words.


Telling us that the end (of the verse) is nigh. It’s time to wrap up.
“Wrap it up” is a figure of speech that means “wear a condom,” following up from the previous few lines about safe sex.
The second meaning above is even more relevant as an extension of the lollipop metaphor.

annotations.text: Bu-Bu-But he's so sweet, sh-she wanna lick the wrapper
annotations.annotation:
#TRIPLE ENTENDRE ALERT:

I. She wants to lick the “wrapper”. Lollipops are sweet and come in wrappers.



II. She wants to lick Wayne’s wrapper AKA condom. Which ties into the previous lines about safe sex and “wrapping it up”

III. He’s so sweet that she wants to lick the “rapper” (That’s a homophone, kids) AKA Wayne himself.

 Your lovely lady lumps, lumps, lumps (Shawty wanna)

annotations.text:
To break the fiends fixes, one give you the sniffles
 The other leave you with the itches
annotations.annotation: Cocaine causes sniffles, while heroin causes itches. Pusha T sells both.

annotations.text:
Whoever said birds fly south for the winter's a damn lie
 Got 'em right here, and if I don't like you, the grams hide
annotations.annotation: “Birds” is slang for a kilo of cocaine, which Jadakiss sells during the wintertime.

annotations.text:
When you broke but they think you got money
 Crackers start showin' you love, your own people act funny
annotations.annotation:
Jadakiss has the worst of both worlds: everyone treats him as if he has money and look to him for handouts or treat him as though he’s changed.   But, although he has the problems associated with having money, he doesn’t even have any money!

Jadakiss has often complained about not having as money as he should.  As a member of the Lox he was so unhappy with his deal with Bad Boy Records the the group started a “Free The Lox” movement with its own merchandise to try to pressure Puff Daddy to release them from their contract.

On I’m Going Back he says, in reference to people with plaques indicating their record sales,

“I ain’t hating on the people who got them [plaques], I got a lot of them, but I ain’t got the money they got”

annotations.text:
Nigga, that's funny, you say you a killer, how?
 What is it, the return of the killer clowns?
annotations.annotation: The killer clown was a serial killer who died in 1994.  Roscoe’s target for this line is a complete clown, so he’s a bit confused when he hears that the guy is claiming to be a killer.

annotations.text:
Deepest regret and sympathy to the streets
 I seen 'em pay for they fix when they kids couldn't eat (So sorry)
 And with this in mind, I still didn't quit
 And that's how I know that I ain't shit (I ain't shit)
annotations.annotation:
Malice reflects on his drug-dealing experiences, giving an example of parents paying to fulfill their drug addiction, rather than buy their kids food, which is obviously the more important priority.

Malice goes in depth about this same, exact example in the CNN Clipse Interview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d2Eh-oUMkYM

Malice was aware of events like this and he continued to serve drugs to his community. With that, he openly admitted that he “wasn’t shit” (cold-blooded and heartless) being that he continued to sell drugs knowing that there are kids that are starving as a result of these transactions.

annotations.text: Man I spit that pimp talk, you hang out where the pimps collide
annotations.annotation: A classic example of the “me (this) / you (that)” dichotomy in rap: while Cam’s verbally slick as a pimp with the ladies, the arbitrary “you"s of the rap world are left surrounded by dudes.

annotations.text: It's a pimp in my ride, no need to pimp the ride
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron is a pimp and has a nice car, so he doesn’t feel the macho need to slap on custom rims and other ameliorative waste favored by Xzibit on his TV show Pimp My Ride.

annotations.text:
This ain't the pimp camp: pimp limp, pimp stance
 Pimp-slap a slim tramp, order steak, shrimp scamp
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron is a pimp and must do pimp-like things, but he is also classy enough to go to restaurants and order fine foods like shrimp scampi

annotations.text: Ok-k-kay, you g-g-gay
annotations.annotation: Lil Scrappy’s go to line, “Ok-k-kay”

annotations.text: I'll soufflé ya toupée
annotations.annotation: I will bring heat to your head, i.e. I will shoot you in the head

annotations.text: Unload the click-clack to ya fit cap
annotations.annotation:
Cam'ron will shoot you in the head! click, clack, click, clack goes the gun

“Fit cap” is a fitted baseball cap:

annotations.text: Hold the shit back, say goodbye and go commit that
annotations.annotation: Cam is referring to murder: say goodbye to your friends and family, and commit murder or be murdered

annotations.text:
For 9 years in Spain had the time share
 Back to Times Square...I got dimes here
annotations.annotation: After laying low in Spain for 9 years, Cam'ron returns to New York (“hey! nice tan!”) to run attractive women (“dimes”) for money (Times Square was prostitute central before Adolph Giuliani cracked down and turned it into a soulless corporate tourist marketing shithole)

annotations.text: By the Port Authority, but I got more authority
annotations.annotation:
Cam has “more authority” than the New York City Port Authority because he decides what drugs to ship

The Port Authority is about two blocks west of Times Square, a big prostitution hub

annotations.text:
From the back of the cop-ride
 To black-on-black, black when we cop rides
annotations.annotation:
I used to sit in the back of cop cars (i.e., get arrested), now I put on all black clothing and steal cars

Alternatively, this could mean “as soon as I’m out of the cop’s car (released from police custody) I immediately put on all black clothes and steal a car”

Also, copping a car can mean just owning or buying one, so he could be saying he owns black-on-black “murdered out” cars (cars with black rims, black tints, and black paint)

The “cop ride” / “cop rides” wordplay here is classic Cam

Also, “black-on-black” refers to the phenomenon of “black-on-black crime”

annotations.text: From whippin' the bacon rolls to outside whippin' the bacon Rolls
annotations.annotation:
Cam'ron has come a long way: from eating bacon rolls (cheap calories) to riding in a Rolls Royce the color of bacon

Cam has used foods to describe the color of luxury items before:


Range Rover as Laffy Taffy
G2 jet as beef stew



The second “bacon” could also be bakin' as in “awesome” or “a place where weed gets smoked”

Or, rolls (in either case) could be ecstacy Cam was selling

Either way, this line inspired the creation of Rap Genius.

annotations.text: Sanaa Lathan knows, I'm rakin' but makin' dough
annotations.annotation: When Cam'ron gets hungry, he just tears through those bacon rolls. He also annihilates luxury cars by driving them too fast. Moreover, he’s quite a “rake” (British term meaning “pimp”). Finally, he’s making cash-money (“Raking in the dough”/“Making dough” etc.)

annotations.text: 80 holes in your shirt, there: your own Jamaican clothes
annotations.annotation:
Jamaicans often wear mesh tank tops with a lot of little holes in them



When Cam'ron shoots you 80 times, you’ll have 80 holes in your shirt, and – voilà! – now you have a Jamaican shirt

This is the line that inspired Rap Genius…

And this is the line that inspired Cam…

annotations.text: I ain't talkin' the Poconos, I'm talkin' the Aspens, to slopes we go
annotations.annotation: Cam takes expensive vacations, not Poconos-style insurance salesman family weekend retreats

annotations.text: You get the "okey doke", play me, baby I hope he know
annotations.annotation: He’s telling his girl to go ahead and make the transaction, and if the guy on the other end tries to con Cam, then Cam hopes the guy knows that there will be consequences.

annotations.text:
We break noses, call him baby Pinocchio
 (Fuckin' liar)
annotations.annotation: Pinocchio’s nose grows when he tells a lie

annotations.text: 1 house, 2 kitchens...who's bitchin'?
annotations.annotation:
One kitchen for cooking food…and one for cooking crack!!!

Also, Cam ain’t complainin'; his house is big and fancy enough to have 2 kitchens. I’m sure you’ve seen this kind of house, very upper-middle classy

annotations.text: I bring the diesel, won't see the Fu-Schnickens
annotations.annotation:
Fu-Schnickens (“for unity coalition”) is rap trio from East Flatbush, Brooklyn that had a large cult fan base in the early 1990s. Their verbal dexterity and goofy imagery was a precursor to that in the better-known work by the Wu-Tang Clan. Cam “won’t see the Fu-Schnickens” because – being a supplier to dealers – he doesn’t hang around the goofy petty-crack dealers that inspired the Fu-Schnickens' style

Basketball player Shaquille O'Neal – aka Shaq Diesel, aka “Shaq Fu” (as in “-Schnickens”) – did a rabbity song with the group called What’s up Doc (Can we rock?)

“Diesel” is also an adjective that can refer to a variety of drugs; it means “good”

annotations.text:
(And I don't trust a hoe)
 That's mother to baby-mother
annotations.annotation: Alternatively, if you’re one of Cam’s baby mamas, how could he possibly have faith in the person who raised you to end up with (admittedly nefarious) Kila?

annotations.text: Tell her drink, come get drunk, it's nut cracker
annotations.annotation:
Come/cum situation here; on the one hand he’s telling the girl “Hey babe, have a drink, come get drunk”

But if you were to switch the comma to “Tell her ‘drink cum, get drunk, it’s nut cracker’” we’re talking a major semantic shift

annotations.text: Rell home
annotations.annotation: Hell Rell, member of Dipset, has come home from prison

annotations.text: Call the network, Dipset, Family Ties
annotations.annotation: An allusion to the NBC network show Family Ties.

annotations.text: They see me in that lavender tank, you'd rather just faint
annotations.annotation: Although Cam is mainly known for popularizing pink – no homo – he is also a fan of a variety of purples (by “tank” he means “SUV”)

annotations.text: I was Fort Laudi, you was Saint Latter-Day Saints
annotations.annotation:
I was in Fort Lauderdale selling drugs while you were off in some other city doing innocent activities, akin to going to the Church of Latter Day Saints

‘Laudi’ (Lord) is also trumping ‘Saints’ here.

annotations.text: Whips get lathered in paint
annotations.annotation: Cam paints all of his cars in gaudy colors

annotations.text:
And I'm appalled think that we at all comfortable
 Me in Mauris
annotations.annotation:
Mauri is Cam'ron’s favorite Italian shoemaker

Here, he emphasizes that his Mauris were made for walking (Cam cannot countenance resting on one’s laurels)

annotations.text:
These rappers all Theodore Huxtable
 They mother's a lawyer, they father's a doctor
annotations.annotation:
Theodore Huxtable was the older son on The Cosby Show. Claire Huxtable, the mother, was a lawyer. Cliff Huxtable, the father played by Bill Cosby, was a doctor



Cam'ron is saying that other rappers are faux-thugs and not really from the streets

annotations.text: Get hung from the rosaries
annotations.annotation: To Cam, a rosary apparently resembles a noose. Some Roman Catholics will offer novenas (a prayer of 9 complete rosaries) in memoriam of a loved one who has died

annotations.text: Call me "C.O.D." - that's coke and them Os of D
annotations.annotation:
You pay Cam C.O.D (cash on delivery) for his C(oke) and O(unces) of  D(ope)

dope = heroin

annotations.text: Some OD'ed, B off them Os of D
annotations.annotation:
“Some of my customers will undoubtedly overdose (“B” means “homie”) off of my ounces of dope (Os of D)”

Also a play on Wu-Tang member Old Dirty Bastard (RIP), called O.D.B. for short

annotations.text: I ain't give a fuck as long as they ain't close to me
annotations.annotation: Ties in with the familial theme of the song; here “close to me” has a double meaning – i.e., if you OD off of drugs you bought from Cam, he won’t care unless you were his friend and/or were physically near him (i.e., could potentially get him caught or dampen his mood)

annotations.text: Pump that Dip in ya veins, get dope like me
annotations.annotation: “Pump that dip in ya' veins” can either mean “enjoy the music we (the Diplomats / dip set) are putting out”, or “enjoy the drugs we’re selling”

annotations.text:
Fuck Kerry and Bush, you should vote for me
 For real, nigga, on the real the last hope is me
annotations.annotation:
A referance to The United States presidential election of 2004.
Republican Party candidate and incumbent President George W. Bush won re-election, defeating Democratic Party candidate John Kerry, U.S. Senator from Massachusetts and eventual United States Secretary of State.

annotations.text:
I guzzle up at the bar
But you see me in the cars
annotations.annotation: Unclear to what extent this is an endorsement of drinking and driving, or just 2 separate thoughts

annotations.text:
See more ice than a hockey goalie
Baby eating guacamole
annotations.annotation:
The “Ice (diamonds), hockey goalie, guacamole” progression is one that Camron’s used before:

You gettin' gwop, good I’m gettin' guacamole
I’m the hockey goalie, y'all action foagies

And again

annotations.text: I'm playing Don Juan
annotations.annotation: Don Juan is a Spanish fictional character who has had his story told by many different authors. He was a wealthy man who devoted a lot of his time seducing women. His life was also centered around gambling and violence. Some famous stories that are about Don Juan are Molière’s play Dom Juan, AKA The Feast with the Statue (1665), and Lord Byron’s play Don Juan Tenorio (1821).

annotations.text:
Start the car up
Take her on a long ride
Yo she think my steering wheel on the wrong side
No I'm sorry
This is the Ferrari
Limon like Bacardi
annotations.annotation: The steering wheel is on the right because his car is a yellow Ferrari made in Italy. He’s playing on Bacardi Limon – the rum of choice for middle school girls – because his Ferrari is yellow

annotations.text:
But la di da di
We like to party
And every night, believe, we gon' leave with somebody
annotations.annotation:
“Lodi Dodi, we likes to party” is one of the most famous refrains in hip hop, invented by Slick Rick, popularized by Snoop Dogg

Cam provides some variation. In the originals, the next line is “We don’t cause trouble, we don’t bother nobody”

annotations.text:
Ass is pretty
Like hoes down in Magic City
annotations.annotation:
Magic City is the famous Atlanta strip club mentioned in numerous rap songs, including Jermaine Dupri’s “Welcome to Atlanta” Remix

This reference is especially pertinent as Dupri produced the track and talks in the background throughout the song (note JD’s laugh after Cam delivers the line)

Apparently, this girls ass reminds Cam of the high-quality “Magic City ass” he sees at the club

annotations.text: I was Def already I just added the So-So
annotations.annotation: Def means cool. Adding So So makes So So Def, which is Jermaine Dupri’s record label

annotations.text:
I live the life of Riley
Whether Teddy or Pat
annotations.annotation: Referring to Teddy Riley (hit music producer) and Pat Riley (NBA champion basketball coach); Cam is hyping his abilities in music and in basketball (in addition to rap, Cam was a good high school basketball player in Harlem before quitting the game to focus on dealing drugs and rapping)

annotations.text: Are you hip to the jive?
annotations.annotation:
A 1920sish way of saying “you feel me?”

Also a swingin' Cab Calloway number

annotations.text: But it's true about Duke from the hoop to the 5
annotations.annotation: But Duke Da God (a Dipset member) is not lying about his basketball skills, or his car (5-series BMW). He’s an honest fellow

annotations.text: To see me and my chicks in DKNY kicks
annotations.annotation: DKNY (Donna Karan New York) is a label founded by Donna Karan in 1989. DKNY is generally a women’s clothing line, but there are mens clothing sold made and sold by the label.

Now Lord you know, just how hard I try

Trying to see some light or even better
Way over way a new day, someday
