annotations.text:
With my muscle you'll be dazzled, but hustlin's a hassle
 Percocet, Demerol, capsules of Paxil
annotations.annotation:
Cam'ron has so many henchmen (“muscle”) that you might suppose he’s rolling with a dazzling entourage. But being a drug dealer is no glamorama…

Although Cam leaves ambiguity, it seems unlikely that he is selling prescription drugs like Percocet (pain reliever), Demerol (pain reliever) and Paxil (anti-depressant); rather, the pharmacist hustles the hustler and Cam – once the addictor – now finds himself hooked on pills

annotations.text:
Cops wanna cuff you, niggas wanna clap you
 Bitches might burn you; they runnin' with that clap too
annotations.annotation: “Clap” can mean shooting at someone, or it can refer to Gonorrhea, which transitions to the threat of getting “burned”, i.e. getting an STD

annotations.text: But the monster made it
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron is referring to himself as the monster. Monster is common Dipset parlance (e.g. “Monster Music” by Juelz Santana)

annotations.text:
Do it for those incarcerated, who had it confiscated
 Hate it when they take powder
annotations.annotation: The it in “(I) do it” is hustle (where rapping is part of Cam'ron’s broader hustle). The confiscated “it” is drugs, specifically powder (cocaine and/or heroin)

annotations.text:
Upstate he take showers
 Baby moms on Greyhound for 8 hours
 See her man face-to-face through the glass
 On the phone. 10 years he got, chasin' that cash
annotations.annotation:
In New York rap, “upstate” refers to prison, since all state prisons are upstate. He introduces the anonymous prisoner by mentioning the prison showers so that we are immediately sympathetic

More sympathetic imagery follows: the mother of his children taking an 8-hour bus ride to visit him (perhaps a subtle invocation of the trope of using women to transport drugs by bus), then having to speak with him over the phone through a glass partition

We find out that for chasing cash (no one is innocent) he is serving 10 years. Long story short: prison is miserable

annotations.text:
Cocaine, he had that game in a smash
 Felt like the Towers when the planes went on crash
annotations.annotation: He was a very successful drug dealer, so when he got busted it was a massive fall like the Two Towers. The head of a drug operation supports so many underlings that he is as much an institution as an individual

annotations.text: It wasn't 9-11, but it was 9-1-1
annotations.annotation: It wasn’t 9-1-1 (September 11, 2001), but it was 911 (police)

annotations.text: Gave him 9 plus 1, dropped a dime on dun
annotations.annotation:
“Dun” is a person, like “son” or “homes”. To “drop a dime” on a person is to inform on him by calling the police and leaving an anonymous tip

Back in the day, this call would have come from a payphone – payphones used to cost a dime. The ‘nine plus one’ refers to the ten year sentence (9 + 1 = 10 = “dime”)

Amazing right?

(yes)

annotations.text:
Ayo, them niggas from the three two, said I can't breeze through
 The 40 if I cop bottles, we can't believe you
annotations.annotation:
Three two and forty refer to NYPD precincts in West Harlem and the South Bronx, respectively. “Cop” is to obtain (buy or steal). “Bottles” are vials of drugs

So some people from West Harlem say he can’t go get drugs in the South Bronx, but he doesn’t pay them any mind. Also funny because 32 and 40 ounces are common sizes for malt liquor bottles

annotations.text:
Landin' in that G2
 Same color as beef stew, favorite letters: GQ
 That's me, true, peach/blue
annotations.annotation:
G2 is a type of private jet — Cam'ron often references Gulfstream’s jets as exemplifying his luxury lifestyle. Beef stew: recognizing that this is a strange color description, he says, in a background adlib, “What? that best describes it”

Cam'ron loves fashion, so he reads GQ magazine (in the music video he is reading a copy of CQ – Cam'ron Quarterly). “That’s me, true” — he admits that he likes fashion. And he has a particular penchant for fancy color combinations like peach and blue

annotations.text:
Lawyer on my side keep me out of jail the fees stew, steep? Woo!
 But it might lead to that R2D2, the mobsters creep through
annotations.annotation:
This line is ambiguous:

He might be saying that his lawyer is expensive, but worth it, since his lifestyle might get him arrested–(R2D2 rode on top of a spaceship, flashing red and blue lights and making beeping noises like a police siren). “Mobsters creep through” the system, i.e. evade prosecution via their connections

On the other hand, he might be saying that charging such a high retainer might get his lawyer killed (those Jews). After Cam'ron mentions “R2D2” on the main vocal, he adlibs “that red dot” (R2D2’s most salient feature) by way of explanation in the background. In rap, red dot usually refers to the point that a laser gun-sight makes on its target. Presumably Cam would hire a mobster to do his lawyer

annotations.text: We the new PE, shittin, pee-ew
annotations.annotation:
PE is short for Public Enemy.

Good rappers “shit” on the competition. “Pee-ew!” is what little white girls say when something smells bad

annotations.text:
To the hood: y'all don't need me, I need you
 'Cause my mission's insane, you couldn't vision the pain
 Always a snitch in the game, what you want: prison or fame?
 Either one, dun, long as my digits the same
annotations.annotation:
An inversion of the rap cliche “the hood needs me.” Psychologically, Cam'ron needs the hood because it grounds him. Practically, he needs the hood to keep track of snitches

“What you want, prison or fame?” means would you rather make your money from drugs (which could lead to prison) or music (which could lead to fame)

Cam will take whichever one makes more money!

annotations.text:
He lookin' frigid, dig it, make sure them digits get changed
 'Cause I can't be in Hell's cell
annotations.annotation: He’s looking like a snitch (because he’s cold, acting funny, blue), so make sure you change the phone numbers because Cam'ron doesn’t want to end up in prison (as his friend Hell Rell’s cellmate)

annotations.text:
Shout out to Mel Mel
 Cash and Hell Rell, Zeek doin' 3, he even fell, hell
 He comin' home on '07 and 12 cells
 'Cause you must have known, I can't trust the phones
annotations.annotation:
Mel Mel, Cash and Hell Rell are all friends who have done time: Money Mel was a fellow New York rapper, Cash is Turk Cash Money, Hell Rell is a member of Dipset, and Zeke is short for Freekey Zekey (a member of Dipset and Cam'ron’s cousin)

Zeke served three years in prison for running an ecstasy ring. At the time of the song he was slated to be released in 2007

On ‘07 and 12 cells…? '07 is presumably Zeke’s release date. 12 cells is less clear: Did he stay in 12 different cells while in prison? Do he and Cam need twelve cell phones to elude the authorities? Has he been smuggled in twelve different cell phones?

annotations.text: For the dough you'll be like Doe, stuck at home
annotations.annotation:
Chasing money (dough) by dealing drugs may leave you on house arrest like Cam'ron’s friend Doe Stacks – a drug dealer from Harlem that grew up with Cam'ron, Jim Jones, Freekey Zekey etc.

Doe was on house arrest for drugs charges when this song was released. Jim Jones also raps about Doe in “Bout it Bout it” (he mentions Doe at the 3:10 mark)

annotations.text:
Nowadays dog, they raid up in the ballparks
 Blaze 'em when they cross sharks
 We raiders of the lost ark
annotations.annotation:
Cops today are such bastards that they make drug raids on basketball courts and shoot you when you cross their informants. Cam'ron and co. are not daunted by these difficulties – like Harrison Ford trying to find the ark of the covenant in the first Indiana Jones movie, Raiders of the Lost Ark

We realize this is all a stretch; your guess is as good as ours

“Lost arc"ing jumpshot?

annotations.text: I'm like a ballplayer, shake up and cross narcs
annotations.annotation:
Continuing with the sports theme, he evades narcotics police the way a basketball player evades a defender – by crossing him over

Fun Fact: Before dropping out of school to sell drugs and rap full time, Cam'ron was a celebrated high school basketball player

annotations.text:
They get mad when I lay up in the Porsche Box
 More props,
annotations.annotation: In yet another sports reference (“lay up”), the cops get mad when Cam'ron chills in his Porsche Boxster, but for insisting on chilling in spite of the police suspicion it attracts, Cam'ron gets more “props” (respect) from the hood

annotations.text: Can't see his son shine like the Four Tops
annotations.annotation: Play on the title of the Four Tops single The Sun Ain’t Gonna Shine

annotations.text:
My antennas will block the scanners
 I got blammers, you'll drop your hammers
annotations.annotation: His antennas block police scanners. “Blammers” are machine guns, which are superior to “hammers,” or single action and semi-automatic guns

annotations.text:
Lawyers to watch lawyers, cameras to watch cameras
 Niggas to watch bitches, Nana to watch Grandma
annotations.annotation:
Cam'ron’s life is a labyrinth of suspicion and distrust:

He needs lawyers to keep an eye on his other lawyers, cameras to spy on the cameras spying on him, sous-pimps to watch his hoes…and one grandma to watch the other, shadier one

annotations.text:
In pajamas I snuck out to watch Santa
 Now look at Killa, you gon' watch Santana
annotations.annotation:
Aww! But also brilliant–

Once upon a time Cam'ron (Killa Cam) was a little boy who wore pajamas and believed in Santa Claus. Now he’s a world-weary, world-famous, fabulously rich rapper / criminal. He is so successful that you’ll be watching his protégé, Juelz Santana

annotations.text: Now I was born by the river in a little tent
annotations.annotation: The opening line from R&B singer Sam Cooke’s classic “A Change is Gonna Come”

annotations.text:
Little gate, little fence - I climbed over
 Little scrapes, little dents - I got over
annotations.annotation: Juelz’s humble ghetto beginnings: hopping fences (minor obstacles), fist fights, etc.

annotations.text: It's been a long time comin' Cam
annotations.annotation: The variety of uses of the word “come” throughout the verse are inspired by the first line of the verse, which Juelz pulled from “A Change is Gonna Come”

annotations.text: It's been a long time riding and a long time running, man
annotations.annotation:
“Riding” is rolling with a gang, usually in a car, looking for trouble

“Running” is used here as in running drugs, hustling, staying ahead of the law (from junkie slang “ripping and running”)

annotations.text: Shit done changed since The Wop and The Running Man
annotations.annotation: The Wop and The Running Man are dances from the ‘80s (note the playful homophone with the line above)

annotations.text:
Since Nino, Gee Money, The Carter, and the Duh-Duh Man
 It's no longer a New Jack City
annotations.annotation:
Nino, G-Money and Duh-Duh Man are characters in New Jack City. The apartment complex-cum-crack house in the movie is called “The Carter.”  New Jack City came out in 1991, and Juelz is saying the drug game has gotten a lot harder since then

New Jack City is a popular movie among rappers, from Lil Wayne (who named his albums ‘The Carter’ partly as an homage to the film) to Biggie Smalls (“We got infiltrated like Nino at the Carter” in “Everyday Struggles”), because it was one of the first to deal with ghetto life and the drug game in a way that glamorized the drug dealers as being ruthlessly brilliant

annotations.text: It's "cop fast and move that quickly" or cops crash
annotations.annotation: Compared to those of New Jack City, in which a resourceful dealer turned an entire apartment building into a fixed base of operations, contemporary (actual) police are more responsive.By purchasing and offloading their wares quickly, dealers minimize their time spent holding inventory (and hence being liable for possession).

annotations.text:
I'm talking crack, man and coming up with O's
 I'm coming up with halves and coming up with wholes
annotations.annotation:
Clarifying that he’s talking about the crack game that made him rich, and not the rap game, hence his references to ounces (O’s) and half-pound bricks (halves) of crack

He sells a half-pound and doubles the worth (to a whole pound)

annotations.text: I was comin' from the Q, Zeek was comin' from the O
annotations.annotation: The letters of their “daily commute” NYC subways. Mine was B when I lived in the city (I hated the subway sooo much!)

annotations.text: Paper-run
annotations.annotation: Comparing Dipset’s time as low-level crack dealers to a kid having a “paper run.” Also, “paper” is money

annotations.text: Waiting for a change to come
annotations.annotation:
Instead of singing songs and marching and doing sissy things, Dipset took the power into their own hands and effected change by waiting on the corner and selling crack

He is also equating the main activity of crack dealers – namely, sitting and waiting on a corner – with the patient insistence for social change and racial equality of the civil rights movement

annotations.text:
Now look: the change has come
 The 7-Pick Up, Yukon, the Range is come
annotations.annotation:
A Change is Gonna Come – which Juelz quoted at the beginning of this verse – was sung as a ballad against racism

Juelz is saying: “Look Sam. Dispet is black and we are ballin'. We have fancy SUVs. You predicted it.. and it happened!”

Sam Cooke was assassinated

annotations.text:
Holler at your motherfuckin' boy, JR (Brr)
 Birdman my pa, bitch, ball bred, born rich (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
Wayne refers to his mentor Birdman as his “pa” and calls himself Birdman Jr. (or just “J.R.”)



Weezy was not exactly born with a silver spoon in his mouth – although he did become famous at 15 (maybe he doesn’t remember the Poor Days..)

annotations.text: Dear Mr. Toilet, I'm the shit
Got these other haters pissed 'cause my toilet paper thick
annotations.annotation: The mention of toilet paper could be wordplay modifying the more common phrase “my paper thick” (I have lots of money) so as to fit the bathroom theme of this and the previous line. Or, it could be interpreted literally, as someone with lots of money can afford luxury toilet paper which would be thicker.

annotations.text:
I know
 But trip and that 40 make a chip out a potato-head wimp
 Then like ranch, I dip (Gone)
annotations.annotation:
If you “trip”, I’ll make chips out of your “potato” head, i.e. shoot you in your Mr. Potatohead-looking face with my 40-caliber gun), and then I’ll “dip” (take off; also a popular accompagnement to potato chips)

Mr. Potatohead:

annotations.text: When it comes to that weight, I don't struggle, I just lift (One, two)
annotations.annotation:
“Weight” means drugs, and Lil Wayne doesn’t have a hard time selling a lot of drugs (someone might “struggle” when lifting weights at the gym)

Also might be a reference to the fact that he settles disagreements by simply “lifting” his gun and shooting, so he doesn’t have to “struggle” with putting up with disagreeable people / lifting weights at the gym to get strong

annotations.text: Hundred grand in my fist, same on my wrist
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne bout to flex on all y’all mofos

This motherfucjer richer than u

And richer than ur momma

annotations.text: Get key money from a quarter, blame it on my wrist (Haha)
annotations.annotation:
I get “key money” (the amount of money one would normally make selling a kilogram of coke) “from a quarter” (from selling a quarter of a kilogram of coke)

How? Blame it on my wrist. i.e., it’s because I cut the cocaine so well (a wrist-heavy activity)

On “Make It Work For You” by Juelz Santana, both he and Young Jeezy discuss their wrist skills (Wayne is also featured on this track):


[Jeezy]
Fuck a magic stick Jeezy got a magic wrist
David Copperfield on the stove all types of shit

[Juelz]
I can show you how to mix that shit
How to whip that shit, how to twist that wrist

annotations.text: I whip coke like hoes, nigga, I'm a pimp (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
The most straightforward interpretation is that Wayne is saying he “whips coke,” meaning turns it into crack, just like a pimp literally “whips hoes”, and therefore he is a pimp

An alternate explanation: Wayne is able to get a kilogram’s worth of money from a quarter kilogram of coke because his wrist technique is so flawless. In other words he whips coke like women do, since women are generally considered better in the kitchen

“I’m a pimp” plays with the listener’s expectations – he’s not talking about hitting women, in fact he is complimenting them

annotations.text:
Yeah
 Fuck bitches, fuck bitches, fuck bitches (Yeah)
 Get money, get money, get money (Bitch), yeah
 Get money, fuck bitches
 Fuck bitches, get money
 Fuck bitches, get money
annotations.annotation:
A reference to the hook to Notorious B.I.G.’s classic “Get Money”, this hook has a clever double meaning: he could be saying what he does is “get money” and also “fuck bitches”

But he also means that he likes to “get money,” and so “fuck bitches” – i.e. “To hell with em! I’m going to focus on money…”

Given the line from the next verse – “Money over bitches I’m yelling it to the grave” – I’m going with the second interpretation

annotations.text: In the heart of the summer, we need a snowplow
annotations.annotation: Wayne is saying that even in the middle of the summer, so much “blow”/ “snow” (drugs) are being sold and used that a snowplow could help with the epidemic.

annotations.text: Coke transactions on the phone, we call it blowjobs (Yeah)
annotations.annotation: The feds could be tapping into his phone line so Wayne needs to be careful. Their code word on the phone for a coke sale is “blow job” (a clever pun since “blow” means coke).

annotations.text: Developed at a young age (What?), go after what pays (Yeah)
annotations.annotation: Watch Lil Wayne pressure a 15-year-old to become more sexually active by recounting the story of his first blow job: Birdman, his sexual mentor, ordered a girl to “suck Lil Wayne’s lil dick!” in front of a room full of people

annotations.text:
New Orleans my birthplace, you heard me?
 Where money's more important than a person, nigga
annotations.annotation: Lil Wayne grew up in the crime-ridden Hollygrove neighborhood in the 17th ward of New Orleans, where people were shot every day over disputes about splitting the profits made from drug dealing. They worked so hard for their money that they would kill to get it, even if it meant killing others to do it.

Breast implants give the recipient the look of perky, non-droopy titties– they look solid (hard). But on the inside, they’re actually really soft.

Just like the people Fab is talkin about.

annotations.text: Justin will cry rivers like he feel I boned Britney
annotations.annotation: Justin Timberlake.  He had a song with a refrain “Cry me a river” and he used to date Britney Spears, so Fabolous is saying he’s going to have sex w/Britney and when Justin gets the feeling that happened he’ll cry a river

annotations.text:
Your girlie ain't been seen since
 The feature with Lil' Mo, over 2 million people, I've reached with my little flow
annotations.annotation:
Fabolous first made it in the rap game by appearing on Lil' Mo’s “Superwoman.” He dropped a verse about how much he loves his girl and it made him an instant hit with the ladies. so “Your girlie ain’t been seen since” means that after that song, your girl ran off with Fabolous

“Over 2 million people I’ve reached” is a brag about how many people heard his very short verse (little flow)

annotations.text: (uh huh, uh huh)
annotations.annotation: This is a nod to those who say his “slow-flow” is jacked from Ma$e or he “sounds like” the Harlem rapper

annotations.text: I use the Black Star Power on broads
annotations.annotation: Fab' is a star, black, and thus will use his celebrity and charisma to seduce girls. He also refers to his black star power on Sickalicious

annotations.text: Even devil worshippers gotta bow to the God
annotations.annotation:
Rappers from New York sometimes use “The God” to refer to themselves. Devil-worshipers are basically anti-God (the actual Christian/Judaic/Muslim God).

Fab is using the wordplay to pretty much say even those who are 100% against him like Devil-worshipers are against God, still have no choice but to acknowledge how good he is.

annotations.text:
"Dear God – I wonder, can you save me?"
 "Illuminati want my mind, soul and my body"
annotations.annotation:
Sets up the struggle between God and doing the right thing and the dark forces of capitalism that defines Jay-Z’s life and ghetto life in general. This line led to thousands of YouTube videos claiming this line confirms Jay-Z sold his soul to the mysterious Illuminati in exchange for fortune and fame. But what Jay-Z is trying to get across is that the struggle for money corrupts completely (mind, soul, and body). Jay is acknowledging that he is starting to fall prey to the pursuit of money, and asks for “God” (in some capacity) to save him.



The Snoop Dogg sample is taken from his song “Murder Was The Case”, which in turn samples an earlier Snoop & Dre song “Lil Ghetto Boy”.

The “Illuminati want my mind, soul, and my body” part of the hook is a Prodigy (from Mobb Deep) sample from his verse in the LL Cool J song “I Shot Ya (Remix)”.

This is a sample from a Prodigy (of Mobb Deep) verse on LL Cool J’s “I Shot Ya Remix”. Prodigy has been outspoken against the Illuminati.

annotations.text: "I can't die, I can't die, I can't die"
annotations.annotation: This Snoop Dogg sample is taken from his song “Murder Was The Case.” In a similar fashion to the other samples used in the hook, it indicates Jay-Z’s struggle to choose between good and evil. In fact as acknowledged in all three verses, the hook may indicate that his environment and the desire for money forced him to eventually do evil activities.

annotations.text: This shit is wicked on these mean streets
annotations.annotation:
Reference to the Martin Scorcese mafia film, the first of several mafia references in this verse.

Reasonable Doubt is filled with the imagery of Italian gangsters, a stylistic and attitudinal inspiration for many black crack dealers-turned rappers, including Jay’s boy Biggie Smalls (his fashion sense, his crew’s name of ‘Junior M.A.F.I.A.’) – the cover art even shows Jay-Z dressed like one

annotations.text: None of my friends speak, we're all tryna win
annotations.annotation:
People are too focused on getting ahead in the crack game to even speak to their own friends. They are all trying to be the top player and don’t want their partners to know that they make more than them because it would bring jealousy, and lead to getting “touched”.

In Jay-Z own words (from Decoded)

“Coming of Age” and “D'Evils” are two songs on the same basic theme. They’re both being in the game and they both deal with competition and friendship. But the “Coming of Age” songs about a boss dealing with the rise of someone younger, while “D'Evils” is about the relationship between peers, two people who grew up together.“ (Carter: 2011 p51)

annotations.text:
But then again, maybe it's for the best though
 'Cause when they're sayin' too much
 You know they're tryna get you touched
annotations.annotation:
Generally when someone talks a lot it is because they are trying to cover something up or draw attention away from it (“the loudest in the room is the weakest in the room”). Jay is happier seeing his friends just keeping their head down and doing their thing than someone acting like his best friend, because that person is more likely to betray him.

This line can also be heard as “seeing too much”, meaning it would be beneficial for Jay to keep a small inner circle. If there are too many people involved in his operation that see what’s going on, there is a higher likelihood that someone could turn him in to the feds or a rival gang.

Could be an allusion to Tessio attempting to turn Michael Corleone into the rival families to be killed; Michael was able to identify him as a traitor because he was the one who approached Michael about arranging a “peace summit”, while everyone else was just doing their job.

annotations.text:
Whoever said illegal was the easy way out
 Couldn't understand the mechanics
 And the workings of the underworld, granted
annotations.annotation:
Most people view drug dealing and hustling as easy money, and working a corporate desk job as hard earned money. But there is a lot more at risk when you’re hustling compared to working in a cubicle. Drug dealers are often depicted as ballers who drive nice cars without a care in the world, and regular employees are often depicted as hard-working citizens with a lot of pressure on them. But a drug dealer always has to think about getting shot down by rival dealers and such, while the worst thing that can happen to a 9 to 5 worker is getting fired and having to find a new job. So someone in Jay-Z’s profession has a lot more on their mind than it seems.

“The ‘mechanics’ here aren’t about the technical details of the business, but the psychological and emotional machinery that’s always working under the surface.”

                           -Jay-Z, Decoded


Note the play on “underworld” and “granted.” “Granted” sounds like granite – a type of rock that is found within continental crust.

annotations.text:
Nine-to-five is how you survive, I ain't tryna survive
 I'm tryna live it to the limit and love it a lot
annotations.annotation:
References to these lofty ambitions pervade Reasonable Doubt.  See this line on “Dead Presidents,”, this line on “Regrets” and essentially the album’s mission statement on “Can I Live”

I’d rather die enormous than live dormant,
That’s how we on it

Jay is saying that getting a job (or other mainstream means of making ends meet) is safe and he could do that and survive, but he doesn’t want to just survive. He is willing to put his life on the line to get the most out of his life that he can. Go big or go home!



Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying,

“The first defence of a lot of people who take the criminal route is that they had no choice, which is almost true. Most of us had choices, but the choices were bleak. The street life was tough and morally compromised and sometimes ugly, but a dead-end nine-to-five job at permanent entry level wasn’t all that attractive, either. The righteous seed in a hustler’s mentality was this: He wanted something more for himself.”

annotations.text:
I used to say fuck mic skills
 I never prayed to God, I prayed to Gotti
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z didn’t worry about rapping and never prayed (or in other words never did anything that might give him hope). He just idolized John Gotti, the infamous mafia kingpin and valued hustling and drug dealing above all else.



Lupe Fiasco discussed his upset over this line (and the accompanying moral values) on “Hurt Me Soul”



Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying,

This reflects that way I actually thought: I ignored my god-given ability, never believing that someone from where I came from could make it out. The whole idea of “D'Evils” is that the narrator is no longer just expressing his ambition to live a full life- he’s been poisoned somehow, possessed with a desire for money, alienated from all that’s good, and focused on the underworld, here represented by Mafia references.

annotations.text:
That's right, it's wicked – that's life, I live it
 Ain't askin' for forgiveness for my sins,
annotations.annotation:
Sinning got him to where he was, and is, now. And he fully accepts that and wants to continue the pursuit of money.

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying,

“The narrator isn’t thinking about redemption or turning back – he’s totally focused on making money, "ends.”

annotations.text: I break bread
annotations.annotation:
“Break bread” in this usage means that Jay socializes with and learns from the older gangsters. But it also has other connotations.

It could be an allusion to The Last Supper, where Jesus broke bread right before he died. Jay could be contrasting the purity of Jesus breaking bread to the corruption of meeting up with other gangsters and discussing how to make it to the top. Same general idea as the God/Gotti line.

annotations.text: All the evils that the game'll do
annotations.annotation: The game is double-edged; it will give you things you wish for but what you wish for might not necessarily be what a person should be seeking for in the first place.  Lupe Fiasco took this further on his album, “The Cool”.

annotations.text:
It gets dangerous, money and power is changin' us
 And now we're lethal, infected with D'evils
annotations.annotation:
An explicit thesis statement from Jay-Z, this is the entire point of the song

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying

D'Evils – this obsession with getting paid – is something the narrator picks up after he “breaks bread with the late heads,” who school him in ruthlessness.

annotations.text:
We used to fight for building blocks
 Now we fight for blocks with buildings that make a killin'
annotations.annotation:
The “building blocks” here have multiple meanings here.

First off, when the narrator and his friend were only kids, they used to just play games with stacking blocks.



Then as they both became heavy in the drug game, they started to search for the “building blocks” with which to build their empires on. This would include where they set up, how much money they had to invest, and of course the drugs themselves.

This progressed to literally “building blocks” meaning city blocks. He has gone from trying to build up his wealth to literally controlling buildings. But this creates conflict with his former friend, who also wants to set up at these buildings, to make a “killing”. Since the building block being controlled is so profitable it leads to many turf wars over control.

As a whole, this line frames the rest of Verse 2. It describes the origins of his relationship with a friend that he grew up with in the drug game that eventually becomes a bitter enemy of his. It also serves as a metaphor for Jay’s rise in the rap game from Hawaiian Sophie to Reasonable Doubt.



In a Reasonable Doubt documentary, Jay describes this line, saying:

“When we was young fighting for those little building blocks, now we fighting for blocks with buildings. Like “I own that block”, you know? And the irony in that, you know, we grew up together so we learnt things together we learnt about our first jump shot, and our first time we rode a bike,  and the first time we learned how to use a condom”

It’s here: go to 27:45. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IXfgKbp9ncQ

annotations.text:
Thinkin' back when we first learned to use rubbers
 He never learned, so in turn I'm kidnappin' his baby's mother
annotations.annotation:
In Decoded, Jay-Z’s book breaking down his rap lyrics, Jay singled out this couplet as one of his favorite lines from his work

Jay reminisces about an earlier, more innocent age when he and his friend were first learning to use condoms, and then connects it back to his current predicament. Since his friend never actually got the lesson and never used condoms, he impregnated a woman. Now Jay-Z is kidnapping that woman to gather information on his old friend’s whereabouts. This plays on the theme of the impossibility of innocence in the ghetto – having a kid, rather than being a joy, is a vulnerability.

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying,

“Here’s where the song takes a sudden turn from a general analysis and reminiscences to a clear narrative. I tried to convey a lot of information in one line: that we were friends so close that we learned basic sex ed at the same time; that he ‘never learned’, which sets him up as someone sloppier, less calculating and cunning than me; that he had a child as a result, and "a baby’s mother”; and that I kidnapped her, which shows how profoundly “blackhearted” I had become, violently exploiting any opening – even the innocent mother of his child. The line goes from the innocence of two dumb kids learning to use condoms together, bypasses any happiness or joy about the birth of a child, and ends in a truly dark place. It’s the poison of “D'Evils” sketched out in a few words."

annotations.text: My hand around her collar, feedin' her cheese
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z choking the woman to intimidate her into cooperation and then beginning to bribe her (cheese = money) into giving him information about the friend with whom he’s had a falling out.

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line

The “cheese: is money, which I’m feeding her to try to get her to rat out the location of her man.

annotations.text:
She said the taste of dollars was shitty, so I fed her fifties
 About his whereabouts I wasn't convinced
 I kept feedin' her money 'til her shit started to make sense
annotations.annotation:
Jay is trying to find this friend-turned-enemy so he keeps paying her. This finishes off the extended metaphor of feeding money: she doesn’t like the “taste” of the first cheese because it was a smaller amount, so he changes the cuisine and gives her bigger bills until she “shits out” the information he needs.

“Shit started to make sense” is a play on words, it can be interpreted as what she was saying started to make sense as in she was telling the truth. But it also can be as she has been eating so much of his money that she started shitting out cents as in money.

A deeper meaning that Jay probably wasn’t actually referring to (but is still interesting food for thought) is that the money the girl is fed appears in her shit, so it wasn’t completely absorbed. So it could be viewed as a commentary of man’s essential inability to ‘digest’ money.

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying

Extending the money-as-food metaphor, I keep feeding her larger bills till she shits out some information, the dollars breaking down to cents/sense as she digests them.

annotations.text:
Who could ever foresee?
 We used to stay up all night at slumber parties
 Now I'm tryna rock his bitch to sleep
 All the years we were real close
 Now I see his fears through her tears
 Know she's wishin' we were still close
annotations.annotation:
The narrator never would have thought when they were little going to slumber parties that he would grow up and try to “rock this bitch to sleep” (kill one of his best friends). But he is not completely cold hearted to the friend, he just feels the need to kill him is a business move (“it’s not personal, it’s strictly business”). Since our narrator is suffering from the same issues as his friend he sympathizes with him, and would still like to be friends with him if they weren’t rivals.

Alternatively, the “bitch” that Jay has to rock to sleep could be the baby’s mama he kidnapped in the previous lines. He is either killing her to send a message, or trying to lull her into a false sense of security (“rock her to sleep”) so she is more willing to hand over the information he needs.

annotations.text: Don't cry, it is to be;
annotations.annotation: The girl wishes that Jay-Z and the man in question were still close, because then she wouldn’t be being leaned on in this way.  Jay-Z gives her the ironic reassurance that “it is to be, in time”, i.e. they will be reunited when they both die.

annotations.text:
In time
 I'll take away your miseries and make it mine, D'evils
annotations.annotation:
Ending the verse with a semi-Biblical touch as he promises redemption for the girl by taking on her pain and sorrow.

Right now, Jay-Z is feeling good. He got the location of the man like he needed, and is ready to take things in his own hands. But he knows that “in time” the pain and suffering he caused to both the girl and his old friend will come back to haunt him. Pain, like matter and energy in the universe, never goes away, it merely gets transferred or rearranged.  Therefore, Jay absorbs the pain of all those he has wronged and has to carry it for the rest of his life.

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying

In the end, I get her to do what I want, but it’s a grim victory. Not only will blood be shed based on the information she’s given me- hers and his- but the last vision of her, tears like a veil over her eyes, begging for both of their lives, is going to haunt me. Her miseries became mine.

The “Illuminati want my mind, soul, and my body” part of the hook is a Prodigy (from Mobb Deep) sample from his verse in the LL Cool J song “I Shot Ya (Remix)”.

annotations.text:
"Dear God – I wonder, can you save me?"
 "Illuminati want my mind, soul and my body"
annotations.annotation:
Sets up the struggle between God and doing the right thing and the dark forces of capitalism that defines Jay-Z’s life and ghetto life in general. This line led to thousands of YouTube videos claiming this line confirms Jay-Z sold his soul to the mysterious Illuminati in exchange for fortune and fame. But what Jay-Z is trying to get across is that the struggle for money corrupts completely (mind, soul, and body). Jay is acknowledging that he is starting to fall prey to the pursuit of money, and asks for “God” (in some capacity) to save him.

annotations.text: "Secret society, tryna keep they eye on me"
annotations.annotation:
The Illuminati’s seal (which is featured, according to a certain kind of person, on the back of the $1 bill) features an all-seeing eye

This is a sample from a Prodigy (of Mobb Deep) verse on LL Cool J’s “I Shot Ya Remix”. Prodigy has been outspoken against the Illuminati.

annotations.text:
The Exorcist got me doin' sticks
 Like, "Homie, you don't know me
 But the whole world owe me, strip!"
annotations.annotation:
Killing his childhood friend set a dangerous precedent for the narrator. Now that emotion doesn’t factor into his decisions, he is willing to stick up anyone. But there is still some residual guilt, so even though he acts like he isn’t afraid to kill, he still blames his actions on others right before he takes out the victim.

Notice the excesses/exorcist homophone, which ties in with material possessions being connected with the devil.

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying,

Another quick scene: Possessed by material lust, the narrator sticks up random people. The quick line of dialogue is meant to show someone completely blinded by desire, reckless and aggressive, but also haunted, the kind of character who talks to his vics as he’s robbing them, making jokes and justifying himself by saying the whole world has done him wrong, so now everyone owes him. This could be the same character from the opening verses; driven over the edge by killing off his best childhood friend, now he’s just a raging psychopath.

annotations.text:
Was thought to be a pleasant guy all my fuckin' life
 So now I'm down for whatever, ain't nothin' nice
annotations.annotation:
Nice guys live decent lives, but usually aren’t cut out to make it to the top. They work the 9-to-5 jobs that Jay said don’t interest him in the first verse. So in order to make it to the top, the narrator has to resort to crime and corrupt himself. Similar to Breaking Bad’s Walter White.

Also a reference to “Down 4 Whateva,” a song from an early 90’s group called Nuttin' Nyce.

annotations.text: But now this higher learning got the Remy in me
annotations.annotation:
A play on Remy Martin…Remy was also a character in the 1995 movie Higher Learning. He starts off as a shy, lonely white guy, who gets into a couple run-ins with black classmates. He turns to a white supremacist group to combat feeling powerless, eventually shooting up a multi-ethnic peace rally and then killing himself. Jay compares his decision to jump into the drug trade to Remy joining the group, as they both end up corrupting.



Also, Remy Martin is a brand of cognac. So Jay is also saying that all of his knowledge about the ugly world of drug dealers leads him to drinking to try and forget it.

annotations.text: Liquor's invaded my kidneys
annotations.annotation: Drinking too much alcohol can cause kidney failure (over time). This follows up the Remy line, since he is now drinking so much Remy Martin that it is starting to damage his health. This indicates that things have gotten even worse for the narrator. He is probably living with PTSD after gunning down his childhood friend, and trying to drink away the pain.

annotations.text: Got me ready to lick off – Momma, forgive me
annotations.annotation:
Continuing from the previous line, the liquor HOV has been drinking has clouded his judgement and given him liquid courage. He’s not completely aware of his actions and he’s ready to bust a cap / lick off at anyone who opposes him.

Jay Z is apologizing to his mom for what he’s about to do.



This is an example of how he disappointed his mom and gave her her fair share of pain.

annotations.text: For the love of money, son, I'm givin' lead showers
annotations.annotation:
This is a play on the phrase “for the love of God”. But this song documents the transition to loving money more than God. Because of that, he is willing to shoot up rival gangs (“give lead showers”) to protect his money.

Also plays on weather vocabulary, since it could be heard as

For the love of money, sun
I’m giving lead showers (as in rain)

Just another example of Jay mixing in some wordplay to strengthen the lyricism of the song.

annotations.text: Stop screamin', you know the demon said it's best to die
annotations.annotation:
No point in protesting your impending murder. Jay-Z cites Satan’s suggestion that death be embraced (from the Book of Genesis: “In that day ye eat of that fruit ye shall die”) and in so doing shows that he accepts the “devil’s” authority.

Additionally Jay-Z is referring to the practice of selling one’s soul “for the love of money” and in turn receiving eternity in hell. If you go through with this, your fate is sealed no matter what, so you might as well enjoy your time on Earth instead of fearing your inevitable death the whole time. In the sense of this song, he is referring to how there is no turning back after the awful deeds he has done (kidnapping the girl, killing his friend, shooting at rival gangs, etc.), so it better have been worth it.

annotations.text: And even if Jehovah witness, bet he'll never testify, D'evils
annotations.annotation:
This refers to the practice of killing a witness to a crime before that witness can testify against you. Jay claims that even if a god like Yahweh, who is supposed to have the highest morality in the universe witnessed this crime, Jay-Z would be able to intimidate Him into silence (note the play on the name of the Jehovah’s Witness religion).

Since one of Jay’s nicknames is Jayhova, this could be him referring to himself in the third person and claiming that even if he saw someone else commit a crime, he would never snitch.

Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying:

The song ends with a dizzying carousel of conversations: First the narrator address his mother, then his girl (“boo), and finally a last victim. The narrator is completely lost to the "D'Evils.” He taunts his victims, defends himself, brags about how low he gets down, invites niggas to try to come get him like George Bush saying “bring ‘em on” to the terrorists. The final two lines, contrasting the demons in his head with a God he thinks is powerless, show how deeply he’s fallen into a moral vacuum. The song isn’t about literal demonic possession, of course, even if some sloppy listeners claim that it is; the truth is you don’t need some external demon to take control of you to turn you into a raging, money-obesessed sociopath, you only need to let loose the demons you already have inside of you.

lyrics:
[Produced by Just Blaze]

[Intro: Gloria Carter]
Shawn Carter was born December 4th, weighing in at 10 pounds, 8 ounces. He was the last of my four children. The only one who didn't give me any pain when I gave birth to him. And that's how I knew that he was a special child.

[Verse 1: JAY-Z]
They say "They never really miss you 'til you dead or you gone."
So on that note, I'm leavin' after this song
So you ain't gotta feel no way about Jay, so long
But at least let me tell you why I'm this way, hold on
I was conceived by Gloria Carter and Adnis Reeves
Who made love under the sycamore tree
Which makes me a more sicker MC, and my momma would claim
At 10 pounds, when I was born, I didn't give her no pain
Although through the years I gave her her fair share
I gave her her first real scare, I made up for birth when I got here
She knows my purpose wasn't purpose; I ain't perfect, I care
But I feel worthless 'cause my shirts wasn't matchin' my gear
Now I'm just scratchin' the surface 'cause what's buried under there
Was a kid torn apart once his pop disappeared
I went to school, got good grades, could behave when I wanted
But I had demons deep inside that would raise when confronted
Hold on

[Interlude: Gloria Carter]
Shawn was a very shy child growing up. He was into sports, and a funny story is at 4 he taught himself how to ride a bike. A two-wheeler at that, isn't that special? But I noticed a change in him when me and my husband broke up.

[Verse 2: JAY-Z]
Now, all the teachers couldn't reach me
And my momma couldn't beat me
Hard enough to match the pain of my pop not seein' me

Spanish Jose introduced me to 'caine, I'm a hustler now

[Interlude: Gloria Carter]
Shawn used to be in the kitchen, beating on the table and rapping until the wee hours of the morning. And then I bought him a boom box, and his sisters and brothers said he would drive them nuts. But that was my way to keep him close to me and out of trouble.

[Verse 3: JAY-Z]

‘Cause I'm still paranoid to this day
And it's nobody fault, I made the decisions I made
This is the life I chose, or rather, the life that chose me

[Outro: JAY-Z]
If you can't respect that, your whole perspective is wack
Maybe you'll love me when I fade to black
If you can't respect that, your whole perspective is wack
Maybe you'll love me when I fade to black
Now if you can't respect that, your whole perspective is wack
Maybe you'll love me when I fade to black

annotations.text: [Produced by Just Blaze]
annotations.annotation:
The track samples Chi-Lites' “That’s How Long” and vocals by Jay Z’s mother Gloria Carter to give an even more personal feeling to the track.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cD7V-QxpdyA

annotations.text: [Intro: Gloria Carter]
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z’s mother, who tells little bits of Jay’s past throughout this song.



Jay-Z and his mother, Gloria Carter

How’d Jay get her on the track? He tricked her!

From his NPR interview:

GROSS: [Y]our mother is featured on [the song].
JAY-Z: Yeah, I tricked her.
GROSS: We’ll actually hear her voice, yeah. Did you say you tricked her?
JAY-Z: Yeah, it was her birthday. It was actually her birthday – December 4th is my birthday, which is the title of the song – and it was her birthday, September 17th, and I told her to meet me down at the studio, that we were going to go to lunch and – for her birthday. And she came down to the studio, and I just brought the track up. And I was like, I just want you to talk on it – because I knew if I told her, she’d get really nervous. So I just – I brought her down to the studio, and I just brought the track up and was like, I need you to talk on this. And she was like, what do you want me to say? And you know, the rest is history.
GROSS: What did you tell her when she said,what do you want me to say?
JAY-Z: Oh, just tell those stories that you told about me – about riding the bike when I was 4 and, you know, those sort of things. And she went in there and was – you know, we couldn’t get off the mike after a minute ‘cause she just kept talking.

annotations.text: Shawn Carter was born December 4th, weighing in at 10 pounds, 8 ounces. He was the last of my four children. The only one who didn't give me any pain when I gave birth to him. And that's how I knew that he was a special child.
annotations.annotation:
Shawn Carter is Jay Z’s real name, and he was born on  December 4th, 1969. He has two bigger sisters and one bigger brother.



Even though Jay weighed above-average (three times the size of an average newborn! http://www.cdc.gov/growthcharts/data/who/grchrt_boys_24lw_100611.pdf) , his mother had a painless labor. According to the Bible, after Adam and Eve sin in The Garden of Eden, God punishes them by making childbirth painful. Since Gloria Carter gives birth without pain, like when Mary bears Jesus, it implied that she is not a sinner. It, of course, also compares Jay to Jesus.  With Jigga’s nickname J HOVA being a Latin version of Hebrew “Jahweh,” which means God, Jay claims to be divine yet again.

annotations.text:
They say "They never really miss you 'til you dead or you gone."
 So on that note, I'm leavin' after this song
 So you ain't gotta feel no way about Jay, so long
 But at least let me tell you why I'm this way, hold on
annotations.annotation:
In the book Decoded, Jay himself claims he was inspired by Joni Mitchell’s “Big Yellow Taxi”:

Don’t it always seem to go
That you don’t know what you’ve got ‘til it’s gone?



Even though “December 4th” is the first track on The Black Album, it acts as a retirement announcement:

So on that note, I’m leaving after this song

Jay couldn’t resist the “Allure” of the game and ended up coming back 3 years later.

annotations.text:
I was conceived by Gloria Carter and Adnis Reeves
 Who made love under the sycamore tree
 Which makes me a more sicker MC,
annotations.annotation:
Gloria Carter and Adnes Reeves are Hova’s parents' names.

Jay alludes to a Biggie line from “You’re Nobody Till Somebody Kills You”:

My sycamore style, more sicker than yours



In “Can’t Knock the Hustle” Jay-Z wrote:

My Pops knew exactly what he did when he made me, tried to get a nut and he got a nut and what

Seven years more mature and after a reunion with his father, these lines show that Jay has come to view his conception as a beautiful thing – “made love under a sycamore tree” – even though his father leaving caused him a lot of pain and struggle, he’s come to terms with the fact that it has made him what he is today. It’s how he became a stronger person and a better artist.

annotations.text:
And my momma would claim
 At 10 pounds, when I was born, I didn't give her no pain
 Although through the years I gave her her fair share
annotations.annotation:
Although a big baby, Jay Z miraculously didn’t give his mother pain during her labor; when Hova started selling drugs and became a criminal, though, he surely caused his mother a lot of pain.



In Decoded, he writes:

My mother didn’t talk about it a lot, but she was scared for me when I really hit the streets.

annotations.text: I gave her her first real scare, I made up for birth when I got here
annotations.annotation:
Hova probably refers to when he was almost shot to death on the streets while dealing. Referring to a later track on the album, “Moment of Clarity”:

Three shots couldn’t touch me, thank God for that

He could also just refer to the times he was beat up or came home late at night.

annotations.text: Was a kid torn apart once his pop disappeared
annotations.annotation: JAY-Z had a very hard time when his father left, hating him for a very long time.  Only recently has JAY-Z said publicly that he forgives his father.  Hov’s father leaving may have played a role in JAY-Z starting to drug deal because he was without a father figure in his life.

annotations.text:
I went to school, got good grades, could behave when I wanted
 But I had demons deep inside that would raise when confronted
annotations.annotation:
Jay attended Brooklyn’s George Westinghouse High School, which was the same school Biggie and Busta Rhymes went to. Despite being one of the most dangerous schools in New York, Jigga avoided problems by spending his time in the school’s cafeteria, where he practiced his rap skills by freestyling to beats pounded out on the table. Westinghouse teacher Salvador Contes said:

You would always see him in the same spot when you walked into the cafeteria, if you walked in on the left side

Unfortunately, Jay’s deep anger at his father often overshadowed his best attempts to behave.

annotations.text: Shawn was a very shy child growing up.
annotations.annotation:
He was very quiet and dressed nice form what I remember” said Brooklyn correction officer Carlos R. Martínez, who studied with Jay at Westinghouse.

He was a clever rapper, he did his thing on the low, very humble” recalls music producer Billy Valdez, who also attended Westinghouse.

annotations.text: He was into sports, and a funny story is at 4 he taught himself how to ride a bike. A two-wheeler at that, isn't that special?
annotations.annotation:
And at age six, he learned to do wheelies!

From Vibe (2003):

I was four years old but I remember that morning clearly. As my mom left for work, she told me to wait till she got home to practice riding my bike. My uncle had promised to put training wheels on the second bike I’d received from my cousin, but he hadn’t gotten around to it. Me being the younger of four kids, I was determined to be independent and not spoiled (Although my family will tell you that I am the latter.) I took the bike outside, and from 10 a.m. to 5pm. taught myself how to ride without training wheels. Because I was so small my whole block in Brooklyn was watching in amazement. It was my first feeling of being famous.

And from O Magazine in 2009:

I was too short to reach the pedals, so I put my legs through the V of the frame. I was famous. The little kid who could ride the ten-speed.

annotations.text: But I noticed a change in him when me and my husband broke up.
annotations.annotation:
More from O Magazine (emphasis ours):


Oprah: [Y]our father left when you were 11. When you look back at that, what did your 11-year-old self feel?

Jay-Z: Anger. At the whole situation. Because when you’re growing up, your dad is your superhero. Once you’ve let yourself fall that in love with someone, once you put him on such a high pedestal and he lets you down, you never want to experience that pain again. So I remember just being really quiet and really cold. Never wanting to let myself get close to someone like that again. I carried that feeling throughout my life, until my father and I met up before he died.

annotations.text: Now, all the teachers couldn't reach me
annotations.annotation:
On school Jay told Oprah he was “bored and distracted.”

In 1980 Jay-Z had a teacher who did inspire him, but the event of his father leaving late that year, or early-1981 numbed him and changed his perspective on school. His sixth-grade teacher Renee Rosenblum-Lowden, who taught him at I.S. 318 in Brooklyn helped Shawn read at a 12th Grade level. He told Teen People in 1999 that “I met someone who helped turn my life around, a very special English teacher.” In 2010 he repeated his sentiments for Miss Lowden, saying:

She must have seen something in me, and she gave me this attention and this love for words.

The line also recalls 2Pac’s on “If I Die 2nite:”

Addicted to drama so even mama couldn’t raise me
Even the preacher and all my teachers couldn’t reach me

annotations.text: So, with that disdain in my membrane
annotations.annotation:
Jay’s disdain and sense of abandonment led him to sell drugs.

This line is a play on Cypress Hill’s most notable phrases: “Insane in the membrane”.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RijB8wnJCN0

annotations.text: Then DeHaven introduced me to the game
annotations.annotation:
DeHaven Irby, a former associate of Jay-Z who got him involved with selling cocaine. The two eventually grew up apart after fighting:

So fuck DeHaven for caving, that’s why we don’t speak

annotations.text: Spanish Jose introduced me to 'caine, I'm a hustler now
annotations.annotation:
Spanish Jose was a friend of DeHaven, who talked about this in a later interview saying that Jay and him weren’t affiliated in any kind

Spanish Jose, who he mentions a lot in his songs, was a friend of mine. Jay didn’t have no affiliation to Spanish Jose.

But since he dealt drugs in Marcy Projects, Hova probably looked up to him as some sort of inspiration while growing up and eventually became a hustler just like Jose.

annotations.text: My self-esteem went through the roof, man, I got my swag
annotations.annotation: During 2011’s “Otis” Jay claimed to have popularized the term “swag”. His first use was in 2001 on “All I Need”. Clearly, he was aware of the term even before this mention, as this track deals with his teenage years.

annotations.text: Got a Volvo from this girl when her man got bagged
annotations.annotation:
“Bagged” is a slang for being captured by the police (and thus sent to jail). These are the lies Jay had to tell to his mom and other friends who were unaware of his drug dealing to explain his sudden wealth.

We know from “Blueprint (Momma Loves Me)” that this girl was named Valencia.

annotations.text:
Plus I hit my momma with cash from a show that I had
 Supposedly, knowin' nobody paid Jaz wack-ass
annotations.annotation:
Since Hova was making money from drugs and his mother didn’t know about it, he used rap as a cover early on to explain where he got the cash since he didn’t have a job.

Jaz-O was Jay-Z’s mentor but they had a falling out; Jay-Z uses this line to take a shot at Jaz by not only referring to him as “wack” but also saying that during that time period no promoter or club owner would have paid Jaz for a performance which meant that Jaz himself obviously couldn’t have paid Jay-Z as his co-performer.

annotations.text:
I'm gettin' ahead of myself; by the way, I could rap
 But that came second to me movin' this crack
 "Gimme a second, I swear," I would say about my rap career
 'Til '96 came, niggas, I'm here;
annotations.annotation:
In a brilliant display of meta-parallelism, Jay-Z’s recounting of his time dealing drugs distracts him from describing his rap career just as actually dealing drugs had kept him too busy to rap

Since his mic skills were not providing the financial security that hustling could give him, he always put dealing first until he released his debut album Reasonable Doubt in 1996. As he’d recall in Heart Of The City:

I thought I told you characters I’m not a rapper
Can I live? I told you in ‘96

annotations.text: Goodbye!
annotations.annotation: JAY-Z is saying goodbye to his old life of drug dealing and living in the Marcy Projects.  He finally “made it” in the rap game and no longer has to live the way that he did.  Hip-Hop is able to financially support him and get him out of the environment he was forced to grow up in.

annotations.text: Shawn used to be in the kitchen, beating on the table and rapping until the wee hours of the morning.
annotations.annotation:
Kitchen table, that’s where I honed my skills

As his mother explains here, Jay’s musical talents were first displayed in their Brooklyn home. His hands created a simple beat for him to practise his rhyming patterns over.

I would just sit at the table, bang on it, and write these rhymes all day long. I remember this one, it was pretty good [laughs]. It was almost like foretelling what would happen. ‘I’m the King of Hip-Hop, renewed like Reebok, the King of the lock, with words so provocative, as long as I live … I didn’t view the hours that I sat at the table as working hard. It was something I loved to do, so it didn’t come hard to me. I figured nothing would come out of it.

annotations.text: And then I bought him a boom box, and his sisters and brothers said he would drive them nuts. But that was my way to keep him close to me and out of trouble.
annotations.annotation:
Boom Boxes were particularly popular in the early hip hop community, which is why it makes sense for Jay’s mother to buy him one, knowing his passion for rapping.

She tried to stay connected to him by supporting his passion for music, she didn’t want him to turn to crime but it was already too late.

annotations.text:
Goodbye to the game, all the spoils, the adrenaline rush
 Your blood boils you in the spot, knowin' cops could rush
annotations.annotation:
Between each verse, Jay-Z recounts phases in his life; the third verse deals with his transition from drug dealer to commercial rapper.

Jay-Z’s run as a street hustler spanned 14 years–in his late teens, he delved into drug-peddling but was convinced to stop by hip-hop producer Clark Kent. Jay turned to music instead and in 1994 he established Roc-A-Fella Records alongside Damon Dash and Kareem Burke. The label served as an outlet for Jay-Z to independently release his debut album Reasonable Doubt, which received widespread acclaim from critics and solidified his standing in hip-hop.

In an October 2013 interview with Vanity Fair, Jay elaborated on his drug-dealing past:

I was a drug dealer. To be in a drug deal, you need to know what you can spend, what you need to re-up. […] Things you can get in easily to get out of [that] life. At some point, you have to have an exit strategy, because your window is very small; you’re going to get locked up or you’re going to die.

annotations.text: No two days are alike except the first and fifteenth, pretty much
annotations.annotation: The first and fifteenth of every month are like the Sabbath of the Bone Thugsian calendar; these are the days government welfare checks are delivered, so drug dealers on those days know that they’re going to be able to sell a lot of drugs (this is the only consistent and stable feature of a drug dealer’s life)

annotations.text: Hustlers, we don't sleep, we rest one eye up
annotations.annotation:
As he made clear in his earlier song “Can I Live”, for Jay, selling drugs was just not a desirable career because it causes insomnia.

So I keep one eye open like C-B-S

This is also a double entendre. On one end he doesn’t sleep and keeps one eye open because he is always looking out for the cops as a dope dealer. The second meaning is hustlers (as in people on the grind/entrepreneurs) never sleep because they have one eye looking out for the next opportunity or the next deal.

annotations.text:
And the drought will define a man when the well dries up
 You learn the worth of water without work
 You thirst 'til you die, yup!
annotations.annotation:
Hova talks about cocaine as it’s water (A common slang in the drug dealing world), so when there’s a drought and the supply of drugs runs out it’s the time in which the real men stand out, those who were able to save some money and had other forms of hustling. Jay always considered himself man, as he said in Can I Live:

I know this game got valleys and peaks, expectation
For dips, for precipitation we stack chips, hardly
The youth I used to be, soon to see a mill'in
No more Big Willie, my game has grown: prefer you call me William

annotations.text:
And niggas get tied up for product
 And little brothers' ring fingers get cut up
 To show mothers they really got 'em
annotations.annotation:
This is a reference to Rich Porter, a drug dealer who rose to prominence in Harlem in the mid-80s. A month before Rich was murdered by his former friend Alpo Martinez, his 12-year-old brother was kidnapped on his way to school and then had his finger cut off in order to extort $500,000 in ransom money from Rich.

The 2002 film Paid in Full was based on Rich and his partners Azie Faison and Alpo Martinez.

annotations.text: This is the life I chose, or rather, the life that chose me
annotations.annotation:
A reference to the common saying “I didn’t choose the thug life, the thug life choose me”.
Hova spent much of his life trying to avoid the drug dealing life, but was forced to make end’s meet.

annotations.text:
If you can't respect that, your whole perspective is wack
 Maybe you'll love me when I fade to black
annotations.annotation:
Black is often associated to death or to an ending, just like in films when at the end of the movie the screen literally fades to blackness. The Black Album was supposed to be Hova’s last record, he’d have faded to black after the release. This was also the concept for the album cover; Jay’s image was supposed to be barely visible just like like a ghost fading into the dark.



Fade to Black is a 2004 documentary about the recording of this album and the Madison Square live concert.



The song comes full circle with this closing line who links back to the opening of the first verse:

They say “they never really miss you til you dead or you gone”
So on that note, I’m leaving after the song

annotations.text:
If you can't respect that, your whole perspective is wack
 Maybe you'll love me when I fade...
annotations.annotation:
These lines echo what Jay said in the opening lines of the track

They say ‘They never really miss you 'til you dead or you gone.’
So on that note, I’m leavin' after the song

Jay’s lyrics fade out before he can finish the line he was repeating, emphasising his disappearance and making the listener really feel how uncomfortable it is to have him go.

lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Yo, fuck all the glamours and glitz, I plan to get rich
I'm from New York and never was a fan of the Knicks
And I'm all about expanding my chips
You mad 'cause I was in the van with your bitch
With both hands on her tits
Corleone hold the throne, that you know in your heart
I got style plus the way that I be flowing is sharp

Counting G stacks and rocking ice that glow in the dark
Forever hottie hunting
Trigger temper, I'm quick to body something

I fuck around and throw three in your chest and flee to my rest

I stopped hanging around y'all
'Cause niggas like you be praying on my downfall
Hoping I flop, hoping I stop

Or be on the street corner with a pipe, smoking the rock

annotations.text: I'm from New York and never was a fan of the Knicks
annotations.annotation: This here is a double entendre. Big L is referring both to his hometown ’s basketball team, New York Knicks, and Nickle bags, which are small amount of drugs (Usually weed) sold in a bag. Big

annotations.text:
Corleone hold the throne, that you know in your heart
 I got style plus the way that I be flowing is sharp
annotations.annotation:
Big L often refers to himself as Corleone which is a reference to the Corleone family of The Godfather book and films. Also, the fact L’s last name was Coleman may have played a minor role in him deciding to dub himself Corleone.

Even though it’s expected of rappers to act as if they’re the best, every one of Big L’s rivals know that he’s better then they’ll ever be, due to his style and insane rapping ability. Hold the throne means being the number 1 in the rap game.

annotations.text:
A while back, I used to hustle, selling blow in the park
 Counting G stacks and rocking ice that glow in the dark
annotations.annotation:
Big L used to sell coke (blow) in St. Nicholas Park, near his boyhood home in Harlem

A typical drug exchange involves a buyer paying an upfront sum of money (G stack). This exchange took place at night due to the fact that Big L’s diamond jewelry (ice) is glowing.

annotations.text: I fuck around and throw three in your chest and flee to my rest
annotations.annotation:
Rappers love shooting three at people don’t they? In Hypnotize, Biggie says,

Dare I squeeze three at your cherry M-3.

L will play around with you, and shoot three bullets in your chest and will leave the scene to go back and kick it with his friends like nothing ever happened.

annotations.text:
I stopped hanging around y'all
 'Cause niggas like you be praying on my downfall
 Hoping I flop
annotations.annotation: Big L’s suggestion that only divine intervention could lead to his defeat echoes Biggie’s track “My Downfall”, a song which was released in 1997, the year before this freestyle

annotations.text: Only thing I haven't got is more stitches than you
annotations.annotation: I think L is refering to the idiom “Snitches get stitches” so only thing you got more than L is stitches cause he never snitched on anybody

annotations.text: Fucking punk, you ain't a leader, what? Nobody followed you
annotations.annotation: You are not a leader if you dont got followers

annotations.text: You was never shit, your mother should've swallowed you
annotations.annotation: This kinda joke is pretty played now but at the time it was more fresh like Big L was. Big L is telling you that you are useless that your mother should have swallowed the sperm you originated from. It’s a funnier way of saying that ‘you should have never been born.

annotations.text: And mad hoes, ask Beavis, I get nothing Butthead
annotations.annotation:
Beavis and Butthead was a popular MTV show in the early 1990’s

He’s saying he gets a lot of oral sex, as in, “I get nothing but head”. The “ask Beavis” isn’t supposed to be literal, just an opportunity to say “but head” and make it clever. Classic Big L right here, and proof that he’s the king of punchlines



This bar is so original and hilarious that the hosts, Stretch and Bobbito couldn’t help but burst out in laughter during the freestyle!

annotations.text: You ain't half as raw, you need to practice more
annotations.annotation: As seen on Fabolous' “I’m Raw”, “raw” is a catch-all phrase for badass or awesome.  In this case, Big L means his rhymes are raw whereas you need to spend more time working on yours

annotations.text: I throw slugs at idiots, no love for city cops
annotations.annotation:
To “throw slugs” means to shoot with a shotgun, or generally any gun; Big L will shoot fools (perhaps cops from the NYPD).

The hate Big L has towards these cops is perhaps due to infamous former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, who supported policies where police would target minorities (specifically blacks), hence Big L’s understandable disliking of law enforcement.

annotations.text: I'm making wonderful figures
annotations.annotation: he is making good money doing what he does best

annotations.text: (Yeah-yeah… Spit, some more) - Bobbito
annotations.annotation:
Robert “Bobbito” Garcia, also known as DJ Cucumber Slice and Kool Bob Love, is an American DJ, author, streetball player, streetball coach, and member of the Rock Steady Crew.

Was DJing in the radio where he spitted this on at the time.

annotations.text: Yo, check it, yo, my shit is hot like jerk chicken
annotations.annotation: Jerk is a style of cooking native to Jamaica, in which meat is dry-rubbed or wet marinated with a hot spice mixture called Jamaican jerk spice. Some historians believe it was originally developed by Maroons, African slaves who escaped into the wilds of Jamaica when the British captured the island from Spain in 1655.

annotations.text:
I was taught that if a nigga swing, swing right back
 Battle Corleone, why do a stupid thing like that?
annotations.annotation:
Big L was raised in a household which taught its children to fight back with equal or greater force and to never accept being pushed around. Everyone knows that Big L is always willing fight, so he questions the thoughtless decisions of his enemies when they challenge him.

Battle in rap terminology often refers to battle rapping which is formally a non-physical form of fighting.

Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer is a fictional reindeer created by Robert Lewis

May

annotations.annotation:
Herb McGruff, also known as McGruff, is a rapper, first seen on L’s Lifestylez of da Poor and Dangerous album and often freestyled with L.

McGruff and Big L are good friends are chill together, smoking weed (puff izzy). He’s down to help L take beat up punks who want to start shit with them.

annotations.text: (Brrrrrrrrrrr!)
annotations.annotation: The sound of a “birdcall”, used to let other drug dealers in the area know if you spot undercover cops.

annotations.text: What happened to that boy? (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
“Clap” is an onomatopoeia for the sound of a gunshot: POP!

Birdman is widely rumored to have paid for the 1997 murder of the rapper Yella Boy, who was in the rap group U.N.L.V., a group Baby had released from his Cash Money label.

While there are all sorts of wild theories for the motive, the most reliable-looking analysis of the rumor comes from Amoeba Music blogger Eric Brightwell, who writes:

U.N.L.V. were let go from Cash Money but didn’t go quietly. Yella Boy supposedly pistol-whipped Baby and shot holes in one of his trucks as it was parked in front of the Melpomene projects. In April, after having bought some dope from a certain D-boy, Yella Boy was shot and killed in his vehicle while parked near Washington and Dryades. He was only 22 years old. Cash Money moved on.

annotations.text: Which explains why I'm worth my weight in gold
annotations.annotation:
In one way, Malice is such an excellent hustler that he has value to the community. On the other hand, Malice dealt so much that the amount of cash he carries equals his body weight’s value in gold. How real is this? Actually, very:

Current price of gold: $1,679
Average body weight: 200 lb
Total value: $4,896,971.40

This comes close to the expected net worth of Malice! Ballin'!

annotations.text: I'm known for the flip of that cocaína
annotations.annotation: “Flipping” is  selling, coca-ina is Spanish for “cocaine” Malice’s claim to fame is his legendary drug dealing.

annotations.text: I'm heavy in the street like the 7-Serie' Beemer, man
annotations.annotation:
7-series BMW:



He’s referencing the massive size of this particular class of sedan, as well as its cachet due to its high cost. It’s both a direct and indirect comparison, in that he commands respect, so he is like a car which commands respect as well but is also literally heavy in the streets.

annotations.text:
I'm the reason that your block is vacant
 Malicious will hit you just to make a statement, bitch
annotations.annotation:
Micro: Your block is vacant because everyone is afraid of Malice and he’s killed your whole team.

Macro: Drug dealing and the violent crime that trailed in its wake helped destroy the urban core of your city, leading white citizens (with $) and eventually everyone else to flee. See, e.g., Detroit.

Malice, the rapper of this verse, goes by “Malicious” when he’s feeling kinda adjectivey

annotations.text: Stunna and Patty Cake, the worldwide pusher (Let's get this money, nigga! Let's get this money!)
annotations.annotation:
Malice, the other rapper in Clipse, is the one that raps “Patty Cake, patty cake, I’m the bakers man”.  “Patty Cake” is a reference to “Grindin”, which contains the words:

Patty Cake, patty cake, I’m the baker’s man/
I bake them cakes as fast as I can"

annotations.text: Been shitting up bricks,
annotations.annotation:
A play on the banality “to shit a brick” i.e. to be rendered metaphorically (and perhaps literally) constipated by anxiety

Here, he means selling bricks of cocaine to crack dealers, ahem, on a regular basis. Drug mules also pass bags of cocaine through their bodies, literally “shitting” cocaine for days.

annotations.text: Boss of the ghetto with the round-shape cookie
annotations.annotation:
A quarter-pound of cocaine is called a “cookie” since oftentimes – as is the case here – it comes in a round-shaped brick.

Make no mistake: he may be on top, but Birdman is very much still running the day to day of his drug game and raking in the profits.

annotations.text: If I don't go to jail, nigga, birds gon' flock (Brrr! Brrr!)
annotations.annotation: In the music video, Birdman refers to the flocking of birds (“the birdcall”) as the hood’s signal that he’s around

annotations.text: Nigga sitting on the toilet, bitch, get off the pot!
annotations.annotation: Continuing the “shitting up bricks” imagery, Birdman wants his supplier (imagine how much of a baller you must be to supply Birdman!) to give him the drugs he’s been holding onto (“sittin' on the toilet”)

annotations.text: Bought mami a fly Benz, the wide, skinny lips
annotations.annotation:
He bought his (probably Latin) girlfriend a very nice Mercedes-Benz

The rims have wide and skinny “lips” – the curved, inward-facing part of the rim from the end of the spokes to the outer edge of the wheel, which implies that he’s rolling on over-sized rims (visit CarGenius.com™ for more info)

annotations.text:
It ain't nothing to a baller, baby
 Pay the cost, big money, heavyweight, Birdman, hood boss, baby
annotations.annotation:
A true baller already knows the life, ducking the police and living large every day. His violent, yet luxurious life is to be expected.

Birdman does not have to look at the price tag; sitting pretty with $150 million, the owner can always afford it. Like a mob don, he is in control of the Magnolia Projects drug game, cashing in and running the show. Even while rich, he can stand to make more.

annotations.text: Make Corleone come out and the black crow'll touch you
annotations.annotation: If provoked, Birdman will become like Corleone, the mafia boss in The Godfather, and the previously unspecified birds will be black crows, heralding death.

annotations.text: [Verse 3: Pusha T]
Uugh!
annotations.annotation: Pusha’s classic adlib

annotations.text: Uugh!
annotations.annotation: Pusha’s classic adlib

annotations.text:
I put this on my Lord:
 My niece was four when she felt chinchilla
annotations.annotation:
Rappers always talk about taking care of their family, wanting to make money to help out their loved ones

Pusha T is going one step further: he’s doing such a good job that his nieces are spoiled and get expensive Chinchilla furs at 4 years old

From the video:

annotations.text: That made fiends rise from the dead like "Thriller"
annotations.annotation: Addicts “rise from the dead” at night after being out of sight/withdrawing all day like the zombies from Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” video to buy from Pusha.

annotations.text:
Gangster, hustler
 At night, still found time to kiss my mother
annotations.annotation:
Pusha still runs the streets as a thug and mob boss, but kicks it with his mom when she calls. He’s hard, but soft at heart for family.

This is similar to Lil Wayne’s “Knuck if you Buck”

I’ll be there momma, they know who I am momma/
I’m still your little boy, but to them I’m the man, momma

annotations.text:
Live like I'm dreaming, kick my feet up
 Gun poked my waist, remind me of my demon, so
annotations.annotation:
Even with his success, Pusha can never relax.  His gun is a physical impediment to him “kicking his feet up”

His gun reminds him of his “demon”, meaning his “dark side” (and also his “ding-dong”). The gun poking his waist could be a metaphor to Paul’s thorn in his side, which kept him humble and reminded him of his own personal demons. The Clipse are deeply rooted in Christian rap lyrics and song titles.
