annotations.text: [Produced by Timbaland]
annotations.annotation:
Timbo’s beat was almost entirely structured by the sample – Elsie Mae’s “Whole Lot of Lovin'”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-NgnB4Ld9MM#t=6

annotations.text: Bentley-driver, nigga
annotations.annotation:
Another vehicle of choice for Jay-Z in the late-90’s was a drop-top Bentley Azure or a Bentley Continental T. The British manufacturer supplied the rich and famous with luxury automobiles which were largely hand-built.

NO, that’s that Continental T
The only car that fit intercontinental me, not guilty

annotations.text:
Get this shit jumpin' ike eight blacks, four crackers—
 Get your ass jumped
annotations.annotation:
“Get this shit jumping” usually means to get a party started but it also has a double meaning to initiate conflict hence the jumping describes the mass hysteria of people jumping out their lounge chairs/off the dance floor(or in general anywhere just jumping from being startled) to escape the fighting/shooting.

He uses a play on words to compare that to 4 white guys getting jumped (beat up) by 8 black guys

annotations.text:
Go against Jigga? Your ass is dense
 I'm about a dollar—what the fuck is fifty cents?
annotations.annotation:
This was a response to an unsigned 50 Cent’s radio hit “How to Rob” in which he listed all the artists he was going to rob, Hov included.

Hov first performed “It’s Hot” live at the 1999 Summer Jam, which he headlined. In an interview with Angie Martinez in 2002 he explained how he was backstage with 50 before he spat the line:

[I told him] ‘Yo, I respect the record, yeah I liked that record, it was hot. But you know I gotta spank you dog!’ That was the conversation. [50 responded] ‘No doubt, do your thing!’ Then it was peace. History … What I respect though is that conversation. It was real.

Hov would reference the infamous incident on “A Star is Born” in 2009.

annotations.text: Hova's like Noah: Keep two in the truck
annotations.annotation: Prophet Noah’s Ark was a gigantic wooden vessel in which Noah saved every kind of animal from extinction by preserving one male and one female from each kind respectively from the great flood. Jay illustrate that similarly to prophet Noah (even if just numerically); he keeps 2 guns in his vehicle.

annotations.text: I'm six-oh-oh, you're three hundred C-E
annotations.annotation:
Like his preference for a Range Rover Mark II 4.6 over a 4.0, Jay-Z understands it is the sutble differences in vehicle choice that maketh a man more baller than the next. The 1990’s Mercedes-Benz 600 SL series delivered 389HP, while the 300 was only 190HP.



The luxury Benz 600 series is also known as the forerunner of the modern Maybach marque, another vehicle which Hov is well-acquainted with.



The Mercedes 600 series would stay a favorite vehicle choice for Hov for many years – he references the car on Jigga That Nigga in 2001 and later on ‘03 Bonnie & Clyde in 2003.

annotations.text:
You wanna play Jigga, nigga? What you drank, fluid?
 Got a full tank, now you wanna pull rank?
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z has a few lines in which he talks about people going crazy from drinking gas.  This is probably a play on the phrase “being gassed up,” which is like having somebody trick you or not acting like your normal self.

On “Dead Presidents” he says “little monkey niggas turned gorillas/stopped in the station and filled up on octane and now they’re not sane”

He basically means, “you wanna start with me? What are you, drunk? That’s not a good idea!”

annotations.text: Thirty-eight revolve like a Sun 'round the Earth
annotations.annotation:
A .38, also known as a .38 Special, is a gun cartridge made by Smith & Wesson, primarily used in revolvers.
Also, the Earth revolves around the Sun.

annotations.text: Fuck losing weight
annotations.annotation:
A common trope in rap: losing weight vs. gaining weight. Success means “gaining weight”, struggle means “losing weight”

It’s intended literally – lack of money means lack of food, and metaphorically – lighter pockets. It further resonates as a loss of means (where money is the end), since “weight” means a large quantity of drugs

annotations.text: Moving cakes
annotations.annotation: Transporting blocks of cocaine; moving cakes, like eating cakes, can counteract weight loss

annotations.text:
Cop a car, new estate
 Nah, fuck it, get the beef and brocs, blue and gray
annotations.annotation:
Butter vs. Guns situation: he could buy a car or house with the money he earns, but instead he’s gonna reinvest in settling some scores (get the beef), buy some gray Timberland boots (aka broccolis), etc..

Also a pun on beef and broccoli, a ubiquitous Chinese dish..

Notice the hit / hit homophone

Cam explains why she is so loyal: when she wanted to fix up her act, he helped her with it

Of course, when she wanted a “fix” of drugs, he gave her that, too (where there’s a homophone involved, Cam is happy to oblige)

annotations.annotation:
Cam recounts a “hit” his troubled young charge did for him:

Remember “Money” from across the street? He’s the fellow selling drugs on Cam’s turf…

Well, she goes to see him. She french kisses him and even diddles his ding-dong. While stroking it she coyly inquires if he knows Cam'ron. “Yes,” he tells her. “Well, don’t fuck with his money,” she says. Then she steps back and empties her six-shot revolver into him – an amazing sight to behold

annotations.text:
This here is
 The end of Tha Carter Two, people
annotations.annotation: The track that closes what is widely regarded as Wayne’s best work and you can easily see why. This also marks the end of the intro and closing type tracks on the The Carter album series. The first one “Tha Carter” featured similar racks with “Walk in” and “Walk Out”. There are also a lot of other similarities between the 2 albums in terms of subject and both launched Wayne and Ca$h Money Records to stardom as he self-proclaimed himself   “The Best Rapper Alive” and no one seemed to doubt that.

annotations.text: I spent a G on these frames, but my vision is priceless
annotations.annotation: Brilliant wordplay from Wayne. He spent $1000 on his glasses (an astronomical sum), but his musical vision (i.e. his innovative style) is so good and unique it couldn’t be bought. It also implies that he can make enough money from his musical vision that he can buy something priceless (e.g. art, cars etc)

annotations.text: You catch my drift, man, you better be Peyton
annotations.annotation:
Lyrics sites say “Peyton,” i.e. you better have good aim with your gun as Peyton Manning has with a football

But as Wayne is from New Orleans and this is about catching, it’s more likely a reference to New Orleans Saints wide receiver Jerome Pathon:

annotations.text: I'm in this bitch throwin' up the "17th" sign
annotations.annotation: Wayne’s in the streets repping for New Orleans' 17th Ward, which includes Wayne’s hometown Hollygrove hood

annotations.text:
That Tec-11, AK-47, one Beretta
 Ready for whatever, tell them pussy niggas, "Come together"
annotations.annotation:
Basically, Wayne is strapped so just like T.I. he feels that he is prepared and ready for whatever conflict is toward him. He proves this just by listing a few of the guns he has on him for emphasis.

Therefore he is asking his enemies to come together because:


He’d rather finish his beef quickly since he’s ready for it rather than deal with each individually.
He is simply stating he wants to fight them because alone they are weak, and he is so powerful and ready he can take them all at once.

annotations.text: Six feet under flowers
annotations.annotation: Wayne is gonna kill you and bury you. People are standardly buried 6 feet in the ground.

annotations.text: Only history I know is Benjamin Franklin
annotations.annotation:
The only history Wayne is familiar with is the money



Benjamin Franklin is the man on the hundred dollar bill.

annotations.text:
And since the future ain't promised to no one
 I live every day like this is the sure one
annotations.annotation: There are no guarantees in life, so Wayne lives every day to the fullest. The “Sure Day” is what Muslims call the Day of Judgment – (From Surah 78.39: “That is the Sure Day, so whoever desires may take refuge with his Lord”)

annotations.text: Running 'cross the porch, in the attic there's a fortune
annotations.annotation:
The same rats and roaches who were people buying drugs in the line before are now actual rats and roaches on the porch of Wayne’s house

But the ground floor is kept purposely decrepit because he’s got tons of money hidden upstairs where people wouldn’t think to look after seeing the front of the house

annotations.text:
And I'm Blooded—soo-woo!
 And I'm Blooded—soo-woo!
annotations.annotation:
“Soo-woo” is the call used by the Bloods to acknowledge each other or warn of danger/cops

The call has been used by a number of artists,
 including The Game, Rich Gang, Chief Keef, Ronny J, Fat Joe, Tech N9ne, G Herbo, Gucci Mane and many more.

For more soowisms, see “Lollipop (remix)”

annotations.text: Stand at the top like a tack in the roof
annotations.annotation: Wayne will stick around at the top of the rap game, kind of like a tack that bolts a shingle to a roof. Incidentally, he would later extend the roof metaphor by calling his next major mixtape No Ceilings

annotations.text: Talk tough 'til I knock off your kuf'
annotations.annotation: A kufi is a traditional African head cover that is often worn by black Muslims in the U.S. – Wayne’s saying he will knock your head off

annotations.text: And I own my team, I'm like a Maloof
annotations.annotation: The Maloofs own the Sacramento Kings (NBA) and their sister team, the Sacramento Monarchs (WNBA). Wayne’s “team” is the Young Money label, which he owns (sort of)

annotations.text: Just like Young Jeezy in a lima-bean 'Ghini
annotations.annotation: This shoutout to Jeezy (and his veggie-colored Lamborghini) is appropriate, since this song uses the beat to his “I Love It”

annotations.text:
Dopeboy fresh from my fitted to my DC's
 All red, so these hoes know who we be's (B's up)
annotations.annotation: Back before Weezy launched his own signature line of skater shoes with Supra Footwear, he occasionally rocked (and namedropped – see, e.g.,  “About All That” from 2006’s Like Father, Like Son) the footwear of rival skateboard apparel company DC.

annotations.text: We be's Bloods—we B's
annotations.annotation: “We are Bloods, we B[lood]s”, which sounds repetitive, except Wayne means to play with the homonym of “be’s” (“be,” used incorrectly on purpose in place of “are”) and “B’s” (short for “Bloods”)

annotations.text: Popeye flow, y'all niggas Sweet Peas
annotations.annotation: His songs are masculine and tough like Popeye, these other rappers are soft like Sweet Pea, the baby in “Popeye”

annotations.text:
And I'm Blooded—soo-woo!
 And I'm Blooded—soo-woo!
annotations.annotation:
“Soo-woo” is the call used by the Bloods to acknowledge each other or warn of danger/cops

The call has been used by a number of artists,
 including The Game, Rich Gang, Chief Keef, Ronny J, Fat Joe, Tech N9ne, G Herbo, Gucci Mane and many more.

For more soowisms, see “Lollipop (remix)”

annotations.text: They like it so much, they say they write that
annotations.annotation:
This is a reference to Gillie the Kid, a Philadelphia rapper who claimed to have written most of The Carter for Wayne

Weezy sympathizes with Gillie; The Carter was so good, a lot of children probably imagined that they had written it..

annotations.text:
Barking at the dog, but I don't bite back
 I ain't CPR, I ain't bringing they life back
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne is referencing the idiom “Barking dog never bites”. Meaning that the people who claim they will take him down will never actually do so.

Wayne doesn’t bark though, so if he were to respond he would just bite. However that would get them too much attention, Wayne is not here to bring their career back, CPR being a life saving technique. So he just ignores them.

Also Wayne is saying he doesn’t bite anyone’s style.

annotations.text: CBR
annotations.annotation: A Honda CBR Bike

annotations.text: Skittles on my wrist, yeah, nigga, the bright pack
annotations.annotation: Skittles refers to his colorful jewelry. “Bright pack” sounds like it would be a type of Skittles (like “tropical”), but it turns out that’s not true.

annotations.text: Air Force fly
annotations.annotation:
#Double entendre
His Air Force trainers are so ‘Fly’ (cool) they’re like a 111.2 million dollar jet meaning they’re extremly fly
and they’re coloured black or ‘night jet’. Also, when the ‘Real’ Airforce flys, Wayne would be a night jet, a very elite aircraft.



The night jet’s official name is the Lockheed F-117 Nighthawk. Interesting fact this plane is nicknamed Wobblin' Goblin but whats it to a goon?



probally nothing!

annotations.text:
The dash say 2, y'all know I'm gon' try
 Cop pull me over, y'all know I'm gon' lie
annotations.annotation: If the speedometer goes past 200, you already know Wayne is going to see what the car is capable of.

annotations.text: Niggas throwing darts, never hit the bullseye
annotations.annotation: “Darts” is used here to mean rhymes in a rap battle and/or bullets; Wayne asserts that other rappers are poor marksmen

annotations.annotation:
In every corner of the globe, where there’s a Blood, you will hear him repping “soo woo”. This references Young Jeezy’s line in the original “I Love It”:

Been around the world, it’s the same ‘caine

annotations.text:
I ain't worrying 'bout you, I'm just trying do me
 Last album did two, I'm just trying do three
annotations.annotation:
He sold two million copies last time, this time he’s aiming higher

Wayne is alluding to Jay-Z’s line in “Heart of the City”:

Damn, little man, I’m just trying to do me
If the record’s two mil, I’m just trying to do three

annotations.text: It's Loso in case you ain't know so baby
annotations.annotation: Tiresome rhyme that shows up in basically every Fab verse (“Loso” is short for “el Faboloso”, which means “Fabolous” in Spanish)

annotations.text: Fake ass Milli Vanilli muhfuckas
annotations.annotation: Milli Vanilli got caught lip synching a performance of “Girl You Know It’s True”

annotations.text: But I only smoke Dutches I don't feel these muhfuckas
annotations.annotation:
Dutches and Phillies are types of cigars used for wrapping blunts

Fabolous doesn’t “feel these” (rushed to sound like “Phillies”) other rappers, much as he – preferring Dutches – doesn’t care for Phillies blunts

annotations.text: You gon run, prolly pull ya achilly muhfucka
annotations.annotation:
You’re a coward, so you’re going to run away, and you’ll probably pull your Achilles tendon doing so

Also, an answer to “you gon pull … what?” above – i.e. you’ll pull your Achilles tendon instead of a gun

annotations.text:
Till' these muhfuckas know that I Am Legend
Call me Big Willy muhfucka
annotations.annotation:
“Big willy” is a slang term for being a big baller that was popular back in the day.  Will Smith was in the movie I Am Legend, so Fabolous is similar to Smith insofar as he’s also a Will (or Willy) and he’s a legend

Will Smith also did a Remix of A Milli which samples the words ‘Big Willy’ instead of ‘A Milli’

annotations.text: I'm wit Freck Billi and some West Philly muhfuckas
annotations.annotation:
Freck Billionaire is a West Philly rapper in Fab’s group “Street Family.” This continues the reference to Will Smith, who is west Philadelphia born and raised…

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hBe0VCso0qs

annotations.text: And you can be a vic if you get silly muhfucka
annotations.annotation:
If you provoke Fab, he’ll turn you into a “vic” (murder victim)

Also a pun on V.I.C.’s song “Get Silly”

annotations.text: So if you feelin froggy leap that lily muhfucka
annotations.annotation: Back in the day, if you thought somebody was trying to start a fight and you were goading them to man up and do it, you would say “if you’re feeling froggy, jump!” Another great pun from Loso

annotations.text: And I'll serve yo fruity ass like Wet Willies muhfucka
annotations.annotation: Wet Willies is a chain of bars with locations in several cities in the southeastern united states. They are known for serving frozen daiquiris etc.

annotations.text: Hill Billy
annotations.annotation:
The Clintons are Hillary and Bill, and hill billies are viewed as uneducated people with poor health, low income, and buck teeth.
(At least they have a tooth paste for their kind!)

annotations.text: Red rover red rover send them bitches over here
annotations.annotation:
This is a play on the classic playground game “Red rover” where people would challenge the other team “red rover red rover send [some member of the other team] over”

Here he’s beckoning for women instead

annotations.text: So I can pick and roll like Stockton and Malone
annotations.annotation:
John Stockton and Carl Malone played for the Utah Jazz and could execute a mean pick and roll

Fab’s version of this is to “pick” a girl and “roll” with her back to his place

But if you ain't tryna bone you'll be talkin to the tone
annotations.annotation: If Simone clearly doesn’t want to “bone” (have sex/rhymes with her name), then she’s going to be hearing a dial tone pretty soon because Fab will hang up on her

Having the characteristics of the Sylvester Stallone character

annotations.annotation: Jim Jones is a rapper.  To “jones” is to desperately want something.  Fabolous isn’t going to jones for a girl because he has plenty of them

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WWqcMhv_Hts

annotations.text:
Early May
 A few days 'til my birthday date
annotations.annotation: Ghost was born on May 9, 1970, which means he will be turning 40 next year. He’s the second youngest member of the Wu, after Method Man. (Inspectah Deck was also born in 1970, but the exact date of his birth is unclear cf. “this style has no origins or birth date”)

annotations.text: Supreme Cliee-ente
annotations.annotation:
Español for Supreme Clientele, which is arguably Ghostface Killah’s best album. Released in 2000, 4 years after Ironman, his solo debut, it sold 700,000 copies at a time when other Wu Tang artists – remember U-God? – were churning out tripe

This was the album that prompted Freddie Foxx’s famous line: “I'mma save hip hop like Ghost saved the Wu”.

Apparently, when yayo is involved, Ghostface’s favorite rapper is…Ghostface

annotations.text: Toney with the Montana, I came to play
annotations.annotation:
A playful way to say that he, whose nickname is Pretty Toney, came with the “Montana” (cocaine), and wants to have a good time.

This is also a Scarface reference (Pacino’s character is Tony Montana)

annotations.text:
If y'all ladies was all mine I'd teach you well
 Free tales, sweet smells, eat well, hear bells
 Before you sleep, read your books like it was my fanmail
annotations.annotation:
Despite his disdain for these women, he can’t help but feel a caretaker’s instinct toward them. If any of them would just let him in, he’d help transform her into a respectable woman with parables, frankincense, a proper diet, Pavlovian techniques and reading material (consulted before bedtime, which is a study technique)

After her balanced, meditative day, the girl would be able to concentrate quite effectively on her nighttime reading…just as she concentrates on Ghostface’s fanmail — as a properly jealous girlfriend should — to see what his groupies have to say

annotations.text:
And no longer shut yourself in, taste the pain, the sorrow
 The sun'll shine and still come out tomorrow
annotations.annotation:
Ghost obviously feels sorry for these girls and their inability to love life

This line strongly implies that at some point, Ghostface Killah has seen Annie, having possibly been introduced to it by Meth

annotations.text:

 You know why? cause you's a
annotations.annotation: Brags about his brilliant raps (often described as “jewels”), laments the girls' burnt nose hairs as cocaine battlescars, and trails off – implying, but not arriving at, a conclusion: the cocaine-fueled ramblings of a conflicted genius

annotations.text: [Produced by RZA]
annotations.annotation:
Produced by none other than the ringleader of the Wu-Tang Clan, RZA, this song gives us a deep look and a walk through the lives of young men, struggling to get by day to day and hunting for riches in the concrete jungle of New York.

This light yet deceptively deep beat samples a beautifully playful piano segment from “As Long As I’ve Got You” by The Charmels.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gp9uZjPaB4w

The sample appears throughout the entire song. RZA tunes it up from F to F#.

The beat contains two distinct parts to it, with the introduction, being a heavily drum-oriented loop, sampling voices from the song mentioned above. This provides a smooth transition into the second loop, which is the backdrop for the rest of the song.

In the transition, RZA samples the beautiful piano melody, which is repeated throughout the entire song. You hear a faint bass, which compliments the aesthetic of being a light song, whereas the heavy drums provide contrast, creating an atmospheric heaviness to the entire song.

This beat breakdown is definitely worth watching.

annotations.text: [Intro: Raekwon & Method Man]
annotations.annotation:
*Raekwon: “‘C.R.E.A.M.’ did a lot for my career personally. It gave me an opportunity to revisit the times where that cream meant that much to us. So, yeah, when I think of this record it just automatically puts me back into ‘87/’88 where we were standing in front of the building. It’s cold outside. We didn’t care. We’re out there, all black on trying to make dollars. Just trying to make some money and trying to eat. Survive.

”This song, I remember writing to the beat a long time ago before we actually came out. That beat is old. That was probably like a ‘89 beat. RZA had it that long because he had a bunch of breaks. He had all kind of things and he was making beats back then, but we was just picking and that beat happened to always sit around and I would be like, ‘I want that beat, so don’t give that beat to nobody.’ And he kept his word and let me have it.

“Meth came up with the hook but our dude named Raider Ruckus, this was like Meth’s homeboy back then, like they was real close, he came up with the phrase ‘cash rules everything around me.’ So when he showed Meth what it was and was like, ‘Cash rules everything around me,’ Meth was like, ‘Word, you right!’ And turned it into a movie, and I came in later that day and heard it and co-signed it.”

annotations.text: What that nigga want, God?
annotations.annotation:
God/Gawd is East-coast slang for a good rapper/compadre; it was originally the term for men in the Five Percenters, an organization that Wu-Tang is a part of.

The group teaches that the “Original Blackman” is God and the “Original Blackwoman” is the planet Earth: “through the inner esoteric powers of the Gods and Earths, people can transform and possess their true potential”

Today a “G” is supposedly a gangster, but it originated from African-Americans calling each other G for God.

Also, Raekwon might be simply asking this to fellow Wu-Tang member, U-God.

annotations.text: Wu-Tang five finger shit, fam
annotations.annotation:
Three things here:

1) Wu Tang takes/steals/jacks/robs, as in “five finger discount”, but not necessarily just petty thefts, perhaps robberies as well, that’s why the Clan has to “look out for the cops”.  One of the acronyms for “Wu Tang” is “We Usually Take All Niggas' Garments”.



2) This is also a reference to the old martial arts flick “Five Fingers of Death”. Wu is known for its Kung-Fu-related rhymes, skits and references. This line refers to them gripping the microphone when they lyrically kill other rappers.



3) This might also be a reference to the Five Percenter Nation, which Raekwon is part of and often incorporates slang from that group in his raps (i.e the line prior to this one).

annotations.text:
Cash rules-
 Word up, two for fives over here, baby
 Word up, two for fives, niggas got garbage down the way
 Word up, know what I'm sayin'?
annotations.annotation: Two crack cocaine vials (containing a rock) for $5, a standard discounted price.  Obviously, of superior quality to the garbage sold down the street by the other guys, too.

annotations.text: Cash rules everything around me, C.R.E.A.M. get-
annotations.annotation:
C.R.E.A.M. is an acronym for “Cash Rules Everything Around Me” and has throughout the years become well-established slang for money.



Cream can also be slang for crack, but the Clan is strictly after that cash money. (And you should too, kids!)

Some also may see this line  as a reflection on the fact that in their world that they’ve gone into they’re ruled by cash and nothing more. This line was used to underline how they’re unable to make choices based off emotion, goals or point of views yet they’re blinded by their pimp of capitalism.

annotations.text: Cash rules everything around me
annotations.annotation:
In an interview with Complex, Raekwon explained how the phrase “C.R.E.A.M.” was born and who had the idea:

Meth came up with the hook but our dude named Raider Ruckus, this was like Meth’s homeboy back then, like they was real close, he came up with the phrase ‘cash rules everything around me.’ So when he showed Meth what it was and was like, ‘Cash rules everything around me,’ Meth was like, ‘Word, you right!’ And turned it into a movie, and I came in later that day and heard it and co-signed it.

annotations.text: [Verse 1: Raekwon]
annotations.annotation:
Rae first wrote a fictional story, but an undisclosed member of the Clan didn’t feel it and suggested he rewrite it. The rest is history, as Rae recounts in an interview with Peter Rosenberg.

http://youtu.be/rt1PfIUMxRs?t=4m25s

Raekwon got a Hip-Hop Quotable for this verse in The Source’s April 1994 issue.

annotations.text: I grew up on the crime side, the New York Times side
annotations.annotation:
Raekwon hails from Staten Island and grew up in the crime-ridden Park Hill projects—an area notorious for its murder rate, and defined by the crack epidemic of the early 1990s. A project regularly splashed across the front page of the established New York Times, Raekwon talked of growing up in Park Hill in a 2011 ARTE New York Minute feature:

Park Hill is a dangerous project. I grew up around drug dealers all my life. […] It’s a project where I learned to grow up fast. Park Hill was like one of the most hated projects in Staten Island. It was drugs, money, guns, prostitution, all that shit was going on when we was growing up.

In 2004’s The Wu-Tang Manual, RZA expanded on these lyrics:

He means the side of black life you always see reported in the newspaper—crime, death, murder. The side Rae and all of us grew up on.

Since the song’s debut in 1994, Raekwon’s opening lines have been recognized as some of the most iconic in hip-hop history. The Source’s April 1994 issue awarded this verse a “Hip-Hop Quotable.”

annotations.text: Stayin' alive was no jive
annotations.annotation:
Simply surviving that neighborhood is an accomplishment. “Jive” is 1970s slang for a joke; surviving the hood is not to be taken lightly.



This line and the previous one are a reference to “Stayin' Alive” by The Bee Gees:

“We can try to understand
The New York Times' effect on man”

annotations.text:
Had secondhands, Mom's bounced on old man
 So then we moved to Shaolin land
annotations.annotation:
Rae had second-hand clothing, his father was a heroin addict as said on “Can It Be All So Simple”, and his mom ended up leaving.

His father’s addiction certainly didn’t help their financial life; it might’ve been the impetus for both the second-hand clothing and the Shaolin (Staten Island) move.



Wu-Tang refers to their home borough, Staten Island, as “Shaolin” in reference to the Gordon Liu movie Shaolin and Wu Tang, which Wu-Tang is named after (when you grow up in a borough that smells like garbage, you develop a keen sense of imagination)

annotations.text: A young youth, yo, rockin' the gold tooth,
annotations.annotation: Alliteration on “young youth”. A young cat with the gold tooth – grills are a sign of status, yet bad for your teeth.

annotations.text: 'Lo goose
annotations.annotation:
‘Lo is short for Polo, and Goose means any jacket that is filled with down/goose feathers.

Raekwon is a known Polo head – he even wears Polo drawers – and you can peep him rocking a Polo Snow Beach jacket in the “Can It Be All So Simple” music video:



Goose jackets were hot back when Raekwon was a teenager, and they can be seen worn by Run-D.M.C. on the cover of their 1986 album, Raising Hell:



The goose jacket worn by Run DMC is called the V-Bomber Jacket made by Double Goose.

annotations.text: Only way I begin the G off was drug loot
annotations.annotation:
“G off” means to be propelled or for his life to start or get anywhere.
He’s saying money from drugs (“drug loot”) was the only way he began to improve his life to get out of his current environment.

RZA had this to say about this line in the Wu-Tang Manual:

The only decent living came from selling drugs

annotations.text: Pullin' out gats for fun
annotations.annotation:
Guns. The name derived from the Gatling gun, one of the earliest rapid-fire weapons in the history of warfare (1861).



Ironically, its inventor, Richard Gatling, thought that the “gat” would lead to fewer deaths by combat (he also never thought that his gun would be a slang rap term, so he wasn’t too good at predictions).

annotations.text:
But it was just a dream for the teen
 Who was a fiend,
annotations.annotation: Being a drug fiend was an obstacle between him and his dream. He was trying to make good money, but he was breaking one of the “Ten Crack Commandments” – Number 4 – Never get high on your own supply. No matter how much money he was making, he wasn’t getting ahead. This is why shortly after describing all he was doing, he mentions that his life got no better.

annotations.text: Started smokin' woolies at 16
annotations.annotation: Woolas, also known as “Wu-bangers”, are Dutch Masters or Philly Blunt Cigars stuffed with marijuana and sprinkled with crack cocaine.

annotations.text:
And runnin' up in gates and doin' hits for high stakes
 Makin' my way on fire escapes
annotations.annotation:
Raekwon recounts robbing and raiding trap houses; places that drug dealers sell out of.

RZA elaborates:

Rushing a known drug-selling spot and either jacking niggas for their loot or taking over the corner yourself. That’s high stakes. You might make a lot money or you might get killed.

Wu-Tang Manual

Also, the video for “C.R.E.A.M.” portrays Rae and another man exiting a window onto a fire escape.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bjZRAvsZf1g&feature=player_detailpage#t=48s

annotations.text: Stickin' up white boys in ball courts
annotations.annotation:
According to the RZA in The Wu-Tang Manual:

Back in the day, a lot of niggas from Park Hill went to New Dorp High School, where there was always racial tension.

annotations.text: My life got no better, same damn 'Lo sweater
annotations.annotation:
All that hard work just so he can sport the same brand he’s been wearing all along. This shows how his life isn’t improving, as he still has the same sweater he was proud of in his youth, but now he’s tired of it.

Without going as far as to call it a metaphor, Rae’s feelings towards the Polo sweater are similar to those he’s beginning to have towards the drug game.

annotations.text: Times is rough and tough like leather
annotations.annotation: A possible allusion to the Run-D.M.C. track “Tougher Than Leather”.

annotations.text:
Figured out I went the wrong route
 So I got with a sick-ass clique and went all out
annotations.annotation:
Because times are “rough and tough like leather” he recognizes that he isn’t on the right path in life.

RZA provides an explanation of the next line in the Wu-Tang Manual:

He’s moving up in the world getting with a well-connected drug ring and moving kilos of coke from international sellers.

“Sick-ass clique” refers to the Wu-Tang Clan.

annotations.text: Catchin' keys from 'cross seas
annotations.annotation: Importing “keys” (kilos) of cocaine from abroad; he’s found more lucrative enterprise with his new business partners.

annotations.text: Rollin' in MPV's,
annotations.annotation:
Notice the double entendre on “rolling”:


Rollin as in chilling and cruising in their whip.
Rollin as in rolling a joint/blunt.





An MPV is not exactly the most impressive car; the fact that he is reminiscing about getting to drive one is meant to underscore his humble beginnings. Though, as the second half of the line reveals, he was making $40,000 a week and could probably afford a better car, so it is possible that he drove the MPV for practical reasons, as elaborated below.



Mazda MPV’s were a popular hood car in the 80’s and early 90s, and was often used by drug dealers for practical reasons; the MPV has sliding doors on both sides, making it easy to get in and out of the car quickly. It also allowed for quite a bit of room for moving drugs and guns. In the Wu-Tang Manual, RZA described them as “the hottest minivan back then”.

Fun Fact: If you watch the video, you can see them jump out of an MPV.

annotations.text: Every week we made forty G's
annotations.annotation:
Raekwon and the clique he joined quickly began making money to the tune of $40,000 a week; coming out to over $2 million a year, which would be worth over $3 million in 2013 dollars.

They eatin'!

annotations.text: Yo, nigga, respect mine, or here go the TEC-9
annotations.annotation:
If you don’t respect Rae and the Clan, he and his Intratec TEC-DC9 semi-automatic handgun are going to get real mad.



The Intratec TEC-9 or TEC-DC9, is a blowback-operated semi-automatic pistol, chambered in 9×19mm Parabellum. It was designed by Intratec, an American offshoot of Interdynamic AB. The TEC-9 was made of inexpensive molded polymers and a mixture of stamped and milled steel parts which gave it the dubious distinction of being one of the most widely used “criminal” guns in the US. More than anything, the TEC-9 is known for its large magazine capacity and low price.

For any serious or professional shooter this gun is of little value – it’s too big and heavy to be carried comfortably, too unreliable when firing anything but FMJ ammunition, and has poor accuracy.

Thanks Wikipedia (and World Guns)

annotations.text: Ch-chick-pow! Move from the gate now
annotations.annotation:
By “gate” he means trap house (spot that he sold drugs out of, like a house or an apartment), so this line is likely a triple entendre:


If you don’t show him the respect he feels is deserved then he won’t sell drugs to you. In the previous lines, he’s just kinda fronting, shooting into the sky, to show that he’s not afraid to kill a fiend who doesn’t get the point.
He’s moved on from the drug selling lifestyle now, since he can make money just rapping.
He has moved on from the starting line that he previously couldn’t progress from; he’s “out of the gate”.



This line also breaks the pattern of rhyming couplets maintained throughout the verse.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Method Man]
annotations.annotation:
https://youtu.be/60h9Cc2eRtI?t=2m57s

From Meth himself.

annotations.text:
Cash rules everything around me
 C.R.E.A.M., get the money
 Dollar dollar bill, y'all
 Cash rules everything around me
 C.R.E.A.M., get the money
 Dollar dollar bill, y'all
annotations.annotation:
One of the most referenced and quoted hooks in the history of hip hop (perhaps THE most referenced), and in music history in general.

Method Man is not glorifying money and excess; rather, he’s saying that money holds power, and is a factor of major decisions made in the world he lives in. Those who have it, have power and those who don’t, won’t get up anywhere; sort of a way of saying the “love of money is the root of all evil” phrase from 1 Timothy 6:10 in the Bible, if you will.

From Akon to Method Man’s friend Biggie, as well as countless others, this line has been heard just about everywhere, albeit sometimes misinterpreted.

The “dollar, dollar bill y'all” verse might have been taken from a 1983 Jimmy Spicer’s song “Money (Dollar Bill Ya’ll)”.



In a 2017 interview on Power 106, RZA spoke about the hook:

https://youtu.be/yrQPCKSWZmI?t=4m27s

annotations.text: [Verse 2: Inspectah Deck]
annotations.annotation:
In one verse Deck takes you through the whole cycle of street life: from scrambling on the street, to hustling, to trying to teach the youth a better way and them not hearing you – and showing how there’s no answer.

RZA, Wu-Tang Manual



In an interview with HipHopDX, Deck explains how he and Rae originally had two verses each, and that he merged them to make the verse we all know today:


There was two verses to “C.R.E.A.M.” A lot of y’all don’t know, me and Rae had two verses apiece for “C.R.E.A.M.” That was a long-ass song, and I’ve got an unheard, second verse that I’m gonna put in that book for you.

There’s a second verse to “C.R.E.A.M.” that I’m going to put out for y’all that never made it. So what I ended up doing was taking the first part of the first verse and the second part of the second verse and putting them together, and that’s how you got the version you know now. But I got the back end of the first verse and the beginning of the second verse as well. We’re telling a whole ‘nother version of the same story. It’s kind of ill.

annotations.text:
It's been twenty-two long, hard years, I'm still strugglin'
 Survival got me buggin', but I'm alive on arrival
annotations.annotation:
Deck was twenty-two when he wrote the rhyme. Rae gets a lot of credit for the realness of this joint, but Deck’s impressions here are some of the most vivid and real you’ll ever hear.

RZA, Wu-Tang Manual

“Alive on arrival” is a play on “dead on arrival.”

“Alive on arrival” is also an allusion to the Ice Cube song of the same name, which describes a man who, after getting caught in the crossfire of a gang shooting, is allowed to die by hospital staff who assume that, because of his race, he was involved in said shooting.

annotations.text: I peep at the shape of the streets
annotations.annotation: Before stepping out Deck will check its all clear.

annotations.text: And stay awake to the ways of the world 'cause shit is deep
annotations.annotation:
This line would later be interpolated by Talib Kweli in Pharoahe Monch’s April 2014 song, “D.R.E.A.M.”:

I stay awake to the ways of the world ‘cause shit is deep

Both of Pharoahe Monch’s verses also interpolate the hook of this song.

annotations.text:
A man with a dream with plans to make cream
 Which failed; I went to jail at the age of fifteen
annotations.annotation:
At the age of fifteen, Deck was caught selling crack cocaine in the Park Hill projects of Staten Island—he noted in a 2007 interview with music journalist Brian Coleman that he was convicted of two felonies and six misdemeanors during his time as a street hustler.

In a November 2013 interview with HipHopDX, Deck addressed these lyrics and explained that his stint in jail taught him to stay sharp:

I went through that. I was 15, locked up […] the only one from Staten Island in here too. I can’t look for no help. I got to hold myself down. […] That’s when Inspectah was born. That was the nigga that shut up and just started analyzing things.

It’s also worth noting that “cream” circulated as Staten Island slang for money in the time of this song’s recording—Raekwon said in a January 2015 interview with 247HH that the term was coined by his cousin:

My cousin from Brooklyn, he actually invented the name—‘cause he used to be coming to Staten Island to work for us in the spot. […] We knew how important that word 'cream’ was to him. We would always tell him, ‘we’re gonna get you your cream, man’.

annotations.text:
A young buck sellin' drugs and such, who never had much
 Tryin' to get a clutch at what I could not—
annotations.annotation:
Like Raekwon in the verse before, Inspectah grew up poor and tried to make money selling drugs. Unlike Raekwon, he had bigger problems (i.e. jail) than accumulating Polo outerwear.

He was trying to get a clutch at what he could not touch (the word is left out to be implied by the rhyme).

However, “touch” is present, in echo form, in the music video:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYhStTIDiwA#t=114

annotations.text: The court played me short, now I face incarceration
annotations.annotation: Inspectah Deck got fucked over by the judicial system which is not a rare occurrence for young black males.

annotations.text: Handcuffed in the back of a bus, forty of us
annotations.annotation:
Inspectah Deck was sent to prison in a big white bus with 40 other inmates.



In Brian Coleman’s book Check the Technique: Liner Notes for Hip-Hop Junkies, Deck speaks about this moment and its influence on this song and his career:

Me on there was about me coming home from jail, trying to put my thoughts down and really take my life seriously. Dudes were telling me that I had talent, so I wanted to stop fucking around. I was handcuffed to the back of a bus, a young nigga up there with grown men. Upstate, not county jail – I was with the big boys. The street taught me to adapt to all situations, so I became the Inspectah. I learned to close my motherfuckin' mouth and peep what was going on. I learned a whole lot during that era. My rap sheet is long. Two felonies, six misdemeanours. Drugs, burglary, gun possession, all that shit. I rarely talk about that shit in rhymes, but you can hear me breathing it. So the stuff on that song was just a page out of an encyclopaedia of rhymes I had back then. I’ve still got verses that were supposed to be on there that got cut out. When I’m done rhyming, I’m gonna put out a book of all my lyrics. I saved all that shit, even from back when I was in high school.

annotations.text: Life as a shorty shouldn't be so rough
annotations.annotation:
A “shorty” (child) should lead a happy life (Wu-Tang is for the children).



PROPOSED SUGGESTION: Inspectah Deck: When I say, “Life as a shorty shouldn’t be so rough,” I’m talking about me, myself—I grew up poor, but we grew up happy as a family. We ain’t have shit, but we was always cool about not having shit at that period and time. My mom was working, doing her thing, but I looked at other cats that used to come to my house and used to come play with my toys. We only had about two or three of them shits, but these niggas had none, so they over at my house everyday.

As a shorty, you might be dealing with, a father who’s a fucking career criminal, your mom’s on drugs. You ain’t got no discipline, you up all night, and you seeing shit you ain’t supposed to see. Niggas is blowing cigarette smoke in your face…weed in your face. They’re drinking and fucking, and you just a 10-year-old or 11-year-old. You get to see all that way ahead of your time. You’re seeing coke getting chopped on the table, guns and all kinds of shit at a young age. That young age is when your mind is the ripest, man. All that information is going on, and it gets sucked in. Your brain is young, and your brain is new. You catalogue all that, and that’s what you become. You become what your surrounding is. If you’re surrounded by lions, you going to move like a lion. If you surrounded by lambs, you going to move like a lamb. So kids are forced to be grown men fast.

Source

annotations.text: But as the world turned, I learned life is hell
annotations.annotation:
Raekwon and GZA have similar lines from their solo albums.

On “Heaven & Hell” Raekwon says:

You don’t believe in heaven ‘cause we’re livin’ in hell

And on “I Gotcha Back” GZA says:

My lifestyle was so far from well
Could’ve wrote a book with a title ‘Age 12 and Going Through Hell’

annotations.text: Livin' in the world no different from a cell
annotations.annotation:
After Inspectah got out of prison, he realized life was just as bad in his slum of Staten Island as it was when he was locked up. This is also statistically true; if Inspectah Deck was a real gangsta during the crack cocaine epidemic he had a 4-7% chance of dying in any given year while gang-banging, or a 1% chance of dying as an average black male in the inner city, the death rate per year on death row is 2%.



This bar is sampled as the hook for the CunninLynguists' track Brain Cell.

annotations.text:
Every day I escape from Jakes givin' chase
 Sellin' base,
annotations.annotation:
“Base” is an abbreviation of ‘freebase’—a drug created in 1974 by a coke-powder smuggler and a chemist who tried to replicate smokeable coke. It would later be the subject of “White Lines (Don’t Do It)” by Melle Mel.

As Jeff Chang further details in his book, Can’t Stop Won’t Stop, it received the name “freebase” because:

The process that made the rocks had literally, in chemist’s terms, ‘freed’ the ‘base.’

“Jake” is a slang term for police, who would regularly try to find Inspectah Deck with the drug, but never caught him.

annotations.text: Smokin' bones in the staircase
annotations.annotation:
“Bones” are joints/cigarettes.



RZA has a similar line to this and the previous bar in the track, “Tragedy”:

Can’t smoke a bone in the staircase without getting chased

annotations.text:
Though I don't know why I chose to smoke sess
 I guess that's the time when I'm not depressed
annotations.annotation:
Today, Inspectah can’t understand why he as a kid chose to smoke sess, a slang word for sensimilla, but he comes to realize that it helped him get a break from the problems in his life; he used it to escape.

Habitual use of drugs like marijuana is a common way of self medicating for depression

Inspectah Deck discussed this at length with hiphoppdx.com


DX: I think one of the strongest lines is when you say, “I guess that’s not the time when I’m not depressed  / But I’m still depressed, and I ask what’s it worth?” A lot of times people want to hide that kind of vulnerability, but you talk about that. Was there a time where you felt like you were suicidal at that point?

Inspectah Deck: [Laughs] Nah, man. I ain’t never been suicidal, dog. I’m too mentally strong for all that shit.

DX: But when you ask, “What’s it worth?” there is a sense of hopelessness there, right?

Inspectah Deck: Yeah, there is a sense of hopelessness of being that child thinking, “Life as a shorty shouldn’t be so rough.” When you’re growing up rough like that—how I was just describing—you come into a point in life where it’s like, “Damn, I’ve been arrested three or four times. I got charges on my shit, and niggas don’t want to hire me.” You going through things with your girlfriend at the time. I wasn’t really going to school, but I always felt I was a smart nigga. I was raised on the street, and for me it was like, “Damn, you wind up at a dead end any way you go, whether it’s hustling…” If you get caught up, you losing money any time you get arrested.

So with the things adding up you’re like, “Damn.” You smoking, and you get high. For that temporary moment, you might think about some other shit, like, “Yo, remember when this was going down?” But then when that high is gone, you get right back into shit. If you’re depressed, you roll a blunt, and when your high is gone, you’re still depressed. I’m like, “What the fuck? What’s it worth? Why even smoke?” That’s what I mean in that line. I’m saying, “Ready to give up so I seek the old Earth.” It’s being ready to give up in the sense of, “Fuck trying to do this righteous shit and something happen. I’m ready to just go nose-dive right into the life now. I’m ready to either just become the kingpin or become the fucking clown and get taken out real quick. Either one.” At that point, you’re just thinking, “I’m about to go head-first into whatever it is I’m doing.”

annotations.text: But I'm still depressed, and I ask: what's it worth?
annotations.annotation:
The peace the speaker gets from smoking is not permanent.  Perhaps, he is developing a tolerance to the drug which is minimizing its effects, a sign he may be becoming dependent on it.  Even if he is able to get some relief from smoking, his problems will still exist when the high wears off.
Reflecting on this leads to him question his direction in life.

While self medicating for depression with a drug like marijuana can offer temporary relief, it is not a solution to the problem, and can make matters worse if depended on too heavily.

annotations.text:
Ready to give up so I seek the old Earth
 Who explained workin' hard may help you maintain
 To learn to overcome the heartaches and pain
annotations.annotation:
In Five Percent terminology, the Black Man is God and the Black Woman is Earth. Your Old Earth is Ma Dukes.

At the end of his wits, Inspectah sits down with her and has a “Great Awakening” to the joys of the Protestant Ethic.

What his mother explained to him is effectively

That which does not kill us makes us stronger.

A statement credited to philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche from his book, Twilight of the Idols.

For Deck to succeed in life, he must “overcome the heartaches and pain” from the challenges he faces. Essentially – no pain, no gain.

annotations.text: And stray shots, all on the block that stays hot
annotations.annotation:
In a drug-controlled area, the whole block is hot—everyone is a potential target.

RZA, Wu-Tang Manual

“Hot” could also mean there is a high police presence there.

annotations.text:
Leave it up to me while I be livin' proof
 To kick the truth to the young black youth
annotations.annotation: Like Saint Augustine, Inspectah’s former life as a sinner gives him street cred when guiding the youth on the straight and narrow.

annotations.text: But shorty's runnin' wild, smokin' sess, drinkin' beer
annotations.annotation:
“Shorty” implies subservience; here, it means “youth”.

The youth is running around doing whatever they want, drinking beer, and smoking sess, which is slang for sensimilla, a high quality female cannabis that has not been fertilized by male cannabis plants, making the buds seedless and very potent with THC.

annotations.text:
Neglected for now, but yo, it gots to be accepted
 That what? That life is hectic
annotations.annotation:
Depending on how you hear the line (“neglected for now”/“neglect it for now”), there are two interpretations of this:


Many urban children living in poverty were neglected and still continue to be so.
The youth is neglecting Deck’s advice.



In both situations, people gotta recognize that life is shitty sometimes, full of pain and betrayal. The earlier you accept that fact, the better off you will be.

annotations.text:
Cash rules everything around me
 C.R.E.A.M., get the money
 Dollar dollar bill, y'all
 Cash rules everything around me
 C.R.E.A.M., get the money
 Dollar dollar bill, y'all
annotations.annotation:
One of the most referenced and quoted hooks in the history of hip hop (perhaps THE most referenced), and in music history in general.

Method Man is not glorifying money and excess; rather, he’s saying that money holds power, and is a factor of major decisions made in the world he lives in. Those who have it, have power and those who don’t, won’t get up anywhere; sort of a way of saying the “love of money is the root of all evil” phrase from 1 Timothy 6:10 in the Bible, if you will.

From Akon to Method Man’s friend Biggie, as well as countless others, this line has been heard just about everywhere, albeit sometimes misinterpreted.

The “dollar, dollar bill y'all” verse might have been taken from a 1983 Jimmy Spicer’s song “Money (Dollar Bill Ya’ll)”.



In a 2017 interview on Power 106, RZA spoke about the hook:

https://youtu.be/yrQPCKSWZmI?t=4m27s

annotations.text: My niggas gots to do what they gotta do
annotations.annotation: Raekwon is asking if you understand just what it is people have to do to survive. He’s hoping that the previous verses have given you a taste of life in NYC and that it’s not the American Dream people think it is.

annotations.text:
Cash rules everything around me
 C.R.E.A.M., get the money
 Dollar dollar bill, y'all
 Cash rules everything around me

annotations.text: Because you can't just get by no more
annotations.annotation: He says that it’s not possible to coast along any more, you’ve got to do something drastic to make it in NYC, but do it fast – straight and fast could mean that you either have one shot at it, or there could be people coming at you, but remember Who the Fuck is 50 Cent.

annotations.annotation: He says that it’s not possible to coast along any more, you’ve got to do something drastic to make it in NYC, but do it fast – straight and fast could mean that you either have one shot at it, or there could be people coming at you, but remember Who the Fuck is 50 Cent.

annotations.text:
Cash rules everything around me
 C.R.E.A.M., get the money
 Dollar dollar bill, y'all
 Cash rules everything around me
 C.R.E.A.M., get the money
 Dollar dollar bill, y'all
annotations.annotation:
One of the most referenced and quoted hooks in the history of hip hop (perhaps THE most referenced), and in music history in general.

Method Man is not glorifying money and excess; rather, he’s saying that money holds power, and is a factor of major decisions made in the world he lives in. Those who have it, have power and those who don’t, won’t get up anywhere; sort of a way of saying the “love of money is the root of all evil” phrase from 1 Timothy 6:10 in the Bible, if you will.

From Akon to Method Man’s friend Biggie, as well as countless others, this line has been heard just about everywhere, albeit sometimes misinterpreted.

The “dollar, dollar bill y'all” verse might have been taken from a 1983 Jimmy Spicer’s song “Money (Dollar Bill Ya’ll)”.



In a 2017 interview on Power 106, RZA spoke about the hook:

https://youtu.be/yrQPCKSWZmI?t=4m27s

annotations.text: [Produced by Easy Mo Bee]
annotations.annotation:
Easy Mo Bee took a spin on what would become a classic sample – Isaac Hayes‘ "Walk on By."

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iqR4CZj0mJQ#t=56

This would later be sampled on many songs, including a Pac song – "Me Against the World."

According to Easy Mo Bee, this beat was originally offered to Big Daddy Kane, who turned it down.

annotations.text: Pop
annotations.annotation:
Like “Gimme The Loot” before it, Biggie plays two different characters in the same song, this time, in the form of a phone conversation.

But there’s something interesting to note here: Pop wasn’t supposed to be voiced by Biggie, but by Craig Mack, of all people.



Around the 40-minute mark in the documentary Crazy Like That Glue: The Craig Mack Story, DJ Four-Five, Mack’s friend and personal DJ at the time, mentioned that Mack was initially the original choice to play Pop, but was removed from the song because of attitude problems with both Biggie and Puffy:

 In talk of making Biggie’s album, Biggie’s voice […] and how they tweaked it and, y'know, took all the bass out of it, like it was a phone? That was supposed to be Craig. A lot of people don’t realize that. […] He didn’t do it.

Craig eventually got dropped from Bad Boy not long after Ready to Die had ran its course on the charts.

annotations.text: Who the fuck is this, pagin' me at 5:46 in the morning?
annotations.annotation: A “pager” was like a proto-iPhone of the early ‘90s (unfortunately, the only apps it had were “58008” and “911”).

annotations.text: It's my nigga, Pop from the barbershop
annotations.annotation:
In the black community, the barbershop is known as the black man’s country club, everything goes through the barbershop. Often “hot” items are sold in a barbershop, the weekly card game or craps game is played in the barbershop. The barber tends to be the local bookie and pay day lender.

This is a typical little detail that Big applies to his music to draw the listener in and fill them with a sense that they are in the story with him, living his words.

annotations.text:
Yeah, my nigga Fame up in Prospect
 Nah, them my niggas, nah, love, wouldn't disrespect
annotations.annotation:
“Yea…yea I remember that guy, from Prospect Plaza! Lil' Fame from M.O.P.! You’ve got him all wrong…he’s a good guy, he wouldn’t ever intend to stick me.”




In case you want to hear from the Fame himself, here he is in an interview with Vlad TV.
https://youtu.be/40LXGAoC4Fg?t=214

annotations.text: Now they heard you're blowin' up like nitro
annotations.annotation:
Nitroglycerin is a popular explosive, just as Biggie is “blowing up” (getting popular), thereby tempting the envious to “stick him”.

This is, literally speaking, before Biggie has blown up like the World Trade.

Biggie would repeat this image in “Kick In The Door”:
Trying to blow up like nitro and dynamite sticks.

annotations.text: Call the coroner!
annotations.annotation:
The murder of Biggie’s foe is a foregone conclusion.  Let the hospital get a head-start on the paperwork!

As Pop explains things, note that Biggie jumps in only after news of implied threats on his mother, stating that these guys are going to die.

annotations.text:
There's gonna be a lot of slow singin' and flower-bringin'
 If my burglar alarm starts ringin'
annotations.annotation:
If you break into Biggie’s property and set off his ADT, he will be forced to make the first step in your funeral arrangements (i.e., kill you)

This is also a potential reference to the Allen & Allen (Allen Toussaint and Allen Orange) penned song “Over You” performed by Aaron Neville and released in 1960. The opening line: “There’ll be some slow walking, Gonna be some sad talking, Gonna be some flower bringing, there’ll be some sad singing, over you”

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Ln1Q0gz6aQ

annotations.text:
What ya think all the guns is for?
 All-purpose war
annotations.annotation:
Directly before and after this lyric, Biggie is referencing the various weapons he has on deck. In other words, he is ready and willing for any type of violent confrontation, and will use whatever methods necessary to win.

All-purpose war is most likely a combination of two pre-existing phrases—“all-out war” and “all-purpose”—when Biggie blends these idioms, he creates an effective image of the idea of total war.

annotations.text:
Got the Rottweilers by the door
 And I feed 'em gunpowder so they can devour
 The criminals tryin' to drop my decimals
annotations.annotation:
Some dog owners, particularly ones who enter their pets into illegal dog fights, give their dogs gunpowder because they think it makes them more aggressive. In reality, gunpowder just gives your dog an ugly case of diarrhea and indigestion. Seems that Biggie was unaware about this when feeding his dogs.



“The criminals trying to drop my decimals” could be construed two ways: they wanted to kill him and drop the decimals of his body temperature or robbers are trying to steal his money. Either way, he keeps guns by the front door to ward off marauders.

annotations.text: And it ain't a dream
annotations.annotation:
Reference to the line on the track “Juicy”:

It was all a dream, I used to read Word Up magazine

In this song, Biggie’s like “ok, no more dreamland!”

annotations.text: With the black talons loaded in the clip
annotations.annotation:
Black Talons are a hollow point bullet, eventually removed from circulation in the US by manufacturer Winchester because of media hype surrounding them for being extra badass (which they weren’t, but still hollow point bullets are inherently badass!)

Ouch!

annotations.text: Touch my cheddar, feel my Beretta
annotations.annotation:
Beretta is an Italian firearm manufacturing company that was founded in 1526, Gardone Val Trompia, Italy by Maestro Bartolomeo Beretta . The manufacturer is mainly known for the M9 series



However Berretta also manufactures other types of firearms meaning Biggie may not just be referring to the handguns.

Cheddar is slang for money, that Biggie has acquired over the years as a hustler.

Taking this warning he has given you, I think it’s best you just leave his money alone

annotations.text: I fuck around and get hardcore
annotations.annotation: Big uses similar intonation of the word “hardcore” on “Machine Gun Funk,” albeit to chide a poseur.

annotations.text: C-4 to your door, no beef no more, nigga
annotations.annotation:
C-4 is a plastic explosive.

Biggie is saying that he’s willing to take extreme measures to get rid of his enemies. – You can’t exactly have beef if you’ve been blown to smithereens.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0nc98hzR-tk

annotations.text: The more weed smoke I puff, the more dangerous
annotations.annotation:
Biggie is saying that the more intoxicated he is the more likely he is to kill somebody.

Allusion to Peter Tosh’s “Steppin' Razor” with the classic hook :

I’m dangerous

(Biggie pronounces it like that)

annotations.text: What you gonna do when Big Poppa come for you?
annotations.annotation: Referencing the iconic chorus of Inner Circle’s “Bad Boys.”

annotations.text:
What's that red dot on your head, man?
 What red dot?
 Oh shit! You got a red dot on your head, too
 Oh shit!
annotations.annotation:
The marks from laser sights. Biggie has those guys foiled.

Pop from the barber shop, mentioned at the start of the song, may have also been there, having indeed made it to Biggie’s crib–there’s simultaneously two red dots, and two shots heard at the end of the song.

annotations.text: And exchangin' all they math again
annotations.annotation: “Math” is slang for phone number, they’re exchanging numbers to stay stay in touch

annotations.text: Parked on Madison across from the Radisson
annotations.annotation: The Radisson Martinique Hotel is located near Madison Square Garden, a drug hub in Manhattan

annotations.text: And from the curb I need to pull a Larry Bird, 'fore I'm up and out
annotations.annotation: Larry Bird had a sick “catch-and-shoot”; AZ is saying that he needs to do one last quick drug deal (a “bird” is a brick of cocaine) before he quits the game.

annotations.text: Big things in the Range, real niggas never change
annotations.annotation: Although wealth will make AZ install big “thangs” (“thangs” can mean speakers, status, or clout) in his Range Rover, it won’t change his fundamental ethos

annotations.text: It was Tuesday when I saw him, figured Friday I could call him
annotations.annotation: He wants to reconnect with the old friend who he ran into in the first verse, but gets distracted in this verse by women and shoes

annotations.text:
Up in Nordstrom's for a fresh pair to floss 'em
 Of course with footwear I be that first nigga that sport 'em
 Caught 'em before the salesmen even had time to assort 'em
 Bought 'em before any celeb stylist ever saw 'em

annotations.text:
In the spot playing possum
 Debating my destination, lacing, weighing my options
annotations.annotation: Just hanging out – “playing possum” – at the store, lacing up the new Nikes, trying to decide where to go for dinner

annotations.text: It was homie from the old clique I just seen and spoke with
annotations.annotation: The man who was shot was the same old friend he ran into in the first verse.

annotations.text: It's Doe or Die, we survive 'till we slain
annotations.annotation: Reference to classic AZ song “Doe or Die”

annotations.text: We go back like Bartles and James
annotations.annotation:
A wine cooler that was popular in the 80’s. Going back like Bartles & James means going way back

Furthermore, in a well-known series of television commercials Bartles and James were portrayed as two elderly friends who went way back (the characters were based on the two men who founded Ernest & Julio Gallo Winery, the company that produced Bartles & James)

annotations.text: If they just wanted some news they could've left him in his Hanes
annotations.annotation: They could’ve gotten info and taken his clothes, leaving him in his Hanes brand underwear:

annotations.text: [Produced by The Heatmakerz]
annotations.annotation:
The Heatmakerz flipped Patti LaBelle’s cover of “Wild Horses” on this track.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WftVepkiErs

The chorus of LaBelle’s song emphasizes AZ’s message:

Wild horses couldn’t drag, couldn’t drag me away
Oh, no, wild horses couldn’t drag me away

Metaphorically, AZ can’t be dragged away from his true self, regardless of what (money, fame, etc) tries to pull him away.

annotations.text: [Produced by Kane Beatz]
annotations.annotation:
In the following video, Kane Beatz speaks on how this song came about after OJ Da Juiceman missed out on the beat.

He also speaks about the beat specifically, while partially recreating the lead melody.

https://youtu.be/0smX2t4fojU?t=59

annotations.text: And I put Young Mula, baby, way above these bitches
annotations.annotation:
Young Money Entertainment is a record label that was founded by Lil Wayne in 2005. The label was an imprint of Cash Money Records until September 2018 when Wayne reached a settlement with Birdman and Universal Music Group after he filed a lawsuit against them over unpaid advances and rights to his catalog.

The label hosts many notable artists such as Drake, Nicki Minaj, and Wayne himself.

annotations.text: Ha! If it ain’t broke, don’t break it
annotations.annotation: This is a play on the phrase, “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it,” which means if something’s fine, then it shouldn’t be changed. The phrase was popularized by Bert Lance when he was quoted saying it in the May 1977 issue of the magazine Nation’s Business.

annotations.text:
Hope I don’t look weak, 'cause when a wolf cry wolf
 You still see that wolf teeth, mothafucka
annotations.annotation:
This is a nod to the fable The Boy Who Cried Wolf, which is about a shepherd boy who called out “wolf” as a joke to prank the other villagers. When he did it the third time, he was being serious but the villagers didn’t come to help the boy, subsequently losing all of his sheep.

Wayne later raps a similar line on his January 2018 song, “For Nothing”:

Wolves never cry wolf and you could feed us onions

annotations.text: If you act foul, you get two shots and one
annotations.annotation:
Acting “foul” means wronging someone in some way, it is also a term to describe the violation of contact rules in sport e.g. basketball.

“And one” is a phrase that’s used when someone is fouled while taking a shot in basketball – either a jump-shot (farther away from the basket) or a layup or dunk (right at the basket).

annotations.text: I'm at your face like Lancôme, haha
annotations.annotation:
Lancôme is a French luxury brand that sells fragrances, skincare, and makeup. They operate under the L'Oréal Luxury Products division, its parent company.

Additionally, Lancôme sounds like “man cum,” making for a sexual double entendre.

annotations.text: You niggas softer than Roseanne's son, hey
annotations.annotation:
Roseanne was a popular American sitcom which starred comedian Roseanne Barr. It ran on ABC from October 18, 1988, to May 20, 1997, and again from March 27, 2018, to May 22, 2018. The show revolves around Roseanne and her fictional family, The Connors.

Roseanne’s son, D.J. Conner (played by Michael Fishman) is portrayed on the show as a gullible, naive, and less-confrontational person. For example, in the episode “Punch and Jimmy,” DJ is being bullied at school and doesn’t want to fight the bully when Dan—his father—offers to teach him how to fight.

annotations.text:
You cannot reach me on my Samsung
 I'm busy fuckin' the world and givin' the universe my damn tongue
annotations.annotation:
Samsung is a South Korean multinational conglomerate that’s headquartered in Samsung Town, Seoul. They’re well-known for their Samsung Electronics brand—the world’s largest manufacturer of mobile phones and smartphones and has been since 2012.

Wayne has used the phrase “fuck the world” before on his November 1999 song of the same name.

annotations.text:
Hehe! All-white bricks
 I’m straight like it’s jumping back to 36, nigga!
annotations.annotation:
“White” is cocaine and a “brick” of cocaine is about 36 ounces or 1 kilogram. If someone dumps in 36 oz of soft (coke) into water while cooking crack (hard) and ends up with 36 oz of crack after it’s finished cooking, then you’re “straight” or good. If not, it means that coke had a lot of cut in it.

This may also be a nod to Gucci Mane—who’s also featured on this song—and his 2008 song “Bricks,” where he says the same thing:

All-white bricks
Off-white bricks

Additionally, Wayne may be talking about 36th street in New Orleans, which runs through his neighborhood.

annotations.text:
Big house, long hallways
 Got 10 bathrooms, I could shit all day, nigga
annotations.annotation:
In 2006, Lil Wayne bought a 15,000 square feet mansion in Biscayne Bay, Florida for $11.6 million. It has ten bedrooms and ten bathrooms and even features a roof-top skate park and a shark lagoon. He later sold it for $10 million in 2015.



Weezy later re-used the same lines for the chorus of his July 2017 song, “Fireworks.”

annotations.text:
What the fuck is up? (Up) It’s Gucci Mane the G (S'Gucci)
 Ask Tity Boi, no pity, boy; this scar city, the city boy (What?)
annotations.annotation:
Gucci Mane gives a shoutout to Tity Boi aka 2 Chainz and their hometown of Atlanta. While 2 Chainz’s from College Park—which is located in South Atlanta—Gucci Mane’s from East Atlanta. Notably, 2 Chainz released a remix of this song two months later in August 2009. It’s also implied that 2 Chainz had a verse on this song before it was later scrapped, giving a reason for this shoutout.



“Scar city” sounds like scarcity, which means a shortage of supply. This correlates with Gucci’s claim that he has no pity.

annotations.text:
So Icy; so, no Nike, boy
 Just Gucci, Louis, Prada, 'scuse me ('Scuse me)
annotations.annotation:
Gucci, Louis Vuitton, and Prada are all expensive designer brands while Nike is a brand that makes athletic shoes and clothing.

So Icey Entertainment is a now-defunct label Gucci was signed to before leaving in 2010 to start his own label, 1017 Records.

annotations.text:
East Atlanta cockin' hammers, bandannas on car antennas (Ugh)
 No, we do not talk to strangers
 Just cut off these niggas' fingers (Huh)
annotations.annotation:
“Hammer” is slang for a gun and “bandanas on car antennas” represents gang affiliation.

The “we do not talk to strangers, just cut off these niggas' fingers” line is a nod to Gucci Mane’s chorus on his May 2009 song, “Cuttin Off Fingaz”:

We don’t talk to strangers, we cop bangers
Trappin at night man, it might get dangerous
But I’m from East Atlanta where they cuttin off fangaz
I’m from East Atlanta where they cuttin off fangaz!

annotations.text: Gucci’s armed and dangerous, cocaine, codeine and angel dust
annotations.annotation:
Gucci may be paying homage to The Notorious B.I.G. and his 1997 song “Notorious Thugs.” Biggie opens up his first verse with:

Armed and dangerous
Ain’t too many can bang with us
Straight up weed, no angel dust

annotations.text:
This AK-47 will hit ya everywhere from the ankle up (Ankle)
 Gun same size as Nia Long, clip long as a Pringles can (Damn)
annotations.annotation:
Nia Long is an American actress who’s known for starring in the television shows The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air and Empire, as well as the films Soul Food, Boyz n the Hood, Friday and Are We There Yet?. Gucci plays on Nia’s last name to describe the size of his AK-47. From a technical standing point, however, Nia’s height is about 5 feet 2 inches while the average size of an AK-47 is about 34.3 inches.

Pringles is a popular brand of potato chips—their cans are notably long as well.

annotations.text: 4-5 Desert Eagle on me, you’ll think I'm a Eagles fan (Huh)
annotations.annotation:
The IMI Desert Eagle is a semi-automatic handgun that chambers the largest centerfire cartridge of any self-loading pistol. However, Gucci here is talking about the IWI Jericho 941, which is a double-action/single-action semi-automatic pistol that uses the .45 ACP handgun cartridge. It’s given the nickname the ‘Baby Eagle’ despite not being related to the IMI Desert Eagle at all.



The Philadelphia Eagles are a professional football team that competes in the NFL and are based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

annotations.text:
Toni Braxton sniper rifle, make you never breathe again (Hah)
 Fuck that nigga, kill that nigga, bring him back, kill him again Gucci!
annotations.annotation:
“Breathe Again” is the second single from R&B singer Toni Braxton’s 1993 self-titled debut album. The song is about Toni reminiscing about an old love of hers.

The song was a success, peaking at #3 on the Billboard Hot 100 and earned Toni her second consecutive Grammy Award for Best Female R&B Vocal Performance in 1995.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pRFEz2MjZgg

annotations.text:
Yeah, the-the-the money is the motive
 Fuck with the money, it get ugly as Coyote
annotations.annotation:
Wayne makes a play on the 2000 American comedy-drama film Coyote Ugly. The movie’s about a woman named Violet Sanford (played by Piper Perabo) who moves from her hometown of New Jersey to New York to pursue her dreams of becoming a songwriter.

While the movie mostly received negative reviews, it was a box office success, bringing in over $100 million worldwide.

annotations.text: I buy a pound, break it down, and put it in a stogie
annotations.annotation:
A “stogie” is a long, thin cigar. Wayne mentions smoking one on his fittingly titled 2007 song, “Get High Rule The World”:

I pop a beat and start rollin'
And then I smoke it like a muthafuckin' stogie

annotations.text: Swagger so bright, I don’t even need light
annotations.annotation:
To have “swag” means to have a keen sense of fashion and confidence. Wayne also boasted about his swag  on T.I’s September 2008’s “Swagga Like Us”:

No one on the corner has swagger like moi

annotations.text:
I’m with a model broad, she don’t even eat rice, ha
 But, would you believe it? She eat dykes
annotations.annotation:
Models often eat little or no food at all in order to lose and maintain a low weight. Wayne’s girl is in the same position.

A “dyke” is another term for a lesbian. Wayne declared his love for lesbian women on 2005’s “U Gon Love Me”:

And I don’t like strippers, I like dyke bitches

annotations.text: And she asked me for a picture, so I gave her three strikes, yeah
annotations.annotation:
“Picture” is a homophone for “pitcher”—a player in baseball who throws the ball towards the catcher, with the goal to get the batter out by striking them out three consecutive times.

“Strike” also means a pose, as in posing for a picture—making for a clever double entendre. It stems from the saying, “strike a pose.”

annotations.text:
I-I’m the man around this motherfucker
 I’m so hot, you probably catch a tan around this motherfucker
 This rap game, I got my hand around this motherfucker
 Yeah, I said "game," but I ain’t playing around this motherfucker!
 Yeah! I’m the best to ever do it, bitch, haha
annotations.annotation:
Wayne affirms his dominance in the rap game—his 2008 album Tha Carter III, which was released the year before this song’s release, achieved critical acclaim and is regarded to be one of the greatest albums of all time.

Lil Wayne himself is also regarded as one of the greatest rappers of all time and appears on multiple top 10 lists.

The “I’m so hot” line may also be a nod to the Hot Boys—a former New Orleans rap group that consisted of rappers Juvenile, B.G., Turk and Wayne himself. A “tan” is a brown color imparted to the skin after long exposure to the sun.

annotations.text:
And you’re the best at never doing shit
 If you the shit, then I'm sewerage
annotations.annotation: Sewage is wastewater produced by a community of people. It mostly consists of soap, detergent, toilet paper, greywater, and blackwater—the water that’s used to flush toilets, combined with the human waste that it flushes away, hence the “shit” wordplay.

annotations.text: Tr-try me and I’ll have your people reading eulogies, haha
annotations.annotation:
A eulogy is a speech or writing that praises someone who’d recently died. They’re usually given at a funeral service. Wayne has also rapped about funerals on his September 2012 song, “Burn”:

Pussy nigga I’ll murder you then dance at your funeral

annotations.text: Make a cat bleed then sprinkle it with vinegar
annotations.annotation:
Apple cider vinegar can promote blood clotting.

The “cat” in question here seems to be the enema recipient, a “man” (“cat” was 1920’s slang for “dude”, also likening the man’s ass to a vagina with the feline nickname).

The odor of vinegar may be used to deter other “cats”–house cats, specifically–from crawling onto certain surfaces. Some pet owners use vinegar to eliminate urine odors from the litter box

annotations.text:

annotations.annotation: Despite having twice referred to Lil Kim as “bitch”, Mr. Bristal expresses surprise that she should act like one, thus raising an important question: is bitch-ness an identity or a behavior? If a nigga can be a bitch, as there is ample evidence of throughout the corpus of rap, can a bitch just as easily be a nigga?

The camera is usually associated with the male gaze, with the purpose of objectifying the female body (see Mulvey, Laura, “Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema,” 1973)

Here, Lil Kim is still objectifying a female body (her own), but she not only recasts the gaze as feminine (her and her “girls”) but also challenges the authority of the male gaze: “he can’t see” the camera.
