A key part of the drug dealer’s code is to keep quiet about one’s activities, whether on the phone or when confronted by police.  Even in rap, you’re not supposed to mention too many details of the drug game.  Note Jay-Z on “Never Change,”

What’s up to my Miami and St. Thomas Connect
I’ll never mention your name, I promise respect

Kenneth “Supreme” McGriff, a former drug dealer, was supposedly irate at 50 Cent for revealing too many details of the Jamaica, Queens drug trade in his song “Ghetto Q'uran.”

Malice knows to keep his mouth shut.

annotations.text: Y'all the type of players that be getting two-day contracts

The Street Family so cool, we could pull bitches
 Even if it was July and we had on Woolrich's
annotations.annotation:
“Street Family” is Fabolous' posse; they are so smooth with the ladies that they can dress like retarded hypochondriacs and still get pussy.

Woolrich’s is a clothing company that sells traditional flannel and wool New England outdoor clothing.  It is not generally regarded as being “hip.”

annotations.text:
I keep the streets so numb they call me "Novocain"
 I turn over 'caine over and over again
annotations.annotation: Novocaine is a numbing agent like cocaine. Pusha keeps the streets numb by “turning over”, or selling, cocaine. Clipse is also from Northern Virigina, also known as NoVA, so this is a delicious pun.

annotations.text: As I left ya, all in three gestures, down, up and aim
annotations.annotation: If Pusha lost all of his money, he would also go on a robbing spree involving 3 motions: victim puts his money “down” and his hands “up” as Pusha aims a gun in his direction

annotations.text: I can define death better than Webster, wet ya
annotations.annotation: Webster is the name of both the hard copy and now online comprehensive English dictionary written and edited originally by Noah Webster

annotations.text:
Yes, I'm holding, whether it's heat or cocaine
 In the door panel of my four-wheel motion
annotations.annotation: I’ve got heat (guns) and cocaine on me whenever I’m in my four wheel drive vehicle, but you’ll have to look in the panel to actually find them

annotations.text:
Ain't jokin', but I laugh how other flows convince you
 With money, it's funny, it's Comedy Central
annotations.annotation:
Comedy Central is a pay to view television channel launched in 1991 that mostly consists of comedies aimed for more mature audiences.

Its slogan is “Everything is Funny”

annotations.text: When I'm on vacation, my babies ride in the rental
annotations.annotation:
No walking for Pusha’s babies…rental strollers are the ultimate luxury item

Alternate interpretation: Pusha is so on top of the drug game that when he’s on vacation, he’s still raking passive income; his “babies” (ladies) ride around in untraceable rental cars delivering drug shipments for him

annotations.text:
I'm livid, they act as if I don't live it
 Saran Wrap, Vaseline so they can't sniff it
annotations.annotation:
Some people still don’t believe Pusha actually sells drugs

“Saran wrap Vaseline” refers to a technique to mask the smell of weed/coke from drug-sniffing dogs (used coffee grinds are a nice addition too). He casually offers this detail as evidence of his authenticity, and plays on “they can’t sniff it” to emphasize his critics' ignorance

annotations.text:
Yves St. Laurent knitted, shorts Bermuda
 You would think they was Pucci if you overlooked Medusa
annotations.annotation:
Pusha is boasting the spoils of his drug dealings. He is wearing luxurious European clothing; a knitted top by Yves Saint Laurent (YSL) and a pair of Bermuda shorts by Versace.

A person who is not familiar with lavish clothing such as the companies mentioned above could mistake his Versace shorts to be made by the Italian clothing company Pucci. Versace and Pucci have similar designs in some of their clothing, but there is no mistaking the iconic head of Medusa which is the company logo of Versace.

annotations.text: I'm a hustla, I'm a I'm a hustla homie
annotations.annotation: A reference to the Jay-Z hook on Cassidy’s “I’m a Hustla”, the song from which the beat for this song was taken

annotations.text: '97 had a brick by the muffler crony
annotations.annotation: In 1997, he was transporting kilograms of cocaine by hiding them by the muffler of his car

annotations.text: Wholesale to my select preferred customers only
annotations.annotation: He wasn’t just a small-time dealer: he sold crack in large amounts and gave good deals to his repeat, high-volume customers.  Sort of like Amazon Prime for drug dealers

annotations.text: The white horse cooked tan you can call it the pony
annotations.annotation: “White horse” is slang for heroin: when he cooks it, it turns tan so you can call it a pony.  This line operates on the assumption that white horses, when they’re ponies, are actually tan or brown.  This doesn’t seem true

annotations.text: It's only the soft it twists like a wrestler on me
annotations.annotation:
The “white horse” refers to cocaine, which is cooked (heroin is tan-colored and commonly known as “horse”, or in this case a “pony”)

“Soft” is slang for pure coke which he then “twists” – hardens and cools – to make “the hard”, i.e. crack

The drug dealer is being cast as a wrestler here, “twisting” the coke like a wrestler twists opponents

annotations.text: It hardens, it cools I prove I'm a juggler whoadie
annotations.annotation:
Again, he’s cooking crack: the coke turns into a rock and then he cools it down before going to sell it.  He’s a juggler because he tosses bags of crack around

“Whoadie” is New Orleans slang for “homie” (a derivation of “Wardy”, since New Orleansites are divided into “Wards”)

annotations.text:
Glock popped got it cheap I'mma smother you
 Hovered and govern the corner you hugged then I shuffle you roadie
annotations.annotation: He stakes out your street corner from which you sell drugs (hugging the block is standing outside slinging drugs), but then because he’s got a gun he can eliminate you and take over your corner

annotations.text: Face it they change, the game's never loving you sorry
annotations.annotation:
Don’t hate the player, hate the game

Corners are going to change hands, you must get used to it if you’re going to be a drug dealer

annotations.text: You live for the moment it's gone then they cover you homie
annotations.annotation: A fairly cynical, existential thought – You’re born, you live, you die, your body is covered by dirt. The end

annotations.text: Back against the wall, post up never fall
annotations.annotation:
Just standing outside, leaning against a wall, waiting for someone to come buy some drugs

Slim Thug would discuss posting up to sell drugs in the chorus of “Wamp Wamp”

I head straight to the bar just to post-up
I roll the dro up, my cup mold up,
Bitch don’t just stand there with your nose up"

annotations.text:
Never fail, keep a burner close you can fend them off
 Get that 10 up off the car and you let it off
annotations.annotation: He recommends keeping a gun (“burner”) to help keep away rivals.  If you rest the gun (in this case a 10-millimeter handgun) on the tire, it’s easily accessible yet if the cops bust you for selling drugs you don’t have a gun on you!

annotations.text: Sort of like Avon and Marlo when you set it off
annotations.annotation:
Avon Barksdale and Marlo Stanfield were the two main rival drug lords who were in an all-out war for control of the Baltimore drug trade in Season 3 of The Wire

When you try starting it up with him, there will be similarly serious disturbances

annotations.text: Black hand white keys ya'll seen this I’m Ray
annotations.annotation: Ray had black hands and played on a piano, which had white keys.  In this case Pusha T has black hands but he works with keys [kilograms] of white [cocaine]

annotations.text:
Got more white in the hood than the KKK
 The grand wizard of that almighty blizzard
annotations.annotation:
He’s got so much cocaine all over the place! He’s basically the president of cocaine

KKK members are white and wear hoods, Pusha has a lot of white (cocaine) in his neighbor(hood). Grand Wizard is a title given to a leader of the KKK

annotations.text: Now nigga go figure I ain’t been out in two
annotations.annotation: This is likely a reference to the roughly two-year gap between the release of Clipse’s first album, Lord Willin', and the release of this mixtape.  Clipse were in career limbo for those years since Jive Records continually delayed release of the Clipse’s follow-up album

annotations.text: Now if you got a question nigga save that for Clue
annotations.annotation:
DJ Clue is a famous mixtape DJ and a has a radio show where you can call in and ask questions

Clue’s logo is a question mark:


This may also refer to the board game “Clue” (where technically you don’t really ask questions so much as make guesses, but now we’re just splitting hairs)

annotations.text: But if you know the answer than you probably copped from dude
annotations.annotation:
Two possible readings:

1) If the above line is meant to refer to DJ Clue, this could be “if you know about me, then you’re probably the type of person who cops mixtapes” meaning that Clipse predominantly caters to real rap fans (a reasonable reading given their record label limbo and lack of mainstream recognition for a few years after dropping “Lord Willin”).

2) Regardless of the DJ Clue interpretation, this could have the meaning of “if you know how I roll you’ve probably bought drugs from me” (in this case he’s “Dude)

annotations.text:
Either you hugged the block or cooked in the kitchen
 Or you was a master, good with your fingers
annotations.annotation:
The hierarchy of the drug trade:

Lowest level: street-level drug dealers (who hug the block)
Next level: Cooking the crack
Next level: Wrapping up the crack into individual units for sale (probably not that difficult, but hey: after two promotions does ANYBODY actually do any work?)

annotations.text: Trying to bag a slab up while that's still wet
annotations.annotation: But Biggie already told you on “Everyday Struggle”! You simply can’t put your crack in bags for sale if it’s damp: the product would be simply ruined!

annotations.text: Cause the fiends is hovering, smothering fussing and they frustrated with headaches
annotations.annotation: Anybody who’s ever worked at a fast-food restaurant knows how stressful rush hour is: you’re frantically trying to get the food ready for all the customers, and they’re grumpy and hungry.  It’s a bit overwhelming.  Now imagine if all the customers were going through crack withdrawal and needing their fixes, and you can imagine what this guy’s life was like

annotations.text:
I used to scuffle them, 22 illusions
 Color top stop don't confuse them
annotations.annotation: He would mark each drug individual drug package with a color to denote its quality

annotations.text:
Other blocks hot cause they're losing
 Hot cause of shootings
annotations.annotation: Rival drug dealers are hot and bothered due to their lack of product. This increased level of stress leads to more violence, which leads to the block becoming hot as in attracting attention from police

annotations.text: Niggas getting rocked like powder
annotations.annotation: Powder cocaine is turned into crack rock: so cocaine gets “rocked” just like the people this guy shoots

annotations.text: Kilos I throw at least 3 like cee-lo every time
annotations.annotation: He sells cocaine in no smaller installments than 3 kilograms.  In cee-lo, participants throw three six-sided dice

annotations.text: Not just your name, your race is betrayed
annotations.annotation:
When a person snitches, you don’t just besmirch your good name, you also betray the community.  The philosophical underpinning of the “Stop Snitching” movement is the notion that, when illegal activity pervades a society, the fear of being snitched on creates distrust within the community.

The fact that the person saying this is a drug kingpin is pretty awesome. He’s the one who others often feel is a shame to their race (by selling drugs), but in his moral code selling crack is ok but ratting out a drug dealer is not

annotations.text: You’re the modern day African capturing slaves
annotations.annotation: Most of the actual slavers who caught people and put them in irons and marched them off to the boats were, indeed, their fellow Africans; in the same way, a snitch betrays his fellow man (see above)

annotations.text: So you made it this far
annotations.annotation:
The song “Carter II” is a little more than halfway through the album Tha Carter II, so Wayne’s impressed that the listener has gotten to this point

This intro is also in the spirit of its sister songs, Fly In and Fly Out, setting the listener into a certain moment and location related to where they are in the album

annotations.text:
We upstairs
 I let you up here
 You special
 Marley, don't shoot 'em
 You know what this is
 It's still Tha Carter II, people
 It's still Tha Carter II, people
 Yeah, you're still in Tha Carter II, people
annotations.annotation:
He’s telling his bodyguard, Marley, not to shoot you since you’ve been personally invited to Tha Carter.

“Marley don’t shoot” is a reference to the interludes on Tha Carter 1, specifically Inside.

annotations.text:
All I have in this world is a pistol and a promise
 A fistful of dollars, a list full of problems
annotations.annotation:
“All I have in this world…” is a Scarface reference.

http://youtu.be/zIRwd1S26Ik?t=7s

A Fistful of Dollars is a Clint Eastwood movie in what’s known as “The Man With No Name Trilogy”.

Like the Eastwood character, Wayne’s a mercenary who doesn’t need more than a gun and his word to get rich, do his business, and solve his problems.

annotations.text: I address 'em like P.O. boxes
annotations.annotation:
A post office box has a mailing address so the mail carrier knows where to bring it.

Wayne will confront/fix his problems, which is known as addressing, just as post office boxes have addresses on them. So Wayne is addressing his “list of problems” just as post office boxes are addressed.

annotations.text:
Yeah, I'm from New Orleans, the Creole cockpit
 We so out of it, zero tolerance
annotations.annotation:
Creoles are residents of New Orleans of various racial descent that moved to the city before Louisiana became a part of the United States.

They don’t take too kindly to strangers, and have zero tolerance for people disrespecting them.

annotations.text: Gangsta gumbo, I'll serve 'em a pot of it
annotations.annotation: Gumbo is a traditional New Orleans dish of soup over rice.  Gangsta gumbo is a New Orleans style of thuggery which Wayne inflicts upon out-of-towners.

annotations.text: I'm wealthy, still fuckin' with that block shit
annotations.annotation:
Even though he’s rich, Wayne still hang out with the people from his block; he never abandoned the hood that raised him.

He even filmed his recent music video for God Bless Amerika on his childhood street.

annotations.text: No snakes at the Carter, tell the gardener cut the grass
annotations.annotation:
No one in Wayne’s house would betray him, and he’s so confident of this that he wants the gardener to cut the grass and show that there’s no one lying there (“snake in the grass”)

Jay-Z used this phrase to explain that you find out who your real enemies are when you get involved in beef because people start piling on.  He said in “The Blueprint 2”

When the grass is cut the snakes will show
Gotta thank my little homie Nas for that though
Saving me the hassle of speaking to half of these assholes

Wayne could also be referring to traitors using snake as symbolism and the gardener is symbolic for a hired killer. If there is a snake in the grass when you mow it, it will be chopped up by the lawn mower.

Therefore, Weezy is explaining that there are no “snakes” hiding in his camp, because he consistently tells the gardener to cut the grass.

annotations.text: I'm ridin' for them reparations, no patience
annotations.annotation: Wayne doesn’t feel like waiting to see if the controversial idea of the U.S. government paying money to descendants of slaves ever gets passed; he’s just going to go rob some white people

annotations.text:
Slow paper is better than no paper
 Fast money don't last too long, you got to pace it
annotations.annotation:
Grinding and accumulating wealth slowly is better than having no money at all and if you make your money quickly you’re likely to spend it, so pace yourself

This seems at odds with his claim on “Feel Me” on which he says

Gotta get it gotta have it
Once I got it I'ma spend it
Then it’s back to doing any damn thing just to get it

annotations.text:
Gotta know that
 Photophobia, no Kodak moments
 Feds walls with my pictures on 'em, naw
 I ain't even in the school yearbook
 I don't do too much posing, got a cool killer look, ah
annotations.annotation:
Wayne continues to educate wannabe crooks, telling them to never get photographed so they can never get found if they become crime suspects

He’s known this since he was a kid (“ain’t even in the school yearbook”). And in the end, there’s no need for him to try and appear tough, because he’s naturally an ice cold killer (“cool killer look”)

annotations.text: Around here, and this here is Tha Carter
annotations.annotation: Wayne’s Tha Carter series of albums is based on the movie New Jack City in which Nino Brown sets up a massive drug enterprise within The Carter housing projects, which he turns into his own fortress.  Wayne’s trying to play on this idea to claim that he’s a drug dealer both in the literal sense and in the figurative sense that the rap he’s selling you is a drug you need to have

annotations.text: And Slim tell me ain't nobody hotter
annotations.annotation:
Which Slim is he talking about?


Souljah Slim, a New Orleans rapper who died in 2003 (Wayne claims that at some point Slim anointed him as the best rapper)?
Ronald “Slim” Williams, who along with younger brother Bryan “Baby” Williams, founded Cash Money Records, and has served as an executive producer on all Lil Wayne’s albums to date?



It’s most likely Baby’s brother, Slim.

annotations.text: Get 'em
annotations.annotation: Quite possibly a nod to Wayne’s track “Get ‘Em” on “The Dedication 2” mixtape.

title.name: Ride for My Niggas (Sky is the Limit)

annotations.text:
You know I ride for my motherfucking niggas
 Most likely, I'ma die with my finger on the trigger
annotations.annotation:
As the saying goes: Live by the sword, die by the sword.  Therefore, Wayne figures he’ll die in a shootout.

This couplet was later interpolated on YG’s “My Nigga.”

annotations.text:
They tell me, "Don't get high" and I should try to make a living
 I tell 'em I'm a hustler, and I'd rather make a killing
annotations.annotation:
Media and adversaries criticize him for using drugs or making references about them in his songs, and often say that he should look for a more “proper” career instead of rapping.

Wayne responds by saying that he is a hustler and he’d rather keep doing what he does and die, than to “make a living” by being a regular person in a nine-to-five (regular job).

annotations.text:
My eyes get so wide as it rise in the skillet
 I let my bitch bag it; if she steal it, I'ma kill her
annotations.annotation: Wayne is referencing the art of turning cocaine into crack by cooking it. Cocaine, heat, baking soda and water are each needed. If each componernt is present and in their correct ratio then sufficient heat should be supplied long enough for the soda to remove the HCL Hydrochloride acid from the cocaine using a base (soda). Cooking crack is an acid-base reaction. His girl puts it into bags to be ready for distribution; if she steals the crack she will die

annotations.text: I bulletproof the ride, now I feel like armadillos
annotations.annotation: Armadillos have a tough exterior shell, much like an automobile that’s been bulletproofed.

annotations.text: My flow is nasty, like C-Y-philis
annotations.annotation:
I think he’s trying to spell out syphilis here and doing incorrectly (S Y Phyllis wouldn’t have the same ring to it)

C also equals see, so it’s literally translated as:

My flow is nasty like. See why? Feel this.

annotations.text: Self-made G
annotations.annotation: A “G” is a slang term for a gangster, so because Wayne crafted himself into what he is by his own power, He is a Self-made Gangster.

annotations.text: Relying on rap, but in the kitchen I'm a chemist
annotations.annotation: Weezy’s kitchen chemistry consists of mixing various elements to manufacture drugs to sell.

annotations.text:
And when I was five my favorite movie was The Gremlins
 Ain't got shit to do with this, but I just thought that I should mention
annotations.annotation: The 1984 movie Gremlins premiered when Wayne was two years old. Maybe it’s because he sees a little bit of himself in those wily creatures?

annotations.text: And them birds don't fly without my permission
annotations.annotation:
A “bird” is a kilo of cocaine. Coke doesn’t get sold unless Weezy allows it

Also an expression of frustration with man’s lack of control over nature, similar to the sentiment expressed in Blood Meridian: “The existence of birds offends me”

The former reading is more in line with the previous lines, but the latter reading makes sense as a transition to the next lines about Wayne’s place in nature

annotations.text:
I'm probably in the sky, flying with the fishes
 Or maybe in the ocean, swimming with the pigeons
annotations.annotation:
Wayne does things differently, he flys and swims with things that ordinarily do not. He is an alien

Might be a stretch but this line could be a subtle reference to M.C. Escher’s famous Sky and Water I. Even if he doesn’t know who Escher is, lots of people have seen this – definitely fits the image of flying fish and swimming birds.



In addition to the previous line, “and them birds don’t fly without my permission”, speaking about commanding the sale of cocaine, Wayne may also be suggesting that he is using airplanes to “fly” and transport Fishscale cocaine and boats to “swim” the pigeons, also slang for a kilo of cocaine.

annotations.text: See, my world is different, like Dwayne Wayne
annotations.annotation:
A reference to the early Nineties sitcom A Different World, whose main character is a college student named Dwayne Wayne

Wayne’s given name is Dwayne but he dropped the D because his father, Dwayne Sr., left him and Wayne didn’t want to carry his name

annotations.text:
You know I ride for my motherfucking niggas
 Most likely, I'ma die with my finger on the trigger
annotations.annotation:
As the saying goes: Live by the sword, die by the sword.  Therefore, Wayne figures he’ll die in a shootout.

This couplet was later interpolated on YG’s “My Nigga.”

annotations.text: Switching lanes faster than she switch subjects
annotations.annotation:
Fun simile sets up the following line’s insult by introducing the girl as chatty and perhaps scatterbrained

Another reading of “subjects” is “male suitors.” In other words, Li'l Wayne informs his target that the lady in question engages in sexual activity not only with him, but also with Li'l Wayne and a slew of other men (subjects).

annotations.text:
And I hate when a nigga say, "Talk is cheap"
 'Cause I'm the type that let money talk for me, yeah
annotations.annotation: wordplay. talk is not cheap for Wayne

annotations.text:
The only thing on a mind of a shark is "Eat"
 By any means, and you just sardines
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne is always using water as a metaphor for the ghetto. This is very appropriate since after Katrina, his childhood neighborhood was effectively in the ocean for a while

He is devouring his competition as a shark would do a sardine

annotations.text: Tucked in my P-R-Ps
annotations.annotation: P.R.P.s are a luxury denim brand

annotations.text: They tried to make a brand-new map without us
annotations.annotation: After the great storm coming the US map will not look the same. Check out the NAFTA superhighway map. New Orleans tore down most of the housing projects after Katrina and began ‘mixed-income’ projects.

annotations.text:
But the tourists come down and spend too many dollars
 And no matter how you change it, it'll still be ours
annotations.annotation: After Katrina, the economy reemerged with tourists and developers. Weezy is saying no matter how the city changes, it’ll still belong to the native New Orleaners.

annotations.text:
You know I ride for my motherfucking niggas

annotations.annotation:
As the saying goes: Live by the sword, die by the sword.  Therefore, Wayne figures he’ll die in a shootout.

This couplet was later interpolated on YG’s “My Nigga.”

annotations.text:
And you don't want to fuck with a soldier
 Use your head or I'll take it off your shoulder
annotations.annotation: If you don’t think about messing with Weezy, you might literally lose your noggin!

annotations.text: See
annotations.annotation:
Homophone.

“See” sounds like the third alphabet “C”

annotations.text:
It's what you all been waiting for, ain't it?
 What people pay paper for, damn it
 They can't stand it, they want something new
annotations.annotation:
Leading up to Graduation, Kanye was in a very public sales feud with 50 Cent. Now that it’s here,  the demand is high, thus paying lots of money for this album. A little stat, Graduation sold 957,000 units in the first week. That’s a lot of paper!



This may also be directed at the collaboration between Kanye and Lil' Wayne. Both rappers were hot at the time and were among some of the best alive. When two rappers of their stature are both killing it in the game, people ask for a collab.

annotations.text:
So let's get reacquainted, became the hood favorite
 I can't even explain it, I surprise myself too
annotations.annotation:
“The magnitude of my success surprises even me!”

This line references the fact that he’s not hood at all, e.g. he wears polos and other clothes that would be considered prep. However, despite this he manages to have become the hood favorite

annotations.text: Life of a Don, lights keep glowin'
annotations.annotation:
A Don is, in mafia terminology, the head of a family—it’s a status that implies power and respect mixed with crime and villainy. Kanye saw himself as the head of the rap (and style) game, despite being hated. He called himself the “Louis Vuitton Don” on “Last Call”.

Barry Bonds had “Don” status in baseball—the undisputed best player in the game, even as steroid allegations and his standoffish persona made him widely hated.

As Bonds approached Mark McGwire, Babe Ruth, and Hank Aaron’s home run records, his at-bats would be preceded by hundreds of flashing lights, as fans would try to catch snapshots of his record-breaking moments—"lights keep glowing."



Like Bonds, West experienced the Flashing Lights, as he was followed by the paparazzi. No matter what people thought of their personas, West and Bonds were undeniably stars.

annotations.text:
Comin' in the club wit' that fresh shit on
 Wit' somethin' crazy on my arm,
annotations.annotation:
I.e., showing up at the club with great clothes and a hot/crazy girl in tow

Dual reference to one one hand (arm) Barry Bonds' notorious elbow armor, and on the other, Kanye’s propensity for eye-catching jewelry and or companions.

annotations.text:
Uh-huh-hum
 And here's another hit, Barry Bonds
annotations.annotation:
The main concept of the song – Wayne and Kanye produce “hits” (successful / popular songs) as effectively as Barry Bonds produces “hits” in baseball



Barry Bonds with Kanye and Kim Kardashian:

annotations.text:
We outta here, baby! We outta here, baby!
 We outta here, baby!
annotations.annotation:
Duane Kuiper is the San Francisco Giants' television play-by-play broadcaster. Kuiper called many of Barry Bond’s home runs. His trademark home run call is “He hits it high… hits it deep… it is (or hits it) OUTTA HERE!” or “HIGH DRIVE…LEFT (or RIGHT) FIELD… IT IS (sometimes: THIS BABY IS) OUTTA HERE!”



Here is Kuiper’s call for Bond’s 756th home run:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cbkHiIQj-Mw

annotations.text: Dude! Fresh off the plane—Konnichiwa, bitches
annotations.annotation:
“Konichiwa” means “hello” in Japanese – “konichiwa bitches” is something Kanye might say after having just arrived in Japan on a world tour. The phrase originated in the “Racial Draft” skit on Chappelle’s Show, where it was said by GZA after the Wu-Tang Clan was officially declared to be Asian.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UL5x60lpGIE

“Konichiwa Bitches” is also the name of the first UK single released off Swedish pop singer-songwriter Robyn’s 2005 self-titled album.

annotations.text: Ask for it, I did it—that asshole done did it
annotations.annotation:
The general public perception of Kanye at the time was that he was a bit of an asshole, what with “George Bush doesn’t care about black people” and various minor award show controversies.

By 2009 the term used more often for him was “jackass”, largely because of President Obama.

annotations.text: Spit it, then he shit it
annotations.annotation:
“Spit it” is slang for rapping (“spitting lines”) and “shit it” is used similarly to “killing it”: doing it excellently. Like so:

‘Cause I dookied any song that they threw me on, gone

annotations.text:
I don't need writērs, I might bounce ideas
 But only I could come up with some shit like this
annotations.annotation:
Kanye doesn’t quite deny using writers – just that he doesn’t need them. He implies any help he gets is limited to him bouncing ideas off other writers.

Consequence’s account of his experience writing with Kanye differs slightly but roughly echoes this sentiment.

It is true I participated in writing with Kanye. You could read it on credits on 808s and Heartbreaks, College Dropout. Every album that he’s had, I’ve been involved from a creative aspect in writing of songs.

And Cons' went on to describe a line in “Champion” as “my brain thought”.

On the other hand, Rhymefest rather bluntly describes “Jesus Walks” as “my words”.



Barry Bonds notoriously hated speaking to baseball writers.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-zW-8OR7mj8

Bonds “don’t need writers”. He can still play baseball without them, but the baseball writers needed him and he sure provided them with lots of “ideas” to write about: chasing records, his steroid controversy, and his personality.

annotations.text:
I done played the underdog my whole career
 I've been a very good sport, haven't I, this year?
annotations.annotation:
In July 2007, West changed the release date of Graduation, his third album, from September 18, 2007, to the same release date as 50 Cent’s album Curtis, September 11, 2007

50 Cent later claimed that if Graduation were to sell more records than Curtis, he would stop releasing solo albums.

Kanye called the debate “stupid” (though surely he understood that it was all marketing):

When I heard that thing about the debate, I thought that was the stupidest thing. When my albums drops and 50's album drops, you're gonna get a lot of good music at the same time.


And then went on to absolutely murder 50’s album, sales-wise.

annotations.text: And I'm doing pretty hood in my pink polo
annotations.annotation:
Kanye maintains his credibility despite his preppy affectations.  The Brooklyn hip-hop group Das Racist later recorded a track about this meme with Spiderfang (“Pink Polo Shorts”)



This also references an incident wherein Beanie Sigel questioned Kanye’s sexuality because of the clothes he wears, going as far as telling him to “come out of the closet already.”

Note the wordplay used as a ‘hood’ also means thug or G, therefore Kanye refers to himself as a hood; the fact that his shirt is pink (pink often equates to ‘pretty’) makes him a “pretty hood.”

annotations.text:
Nigga, please, how you gon' say I ain't no Lo-head?
 'Cause my Dior got me more model head?
 I'm insulted,
annotations.annotation:
A “Lo-head” is a connoisseur of Polo clothes, and his Christian Dior outfit helped him bed models. Kanye often boasts about his fashion/style.

Kanye’s claiming to be a “Lo-head” would get him disses by real Lo-lifes – gangs who used to rob stores for Polos back in the day, many of whom became rappers.

annotations.text:
You should go 'head
 And bow so hard 'til your knees hit your forehead
annotations.annotation: Playing off of the Japanese theme in the first line, ‘Ye requests his haters worship him, which would usually involve bowing. In Japan, bowing to show respect is a common action.

annotations.text: And the flow just hit code red
annotations.annotation:
“Code Red” is a term coming from power plants/other facilities meaning something has gone wrong in the process. (i.e. a machine overheating, too much radiation spilling out) A Code Red is also accompanied by loud alarms, and usually flashing red emergency lights.

What Yeezy is saying with this line is that his rapping flow has become so tremendous that it should be shut down, turned off, ect.
YOU CANT HOLD HIM BACK!

annotations.text:
Top five MCs, you ain't gotta remind me
 Top five MCs, you gotta rewind me
annotations.annotation:
Kanye’s had a history of flaunting his confidence, so it’s no shock Ye drops another line filled with braggadocio. Kanye feels as if he’s a top 5 rapper, either at the time of the release or of all time. This isn’t a far stretch as MTV named him one of Top 5 hottest rappers in the game in 2007.

Kanye continues his confidence, stating that his rapping ability is so good that you have to rewind him after hearing his bars. It might be because he’s rhyming fast or because the lyrics are so good you have to listen to them twice, but regardless he’s that good that you need to hear it twice.

annotations.text: I'm high up on the line, you could get behind me
annotations.annotation: As he’s previously just bragged, he’s on top of everything in the rap game, so the only place left to be is behind him. This references the batting orders used in baseball, where a more respected player bats as leadoff hitter (e.g. Derek Jeter)

annotations.text: But my head's so big, you can't sit behind me (Sit behind me)
annotations.annotation:
He’s so arrogant (“head so big”) you won’t be able to see if you sit behind him. Kanye’s making fun of himself here, because he is full of himself and literally has a head too big for his body

Also an allusion to the song’s title character, Barry Bonds, whose head became suspiciously large (literally) later in his career as a side effect of alleged steroid use.

It’s also another reason why Kanye should avoid awards ceremonies, for the sake of everyone else…

annotations.text: Life of a Don, lights keep glowin'
annotations.annotation:
A Don is, in mafia terminology, the head of a family—it’s a status that implies power and respect mixed with crime and villainy. Kanye saw himself as the head of the rap (and style) game, despite being hated. He called himself the “Louis Vuitton Don” on “Last Call”.

Barry Bonds had “Don” status in baseball—the undisputed best player in the game, even as steroid allegations and his standoffish persona made him widely hated.

As Bonds approached Mark McGwire, Babe Ruth, and Hank Aaron’s home run records, his at-bats would be preceded by hundreds of flashing lights, as fans would try to catch snapshots of his record-breaking moments—"lights keep glowing."



Like Bonds, West experienced the Flashing Lights, as he was followed by the paparazzi. No matter what people thought of their personas, West and Bonds were undeniably stars.

annotations.text: Ayy, Mr. West, we so outta here, baby!
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne is directly speaking to “Mr. West” or Kanye West.

BUT ALSO

Barry Bonds played in the National League West. Being one of the most controversial, talked-about and best baseball players of all-time, he could conceivably be called “Mr. West”. Bonds won 7 National League Most Valuable Player awards during his career.

annotations.text: [Verse 3: Lil Wayne]
annotations.annotation:
Before the release of Graduation, Kanye had attracted criticism for his verses in comparison to his guest rappers. The consensus was Jay Z’s out-rapped Ye on “Diamonds From Sierra Leone (Remix),” which is just the first of many examples.

So Kanye, with the confidence that comes from being Kanye, decided to feature Lil Wayne—who at the time was starting to have his “I’m the Best Rapper Alive” boasts taken seriously.

Both Hip Hop DX and Pitchfork felt Kanye bested Wayne—something which was very uncommon circa 2007. A win on a track right when Ye needed it.

annotations.text: My teeth and my ice so white like Shady
annotations.annotation:
A play on his diamond jewelry being “white” like Eminem (Slim Shady). He also is commenting on Em’s unusually white teeth.



Again, even more evidence that the line before was a dig towards Eminem – in this line however he seems to form some metaphorical relation to him.

annotations.text: I'm so fuckin' good like I'm sleepin' with Meagan (Ha!)
annotations.annotation:
Meagan Good:



Note the “fucking good” / “sleeping with Meagan” wordplay

In retrospect, this line could hint towards the truth. In 2016, Meagan Good spoke with an NY Post stating she had indeed slept with The Rapper Eater along with others.

annotations.text: Oops, I meant "have them"—I'm so crazy
annotations.annotation: Wayne’s claim that he never writes anything down is perhaps belied by his occasional use of what we’ll call “typo humor” – that is, saying a word as it’s written and not as it’s pronounced, which is symptomatic of reading text aloud too fast: see also this verse from Tha Carter III, in which he willfully mispronounces “asinine” and later conflates “nine” and “none”

annotations.text: Sleeping with daisies
annotations.annotation: “Pushing up daisies” is a common euphemism for being dead, as is “sleeping with the fishes.” This is a new amalgamation, but it gets the point across.

annotations.text: Oops, I meant "have them"—I'm so crazy
annotations.annotation: Wayne’s claim that he never writes anything down is perhaps belied by his occasional use of what we’ll call “typo humor” – that is, saying a word as it’s written and not as it’s pronounced, which is symptomatic of reading text aloud too fast: see also this verse from Tha Carter III, in which he willfully mispronounces “asinine” and later conflates “nine” and “none”

annotations.text: And my drink's still pinker than the Easter rabbit
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne’s drink is still pink because he puts cough syrup in it, and it’s been that way since his famous verse on “We Takin' Over”:

I don’t even talk, I let the Visa speak
And I like my Sprite Easter-pink

annotations.text: And I'm still col' like Keyshia's family
annotations.annotation:
Play on words with “cool” and “col”.
Keyshia Cole’s family. Cole sounds like the word “cool” if you pronounce it like “col'”.

annotations.text: Stove on my waist turn beef to patties (Bow!)
annotations.annotation:
This means that his waist is HOT
When your waist is hot it means you’re packing heat which means a gun as also expounded from the ad lib BAOW! which is a gun sound



From there, Mr. Weezy goes on to explain that his gun will turn “beef” (a feud, especially between rappers) into “patties” (as in beef patties, or hamburgers).

annotations.annotation:
Weezy, like most rappers, claims to have sold crack prior to rapping.


Strong crack is called fire by fiends, the same way potent marijuana is called fire

Since Wayne has this fire, he’s the fireman



“You can spark it up and I'ma put you out,” is a double entendre.


Sexually, if the girl can spark Wayne’s interest and get it up, he will treat his dick like a firehose and blast her in the face
In pimp terms, Wayne is going to get the bitch hooked on crack and then put her out on the street to sell her ass for more crack money – she sparks it up and he puts her out

annotations.text: He-Man, ski mask, spendin' next week's cash, he fast (Oh)
annotations.annotation:
A ski mask is a form of cloth headgear designed to expose only part of the face. It’s usually used by robbers so that witnesses cannot recall their faces.
Weezy rocked a very unusual mask on the video for Drake’s single — “HYFR”.

annotations.text:
And I don't even need a G-pass, I'm past that
 I'm passin' 'em out now (Yeah), and you can't have that (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
A G pass is a “gangster pass” which is like a certificate of authenticity of gangsterness.  Wayne is now sufficiently gangster that people know it even if he doesn’t have the pass: in fact, he’s now in charge of doling them out (that’s a hard job to get!)

Also, if you tip a stripper a lot of money, it could be described as “trying to buy a G pass” (i.e., trying to give her $1,000 in tips so that she’ll let you touch her special parts)

It’s likely that Weezy intends this as a 2nd meaning, since he flashes a wad of dollar bills in the video when he says it

annotations.text: Gotta be abstract (Oh, no)
annotations.annotation:
In rapping about crime you have to be abstract as opposed to specific lest you incriminate yourself.

In a literal reference to the above line, his jewelry is highly mixed in color, so much so you have to think outside the box or abstractly to see what it is. His scheme is so bizarre that it takes thought to understand.



The abstraction ties into the classic line that follows in which he is not specifically saying he is a pimp, but “don’t be surprised if she asks where the cash at”.

annotations.text:
I see she wearin' them jeans that show her buttcrack (Hey)
 My girls can't wear that, why? That's where my stash at (Uh-uh-uh)
annotations.annotation:
His girls can’t wear low-rise jeans because they’re transporting drugs for him and the drugs would be visible and they’d get caught

This is a running theme among rappers, dating back to Biggie’s line from “Everyday Struggle”:

I got my honey on the Amtrak
With the crack in the crack of her ass

annotations.text: She need her candle lit (Yeah), and I'ma wax that (Got 'em)
annotations.annotation: He’s going to fuck her. To “wax” is to work something hard (think Karate Kid). Obviously a pun on the candle thing, possibly also a pubic hair depilation pun (remember that scene in Phenomenon where Kyra Sedgewick shaves John Travolta, gosh that was romantic)

annotations.text: Fresh on campus, it's the Birdman Junior (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne is Birdman Jr. (his surrogate father being Birdman of Big Tymers).

Wayne was taking classes at the University of Houston to study political science. He was actually going in person (but that got “out of control” so would soon stop and switch to the University of Phoenix to study psychology online).

Note the class rank wordplay:

Fresh – freshman
Jr. – Junior

annotations.text: Money too long, teachers, put away your rulers (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
Wayne has so much money that you can’t measure it (stacked up) with a ruler.



This also ties into the previous line, referring to Wayne arriving on a school campus. Teachers at a campus would most likely have a ruler with them in their classroom, along with other classic school supplies.

annotations.text: Raw Tune, not a cartoon (Ayy)
annotations.annotation:
His songs are raw: that is, they’re vivid descriptions of a harsh reality. They are not cartoonish fluff

His name is also Tunechi (usually shortened to Tune), playing on one of his many nicknames. His music is a raw reproduction of who he is.

Weezy recycled the line on his mixtape track “The Burn” from Da Drought 2. He also had the song “Raw Tune.”

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gFmmgd5zFnA

annotations.text: No shirt, tattoos, and some war wounds (Sexy)
annotations.annotation: Lil Wayne has over 326 tattoos.  The war wounds mentioned are a reference to the scar he acquired after accidentally shooting himself in the chest at age 11 with a 9mm pistol. These features are all clearly visible without a shirt on.

annotations.text: Been in that water since a youngin, you just shark food (Yum, yum)
annotations.annotation: On Tha Carter 2 Lil Wayne continually uses the water as a metaphor for the ghetto. This is very appropriate since after Katrina, his childhood neighborhood was effectively in the ocean for a while

annotations.text: Quick Draw McGraw, I went to art school (Hah)
annotations.annotation: Quick Draw McGraw was a cartoon character who was a sheriff in the Old West. Wayne plays with the double meaning of bragging how fast he can “draw” a gun and “draw” a picture.

annotations.text: Been handlin' the game so long, my thumbs bruised

My money three-sixty, you only one-eighty (That's right)
 Half of the game too lazy (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
He’s twice as rich as other rappers – he has enough money to own the whole rap game (360 degrees) whereas other rappers can only have half (180 degrees). It also means that his money comes back around when he spends it (360 degrees is a full circle), so he always makes his money back.

Lil Wayne probably learned this game from his “daddy” Birdman, who judges his bank account as a multiple of Weezy’s: “If Weezy got 15 I got 45”

annotations.text: Eagle, Eagle Carter man
annotations.annotation: Lil' Wayne grew up on the corner of Apple and Eagle Streets and The Carter was the album on which this song appears, so he’s shouting out his neighborhood and building his brand at the same time

annotations.text:
On my way to the east to the laundromat
 Got to wash that money and get on my ass
annotations.annotation: Weezy depicts money laundering. He has just gotten money off of a brick so he now has to make the money appear legal. A laundromat is where you go for cleaning services and he draws parallels between cleaning things at the laundromat and cleaning the dirty money he has off of drugs.

annotations.text:

Then it’s back to doing any damn thing just to get it

annotations.text:
I say, "Look coach they pitching at me under hand"
 But I'm a designated hitter I adjust so fast
annotations.annotation:
In baseball, in the majors nobody could get away with pitching underhand because you can’t throw fast enough

Lil Wayne’s enemies attempt to attack him “underhand” (with weak material) – but Lil Wayne isn’t some minor league chump: he’s like a designated hitter in the American League of Rap

Underhand pitch:

annotations.text: It's money over bitches that I am going to keep proving
annotations.annotation: Another nod to the M.O.B code which Wayne likes to remember us every now and then he follows strictly! He went as far as tatting it on his chest and recording a song with that title, with his father — The Birdman

annotations.text: Out of all the Hot Boys she say I'm the coolest
annotations.annotation:
Hot Boys was the group Wayne was a part of when he was a teenager.

Notice the juxtaposition of “Hot” and “Cool”.

annotations.text: But niggas'll never see me like Momma Tigger
annotations.annotation: The mother of the character Tigger, of Winnie the Pooh fame, is referred to in the story, but is never shown onscreen. Similarly Weezy is able to remain inconspicuous.

annotations.text:
So roll the carpet out
 'Cause you fucking with a nigga from the royal South
annotations.annotation: A red carpet is traditionally used to mark the route taken by heads of state on ceremonial and formal occasions, and has in recent decades been extended to use by VIPs and celebrities at formal events. Wayne of course is no stranger to it and implies that he should be treated as Royalty. As from the South reference, he may indeed be the biggest rapper to ever come from the Southern hip-hop scene, along with some other big names such as Outkast; Ludacris; Rick Ross, T.I. etc.

annotations.text: Hey bitch nigga get ya ass on the ground and bow down to ya majesty now I am the prince
annotations.annotation: Around this time, Wayne was aiming to drastically improve his skills and get more respect in the game. He started putting out much more work and started calling himself “the best rapper alive”. Wayne is letting everybody know that while he’s only the prince right now, he will eventually become king.

annotations.text:
There's no fear in my eyes where they lookin' at
 Better look on map
 Besides, me nah like to eye fight
 Me nah think such a ting is worth a man's life (Christ!)
annotations.annotation:
Scientists have long known that humans can find fear in others in their eyes. But, no matter how hard you look, during a confrontation Brooklyn boy Jay Z will have no fear in his eyes. Instead, he values honest eye-to-eye interactions.

Hov employs Jamaican Patois to express how ridiculous it would be for anyone to test him in his borough. He actively avoids confrontation and finds the idea of taking someone’s life over a disapproving look ridiculous. The use of Patois to express his sentiments makes sense in the fact that a large numbers of Jamaican immigrants reside in Brooklyn.

In 2010 Das Racist would take issue with Hov’s use of “fake Patois.”

annotations.text:
But if a man test my Stuy
 I promise he won't like my reply
annotations.annotation:
In the previous lines he expressed disdain at having to take someone’s life over trivial matters. But, if you test his Brooklyn borough, he may have no choice but to react violently and take a life. He was raised in the Marcy Projects, a public housing complex located in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn.

“Test my sty” could also refer to someone criticizing his rap or dress style. Either of these will have negative consequences for the perpetrator.

In a piece of homonym wordplay to link this first line back to the previous, a “stye” is an infection that causes a tender red lump on the eyelid.

annotations.text: Boom-bye-bye, like Buju, I'm crucial
annotations.annotation:
“Boom Bye Bye” is a track by Buju Banton about killing homosexuals. In the track he references Brooklyn women. Fellow Brooklyn artists Smif-n-Wessun used the same line and infliction on their 1995 track “Sound Bwoy Bureill.”

In 2012 Hov came out in support of same-sex marriage shortly after his friend President Obama did the same. Therefore this line may simply be Hov continuing to show his Brooklyn-related knowledge, not condoning Buju’s sentiments in “Boom Bye Bye.”

I’ve always thought it as something that was still holding the country back. What people do in their own homes is their business and you can choose to love whoever you love. That’s their business. It’s no different than discriminating against blacks. It’s discrimination, plain and simple.

annotations.text: I'm a Brooklyn boy, I may take some gettin' use to
annotations.annotation:
Hov has a strong Brooklyn personality, formed from his days growing up in the Marcy Projects and his years spent dealing crack cocaine on the streets.


Cough up a lung, where I’m from, Marcy son, ain’t nothing nice

Mentally been many places but I’m Brooklyn’s own

I’m from the M-to-the-A-baby-R-C-Y
So it’s hard for me to let the larceny die

I’m from murder, murder Marcyville
My nigga, you heard I clap you, I certainly will

annotations.text:
Chain snatchin', ain't have it, gotta get it
 Same shiddit, from Brownsville to Bainbriddidge
annotations.annotation:
“Chain snatching” is a similar street robbery move to purse snatch theft, except that it involves ripping someone’s necklace straight off their neck. Here Jay is suggesting that snatching and running is his general, Brooklyn-formed attitude towards all objects he does not possess.

Get your chain tooken
I may do it myself, I’m so Brooklyn!

Brownsville is one of the most dangerous neighborhoods in Brooklyn; while Bainbridge is a main street that runs through Bedford-Stuyvesant. Hov has no qualms about pulling the same shit all over Brooklyn.

annotations.text:
Fatherless child, Mama pulled double shifts
 So the number runners was the only ones I hanged widdith
 Before you know it I'm in the game, bang fiddith
annotations.annotation: Jay-Z’s father left him when he was 11 and since his mom was always busy working, he started only hanging out on the streets and getting into criminal activity. More about the numbers game here

annotations.text: Fear no orangutans,
annotations.annotation:
By “orangutans”, Jay is referring to the habit of gangsters to call themselves “guerillas”, a la 50 Cent’s G-Unit (originally “Guerilla Unit”); note the “guerilla/gorilla” pun he’s making

Also a play on the idea of the city as a “concrete jungle”

annotations.text: Like oranges-es, I'm dangerous
annotations.annotation:
This might be a stretch, but he may be referring to the cinematography in the Godfather. Simply put, if you see any character in the Godfather near an orange (or even orange slices in a jug), they are about to die; thereby making the oranges very dangerous.

Considering the the story of the Godfather is set in New York city, of which Brooklyn is a borough, and home to the controlling Tattaglia family; Jay Z might be a fan of this organized crime drama, the genre which his album American Gangster (2007) draws inspiration from.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jY8yBhhZkwY

We can also see Hov' making connections to the movie back in his 2002 album; The Blueprint², on the song Guns & Roses.

“Every time I get out, they pull me right back in”
“The Michael Corleone of the microphone”

https://genius.com/Jay-z-guns-and-roses-lyrics#note-230637

annotations.text:
I father, I Brooklyn-Dodger them
 I jack, I rob, I sin
 Aw, man—I'm Jackie Robinson
 'Cept when I run base, I dodge the pen
annotations.annotation:
Jackie Robinson was the first black athlete to play Major League Baseball in the 20th century as a member of the Brooklyn Dodgers. “Dodger” means criminal; Jack “the Artful Dodger” Dawkins was Oliver Twist’s pickpocket mentor in Dickens' classic novel. Hov references his criminal past by stating that he jacks, robs, and sins, thus making him Jackie Robinsin



This is one of Hov’s, and rap’s, greatest triple entendre:


When Jay “runs base” – sells drugs like freebase cocaine – he aims to dodge jail time in the penitentiary. Meanwhile in baseball Jackie Robinson is running bases, dodging so as to not to get tagged out and sent back to the pen scoreless. His high speed made him excellent at stealing bases. In his first year in the MLB he hit 12 home runs and helped the 1947 Dodgers win the National League pennant.
A homophone of base/bass: When Jay raps along to the bass of the beat, he freestyles rather than writing raps beforehand. Therefore he is “dodging the pen.”
The pen Robinson isn’t dodging likely is the one that was used to sign his Brooklyn Dodgers contracts. Because Jay runs base (sells drugs), he doesn’t have to sign any paperwork, as his work is illegal.



Note how Hov begins the verse with “I father” like a prayer. He later says “Aww man” – which sounds like “Amen” to end the prayer. God protecting him while he is jacking, robbing and sinning in his Brooklyn prayer.

New Yorkers used to call anyone from Brooklyn “trolley dodgers” because of the numerous street-car lines that criss-crossed the borough. This is where the Brooklyn Dodgers got their name from.



In 2013, this track was used in a trailer and several television commercials for the Jackie Robinson biopic 42: The True Story of an American Legend.

annotations.text: Now when I bring the Nets, I'm the Black Branch Rickey
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z was a part owner of the Nets and at the time he wanted to move them to Brooklyn. Branch Rickey was the white general manager of the Dodgers who signed Jackie Robinson (referenced earlier). So if Jay-Z brought the Nets to Brooklyn, this would be groundbreaking because he’s a black NBA owner and he’d be bringing a new team to Brooklyn

Mission accomplished in 2012:

annotations.text: Spread love, Biggie; Brooklyn, hippie
annotations.annotation:
Jay is alluding to the Notorious BIG line from “Juicy”: “spread love, it’s the Brooklyn way”

For Jay, Biggie’s words are the Brooklyn thug version of the hippie slogan from the 60’s: “Make love, not war”

annotations.text:
I pity the fool with jewels like Mr. T
 With no history in my borough, they borrow
 With no intentions of returnin' tomorrow
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z pities flashy guys who come into BK with no history there, because their jewels will be borrowed and not returned (stolen), and they may end up dead.

First line also references Mr. T’s famous line from Rocky III, “I pity the fool” (which even became a TV show!)

So if you’re a stranger, don’t come round lookin' like this:

annotations.text:
The sun don't come out for many, like Annie
 Half-orphan, Mama never had an abortion
 Papa sort of did; still, I managed to live
 I go hard, I owe it all to the crib
annotations.annotation:
Jay has a strong connection to the musical Annie, which began with the sampling of “It’s a Hard Knock Life” on his Platinum hit single “Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)” in 1998. To get the sample cleared he told the musical’s writer and director Martin Charnin that he had seen the play as a child and connected with the young orphan Annie.

Connecting this section to the previous bar is the fact that “Tomorrow” is another song from the musical, with lyrics that speak on keeping faith in dire situations as “the sun will come out tomorrow.”



While Gloria Carter didn’t have an abortion, Hov feels his father chose to do this in a way by abandoning him when he was 11 or 12 years old. He has said he owes his success and drive to his mother sticking around and providing a stable home for him and his siblings:

My Mom was just such a strong woman. A beautiful, strong woman who never allowed me to feel sorry for myself and always gave me inspiration. She told me I could be anything in the world, and don’t let anyone tell me different. Those things she told me I believe whole-heartedly to this day. I was the clay that she molded.

annotations.text: Get so dark, but I see good
annotations.annotation: Apparently, Brooklyn natives favor a diet rich in vitamin A, because even though the street lights go out regularly and it is very dark, Santi has excellent night vision. It must come from all the “leafy greens” that they consume on a regular. Thanks, beta-carotene!
