annotations.text: ("Fuck all you hoes!" Get a grip, motherfucker!)
annotations.annotation: “Get a grip” means, “try to control yourself,” or “take a reality check,” which is Big’s response to the previous “fuck all y'all hoes” line. In a field crowded with aggressive cartoon thugs, Biggie is about to bring us all down to earth with a deeply personal reflection on his roots, setting himself apart from his one-dimensional competitors.

annotations.text:
Yeah, this album is dedicated
 To all the teachers that told me I'd never amount to nothin'
annotations.annotation:
According to Miss Wallace, B.I.G.’s mother, in the biography Unbelievable: The Life, Death, and Afterlife of the Notorious B.I.G., this exchange happened between B.I.G. and his teacher:

BIG: Do you know how much a garbage collector makes, sir?
Teacher: No.
BIG: A teacher makes a starting salary of $22,500, a garbage collector starts at $29,000
Teacher: Do you have a point, Mr. Wallace?
BIG: Yes, sir. You said some of us inside here are gonna be garbage collectors. But we’re gonna be making more money than you, so that’s cool.

The encounter was also acted out in the movie interpretation of Biggie’s life, Notorious.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MHFR8fKTqI4#t=12

annotations.text:
To all the people that lived above the buildings that I was hustlin' in front of
 Called the police on me when I was just tryin' to make some money to feed my daughter (it's all good)
annotations.annotation:
According to a New York Times interview from 1994, Biggie sold drugs from when he was 12 years old. He worked the area highlighted in red below, around the corner from his mother’s home (highlighted in orange) in Clinton-Hill (then considered a part of Bed-Stuy), Fulton Street between St. James Place and Washington Avenue:



Biggie’s first daughter, T'yanna Wallace, was born on August 8, 1993, one year before this song was released. Though he was already signed to Puff Daddy’s Bad Boy Records at the time, he continued selling drugs to support his daughter until Diddy found out and forced him to quit.

annotations.text:
And all the niggas in the struggle
 You know what I'm sayin'? It's all good, baby baby
annotations.annotation:
Biggie did not have it easy growing up and had a single mother who struggled with money. Like many others, he had to resort to drug dealing in order to make money and dropped out of high school aged 17.
The struggles Biggie experienced in his life are the same struggles so many were and still are putting up with now and Biggie wants this song to give a message of hope for those in the hood who are struggling to make it in life.

annotations.text: [Verse 1: The Notorious B.I.G.]
annotations.annotation: This verse was later used in Jay-Z’s song “A Dream” from The Blueprint 2: The Gift & the Curse in 2002.

annotations.text: It was all a dream, I used to read Word Up! magazine
annotations.annotation:
Biggie’s most famous lyric, and arguably one of the most iconic lyrics in hip-hop history. Big establishes the song’s nostalgic theme by remembering his childhood dreams of being a rapper.

Word Up! was a teen music magazine that featured posters and party photos of rappers and R&B singers.

In the 1980s, before journalistically credible hip-hop magazines like The Source and VIBE were available, Word Up! was one of the only places to see and learn about rap artists.

Here’s an issue from 1990 (when Big was 17 years old) that features Salt-N-Pepa and Heavy D:



The popularity and influence of this lyric can’t be overstated.


Complex ranked it #1 on their list of the best opening lines in rap history.
Jay-Z built an entire song (“A Dream”) around it.
Bad Boy’s pop girl group named their album (It Was All A Dream) after it.
Over 500 artists have quoted, sampled, and interpolated it on their own songs, including Missy Elliott, The Game, Vampire Weekend, Usher, Migos, and Wu-Tang Clan.

annotations.text: Salt-n-Pepa and Heavy D up in the limousine
annotations.annotation:
Salt ‘n’ Pepa are considered one of the great rap groups of all time, as well as two female pioneers in the game.

Jamaican-American rapper Heavy D and Biggie eventually became friends. They recorded “A Buncha Niggas”, “Jam Session” and Heavy D made a cameo on the video for “One More Chance”

And, while they’re not actually in the picture together, they were both featured on the cover of the June 1990 issue of Word Up!:

annotations.text: Hangin' pictures on my wall
annotations.annotation:
Pictures he had cut out from Word-Up… as he is seen doing at this moment in the video:

https://youtu.be/_JZom_gVfuw?t=24s

annotations.text: Every Saturday Rap Attack, Mr. Magic, Marley Marl
annotations.annotation: Rap Attack was the first exclusively-rap show to be aired on a major radio station. It hosted by Mr. Magic, DJed by Marley Marl, and featured Tyrone “Fly Ty” Williams as the show’s co-producer. It debuted in 1981 in New York City on WHBI-FM and moved to WBLS-FM in July 1982.

annotations.text: I let my tape rock 'til my tape popped
annotations.annotation:
When you play a tape all the way to the end of one side, the cassette door pops open. In 1980s it was very common for kids to tape the radio shows they loved, while choosing the songs they wanted to record, so they could listen to them again later.

Biggie was implying that Rap Attack was so good that he’d “rock his tape” (record the whole show) without making any edits until he hit the very end of the tape and it popped out. This is major props to the show’s hosts, Mr. Magic and Marley Marl.



Biggie might also be saying that he played those tapes so much that they eventually “popped” (got ruined), which was very common with old cassettes.

annotations.text: Smokin' weed in Bambú, sippin' on Private Stock
annotations.annotation:
Biggie is a fan of Bambu brand rolling papers.

Here’s a young Barack Obama looking like the Bambu guy:



Private Stock is type of malt liquor from Boston, i.e. the capitalization of “Private Stock”, which also means Biggie’s own personal supply

annotations.text:
Way back, when I had the red and black lumberjack
 With the hat to match
annotations.annotation: A matching flannel shirt and hat Biggie wore in his youth. As portrayed in Notorious:

annotations.text:
Remember Rappin' Duke? Duh-ha, duh-ha
 You never thought that hip-hop would take it this far
annotations.annotation:
“Rappin' Duke” was a 1984 novelty rap song “performed” by the late Hollywood icon John Wayne (whose nickname was “Duke”).

The song was actually recorded by standup comedian Shawn Brown,  and the song’s chorus, “duh-ha, duh-ha,” was an impression of Wayne’s distinctive laugh.

https://youtu.be/RAkB1CabkAo?t=18

In the early 1980s, many critics thought hip-hop would be a short-lived “fad,” an impression that was fueled by the popularity of gimmicky parody songs like “Rappin' Duke,” “Rappin' Rodney,” and “The Superbowl Shuffle.”

annotations.text: Now I'm in the limelight 'cause I rhyme tight
annotations.annotation:
It probably had a little bit more to do with than tight rhymes, but Biggie took rap to the next level with his forward thinking rap skills.



The Limelight was a club owned by notorious NYC club king Peter Gatien in the 80s and 90s, housed in a former church on 20th Street in Manhattan. The club was well known Sunday hip hop night that was the setting for some of Hip Hop’s best performances, namely earlier performances by Biggie and Jay Z.

“In the limelight” is also an idiom that means “to be a celebrity” or “to be in the public eye.” It comes from an old type of bulbs used for stage lighting, which contained the chemical “quicklime”. Even today, the electric stage lights used are referred to as “limes”.

annotations.text: Time to get paid, blow up like the World Trade
annotations.annotation:
This is a reference to the 1993 bombing of NYC’s World Trade Center.



On February 26, 1993, a group of Middle Eastern terrorists detonated a van packed with explosives in the basement parking lot of the Center’s North Tower. The attack—which produced minimal damage to the building— was in response to America’s support of Israel.

Biggie is “blowing up"—quickly becoming rich and famous—and here he’s using a recent explosion as a metaphor for his sudden impact.

After the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, where the towers were destroyed, the words “World Trade” were frequently censored when “Juicy” was played on the radio.

This line became one of Big’s most famous lyrics, inspiring his July 1995 cover shoot with The Source Magazine. Photographer Chi Modu remembers:

When the idea came to me to represent Notorious B.I.G as the King of New York, I thought what better setting than to have two of the quintessential New York City buildings in the background.

annotations.text: Born sinner, the opposite of a winner
annotations.annotation:
Some people might claim that if you’re born in an area like Bed-Stuy (where Biggie is from) you’re born to sin, because some people from those areas need to do crime in order to survive.



The line went on to be the inspiration for J. Cole’s sophomore album’s title, Born Sinner, and was sampled on the hook of “Villuminati”.

annotations.text: Remember when I used to eat sardines for dinner
annotations.annotation: Sardines are a type of fish, usually sold in a can. They are cheap and usually cost a few dollars for just a can of them. In other words, their low cost appeals to struggling families. B.I.G. recalls what it was like being impoverished and eating the cheap fish. It is a moment of realization that he has “made it” and is financially well-off.

annotations.text:
Peace to Ron G, Brucie B, Kid Capri
 Funkmaster Flex, Lovebug Starski
annotations.annotation:
A shoutout to five iconic New York hip-hop DJs.


Ron G is a Harlem DJ, best known for his “blend” mixtape and stint on WBLS in the late 1980s. Before “Juicy,” he worked with Biggie on Mary J. Blige’s “Real Love (Remix)” and a song called “Stop The Breaks.”
Brucie B is Harlem DJ famous for his live mixtapes and parties at the ’80s club The Rooftop. He became Bad Boy’s official tour DJ months after “Juicy” dropped.
Kid Capri is a Bronx DJ known as the first true superstar of the mixtape scene, starting in the late ’80s. He later made a cameo in Biggie’s “One More Chance” video.
Funkmaster Flex is a Bronx DJ known for his shows on KISS-FM in the late ’80s and Hot 97 starting in 1992. He conducted Biggie’s first radio interview in 1994 on Hot 97.
Lovebug Starski was a Bronx DJ known for appearing at pioneering hip-hop clubs Disco Fever and Harlem World, staring in the late ’70s. He claims to have helped invent the word “hip-hop” with Furious 5’s Cowboy.



Ron G remembered a pre-“Juicy” Biggie in a 2014 Nah Right interview:

He would always come to my house, and talk about how he wanted to be rich. Like, ‘Yo, the nigga Puff, he about to sign a nigga, G.’ And was like, ‘Yo, that’s what’s up!’ [Laughs.] To be a part of hip-hop history, and see a person before they become a star, it’s feelings you can not even imagine. And I always had the blessings to see that.

annotations.text: I'm blowin' up like you thought I would
annotations.annotation:
This was Biggie’s debut album, and he had only recently started to taste fame.

Notably, he’d been featured on the remix of Mary J. Blige’s “Real Love”, and his song “Party and Bullshit” had been included on the soundtrack to Who’s the Man?.

annotations.text: Call the crib, same number, same hood
annotations.annotation:
This is true! Biggie lived in his mother’s apartment (#3L) at 226 St. James Place until after Ready to Die’s release.  As told in The New York Times shortly after the album came out:


[D]espite new-found economic independence and the fear he feels while sitting in his own home, he is reluctant to move.

“I could never see myself moving in the suburbs,” he said. “It ain’t going to be right, and the lyrics are going to be soundin' nasty. I know it. There won’t be nothing to rap about except the birds.”


This shows that despite “blowin' up” Biggie has stayed true to his roots in the hood and isn’t going to let go of the people who he’s grown up with.

annotations.text: It's all good
annotations.annotation:
Big used to hustle for a living to feed his family now he has a career in music that he is certain is going somewhere, now he can look after himself, his family and friends!

Note: Puff Daddy can be heard ad-libbing this line (and many others throughout the song) in the background.

annotations.text:
You know very well (Yeah)
 Who you are (Money, hoes and clothes)
 Don't let 'em hold you down (Bankrolls, yeah, haha)
 Reach for the stars (It's all good)
 You had a goal (C'mon)
 But not that many (It's all good)
 'Cause you're the only one
 I'll give you good and plenty (Check it)
annotations.annotation:
This iconic hook, sung by girl-group Total, is a flip on the chorus of Mtume’s “Juicy Fruit”, which is sampled for the beat. The lyrics of the original are as follows:

You know very well what you are
You’re my sugar thing, my chocolate star
I’ve had a few, but not that many
But you’re the only love, that gives me good and plenty

Biggie’s version flips the meaning, addressing his aspiration to fame rather than romantic love, but keeps the  reference to Good & Plenty candy, which B.I.G. presumably ate by the handful.

annotations.text:
I made the change from a common thief
 To up close and personal with Robin Leach
 And I'm far from cheap,
annotations.annotation:
Robin Leach was the host of the reality TV show Lifestyles of the Rich & Famous, which aired between 1983 and 1995. The show featured interview segments where Leach got up close and personal with wealthy celebrities and socialites.



The “Juicy” music video features a pool party at a mansion in The Hamptons, a scene straight out of an episode of Lifestyles. Big’s even being interviewed by a reporter, which he mentions (“interviews by the pool”) later in this verse.

Prior to Biggie, a number of artists had referenced Lifestyles of the Rich & Famous in their music, including Ice Cube, Ice-T, CL Smooth, Akinyele, R. Kelly, 2 Live Crew, Lakim Shabazz, Original Flavor, Above The Law, and Master P.

In the October 1994 issue of The Source, Miss Info made a pun on the show’s title in her review of Biggie’s debut, Ready To Die:

Like a lyrical version of the movie The Killer, Big weaves tales like a cinematographer. Each song is like another scene in his Lifestyles of the Black and Shameless, the Tec and the stainless.

It’s also possible that Biggie’s use of the word “change” is a double entendre—he changed his life, but he also made change (as in small money) when he was a common thief.

Using the phrase “common thief”—an old British expression—gives Big an air of sophistication. In the “Juicy” video, he’s shown behind bars in prison when the line is rapped. His life as a stick-up kid is further detailed on classic songs like “Gimme The Loot.”

annotations.text: I smoke skunk with my peeps all day
annotations.annotation:
Skunk is a term given to literally dank strains of weed that smell like a skunk’s spray. It might be why whenever you smell a skunk that’s been run over on the freeway, you crave a Double-Double and a milkshake…



Biggie smokes up his whole crew like a true baller.

annotations.text: Spread love, it's the Brooklyn way
annotations.annotation:
Shoutout to his hometown!

To build on the previous line (“i’m far from cheap”), he spreads LOVE in the form of money to those he grew up with, rather than being greedy and keeping it all for himself. As he says in Big Poppa:

Givin' ends to my friends and it feels stupendous

annotations.text: The Moët and Alizé keep me pissy,
annotations.annotation:
Big stays drunk (“pissy”) off Moët champagne and Alizé, a blend of cognac and passion fruit juice.



Both were considered sophisticated drink choices in 1994, when artists like Nas, Above The Law, and Queen Latifah first began name-dropping Alizé in their songs.

Biggie was the first rapper to mention mixing champagne and Alizé. In 1995, likely inspired by Big, both R. Kelly and Jodeci mentioned the mix of Moët and Alizé on songs.

In 1996, 2Pac wrote an entire song about the mix of champagne and Alizé, which he dubbed “Thug Passion” (although he replaced Moët with a more expensive brand, Cristal). He shouts out Alizé throughout All Eyez On Me, including this reference:

Yo, two years ago, a friend of mine
Told me Alize and Cristal blows your mind

Was 2Pac’s “friend” Biggie? Probably not, but it’s an interesting coincidence that this line from “Juicy"—the first mention of champagne and Alizé on wax—had come out two years ago.

annotations.text:
Girls used to diss me
 Now they write letters 'cause they miss me
annotations.annotation:
BIG’s starting to get fan letters and girls from his hood (the ones who used to diss him) are relaying how much they miss him because he is successful and rich.

They paid him no mind when he wasn’t famous but now that he’s become a big deal in the music industry, all the ladies are trying to get a hold of him.



This line is also a reference to 2Pac’s verse in Digital Underground’s track “Same Song”.

Girls used to frown, say I’m down, when I come around
Gas me and when they pass me they use to diss me
Harass me, but now they ask me if they can kiss me

annotations.text:
I never thought it could happen, this rapping stuff
 I was too used to packing gats and stuff
annotations.annotation: Biggie never thought rapping would be his future. He just freestyled on the streets for fun. His job was selling drugs, and he was arrested on weapons charges in Brooklyn and sentenced to five years probation. It wasn’t until his release from jail in 1992 that he made his first demo–with no serious intentions. But the editor of The Source Magazine heard the demo and featured Biggie in the ‘Unsigned Hype’ column. Word soon got to upcoming producer Puff Daddy and we all know what happened next.

annotations.text:
Now honeys play me close like butter play toast
 From the Mississippi down to the East Coast
annotations.annotation:
Note the bread related wordplay with HONEYs, butter and toast!

Now Biggie and women are about as inseparable as butter and toast are together, no matter where he is. Whether he finds himself on the East or on the West Coast, he’s still getting mad love!

annotations.text: Condos in Queens,
annotations.annotation: A neighbouring NYC borough to his native Brooklyn. In the early 90s Manhattan wasn’t quite the bougie paradise that it is now, so Queens was a perfectly admirable aspiration.

annotations.text: Sold out seats to hear Biggie Smalls speak
annotations.annotation:
While he may not have given many speeches in his short career, Biggie’s most likely using “speak” to mean “rap” here.

His live shows were indeed lit:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ji_l8eylXdc

annotations.text: Living life without fear
annotations.annotation: B.I.G. was struggling back in the hood, looking over his shoulder all the time to make sure the cops or other dealers weren’t on his back. Now that he’s on top, he feels more physically secure in addition to his newfound financial security.

annotations.text: Puttin' five karats in my baby girl ear
annotations.annotation:
Biggie’s first child was born while he was in prison and unable to afford nice things (or even diapers) for her. Now that he made it, he’s buying her the finest jewelry.

Biggie often said things like, “I just want to be able to feed my daughter” or “I want to make something of myself”. He didn’t want to change the world, like maybe 2Pac did. Biggie was a very simple guy, whose main goal was to provide for his family.

Interesting note: five karats refers to gold or diamonds with 5 fine parts per 24 whole, i.e. a 5/24 purity with 24/24 being the highest possible. Biggie most likely is talking about five carats (with a C), which refers to 1 gram of gold in total.

annotations.text: Lunches, brunches,
annotations.annotation:
Biggie mentions brunches as a sign of the high life. While a brunch isn’t too expensive or flashy, brunches still haven’t really caught on in the ‘hood.

Also, the fact that he eats brunch AND lunch is another indication of opulence. (And it’s part of why he looks the way he does.)

annotations.text: Interviews by the pool
annotations.annotation: The pool featured in the music video for this song went on the market in 2012 (along with the Hamptons house it was on the roof of (!)) for $10.975 Million.

annotations.text: Considered a fool 'cause I dropped out of high school
annotations.annotation:
You say “I’m cool, huh, I’m no fool”
But then you wind up droppin' outta high school

He did indeed drop out of high school at age 17. But most of that is because he had to find a way to make money, and continuing to go to school wasn’t helping with that.

This could also be a reference to King Tee’s “Played Like a Piano”:

“I went to high school, but I flunked every class”

After-all, King T has been mentioned as one of Biggie’s favorite MCs.

annotations.text: Stereotypes of a black male misunderstood
annotations.annotation:
The obstacles Biggie faced as a young black man in America still face the population today.


One in six black men had been incarcerated as of 2001. If current trends continue, one in three black males born today can expect to spend time in prison during his lifetime.
African Americans represent 12% of the total population of drug users, but 38% of those arrested for drug offenses, and 59% of those in state prison for a drug offense.
African Americans serve virtually as much time in prison for a drug offense (58.7 months) as whites do for a violent offense (61.7 months).
In 2002, blacks constituted more than 80% of the people sentenced under the federal crack cocaine laws and served substantially more time in prison for drug offenses than did whites, despite that fact that more than 2/3 of crack cocaine users in the U.S. are white or Hispanic.
35% of black children grades 7-12 have been suspended or expelled at some point in their school careers compared to 20% of Hispanics and 15% of whites



(source)

annotations.text:
You know very well (Yeah)
 Who you are (Money, hoes and clothes)
 Don't let 'em hold you down (Bankrolls, yeah, haha)
 Reach for the stars (It's all good)
 You had a goal (C'mon)
 But not that many (It's all good)
 'Cause you're the only one
 I'll give you good and plenty (Check it)
annotations.annotation:
This iconic hook, sung by girl-group Total, is a flip on the chorus of Mtume’s “Juicy Fruit”, which is sampled for the beat. The lyrics of the original are as follows:

You know very well what you are
You’re my sugar thing, my chocolate star
I’ve had a few, but not that many
But you’re the only love, that gives me good and plenty

Biggie’s version flips the meaning, addressing his aspiration to fame rather than romantic love, but keeps the  reference to Good & Plenty candy, which B.I.G. presumably ate by the handful.

annotations.text:
Super Nintendo, Sega Genesis
 When I was dead broke, man, I couldn't picture this
annotations.annotation:
Super Nintendo and Sega Genesis are video game consoles that were popular in the early ’90s. The systems cost between $150 and $200 (not to mention the $50 games), an unattainable luxury when Big was a teenager. The Console War between Sega and Nintendo was in full-swing during the 90s similar to the rivalry between Playstation and Xbox nowadays. Each child had to pick a side since nobody was rich enough to have both. Biggie is saying he’s able to live his childhood dreams by saying he has both of the consoles.



Biggie raps about playing Nintendo with his crew on Junior M.A.F.I.A.’s 1995 hit “Get Money”:

You wanna sip Mo' on my living room flo'
Play Nintendo with Cease and Nino

He raps about playing Sega on Pudgee Tha Phat Bastard’s 1995 track “Think Big”:

Flipping coke in corner store bodegas
In the back room playing Sega, Street Fighter II

annotations.text: 50-inch screen,
annotations.annotation: Huge TVs in the pre-flat-screen 1990s weren’t common at all, or very pretty.

annotations.text: Money-green leather sofa
Got two rides, a limousine with a chauffeur
annotations.annotation:
Biggie has 2 cars plus a limousine. One of this cars probably was a Toyota Land Cruiser J8 (build year 1990-1997). There’s a photo of him with this ride, as he says, and he also mentions it for example in “Machine Gun Funk”.

Come on the ave, I’m real hard to find now
Cause I’m knee-deep in the beats
In the Land Cruiser Jeep with the MAC-10 by the seats



He must have been a big fan of those Asian cars, especially of Toyota and Lexus. In many lines he mentions these marques such as in “Ready To Die”:

I want it all from the Rolexes
To the Lexus. Getting paid is all I expected
My mother didn’t give me what I want, what the fuck?

annotations.text: Phone bill about two G's flat
annotations.annotation:
In the 90s, roaming charges were insane, and there were no warnings when “roaming” charges kicked in. Often you could rack up massive cell phone bills without ever getting a warning.

Back in those days, NYNEX was the phone provider for NY. It was common practice for NYNEX and all “baby bells” to have local (in your area code), regional (within your area and surrounding area codes), and long distance calling plans. Perhaps calling out of the region cost a lot, but what must have really jacked up the bills was Biggie’s cell phone, seen in the music video for Warning:



Biggie also had a pager (Like texting, except the only thing you could text is a callback number). In Warning, he starts off the verse by asking “Who the fuck is this? Paging me at 5:46 in the morning?"

Maybe that’s how he racked up such a high phone bill.

annotations.text: No need to worry, my accountant handles that
annotations.annotation: It’s the ultimate progression; from being poor and having to worry about every penny so he could feed him and his family, to being rich and spending two thousand dollars on a phone bill. This might feel like a throwaway line, but the relief and contentment that Big displays in it are indicative of all the hard work he has put into his career.

annotations.text: And my whole crew is loungin'

Celebrating every day, no more public housin'
 Thinkin' back on my one-room shack
annotations.annotation:
While not an actual shack, the apartment Biggie grew up in was in the then-dangerous, now-Bougie Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn (then considered a part of Bed-Stuy).

It probably wasn’t very nice back in 1993, but a lot’s changed since then. In 2013, apartment #3L at 226 St. James Place went on the market as a newly-renovated 3-bedroom for $725,000.



not a shack

Lots of famous people lived in Bed-Stuy–Big Daddy Kane, Jay-Z, Aaliyah, Fabolous, O.D.B.,  Chris Rock, Mike Tyson, Lena Horne, the list goes on.

annotations.text: Now my mom pimps an Ac' with minks on her back
annotations.annotation: Biggie’s mom, Voletta Wallace, went from being a single mother working two jobs to wearing mink coats and pushing an “Ac,” which is an abbreviation for Acura, the luxury vehicle division of Japanese automaker Honda, on the back of her son’s success. Shoutout to moms.

annotations.text: And she loves to show me off of course
annotations.annotation: Biggie’s mother Voletta is proud of  her son and how he changed his life and always brags about his accomplishments to her friends and relatives.

annotations.text: Smiles every time my face is up in The Source
annotations.annotation:
The Source is one of the most popular hip hop magazines

Notice the parallel between Biggie’s use of Word-Up Magazine in the first verse (which is about his humble beginnings) in which he reads the magazine, to his use of The Source in the third verse (which is about his life at the top), in which he is on the cover of the magazine



“Unsigned Hype,” from The Source:
http://www.thesource.com/articles/66524/

annotations.text: We used to fuss when the landlord dissed us
annotations.annotation:
Biggie’s mother had trouble paying for rent and heat.

Hood landlords are notoriously strict and crabby, often evicting families over tiny amount of money and generally scamming the neighborhood

annotations.text:
No heat, wonder why Christmas missed us
 Birthdays was the worst days
 Now we sip Champagne when we thirsty
annotations.annotation:
Christmas and birthday gifts were not within the budget of Big’s family. However, after Biggie made it, not only did Champagne become affordable, but he also set it as his standard.

An alternative (yet very plausible) explanation for missing out on Christmas and birthdays is that Biggie’s mom was a Jehovah’s witness, and Witnesses do not celebrate Christmas or birthdays.

Another explanation is that they didn’t celebrate Christmas because their chimney was broken (thus “no heat”). The idea of Santa entering homes through the chimney is an old tradition.

annotations.text:
Uh, damn right I like the life I live
 'Cause I went from negative to positive and it's all (It's all good, nigga)
annotations.annotation: A lot of times rappers that come from the tough hoods are being accused of being sell outs or not being real anymore. 2Pac talked about it in “I Ain’t Mad At Cha”. Biggie is saying that he’s not ashamed of being rich and in the life he lives now, he earned the right to enjoy himself.

annotations.annotation: B-Town is a slang term for Brooklyn, his home town. He references the borough constantly throughout his songs to show that he is proud of where he’s from.

annotations.text: Junior Mafia, mad flavor (Bad Boy)
annotations.annotation: Biggie gives a shoutout to his prodigies Junior M.A.F.I.A., who he helped mentor during their collective career in the mid-90’s. Junior M.A.F.I.A. broke out into the mainstream with the release of their 1995 album Conspiracy, which featured verses and production from The Notorious B.I.G. himself. Think of Junior M.A.F.I.A. almost like Biggie’s posse.

annotations.text: [Produced by Pete Rock and Poke of Trackmasters]
annotations.annotation:
The title of this song, as well as the backdrop for the beat are both derived from Mtume’s “Juicy Fruit.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vnUUgMVd9J0

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bnUgNP5VmNU

Pete Rock alleged that Diddy stole the idea for the original song’s beat after hearing it from him during a visit. Rock explained this in an interview with Wax Poetics:

I did the original version, didn’t get credit for it. They came to my house, heard the beat going on the drum machine, it’s the same story. You come downstairs at my crib, you hear music. He heard that shit and the next thing you know it comes out. They had me do a remix, but I tell people, and I will fight it to the end, that I did the original version of that. I’m not mad at anybody, I just want the correct credit.

The original Pete Rock mix:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hfMgsXzFftA

Jay cleverly sings along with this part of the song out of tune – just the type of thing that insincere artists use auto-tune to fix

annotations.text: Only rapper to rewrite history without a pen
annotations.annotation:
A lot of rappers brag about not writing their lyrics (with a pen) before rapping in the studio. Like Lil Wayne in “A Milli”

Jay-Z, actually spits his shit off the top of the head. Some other rappers do the same. It has been highly publicized that he does not traditionally write down rhymes before he might step into the booth

Sidenote: Producer No I.D. said in an interview that upon hearing the beat in a studio session with Jay-Z, Kanye West came up with this hook which would explain the next lines similarity to “Big Brother.”

annotations.text:
No I.D. on the track let the story begin...
 Begin...
 Begin
annotations.annotation:
The beat is courtesy of Kanye’s mentor No I.D. It’s a interpolated line from Kanye’s track, “Big Brother”

No I.D. explains the creation of the song more in-depth here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CgMglv3eYcg

No I.D. also told New York Times that Jay-Z wrote “D.O.A.” in a little under a day following a jokey conversation between the producers and Jay about “Crank Dat” by Soulja Boy Tell ‘Em

The line is a double entendre, as Jay-Z, rather unusually, doesn’t say his own name anywhere in the song.

annotations.text: This ain’t for iTunes,
annotations.annotation:
Apparently iTunes consumers disagreed, as The Blueprint 3 debuted on iTunes in the top 10 best-selling albums and the “D.O.A.” single reached the top 50 on the iTunes charts, making this a line that reflects the Pretense of the Modern Age

Originally, Jay put his previous album American Gangster up on iTunes, but did not allow individual songs to be bought, as he believed the album should be consumed as a whole.



 It’s not for iTunes, as in the song is not made for commercial success mere to ‘destroy’ the usage of auto-tune. It’s not a sing along track (the next line).

A lot of artist release easy sing along tracks on iTunes to make money quick. Catchy lyrics with an auto-tune overlay.

annotations.text: This is Sinatra at the opera,
annotations.annotation:
Frank Sinatra performed at the Blackpool Opera House on a 1953 tour of the UK. In 1953 Sinatra had just signed with Capitol Records, fresh off a supporting role in From Here To Eternity. This career upswing followed a disastrous three-year period for the singer in which Sinatra suffered on-and-off vocal trouble, got dropped from two record labels, and married and separated from Ava Gardner

The metanarrative around The Blueprint 3 release has often invoked a parallel between Sinatra’s and Hova’s respective comebacks. The idea seems to have cemented itself in the public consciousness after Kanye West’s infamous May 20, 2009 blog post on the music industry A-list in which Ye wrote “JAY IS SINATRA.”

And of course, Jay-Z straight up says “I am the new Sinatra” in “Empire State of Mind”

So there you go

annotations.text:
Bring a blonde
 Preferably with a fat ass who can sing a song
annotations.annotation:
There are several things going on here with this line:
Jay alludes to the following:


“It ain’t over ‘till the fat lady sings”, as in opera.
“Bringing a blonde” seems like a Sinatra move (could refer to Marilyn Monroe, with whom Sinatra was rumored to have had an affair)
Jay-Z’s girlfriend Beyonce is blonde, famous, has a fat ass..but it’s not the same
A critique of how rappers nowadays are doing songs with popstars, and change the style of production just to sell more records. The line after this one shows that’s “not politically correct”.



Remember, Autotune is not the only thing he is criticizing; it’s mainstream rap too!

annotations.text: This might offend my political connects (uhh!)
annotations.annotation:
Talking about the politics of the rap game and may be a  reference to Kanye West, Jay-Z’s friend/producer/collaborator, whom Jay does not call out in this song, despite his being one of the more egregious Auto-Tune abusers

After the song was released, Jay decided to go out of his way to say he’s not talking about people like Kanye, who understand melodies, but he’s only taking on the bad rappers doing auto-tune (reminds me of Bush’s speech about how we are not at war with all Muslims, but only certain Muslim extremists). Jay-Z helped President Obama get elected tremendously. He is saying this might offend his political connection because it’s not ‘politically correct.’

Also, Jay-Z has friends in government politics (not just rap-drama politics), and while it’s hard to see why this song would offend any politicians, he can back up saying that he has “political connects”.

annotations.text: My raps don’t have melodies
annotations.annotation:
Refers to his statement that it is necessary to understand melodies to use AutoTune correctly, or you shouldn’t at all.

T-Pain, he does great melodies. If you listen to Kanye, great melodies. If you listen to [West’s] ‘Say You Will’ or ‘Heartless,’ great melodies. [Lil Wayne and T-Pain’s] ‘Lollipop’ was a fantastic melody. Everybody can’t do it. Let them guys do it. They got their little niche, let’s move on."

However, Jay’s raps don’t even have melody. It’s all raw meaning no melodies need to be understood, this being one of the many reasons he won’t use it. He did try using it on Jeezy’s “Put On (Remix)”, but as this track highlights, he decided he didn’t need it.

annotations.text:
Get your chain tooken
 I may do it myself,
annotations.annotation: “Chain snatching” is a similar street robbery move to purse snatch theft, except that it involves ripping someone’s necklace straight off their neck. Brooklyn’s own Jay-Z has a Marcy-formed attitude towards all objects he does not possess.

By “recession” he may be also referring to the lack of quality rap music at the time and the ‘auto-tuners’ are going to make it worse – may also mean they are making music that is greatly depressing.

annotations.text:
I made this just for Flex and... Mister Cee
 I want niggas to feel threatened (uhh!)
annotations.annotation:
The way Jay says “I made this just for Flex and (pause)”
sounds like “I made this just for flexin'”. Jay made this song just to send a message (this ain’t for itunes)

Funkmaster Flex and Mister Cee are DJs on Hot 97 who Jay respects (D.O.A. premiered on their station)



The placement of “Mister Cee” may also be a means to emphasize the threat that follows: “See, I want people to feel threatened!”

annotations.text:
Stop your bloodclot crying
 The kid, the dog, everybody dying, no lying
annotations.annotation:
“Blood clot” (pronounced “blood claat”) is Jamaican slang for “blood cloth” (i.e. feminine hygiene product). The term is synonymous with “fucking”, as in “stop your fucking crying”

This whole line is an homage to “You’re Nobody (Till Somebody Kills You)”, the last song on Disc Two of The Notorious B.I.G.’s Life After Death:

Here’s a tissue, stop your blood clot crying
The kids, the dog, everybody dying, no lying

This bar is quite a popular one. 50 Cent uses it in his song, Stop Crying from his 2011 album, The Big 10.

This line could be a shot a multiple big names in the industry. “Blood clot crying” could be a shot at Game who was apparently caught on camera crying, he also happens to be a Blood. Game and Hov have taken several shots at each other. “The Kid” is a common nickname of 50 Cent and “The Dog” is a nickname of DMX. Jay has/had a frenemy history with all three of these rappers.

annotations.text:
You niggas' jeans too tight
 Your colors too bright,
annotations.annotation:
The remark refers more generally to what Jay-Z perceives as a trend toward “softness” in rap, as in addition to using auto-tune, he’s accusing rappers of rocking the tight pants and brightly colored T-shirts and trying to appeal to this demographic that has become ubiquitous in yuppie neighborhoods including Harlem and much of Brooklyn.

Possibly also a reference to “blipster” fashion (Kanye, our blipster-in-chief, was of course a key collaborator on this track)

annotations.text: (That's too far, nigga!)
annotations.annotation:
This is Kanye’s interruption: he can only take so much before protesting Jay’s criticism of the effeminate metro-fashion Kanye personifies.



No I.D. spoke about this during an interview with Complex, stating that Jay Z said:

‘Ye told me to do it.’ Then Kanye came in and said ‘Damn Jay, you went too far!’ and I stopped him and said ‘You’ve gotta put that on the record!’ And that’s how it all came together.

annotations.text: I might bring back Versace shades (uhh!)
annotations.annotation: More big ups to Biggie, who frequently wore and referred to wearing Versace sunglasses: “I’m clockin' ya, Versace shades watchin' ya”

annotations.text: This ain’t for Z100
annotations.annotation: The meme Top 40 pop music station in New York

annotations.text: To keep it 100 (uhh!)
annotations.annotation:
Bun B, who did a verse on Jay-Z’s “Big Pimpin”, has a song called “Keep it a hundred”

“Keep it a hundred” can also mean “keep it real”, which would be the opposite of what Z100 keeps it, which is why this makes for a delightful pun (even though the advice seems odd coming from Kanye, who epitomizes rap-crossover success of the Z100 variety)

This is also a homophone of “keep it one hunted – Jigga’s murdering everyone and is the one to beat at the top of the rap game food chain.

annotations.text: This is for Hot 9-7
annotations.annotation: The opposite of Z100 from the line above, Hot 97 is the seminal thug New York hip hop radio station, which, ironically, has caught flak since 2007 for turning away from hip-hop in favor of more R & B (Jay still respects the station though and namechecks two DJs from there earlier in the song)

annotations.text: This shit for Clue,
annotations.annotation: DJ Clue, a well-known mixtape DJ who kept it real (wouldn’t use Auto-Tune)

annotations.text: For Khaled, for we the bestin... (uhh!)
annotations.annotation:
DJ Khaled is a popular artist. Jay-Z uses DJ Khaled as an example of the kind of rap that people should be pursuing.  “We the best” is Khaled’s common refrain that he shouts over his tracks

Khaled said that this line “brought a tear to [his] eye”

annotations.text:
La da da da...
 Hey, hey, hey, goodbye... (Good riddance!)
 Hold up...
annotations.annotation:
Sample of “Na Na Hey Hey Kiss Him Goodbye”, the 1969 single by Steam

Sports teams often sing this to vanquished opponents (in this case, auto-tune)

Jay cleverly sings along with this part of the song out of tune – just the type of thing that insincere artists use auto-tune to fix

annotations.text: Hold up, this shit need a verse from Jeezy... Ay!
annotations.annotation:
Young Jeezy, a rapper who frequently collaborates with Jay-Z (see “As Real as it Gets”, “My President is Black”)

Jay-Z is on the verge of needing to get off Jeezy’s tip (see more Jeezy props in “A Star is Born”)

annotations.text: I might send this to the mixtape Weezy
annotations.annotation:
Not the Weezy (Lil Wayne) of the softer crossover hits (“Lollipop”, for example), but the true thug Weezy of his direct-to-the-street mixtapes

Later, Weezy playfully sampled this line on his version of D.O.A., off his No Ceilings mixtape

annotations.text: Get somebody from BMF to talk on this
annotations.annotation:
BMF = Black Mafia Family, the Detroit-based drug trafficking organization that promoted Young Jeezy, among other hip-hop artists

16 members of the Atlanta wing of BMF were indicted in 2007, which has led some observers of that investigation to associate BMF with snitching. This leads to a double meaning of “talk on this” as rapping on the song as well as talking to investigators

annotations.text: Get this to a Blood, let a Crip walk on it (uhh!)
annotations.annotation:
#TRIPLE ENTENDRE


The Bloods and The Crips are well-known rival gangs
“Crip walk on it” is a play on the Crip Walk, a dance popularized by the Crips
Before becoming a well known dance move, it was used by members of the Crips gang as a way of adding a ‘signature’ to their victims.
Jay suggests this song is so hard, a copy of it might be found on the body of a Blood who has been recently killed.
Peep the clever wordplay on ‘crip’ and ‘walk’ Jay is also suggesting  that if you give this song (or album) to a cripple the lyrics and flow will be so immaculate they just might walk.
He is Hov afterall

annotations.text: Get 3 Thou' to style on this
annotations.annotation: He’ll get Andre 3000 to rap on his track. Andre can bring boxes of stylish excess inventory from his destined to fail clothing line called “Benjamin Bixby”

annotations.text: Get back to rap, you T-Pain'n too much (uhh, uhh!)
annotations.annotation:
“T-Paining” = singing like T-Pain, a rapper/singer who is synonymous with auto-tune

“Not T-Paining” just seems like common sense, cf. T-Paine

annotations.text:
I don’t be in the project hallway
 Talkin' 'bout how I be in the projects all day (uhh!)
annotations.annotation:
This sounds like a shot at Mobb Deep, whose song “Project Hallways” talks about, well, being in the project all day.  Jay famously feuded with Mobb Deep in 2001, when he basically ended Mobb Deep’s career by putting a picture of Mobb Deep member Prodigy wearing a ballet outfit as a child on the big screen at SummerJam

What I want to know is: what’s so bad about doing ballet as a boy? It builds poise!

However, judging by the relevancy of Mobb Deep these days, it seems more likely a shot at rappers who still rap about the projects when they live in mansions. Rappers like Wayne and Birdman are guilty of this, leading to people questioning their music as a whole.

annotations.text: [Produced by Jiv Poss, Puff Daddy, Stevie J and DJ Enuff]
annotations.annotation:
For the original version of this track, Jiv Poss flipped Billy Preston’s “I Wonder.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W80MbPez0LE

Jiv Poss said this in an interview with HipHopDX:

That [Billy Preston] sample wasn’t even a straight loop, it was a chop. It was like three or four different chops I did, because it was like a little part here, then he’d say a word, then another part here, so I chopped and made that loop. I took the kick and snare and hi-hat from a Barry White joint, chopped it up and there you have it. Just raw, Brooklyn, New York Hip Hop. And that’s what Big wanted. That’s what he got.

Unfortunately, this sample was never cleared – prompting a remaking of the beat featuring the same sample, only replayed by Diddy and Stevie J.

annotations.text:
Yea though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death
 I will fear no evil, for you are with me
 Your rod and your staff, they comfort me
 You prepare a table for me, in the presence of my enemies
 You anoint my head with oil, my cup overflows
 Surely goodness and love will follow me all the days of my life
 And I will dwell in the house of the Lord forever
annotations.annotation:
Psalm 23:4-6, a frequent reading at Christian funerals.

Biggie had these verses tattooed onto his left arm, per Shaheem Reid of MTV:

He and his mother said that prayer and many others together. Right before his death, Big started reflecting, and he wanted to live by it. Cease and D-Roc also got the same tat on their arm. Before he got the Psalm, he contemplated getting his son’s name on his arm but told his people the tat process was too painful for another one. Diddy recites part of the Psalm to open the song “You’re Nobody Until Somebody Kills You.”

annotations.text: Hittin' fanny, spendin' chips at Manny's
annotations.annotation:
Manny’s was a booth located in New York’s famed diamond district own by the legendary hip-hop jeweler Tito Caicedo (a.k.a Tito the Jeweler). Tito is famous for being the designer of Biggie’s famous Jesus Piece. His father, Manny, an establised jeweler in Ecuador by the age of 19, immigrated to the States during the 1960s.
Fascinated with jewelry for as long as he could remember, Tito started working with his father in late 1970s. Manny and Tito proved to be a successful team, drawing attention from some of the biggest rap stars in the early days of hip-hop, such as Kid ‘N Play, Eric B. & Rakim, Biz Markie, LL Cool J, Jay-Z (even before he had a major record deal), The Notorious B.I.G., 2Pac, etc.
In summing up the high points of a career spanning over thirty years, Tito states, “Whenever an artist or potential client walks into my shop humming or signing my name from a line written by Biggie, Jay-Z  or Noreaga, that’s priceless”.

Tito passed away in March, 2016.

annotations.text:
Six up in your wig-piece, nigga deceased
 Muah, may you rest in peace
annotations.annotation: Potential subliminal 2Pac diss here. Six up (Six coupe) might be referring to the Cadillac that the shooters (Orlando Anderson and the other Southside Crips) were driving that fired shots at 2Pac, which resulted in him being deceased.

annotations.text: With my Sycamore style, more sicker than yours
annotations.annotation:
Notice how he flips the word “syca-more” to “more sicka (sicker)”

Jay-Z later referenced/bit this line in “December 4th”

I was conceived by Gloria Carter and Adnes Reeves
Who made love under a sycamore tree
Which makes me a more sicker MC

annotations.text: As I leave my competition, respirator style
annotations.annotation:
Biggie’s competitors will end up being put on life support (“guaranteed to be in I.C.U.”)

This is also a potential subliminal diss to 2Pac, who after being shot was on a respirator for a week before dying. Biggie didn’t let the beef go despite Pac’s death – for instance dissing him on “Long Kiss Goodnight”

annotations.text:
I spit phrases that'll thrill you
 You're nobody 'til somebody kills you
annotations.annotation:
The Notorious B.I.G. is one of hip-hop’s most quoted artists and is widely considered one of the greatest MCs of all time, so his claim to spit phrases that’ll thrill the listener is spot on.

In the May 1997 issue of The Source magazine, Biggie earned a spot in the highly coveted “Hip-Hop Quotable” column for his first verse on “Kick In The Door.”

Nas would later reveal on his 2002 song “Last Real Nigga Alive” that the verse was written about him – though Biggie never mentioned Nas by name.



And while Big was MOST CERTAINLY somebody before he passed away in 1997, his legend has grown in the years since his death.

annotations.text: You're nobody 'til somebody kills you
annotations.annotation:
The hook (and song title) is a reference to “You’re Nobody Till Somebody Loves You”, a popular 1940s pop standard covered by artists including Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Nat King Cole.

Being murdered often makes someone significantly more famous than they otherwise would have been had they not been killed.

The line may be a subliminal diss toward recently murdered rapper rival Tupac Shakur, who achieved a martyr status in the hip hop world after being killed. Biggie explicitly denied the song being a jab at Tupac, as can be read on page 69 of the May 1997 issue of Spin magazine, but the timing is still striking.

 What’s missing is the depth and complexity of Ready to Die, with the exception of “You’re Nobody (‘Til Somebody Kills You),” a funky fright-night riff. It’s an ambiguous song (“Not about Tupac,” says Biggie), in which the narrator is both mesmerized and disgusted by the live-fast-die-young credo.

annotations.text:
Uhh, uhh
 Watch Casino, I'm the hip-hop version of Nicky Tarantino
annotations.annotation: Biggie conflates Nicky Santoro (Joe Pesci’s character in Casino, who notably squeezes a dude’s head in a vise is an all-around psychopath) with Quentin Tarantino, the director of violent movies such as Pulp Fiction.

annotations.text: You ain't worth spit, just a memory
annotations.annotation: This is similar to the famous bowdlerization of John Nance Garner’s description of the vice-presidency, as being “not worth a bucket of warm spit” (his actual statement was “warm piss”).

annotations.text: Silly cat, wore suede in the rain
annotations.annotation:
Being suede means to not giving care to anything, and having many female companions around him. This is again a possible 2Pac diss, as he was doing exactly the same thing.

“Wearing it in the rain” could mean that he was stupid by doing it during the time when the world wasn’t like this, it was a cold, grey place, just like rain.

annotations.text:
I can't recall his name (what was his name?), you mean that kid
 That nearly lost half his brain over two bricks of cocaine?
annotations.annotation:
Possible 2Pac referrence, however not that highly. If it is, then Biggie is again playing with 2Pac’s fans and overall hip-hop fans and the beef followers here. He will never diss him properly, nor put his name in his raps, because to him he is still nobody, even though somebody killed him.

2Pac died at the age of 25, which is very young for becoming a corpse.

The two bricks of cocaine is a possible reference to 2Pac’s mother abusing a lot of crack. She meaned the world to him, as indicated in his hit song “Dear Mama”, he even would lose touch with his second half of his brain (possibly the left one, which is responsible for logic and analytic thought due to him losing it for a crack addict and a person that can’t be trusted, the way Biggie refers to a mother in “Ten Crack Commandments”).

annotations.text:
A fuckin' shame, duke's a lame, what's his name?
 Dark-skin Jermaine, see what I mean?
annotations.annotation: Biggie and his friends are discussing the story of Jermaine and one of them is eventually able to remember – since being killed in the game automatically gets you a long-lasting legacy and name recognition. Once he was killed over his two bricks of cocaine he was immortalized by those who only knew of him tangentially, and he’s now become a sort of mythic figure.

Brooklyn

annotations.annotation: Biggies partner is upset with him and throwing his clothing out the window. He sees his polo shirts and his Timberland Boots getting carried away by the strong wind.

Hide my car keys so I can't leave
 A real slick bitch, keep a trick up her sleeve
annotations.annotation:
B.I.G.’s girl went to great lengths to make sure he didn’t fall victim to temptation. Including hiding his car keys so that he couldn’t drive to other women.

In Goodfellas, one of BIG’s favorite films, Karen hides Henry Hill’s car keys so he can’t go out and party.

annotations.text:
And then we lie together, cry together
 I swear to God I hope we fuckin' die together
annotations.annotation:
This whole couplet is an emotionally capturing couple of lines that express Biggie’s “dying” need for this woman. This in particular makes them appear inseparable, and do everything together.

It’s also noticed that the entire song has a misogynistic tone to it, however Biggie tones it down and eventually, as referenced in the first verse, is starting to “treat her right.”

annotations.text:
When I pulled up, police was on the scene
 Had to make the U-turn, make sure my shit was clean
 Drove down the block, stashed the burner in the bushes
 Stepped to police with the shoves and the pushes
annotations.annotation:
Even in his state of upset and despair, Biggie still has the state of mind to recognize the police cars, ditch his gun (burner) and go up to see what it is.

Biggie has a known problem with the police so he treats them disrespectfully. He explains why earlier on the album https://genius.com/6723

annotations.text:
It didn't take long before the tears start
 I saw my bitch dead with the gunshot to the heart
 And I know it was meant for me
 I guess the niggas felt they had to kill the closest one to me
annotations.annotation: Biggie’s girl was an accessory and sometimes an accomplice in his crimes she helped plan out his robberies and would even kill for Biggie, it’s likely a victim of one of their crimes seeked revenge. They probably couldn’t get to Biggie so they instead killed the person that meant the most to him.

annotations.text:
And when I find 'em your life is to an end
 They killed my best friend, me and my bitch
annotations.annotation: Biggie is incredibly torn up about the death of his partner in crime and the love of his life. He wants to get revenge, but he also feels guilty about his role in the killing. This is foreshadowed at the end of the previous verse, where he says “I swear to God I hope we fuckin' die together.” While he is mourning her loss, he is also feeling guilty and that it should’ve been him who died, which is a common symptom of grief.

annotations.text: [Produced by True Master & Ol' Dirty Bastard]
annotations.annotation:
Brooklyn Zoo, the lead single, off Ol' Dirty Bastard’s debut studio album was produced by True Master and co-produced by Ol' Dirty himself. It was True Master’s first legally published beat since he had been RZA’s disciple for some time.

According to the book The Wu-Tang Clan and RZA: A Trip Through Hip Hop’s 36 Chambers the beat was made by using Ensoniq EPS-16+, a sampler which belonged to RZA.





For larger scale of the picture click here



The beat is largely based on a piano loop which remained unknown for over 20 years (since it was made in 1993) until 2014 when a WhoSampled user found out that the loop was taken from a 1967 reggae track “Step Softly” by Bobby Ellis and The Desmond Miles Seven.

https://youtu.be/gaAmd_Xh3KU?t=11s

annotations.text: [Intro]
annotations.annotation:
According to the Buddha Monk’s “The Dirty Version: On Stage, in the Studio, and in the Streets with Ol' Dirty Bastard” this track was recorded just after an argument Ol Dirty had with members of the Brooklyn Zu.

He used that energy he had from arguing to create an amazing track. The intro contains some words that Ol Dirty used in the argument.

annotations.text: I ain't no motherfucking joke, you know who you talking to?
annotations.annotation: Don’t dismiss Dirty just because he’s better known as a hypeman. Also possibly in reference to/inspired by the Rakim song I Ain’t No Joke.

annotations.text: I'm the one-man army, Ason
annotations.annotation:
Ason Unique is one of O.D.B.’s aliases

Ason is a title for ancient Japanese nobility who were demoted to commoners during the Nara period (710-794). The term comes from the kabane nomenclature system.

Raekwon and the late J. Dilla recently released an ODB tribute, “Ason Jones,” on Only Built For Cuban Linx II. The title of ODB’s album A Son Unique, is another play on the name.

annotations.text: I never been tooken out, I keep MC's looking out
annotations.annotation:
Ol' Dirty’s never been defeated, taken out of the picture. He has other rappers nervous because of it.

Note the similarity to Big Daddy Kane’s lyrics in “Raw”:

And in my lifetime, believe I’ve never been
Beaten, or eaten and just tooken out
You know come to think about it, I keep MCs looking out

Some thought this was a dis to Kane but given their Brooklyn backgrounds and Dirty’s appearance on Kane’s “Show And Prove” a year earlier, it’s more likely to be a salute if anything.

annotations.text: I drop science like Cosby dropping babies
annotations.annotation:
PROPOSED SUGGESTION:

It’s Cosby droppin' babies.

Bill Cosby played OB/GYN Cliff Huxtable on the Cosby Show.  Obstetricians deliver lots of babies.  ODB is saying he drops science with the frequency of Cliff Huxtable delivering babies.

annotations.text: Enough to make a nigga go crazy
annotations.annotation:
The science, or knowledge, that O.D.B. is dropping has the potential to blow people’s minds!

This line was also referenced in the song “Girlfriend” by Alicia Keys, in which she sings:

It’s enough to make a nigga go crazy

annotations.text: In the G-Building, taking all types of medicines
annotations.annotation:
Frequently misheard as “energy building” (a mistake that made it into Yale’s Anthology of Rap), this is actually a reference to Brooklyn’s infamous G Building, the psychiatric ward of Kings County Hospital.

During ODB’s drunken appearance on Yo! MTV Raps, Ed Lover asked him what the G building was. He replied:

See, the creation of everything that started from the origin of rap, y'know, you had, y'know, people that was… not like me. That’s why they stay in the G building – because I only roll with crazy people, I only battle crazy people. So when I said the G building… I just said the G building.

The G Building has since been closed amid allegations of physical and sexual abuse and a death in the waiting room.

annotations.text: Ason? I keep planets in orbit
annotations.annotation: One of ODB’s aliases is Ason Unique, literally pronounced “A Sun”. According to Five Percent teachings the Original Man is represented by the Sun, which keeps planets in orbit with gravitational force.

annotations.text:
While I be coming with deeper and more shit
 Enough to make you break and shake your ass
annotations.annotation: He makes music to make people catch a groove to it and dance to it.

annotations.text: As I create rhyme good as a Tastykake makes
annotations.annotation:
Tastykakes was a line of snacks created by the Tasty Baking Company, founded in 1914.



The company was later sold in 2011 to a bakery company called Flowers Foods for $34 million.

Ol' Dirty is saying that his rhymes are made to a high standard, similar to a Tastykake.

annotations.text:
This style, I'm mastered in
 Niggas catching headaches, what? What? You need aspirin?
 This type of pain, you couldn't even kill with Midol
annotations.annotation:
“Catchin' headaches” could refer to the listener’s attempt to interpret ODB’s eccentric flow, which can be a headache-inducing activity at times (and always an intellectually rewarding one.) Neither Asprin, a mild pain reliever, or Midol, an over-the-counter painkiller that’s typically used for menstrual cramps, could remedy one’s pain after hearing an ODB track.

The exhortation “What what!” seems to recall the thumping sensation of a particularly aggravating headache.

annotations.text:
Fuck around, get sprayed with Lysol
 In your face like a can of mace, baby
annotations.annotation:
If you fuck with Dirty, it will hurt, and you will experience a sting like Lysol or mace (pepper spray) on the skin. Though it is unclear if Dirty is familiar with historical uses of Lysol to “fuck around,” the disinfectant was a widely used form of birth control during the mid-20th century.



“A can of Mace” refers to a generic trademark for an early type of aerosol self defense spray).

annotations.text: Give me my fucking shit, chk-chk, blaow
annotations.annotation:
An onomatopoeia representing a gun being cocked and fired

This was also used by Raekwon in C.R.E.A.M. by the Wu-Tang Clan

annotations.text: Utmost
annotations.annotation: Utmost can be defined as “most extreme; greatest.” A position held for God. ODB is displaying knowledge of self. His belief that he’s a God and MC.

annotations.text: Introducing
annotations.annotation: A reference to ODB’s ‘Introducing the Ghostface Killah’ from Da Mystery of Chessboxin'

annotations.text: [Produced by Easy Mo Bee]
annotations.annotation:
In this beat, Easy Mo Bee flipped a tiny portion of Leroy Hutson’s “Can’t Say Enough About Mom.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TK0j1ehHZLs#t=349

The drums come from Avalanche’s “Overnight Sensation.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vm0qGm57G9U

annotations.text: [Verse 1: The Notorious B.I.G.]
annotations.annotation: Two versions of The What exist. Biggie was not happy with his verses on the original, unreleased version, as he felt Method Man’s was better. Check it out here!

annotations.text:
I used to get feels on a bitch
 Now I throw shields on the dick to stop me from that HIV shit
annotations.annotation:
Back when he was ignorant to the danger of AIDS and the importance of condoms (“shields”), Big would have unprotected sex (“get feels” being a reference to the increased sensation he felt).

This line was famously interpolated by Lil Kim on her 1996 song “Big Momma Thang”:

I used to be scared of the dick
Now I throw lips to the shit, handle it like a real bitch

By beginning this song with a line about sex, Biggie creates a fitting transition from the theme of the album’s previous two songs, “One More Chance” and the related interlude entitled “Fuck Me.”

annotations.text: And niggas know they soft like a Twinkie filling
annotations.annotation:
The snack, Twinkies has a soft, white filling.
Here Biggie mocks so on so “hardcore” thugs when they’re softies.

annotations.text: Playing the villain, prepare for this rap killing
annotations.annotation:
“Playing the villain” refers to a couple of things, most obviously the fact that he portrays a gangster persona in most of his music. However, this is probably also a reference to Let’s Do It Again, which is where the name “Biggie Smalls” comes from. In the movie Biggie Smalls is the villain of the story; a big-shot gangster from Atlanta.

As for the Rap Killing, he is probably just talking about lyrically murdering other rappers in the game.

annotations.text:
Biggie Smalls is the illest, your style is played out
 Like Arnold on that, "What you talking 'bout, Willis?"
annotations.annotation:
A celebrated line, oft-repeated by Gary Coleman’s character Arnold on the TV show Diff'rent Strokes.



As with Arnold’s line, Biggie finds other rappers' verses full of tired old phrases, “played out” (rendered banal) by repetition

See the “Flava In Ya Ear” remix for another Diff'rent Strokes based simile from Biggie.

annotations.text: The Black Frank White
annotations.annotation:
Frank White is a character played by Christopher Walken in the movie, King of New York. Frank White is a drug dealer who plots to take over the New York drug trade by eliminating the competition.

The Notorious B.I.G. refers to himself as the “Black Frank White,” aliasing himself as the King of New York. The similarity can be seen in their names and initials—Christopher Wallace and Christopher Walken.

annotations.text: Is here to excite and throw dick to dykes
annotations.annotation:
He will excite women sexually, even throw dick to lesbian women.
Dyke is a slur for lesbian girls.

annotations.text: Bitches I like 'em brainless, guns I like 'em stainless steel
annotations.annotation: Stainless steel is made of different alloys such as chromium and nickel. These alloys make the steel virtually resistant to all stains. This is preferable to Biggie as he likes his “tools” to be impeccable and flawless.

annotations.text: I want the fucking fortune like the Wheel
annotations.annotation: A reference to the medieval poetic device comparing life’s arbitrary ups and downs to a spinning wheel (and/or “Wheel of Fortune” with Pat Sajak and Vanna White)

annotations.text: You don't want to fuck with the M-E...
annotations.annotation:
An original way to hand over the verses. Biggie starts spelling Method Man’s name and Meth finishes it. To get the timing right, Meth starts rhyming over Biggie’s line. So his T-H-O-D Man actually comes before the M-E.

The Ready To Die (OG Edition) mixtape has an alternate version with a different first verse. This version uses the same M-E / T-H-O-D handover, but Biggie’s shorter last line matches up exactly with Meth’s first line:

You don’t want none a me, N-O-N-A-M-E
T-H-O-D Man, here I am

In The Rap Phenomenon documentary Meth explains Biggie considered Meth’s verses to be better and thus may have changed what was originally recorded.

annotations.text: ...T-H-O-D Man, here I am
annotations.annotation:
Method Man creeps onto the mic like a phantom, both interrupting and finishing Biggie’s line, while quoting from his classic Wu-Tang single.

Meth told XXL that it was Big’s idea for the two verses to blend together:

The way he ended his verse—he wanted me to start my verse with “T.H.O.D.,” because he ends his verse with, “You can’t fuck with M.E.” So that’s why my verse starts out, “T.H.O.D. Man…” But it didn’t actually come out that way. You can’t hear it, because I came over the top of him. If I wouldn’t have [rhymed over him], it wouldn’t have been on beat.

annotations.text:
I'll be damned if this ain't some shit
 Come to spread the butter lyrics over hominy grit
annotations.annotation:
In the (Dirty) South, butter is often spread over grits for breakfast (Grits can be made of hominy, a pre-soaked cornmeal)

Here, Meth spreads his buttery lyrics over harmony grit – a harmonious but yet gritty production from Easy Mo Bee.

annotations.text: Your frontin' got me mad enough to touch something
annotations.annotation: “Touch something” is slang for pulling out his gun – Method Man uses the same term on “What the Bloodclot!?!” off his 1994 album Tical (released only a few months after Ready to Die)

annotations.text: Yo, I'm from Shaolin Island and ain't afraid to bust something
annotations.annotation: Shaolin Island is a slang term used by members of Wu-Tang Clan to describe Staten Island in New York City. (c.f. Raekwon on “Can It Be All So Simple”)

annotations.text: I got a 6-shooter and a horse named Trigger
annotations.annotation: Trigger (1934-1965) was a  golden palomino horse that was famously owned by Roy Rogers, the famous American singer and actor known for his portrayal of a cowboy in various radio, film, and television shows (especially The Roy Rogers Show)

annotations.text:
It's real, '94 rugged-raw
 Kickin' down your goddamn door
 And it goes a little something like this
annotations.annotation:
Kicking down a door is a reference Biggie always uses

https://genius.com/The-notorious-big-kick-in-the-door-lyrics

https://genius.com/19919623

annotations.text:
Fuck the world, don't ask me for shit
 Everything you get you gotta work hard for it
annotations.annotation:
Don’t look to them for no handouts; go work for yours. It’s a reference to a song called “Make The Music With Your Mouth, Biz” by Biz Markie where he says:

Let me tell you party people, you gotta admit
Anything than you want you gotta work hard for it"

So the hook is a clear nod to Biz, a hip hop pioneer.

annotations.text: Meth-tical, putting niggas back in ICU
annotations.annotation:
Tical, the name of Meth’s first album – also slang for a really nice blunt

Meth often uses “Methtical” as a nickname for himself

annotations.text: And niggas love it, not in the physical form but in the mental
annotations.annotation: Basically, “Pause,” or “No homo.” He is saying dudes love him and his music on a mental level, but not him physically. Also, it’s mental because, throughout, he is saying his verses are like mind-altering substances.

annotations.text: (Assume the position) Stop look and listen
annotations.annotation:
About writing this line, Meth told Complex


Contrary to what everybody thinks, Big sat there and wrote his verse on paper. I sat down and I wrote my shit on paper. The reason I know this is because he told me, ‘I need you to say this line right here.’ I was like, ‘What line, Big?’ He was like, ‘I’ve got more Glocks and tecs than you / I make it hot, niggas won’t even stand next to you.’ I was like, ‘I got you.’

After he did that with me, when I wrote my second verse, I was like, ‘Damn, now I gotta put him in my verse and shit.’ So, ‘Stop, look and listen,’ was all I had for him. That shit was done fast and shit.

annotations.text: I spit on your grave then I grab my Charles Dickens, bitch
annotations.annotation:
Meth will spit on your grave while grabbing on his dick (named “Charles Dickens” to underscore the nexus between sex/death/literature…)



Years later, Method Man acted on the TV show The Wire, which had an episode titled “The Dickensian Aspect”, a journalistic term for the element of story which covers poverty and social injustice.

annotations.text: [Verse 4: The Notorious B.I.G. & Method Man]
annotations.annotation: Highlighted made a video on the rhyme scheme of this verse, watch it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LlK1FMItISQ&list=PLgoFgkHrHlE4lWH6uKJe6qNfMOtcQqit_&index=186

annotations.text: Welcome to my center, honeys feel it deep in they placenta
annotations.annotation: The placenta is an organ that develops in the uterus during pregnancy. Although Biggie likely fucked pregnant women at various points throughout his life, this sexual boast shouldn’t be taken literally.

annotations.text: Pop duke left mom duke, the faggot took the back way
annotations.annotation:
For Biggie to call his father a “faggot” – implying that leaving his mother was born not of a testosterone-driven desire to sow seed but of feminine cowardice – is a striking choice; most rappers portray their fathers as violent, hyper-masculine figures (except Eminem and Tyler, the Creator).

“Taking the back way” is a metaphor for cowardice (slunk out the back door) as well as a reference to gay (i.e. “butt”) sex

annotations.text:
So instead of making hoes suck my dick up
 I used to do stick-ups, 'cause hoes is irritating like the hiccups
annotations.annotation:
Biggie blames his father’s abandonment for his lack of interest in sex as a young man (I bet the big paunch didn’t help either)

He also may have chosen robbery over pimping as a way of making cash because women annoy him

annotations.text:
Excuse me, flows just grow through me
 Like trees to branches, cliffs to avalanches
annotations.annotation:
Organic rhymes..

Like branches grow on trees, and avalanches form on cliffs, flows originate from Biggie

The beat to this song samples “Overnight Sensation” by a band called Avalanche. It might seem a bit of a stretch to say that he was referencing it, but Biggie was known to watch producers while they were making a beat for him.

annotations.text: Deep like the mind of Farrakhan
annotations.annotation:
“As a counterpart against an exposion of black-on-black violence and drug abuse, many of rap artists became involved with Louis Farrakhan’s Nation of Islam.”
- David Toop: Rap Attack 3

Wiki:

Louis Farrakhan, formerly known as Louis X, is an American minister and political activist. He is the leader of the Nation of Islam (NOI), an organization which the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) describes as black nationalist, black supremacist and a hate group. Previously, he served as the minister of mosques in Boston and Harlem and had been appointed National Representative of the Nation of Islam by former NOI leader Elijah Muhammad.

After Warith Deen Muhammad reorganized the original NOI into the orthodox Sunni Islamic group American Society of Muslims, Farrakhan began to rebuild the NOI as “Final Call”. In 1981, he officially adopted the name “Nation of Islam”, reviving the group and establishing its headquarters at Mosque Maryam.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Farrakhan

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nation_of_Islam

 (I got more Glocks and TECs than you)
 I make it hot, (niggas won't even stand next to you)
annotations.annotation:
About writing this line, Meth told Complex


Contrary to what everybody thinks, Big sat there and wrote his verse on paper. I sat down and I wrote my shit on paper. The reason I know this is because he told me, ‘I need you to say this line right here.’ I was like, ‘What line, Big?’ He was like, ‘I’ve got more Glocks and tecs than you / I make it hot, niggas won’t even stand next to you.’ I was like, ‘I got you.’

After he did that with me, when I wrote my second verse, I was like, ‘Damn, now I gotta put him in my verse and shit.’ So, ‘Stop, look and listen,’ was all I had for him. That shit was done fast and shit.
