annotations.text: [Verse 1: JAY-Z]
annotations.annotation:
This song was intended by Irv Gotti to be for Ja Rule to promote him and land him a record deal but Jay-Z heard it and wanted in on it.

Ja Rule likely didn’t put this song on his album to not risk over-saturation but Jay-Z returned the favor for jacking Ja.

annotations.text: Can I hit in the mornin' without givin' you half of my dough
annotations.annotation:
Can we make love in the morning without any expectation of marriage? Clearly Jay hadn’t heard of the pre-nup, but it’s a theme he revisited regularly, most notably on “Big Pimpin'”

Many chicks wanna put Jigga’s fists in cuffs
Divorce him and split his bucks
Just because you got good head, I'mma break bread
So you can be living it up

He would mellow on the topic in later years, notably 2002’s “Excuse Me Miss”.

Love let’s go half on a son,

J. Cole did a whole song referencing this line; entitled In The Morning (Remix).

annotations.text:
And even worse, if I was broke would you want me
 If I couldn't get you finer things like all of them diamond rings
 Bitches kill for would you still roll
annotations.annotation:
Jay questions the devotion of this woman, insecure that all she is interested in is money, or what he can do for her. Nas picked up on this during “Ether,” rapping:

What you think, you getting girls now cause of your looks
Ne-gro please, you no mustache having
With whiskers like a rat

Having a girl down to roll is much sought after in the hood. His verse on “You Must Love Me” described that very situation, a girl willing to ride or die with him purely out of love, not lust of money.

annotations.text:
If we couldn't see the sun risin' off the shore of Thailand
 Would you ride then, if I wasn't driving
annotations.annotation:
It’s a pertinent question. In 1998 Jay still hadn’t truly broken through. This track was released before “Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)” propelled him in to the stratosphere of rap, selling 5 million copies of his second album. His first album is entitled Resonable Doubt, a play on the leap of faith he was taking pursuing rap as a career over the streets.

He’d later go on to say:

London, England, South of France
And all points between they know about your man
Konichiwa ladies when I’m out in Japan
I’m a Tokyo Giant like Ichiro, I am
Piss poor n—- from the hood but I blew

He could have just as easily gone back to that poor hood persona.

“If I wasn’t driving” refers to taking public transport, although Jay rarely drives in his current financial state, preferring to let a professional take care of that.

annotations.text: If I wasn't a eight-figure nigga by the name of Jigga
annotations.annotation:
Although Jay had yet to make real money in the rap game (that would come soon on this very album, selling 5 million copies), he didn’t enter it empty handed. During “U Don’t Know” he raps:

I came in to this motherfucker hundred grand strong
Nine to be exact, from grinding G-packs

Jay, Dame and Kareem Burke started Roc-A-Fella with their own money, so for Jay to be worth over $10 million is no stretch at this point in his career. He was entirely independent, apart from a distribution deal with Def Jam.

annotations.text: Would you come around me or would you clown me
annotations.annotation:
This line has a direct root in “Where I’m From”, when Jay raps:

And girls in the projects wouldn’t fuck us, said we talked too much
So they ran up to Tompkins and sought them dudes to trust
I don’t know what the fuck they thought, those n—s is foul just like us

During the film Streets Is Watching there is a specific scene where women are seen dissing Jay and his friends and leaving them, “clowning” them for dressing the way they do and rapping.

annotations.text:
If I couldn't flow futuristic, would ya
 Put your two lips on my wood and kiss it, could ya
annotations.annotation:
This harks back to his days in The Originators, using incredibly complex and fast flows that incorporated stacked rhymes and triplets.

It was more about the technique than what I was saying. I was trying to say things in different ways—doing faster flows and triplet styles. It was more of a technical thing

Jay even felt he had “pioneered” the triple rhyming style, saying in Decoded:

I’d just go in on it in the breakneck double and triple time rhyming that me and Jaz thought we’d pioneered.

His flow has been imitated in subsequent years, most famously by his protégé Young Chris, whose had to defend both himself and Jay in the ensuing controversy.

If Jay wasn’t a rapper, would this girl even care? Would she be attracted to him if he wasn’t spitting rhymes?

annotations.text:
See yourself with a nigga working harder than nine to five
 Ten to six, two jobs to survive,
annotations.annotation:
Jay actually worked even harder than this pre-rap, recalling in Decoded a time when he was arrested carrying cocaine, released, and had to work “sixty straight hours” to make back what he’d lost.

A kid from Marcy owed me money, so I went out with him on the streets and worked for sixty straight hours. I would give him work to sell, wait while he turned it around, then take that money uptown to cop more work. I kept him working three nights in a row, his girl brought him sandwhiches in the middle of the night.

Clearly someone maintained a relationship through such trying conditions, and Jay had his own version of this dedication before he made it big.

This statement is in response to the wave of female interest he was experiencing since becoming a rapper. During the N.O.R.E. Rap Radar Podcast he related a story about Hov in the very early days and his ways with women:

I hooked up Hov with a couple of chicks from back in my hood back in the days. I was kind of mad, Elizabeth and them, they just went over there, what the fuck he’s doing, fuck him! No, he was hotter, “Ain’t No” was hotter I can’t lie.

annotations.text:
Or
 Do you need a baller, so you can shop and tear the mall up
 Brag, tell your friends what I bought ya
annotations.annotation:
Jay wasn’t quite on his “Girl’s Best Friend” bent yet. This single came out September 1998, the first from the album. While Jay did brag about money a lot prior to this track, it was rarely in relation to women. The exception was “Imaginary Player,” which introduced one of the strongest floss games to emerge in hip hop.

The less said about “I Know What Girls Like” the better…

annotations.text:
If you couldn't see yourself with a nigga when his dough is low
 Baby girl, if this is so, yo
annotations.annotation:
Ironically Jay had created a situation where this scenario would never again play out in his future. It doesn’t seem borne of any life experience, although in “Song Cry” he raps:

Used to tell they friends I was ugly and wouldn’t touch me
Then I showed up in that dubbed out buggy
And then they got fuzzy and they don’t remember that
And I don’t remember you

Implying he didn’t become attractive until he turned up in an expensive whip. This is an early example of the “Gold Digger” mentality, and Jay want’s no part of it.

annotations.text:
Can I get a woop woop
 To these niggas from all of my bitches
 Who don't got love for niggas without dubs
annotations.annotation:
The female response, refusing to mess with a guy who is broke. Her verse embodies this message. This was the first track Amil featured on with Jay, shockingly similar to Foxy Brown’s star turn on “Ain’t No,” an aggressive female presence going toe to toe with Jay.

Amil’s sentiments here would be echoed in TLC’s hit single “No Scrubs” just a few months later.

annotations.text: [Verse 3: Ja Rule]
annotations.annotation: This was Ja Rule’s first appearance on a major single. Irv Gotti was in the middle of brokering record deals for Mic Geronimo and Ja Rule. He intended to use this song as a promotional single for Ja Rule on the Rush Hour soundtrack) but rumor is that Jay-Z heard the beat in the studio and wanted to use the beat himself and Irv agreed only if Ja Rule could remain on the track. Soon after the release of this single, Ja Rule was signed to Def Jam off the strength of his features on The Natural, Vendetta, Streets is Watching, and this track under the guidance of Irv Gotti who intended to form a Supergroup of Ja-Jigga-X

annotations.text:
Yeezy, Hova, Yeezy
 Yeezy Yeezy, Hova, hold up
annotations.annotation:
HOVA is one of New York rapper JAY-Z’s many aliases, which is derived from the Herbrew word “Jehova.” La Live broke down the significance of this nickname and explained that he uses the self-proclaimed title to classify himself as a “God rapper.” He first used the nickname on his February 1998 track, “A Million and One Questions (Remix)”:

Ha! Well they call me Jay-Hova ‘cause the flow is religious

Yeezy is a nickname for Chicago rapper Kanye West, who produces this track. Kanye and Jay are frequent collaborators and have worked together on a large number of tracks.

Either love me, or leave me alone”

annotations.text:
These niggas want me to go, don’t they know that I'm gone
 They know I'm space shuttle level, they need oxyg-g-g-gen
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z has been rapping for 30+ years. Due to his seniority and success in the rap game, along with more and more trying to enter the arena, Jay-Z is saying these other rappers want him out.

In rebuttal to this, Jay-Z implies that he is already gone…on to another level. So high that he has entered space (space shuttle level) where there is no air, leaving him in need of oxygen.

annotations.text:
Seen Single White Female when she dyed her hair blonde?
 Sometimes I look at these rappers, the movie remind me of them
annotations.annotation:
In the movie, Single White Female (1992), the antagonist attempts to both ruin the life of, while simultaneously becoming/taking over the life of the film’s main character. She goes so fart to even alter her image, including dying her hair blonde, to look like the main character.

In saying rappers remind him of the movie, Jay-Z is noting how he sees rappers who are also imitating his look and style in hopes to gain successes similar to his own.

annotations.text:
And really the fact is, we not in the same bracket
 Not in the same league, don't shoot at the same baskets
 Don't pay the same taxes, hang with the same bitches
 So how am I in the way, what is it I'm missing?
annotations.annotation:
He’s on such a higher plane than these other rappers that they aren’t even able to do what he does.  Even if he retired it wouldn’t help them: he’s not in their way, he’s playing a different game than they are

Notice the double entendre on “bracket” – if this were the NCAA, other rappers wouldn’t be in the same bracket as Jay in the tournament. If this were tax season, however, they wouldn’t be in the same tax bracket (“March Madness” -> “April Madness”)

annotations.text:
Oh, they call me a Camel
 But I mastered the drought,
annotations.annotation:
A lot of disses thrown at Jay-Z (specifically Nas' “Ether”) have centered on him being ugly and looking like a camel.

Jay-Z chooses to emphasize the camel’s strong suit, and compare it to his own ability, when dealing drugs, to withstand a “drought”, or a shortage of supply.



This could also refer to his continued success during a downturn in the music industry.

annotations.text: Half man half mammal
annotations.annotation: Here we find out that Jay-Z didn’t know that humans in fact already are mammals

annotations.text: H-O-V, I got my own lane, already (already)
annotations.annotation:
Maybe a bit egotistical to assume that High-Occupancy Vehicle lanes, implemented to encourage carpooling, are named after Jay-Z, but nevertheless, he can be seen passing other rappers with ease.



Also, lane as in the rap game (he actually has several lanes such as the fashion industry, his record label, and recently signing free agents in major league sports, etc), where he definitely has the knowledge/experience.

Also, Jay could be responding to Game’s dislike of his advice.

Ties into the theme of the track very well.

annotations.annotation:
A scene from the 2003 film Livin' tha Life which was filmed and produced entirely in Compton, California:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TnLZ6U7AVm8

The movie only had a $400 budget and there was no script, so the actors, who were mostly local stand-up comedians, were told to improvise all their lines.

annotations.text: I've been there before now I'm fuckin' with Doc
annotations.annotation:
He doesn’t have to worry about carrying a gun anymore, he used to be into the gangsta scene but now he’s on a label with Doctor Dre, so he can just make money making music

He’s also referring to the days when he was shot 5 times and fell into the coma. He said this for example in Dreams

annotations.text: (Gotta do them Calvin Broadus numbers)
annotations.annotation: Calvin Broadus is Snoop Dogg’s real name.  He’s saying they aim to sell as many records as Snoop did: Snoop’s debut album Doggystyle sold 802,000 copies in its first week (making it the fastest selling album of all time until Eminem’s Marshall Mathers LP surpassed it).  These are lofty ambitions, but Game came close: his album sold roughly 500,000 copies in its first week and eventually went double platinum

annotations.text: If not, I pitch rocks, anticipatin' my incarceration
annotations.annotation: If he was not signed to Aftermath and having Dr. Dre produce beats for him, he would be selling crack cocaine and waiting to be caught by the police and serve jail time.

annotations.text: Media think I'm fakin' like Mason, but when it comes to mace
annotations.annotation:
This is a reference to rapper Mase (real name Mason Betha) who in 1999 during a radio interview with Funk Master Flex, retired from Hip Hop, claiming a higher calling from God to become a preacher. Many viewed him a sell out, who was afraid of the violence in Hip Hop follow in the murders of Biggie and Tupac.

The second part is a play on words referring to mace or pepper spray that people use in self defense.

annotations.text: Fuck R. Kelly, I don't take it in the face
annotations.annotation: This line is a reference to the sex tape of R. Kelly having intercourse with an underage child, in which he proceeds to urinate in her face.

annotations.text:
I'm far from religious, but I got beliefs
 So I put canary yellow diamonds in my Jesus piece
annotations.annotation:
His religiosity is expressed by buying sick diamonds for his crucifix necklace (yellow diamonds, a.k.a. canaries, are very rare and valuable)

Prefigures Gucci Mane’s “Lemonade”

Kind of ironic too that he went on to name his album Jesus Piece.

annotations.text:
I waited for 3 years while everybody else dropped
 Now I understand why Nas did a song with his pops
annotations.annotation:
On Nas' song “Bridging the Gap” Nas' father played the cornet. During this time others albums were being dropped, increasing pressure for Game to do an album soon

Nas and Game would later appear on Hip Hop Is Dead, on the Dr. Dre produced track Hustlers

annotations.text:
I'm Ready To Die without a Reasonable Doubt
 Smoke Chronic and hit it Doggystyle before I go out
 Until they sign my Death Certificate, All Eyez On Me
 I'm still at it, Illmatic, and that's The Documentary
 Ready To Die without a Reasonable Doubt
 Smoke Chronic and hit it Doggystyle before I go out
 Until they sign my Death Certificate, All Eyez On Me
 I'm still at it, Illmatic, and that's The Documentary
annotations.annotation:
Game name-drops the legends he studied in his pursuit to be the next hip-hop legend. While recovering from the 5 gunshot wounds he suffered in October 2001, he told his brother to go out and buy all the hip hop classics which included:


The Notorious B.I.G. – Ready To Die


Jay-Z – Reasonable Doubt


Dr. Dre – The Chronic


Snoop Dogg – Doggy Style


Ice Cube – Death Certificate

Albums from Big Daddy Kane (BDK didn’t make the verse)



Game was already well-versed with:



2Pac – All Eyez On Me


Nas – Illmatic




Game studied all of these classics and composed The Documentary, the album on which this song of the same name appears.
Also it is noteworthy that Game placed his album with the classics of the genre as if to say his album will be a classic one day.
And today, its fair to say it is.

annotations.text:
If I die my niggas
 Fuck it, I did a song with Mary Blige, my niggas
annotations.annotation:
He’s alluding to a Jay-Z line from “If I should Die” in order to set up his peace offering to Jay

Jay-Z’s line is

If I should die don’t cry my niggas,…
I did songs with Mary J. Blige my niggas

He did the song “Don’t Worry” with Mary J. Blige off the same album, The Documentary

annotations.text: Got a hook from Faith, no verse from Jay
annotations.annotation:
Faith Evans worked with him, singing the chorus on Don’t Need Your Love

As a caveat, his career is lacking for not having worked with Jay-Z

annotations.text:
I guess on Westside Story he thought I spit in his face
 Told Ed Lover & Moni Love I was talkin' to Ja
 With that Maybach line, it was payback time
annotations.annotation:
On “Westside Story”, Game had a line that he directed  at Ja Rule

However, he was worried Jay took take the diss personally because Jay also wears throwback jerseys and drives Maybachs

Game thinks Jay-Z is offended that he said on the song “I don’t wear button-ups and drive Maybachs.”  This would be a reasonable reading since at the time the common attack on Jay-Z was that he was too old and out of touch to be a top rapper.  The idea of somebody wearing non-thug clothing while driving in stuffy luxury vehicles would illustrate this

Ed Lover and Moni Love are big radio personalities in hip-hop.  He clarified to them that the line was going after Ja Rule, not Jay-Z (the clip of his clarification appears in this song after this verse)

annotations.text: Take your car and trade it in for eight 300 Z's
annotations.annotation: This line is about the preceding lines and Ja Rules Maybach. Game says that he will take the very expensive Maybach and trade it in for 8 Nissan 300z sports cars.

annotations.text: You'll do life in a cemetery, I'll do mine with Shyne
annotations.annotation:
Shyne is the rapper who went to prison to take the fall for Puff Daddy in Puff’s nightclub shooting incident.  He’s saying “fuck with me, I’ll kill you. You’ll be dead and then I’ll go to prison”

Shyne is now free, but he has been deported to Belize

annotations.text:
I'm the second dopest nigga from Compton you'll ever hear
 The first nigga only put out albums every 7 years
annotations.annotation:
Dr. Dre is from Compton, and there was a 7-year wait between his first album, The Chronic, and his follow-up 2001.

This song was released in 2005, at that time there were rumours that Detox would be released in 2006.

So, The Chronic was released in 1992, after that, the album 2001 in 1999, and Detox should have been released in 2006. Detox was eventually scrapped in favor of Compton in 2015.

annotations.text:
[Interlude: Radio Interview]
 (You know what speaking of Jay
 That just makes me roll down
 Now your song Westside Story)
 Uh Oh
 (You got a line that says
 "I don't do button up shirts
 Or drive Maybachs"
 Is that a shot at Jay?)
 Nah, I was talkin' about Ja Rule
 Yeah, so, I mean, I just-I-I got a lot of respect for Jay
 You know what I'm sayin'?
 I never take shots at legends
 I just-that's just somethin' I don't do
annotations.annotation:
This is an excerpt from a radio interview Ed Lover conducted with Game



This is the line Ed is referring to:

And I don’t do button up shirts or drive Maybachs

However, later on in his career in 2009, Game went after Jay in “I’m So Wavy” and “Uncle Otis”.

annotations.text: I'm a son of a gun 'cause moms was a Hoover Crip
annotations.annotation:
Hoover is a street in south-central Los Angeles.  If you stay north on it, it turns into the USC (University of Spoiled Children) campus

It is the main thoroughfare of the Hoover Crips (the “H” pictured below) of whom Game’s mother was apparently a member

annotations.text:
The protégé of Doc Dre, I could finally put the shoes on
 Now that the rumors of Rakim and Cube gone
annotations.annotation:
Rakim was signed to Dr. Dre’s Aftermath, but his album Oh My God was never released due to creative differences with Dr. Dre

So when Ice Cube’s rumored release on Aftermath (called Helta Skelta) also fell through (because they also got into beef), The Game was the best rapper they had.

Now Game can put some shoes on in order to walk, and take his first steps into the rap game.

annotations.text:
They say truth hurts, sunk like quicksand
 Don't stop me in traffic and ask about Hittman
annotations.annotation:
Continuing with Dre proteges that are no longer, Truth Hurts is an R&B singer that was signed to Aftermath for one album and Hittman is a rapper that was dropped from the label before releasing an album

Dr. Dre and Aftermath Entertainment have a long history of signing artists and then ignoring them resulting in the artist being dropped or leaving the label without releasing any music

annotations.text:
I gotta restore the feelin' that crawled from under the rock
 After Tha Dogg Pound crushed the buildings
annotations.annotation:
New York City suffered a huge blow to its pride in 1995 when Tha Dogg Pound released “New York, New York.”.

West Coast gangster rap dominated the rap scene and nobody was paying much attention to New York.  Then Tha Dogg Pound put out a video disrespecting NYC by having Snoop knocking over NYC landmarks

Game wants to bring that West Coast swagger back.

This is also a reference to Jay-Z on Money, Cash, Hoes.

annotations.text:
I got a family to feed, I'm the middle of 9 children
 We can talk about a loan after I sell 5 million
annotations.annotation:
Double-Entendre:


Being the middle of 9 children, Game is the 5th oldest/youngest child in his immediate family (although probably otherwise in terms of who’s living… ), hence the mention of 5 million in 2nd bar here.
A reference to a 9 to 5, a typical job that covers the minimal requirement of 48 hours a week (asides commercially rapping though, probably…).





Contextually suiting, The Documentary did end up selling over 5 million albums. Good prediction, Game!

annotations.text:
If I tell you I ain't Game and I don't know Dre
 You goin' do me like Xzibit and cut half my face?
annotations.annotation:
This is a nod to the incident which involved rapper Xzibit getting attacked by a group of unknown assailants in August 2003 which left him with multiple stitches in his face as referenced on the second line.

Eminem has commented on this topic on the 2004 D12 track “American Psycho II” as well:

And go find who did that shit to Xzibit
And go fill up a whole liquor bottle with piss
And shatter his fucking lips with it

annotations.text:
I take all the credit for puttin' the West back on the map
 If you ain't feelin' that, guess I'm Guerrilla Black
annotations.annotation:
Guerrilla Black is a West coast rapper perhaps best known for sounding eerily like (and kind of looking like) The Notorious B.I.G.



The relevant thing about him is that he was a huge flop. His first album, Guerilla City, only sold 46,000 copies. If people didn’t appreciate The Game representing the West Coast, he’d have been forgotten just like Guerilla Black.

annotations.text: [Produced by Ski Beatz]
annotations.annotation:
The sample for this track is Ahmad Jamal’s jazzy-toned “Pastures.”

Skip to 1:09 for the sample

https://soundcloud.com/docdrilla/ahmad-jamal-pastures#t=1:09

Ski Beatz had this to say when asked about his role in the song:


That was my song! It was a song I was working on for my album at the time. It was me and Suede from Camp Lo rapping on it. I was happy about the song so I ran up in Dame’s house and Jay was there. I played it for them and they got the mad frown face, bopping they head, like, ‘This is dope!’

Then Jay was like, ‘You know you gotta give me that song right?’ I was like, ‘What do you mean? I just did this song!’ He was like, ‘Come on B, I need that for my album. You know we’re working on this album. Give me that beat, I want that hook too.’ He took the beat, the hook, and the flow too! Which was cool, it wasn’t like he didn’t ask me for it. He didn’t jack it. He told me he was going to do it.

The thing with Mecca [was] she sung the hook. She got paid for singing, obviously. But I wrote the hook for the song. I guess the people that she was dealing with got in her ear and made her think she wrote the song and that she deserved all the publishing and that burned the bridge for what we was doing. They definitely wanted to work with her but it never got that far.

annotations.text: Marcy, Brooklyn... yeah
annotations.annotation: The Marcy Houses, located in Brooklyn, New York, is a public houses complex, where Jay-Z was born.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Mecca]
annotations.annotation:
Per Village Voice, Mecca was just 17 when Ski flew her from Virginia to NYC to sing this hook.

As Mecca tells it:

I was there with Ski, and he and I created the melody together, and then Ski came up with the lyrics.

Or as Ski tells it:

[Mecca] got paid for singing, obviously. But I wrote the hook for the song. I guess the people that she was dealing with got in her ear and made her think she wrote the song and that she deserved all the publishing and that burned the bridge for what we was doing. They definitely wanted to work with her but it never got that far.

And that explains why you don’t see Mecca on any other Jay-Z songs.

annotations.text:
I'm feeling it, fill the glass to the top with Moët
 Feeling it, feel the Lex' pushing up on the set
annotations.annotation: Moët & Chandon is one of the biggest producers of champagne worldwide, while Lexus (Lex' in the song) is the luxury vehicle division of Toyota. Jay is mentioning here luxury brands to make the listener aware of his wealthy lifestyle.

annotations.text: I'm feeling it, feel the high that you get from the lye
annotations.annotation:
Back in the day Jay did occasionally indulge in marijuana, although he basically swore it off in the years that ensued. In Decoded Jay recalls a scene where he was with The Notorious B.I.G. and got completely smoked out.

Weed plays a huge role in this track, with Jay riding the feeling that the game has given him down whatever road it takes him. In this instance, it takes him towards getting high and enjoying himself.

An “L” is a blunt.

annotations.text:
I keep it realer than most, I know you feeling it
 Cristal's on ice, I like to toast, I keep on spilling it
annotations.annotation:
Jay always talks about his choice liquors, even drinking D'Usse out of his Grammy in 2013, and purchasing Armand de Brignac Champagne brand for $200 million, but for Jay to be really on top of his game (and feelin' himself), he prefers a toast with Cristal, and best believe he’s spilling some on wife, Beyoncé.



Ironically, after buying the Ace of Spades Champagne along with Armand De Brignac, Jay called for a boycott on Cristal, ceasing from mentioning its name in his raps. Cristal is wine brand created in 1876 for Alexander II.

annotations.text:
Bone crushers I keep real close, I got the skill for this
 On my back the flyest clothes, looking ill as shit
annotations.annotation:
The opening of the verse is spoken directly to a female companion, as Jay displays his trademark cockiness but manages to back it up, with a whole bunch of Cristal, and incredible clothing, which at the time might have seen like a boast, until his Iceberg Slim persona rocking Iceberg clothing, and his eventual creation of a Rocawear empire.

“Bone crusher” was mentioned in “Can’t Get With That,” in similar circumstances. It may mean his lyrical skill, or it may simply mean something like brass knuckles.

annotations.text:
Transactions illegitimate 'cause life is still a bitch, and then you die
 But for now, life, close your eyes and feel this dick
annotations.annotation:
This is a reference to AZ’s existentialist hook on “Life’s A Bitch” by Nas:

Life’s a bitch and then you die

Jay takes the personification of life even further by fucking her, enjoying her while he can.

annotations.text:
Since diapers, had nothing to live for like them lifers but
 Making sure every nigga stay rich within my cipher
annotations.annotation:
A huge theme during Reasonable Doubt was the idea that hustlers are pre-determined to be hustlers, via the harsh conditions they face and the lack of opportunities. A “lifer” is someone imprisoned for life, Jay feels rail-roaded into a certain existence as if he’s already serving a life sentence.

On that note, now that he’s achieved a little bit of success he wants to ensure he shares it with those around him. This line was incredibly prophetic. In subsequent years he’s “made more millionaires than the Lotto did,” with people like Memphis Bleek, Dame Dash, Cam'ron, Beanie Sigel, Emory Jones, and even Lyor Cohen profiting off his incredible run. This isn’t an exhaustive list by any means.

annotations.text:
We paid the price to circle us, success, they turned my mic up
 I'm 'bout to hit these niggas with some shit that'll light ya life up
annotations.annotation:
This was a major theme on Reasonable Doubt, the idea that Jay had paid his dues, living “a whole bunch of life” in order to craft these stories.

To “light ya life up” means to give hope or meaning where there was none before. Again, this proved to be prophetic, because Jay gave another version of the stereotypical Black American narrative (you either play ball or sell drugs). Now, a kid from the streets could attain wealth and power merely through strength of will.

annotations.text:
If every nigga in your clique is rich, your clique is rugged
 Nobody will fall 'cause everyone will be each others crutches
annotations.annotation:
There’s a theme in rap of successful artists coming back and putting their friends on. Eminem did it with D12, Nelly did it with St. Lunatics, and Jay did it with Roc-A-Fella.

This is another way of diversifying your income stream. If each member of an entourage has their own identity, and their own way of making money, if one of them falls the others can pick them up. Jay’s basically laying out the blueprint for how he would run Roc-A-Fella, although it didn’t quite work out that way.

Essentially, Jay remained the key piece of the money-making puzzle. If he ever fell off, his friends would too, which was exemplified by the split of The Roc and Dame Dash and Kareem Burke’s subsequent financial failures.

Even Memphis Bleek, who achieved Gold success more than once on the label, is still reliant on Jay’s name, although he works incredibly hard himself.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Mecca]
annotations.annotation:
Per Village Voice, Mecca was just 17 when Ski flew her from Virginia to NYC to sing this hook.

As Mecca tells it:

I was there with Ski, and he and I created the melody together, and then Ski came up with the lyrics.

Or as Ski tells it:

[Mecca] got paid for singing, obviously. But I wrote the hook for the song. I guess the people that she was dealing with got in her ear and made her think she wrote the song and that she deserved all the publishing and that burned the bridge for what we was doing. They definitely wanted to work with her but it never got that far.

And that explains why you don’t see Mecca on any other Jay-Z songs.

annotations.text: I'm in the rain doing a buck 40, hydroplaning, what, shorty?
annotations.annotation:
Despite a rainy forecast, Jigga has one of his whips out for a drive. The roads are wet and slippery, but this doesn’t stop him from doing 140 miles-per-hour, eventually causing him to “hydroplane.” Hydroplaning occurs when a car’s wheels lose grip with the road as a result of water building between the tires and surface or the road.



Going 140 mph is probably not the safest thing to do while its raining, but Jay-Z pretty much does what he wants.

annotations.text:
(Where you disappear to, son?) Maintaining
 Putting myself in a position most of these rappers ain't in
annotations.annotation:
This is a direct call back to his hustling days. During Decoded Jay recalled times when he would disappear for months on end to hustle out of state:

When I’d leave Brooklyn for long stretches and come back a hundred years later, Clark would find me and say, ‘Let’s do this music.’… I was so skeptical about the business that I would also get annoyed.

Jay also explained that the feeling on the street was “these rappers are hoes,” being pimped out by the major record labels. And after his mentor Jaz-O was handled poorly by EMI, it further showed Jay he had to create his own situation, and not rely on corporate people to keep their word.

annotations.text: I'm living, the ill streets' blues got you hunger pang-in'
annotations.annotation:
A play on the title of the T.V. show Hill Street Blues, Jay-Z’s streets are “ill” (sick); the denizens are hungry for sustenance

 Also a reference to this Kool G Rap classic.

annotations.text: Warming it up for the perfect time to hit your brain
annotations.annotation:
This bar is an early example of one of Jay’s famous double entendres.

Firstly, when cooking crack a young Shawn Carter had to heat up a cocaine and baking soda water solution to a specific temperature and cook it for the right amount of time to ensure his product was the best. When the crack is then smoked, it hits the brain faster than other drugs since the blood travels a short path from the lungs to the brain. It’s a very intense high, too.

Secondly, the bar relates to Jay’s plan to takeover the rap game. He spent many months working on his debut album Reasonable Doubt, quietly preparing an album that would be the best product distributed on New York streets for many years.

annotations.text:
No doubt, they can vouch my life is real as shit
 '95 South
annotations.annotation:
Before he became a full-time rapper Jay used to drug-run along the I-95. The legendary DJ Clark Kent can do the vouching for Hov here:

Last night, my man Jay-Z killed the B-Sides show. There were plenty of great moments. But, for us, nothing was better than seeing this sign on stage. Probably didn’t mean much to many, but, there were a group of us that loved this one feature. Before I could search, find, and convince Jay to get to the music, this was the way, the road, the route to the paper. It was the main reason Jay didn’t want to rap. But, once I talked enough, we started to work. One of the first songs was named ‘95 South..’ It quickly became our unofficial theme song. It was so important to us, we made a second version. As soon as I saw the sign on stage, I could hear every one of the six verses. Might not have meant to much to those of you that saw the show but to us it was everything. Just look at how far you can go. You killed it Homie.

annotations.text: And Papi on the Hill and shit
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z often mentions a “Papi” as his early drug connect, along with “Spanish Jose” and other intentionally unverifiable names, like “sure, I used to sell drugs! Who was my connect? Papi…you know…Papi, Papi Chulo, the one on the Hill.”

“The Hill” is a historic black neighborhood on Maryland’s Eastern Shore in a town called Easton where Jay Z used to sell drugs. Easton is a neighboring town to Cambridge, in which he refers in the following bar.

annotations.text: And all the towns like Cambridge that I killed with, shit
annotations.annotation: Hov’s close friend Emory “Vegas” Jones grew up in Cambridge, Maryland. Hov would stay with Vegas when he was drug-running along the I-95, stopping to cook crack at his house on Robbins Street.

As Mecca tells it:

I was there with Ski, and he and I created the melody together, and then Ski came up with the lyrics.

Or as Ski tells it:

[Mecca] got paid for singing, obviously. But I wrote the hook for the song. I guess the people that she was dealing with got in her ear and made her think she wrote the song and that she deserved all the publishing and that burned the bridge for what we was doing. They definitely wanted to work with her but it never got that far.

And that explains why you don’t see Mecca on any other Jay-Z songs.

annotations.annotation:
Back in the day Jay did occasionally indulge in marijuana, although he basically swore it off in the years that ensued. In Decoded Jay recalls a scene where he was with The Notorious B.I.G. and got completely smoked out.

Weed plays a huge role in this track, with Jay riding the feeling that the game has given him down whatever road it takes him. In this instance, it takes him towards getting high and enjoying himself.

An “L” is a blunt.

annotations.text: The Cristals they keep me wet like Baywatch
annotations.annotation:
Baywatch was still incredibly popular during the mid 90s, a TV show about surf-lifesavers and their complex personal lives. Cristal is wet, but it’s a double entendre. To be “wet” also means to be with women, so not only does Cristal quench Jay’s thirst, it makes him seem more appealing to women due to his wealth.

Now he just uses cash.

annotations.text:
I keep it tight for all the nights my momma prayed I'd stop
 Said she had dreams that snipers hit me with a fatal shot
 Those nightmares, ma, those dreams that you say you've got
annotations.annotation:
Jay would elaborate more on this during “Regrets”:

My mom’s crying because her insides are dying
Her son trying her patience, keep her heart racing

During interviews he hasn’t been too open about the way his mother must have felt, to lose another of her family to the streets. He’s been very vocal on tracks though:

Til you heard the cries of my mama, me givin her drama
Told her I ain’t promised tomorrow, gotta live for the day
And before she could say Jay…
I was out the door, pouch full of raw, a outlaw mentality

The “sniper” in this instance most likely refers to the Feds, whom Jay was slightly paranoid about at the time:

 you gotta know
It always crossed my mind that Feds be tappin the lines like Gregory Hines

By this point Jay was out of the game for good, so he can look back on it with a more calm frame of mind.

annotations.text: Give me the chills but these mills, well, they make me hot
annotations.annotation: The nightmares that he might get shot cause him anxiety, nerves. During “Regrets” he admits to being scared, but on “Can I Live” he’s defiant, saying “I’d rather die enormous than live dormant.” These lines are somewhere between the two extremes. He’s almost detached, saying her fears scare him too, but it’s a small price to pay for the money he’s making.

annotations.text: Y'all don't feel me, enough to stop the illing right?
annotations.annotation:
“‘Illin’”  is referencing the ‘illegitimate’ transactions he must do to get by.

It’s used the same way in “Can I Live”:

Illin' for revenue/Rayful Edmonds like"

Is the money he’s made enough to get him out of the game permanently? It’s a gamble either way. If he stays, he’s gambling with his life. If he leaves, he’s gambling his future and income.

annotations.text: But at the same time these dimes keep me feeling tight
annotations.annotation:
Dimes refers to dime bags, which keep him feeling tight because being a drug dealer causes you to feel trapped, always having to watch for police or cats that wanna kill you.

The line could also refer to dimes as in beautiful women (10 out of 10=dime) because they compliment him now that he’s paid, which makes him feel good (“tight”).

annotations.text:
I'm so confused, okay I'm getting weeded now
 I know I contradicted myself, look, I don't need that now
annotations.annotation:
Jay is confused from the weed smoke, and doesn’t “need” your input on his consistency. He’s self commenting on how weed disorients your train of thought.

He’s confused whether or not to get out of the game.  His mom is scared of him getting killed, and he has already made millions.  But the attention from the girls the pecks that come with the drug-dealing life make this a hard decision.

The verse flows in a probing fashion. Jay is painting a picture of an inner struggle to quit the game of drug dealing as well as the burden of knowing his loved ones(mom most pointedly) are worried about how this is going to end for him. His confusion is with all these choices and decisions he has to make and then it gets so bad, he succumbs to smoking weed, something he’s been against just to show the listener how vulnerable he’s feeling by the end of this verse. He’s aware of the contradiction and he doesn’t need you to add any further chastising to his already tormented/confused state of mind.. Just let him be…

annotations.text:
It's just once in a blue when there's nothing to do
 And the tension gets too thick for my sober mind to cut through
annotations.annotation:
Hov employs the idiom “one in a blue moon” here to describe how he rarely smokes marijuana. He explains he is using the weed as a calming influence as the tensions of the streets overrun his brain.

His protégé J. Cole riffs on these lines in “How High:”

No I don’t smoke, maybe once in a blue
When the tension gets thick then there’s nothing to do

annotations.text: Me and the chick on the island and then we're boning
annotations.annotation: The line is “me and the chick on the L and then we’re boning” — Jay’s still talking about weed, L is east coast slang for a blunt. Though it could be a homophone / double entendre for being on “The Island” i.e Manhattan (maybe he took the L train from BK…)

annotations.text:
Take one more toke and I leave that weed alone, man
 It got me going, shit
annotations.annotation: Jigga only smokes Brooklyn’s finest so he was definitely toking some quality kush

annotations.text: [Chorus: Mecca]
annotations.annotation:
Per Village Voice, Mecca was just 17 when Ski flew her from Virginia to NYC to sing this hook.

As Mecca tells it:

I was there with Ski, and he and I created the melody together, and then Ski came up with the lyrics.

Or as Ski tells it:

[Mecca] got paid for singing, obviously. But I wrote the hook for the song. I guess the people that she was dealing with got in her ear and made her think she wrote the song and that she deserved all the publishing and that burned the bridge for what we was doing. They definitely wanted to work with her but it never got that far.

And that explains why you don’t see Mecca on any other Jay-Z songs.

lyrics:
[Verse 1 - Pusha T]

It go hot waist - Desert taste, four pounds of metal, tri-angle faceHesi-tate? Never, I'll put hole in whoever
Don't make Push' Russian Roulette ya
Gamble with ya life
Change came from cocaine I've measured
White was the treasure, comfort was the steelI pedal to the corner like a child on a big wheelFlow more sicker, so much shake in the street
They measure my weight in Richter
Make no mistake, I rhyme for the public
But still I push yay that make the ghettos quakeBy all means I've seen I've lived
By 22 years old, 50 thousand dollar vehicles I rimmedMy dreams start over the stoveI ran over the globe and back again
You seen em, five-ten, hair swingin, dark skinned
Gun on my hip like a sergeant
Wrist Green Power, Chris Tuck' in my watch
Anytime the small hand move, it's Rush Hour
[Hook]
Homie you don't want no probs wit us
Cause we the type of dudes who don't think when we bustYou die (Eghck!)
When you come close to
And you get held back cause you're not supposed to
You die (Eghck!)
When we roll up on dubsAnd get VIP all up in the club
You die (Eghck!)
Homie I am a star
And you might get hurt walking up to my car

[Verse 2 - Malice]

I offer y'all, 24 bars of rawLike eight balls in hard or soft
Time I, push em off, they need help now
Cause I, flood the street with straight melt downAnd I'm not proud, in fact I hate this route
This the same game got my brother strung out
So I, count the ways that it fucked up his life
So I don't have a problem with upping my price, uhAnd who said the game ain't fair?
A God damn loser!
Look, just like chicks, them cats they be runnin' they lips
Worried to death am I still in the Clipse
Well, here's a secret bout me and the Clipse
Even in my absence I'm still the shit ya dig?!
Everything doing it big, from the cars to the home
From the cash to the chrome, they can't say the game ain't grown
Did they tell you bout the nine? I keeps me that
And I don't ever fall off like Adebisi HatWhen times get tight, the coke game like riding a bikeYou heavy as me? Not in your life. Hang it up

[Hook]

[Verse 3 - FAM-LAY]

See me in a gold Hummer
With two ??? bitches that makes ???
Somebody touch them, then I'm a bust them
Both hoes is accustomed
To getting coke through customs
They ain't' the average women would cut them
Trey Eighters out the leather blazerPoint 'em at your Chevy BlazerThen bust holes in your Pelle blazerYou 'bout to ride in Hell's elevator
You got somethin' else to say to God?
You gonna have to tell him later
Time is money
Doubt none of y'all find this funny
See I ain't got time for dummies
So I keep the Nina Ross right beside the tummyAnd I'm leavin' with the scratch and the finest bunnyI'm so far from a million dollars
If y'all feel me, holler
Put your drinks in the air, then peel your collar
Chrome wheel Impalas
Make 'em bounce for FAM-LAY
Cuz your drunk ass might get killed tomorrow
Narcs jumpin' out of U-Haul trucks
Leavin' you all stuck
Behind a park bench, balled-up
So I sleep all day, hustle all night
Like a vampire
But I don't suck blood, I bust slugs
Liquor got me trigger-happy
I can tell that you a hater how you lookin' at me
Young boy, but I'll pop
16 from a magazine
Washing machine
Kill the first
Cop on the scene
I'm stupid

annotations.text: It go hot waist - Desert taste, four pounds of metal, tri-angle face
annotations.annotation: Referring to the heat (gun) on his waist: the Desert Eagle weighs about four pounds (and is therefore sometimes referred to as a four pound) and has a triangle face

annotations.text: Change came from cocaine I've measured
annotations.annotation: Pusha’s change from being poor to making money came from his drug dealing.

annotations.text: I pedal to the corner like a child on a big wheel
annotations.annotation: Technically “peddle.”  He sells coke to the fiends on the corner (recurring theme!)

annotations.text: Flow more sicker,
annotations.annotation: Reference to B.I.G. line “With my sycamore flow, more sicker than yours”

annotations.text:
So much shake in the street
They measure my weight in Richter
annotations.annotation:
Shake is probably a reference to the fiends shaking from a hit or in anticipation of their next hit.  Basically fiends are always shaking.  Could also be a stand-in for cocaine.

He moves so much weight (large quantities of coke) that you need a scale that can capture seismic activity to quantify it.

annotations.text:
Make no mistake, I rhyme for the public
But still I push yay that make the ghettos quake
annotations.annotation: Keeping with the earthquake metaphor, the weight he’s pushing is so heavy the whole ghetto quakes.  Or perhaps the number of fiends he serves is so great that their collective trembling makes the ghetto quake.  Either way, he sells a lot of cocaine!

annotations.text: By 22 years old, 50 thousand dollar vehicles I rimmed
annotations.annotation: Earning enough money to be able to afford expensive vehicles and accoutrements for their wheels by 22 is pretty impressive, but c'mon, spending that kind of money on status symbols and dated consumer goods? Pay for a kid’s college education or something. Jesus

annotations.text:
Wrist Green Power, Chris Tuck' in my watch
Anytime the small hand move, it's Rush Hour
annotations.annotation: Um, Chris Tucker was in the movie Rush Hour.  That’s all I have

annotations.text: Cause we the type of dudes who don't think when we bust
annotations.annotation: We will shoot you without considering the pros and cons of our actions

annotations.text: Eghck
annotations.annotation: This is the sound made by a person who has just tasted the (disgusting) drip of cocaine coming down his nasal passage

annotations.text:
And I'm not proud, in fact I hate this route
This the same game got my brother strung out
So I, count the ways that it fucked up his life
So I don't have a problem with upping my price, uh
annotations.annotation: Typical Clipse ambivalence about the coke game.  Note how he resolves the confict: by charging more for the drugs he’s selling.  Moral dilemma resolved!

annotations.text:
Them cats they be runnin' they lips
Worried to death am I still in the Clipse
Well, here's a secret bout me and the Clipse
annotations.annotation:
He’s singing a different tune from “Virginia”, where he rattles off an extensive list of topics of conversation that are verboten:


the Neptunes
the loud, screaming chick with the hair
the Clipse’s music
the release date of their album

annotations.text: Even in my absence I'm still the shit ya dig?!
annotations.annotation: This song was released between the Clipse’s first album, Lord Willin' (2002) and their second, Hell Hath No Fury (2006). He’s just reminding the listener that although his profile hasn’t been so high since his first album, he is in as good form as ever

annotations.text: Adebisi Hat
annotations.annotation: Character in Oz who wore hat that, while always precariously perched on his head, never fell off

annotations.text: When times get tight
annotations.annotation: Dealing cocaine is always a fallback for these guys. A good thing they have marketable skills besides rapping, given their persistent label woes

annotations.text: You heavy as me? Not in your life.
annotations.annotation: “In terms of the amount of cocaine you move or the weight you carry in the rap game, you just don’t measure up”

annotations.text: See me in a gold Hummer
annotations.annotation: They See Me Rollin', They Hatin'

annotations.text:
Wake up, wake up, wake up, wake up, wake up
 It's the first of the month
annotations.annotation:
Welfare checks are checks distributed by the government to people whose low income places them below a prescribed living standard called the poverty line. In many states, they are delivered on the 1st and 15th of each month.



Since there are many things the Bone Thugs plan on doing with this money (including smoking weed and eating steak) they wake up as early as possible to allot it all into the day.

annotations.text:
So get up, get up, get up, get up, get up
 So cash your checks and come up
annotations.annotation:
“Checks” are welfare checks, which arrive on the 1st and 15th of every month.

Chris Rock called this song a “welfare carol” in his stand-up routine on Black People vs Niggaz. (Fast forward to 4:20!)

The “wake up, wake up” and “get up, get up” lyrics are a direct allusion to Marvin’s Gaye’s Sexual Healing.

Since there are many things the Bone Thugs plan on doing with this money (including smoking weed and eating steak) they wake up as early as possible to allot it all into the day.

annotations.text:
So get up, get up, get up, get up, get up
 So cash your checks and come up
annotations.annotation:
“Checks” are welfare checks, which arrive on the 1st and 15th of every month.

Chris Rock called this song a “welfare carol” in his stand-up routine on Black People vs Niggaz. (Fast forward to 4:20!)

The “wake up, wake up” and “get up, get up” lyrics are a direct allusion to Marvin’s Gaye’s Sexual Healing.

annotations.text: Hit up the block to where? East 99
annotations.annotation:
The corner block of E. 99th Street and St Clair is where the five members lived throughout much of their teens, including the early years of their rapping career.



They continued living in the area until Eazy-E brought them to Los Angeles to finish the recording process for Creepin On Ah Come Up.

annotations.text: I get with my nigga to get me some yayo
annotations.annotation: Yayo is a nickname for cocaine. What they are implying in this sentence is that they’re going to use their cashed checks on drugs such as cocaine

annotations.text:
'Cause the po-po creep when they roll slow
 If you can't get away, better toss that yayo
 Keep your bankroll
annotations.annotation: The police are hot on cocaine in the neighbourhood so Krayzie is saying its better for you to ditch the coke and hold on to the money so you can get away and spend it later.

annotations.text: Yeah, we havin' a celebration, love to stay high
annotations.annotation: This line serves as the basis for The Game’s single released 17 years later, which heavily samples this song and its carefree vibe.

annotations.text:
Wake up, and I see that my sister was already dressed
 She said, "I'ma run and go get my stamps"
annotations.annotation: While all states in the U.S. now use a debit card system to give out food benefits, there was a time when food stamps were actually stamps:

annotations.text: Sort through the mail and put it up into me pocket
annotations.annotation: Bizzy Gets Bizzy With The Mail #BizzyBone

annotations.text: But ain't no bucket ride that RTA, hop on the 10 to the Clair
annotations.annotation: Bizzy has no “bucket” (car), so he neets to ride the Regional Transit Authority #10 bus, which runs through 93rd and 105th streets, to St. Claire, where he could score some dope.

annotations.text: Ready to get 'em up with-a me thugs
annotations.annotation: Bizzy couldn’t wait to go fuck with his niggas on St.Clair and just do gangsta shit.

annotations.text: And to cash that dum, man, I gotta get paid
annotations.annotation: The “dum” he’s saying he wants to “cash” refers to a dummy rock or a dum-dum that he wants to sell. A dummy rock is fake crack cocaine that low-end dealers would sell when they could not get ahold of actual crack cocaine to sell.

annotations.text: Playa, playa, holla, holla, St. Clair got much to offer
annotations.annotation: Saint Claire Avenue is the main thoroughfare in East 90’s Cleveland; a lot of drug dealers post up on Saint Claire. They sell weed on 93rd street and crack further up

annotations.text:
Whether it be weed on 93
 Or off on the Glock-Glock for some dollars
annotations.annotation: Bizzy sells weed on the corner of 93rd and St. Claire, and sometimes stoops on the “Glock-Glock” (or “Double Glock”, the nickname of the corner of 99th and St. Claire, the heart of the Cleveland ghetto) and makes his money over there

annotations.text: So, get a bag of dope and a quarter O, oh
annotations.annotation: This line is about getting a bag of “dope” AKA  marijuana; And also a “quarter roll”, the paper coin holders used to hold quarters. So as to then roll them and smoke a blunt. Some people think the line contains “yayo” and “quarter O”, but buying Quarter Ounces of weed in urban environments used to be rare for non-dealing smokers. Especially as the entire song is reference to waiting for your government check to arrive on the 1st of the month when you are out of money or pinching pennies. No one buys an ounce when their funds are running low.

annotations.text:
Most all of my niggas got the same
 And we gonna roll it all up to smoke
annotations.annotation: Everybody else also got a bag of dope and a quarter O on the 1st of the month…so we’re going to smoke a lot!

annotations.text:
I gotta get paid on the 1st, gotta blaze up my spliff
 Get live with the Bone Thugs
 Poetic Hustlaz and the Graveyard Shift, on the 1st
annotations.annotation:
Poetic Hustlaz and the Graveyard Shift were part of Mo' Thugs, which is the extended family of Bone Thugs-N-Harmony.



Mo' Thugs (and these sub-groups especially) were close friends of the Bone Thugs and often joined them in their day-to-day activities, including smoking weed and making money.

annotations.text: [Produced by Dr. Dre]
annotations.annotation:
Via Wikipedia, citing the sleeve notes of the 2006 remastered version of Labi Siffre’s Remember My Song (1975):

Producer Dr. Dre wanted to use a sample of Labi Siffre’s “I Got The …” for the rhythm track. […] Siffre, who is openly gay, stated, “attacking two of the usual scapegoats, women and gays, is lazy writing. If you want to do battle, attack the aggressors not the victims.” Eminem made lyric changes and Siffre cleared the sample.

http://youtu.be/xKISdd2mKzU?t=2m8s

Not only are there clean and explicit versions of this song (with moderately unique lyrics), but there is also an extra-explicit version, released as the B-side to “Guilty Conscience” single. Perhaps the extra-explicit version is the one Siffre refused to clear the sample for?

annotations.text:
Hi, my name is, what? My name is, who?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
 Hi, my name is, huh? My name is, what?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady

Hi, my name is, what? (Excuse me) My name is, who?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
 (Can I have the attention of the class for one second?)
 Hi, my name is, huh? My name is, what?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
annotations.annotation:
In a clip from HBO’s The Defiant Ones, Dr. Dre and Eminem recap the first time they met and also how “My Name Is” was born.

While Eminem admitted he was a little star struck meeting Dre for the first time, thinking to himself: “Dude, I see you on T.V. all the time—you’re one of my biggest influences ever, in life,” Dre thought Eminem’s “shit was fucking incredible.”

When Em showed up to the studio for his first session, Dre had a beat ready featuring a sample of Labi Siffre’s 1975 song “I Got The….” Dre recalls playing the beat and within a matter of seconds, watching the “My Name Is” lyrics come out of Em’s mouth:

I was like, ‘Listen, man, I put this sample together, tell me if you like it,’ and I hit the drum machine, and then maybe two or three seconds went by, and he just went, ‘Hi, my name is, what? My name is, who?’ I’m like, ‘Yo, stop. Shit’s hot.’

Watch the full clip here:

https://players.brightcove.net/4863540648001/default_default/index.html?videoId=5503026503001

annotations.text: Hi, kids, do you like violence? (Yeah, yeah, yeah)
annotations.annotation:
These lines are silly, but thought was put into them. This was Eminem’s first ever real single, and he knew that his career relied on its success. So he made sure to make a mark from the very first line, roping in the children that would become big supporters of his music. (the phrase is even followed by childish screams of “YEAH!”)

This question pokes fun at how parents will allow their kids to watch cartoons like Tom & Jerry that desensitizes violence without thinking twice, but then place blame on controversial artists like him when their kids start acting out. Eminem knows that kids are already attracted to violence by all of the aggression that surrounds them in the media, and wants to bring attention to the fact that it isn’t just rap music that is ruining everyone’s perfect little boys and girls.



“Violence” was changed to “Primus” on the clean version. They’re an American rock band, which correlates with the NiN reference in the next line.

Primus is the band responsible for the South Park Theme. South Park is actually a lot like the TV version of Eminem; it is controversial, it deals a lot with pop culture, and it depicts the negative impacts of the media on kids in a humorous way. Eminem is actually a big fan of the show and compares himself to one of the characters on the show in a later song (Cartman). Eminem establishes the South Park connection to show that there is more than one outlet influencing the youth of America.

annotations.text: Wanna see me stick nine-inch nails through each one of my eyelids? (Uh-huh)
annotations.annotation:
Eminem references the controversial rock band Nine Inch Nails here, highlighting the idea that rappers aren’t the only ones responsible for driving the youth to violence; there is television, movies, and rock music.

The literal meaning of the line, is that kids would probably laugh if they saw him sticking nails through his eyelids, because they are desensitized to violence and respond well to shock tactics.

annotations.text:
Wanna copy me and do exactly like I did? (Yeah, yeah)
 Try 'cid and get fucked up worse than my life is? (Huh?)
annotations.annotation:
Slim is sarcastically prompting his younger audience to view him as a Role Model although he clearly has all of the traits that depict him as the exact opposite of one.

“‘cid” is short for “acid”, the common nickname given to LSD, a very powerful drug that induces strong and vivid hallucinations.

Also note that at this point in time, Eminem’s life was miles from good: it was so messed up that it could be compared to the effects of taking LSD. Examples of how difficult his life was is seen throughout The Slim Shady LP (see “If I Had”, “Brain Damage”, and “Rock Bottom”)

annotations.text: My brain's dead weight, I'm tryna get my head straight
annotations.annotation:
The constant self-debauchery and drug use has left Em’s brain fried to uselessness. So his brain isn’t really doing anything for him, it’s just sort of floating around in his skull.

This line is also a bit of wordplay on the homophone weight/wait: “My brain’s dead, wait, I’m trying to get my head straight.”

annotations.text: But I can't figure out which Spice Girl I want to impregnate (Oh)
annotations.annotation:
The Spice Girls were a Margaret Thatcher-inspired world famous Brit pop girl band, and hate-fucking female pop stars is a theme in Eminem’s radio songs (see also the reference to Pamela Lee a couple lines down).

In “The Real Slim Shady” it’s Christina Aguilera, and in “I’m Back” it’s Jennifer Lopez.



Allegedly, this line was inspired by radio show DJ’s constantly asking Eminem which Spice Girl he would date if he had the choice. He got sick of this question and decided to parody it in his song.

annotations.text:
And Dr. Dre said, "Slim Shady, you a basehead" (Uh-uh)
 "Then why's your face red? Man, you wasted"
annotations.annotation:
It’s Dr. Dre calling him a “basehead” (another word for “crackhead”) that makes Eminem fantasize about killing him in “The Real Slim Shady”.

This line also shows the world that Eminem has a Dr. Dre co-sign. Em was relatively unknown to the masses before this song came out, so he had to draw attention to himself in his first real single; the respect from a hip-hop legend like Dre helped achieve this.

annotations.text:
Well, since age 12, I felt like I'm someone else
 'Cause I hung my original self from the top bunk with a belt
annotations.annotation:
Slim Shady “killed” Marshall Mathers to become famous, and that’s what led to the identity crisis and multiple personalities. This line is later referenced in the song “Insane” off of his album Relapse.

The bastard won’t even eat nothing, he’s scared
He just hung himself in the bedroom, he’s dead!

Em actually did try to commit suicide after Infinite came out but before he invented Slim Shady. Saying he “hung his original self” is true to his real life.



The censored version of this lyrics is just as awesome:

Since age 12 I felt like a caged elf
Who stayed to himself in one space, chasing his tail

Everyone knows that Em hates censors, but he realizes that there’s nothing he can do about it. So instead of just putting 5 seconds of silence in the song and sounding ridiculous, he rewrote the lyrics so even the censored version of the song would sound good. There’s actually a great RapGenius blog post about rewriting lyrics for the censors.

annotations.text: Got pissed off and ripped Pamela Lee's tits off
annotations.annotation:
Pamela Anderson married Tommy Lee in ‘95 and became Pamela Anderson Lee for a few years. Some believed that this was a jab at Kid Rock since Pamela was his ex-wife, but the two didn’t even meet until after this song was released. He probably just mentioned her because, well, there’s a lot to rip off.





The edited version of these lyrics read:

Got ticked off and ripped Pamela Lee’s lips off
Kissed em and said “I didn’t know silicone was supposed to be this soft!”

Which is a reference to her plastic surgery

annotations.text: And smacked her so hard I knocked her clothes backwards like Kris Kross
annotations.annotation:
Kriss Kross was an early 1990’s rap/hip hop duo, made up of Chris “Mac Daddy” Kelly and Chris “Daddy Mac” Smith, best known for their hit song “Jump.” They were only 12 and 13 years old when they recorded their first album and were well known for wearing their clothes backwards.

On an interesting note, Jermaine Dupri discovered this group – Dre and Dupri have famously had beef with each other for years.

annotations.text:
I smoke a fat pound of grass, and fall on my ass
 Faster than a fat bitch who sat down too fast
 Come here, slut; "Shady, wait a minute, that's my girl, dawg"
 I don't give a fuck, God sent me to piss the world off
annotations.annotation:
Slim is not the most flattering person ever, and this is a prime example of his twisted mind: he points out an overweight woman in the rudest way possible and then proceeds to seduce her away from her man.

Note that in the clean version of this song, “God” is replaced with “Dre”, most likely due to the relative cultural insensitivity of saying God’s name in vain.

Also when he says “Come here, slut; “Shady, wait a minute, that’s my girl, dawg”“ the phrase "girl, dawg” is a play on the word Bitch. Like the guy is at the same time saying “Shady, wait a minute, that’s my bitch”

annotations.text:
My English teacher wanted to flunk me in junior high (Shh)
 Thanks a lot, next semester I'll be 35
 I smacked him in his face with an eraser, chased him with a stapler
 And stapled his nuts to a stack of paper (Ow)
annotations.annotation:
According to Em’s autobiography, The Way I Am, this line was originally:

My English teacher wanted to fuck me in junior high
The only problem was, my English teacher was a guy

As Em wrote in Angry Blonde:

To me there was absolutely nothing homophobic about that line. IT WAS JUST A LINE! It was just something funny, but like most of my lyrics, it got analyzed too much. Right away people started saying all kinds of shit. Like I don’t like gay people. I don’t hate gay people. I just don’t stray that way. I don’t care about gay people. Just don’t bring that shit around me.

Openly gay musician Labi Siffre, whose song “I Got The” was sampled for this song, insisted the line be changed.

Em did, in fact, fail 9th grade three times, showing that the altered lines are reflective of both him personally and Slim Shady.

annotations.text:
Walked in the strip club, had my jacket zipped up
 Flashed the bartender, then stuck my dick in the tip cup
annotations.annotation:
This plays off the idea that dudes who wear trench coats are naked underneath and ready to flash people. And tip cup can be interpreted more than one way…





The clean version is

Served the bartender and walked out with the tip cup

Not quite as descriptive, but still funny since the bartender is actually the one being served in this situation.

annotations.text: Extraterrestrial, running over pedestrians in a spaceship
annotations.annotation:
This line, also censored by Siffre, q.v. comment supra, was originally “extraterrestrial killing pedestrians, raping lesbians”, but was changed for the final recorded version to clear the sample.

The version of this song with the lyrics mentioned above can be found on Unmastered Sequence.

annotations.text: While they're screaming at me, "Let's just be friends"
annotations.annotation: In the original version Eminem said that he was ‘raping pedestrians’ which then ties into this line. So that’s why this line might seem a bit out of context.

annotations.text: 99 percent of my life, I was lied to
annotations.annotation: Eminem was 25 when the ‘Slim Shady LP’, so for 24 years Eminem was lied to. Most likely people to lie to Eminem was Debbie Mathers, Kim Mathers, his teachers and bullies, and his brother (cause brothers fight).

annotations.text: I just found out my mom does more dope than I do (Damn)
annotations.annotation:
Eminem has accused his mom of being a drug addict on numerous occasions, including on songs such as My Mom and Cleanin' Out My Closet.

This line in particular is one of the lines that caused Eminem’s mom, Debbie, to sue him for $10 million in 1999. She settled for $25,000, but ended up only walking away with $1,600.

At this time, Eminem was also using drugs, only recreationally at the time, but still says that his mom uses more than him.

annotations.text:
I told her I'd grow up to be a famous rapper
 Make a record about doin' drugs and name it after her
 (Oh, thank you)
annotations.annotation:
Eminem did eventually make a song claiming his drug habit stemmed from the fact that his mom force-fed him pills as a child, ten years later. The song is called “My Mom”, on his 2009 album Relapse.

The way he says “after her” sounds like “Aftera” which is an emergency contraceptive drug.

annotations.text:
You know you blew up when the women rush your stands
 And try to touch your hands like some screamin' Usher fans
 (Ahh, ahh, ahh)
annotations.annotation:
Released in 1999, prior to the Eminem’s familiarity established with Dr. Dre’s 2001, “My Name Is” was something of a juggernaut of a debut single, as it quickly propelled Eminem to superstardom. With this came an expansion of his fanbase, as even women started to take interest in the Detroit MC.

This led to a popularity among females that closely resembled that of R&B singer, Usher. You can even hear women screaming in the background. Early in his career Em opened for Usher a few times, one in which he met now longtime friend Royce Da 5'9".

annotations.text:
This guy at White Castle asked for my autograph (Dude, can I get your autograph?)
 So I signed it, "Dear Dave, thanks for the support, asshole"
annotations.annotation:
White Castle is a hamburger restaurant chain.



Eminem comedically suggests that he doesn’t care about his fans, even though he does. This is a classic example of an Eminem lyric that doesn’t necessarily mean what the words suggest. However, he does get on a more serious note in the track “The Way I Am” which was released on his next album The Marshall Mathers LP.

And I’m thankful for every fan that I get
But I can’t take a shit
In the bathroom without someone standing by it
No, I won’t sign you an autograph
You can call me an asshole, I’m glad

This lyric was later referenced in the skit interlude of “Asshole” on his 2013 album The Marshall Mathers LP2 and even later in the poster of his Kamikaze album.

annotations.text: Stop the tape, this kid needs to be locked away (Get him)
annotations.annotation:
Eminem is mocking what a politician-type would say about him. Basically, they’d say to stop playing his music and put him in prison.

"Stop the tape!" is the recording media equivalent of “stop the presses!” (printed media, usually printing newspapers), a phrase for when something is wrong.

When he says “Stop the tape!”, the beat really stops. And once he finishes the phrase there’s an ad-lib.

annotations.text: Dr. Dre, don't just stand there, operate
annotations.annotation: Dr. Dre produced “My Name Is”, and right when this line comes on the background track changes. This is a double entendre: either asking Dre to perform something on the recording booth to “save the song” from this angry white boy, or taking the “Dr.” part literally and requesting him to literally cut Eminem open and operate on him as a request to change the beat up.

annotations.text:
I'm not ready to leave, it's too scary to die (Fuck that)
 I'll have to be carried inside the cemetery and buried alive
 (Huh, yup)
annotations.annotation:
Horror movie tropes were important to Eminem when this song came out; during concerts, he would have someone onstage dressed as a mummy (one time it was Dustin Hoffman). He even features a mummy on the album artwork to The Slim Shady LP.



Even though this is mostly a joking line about how he viewed death differently than others, he is actually trying to get a point across. Some people thought them Em didn’t care about his life when he was coming up, so he clarified that he valued his life in a way that is still humorous.

annotations.text:
Am I comin' or goin'? I can barely decide
 I just drank a fifth of vodka, dare me to drive? (Go ahead)
annotations.annotation:
“A fifth” refers to a fifth of a gallon, which would be an absurdly dangerous amount to drink even before driving.

The radio version is ‘I just drank a fifth of Kool-Aid- dare me to drive?’ (maybe due to Kool-Aid having some violent subtext )

This line is repeated later by the fictional deranged fan on the song “Stan” while he’s actually drunk driving.

annotations.text:
All my life I was very deprived
 I ain't had a woman in years and my palms are too hairy to hide (Whoops)
annotations.annotation: Reference to old wives' tale that masturbation causes hair to grow on one’s palms. This is a stark contrast to the typical rapper listing how many bitches they fuck.

annotations.text: Clothes ripped like the Incredible Hulk
annotations.annotation:
The Incredible Hulk is a superhero in the Marvel universe. He is the alter-ego of a mild-mannered doctor named Bruce Banner. When Banner is put under a heavy amount of emotional stress, he physically transforms into a large, muscular monster with green skin. Any clothes Banner was wearing will rip apart because the transformation makes his body much larger.



Em read a lot of comic books when he was a kid, and has made other references to the Incredible Hulk in his songs, such as in “Careful What You Wish For”, “Cold Wind Blows” and “Drop The World”. Em walks around with ripped clothes like Hulk does, but it’s likely his clothes are ripped because he was so poor at the time this song was written.

annotations.text: I spit when I talk, I'll fuck anything that walks (Come here)
annotations.annotation: If you’ve ever rapped for extensive periods your mouth starts to foam up which results in you spitting when you talk. Eminem or in this case Slim Shady is a very controversial person and for a good reason. He’ll fuck anything that walks (probably more).

annotations.text:
When I was little, I used to get so hungry I would throw fits
 How you gonna breastfeed me, Mom? You ain't got no tits
annotations.annotation:
In his mother’s book “My Son Marshall, My Son Eminem” she states

“[This line] was horrible and upsetting, because I’d contracted toxemia-blood poisoning-when I gave birth to him and hadn’t been able to breast-feed.”

annotations.text:
I lay awake and strap myself in the bed
 With a bulletproof vest on and shoot myself in the head (Bang)
annotations.annotation:
Which would obviously defeat the purpose of the vest…



The censored lyrics are “Put a bullet proof vest on, and tap myself in the head” accompanied with a metallic clanging sound, instead of Eminem saying bang…Probably because he killed Marshall and became Slim Shady.

annotations.text:
'Cause I'm steamin' mad (Grr)
 And by the way, when you see my dad (Yeah?)
 Tell him that I slit his throat in this dream I had
annotations.annotation:
Everyone knows Em’s dad split on the family when he was a baby. At first he tried to reach out to him through letters, but they were sent back every time, so his desire to meet his dad turned to hatred. He has bashed his dad in his lyrics numerous times to try and vent his anger towards him (see “Cleanin' Out My Closet”, “Hailie’s Song”, “Rhyme or Reason”).

The irony here is that the “My Name Is” music video states “Starring Marshall Mathers” at the beginning, which is actually Em’s father’s name as well (Eminem is Marshall Mathers III, his father is Marshall Mathers Jr.) So when his half-brother Michael Mathers and half-sister Sarah Mathers saw that, they thought it was referring to Marshall Mathers II (even though the song was actually about slitting MMII’s throat…).

When Em’s dad heard about all this he finally tried to contact him, but it was far too late at that point. And Sarah and Michael were actually referenced in a later song called “Marshall Mathers” where they were called out for trying to reunite with him after he got famous, but they were ignored when they tried to reach out to him as well.



Eminem has softened with his views on Kim and his mother as the years go on, but the one constant has been his anger towards his father. His reasoning for this is that since he is now a father he could never imagine someone running out on his daughter like he did to Em.



The edited version of the lyric is just as venomous

And by the way, when you see my dad
Ask him if he bought a porno mag and seen my ad

Here, Eminem tells the listener to inform the father who abandoned him that he is featured in a pornographic magazine advertisement. These ads typically sell pornographic movies, sex toys and phone sex lines. In other words, he is sarcastically saying, “Dad, look what the son you left behind does for a living,” and implying that it’s his fault.

annotations.text:
Hi, my name is, what? My name is, who?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
 Hi, my name is, huh? My name is, what?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady

Hi, my name is, who? My name is, huh?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
 Hi, my name is, huh? My name is, who?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
annotations.annotation:
German poet Goethe once said:

Names are but noise and smoke, obscuring heavenly light

Eminem seems to have similar views, since he loves confusing his audience as to which one of his alter-egos is talking. But for this particular song, he is introducing his murderous alias Slim Shady to the mainstream (this was his first single under Aftermath Entertainment), knowing it will cause some confusion.

Dre told Esquire about this line:

When me and Marshall got in the studio, it instantly clicked. […] I put on the beat, and maybe five seconds in–I swear to God–he goes, “Hi, my name is.” That was it.

annotations.text: Yeah, gotta say what's up to my nigga Slick Rick
annotations.annotation:
Slick Rick – one of the most influential Golden Era rappers – was known for his storytelling style of rap. This song is a cover of his 1985 classic with Doug E Fresh, “La Di Da Di”.



For those interested in intellectual property law, “La Di Da Di” was one of the first cases to bring up the now-established Fair Use defense of its sampling.

annotations.annotation:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tbog-1RoZwA
Snoop Dogg knew that unlike other music genres, remaking or covering originals in Hip hop which was never done before at that time could have been seen by many as ‘biting’ or ‘dickriding’.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d61tWnYYwYc

Also, due to the rising tension between the West and East Coast hip hop scenes at the time and the fact that both Slick Rick and Doug E. Fresh are from New York, Snoop said that he initially caught some flack from where he came from for doing this cover as many people thought that if he were to cover any hip hop joint, it should at least be something from the West Coast scene.

Snoop disagrees with both these views and defends his usage of remaking a classic on the grounds of paying homage. This diss was aimed at those who would disagree with this view.

annotations.text:
But for those who with me, sing that shit
 As it go a little something like this
annotations.annotation:
This track is a remake of E Fresh’s 1985 hit, “La Di Da Di” which featured Slick Rick.

At the time of release, Slick Rick was incarcerated for attempted murder. Snoop made this track to pay tribute to Rick as he admired Rick’s style.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q5LkADdZFB4
