I gave myself a stretch, up, a morning yawn, and
 Went to the bathroom to wash up
 I threw some soap on my face and put my hands up on a cup
annotations.annotation: This was taking directly from the original “La Di Da di”

annotations.text:
And said "Um, mirror mirror, on, the wall
 Who is the top dog of them all?"
annotations.annotation:
An allusion to Snow White (with Snoop casting himself as the Wicked Queen), this line is also taken directly from the original “La Di Da Di”





Like most people, Snoop misremembers the quote from Snow White, which is actually “Magic Mirror, on the wall…”

annotations.text: The mirror said, "You are, you conceited bastard!"
annotations.annotation:
The mirror is telling Snoop that he is the best. In the story of Snow White the queen would ask the mirror “who is the fairest one of all” knowing that she would be the fairest.
Snoop is doing the same thing here, he knows he’s the best but he still wants to mirror to say it. The mirror calls Rick out on it though and calls him a “conceited bastard” meaning
cocky.

annotations.text: Used Oil of Olay 'cause my skin gets pale
annotations.annotation:
The brand name-naming in this section is reminiscent of American Psycho; from Ovid to Snoop Dogg to Easton Ellis, the hygiene poem is a “classic”

Ovid, The Art of Love, Book I Part XIV: “Look Presentable”

Neatness pleases, a body tanned from exercise:
A well fitting and spotless toga’s good:
No stiff shoe-thongs, your buckles free of rust,
No sloppy feet for you, swimming in loose hide:
Don’t mar your neat hair with an evil haircut:
Let an expert hand trim your head and beard.
And no long nails, and make sure they’re dirt-free:
And no hairs please, sprouting from your nostrils.

Snoop went back into his house to retrieve his herbage that he had forgotten to pick up.

annotations.text: Dilly (dally)
annotations.annotation:
A British phrase, meaning “to waste time”

It made more sense coming from Slick Rick – who is English

annotations.text: (Valley)
annotations.annotation: The Valley is a colloquial term used to refer to the San Fernando Valley, a large and massive suburban area directly north of Los Angeles, and includes the cities of Burbank, Glendale, and San Fernando.

annotations.annotation:
Play on the 1963 Japanese hit “Sukiyaki”, soulfully immortalized by A Taste of Honey

This is the part of the song that caused copyright trouble in Slick Rick’s 1985 version, ultimately leading to an edited CD version which omitted the sample. Snoop Dogg, however, has earned the protection of the “Fair Use” defense, since he has made artfully transformative changes (Sukiyaki’s version was not from a dope fiend’s POV)

annotations.text: Here comes your mother with those two little guys
annotations.annotation: She has more children than just Sally, and them being with her makes her later violence all the more powerful. (The later line mentioning “the kids” refers to these little guys, her sons.)

These lines have been slightly changed from the original:

Ricky, Ricky, Ricky, can’t you see
Somehow your words just hypnotize me

However this quatrain would probably make its most famous appearance as the hook of Biggie’s “Hypnotize”

annotations.annotation: I think that a lot of men have a rule: they will not have sex with any woman who is older than their mom (same age ok)

annotations.text: I says I'm 19, she says, "Stop lyin!"
annotations.annotation: Snoop was 22 when this song was released (although he was 19 when he blew up on the West Coast ur-rap “Deep Cover”). I think Snoop just says he’s 19 because that’s the age mentioned in Slick Rick’s version (Slick Rick actually was 19 when his version was recorded). Another possibility is that this all “happened” before Snoop blew up, showing how powerful of an effect on women he really has.

annotations.annotation:
Referring to sex with no condom on. Elektra Records was so concerned about this meaning that they made Dirty record a PSA encouraging safe sex.



Though in an interview he did with Howard Stern the day after he interrupted the Grammies, he stated that “raw” was “war” backwards, meaning that his outlook on life is one of peace.
This is part of why in the beginning of this album, he says that he loves everyone.

annotations.annotation:
Potentially refers to the shimmy, a somewhat suggestive Jazz Age dance which has incorporated itself into club dancing.



In regards to Ol' Dirty Bastard, though, it’s probably just one of many manifestations of him expressing himself rather crazily.

annotations.text: [Produced by RZA]
annotations.annotation:
The off-kilter piano production heard throughout the song was a perfect contrast to ODB’s unhinged drunken master flow. It epitomized the Ol' Dirty Bastard persona in musical terms, a drunken saloon pianist plunking a two-note melody which sampled two songs:


Stevie Wonder’s “Knocks Me Off My Feet”



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RbSZeijqLTc

The Emotions’ “I Like It,” which provides an ungainly, limping breakbeat sound to the beat:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1nWzxt4P_Xk

annotations.text: [Produced by Don Cannon]
annotations.annotation:
This track is the one that brought Don Cannon into the spotlight. In an interview with HipHopDX, Cannon said this about the beat’s influence.


HHDX: Did you find that once you had your first big single, Jeezy’s “Go Crazy,” they were gravitating towards you more?

Cannon: Yeah they are gravitating towards me more but they realize I am not going to give them the same beat that I gave Jeezy. You know I am a producer, I make records and will put my input in but it is all up to the artist. I cant make Lil Scrappy; Lil Scrappy gotta make Lil Scrappy. I can give you the hottest beat in the world, but you have to make yourself.


The soulful beat emphasizes a feel-good, chopped sample of The Impressions‘ “Man, Oh Man (I Want to Go Back)”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V8kEKxwFnkk

This is an allusion to Jay-Z’s opening to his guest verse on Scarface’s “Guess Who’s Back”:

Guess who’s bizzack, you still smell the crack on my clothes
Don’t make me have to relapse on these hoes

https://youtu.be/U6Q1H8CE4-A?t=43

annotations.text:
Like Krispy Kreme, I was cooking them O's (cooking them O's)
 Like horseshoes, I was tossing them O's
annotations.annotation: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, Inc. is an American doughnut company. Krispy Kreme cooks Doughnuts which are shaped like O’s. O’s is also slang for ounces. Horseshoes is a game which you have to throw a horseshoe towards a metal pole in the ground. So Jeezy is Cooking O’s, and tossing them out to buyers.

annotations.text: I'm emotional, I hug the block (ay)
annotations.annotation: An allusion to his childhood block that he grew up in; hugging often meaning a strict attachment to Jeezy’s past

annotations.text: I'm so emotional, I love my Glock
annotations.annotation: Jeezy is quite a fan of his pistol made by Austrian manufacturer Glock.

annotations.text:
Cash rules everything around me, so what's realer?
 About the scrilla, call me a Ghostface Killa (yup)
annotations.annotation: An allusion to the Wu-Tang song “C.R.E.A.M.”; Jeezy agrees with the sentiment of the song (he loves “scrilla” i.e. money) and considers himself a killer with a ghostly face (a play on the name of the rapper Ghostface Killa, a member of Wu-Tang)

annotations.text:
It's kinda hard to be drug-free
 When Georgia Power won't give a nigga lights free
annotations.annotation: Georgia Power is an electric company which operates in Atlanta, Georgia, Jeezy’s hometown. Because electricity costs money, Jeezy has to sell drugs in order to get the money to pay for electricity

annotations.text: Buy 18 the hard way (let's get it)
annotations.annotation: This is a craps metaphor…hard to explain…you’ll figure it out when you are a divorced middle-aged alcoholic living in Vegas

annotations.text:
So I suggest you don't play with my chains
 I'll send these hollows atchya, let em play with ya brain (that's right)
annotations.annotation: Jeezy is warning anyone who might want to take his chains about the possibility of being shot in the head, specifically with a hollow point round.

annotations.text: The product's white, a star is born (yeeaah)
annotations.annotation: White is a street name for crack cocaine. This is the product Jeezy refers to making and selling throughout the song.

annotations.text:
Wrap the work like spandex with the latex (yeah)
 Then we ship it out of town, call it safe sex (ay)
annotations.annotation:
Drug dealers refer to a brick of drugs as “work” since you have to work hard selling it

He’s wrapping up the brick of cocaine in latex – in order to mail it – with the same care and precision that he would use in putting on a condom; it fits the brick like a spandex onesie

annotations.text: More than a relief pitcher, I'm the closer
annotations.annotation:
“Closers” are the best “relief” (ie non-starting) pitchers in baseball. He’s saying that he’s a very good “relief pitcher” i.e. someone who “pitches” (sells) you “relief” (drugs)

“More than a relief pitcher, I’m the closer”

In baseball, a relief pitcher comes into the game to take over the pitching if the starting pitcher gets hurts, gets tired or doesn’t play well. A closer is a pitcher that specializes in, as the position title suggests, closing out games. He is essentially the most valuable relief pitcher on the team

I think the point Jay makes with the relief/closer analogy is that he’s able to “finish the job”, any goals that he sets out to accomplish- he does. The line is about finishing strong whatever you start

annotations.text: The Mariano of the Mariott
annotations.annotation:
Mariano Rivera is a Hall of Fame closing pitcher who played his entire career (1995-2013) for Jigga’s hometown New York Knicks. He is widely regarded among the best closers of all time.

The Marriott hotel near Madison Square Garden in Manhattan is a hub for drug deals, due to its proximity to Port Authority and Penn Station

annotations.text:
See, I'm a hustler's hope, I'm not his pipe dreams
 So when they speak of success, I'm what they might mean
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z was a dope boy himself until he channelled his hustler mentality into success in the music industry

Since Jay-Z went from hustler to millionaire, his type of success seems attainable for other hustlers (i.e., not a pipe dream)

The phrase “pipe dream” is derived from the hallucinations of smokers of opium pipes in the 19th Century; here, it is a double entendre for the crack smokers who the hustler serves

annotations.text: Attract money, my worst color is light green
annotations.annotation:
Jay Z is a successful businessman, and he his currently the richest rapper alive at the moment, with recent investments like tidal, he definitely attracts money.
My worst color is light green means his worst feeling is when his money moves light

annotations.text: My favorite hue is Jay-Z Blue
annotations.annotation:
Having a Personal Patented Blue was pioneered by French modernist Yves Klein.



GMC motors actually modeled a “Jay-Z Blue” Yukon Denali after this line

annotations.text: My bad influence got the world drinking gold bottles
annotations.annotation:
Whatever champagne Jay-Z drinks, the world will follow. Originally everybody drank the famous French champagne Cristal, a trend Jay-Z popularized until the Cristal company’s racist statements disapproving of rappers drinking their champagne made him switch to Armand Champagne, aka “Ace of Spades”

And guess what everybody else started drinking when Jay switched?? Copycats! (Armand comes in a gold bottle)

annotations.text:
When Puff was in that tub spilling Mo'
 I was at my video, Cris' on the speedboat
 In My Lifetime, nigga, go through your research
annotations.annotation:
Hov is presenting evidence that he pioneered the drinking of Cristal in hip-hop, while Puff Daddy was still drinking the cheaper Moët in Biggie videos.

In the video for his 1994 single “In My Lifetime,” Hov is seen drinking Cristal on a speedboat in St. Thomas that he borrowed from his connects.

annotations.text: St. Thomas, my nigga, that was me first
annotations.annotation: Saint Thomas is a popular vacation spot in the Virgin Islands where the “In My Lifetime” video was shot in 1994. Hov had connects on the island, namely Kareem “Biggs” Burke and his family, so the Roc-A-Fella Records crew was able to borrow luxury mansions, boats and vehicles for the opulent video shoot.

annotations.text:
I came feet-first
 In the game like a baby born to breech birth
annotations.annotation: A breech birth occurs when a baby is born bottom or feet first instead of head first. It is a highly risky occurrence for both the baby and mother; just as entering the drug-dealing game is for a young hustler. Hov came into both the drug game and rap game feet first, that is, he was well aware of the consequences either may bring.

annotations.text: The corporate thugs is like "Nah Hov', talk that shit
annotations.annotation: “Corporate Thugz Entertainment”, Jeezy’s record label (apparently they want Hov to continue rapping about the illicit drug trade)

annotations.text: '80s baby
annotations.annotation: This term confuses a lot of people. The term “80s baby” doesn’t mean a person born in the 1980s. It’s a person that was a teenager in the 1980s and experienced the youth culture of the 1980s.

annotations.text: Master of Reaganomics
annotations.annotation: Reaganomics is a term for President Ronald Reagan’s economic policies, but here it is a reference to the popular belief that Reagan’s administration introduced crack cocaine to impoverished black neighborhoods. Jay-Z professes to have been a master of moving crack.

annotations.text: School of Hard Knocks, every day is college
annotations.annotation:
The “School of Hard Knocks” is a classic idiom coined by Elbert Hubbard in 1902. It is used when one believes their [often difficult] life experiences are a form of education that cannot be taught formally.

Hov believes growing up in the Marcy Projects was his strongest form of schooling, where all of the classes happened to be held in the street.

annotations.text:
Nigga pay homage
 Or pay the doctor, I spray Llamas still
annotations.annotation:
Show respect or prepare for gunfire and medical bills. Jiggaman may be be saying one of 2 things or both:
1) I still pull triggers (I’m not entirely above street level) and/or
2) I still use Llama brand pistols specifically: the company filed for bankruptcy in 1992 and were permanently shut down by 2005.

annotations.text: The time'll reveal, you know I'm being honest
annotations.annotation:
Hov makes a Biblical reference here to prove his honesty; as taken from John 3:21:

But whoever lives by the truth comes into the light, so that it may be seen plainly that what they have done has been done in the sight of God.

Hov has told us before he tells no lies in his music. All of this truth-telling about growing up in the Marcy Projects and his life experiences since has brought him into the light, that is, stardom. Hence we have a need for sunglasses, because Jay’s star shines as bright as a trillion watts.

annotations.text: Ya ain’t pull my coat yet and I keep my shit in coat check
annotations.annotation: This bar seems like a nod to the novel and film Get Shorty, where Ray Bones steals Chili Palmer’s coat from coat check. Bones ends up with a broken nose and and a bullet scar on his scalp as a result. Nobody was pulling Chili’s coat after that, just like nobody is going to pull Jay-Z’s coat based on his reputation.

annotations.text: The time'll reveal, you know I'm being honest
annotations.annotation:
Hov makes a Biblical reference here to prove his honesty; as taken from John 3:21:

But whoever lives by the truth comes into the light, so that it may be seen plainly that what they have done has been done in the sight of God.

Hov has told us before he tells no lies in his music. All of this truth-telling about growing up in the Marcy Projects and his life experiences since has brought him into the light, that is, stardom. Hence we have a need for sunglasses, because Jay’s star shines as bright as a trillion watts.

annotations.text: See, don't consider these niggas your friends. I mean, you might not want even to call them associates. I heard y'all after I went down. Like "Dram's done." "You're supposed to do it the right way." What is the right way, nigga? Oh I didn't help the game out? Oh, ok. Kill yourself!
annotations.annotation:
DJ Drama got big producing mixtapes, most notably Dedication 2 for Lil Wayne.  The marketing of these tapes with their unauthorized samples predictably upset the RIAA, who managed to get the police to arrest him

This introductory rant is Drama lashing out at what he believed to be the insufficient amount of support he received from members of the hip-hop game.  Lil Wayne in particular responded strangely to Drama’s arrest, talking about how he needed to “play fair”.  That’s a strange comment for him to make, considering how much he benefited from collaborating with Drama

annotations.text: For all of ya'll I know you're feeling yourself
annotations.annotation: This is the same inflection and rhythm as Slick Rick’s classic line “For all ya’ll, keep ya’ll in health” off of “La di Da di” (which, of course, Snoop turned into “For all my dogs, keep ya’ll in health” into his classic “Lodi Dadi”)

annotations.text: Suicide it's a suicide, suicide it's a suicide
annotations.annotation:
A phrase used so often in rap that it has its own Wikipedia page:

The phrase…was first used by rapper KRS-One on the song “Moshitup” in 1987. It has since entered into hip hop music as a meme, and has been used by artists such as Ice-T, Gravediggaz, Redman, Ras Kass, Jay-Z and Jedi Mind Tricks

(They forgot to mention Snoop Dogg’s “Serial Killer”)

annotations.text:
Through the ups and downs I just try to stay level-headed
I hear a lot of bullshit but I never sweat it
Cause when you ask 'em 'bout it, They goin' say they never said it
They know if it's beef I let the Mac-11 dead it
annotations.annotation:
Let’s work backwards:

1) “If there is beef, I will squash it with my mac-11” therefore:

2) “People will not fess up to talking shit about me, because it will lead to beef” therefore:

3) “I don’t sweat the shit people say about me, because I will never be able to get them to admit they said it anyway.”

I say that if you remove the threat of death, you might be able to engage in some constructive dialogue

annotations.text: And when I spit you could dig it like a shovel said it
annotations.annotation: While he’s saying you’ll dig his lyrics as though his lyrics were made by a shovel (shovels dig), he’s also saying that when he spits bullets with his Mac-11 that you can dig his enemies into the ground

annotations.text: Tell em lay down on the couch baby, I am the shrink
annotations.annotation: Psychiatrists see patients and have them lay on a couch to relax; Fabolous has a similar approach towards helping women with daddy issues, but his tactics are probably not considered ethical by The American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law

annotations.text: Niggas go Tom Cruise crazy for the Katie Holmes
annotations.annotation: Tom Cruise famously went couch jumping crazy in professing his admiration for Katie Holmes on Oprah

annotations.text:
I know niggas living in the Fed
Who say don't look down unless she giving you some head
annotations.annotation:
Guys in jail (or alternatively, Ben Bernanke) will warn you keep your eyes alert for danger…unless a girl is giving you head

Although it seems that getting oral sex would be a time you have to be particularly wary because your guard is especially down, but if you can’t look at the top of a girl’s head mid-fellatio, there’s no point in living anyway

annotations.text:
I gotta be Kobe, you never see niggas like Smush in the paper
Unless he got pushed in the paper
annotations.annotation: Fabolous wants to be the top dog like Kobe Bryant; being a role player like Smush Parker is no way to get recognition (such players only get publicity if they get in altercations after getting bullied on the court)

annotations.text:
So my niggas be on some bullshit, I call them the "Heat sweepers"
They ride around with the street sweepers
annotations.annotation:
Much like the Chicago Bulls, who “swept” (i.e. defeated 4-0) the Miami Heat in the first round of the NBA playoffs in 2007, Fabolous and his crew are “on some BULLshit” (get it?)

They “sweep up the streets” (i.e., kill people) with their “heat” (slang for a gun, in addition to being Miami’s basketball team)

A “street sweeper” is a drive-by shooting style shotgun, such as the Striker-12

annotations.text: Catch me in the kid robot
annotations.annotation: Kid Robot is a somewhat popular and trendy producer of streetware

annotations.text: 5 in the jersey, cause the kid so hot
annotations.annotation: Fabolous is willing to put five bullets into your jersey (Jason Kidd used to play point guard for the New Jersey Nets and wore number 5)

annotations.text:
Similar to Jason, you point at the guard/God
You must got an appointment with God
annotations.annotation:
Jason Kidd is a point guard. If you aim for Fabolous (the God, generic term for “black man” taken from NGE theology), you’re asking for death

Jay-Z had a similar conflation of “guard” and “God” in his verse on Sauce Money’s “Pre-Game”:

Busting off the roof, shooting God/guard like Kobe

annotations.text: Ain't goin' nowhere for a while, you could get a Snicker
annotations.annotation:
Reference to Snickers' Not Going Anywhere for a While campaign.  Fab is boasting that he’s going to be at the top for a while

Fabolous used a similar rhyme in the end of his classic verse on “Forgive Me Father”

And they won’t be goin nowhere for a while
They might as well pull out a snicker

annotations.text: Nigga with mental loss can't forget I been a boss
annotations.annotation:
“My boss-ness leaves such a strong impression that even someone suffering from a brain injury would be hard-pressed to forget it”

A trope in hip hop songs is “person with some type of disability nevertheless perceives something amazing about me through the very sense the disability affects”

annotations.text: Trying me is like bungeeing with dental floss, fucker
annotations.annotation: A strand of dental floss cannot support the weight of a falling human. The floss will likely snap causing the victim to plunge to their death a la suicide.

annotations.text: [Verse 1: Jay-Z]
annotations.annotation:
Jay Z uses the word talking 27 times in this verse.

That’s some classic Jay right there.

annotations.text:
What we talkin' 'bout? Real shit or we talkin' 'bout rhymes?
 You talkin' 'bout millions or you talkin' 'bout mine?
 What we talkin' 'bout? 'Cause I ain't got time

annotations.annotation:
Hova is trying to figure out in this song why everybody disrespects him. Is it just for marketing purposes or do they actually dislike him? Is it because he earns millions with music while other rappers don’t? Just say it, he doesn’t have time to waste.

Don’t waste my breath
I don’t know how many moons a nigga got left

Jay Z has seen old friends – from Dehaven and Jaz O – try to take shots at him, claiming that he stole from them but it’s just fiction. Hova wants #factsonly.

“Pardon my back” is an expression that means that you are walking away and ending the conversation.

annotations.text:
I'm talkin' 'bout life (Life, life)
 And all I hear is, "Oh yeah, he keeps talkin' 'bout crack"
 I ain't talkin' 'bout profit, I'm talkin' 'bout pain
 I'm talkin' 'bout despair, I'm talkin' 'bout shame
annotations.annotation:
When Jay Z raps, he raps about his real life which includes a history of drug dealing. He’s a hood reporter, he gives the news with a twist of its just his ghetto point of view.

If you watch the Charlie Rose interview, Hova explains that he isn’t glorifying crack or drugs like critics claim but rather just putting on wax the details that he’s seen and lived.

I’ve been around it, I grew up in Brooklyn, Marcy projects, its was everywhere…I survived it.


Jay Z

annotations.text:
I ain't talkin' 'bout gossip, I ain't talkin' 'bout Game
 I ain't talkin' 'bout Jimmy, I ain't talkin' 'bout Dame
 I'm talkin' 'bout real shit, them people playin'
annotations.annotation: Hova is tired of getting in petty disputes and tries talking about life, he’s not going to respond to The Game, Jim Jones or Dame Dash, he only wants to focus on real and important subjects.

annotations.text:
What is you talkin' 'bout? I don't know what y'all sayin'
 People keep talkin' 'bout, "Hov, take it back!"
 I'm doin' better than before, why would I do that?
annotations.annotation:
Baller line: everybody criticizing Jay Z for straying from his old style should realize that he’s moved on in life

Same sentiment as previous lines he dropped:

Everybody look at you strange say you changed uhh, like you work that hard to stay the same

Jay is doing better than he was back when he made his first albums, when he had those people in his life; why would he rap about that stuff again? If he wants to keep it real, his subjects have to evolve with time.



This showcases the intricate task for an artist (especially a rapper) to have your audience grow along with you.

annotations.text:
Ain't nothin' cool 'bout carryin' a strap
 'Bout worryin' your moms and buryin' your best cat
 I'm talkin' 'bout revenge while carryin' his casket
annotations.annotation:
It would be foolish of Hov to want to go back to a life where carrying a firearm was a necessity. He escaped his past life and doesn’t wish to return to it. In “December 4th” he explained why he preferred the rap life to the criminal one:

And niggas get tied up for product
And little brothers' ring fingers get cut up
To show mothers they really got em
And this was the stress I lived with till I decided
To try this rap shit for a living

Jay cares a lot about his mom, if you think about hurting her or making her suffer don’t do that, you’re making him nervous:

You could try me fucka but when I squeeze it hurts, fine
We’ll lose two lives, yours and mines
Gimme any amount of time don’t let Ms. Carter grieve
At the funeral parlor drippin' tears on my sleeve

Similar sentiments were expressed in Who Gon Stop Me with the lyric “middle finger to my old life”

annotations.text: All teary-eyed, 'bout to take it to a mattress
annotations.annotation: From The Godfather, “taking it to the mattresses” means getting ready for war between two families. Under a Matress is also often a place where to hide a weapon.

annotations.text:
I'm talkin' 'bout music, I ain't talkin' 'bout rap
 You talkin' 'bout who's hot, I ain't talkin' 'bout that
annotations.annotation: Hov continues to express that he is aiming for the bigger pie (The whole music industry) where there are more pieces to eat and the size is bigger (To go for the whole music industry instead of one specific genre). He in the industry to check for who is popping, he is there to be the best overall.

annotations.text:
The conversation is changed, let's yap about that
 I don't run rap no more, I run the map
annotations.annotation:
Again, Jay Z would like to reiterate that he has moved beyond rap beef and is now too busy plotting geostrategy. He doesn’t run the rap game, he runs New York.



JAY: Why not have your cake and eat it too, dogg? Take a look at the Rap Map – where rap and maps meet

Shots are being fired at the all talk, no action nature the world had fallen in to, thanks largely to online platforms for the free expression and exchange of opinion.

Jay really sold drugs. He really influenced fashion. He really influenced hip hop.

Present day Jay continues to innovate. And he continues to dismiss his opposition’s words.

 Talkin' 'bout what I wear, talkin' 'bout where I be
annotations.annotation:
To be fair, Jay also talks a lot about what he wears

In this case he’s taking a jab at Cam'ron, who dissed him on You Gotta Love it

How’s the king of New York rocking sandals with jeans?
Open toe sandals with chancletas with jeans on
How’s the king of New York rocking sandals with jeans and he 42 years old?

annotations.text: Yeah, check out my hair, these ain't curls, these is peas
annotations.annotation:
This was Jay-Z’s hairstyle while recording Blueprint 3. Part of his ritual is that he grows his hair every time he records a new album



Jay’s also addressing his race here, saying despite the fact that he’s black, he’s very successful.  Different races have different hair types/textures, with white and lighter-skinned people sometimes having curls instead of “peas”.

annotations.text:
Peasey head still get paid, I'm combin' through G's
 Please, we ain't focused on naps
annotations.annotation:
Another line that Jay-Z borrowed. In “Rock Box” Run says

Peasy head and still get paid

People make fun of his hair but he doesn’t really care because no matter what they say, he’ll still earn money instead. Hova is focused on working, not sleeping and taking naps like his competition.

“Naps” also refers to nappy hair, a common hair style in the hood.

annotations.text:
The conversation is changed, let's yap about that
 I don't run rap no more, I run the map
annotations.annotation:
Again, Jay Z would like to reiterate that he has moved beyond rap beef and is now too busy plotting geostrategy. He doesn’t run the rap game, he runs New York.



JAY: Why not have your cake and eat it too, dogg? Take a look at the Rap Map – where rap and maps meet

annotations.text:
A small part of the reason the President is black
 I told him I got him when he hit me on the jack
annotations.annotation:
“Jack” refers to the telephone (phone jack). When Obama decided he was running for President, one of the first people he asked to help raise votes was Jay-Z. In Jay’s interview with Howard Stern in 2012, he talks about this.

‘I got him’ could refer to both help with the youth and financial support, Presidential campaigns are REALLY expensive.

annotations.text:
Talkin' 'bout progress, I ain't lookin' back
 You know I run track, try not to get lapped
annotations.annotation:
No more obvious was his comparison between athleticism and rapping than on “Breathe Easy (Lyrical Exercise)”.

Blueprint 3 is all about moving the genre forward, pushing it in to new and exciting places. This was fresh off Jay’s huge Glastonbury 2008 festival performance, in which he was the first rapper ever to be booked for a headline slot.

Saying he “runs track” just means he raps on the track.

annotations.text: Dame made millions, even Jaz made some scraps
annotations.annotation:
I’ve done made more millionaires than the lotto did
Dame made millions, Biggs made millions
Ye made millions, Just made millions
Lyor made millions, Cam made millions

Dame Dash made lots of money off Roc A Fella Records and Roc A Wear, but the two eventually split. When Jay Z entered the rap game Jaz-O was sort of his mentor, but he didn’t make nearly as much money as Hova did.

annotations.text: He could've made more but he ain't sign his contract
annotations.annotation: Early on in the Roc-A-Fella Records days, Jay and Dame offered Jaz a record deal (reportedly for $150,000 to $300,000), but the offer apparently wasn’t high enough for him so he ditched it.

annotations.text:
Grown men, want me to sit 'em on my lap
 But I don't have a beard and Santa Claus ain't black
 I repeat, you can't sit on my lap
 I don't have a beard, now get off my sack—scream at me!
annotations.annotation:
Everyone asks Hova for stuff, just like kids do when they sit on Santa Claus' lap at the mall



Jay doesn’t get how people think he’ll grant their wishes; Santa isn’t black like him…Or is he?

annotations.text:
They talk, we live
 We see what they say, they say, they say
 I see what y'all talkin' about, ha ha
 They talk, we did
 Who cares what they say, they say, they say?
annotations.annotation:
Shots are being fired at the all talk, no action nature the world had fallen in to, thanks largely to online platforms for the free expression and exchange of opinion.

Jay really sold drugs. He really influenced fashion. He really influenced hip hop.

Present day Jay continues to innovate. And he continues to dismiss his opposition’s words.

annotations.text:
You stuck on being hardcore, I chuck the deuce up
 Peace out
annotations.annotation:
“Chuckin' the deuce” is a term that originated in the Southern part of the United States. It’s what someone does when they’re just passing by, or leaving. People used to say “peace” instead of goodbye, now they just do it with their hand signals.

(cf. Chris Brown’s “Deuces”)



Jay’s moved on from his gangster rap past. Now that he deems it so, it’s “lame” to continue the aggression.

annotations.text: Welcome to the Blue-ah-Print-ah tre-piece, Jay-Z your tutor
annotations.annotation: Jay’s grown now. He killed the throwback 6 years prior. His Presidency at Def Jam required him to wear an expensive and sophisticated three piece suit.

annotations.text:
Moo ya
 Rass clot when rude boy come through with the roof up
annotations.annotation:
“moo-ya ras clot” = move your ass
Basically, “watch out when I come through your neighborhood in my convertible”

(goes with the “beep beep”)

annotations.text:
So I could see the sky
 'Cause everybody talkin' Hov, I think we know why
annotations.annotation:
In relation to the previous line, he rides in drop top cars so he can look at the sky, while everybody’s talking about him he’s busy staring at where he wants to be, the top.

Also, this line’s similar to the one Jay used on the ending of Never Let Me Down by Kanye West :

Hov’s a living legend and I’ll tell you why
Everybody wanna be Hov and Hov’s still alive.

annotations.annotation:
The whole hook indicates the loss of control, and now everything is for the taking. The song  refers to the rap game about to be overthrown and taken over by Roc Nation, but in the video for the song, Jay-Z and Kanye tried to capture the actual falling apart of nations

Kanye says:

I showed Jay some references from the classic rebellious zones of the world. We live in very orderly society in America, but when you get into Brazil, you get into the Middle East, you get into Africa, you get into Eastern Europe, when you get into places like that, there’s a different sort of ‘we run this town’ going on. There’s less order and more chaos.

annotations.text: We are, yeah, I said it: we are
annotations.annotation:
I wanted the whole song to feel like a march, a battle cry. Muhammad Ali had the shortest poem ever: ‘Me: We!’ My statement was ‘We Are!’ Maybe you didn’t hear me? We Are. Yeah I said it. We Are.

This line kind of shifted the perception of power amongst this trio at the time. Most people viewed Hov as the obvious leader, since he’s the mogul that gave Rihanna and Kanye a chance to be successful. But he wants to make it clear that all three of them are equals and should be taken seriously. Obviously both Yeezy and Rihanna have seen massive success since this song came out, but at the time they were almost seen as Jay-Z’s (interesting and talented) sidekicks (Yeezy especially, since this was before MBDTF)

annotations.text:
This is Roc Nation, pledge your allegiance
 Get your fatigues on, all black everything
annotations.annotation:
Roc Nation is like an army and you can show that you’re part of it by wearing the all-black uniform.

This has become a certified Hip Hop meme, appearing in “Murder To Excellence” and even a namesake song by Lupe Fiasco.

After all, Jay said he was a trendsetter.

annotations.text: Black cards, black cars, all black everything
annotations.annotation:
The American Express Black Card, reserved for the richest of the rich. You need to establish a 250K per year spending pattern over several years in order to be approved



Apparently, unlike his protege, Jay doesn’t have a preference between black card and African-American Express…

annotations.text: And our girls are blackbirds ridin' with they Dillingers
annotations.annotation:
This is a clever play on a line from “Public Enemies”, the movie about the famous bank robber John Dillinger.  In the movie, Dillinger’s dying words are to tell his girlfriend “Bye bye blackbird”

Jay-Z is taking the affectionate term blackbird literally: his crew’s girlfriends/wives are all black birds (bird being a term for girl).  He’s using the term as a way of casting himself and his friends as Dillinger-esque gangsters



A Derringer pistol is sometimes referred to as a Dillinger.

annotations.text: I get more in depth if you boys really real enough
annotations.annotation: This is pronounced “in Depp” by Jay-Z to maintain the Dillinger/blackbird metaphor: Johnny Depp played Dillinger in Public Enemies

annotations.text: This is la Familia,
annotations.annotation:
La Familia is the group consisting of Jay-Z, Kanye West, Beyoncè and Rihanna. He’ll rep it later in his career as well.

Yeah, I’m talking Ye, yeah, I’m talking Rih
Yeah, I’m talking B, nigga, I’m talking me

This term, however, originated in Jay’s career from the album The Dynasty: Roc La Familia

annotations.text: I'll explain later
annotations.annotation:
We beat you to it, buddy!

Though he did keep his word, and do so on the song La Familia from Magna Carta Holy Grail.

It’s not the first time he’s pulled that trick either, since he hinted at the Throne’s Welcome to the Jungle on Kanye West’s Power (Remix).

annotations.text: I gave Doug a grip and lost a flip for five stacks
annotations.annotation:
Jay gave then-Universal CEO Doug Morris, now with Sony, $5 million to buy out his contract and start the Roc Nation label.

The ‘lost a flip’ refers to his unusual negotiations with Morris, which included a coin toss to decide certain financial details.

annotations.text:
Back to runnin' circles round niggas, now we squared up
 Hold up
annotations.annotation:
He’s saying he “broke even” (which is what gambling addicts usually tell people when they lost like $5K)

Note the shape wordplay (circles, squares)

annotations.text:
Hear the screams from everywhere (Yeah)
 I'm addicted to the thrill (I'm ready)
 It's a dangerous love affair (What's up? Come on)
 Can't be scared when it goes down
 Got a problem, tell me now (What's up?)
 Only thing that's on my mind (What's up?)
 Is who's gon' run this town tonight (Ah, what's up?)
 Is who's gon' run this town tonight (Yeah, what's up? Yeah)
 We gon' run this town
annotations.annotation:
The whole hook indicates the loss of control, and now everything is for the taking. The song  refers to the rap game about to be overthrown and taken over by Roc Nation, but in the video for the song, Jay-Z and Kanye tried to capture the actual falling apart of nations

Kanye says:

I showed Jay some references from the classic rebellious zones of the world. We live in very orderly society in America, but when you get into Brazil, you get into the Middle East, you get into Africa, you get into Eastern Europe, when you get into places like that, there’s a different sort of ‘we run this town’ going on. There’s less order and more chaos.

annotations.text: You can call me Caesar, in a dark Caesar
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z is the emperor, like the emperors of Russia (which were, in turn, a Russian-language adaptation of the title “Caesar”

A ‘dark ceaser’ is a kind of haircut—a low cut, like Jay wears.

This isn’t the first time that Jay compares himself to Caesar, in 2003’s “Encore,” he quoted his famous “Veni, Vidi, Vinci”:

And I need you to remember one thing (one thing)
I came, I saw, I conquered

annotations.text: Please follow the leader, so Eric B we are
annotations.annotation: Eric B. & Rakim had an album in 1988 called Follow the Leader. Leader refers of course to himself.

annotations.text: Microphone fiend,
annotations.annotation:
Another Eric B & Rakim song

Rakim is often considered one of the best rappers,  (the original rapper to go by the nickname “The Microphone Fiend”) – Jay now likens himself to Rakim, he’s also one of the best.

annotations.text: This the return of the god
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z refers to himself as “Hova,” which is short for “Jay-Hova,” which is a play on “Jehovah,” which is the Hebrew name for God

Also a continuation of the Rakim reference above; Rakim was the first rapper to call himself “Gawd MC” based on his 5%er religious beliefs – Jay-z is returning to the roots of foundational rappers

annotations.text: Peace, God, ah ah, it ain't no nobody fresher
annotations.annotation:
A common greeting among the Five Percenters, also known as the Nations of the Gods and Earths, who teach that the original black man is God.

This line follows the previous two in referencing Rakim, who refers to himself as “God,” as Jay-Z has in the past.

He’s saying peace God because he is trying to show his respects to Rakim as it could be interpreted that by Jay saying this is the return of the God (referencing himself as the God) that he’s taking a shot at Rakim.  Peace God means he is not taking a shot and has respect for him.

annotations.text: I'm in Maison, ah, Martin Margiela
annotations.annotation:
Maison Martin Margiela is a high-end fashion boutique that makes stuff like this:



Jay, however, pronounces it more like “Mason” (The French word “maison” would be pronounced more like “maize-on”), presumably to fuck with the Freemason/Illuminati conspiracy theorists.

The “Ah” is crucial to this line working. It’s supposed to be a misleading line, with “I’m in mason” referencing the theories about his masonic ties, then by slipping in the “ah” he changes the meaning to say he’s actually “in” (Wearing) his clothes.

annotations.text: We got a banquette full of broads, they got a table full of fellas
annotations.annotation:
Banquette – A long upholstered bench placed against or built into a wall.

So basically Jay is teasing some less-baller people in the club: “We have an entire couch section full of ladies, and those guys are all scrunched together at one itty-bitty table”

Similar to Jay’s “Imaginary players” video

Even some people who should know better think that Jay is saying “Bankhead” (the ATL neighborhood) here, which he isn’t.  However, he acknowledges how similar the two words are on “Kingdom Come”, where he gets the ladies “dancing on the banquette/Like they from Bankhead”

annotations.text: They should throw their hand in 'cause they ain't got no spades
annotations.annotation:
This is a double entendre.

On one hand:
Those guys are broke, they should just quit trying in the same way that when you’re out of spades in the game “spades.“  Within the card game, many people have a house rule that if your hand is dealt without any spades, the hand is discarded.

And on the other hand:
They don’t have any Ace of Spades champagne at their table, apparently because they can’t afford it.
Ace of Spades is Jay’s new choice of drink.

annotations.text:
Yeah, my whole team got dough
 So my banquette is lookin' like Millionaires' Row
annotations.annotation:
Everyone in his crew is rich, so when you see them together (sitting at a “banquette” (a classy booth) rather than a lowly table like the other crew), it’s like seeing a street in the fanciest part of town (“millionaires' row”).

Also, there’s the contrast between his crew having “dough” (money) and the other crew having “no cake” two lines earlier.

annotations.text: [Verse 3: Kanye West]
annotations.annotation:
Kanye’s verse, rather than being about cementing his place at the top, is about how it feels to be there, and the good and the bad about it (something he was pondering a lot around the time of this song’s release – hence 808s and Heartbreak).

To help paint the medium for his lyrics, he lets the beat switch out for a bit to a more laid-back, melodic soundscape for the first part of his verse.



On a leaked tape:

I’m pushing the envelope! I wrote my fuckin' ‘Run This Town’ verse for a fuckin' month! When I heard Eminem’s verse on the Drake shit, I went back and rewrote my shit for two days. I canceled appointments to rewrite! I fuckin' care!

annotations.text:
It's crazy how you can go from bein' Joe Blow
 To everybody on your dick; no homo
annotations.annotation:
These opening lines presage a whole verse about what it’s like to become famous quickly, and how Kanye’s taken advantage of the fact that he’s done it.

What happened to the days when you could say things like “so many niggas on my nuts I thought I lost my dick” without having to plead “no homo”?

It’s also worth noting that Kanye is using the “no homo” trope just to set up the no Volvo joke: Kanye is on the record saying that rap is too homophobic and the use of “no homo” in a Kanye verse is completely out of character if not understood as a set-up for the joke.

The phrase “Joe Blow” means a hypothetical average man. So Kanye is simply saying it’s crazy how you can go from being classed as average to being classed as super-star and having everybody on you and buzzing off you which in his terms is “everybody on your dick”. The “no homo” bit was just him adding flair to the bar and setting up the line to rhyme with the next bar.

annotations.text: I bought my whole family whips; no Volvos
annotations.annotation:
Apparently Kanye is not overly concerned with the safety of his loved ones, but he does want them to have fast, expensive cars (“whips”).



Furthermore, Kanye plays on the meaning of “family whips”. Volvos are from Sweden, where they are the stereotypical family car. There’s even a saying: “Volvo, villa, vovve,” meaning “Volvo, house, dog,” implying a very average life.

annotations.text: Next time I’m in church: please, no photos
annotations.annotation: A bit before this song came out Kanye’s mother (Donda West) passed away, and classless paparazzi still tried to snap pics of him while in mourning

annotations.text: Police escorts, everybody passports
annotations.annotation:
The life that successful rappers live allow them to be escorted from place to place by the police – which is a symbol of the status that you’re at when you can hire government workers as personal bodyguards

And not only do they all have passports (since they travel internationally so often) but they’re always passing ports, most likely because they can afford personal yachts and rub it in all of our poor faces

There’s a third layer to this particular line, with Ye inferring that police escorts are necessary for anyone “past sports” i.e. anyone with sportsman levels of fame upwards (to include music and movie figures, dignitaries of various stripes etc.)

annotations.text: What you think I rap for, to push a fuckin' Rav 4?

I can spend my whole life Good Will Hunting
 Only good gon' come is this good when I'm cumming
annotations.annotation:
I could’ve tried to be a good guy my whole life – stayed poor, bought all of my clothes at thrift shops and Goodwill donation shops – but now that I’m rich I’m going to have a lot of sex instead!



Also, if Mr. West had decided to be the “good guy” and not use his abilities like Matt Damon in the film “Good Will Hunting”, he wouldn’t have the cars, money, girls and the shows. Despite that, he still thinks he would be getting it in. Before Will had an intervention, he was wasting his talent, this is not going to happen to Kanye.

annotations.text: And up top, ungh, two bee stings
annotations.annotation:
Small breasts, usually found on skinny girls. Kanye’s girl may have a big booty, but she’s still skinny, the advantage for him of being rich and famous

He may also be referring to bee stung lips, a new trend in fashion and plastic surgery:

annotations.text: And I'm beasting off the Riesling
annotations.annotation:
Quite popular in Central Europe, Riesling is a sweet white wine. Kanye sure likes it.

Kanye may also be comparing the girl from the line above to the shape of a Riesling bottle



This analogy helps explain why white girls like Riesling so much: “it’s sweet! and skinny!…like me!”

annotations.text: And my nigga just made it out the precinct
annotations.annotation: A reference to a friend of Kanye’s getting out of jail, a topic which he revisits in “See Me Now.”

annotations.text: I'm just tryin' to change the color on your mood ring
annotations.annotation: Popular in the 60s and 70s, a mood ring supposedly changed color to reflect the mood of of the person wearing it. This was a hoax – the rings actually changed to reflect the temperature.

annotations.text:
Reebok, baby, you need to try some new things
 Have you ever had shoes without shoe strings?
 "What's that, Ye?" "Baby, these heels"
annotations.annotation:
Kanye’s buying some expensive high heels for a girl who’s only ever worn slummy sneakers for footwear

Ye could also be referring to Margiela sneakers/shoes that often come with no laces.



Also a possible nod to inmates. In prison they remove their strings as a safety measure, hence why Run DMC used to remove the laces in their Adidas

annotations.text: "Is that a May— what?!" "Baby, these wheels"
annotations.annotation:
A Maybach is a very expensive sub-brand of Mercedes that’s popular among rappers:



See Fat Joe’s verse in “Make it Rain” and also Jay-Z in “Allure”

annotations.text:
Yeah, I'm out that Brooklyn, now I'm down in Tribeca
 Right next to De Niro,
annotations.annotation:
Shawn Carter was born and raised in Brooklyn’s Marcy Houses. After overcoming the racial bias and sabotage displayed by the building’s other residents, he purchased his Hudson Street TriBeCa penthouse apartment in 2004. It is still the main New York residence of Jay and wife Beyoncé.

Fellow TriBeCa resident Robert DeNiro has received credit for the neighborhood’s mid-‘90s revitalization. DeNiro is one of the co-founders, and the public face, of the annual Tribeca Film Festival, as well as one of the co-founders of The Tribeca Grill and the production company TriBeCa Productions.

Back in 2012, DeNiro and Jay shared a few unpleasant words (mostly on DeNiro’s part) after he repeatedly failed to call the movie star back, and never delivered on a promise to record a song for the Tribeca Film Festival. DeNiro called him “rude [and] disrespectful,” with Hov replying that the veteran actor hadn’t shown him enough respect:

It doesn’t matter who you are, everybody has to be respectful and everybody has to be a human being, you know? No one’s above manners … We’re all human beings and we all have to be respectful to one another and that’s just standard. That’s how I carry on with anybody.

In February 2016 they re-united publically at the amFAR Gala, signalling their issues had been resolved.



DeNiro also sounds like “dinero,” the Spanish word for money. In his previous career as a drug dealer Hov would follow the money across the city; and later his success in the rap game meant he was able to pay $6.85 million for his penthouse.

annotations.text: But I'll be hood forever
annotations.annotation:
Even though he moved to a fancy area, Jay will never forget where he’s from.



Also, no matter how big and rich he becomes and how much he interacts with DeNiro or his neighbors, he’ll still be considered “hood” by that crowd; he’ll never quite fit in.

annotations.text:
I'm the new Sinatra, and since I made it here
 I can make it anywhere, yeah, they love me everywhere
annotations.annotation:
As Frank Sinatra sang in “New York, New York”

If I can make it there, I can make it anywhere

And as Hova said in The Blueprint, he is

The Sinatra of my day

Just like Frank’s, Jay’s talent isn’t limited to New York City or the United States. He’s a worldwide star.

Also, Frank Sinatra was a son of Italian immigrants, an outsider to the establishment he made it in – just like Jay. Sinatra had alleged ties with the Italian mafia, thus remaining ‘hood forever’, regardless of him being a star. Again, just like Jay.



The genius thing: “New York, New York” was originally written for the Scorsese film New York, New York, a musical starring… Robert DeNiro.

annotations.text:
I used to cop in Harlem–hola, my Dominicanos (Dimelo!)
 Right there up on Broadway, brought me back to that McDonald's
annotations.annotation:
Jay used to “cop” (buy) drugs in Harlem to sell in Brooklyn, where he lived. Back in the day, there were only 2 McDonalds in all of Harlem/Washington Heights, one of which was (and still is) on 145th and Broadway.

That part of the city was the spiritual home of New York’s large Spanish-speaking Dominican population. All the hustlers would meet up in there (before going across the street to Brands – the cheapest/best liquor store in the Tri-state)

annotations.text: Took it to my stash spot, 560 State Street
annotations.annotation:
A “stash spot” is a place to safely store cash and drugs. 560 State Street is a residential building in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. Hov bought apartment 10B in the early-90’s, and lived there with B-High and Ty Ty. The apartment served as a stash spot for him.

Having moved out in 1997, he visited his old apartment with Ron Howard 15 years later for the Made In America documentary. As you can see in the below photo, the Barclays Center, which Hov is an investor in, is now a stones throw away from Hov’s old bachelor pad.

annotations.text: Catch me in the kitchen, like a Simmons whippin' pastry
annotations.annotation:
“In the kitchen” refers to cooking up crack. Another word for crack is “flour”, and flour is the basis for pastry.

Vanessa and Angela Simmons, the twentysomething daughters of Reverend Run of Run-D.M.C., run Pastry, an apparel and shoe brand



“Kitchen” also could be a reference to the Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood on Manhattan’s West side.

Also an umpteenth reference to Russell Simmons, the original Def Jam’s founder and hip hop pioneer, who Jay cites as a mentor, who sold fake crack to fiends before he got rich, as he said in his autobiography.

annotations.text: Cruisin' down 8th Street, off-white Lexus
annotations.annotation:
After “shopping” he’s driving back to Brooklyn via 8th Street in the off-white Lexus “GS 300” that he bought before he had a deal.

Art collector Hov understands the importance of being precise about color.

annotations.text: Drivin' so slow, but BK is from Texas
annotations.annotation:
He’s driving with Beyoncé (Knowles), who is from Houston, TX.  He feels the need to point this out because slowness is associated with Houston-style rap, which is “chopped and screwed”, resulting in a “slow” kind of music.

Also, driving slow aka “Tippin'” is a trend in Houston – it’s considered a way of showing off your fancy rims (while avoiding speeding tickets! Smart..)

annotations.text: Me? I'm out that Bed-Stuy, home of that boy Biggie
annotations.annotation: Jay-Z and his close friend The Notorious B.I.G. were both born and raised in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant.

annotations.text: Now I live on Billboard and I brought my boys with me
annotations.annotation:
Both Billboard charts and actual billboards. Jay Z is famous! (and as a result, so are some his friends)

In June 2010, Jay-Z was featured on a huge 225 x 95 feet Brooklyn Nets billboard right around the corner from Madison Square.



Also, note the alliteration from the previous line: Bed-Stuy, boy, Biggie, Billboard, brought, boys.

annotations.text: Say what up to Ty Ty, still sippin' Mai Tais
annotations.annotation:
Tyran “Ty Ty” Smith is Jay’s right-hand man, who has been working alongside him since the early Roc-A-Fella Records days. He is currently an A&R executive at Roc Nation, an entertainment company he co-founded with Hov in 2008.



Since the ‘90s Hov and Ty Ty have been together, ordering themselves a Mai Tai, which is an alcoholic cocktail based on rum, Curaçao liqueur, orgeat syrup and lime juice.

Can’t stop I, from drinking Mai Tais, with Ty Ty

annotations.text:
Sittin' courtside, Knicks and Nets give me high fives
 Nigga, I be spiked out, I could trip a referee
annotations.annotation:
At the time of recording Jay-Z was a co-owner of the NBA’s Brooklyn Nets, and Brooklyn’s own Spike Lee is known as the quintessential court-side sitter at New York Knicks games. Like Spike, Hov sits so close to the court that he could stick his foot out a little too far and trip a referee.

When you front row at the Knicks game, those the Spike Lees
You front row everywhere, you in the H.O.V.’s

In an interview with Time Out magazine in September 2008, Jay named Spike Lee as one of his favorite New Yorkers, saying:

… because he’s a fixture courtside. When you think about the city, you think of [him.]

annotations.text: [Chorus: Alicia Keys & Jay-Z]
annotations.annotation: In November 2012, Alicia Keys stated that when she recorded the first takes for the chorus, Hov was unhappy with the way that they sounded, as she was battling nasal congestion at the time.

annotations.text:
In New York (Ayy, aha) (Uh, yeah)
 Concrete jungle (Yeah) where dreams are made of
 There's nothin' you can't do (Yeah) (Okay)
 Now you're in New York (Aha, aha, aha) (Uh, yeah)
annotations.annotation:
New York City is commonly known as the “Concrete Jungle” due to the way that the numerous skyscrapers tower over streets like trees in a forest.



The city also represents a central hub on the East Coast for people with aspirations for fame and fortune, where dreams come true… and are made up.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=knnIEY3bmQI

annotations.text: (You welcome, OG)
annotations.annotation:
Yankee Stadium is in Morrissania, a section of the Bronx which is oft nicknamed “The X.” Jay is at the game with his close friend and 40/40 Club co-owner Juan “OG” Perez, who Hov also shouts out in “My 1st Song” and “Success.”

Juan’s wife, Desiree Perez, is a close friend and adviser to Yankee’s controversial player Alex Rodriguez, so it’s no coincidence that Hov is there with him.

annotations.annotation:

Juan’s wife, Desiree Perez, is a close friend and adviser to Yankee’s controversial player Alex Rodriguez, so it’s no coincidence that Hov is there with him.

annotations.text: Shit, I made the Yankee hat more famous than a Yankee can
annotations.annotation:
In the greatest Yankees rap reference of all-time, Jay-Z proclaims that he is a major reason for the high sales of New York Yankees headwear. Since the beginning of his career Hov has proudly worn a Yankees fitted to show support for his favorite MLB team; and his influence has rubbed off on the general public.

This line would come full circle for Hov when he performed the track live at Yankee Stadium prior to the start of Game 2 of the 2009 World Series:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N7HAMsB2FLc
Jay was able to explore the field before his performance, and described the feeling of hearing his music being played there in an interview with ESPN:


I felt like a kid. The field is beautiful. I’ve never been that close to the field. Walking around, I jumped over the center-field fence and everything, like I was catching a home run.

Incredible. Beyond explanation. Just the whole fact, being in Yankee Stadium, really interacting, knowing the players. I grew up a fan of the Yankees – Reggie Jackson, Mickey Rivers, Chris Chambliss, God bless Thurman Munson, all these guys. To be there and interact with all these guys [the current Yankee team], they’re throwing the Roc sign up – it’s fantastic."

annotations.text:
You should know I bleed blue, but I ain't a Crip though
 But I got a gang of niggas walkin' with my clique though
annotations.annotation:
Jay is not a Crip, a LA gang whose color is blue, but he is a Yankee fan, his blood is as blue just like the team logo background.



Blue blood is also an English idiom for nobility, from the Spanish phrase, “sangre azul.” For Jay it’s a way of saying not only that he is noble, but he is considered “rap royalty.”

annotations.text: Welcome to the meltin' pot, corners where we sellin' rock
annotations.annotation:
A “melting pot” is a society in which many different types of people blend together as one. It’s a common metaphor for American immigration, which is often associated with Ellis Island (which is actually in New Jersey, but whatever!). New York City, where people from different backgrounds and cultures live together, is a prime melting pot.



“Rock” in this case is a nickname for crack cocaine. You “cook” powder cocaine to get crack cocaine (this cleverly refers back to the melting pot).

annotations.text: Afrika Bambaataa shit, home of the hip-hop
annotations.annotation:
Afrika Bambaataa ’s 1982 single “Planet Rock” revolutionized New York hip-hop (Afrikaa!)



Kevin Donovan, also known as Afrika Bambaataa, is considered to be one of the originators and founding fathers of Hip Hop. Bambaataa is responsible for spreading and promoting the Hip-Hop culture. Jay-Z is paying homage to one the founders of Hip-Hop. Without Bambaataa, Hip-Hop may not be what it is today.

annotations.text: Yellow cab, gypsy cab, dollar cab, holla back
annotations.annotation:
In New York it’s not all about the subway. If you need a ride there are different options:


The standard, popular yellow cab.
An gypsy cab, which is an illegal, unlicensed taxi.
A dollar cab, one of the illegal, unmarked taxis that used to go around Brooklyn at night, famous for letting as many people as possible on board, even in the trunk!





“Holla back” could be a reference to a line from the song “N.Y.C.” in the Broadway musical Annie:

Enough of cab drivers answering back

Jay’s “Hard Knock Life” references the same musical.

annotations.text: Eight million stories out there in the naked
annotations.annotation:
The Naked City is a gritty late 1940s film noir about crime in New York City. Jay’s line is a reference to a line from the movie, in which the narrator says “There are eight million stories in the Naked City; this has been one of them”.



This line also brings us back to Jay’s track “Never Change” from The Blueprint, as well as alluding to the first bar of Kurtis Blow’s “8 Million Stories” and A Tribe Called Quest’s track and line on their 1993 album Midnight Marauders.

As of 2010, the US Census Bureau estimated New York City to have a population of approximately 8.175 million people. “8 million stories” alludes to the idea that every NYC resident has a different story, background, life, etc.  All of this contributes to the allure and character of NYC.

annotations.text:
City, it's a pity half of y'all won't make it
 Me? I gotta plug Special Ed, "I Got It Made"
annotations.annotation:
While many New Yorkers die or fade into the slums, Jay Z “made it”.

Special Ed was a fellow Brooklyn rapper who rapped about what it meant to “make it” in his best known song, “I Got It Made”, released on his 1989 album Youngest in Charge when he was just 16.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MYUPmiT-Yzw

“It’s a pity” is also how Large Professor continues his “8 Million stories in the city” line on ATCQ’s “Keep It Rollin'.”

annotations.text: If Jeezy's payin' LeBron, I'm payin' Dwyane Wade
annotations.annotation:
JAY-Z flips the hook of Jeezy’s 2009 song “24-23”:

See I used to pay Kobe, but now I pay Lebron
Kobe, Lebron, Kobe, Lebron

Jeezy uses Kobe and Lebron’s jersey numbers from the 2009-2010 NBA season (24 and 23) as an analogy for the drug game—he used to pay $24,000 for a kilo of cocaine, but now he only shells out $23,000.

So while Jeezy bragged about paying $23,000 for a kilo of cocaine, Jay takes this a step further, claiming that he can get a kilo of coke for Dwyane Wade’s jersey number, which is 3.

annotations.text: Three dice cee-lo, three-card Marley
annotations.annotation:
Continuing with the references including the number 3, Hova refers to two street games:



Cee-lo is a popular ghetto dice game, referenced in many rap songs, including  Nas' “N.Y. State of Mind”







A play on 3-card Monte, the gambling hustle you see played in the blocks.

annotations.text: Labor Day Parade—rest in peace, Bob Marley
annotations.annotation: There is an annual West Indian Carnival in Crown Heights, Brooklyn on Labor Day weekend that includes a parade. Jay pays homage to the West Indian residents in Brooklyn, and shouts out the musical leader of the region, Bob Marley.  It continues his theme of paying respect to those who created the cultural hub that New York has become.

annotations.text: Statue of Liberty, long live the World Trade
annotations.annotation: Referencing the horrific attacks on the World Trade Center on September 11th, 2001, where 2 planes were hijacked and flown right into the 2 buildings causing both of the towers to collapse killing around 3000 people.

annotations.text: Long live the king, yo—
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z, ever the Loyalist, still refuses to accept the events of the American Revolution more than 200 years after.

Actually referring to The Notorious B.I.G. (who didn’t live that long, sadly), who was Jay Z’s mentor and high school friend.

annotations.text: I'm from the Empire State, that's
annotations.annotation: New York’s slogan is “The Empire State.”

annotations.annotation: In November 2012, Alicia Keys stated that when she recorded the first takes for the chorus, Hov was unhappy with the way that they sounded, as she was battling nasal congestion at the time.

The city also represents a central hub on the East Coast for people with aspirations for fame and fortune, where dreams come true… and are made up.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=knnIEY3bmQI

annotations.text: (Welcome to the bright lights, baby)
annotations.annotation: Manhattan is known for its glowing evening skyline, which is a central image in the Jay “no-Z” McInerney novel Bright Lights, Big City, a novel celebrating the excesses of financially well-off young people in the mid-1980s.

annotations.text: Lights is blinding, girls need blinders
annotations.annotation: The “bright lights” of New York blind – and at the same time attract – all the pretty girls. They need to wear blinders (put on racehorses so that they are not distracted in a race) and walk in a straight line, ignoring all the fancies

annotations.text:
So they can step out of bounds quick, the side lines is
 Lined with casualties who sip the life casually
 Then gradually become worse –
annotations.annotation:
Starting from this line, Jigga describes chasing wealth and status using the language of addiction.

Even though they try to stay away from their surrounding, the characters here become seduced by the capitalist lifestyle and end up “addicted to the limelight”. The references to MDMA and Ambien in the last two verses only amps up that addiction discourse.

annotations.text: Don't bite the apple, Eve!
annotations.annotation: In the Bible, the “apple” represented temptation, drawing Eve to sin. Similarly, the “Big Apple” (New York) turns perfectly nice young ladies into materialistic girls.

annotations.text:
Caught up in the in-crowd, now you're in-style
 Into the winter gets cold, en vogue with your skin out
annotations.annotation:
At this point, the girl has been completely absorbed by the city. Even though New York is pretty cold in the winter, she still wants to show off her body with fashionable (or en vogue, in French) dresses.

InStyle is a fashion magazine and Jay makes “and in the winter” sound like “Anna Wintour gets cold in Vogue with your skin out”, referring to Anna Wintour, the Editor-in-Chief of Vogue magazine, which shows how much the girl focuses on style and appearance before morals.

annotations.text: Good girls gone bad, the city's filled with them
annotations.annotation:
A self-referential quotation from “Song Cry”:

They say, “You can’t turn a bad girl good
But once a good girl’s gone bad, she’s gone forever”

New York is filled with girls that tried to build a career in the fashion or modelling business but never succeeded.

annotations.text:
Mami, took a bus trip, now she got her bust out
 Everybody ride her, just like a bus route
annotations.annotation:
A very lyrical way of telling an age-old story: girl came to the city and had no money (“bust out”) so she became a prostitute  (or at least very promiscuous) who everybody “rides”.

Breasts are referred to as a “bust” because it comes from the name for a statue of the head and shoulders of somebody.

annotations.text: "Hail Mary" to the city, you're a virgin
annotations.annotation:
Play on the virginal status of Mary, the mother of Jesus, who was born without sin (with the suggestion that moving to the city will corrupt you); Jay Z “hails” (celebrates) the city’s darker elements.

One could also interpret “Hail Mary” as a last ditch attempt at success (i.e. a Hail Mary pass in football). In other words, a “Hail Mary to the city” could refer to the theme of coming to New York as an attempt for success despite the danger and risk that lies there.

annotations.text: And Jesus can't save you, life starts when the church end
annotations.annotation:
This line can be read in two ways:


The idea of Church, Christianity especially, is that the purpose of living is following the rules in order to get to heaven. In Jay’s eyes, this is the next world, you should set your own rules. New York is a concrete jungle, there’s No Church in the Wild.
Jay meant that real life (even Christianity) starts when you get out of the walls of your house or of a church and you have to overcome the problems you face.

annotations.text: MDMA got you feelin' like a champion
annotations.annotation: “MDMA” = 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (aka Ecstasy, the “party drug”)

annotations.text: The city never sleeps, better slip you a Ambien
annotations.annotation:
Another callback to Sinatra’s “New York, New York”

I want to wake up in the city that doesn’t sleep

Ambien is a powerful sleeping pill, essential for an outsider to get some rest in the city that never sleeps, if they aren’t used to the 24 hour nature of the environment.

Media scapegoat who they can be mad at today
See, it's as easy as cake, simple as whistlin' "Dixie"
While I'm wavin' the pistol at sixty Christians against me
Go to war with the Mormons, take a bath with the Catholics
In holy water, no wonder they tried to hold me under longer
I'm a motherfuckin' spiteful, delightful eyeful
The new Ice Cube, motherfuckers hate to like you
What did I do? (Huh?), I'm just a kid from the gutter
Makin' his butter off these bloodsuckers, 'cause I'm a motherfuckin'

[Chorus: Eminem & JAY-Z]
Renegade, never been afraid to say
What's on my mind at any given time of day
'Cause I'm a renegade
Never been afraid to talk about anything
(Anything?), anything (Anything)
Renegade, never been afraid to say
What's on my mind at any given time of day
'Cause I'm a renegade
Never been afraid to holler about anything
(Anything?), anything (Anything)
Renegade, never been afraid to say
What's on my mind at any given time of day
'Cause I'm a renegade

(Anything?), anything (Anything)
Renegade, never been afraid to say
What's on my mind at any given time of day
'Cause I'm a renegade
