(Anything?), anything (Anything)

annotations.text:
Motherfuckers say that I'm foolish, I only talk about jewels (Bling-bling)
 Do you fools listen to music or do you just skim through it?
annotations.annotation:
All I know about music is that not many people ever really hear it. And even then, on the rare occasions when something opens within, and the music enters, what we mainly hear, or hear corroborated, are personal, private, vanishing evocations.

Jay-Z’s opening “Renegade” lines reflect the themes of the above, found in James Baldwin’s 1957 devastating short story, “Sonny’s Blues.”  In a situation similar to the drug-addicted “Sonny” in Baldwin’s piece, it is only through music that Jay is able to externalize his pain, confront his past, and muse on his current situation.

A topic of discussion that has been present throughout Jay’s career is how this street-smart emotional vulnerability has not always registered with, or been appreciated by, critics and listeners. Here Hov openly lambastes those in that category, suggesting that they are only superficially listening to his discography—judging it solely off tracks such as “Big Pimpin'” and “Money, Cash, Hoes;” while ignoring introspective cuts such as “Where I’m From,” “You Must Love Me” and “This Life Forever.”

In his 2010 autobiography Decoded Jay pointed out the target of these lines:

This is directed at critics who only listen to songs that fulfill their preconceived notions-the ‘bling bling’ in the background summarizes their usual complaint about my music.

annotations.text: See, I'm influenced by the ghetto you ruined
annotations.annotation:
JAY-Z references his humble origins in Brooklyn, New York, where he grew up in a rundown neighborhood. Jay specifically alludes to gentrification in his hometown, which damages the community present and directly affected Jay’s family.

Jay famously grew up poor and was forced to sell drugs to provide a stable income. In an interview with GQ magazine, Jay described growing up in the ghetto and the hardships he faced:

It’s like crabs in a barrel. You’ve seen crabs trying to get out of the barrel? They pull each other down, trying to get up. They just grabbing at whatever they can. People are at the point where they’re ready to do anything so it’s very dangerous. And you’re living in close quarters so you have to deal with danger every day, from every angle.

In addition, Jay references his 1999 track, “So Ghetto,” which also delved into his hood origins and being a “gangster.”

annotations.text: The same dude you gave nothin', I made somethin' doin'
annotations.annotation:
Jigga feels he was disadvantaged from the beginning, and unassisted by any authoritative power. Against the odds, and with no help, he has still risen

Additionally, the next line, “What I do, through and through” should be read as a continuation of the last part of this line, so that if it were prose, it would be:

I made something [of myself, of hip-hop] doing what I do through and through.

The prose version emphasizes the value Jay-Z places on artistic integrity, which is something he repeatedly talks about in his music and his book. It also sets up a syncopated and prosaic flow of enjambment  to give the verse a feeling prosaic sentences instead of lines (e.g. “The block where they / pop toasters”).

If he’s going to do art, he’s going to do it “through and through,” his own way; as he says, “the secret of long-term success is the freedom just to be yourself,” and no one gave him that freedom. He took it.

The flow in the actual version is great because it emphasizes “doing” – (“B.I.G. I did it!”). In DECODED, Jay-Z repeatedly talks about how much he respects “doing” – work ethic (“Honor Among Predators,” etc.).

annotations.text:
What I do through and through and
 I give you the news with a twist, it's just his ghetto point of view
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z explains what goes on in the hood as well as a news reporter does. However, the news reporter says this from the outside looking in, but Jay-Z can give the perspective of someone who has lived that.

In Decoded Hova gives his own explanation to this line saying

This is one of the things that make me – and all serious rappers – renegades. When we report the news, it doesn’t sound the same as when you hear it from CNN. Most of us come from communities where people were just supposed to stay in their corners quietly, live and die without disturbing the master narrative of American society. Simply speaking our truths, which flew in the face of the American myth, made us rebels.

annotations.text:
The renegade, you been afraid I penetrate pop culture
 Bring 'em a lot closer to the block where they pop toasters
annotations.annotation:
JAY-Z discusses his pop appeal and success on the mainstream charts. As of 2019, he has placed 100 songs in the BillBoard Hot 100 charts and four number one hits, with three of them appearing as features on “pop tracks.” Over the course of his career, Jay has collaborated with the likes of Rihanna, Alicia Keys, Beyonce, and Mariah Carrey, which has given him a chance to embrace mainstream music and accumulate more money.

At his peak, JAY-Z was so popular that he became as mainstream as the biggest pop stars of that time, furthering his pop appeal. His accessible music allowed for him to reach the top of the music industry, while also allowing him to remain true to himself and his origins.

Jay’s music illuminates the issue that people are facing in the ghetto and offer insight into the perspective of someone who experienced traumatic hardships while growing up. He frequently discusses his drug dealing past and gang activity, which includes the process of firing a weapon.

annotations.text: And they live with they moms, got dropped roadsters
annotations.annotation:
Another harsh reality of hood life, many people “live with they moms” because their fathers abandon their families.

The choice of the phrase “pop toasters” is clever as the insinuation to “shoot guns” can be interpreted to follow “shoot pops”, a play on the phrase “Moms and Pops”.

The two thoughts on hood live could be said to be juxtaposed for a reason; Jigga says they live with their Moms, not both parents or just their Dad, which means that these guys that usually cause turmoil in the hood are more than likely lacking a father figure in their lives to guide them. Hov is essentially blaming the behavior of the guys that pop toasters on the fact that they didn’t have fathers growing up. A vicious cycle.

Reaching even further, the fact that these toaster-popping people live with their Moms could be an implication of their youth, perhaps 14-21 years old (but driving $100,000 cars in the next line…)

annotations.text: From botched robberies, niggas crouched over
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z is saying they (being him and people from the hood) brought fancy convertibles with the the money they got from botched robberies, which while successful in acquiring goods and paper usually resulted in people getting shot or killed (“crouched over”).



Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying; “The image of niggas "crouched over” is meant to show the other side of the usual street story – what happens when shit goes bad, the gun gets dropped, and you’re the one on your knee."

annotations.text:
Mami's knocked up 'cause she wasn't watched over
 Knocked down by some clown
 When child support knocked, "No, he's not around"
annotations.annotation:
In the first line, he’s using “mommy” or “mami” as he often does for a general term for a female. In this case probably a young teen. Saying that the reason she was impregnated or “knocked up” is because her parents didn’t watch over her (or couldn’t), and were not around (i.e. mom working lots of hours, father absent or incarcerated). So as a result the young lady had sex behind her parents' backs.

“Knocked down” after being “knocked up” because getting pregnant was a misfortune rather than a joyous event as it is in middle-class families. The mother is left to raise the child by herself like many other inner-city women

This section can also be a reflection on Jay’s childhood. His father (who he says numerous times he doesn’t want to be like) knocked up his mother because she didn’t have someone looking out for her. That clown reference is to his father who left Jay as a child with his mother to raise by herself with no child support payments.

Sidenote: Jay-Z in Decoded explains a part of this line saying; “Again I’m talking about the flipside of the Money, Cash, Hoes” type songs. Sex can knock you up and knock you down."

annotations.text:
Now, how that sound to ya? Jot it down
 I bring you through the ghetto without ridin' 'round
 Hidin' down, duckin' strays from frustrated youths stuck in they ways
annotations.annotation:
JAY-Z’s music comes with an inherent truth attached and offers a vivid glimpse into live in an impoverished neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York. Jay’s music illuminates the issue that people are facing in the ghetto and offer insight into the perspective of someone who experienced traumatic hardships while growing up. He frequently discusses his drug dealing past and gang activity, which includes the process of firing a weapon.

Jay approaches these lines as if they’re an interview and provides the outsider with a chance to experience what he’s been through. JAY typically allows others to look at life through his perspective and attempts to demonstrate what actually occurs in the ghetto. On his September 1998 track, “Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem),” the chorus portrays the difficulties the children face:

It’s the hard knock life for us
It’s the hard knock life for us
Instead of treated, we get tricked
Instead of kisses, we get kicked
It’s the hard knock life!

In particular, these lines discuss the psychological effects that poverty and gang violence have on impressionable kids. JAY-Z reasons that these kids are often a product of the environment they are in, as opposed to being malignant psychopaths.

annotations.text:
Just read a magazine that fucked up my day
 How you rate music that thugs with nothin' relate to it?
annotations.annotation:
How can the critics rate his music when they haven’t even been through what he’s been through? Critics aren’t in the right position to write about his work- he raps for “thugs with nothing”, people growing up in the same situation as him, and for those who understand him.

Eminem was engaged in a very public beef with The Source at the time, and whilst Jay was being embraced by the culture and reviewers, this is a show of solidarity to his guest.

annotations.text: I help them see they way through it, not you
annotations.annotation:
Through his music, he helps people on the daily grind survive by the gritty truth in his music, instead of the average Joe who’s never experienced a day of hardship in their life.

In Decoded Jay explains this line saying; “Magazines, even hip hop magazines, would reduce a song to a rating, a number of mics or stars or some other system. But I always wondered how they could try to pin down and attach a rating to music that was really helping people understand their own lives. I always thought that critics should factor the truthfulness of the thyme. Truth is a constraint. It’s easy to make up a complete fantasy in a song. Trying to rhyme and be witty and tell a coherent story or talk about a coherent concept and stick to something true about life is difficult. But it’s that element of truth that makes the songs deeper than just entertainment, that make the music a light that can help people see their way through a hard life.”

annotations.text:
Can't step in my pants, can't walk in my shoes
 Bet everything you worth, you'll lose your tie and your shirt
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z’s music helps ghetto kids to get through their tough lives, not critics' album reviews and articles. Critics could never do what Jay does

The “tie and your shirt” reference is another dig at critics' disconnect from the ghetto as they sit in their office buildings, and it revitalizes the otherwise banal “lose your shirt.” But it also means that this is all their worth – their “tie and shirt,” their appearance. They’ve got nothing else to contribute to the world, while Jay-Z (as said in the last line) helps kids survive the ghetto life through his music.

In Decoded jay explains this line saying; “This is meant both literally and figuratively – the critic. I’m imagining here is a suit and tie sort of guy who literally doesn’t dress like me. But he also can’t wear the life I’ve worn, and if he tried to step in my shoes, walked the stressed I’d walked, he’d lose that tie and shirt, not just his clothes but that smug attitude they represent.”

annotations.text: [Verse 2: Eminem]
annotations.annotation:
This song spawned the phrase of “renegading” someone. It was popularized by Nas – in “Ether”:

And Eminem murdered you on your own shit

That even though the song was for Jay-Z’s album, Eminem destroyed him on it or “renegaded” him. To be renegaded is when you feature someone on your track and they completely outclass you.

In an interview with Rosenberg Radio Jay Z admitted that Eminem had the better verse. His defense was in the essence that every dog has its day and that he has had the better verse on the majority of his songs. Blaming Nas for the phenomena that people wonders who murdered who before the record is already released and debate afterward who bodied who –  instead of just enjoying the song. He also admitted it in “A Star Is Born”:

His flow on Renegade, fucking awesome
Applaud him

Numerous artists, critics and fans have praised Eminems verses on this song – including Talib Kweli who called this his “3rd favorite Hip Hop verse of all time”.

The verse is exceptional as said by various artists and this rhyme scheme highlights the complexity of the verse.



In 2014 Eminem rapped this verse over Jay’s “Run This Town” at the “The Monster Tour”:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lXjOs9dBgoI

Andre Gainer from Lyricology 101 deconstructs the rhyme schemes, flows and performance in the verse:
https://youtu.be/_EIefzGnk3I?t=2m38s

annotations.text:
Since I'm in a position to talk to these kids and they listen
 I ain't no politician, but I'll kick it with 'em a minute
annotations.annotation: Eminem often jokes about the role he plays towards children, and mocks the parents who see him as a ‘menace’ but are ultimately powerless against his influence–especially expressed in his song “White America”. He’s taking a more serious stance here.

annotations.text:
'Cause see, they call me a menace and if the shoe fits, I'll wear it
 But if it don't, then y'all'll swallow the truth, grin and bear it
annotations.annotation:
Eminem alludes to the negative reception that surrounds his music and the constant criticism he receives for obscene themes and topics. Em has faced a wide variety of critics throughout his career  for a variety of reasons but most famously for his questionable subject matter. In particular, Em’s February 1999 album The Slim Shady LP" was extremely controversial for pushing the limits on taboo themes and attempting to distance himself from the conventional ideologies.

Em’s music is considered negative due to his tendency to incite violence, promote misogyny, encourage domestic abuse, and advertise excessive drug consumption.

Eminem reasons that he is wrongfully portrayed as a “bad person” in the media and that people are incorrectly assigning blame to him that he doesn’t deserve. Em previously attempted to prove that he wasn’t a inspirational figure on his February 1999 track, “Role Model,” where he described his various flaws:

Now, follow me and do exactly what you see
Don’t you wanna grow up to be just like me?
I slap women and eat shrooms, then OD
Now, don’t you want to grow up to be just like me?

annotations.text: But there's a huge interference, they're sayin' you shouldn't hear it
annotations.annotation: Refers to the censorship of his lyrics on the radio and MTV, and protests against his supposed homophobia and misogyny. Examples are when gay rights groups didn’t want Eminem to participate in the Grammy’s, and when he was stopped at the Canadian border for some of his hateful lyrics, such as this line.

annotations.text:
But I'm debated, disputed, hated and viewed in America
 As a motherfuckin' drug addict, like you didn't experiment?
annotations.annotation:
Instead of listening to Em’s lyrics and deciding whether his music is good, moralizing parents and politicians just label him as a drug addict.

When this song was written/recorded, the parents of most teenagers were baby boomers who grew up in the weed-addled 60’s and 70’s. Eminem is pointing out the hypocrisy of parents branding him a drug addict, even though it’s very likely they themselves experimented with drugs at some point in those pre-Reagan counter-cultural years.

annotations.text: You fuckin' do-gooders, too bad you couldn't do good at marriage (Haha)
annotations.annotation:
Eminem takes a shot at parents taking a moral high-ground towards him and his music, when a lot of them are probably part of a troubled marriage, which is negatively impacting on their children more than he is.

Also, upon close inspection the pure technical brilliance of this verse emerges; Em has been using multi-compound syllable rhyming of 5 syllables consistently since his third line (“shoes fits I’ll wear it”). Try going through the verse and counting all the times he uses words that rhyme with “shoe” and you’ll realize that almost the entire verse is comprised of internal rhymes and other poetic devices.  For example:

truth – grin – and – bear – it
lu – cra – tive – lyr – ics
who – could – in – her – it…

A true rap genius.

Also notice the “o” assonance in the verse. It already starts way back in the beginning of the verse, at “if the shoe fits”, and doesn’t stop until the end of the verse.

You fucking do-gooders, too bad you couldn’t do good at marriage
And do you have any clue what I had to do to get here

annotations.text: 'Cause here we go, he's Jigga-Jur-Jigga-Jih-Jigga
annotations.annotation:
If you are familiar with the the original—Bad Meets Evil's—"Renegade," you know this line is a replacement. Originally, the track being Eminem’s and Royce Da 5'9"’s, Eminem rapped:

‘Cause here we go; he’s Royce, he’s the King of Detroit

When JAY-Z’s version for The Blueprint was created, with JAY-Z versus Royce, this line was out of place. Therefore, Eminem introduced JAY-Z by his nickname, Jigga, all with a onomatopoetic flourish reminiscent of Eminem’s “My Name Is.”

Em later reused this sound in the beginning of his feature verse on Logic’s 2019 single “Homicide,” in which he raps:

Jigga-jigga-jigga-jigga-jigga like JAY-Z
Jig is up, you fuckers who didn’t write anything

annotations.text: And I'm the sinister Mr. Kiss-My-Ass is just a
annotations.annotation:
Telling people to kiss his ass is a common command in Eminem songs. See these lyrics from Still Don’t Give a Fuck or The Real Slim Shady.

Sinister in archaic terms also refers to left-sided/handed people, which Em is. In common folk mythology, the left was associated with the Devil, which Shady could definitely pass off as.

annotations.text:
Renegade, never been afraid to say
 What's on my mind at any given time of day
annotations.annotation:
After hearing songs like “Kim”, it’s not hard to believe that this is true about Em.

Eminem also criticizes society with this line. If you express yourself in the way you feel, don’t bite your tongue, just speak your mind you’re setting yourself apart from the others and you’re a renegade.

annotations.text:
'Cause I'm a renegade
 Never been afraid to talk about anything
 (Anything?), anything (Anything)
 Renegade, never been afraid to say
 What's on my mind at any given time of day
 'Cause I'm a renegade
annotations.annotation:
JAY–Z and Eminem have no qualms rapping about anything, no matter how offensive—they are “renegades“ in the sense that their songs veer from conventional themes and reject mainstream appeal.

Jay gave insight into the song’s premise in his book Decoded:

Eminem produced this song and came up with the concept, which was to attack the mistaken perceptions people had of him.

In the year prior to this song’s release, Hov and Em had dropped songs that drew criticism for being offensive. Jay’s “Big Pimpin'“ copped heat for its racy lyrics, while Em was heavily criticized for the violent subject matter on The Marshall Mathers LP.

The ad-libbed “Anything?” is an allusion to Jay’s 1999 track of the same name, which samples a song from the 1968 Oliver Twist musical:

Yes I’d do anything (Anything?)
Anything for you

Jay and Em are like the Artful Dodger—they are devoted and would do and say anything. The Artful Dodger grew up on the streets and had to make his own way, much like Hov and Eminem.

annotations.text: Never been afraid to holler about anything
annotations.annotation: When Em says his part of the hook he says “never been afraid to talk about anything”. Jay says holler instead, showing that despite the fact they had some similarities growing up, they had different upbringings. Jay grew up in the hood, where holler would be used as a greeting to others. Eminem grew up in a poor part of Detroit, but even he wouldn’t describe it as the hood, and there would be less sayings like holler.

annotations.text:
I had to hustle, my back to the wall, ashy knuckles
 Pockets filled with a lotta lint, not a cent
annotations.annotation:
A portrait of a harsh life as a poor black kid in the projects. Black skin becomes “ashy” or white, when it gets dry and damaged during cold winter weather. It is also a double entendre meaning Jay is “white knuckling”, because his “back [is] to the wall”.

Too bad young Jay-Z didn’t have any shea butter!

The “My back to the wall” part can be interpreted in two different ways:


It gives you an image of his “back to the wall”, waiting on the blocks for customers.
His back was to the wall, meaning that he didn’t have a cent in his pocket, as he repeats in the next line.



“Pockets filled with a lot of lint” could also potentially be a reference  to Rakim’s line in Paid in Full.

annotations.text: Gotta vent, lotta innocent lives lost on the project bench
annotations.annotation:
Benches are where drug dealers congregate in the projects, and hence where much of the violence happens

Also, Jay plays off the last line: “not a cent… lot of innocent lives lost…” Innocent can be interpreted as in/no/cent, meaning these people dying on the project bench are in the state of having “no cent(s);” they are “in-no-cent;” they are poor.

annotations.text:
What you hollerin'? Gotta pay rent, bring dollars in
 By the bodega, iron under my coat, feelin' braver
annotations.annotation: That’s what life is like living in an area such as Bedford–Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, also known as “Bed-Stuy”, which is where Hov grew up. By “iron under my coat”, Hov is conveying that with a pistol under his coat he felt braver and even safer, due to the volatile environment in which he lived. When he was 12-years-old, he even shot his older brother in a shoulder after his brother attempted to steal his jewellery to subsidise his crack addiction.

annotations.text: Durag wrappin' my waves up, pockets full of hope
annotations.annotation:
He’s got a durag on his head and pockets full of drugs

“Hope” = drugs has a double meaning:


A drug brings hope to an addict by sating his desire
Selling drugs was Jay’s hope for financial independence



Nice improvement from his pockets “full of lint” at the beginning of the verse



Jay-Z in Decoded explains this line saying, “It’s when you take the hustler down a notch that you can start to relate to him, even if it’s still complicated. The pocket that was once filled with lint is now filled with "hope” – which is what the crack is to this kid. It’s contraband to the law and poisonous salvation to the crackhead, but to the hustler, it’s a way out."

annotations.text:
An orphan, my pops left me
 And often my mama wasn't home
 Could not stress to me, I wasn't grown
annotations.annotation:
As a kid, Jay lived in the tough Brooklyn projects and was raised by his mother, a single parent, who wasn’t capable of supporting everyone.

For a 2010 The Guardian profile piece, Hov said he was forced to be the man of the family at a young age to support everyone:

Even when I was making terrible decisions, I was making them out of desperation rather than ignorance. I felt I was in a survival of the fittest situation.

annotations.text: 'Specially on nights I brought somethin' home to quiet the stomach rumblings
annotations.annotation:
His mother definitely wouldn’t be able to tell him he was too young on nights when he made money and could bring home some food.

Jay-Z confirmed this in Decoded saying:

Of course, my mother didn’t want me on the streets, but it was hard to argue with a young kid who’s actually contributing to a household that’s stretched thin, even if he’s into some dangerous shit to do it.

annotations.text:
My demeanor thirty years my senior
 My childhood didn't mean much, only raisin' green up
annotations.annotation:
Because of this lack of parental supervision and his selling drugs at a young age, Jay-Z was very precocious: his childhood wasn’t a childhood since it was all about making money – he acted 30 years older than he actually was

If that’s still true, then Jay-Z now acts like he’s – if you’ll allow me to do the calculation here, just one moment…like he’s 74 years old

“Raising green up” is a double entendre: it could stand for getting money, or it could stand for the drugs that Jay peddled in his childhood (raising green = growing weed).

annotations.text: Raisin' my fingers to critics
annotations.annotation:
Probably the middle one to say “fuck you critics”, to be precise



He could also be raising his index finger as if to say, “I’m number one,” to taunt those who doubted him.



In Decoded Jay explains this line saying; “After so much of the song is about stripping the life of any sense of glamour and pointing out the real life of the kid i the ghetto, I turn it around to a defiant, triumphant note with this series of raises: raising green up (making money), raising my middle finger to the critics who don’t get it, and raising my face to the sky to talk to my nigga Big.”

annotations.text:
Raisin' my head to the sky
 Big, I did it, multi before I die
annotations.annotation:
‘Raising my head to the sky’ is a reference to The Notorious B.I.G.’s single “Sky’s the Limit”. Telling The Notorious B.I.G. up in heaven that he made it and went multi-platinum and is a multi-millionaire many times over.

This is a fulfillment of Jay’s own prediction on the Puff Daddy song “Young G’s” in which he said:

I hated algebra but I loved to multiply
And I told my nigga Big I’d be multi before I die
And it’s gon' happen, whether rapping or clapping, have it your way
‘Cause if that’s my dough you’re trapping, I’m clapping your way

annotations.text: I drove by the fork in the road and went straight
annotations.annotation:
Jay explains this line in Decoded noting, “I love this concept: Instead of being forced into a fucked up choice where you lose either way, choose your own path. The fork in the road I was presented with was either having those pockets full of lint, of pockets full of dope. I went straight stopped selling drugs but I also didn’t accept the false choice between poverty and breaking the law. I found my own way through and with my music, I try to help others see their way through it, too.”

In his former life he had 2 choices – be poor, or deal drugs (risky!). He avoided being poor and avoided the usual consequences of dealing drugs (jail, death) by getting out early enough and becoming a successful rapper. By going straight, he “chose my own fate” and made his own path in the road.

Note the pun on the phrase “going straight” (meaning a former criminal who starts obeying the law)

To quote Yankees star Yogi Berra (and/or poet Robert Frost):

If you see a fork in the road, take it!

Also, Jay-Z pays homage to Cappadonna’s “Slang Editorial”

annotations.text: [Verse 4: Eminem]
annotations.annotation:
Considered by many to be his best verse of all time, this final section of the song deals with the complications of critics and the media, and how he just doesn’t care what they say.

“See it’s a matter of taste/we the people decide if shadys as bad they say he is”–Eminem raps, saying the people decide if he’s any good.

The final stanzas of this verse contain many religious symbols and outright shots at Christians, Catholics, and Mormons. All in all, this verse has insane flow and an amazing message overall–noted by Nas and even Jay-Z himself!

annotations.text:
See, I'm a poet to some, a regular modern-day Shakespeare
 Jesus Christ, the king of these Latter-day Saints here
 To shatter the picture in which of that as they paint me as
 A monger of hate, satanist, scatter-brained atheist
annotations.annotation:
Em refers to himself as a modern day poet who, like Jesus, influences millions of young people around the globe.

Since he’s portrayed as the sacrilegious problem to the youth by media, Marshall uses this verse to “shatter” that picture by mocking religious critics, both Christian and Mormon (Latter-day Saints).

Here, he sets up some contradictory statements about himself, both calling back to his criticism of his detractors as hypocrites and setting up his further discussion of people’s contradictory opinions. Generally, an atheist doesn’t believe in supernatural beings, such as God or the devil, so an atheistic satanist is oxymoronic. However, the use of scatter-brained, in addition to keeping the rhyme with Latter-day, acknowledges that Em’s thoughts aren’t the result of carefully considered doctrines of belief, so he could be both at the same time, a sentiment he similarly addressed much later in his career.

Like William Shakespeare, Em wrote a twisted version of “Romeo and Juliet” – the main difference – he murders Juliet.

annotations.text:
We as a people decide if Shady's as bad as they say he is
 Or is he the latter, a gateway to escape?
annotations.annotation:
Since Slim Shady is a whole other person than Eminem, Eminem belongs to “we as a people”. We – society, including Eminem – can judge the alter-ego Slim Shady.

Eminem channels the “We the People” philosophy of direct democracy because representative democracy wasn’t working out for him:

“When you hear the words about raping your mother or killing your mother, I think that the industry should be embarrassed that that’s award-winning entertainment” – Congresswoman Barbara Cubin, (R-Wy.)

Rep. Cubin is refering to the lyrics from “Kill You”:

Shut up slut, you’re causing too much chaos
Just bend over and take it like a slut, OK Ma?
‘Oh, now he’s raping his own mother, abusing a whore,
snorting coke, and we gave him the Rolling Stone cover?

The funny part is – in these lyrics – Eminem is satirizing his critics!!!! (I guess Barbara missed the joke..)

But the best part about this whole line (and the entire idea) is that Slim Shady does not exist. He is the fictional altar ego of Eminem. Therefore, if people (ie. critics, parents, etc.) take him seriously, his influence is just that much greater. But if they realize that what he is saying isn’t real, and take his words with a grain as salt, people wouldn’t view as bad as they do now.

It’s worth adding that in context it means it’s up to us to decide if he’s hurting the youth like “they” say he is, or if he’s really helping the youth by breaking down racial barriers and showing a productive outlet for anger and other feelings through art.

‘Latter’ is also a homophone of ‘ladder’, as he could the latter mentioned option, or he could be ‘the ladder’, a way to escape possibly from a hole one has been forced into.

annotations.text: Media scapegoat who they can be mad at today
annotations.annotation:
“Scapegoat” is a term used when someone or something is blamed for the wrongdoings and issues in the world, despite it not being their fault.

He is saying how he feels the media blames him for problems going on in the world like homophobia and violence, when he isn’t the cause of these issues.

It is easier to put the blame on one person for all the bad things going on than look at the topic as a whole and finding the real root of the issue.

“Scapegoat” is a term that comes from the Bible:

But the goat, on which the lot fell to be the scapegoat, shall be presented alive before the LORD, to make an atonement with him, and to let him go for a scapegoat into the wilderness.
Leviticus 16:10

The use of this word further ties in the religious wordplay and imagery he uses in the rest of this verse.

annotations.text: While I'm wavin' the pistol at sixty Christians against me
annotations.annotation: Eminem’s anti-Christian remarks fueled “Christian rapper” KJ-52’s song “Dear Slim”, modeled after Em’s “Stan”. KJ-52’s song was actually written because KJ was a huge fan of Eminem and wanted him to change his ways.

annotations.text: Go to war with the Mormons,
annotations.annotation: Mormons are people who practice Mormonism, or the doctrine of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints – one of the most conservative branches of Christianity. Mormonism is a religious and cultural movement sparked in the 1820’s. They emphasize standards they believe were taught by Christ. Mormons would look at Shady with disgust. But he doesn’t care, he’d “go to war” with them.

annotations.text:
Take a bath with the Catholics
 In holy water, no wonder they tried to hold me under longer
annotations.annotation: Catholics people baptize their babies and the “baptism” nowadays consists of the priest pouring a little cup of holy water over the head of the baby. At Jesus Christ’s times people were baptized being fully immerged in holy water and Em is saying that Catholics, pretending that they’re baptising him, would try to drown him by keeping his head under water.

annotations.text:
I'm a motherfuckin' spiteful, delightful eyeful
 The new Ice Cube, motherfuckers hate to like you
annotations.annotation:
Eminem references California legend Ice Cube and his May 1990 track, “The Nigga You Love To Hate”:

Now, who do ya love to hate?
Cause I talk shit and down the eight-ball ‘cause I don’t fake
You’re begging I fall off
The crossover, might as well cut them balls off

Both tracks focus on similar concepts, as they each discuss their unjust portrayal in the media and use as a “scapegoat” for troubled children. Em reasons that people love to blame him for their problems, when he is not the primary causation for the issues they face.

annotations.text:
Renegade, never been afraid to say
 What's on my mind at any given time of day
annotations.annotation:
After hearing songs like “Kim”, it’s not hard to believe that this is true about Em.

Eminem also criticizes society with this line. If you express yourself in the way you feel, don’t bite your tongue, just speak your mind you’re setting yourself apart from the others and you’re a renegade.

annotations.text:
'Cause I'm a renegade
 Never been afraid to talk about anything
 (Anything?), anything (Anything)
 Renegade, never been afraid to say
 What's on my mind at any given time of day
 'Cause I'm a renegade
annotations.annotation:
JAY–Z and Eminem have no qualms rapping about anything, no matter how offensive—they are “renegades“ in the sense that their songs veer from conventional themes and reject mainstream appeal.

Jay gave insight into the song’s premise in his book Decoded:

Eminem produced this song and came up with the concept, which was to attack the mistaken perceptions people had of him.

In the year prior to this song’s release, Hov and Em had dropped songs that drew criticism for being offensive. Jay’s “Big Pimpin'“ copped heat for its racy lyrics, while Em was heavily criticized for the violent subject matter on The Marshall Mathers LP.

The ad-libbed “Anything?” is an allusion to Jay’s 1999 track of the same name, which samples a song from the 1968 Oliver Twist musical:

Yes I’d do anything (Anything?)
Anything for you

Jay and Em are like the Artful Dodger—they are devoted and would do and say anything. The Artful Dodger grew up on the streets and had to make his own way, much like Hov and Eminem.

annotations.text: Never been afraid to holler about anything
annotations.annotation: When Em says his part of the hook he says “never been afraid to talk about anything”. Jay says holler instead, showing that despite the fact they had some similarities growing up, they had different upbringings. Jay grew up in the hood, where holler would be used as a greeting to others. Eminem grew up in a poor part of Detroit, but even he wouldn’t describe it as the hood, and there would be less sayings like holler.

annotations.annotation:

annotations.text:
Now, who's hot, who not?
 Tell me who rock, who sell out in the stores?
 You tell me who flopped, who copped the blue drop?
 Whose jewels got rocks?
 Who's mostly Dolce down to the tube sock?
annotations.annotation:
From 1994-2002, 20/25 of the albums released under Bad Boy Records sold a million units or more. That means they had plenty of money to buy drop-top convertibles, chains, and Dolce & Gabbana clothing



This is one of the most memorable flows of all time

Drake also quoted these famous Ma$e bars in “Worst Behavior”.

annotations.text:
The same old pimp, Mase
 You know ain't nothing change but my limp
annotations.annotation: Money hasn’t changed Mase as a person, but it has raised his confidence/changed the way he carries himself…and his name, going from “Murder Mase” to just “Mase” after signing to Bad Boy Records. His limp has changed because he was carrying more money  than ever before in his pocket due to his level of fame in the rap game.

annotations.text: Can't stop till I see my name on a blimp
annotations.annotation:
Mase won’t stop grinding until his name is everywhere, even on a blimp!

A reference to Ice Cube’s 1992 classic “It Was a Good Day”

Even saw the lights of the Goodyear Blimp
And it read “Ice Cube’s a Pimp”



This reference was itself a callback to a famous scene in the 1983 film Scarface in which Tony Montana looks out on the TWA blimp:

annotations.text: Guarantee a million sales, call it love or luck
annotations.annotation: That was actually an understatement. Mase’s debut album Harlem World sold 4 million copies worldwide. Way to level up for Mase who just two years before dropped out of college to pursue a rap career.

annotations.text: You don't believe in Harlem World, nigga, double up
annotations.annotation:
Mase’s debut album was Harlem World



Double up is a gambling strategy, which ties into the next line about laying a bet down. He is telling his doubter to double their bet against him, so he will win twice as much money since he can’t be stopped.

Double Up would also be the name of his second album. If you didn’t like the first album or thought it was a fluke, wait til you hear the new one.

annotations.text: We don't play around, it's a bet, lay it down
annotations.annotation:
Double entendre!


Ma$e and crew are always serious and you can bet they aren’t messing around. If you mess with them, they’ll ‘lay you down’ in your coffin.
‘Lay it down’ is a reference to betting in casino games. Ma$e doesn’t play for fun, but rather for cash. To place a bet in a casino, you have to lay your cash down. Also “lay it down” as in recording a verse

annotations.text: Niggas didn't know me '91, bet they know me now
annotations.annotation: This a reference to the fact Ma$e had been rapping since 1991 under the name Murder Mase, but his popularity was limited until his affiliation with Bad Boy in 1996 drove him to international superstardom.

annotations.text: I'm the young Harlem nigga with the Goldie sound
annotations.annotation:
Ma$e compares his music to “Goldie,” the main character in the 1973 blaxploitation film The Mack.



Goldie was a pimp known for his flashy style, smooth demeanor, and slick talk. This lyric connects to the “true pimp niggas” line later in Ma$e’s verse.

It’s likely that this line inspired young Harlem rapper A$AP Rocky to name his debut single “Goldie.”

Ma$e referenced Goldie again on his 1999 song “If You Wanna Party”:

Young kid’ll live by Goldie advices
Pimp hoes that come across so righteous

annotations.text: Can't no Ph.D. niggas hold me down
annotations.annotation:
Ph.D. here means playa hater’s degree.

To emphasize his point, Mase appeared on Puff Daddy’s “Can’t Nobody Hold Me Down”

annotations.text: Cudda schooled me to the game, now I know my duty
annotations.annotation:
Refers to Fo'Reel Entertainment CEO Cudda (pronounced “Cooter”) Love, Mase’s former manager, and the man who brought Mase back out of retirement

Cooter’s education in crack-dealing actually leads to JOBS, which is more than you can say about the college education provided by some professors who got a Ph.d. (which, of course, Mase claimed on “Can’t Nobody Hold Me Down” actually stands for “playa hater’s degree”)

annotations.text:
Stay humble, stay low, blow like Hootie
 True pimp niggas spend no dough on the booty
annotations.annotation:
This cryptic line was finally explained by Darius Rucker, the lead singer for the 1990s band Hootie & the Blowfish. True players don’t have to pay for sex:

We were at the Grammys, and some really hot girl walks by. One of [Biggie’s] boys was like, ‘I’ll pay her,’ just as a joke. I go. ‘Man, I’m not paying for it.’ We laughed and then his next record, he’s got a line that goes. ‘Stay humble, stay low, blow like Hootie/True pimp niggas spend no dough on the booty.’ Great line.

annotations.text: And then you yell, "There go Mase!", there go your cutie
annotations.annotation: Mase is saying he’ll steal your girlfriend and you’ll be left scratching your head.

annotations.text:
I don't know what they want from me
 It's like the more money we come across
 The more problems we see
annotations.annotation:
This song popularized the phrase “more money, more problems,” but the idea was already common, perhaps inspired by the famous Biblical proverb “the love of money is the root of all evil.” (1 Timothy 6:10)

In 1984, a newly famous Madonna made a similar observation in an interview with Record Mirror magazine:

The more money you have the more problems you have. I went from making no money to making comparatively a lot and all I’ve had is problems. Life was simpler when I had no money, when I just barely survived

In 1996, 2Pac rapped on “Hold Ya Head”:

And mo' money mean litigatin', mo' playa hatin'

It’s likely that the “Mo' Money, Mo' Problems” chorus, sung by Kelly Price, was written by the song’s co-producer, Stevie J., perhaps with Puffy’s involvement. This trio—Price, Puffy, and Stevie J—also worked together on SWV’s 1997 hit “Can We.”

The phrase “mo' money” had become very popular thanks to the 1992 Damon Wayans comedy Mo' Money. AZ and Nas' 1995 song “Mo' Money, Mo' Murder, Mo' Homicide” may have also been an influence on the song’s title.

annotations.text: I'm the D to the A to the D-D-Y
annotations.annotation:
Put it together and you get “Daddy”. And that’s who he his, Puff Daddy.



Puff Daddy’s birth name is “Sean Combs”. And Puff Daddy isn’t his only pseudonyme. He also goes by the name of “P. Diddy”, “Sean”, “Puffy” and lately most of the time people call him just “Diddy”.

annotations.text:
I call all the shots, rip all the spots
 Rock all the rocks, cop all the drops
annotations.annotation:
Puff is one of the biggest shot-callers in the music business, as the head of Bad Boy Records.


“rip the spots” = rock the stage at concert venues
“rock the rocks” = wear diamonds
“cop the drops” = buy drop-top convertible cars

annotations.text: I know you thinking now, "When all the ballin' stops?"
annotations.annotation:
By the time this song was released in 1997, Diddy, Biggie, and the rest of the Bad Boy crew had dropped hit after hit. The Notorious B.I.G. had released his successful singles “Juicy” and “Big Poppa” in August of ‘94, Craig Mack dropped “Flava In Ya Ear” in June of the same year, and only about a month earlier, Diddy released his collaboration with Ma$e, “Can’t Nobody Hold Me Down,” which peaked at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100.

This succession of dominance over the rap game would lead Bad Boy’s rivals, which included those on the West Coast who they had been feuding with, to have negative feelings towards them. Biggie’s former friend turned mortal enemy, 2Pac had died in 1996 a year before this album came out and tensions were high, but nevertheless Bad Boy stayed on top.

annotations.text: Nigga never home, gotta call me on the yacht
annotations.annotation:
Owning a yacht with a cellular phone was a major flex when this was recorded in 1996. Puff really did spend a lot of time on the water—in 1998, he did the entire interview for an Observer article over his yacht phone.

In his 2017 Genius Level interview, DJ Premier remembered how outlandish Puff’s boat phone seemed back then:

I remember Puff calling, like, ‘Yo, here’s all my numbers—my house phone, my cell phone, my car phone, my boat phone.’ And we said, ‘He got a boat phone??’ We was like, ‘Puff is huge!!’

Puffy and Biggie famously filmed the “Hypotize” video aboard a yacht in Malibu, CA.

annotations.text: Ten years from now we'll still be on top
annotations.annotation: This turned out to be quite prescient.

annotations.text: Yo, I thought I told you that we won't stop
annotations.annotation: “We won’t stop.” is a commonly used phrase by Diddy. It can be heard during many of his famous verses.

annotations.text:
Now what you gon' do with a crew
 That got money much longer than yours
 And a team much stronger than yours?
annotations.annotation: How are you going to mess with Bad Boy Records when they not only have more money than you but they’re stronger in the lyrics department as well? The odds don’t seem to be in your favor.

annotations.text: Violate me, this'll be your day, we don't play
annotations.annotation: If you disrespect Puffy, this will be the day you die. His crew are serious and not playing games, they will murder you if you cross them.

annotations.text: Mess around, be D.O.A., be on your way
annotations.annotation: DOA = Dead on Arrival, so he’ll kill anyone that think he’s messing around. Might be an empty threat but…

annotations.text: Deal with many women but treat dimes fair
annotations.annotation:
Puff is saying that even if you meet and sleep with a lot of women, treat the best looking ones very well.

A dime is a 10 cent peace or slang for an attractive women like a 10/10

annotations.text: And I'm bigger than the city lights down in Times Square
annotations.annotation: The city lights in Times Square have been replaced with wall-to-wall LCD screens and a pedestrian mall.

annotations.text:
I don't know what they want from me
 It's like the more money we come across
 The more problems we see
annotations.annotation:
This song popularized the phrase “more money, more problems,” but the idea was already common, perhaps inspired by the famous Biblical proverb “the love of money is the root of all evil.” (1 Timothy 6:10)

In 1984, a newly famous Madonna made a similar observation in an interview with Record Mirror magazine:

The more money you have the more problems you have. I went from making no money to making comparatively a lot and all I’ve had is problems. Life was simpler when I had no money, when I just barely survived

In 1996, 2Pac rapped on “Hold Ya Head”:

And mo' money mean litigatin', mo' playa hatin'

It’s likely that the “Mo' Money, Mo' Problems” chorus, sung by Kelly Price, was written by the song’s co-producer, Stevie J., perhaps with Puffy’s involvement. This trio—Price, Puffy, and Stevie J—also worked together on SWV’s 1997 hit “Can We.”

The phrase “mo' money” had become very popular thanks to the 1992 Damon Wayans comedy Mo' Money. AZ and Nas' 1995 song “Mo' Money, Mo' Murder, Mo' Homicide” may have also been an influence on the song’s title.

annotations.text: [Verse 3: Notorious B.I.G.]
annotations.annotation:
Allegedly at the time Puffy and Stevie J produced the song Puffy wanted himself, Ma$e and Biggie to be on it, representing the Bad Boy Family in the hopes it would become their signature song.
When asked how the track was made by XXL Stevie J said:

Ma$e came to me in the studio one day with this “I’m Coming Out” sample. He’s like, “When you gonna use this right here? Either my album, Puff album or Big album?” So we laid the track first but nobody knew who was gonna get it. And then when Big came with the “B-I-G P-O-P-P-A!” What!? That was Big’s joint. Everybody felt that.

annotations.text:
B-I-G P-O-P-P-A
 No info for the DEA
annotations.annotation:
In brief: Biggie is Big Poppa; he would never snitch to the D.E.A. (Drug Enforcement Agency)

Perhaps the leanest couplet in all rap

annotations.text: Federal agents mad ‘cause I'm flagrant
annotations.annotation: He is “flagrant” in his disobeyance of the law (by rapping about his criminal behaviour and making conspicuously expensive purchases)

annotations.text: My team supreme, stay clean
annotations.annotation: Supreme Team was a famous and highly respected drug operation in Brooklyn, led by Kenneth “Supreme” McGriff. Supreme Team “stayed clean” in two ways: 1) Their appearances, i.e cars, clothes, jewelry, haircuts, shoes etc. and 2) They managed to maintain clean criminal records for a relatively long time, given how much crime they committed. Biggie is claiming Supreme Team, and its reputation, as his own here.

annotations.text: Triple beam lyrical dream, I be that
annotations.annotation:
A broke drug dealer who went on to become a succesful rapper, Big is the epitome of the rags to riches story. JAY-Z, and others, followed in Big’s footsteps in this respect.



Triple beam refers to the scale used for measuring quantities of chemicals or street drugs accurately.

annotations.text:
Cat you see at all events bent
 Gats in holsters, girls on shoulders
annotations.annotation: B.I.G. is the dude you see at all the parties where him or the people at the event high/strapped with girls on their shoulders getting a good view of B.I.G.’s show

annotations.text:
Playboy, I told ya, mere mics to me
 Bruise too much, I lose too much
annotations.annotation:
“Mere Mics to Me” is Biggie saying that it’s only about making music for him. It’s a mic: not a gun, or a sword, or any tool for making war. He uses the term “Playboy”, a term of endearment, before offering an olive branch. Ask yourself: who could be the “Playboy” he’s talking to here?

In the same vein, “Bruise too much, I lose too much” is Biggie’s way of saying that he gains nothing by fighting and going to war (think East Coast/West Coast beef). He’s come so far in his career, and he doesn’t have to fight now.

These lines, and indeed Biggie’s entire verse in this song, indicate a desire to move into the next realm: the realm where he wouldn’t have to look over his shoulder for a DEA agent, or a rival, or someone repping the West Coast looking to shoot him. It is indeed sad to think that he was killed before he could truly enjoy the life his genius had wrought for him.

annotations.text:
Step on stage, the girls boo too much
 I guess it's ‘cause you run with lame dudes too much
annotations.annotation:
It would be impossible to prove, but Biggie might be referring to an incident at the 1995 Source awards.

“With his chest puffed out, Suge took the stage to accept his label’s award for best soundtrack, for Above the Rim. Giving a stink eye to the audience, he digressed, throwing a pointed barb at Sean "Puffy” Combs, the head of Bad Boy, Biggie Smalls’s label. Alluding to Puffy’s tendency to insert himself in his performers' works, Suge said: “Any artist out there wanna be an artist, and wanna stay a star, and don’t have to worry about the executive producer trying to be all in the videos, all on the records, dancing—come to Death Row. The venue erupted in boos.”

https://www.vice.com/en/article/gqkqz3/tupac-biggie-friends-to-foes

annotations.text:
Me lose my touch? Never that!
 If I did, ain't no problem to get the gat
annotations.annotation: Even though Biggie doesn’t have to show off his “hard” side to command respect, he could do it in a heartbeat if one were to ever challenge him on it (by literally bringing out the big guns–“the gat”–he demonstrates that he is the true player at the top of his game… and he was!)

annotations.text:
Where the true players at? Throw your Rolies in the sky
 Wave 'em side to side and keep your hands high
annotations.annotation:
“Rollies” are Rolex watches.  This is a decadent variant of the traditional rap concert instruction for the audience to throw their hands in the air.

Big had a thing for Rolexes.

annotations.text:
While I give your girl the eye, player, please
 Lyrically, niggas see B.I.G be flossin’
annotations.annotation: Biggie is eyefucking the shit out of your girl

annotations.text: Jig on the cover of Fortune, 5-double-O
annotations.annotation:
Biggie is imagining himself on the cover of Fortune magazine, looking jiggy (stylishly dressed) of course.

Sadly, Biggie never made it to the Fortune 500 (although Jay-Z did in 2005!)

annotations.text: Here's my phone number, your man ain't got to know
annotations.annotation:
He transitions from his “five-double-oh” Fortune 500 reference to his night club phone number dialogue (as if “five-double-oh” were the last digits of his phone number, get it?)

annotations.text:
I got the dough, got the flow down pizat
 Platinum plus like thizat
 Dangerous on trizacks, leave your ass flizat
annotations.annotation:
He’s paid, has a good flow, a platinum AMEX, and will still knock that ass out if he needs to.

“Platinum plus” may also refer to his album and record sales. When this track was released on July 11, 1997, Biggie’s first album, Ready to Die, had been certified double platinum, denoting more than 2,000,000 sales, and two of his singles had been certified platinum, denoting 1,000,000 sales: Warning on May 23, 1995, and Hypnotize on June 11, 1997, although the latter was after this track was recorded as Biggie had died in March of that year. (See RIAA’s Gold and Platinum Program, the official source, for all of these figures).

Minus the decorative “-izzles”, the line is easier to follow:

I got the dough, got the flow down pat
Platinum plus like that
Dangerous on tracks
Leave your ass flat

But not as good, huh?

annotations.text:
I don't know what they want from me
 It's like the more money we come across
 The more problems we see
annotations.annotation:
This song popularized the phrase “more money, more problems,” but the idea was already common, perhaps inspired by the famous Biblical proverb “the love of money is the root of all evil.” (1 Timothy 6:10)

In 1984, a newly famous Madonna made a similar observation in an interview with Record Mirror magazine:

The more money you have the more problems you have. I went from making no money to making comparatively a lot and all I’ve had is problems. Life was simpler when I had no money, when I just barely survived

In 1996, 2Pac rapped on “Hold Ya Head”:

And mo' money mean litigatin', mo' playa hatin'

It’s likely that the “Mo' Money, Mo' Problems” chorus, sung by Kelly Price, was written by the song’s co-producer, Stevie J., perhaps with Puffy’s involvement. This trio—Price, Puffy, and Stevie J—also worked together on SWV’s 1997 hit “Can We.”

The phrase “mo' money” had become very popular thanks to the 1992 Damon Wayans comedy Mo' Money. AZ and Nas' 1995 song “Mo' Money, Mo' Murder, Mo' Homicide” may have also been an influence on the song’s title.

annotations.text: Chorus
We fly high, no lie (You hear that?), you know this (Let’s ride... Ballin'!)
annotations.annotation: To ball is to be flashy. Be rich. Buying whatever you want, driving whatever you want, living the rich and holly-wood life.

annotations.text: (We in the building)
annotations.annotation:
An announcement like “I have arrived”

This is nowhere near as popular a meme as “Ballin!”, although rappers definitely say it frequently. Lil Boosie recorded a song called “We in the Building” in 2008.

annotations.text: (Ballin'!)
annotations.annotation:
Jones claims to have taken this ad-lib from 2Pac. Anyone know any Pac songs where he says this?

https://youtu.be/2q2WJG0WdOI?t=364

annotations.text: Eight fly rides just to drive in my garage
annotations.annotation: Jim wants to variety of “fly” (nice) “rides” (cars) to choose from

annotations.text: (Choose one!)
annotations.annotation: In the next verse, Jim develops the “choose one” theme into a meditation on vanitas – enjoy your choices now, because you only have “one chance” in life

annotations.text: G4 Flights
annotations.annotation: A G4 is a luxary corporate/private jet selling for $40 million or more. The “G” stands for ‘Gulfstream’ and it is the fourth version of the series.

annotations.text: So we lean with it, pop with it (Bankhead)
annotations.annotation:
“Lean with it, pop with it” seems based on “Lean Wit It, Rock Wit It" by Dem Franchize Boys, who hail from Bankhead, a neighborhood on the west side of Atlanta.



And “I think she like me” a few lines down seems to be based on another Franchize Boys song, “I Think They Like Me”.

annotations.text: 'Vertible Jones, mean with the top missin'
annotations.annotation:
“‘Vertible” is short for convertible, but Jim seems to be playing on the act of self-invention involved in living the life of a baller: “keeping up with the Joneses”, so to speak

The “Joneses” in “keeping up with the Joneses” refers to the New York socialite family of celebrated auteur Edith Wharton (née Jones), a dame who was always down to ball

annotations.text: Flossin'!
annotations.annotation: “Flossing” (Fr. “frimer”) is a synonym for “balling”, although it focuses more on the conspicuous consumptive aspect and less on the required attitude

annotations.text: I'm sittin' clean with the bottom kitted (Do it!)
annotations.annotation: A “body kit” is a collection of exterior modifications to a car, which are purchased as a package. Usually, the desired effect is to make the body look like it is sitting lower

annotations.text: Mami on stage doin' the rain dance
annotations.annotation:
To “make it rain” is to toss dollar bills at strippers en masse; the activity was popularized by the masterpiece song “Make it Rain”

Here, the stripper is making the men make it rain, taken by Jones literally to form a pun on the Indian pow-wow activity (intended to make the gods make it rain)

annotations.text: So we lean with it, pop with it (Bankhead)
annotations.annotation:
“Lean with it, pop with it” seems based on “Lean Wit It, Rock Wit It" by Dem Franchize Boys, who hail from Bankhead, a neighborhood on the west side of Atlanta.



And “I think she like me” a few lines down seems to be based on another Franchize Boys song, “I Think They Like Me”.

annotations.text: Hundred G's worth of ice on the Audemars (Flossy!)
annotations.annotation: Audemars Piguet is a Swiss luxury watch brand; Jim has Audemars studded with diamonds.

annotations.text: While I switch gears, bitch lookin' at the bracelet
annotations.annotation: Imagine Jim on a date, carefully timing his gear-shift in order to entrap the young lady’s stare (“got em!”)

annotations.text: Flashbacks to last night of me ballin' out
annotations.annotation: The next couple of lines go over just how under the influence he was last night, so his memories are few. Still, he’s sure he was ballin' out.

annotations.text: (Harlem!)
annotations.annotation: Considering that this song seemed destined from its inception to be a huge hit in the Meatpacking District, the Uptown shoutout seems insincere

annotations.text: 1 AM, we was at the club (What happened?)
annotations.annotation:
This whole section that follows is an interpolation of a song from Jim’s sometimes-enemy Jay-Z. On Jay’s “Do It Again (Put Ya Hands Up)”, the chorus details a night out hour by hour:

12 AM on the way to the club
1 AM DJ made it erupt
2 AM now I’m getting with her
3 AM now I’m splitting with her
4 AM at the Waffle House
5 AM now we at my house
6 AM I be digging her out
6:15 I be kicking her out
7 AM I'ma call my friends
12AM we gonna do it again, we gon, we gon, we gonna do it again

annotations.text: (Money ain't a thing)
annotations.annotation: A nod to the Jermaine Dupri / Jay-Z hit “Money Ain’t a Thang”

annotations.text:
You talkin’ buck 80 if the Bentley is the topic (That Grey Poupon)
 But of course gotta fly the Spur ([?])
annotations.annotation:
Two interpretations:


Jones' Bentley Flying Spur costs about $180,000 and is the color of Dijon mustard
Jones likens himself, when driving in his Bentley, to the dapper “Pardon me, would you have any Grey Poupon?” gentleman of pop cultural fame (although the Grey Poupon guy was driving a Rolls Royce in the commercials, not a Bentley, but you get the idea)



https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uwOCOm9Z0YE

annotations.text: Drive 80 up Lenox 'cause I got a urge (Speedin', speedin’)
annotations.annotation: Between 110th and 125th Street, it would be somewhat difficult to drive 80 m.p.h. on Lenox, as the artery is clogged by traffic jams day and night

annotations.text: Lifestyle rich, famous
annotations.annotation:
Like the TV show from the 1980s

Jim really seems to be going for a pre-‘87 air of excess here, from the Grey Poupon commercial to The Bonfire of the Vanities-style speeding

annotations.text: I beat the trial over Rucker (Let's do it!)
annotations.annotation: Jones frequents Rucker Park, the famous basketball court in Harlem… Junior M.A.F.I.A. jumped Jim Jones at the Rucker while Cam'ron watched, an incident which was caught on video and widely circulated

annotations.text: She say she want some Marvin Gaye,
annotations.annotation: Gaye is a late R&B legend responsible for songs such as Sexual Healing.

annotations.text: She be grabbing, calling me Biggie, like Shyne home
annotations.annotation:
Much as everyone confuses rapper Shyne with Biggie Smalls (aka the Notorious BIG) because of their eerily similar voices, Kanye’s girlfriend keeps calling him “Biggie” because he’s got a big penis!

Shyne, the Bad Boy Records artist who was sentenced to ten years on several charges associated with a December 27, 1999 incident at a Manhattan club he visited with P. Diddy and J-Lo, is known for his uncanny ability to channel of Biggie’s vocal tics. As of October 2009, Shyne is finally home, or at least out of prison

annotations.text:
She got a light-skinned friend, look like Michael Jackson
 Got a dark-skinned friend, look like Michael Jackson
annotations.annotation:
This couplet surely came up at “Regarding Michael Jackson: Performing Racial, Gender, and Sexual Difference Center Stage,” an academic conference held on the Yale campus from September 23-24, 2004. People there talked about this line for, like, months.

Kanye can relate two girls of different races to Michael Jackson be because he was once black before his vitiligo came into effect. It is speculated that Michael used skin bleaching creams to make his skin lighter, however, in an interview with Oprah Winfrey he stated that he only uses makeup to cover up the blotches on his skin.

Alternately, it could go slightly deeper in that she has an unattractive friend with a light complexion who reminds him of the late Michael Jackson, and she also has another unattractive friend with a darker complexion which also reminds him of Michael Jackson, but the younger, Pre-vitiligo diagnosed Michael Jackson.

In a 2013 New York Times interview, West cited writing this very line as the moment he knew he was going to be a big star.

annotations.text: My dog said you ain't no freak, so you 'bout to prove my man wrong
annotations.annotation:
Freak: (def.) A girl who is most likely very innocent-looking and often shy, but when it comes to sex likes to be kinky etc.
Kanye’s friend considers her a prude, Ye is confident that assessment is misguided.

annotations.text: She say she want some Marvin Gaye,
annotations.annotation: Gaye is a late R&B legend responsible for songs such as Sexual Healing.

annotations.text: Verse 2: Twista
annotations.annotation: Before this verse, there’s an interlude where a girl (voiced by future TV personality Aisha Tyler) tells Kanye she wants him to “do it faster”. Since Kanye has no hope of spitting as fast as she wants, he calls in Twista, who at one point was recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records as the World’s Fastest Rapper. It’s also just humorous that Twista raps very fast on a song that’s called “Slow Jamz.”

annotations.text: With my Earth in the Wind smokin' Fire
annotations.annotation:
A play on words mentioning R&B group Earth Wind & Fire (hailing from Chicago like Kanye and Twista) while referencing smoking weed.

Earth = weed
Wind = blowing the smoke
Fire = lighting the Blunt / smoking GREAT weed

annotations.text: Jodeci
annotations.annotation: Seminal band–or artist collective, really–from the Hampton Roads area of southeastern Virginia (it’s near Norfolk). Timbaland, Missy Elliot, Ginuwine, and K-Ci and Jo-Jo (“Jo” and “Ci”) spun off from Jodeci.

annotations.text:
And when I come over and bend your ass
 You be bumpin' Teddy Pendergrass
 I done hit it from the back
annotations.annotation: Teddy Pendergrass is a legend of Seventies Philly soul best known for his work with Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes (he sang lead on “If You Don’t Know Me By Now”). T-Pain revisits this Teddy Pendergrass joke in his verse on R. Kelly’s 2007 remix of Bow Wow’s “I'ma Flirt” (“I'ma flirt whether I’m in or out of town/That’s why they call me Teddy Bend-her-ass down”). Pendergrass was also known as TP, which might have been the basis for the comparison.

annotations.text: She say she want some Marvin Gaye,
annotations.annotation: Gaye is a late R&B legend responsible for songs such as Sexual Healing.

annotations.text:
And if you ain't got no man, hop up in my Brougham
 I keep it pimping like an old man
annotations.annotation:
Twista’s telling this girl if she doesn’t have a man she can ride with him, because he’s planning on taking her back to his place.

A Brougham was a car manifactured by Cadillac. These particular types of Cadillacs dates back to ‘55 until it became its own model in ‘87.

Twista is saying,“I keep it pimping like an old man,” because he was most likely in one of the old school Broughams and because he picked that girl up without much effort, as a pimp would do.

1955 Eldorado Brougham:

annotations.annotation: He exposes the inconsistency in his girls' positions on him like a nudist exposes his/herself

annotations.text: I'm Jesus, they Judas,
annotations.annotation:
Ultimately Cam'ron expects to be betrayed and relies on his wits (which are considerable, if wittiness is the standard)

Cf. another Cam Judas reference in “Killa Cam”

annotations.text: My diamonds: the bluest
annotations.annotation: Blue diamonds are particularly exotic and rare, so he is getting at the idea that he is both wealthy and a unique personality that should not be reduced to oppositional banalities

annotations.text: Ashanti-foolish
annotations.annotation:
As foolish as Ashanti presented herself in her number-one single “Foolish”



“Foolish”, along with Notorious B.I.G.’s “One More Chance” (Remix), samples “Stay With Me” by DeBarge

See the connection?

annotations.text: I'm with a stewardess, mami say a "flight attendant"
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron is playing on political correctness (a woman might be put off by the use of the term “stewardess” and correct his antiquated slang)

annotations.text: Called her a "stupid bitch".
annotations.annotation: He called her a “stupid bitch” because she corrected him for using the term “stewardess” (rhyme!)

annotations.text: Sorry? Nah, I might have meant it
annotations.annotation: The jump from “flight attendant” to “might have meant it” is just impressive, and characteristically dexterous

annotations.text: Demented
annotations.annotation: Dementia (meaning “deprived of mind”) is a serious cognitive disorder

annotations.text:
4 mil? I might have spent it
 But I got It back right back
annotations.annotation: Cam casually brags about maybe spending 4 million dollars (so casual!). To make sure the girl knows he’s not broke, he indicates that he made it all back quickly

annotations.text: My life is splendid
annotations.annotation: Hovercrafts and bubblebaths sound pretty sweet to me, too

annotations.text: Me and mommy drinking, drinking to the point she hurls
annotations.annotation: The “drinking, drinking” bit builds up tension that foreshadows the coming hangover

annotations.text: I'm bout to swirl the whirl-whirl,
annotations.annotation:
“Swirl the whirl-whirl” could refer to


“the whirlies” you’d always get in college
vomiting in the toilet after having too much to drink
a whirlpool jacuzzi for some freaky action

annotations.text: Come and stay with me, oh, where I live? The mall
annotations.annotation: He is materialistic, sure – he likes Italian clothes (see above). Given Cam'ron’s tendency to switch meanings up, he could also mean “them all”

annotations.text: Before MIMS I been hot
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron was hot shit even before MIMS stole Washington Heights' heart with This Is Why I’m Hot in early 2007

annotations.text: I get it cooking like Crisco
annotations.annotation:
Crisco is a popular brand of shortening (semi-solid fat used for baking)

When looking for something interesting to write about Crisco, I found a textbook Wikipedia censorship gaffe. Under trivia:

Crisco was, at one time, a favoured lubricating agent for fisting

annotations.text: Mami what the hell you like, you know what the hell I like
annotations.annotation: Note that he works her opposition to his advances to his benefit…the man is a master of banter

annotations.text: A hood bitch, stretch marks, beaty beat, cellulite
annotations.annotation: You know the one stripper you and your college buddies see and are all like “aww, gross”? That’s what Cam likes

annotations.text: My mouth is like the sewer, yeah yeah I keep it gutter
annotations.annotation: Actually, Cam'ron is pretty clean in this song; he’s probably just using this as an excuse for why he oughtn’t meet the girl’s mom

annotations.text: You clogged up, I'll be your plumber
annotations.annotation: The plumber / sex metaphor has been used since time-immemorial (I would say that Shakespeare invented it but did they have plumbers back then?)

annotations.text: Sorta like Drano
annotations.annotation: Plumbers' clog remover of choice:

annotations.text:
I'm a leprechaun, but I sell Meth-a-don
 Mari-juan, hero-on, ten year run, marathon
annotations.annotation:
Cam'ron is like a leprechaun, except instead of a pot o' gold, Cam'ron has a stash (methadone, marijuana, heroin)

He sold drugs for 10 years straight, showing his endurance

annotations.text: My hood like Lebanon, but that's its Benneton
annotations.annotation:
A play on the double meaning of “hood” (a hoodie by the girly designer United Colors of Bennetton, a neighborhood… or a “neighborhoodie”?)

“Hood like Lebanon” evokes local violence (think Beirut), but remember that people wear a lot of hoodie-style head coverings in the Hezbollah part of Lebanon too

annotations.text: You up in something fly, I got my weapon on
annotations.annotation: Her “fly” outfit is presumably not Benetton (it just rhymes better); his “weapon” is either a condom or just his dick

annotations.text: Mami the pepper spray
annotations.annotation: “Pepper” keeps with the food theme, although she has pepper spray to defend herself from hoodlums

annotations.text: Lets get this guacamole, you feeling hot then hold me
annotations.annotation: Guacamole is money (see also). If the girl is “hot” (aroused), she should hold him because 1) he’s down to fuck, 2) he’s so cold (from his diamonds and ice) that he’ll cool her

annotations.text: You had your guard up at first like a soccer goalie
annotations.annotation: A soccer goalie guards the goal and probably wears protective shin guards; the girl in question here has certainly not been receptive to Cam’s come-ons

annotations.text: Lets hit the Pacific, terrific, I'm feeling melodic
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron is always melodic, but might want to avoid actually singing melodies over his lyrics

annotations.text: Want to shoot it and cock it
annotations.annotation: He wants to cock his pistol and shoot at her (with his cock)

annotations.text: Not the Glamour, baby girl, I'm talking something else
annotations.annotation:
By “shoot it” he doesn’t mean that he wants to take “glamour shot” photos of her, like you find in the fashion magazine

HE WANTS TO EJACULATE

annotations.text: Listen love I ain't the one to get lovey-dovey
annotations.annotation: He may not get lovey-dovey, but he does get sing-songy

annotations.text: You got to love me shots of bubbly
annotations.annotation:
The “shots of bubbly” could refer either to liquor or cum shots (based on the activity he describes in the next line)

He’s using “me” to mean “my”, as in “me Lucky Charms”

annotations.text: Get your mouth wet, you the outlet, got to plug me
annotations.annotation: Like “pipe/plumber”, I would swear that the “outlet/plug” sex analogy dates back to Shakespeare except that I’m 90% sure they didn’t have electricity back in Shakespeare times

annotations.text: Verse 3: Kidd Kidd

Kidd Kidd told XXL:

2 Chainz was actually supposed to be on the song. He was supposed to have my verse. This was when he was Tity Boi. But I guess I just did my verse and everything worked out.

annotations.text:
Mrs. Officer, Mrs. Officer
 Tell your lieutenant get them cuffs off of ya
annotations.annotation:
This line, like Lil Wayne’s similarly-delivered line (“I know you wish your name was Mrs. Carter, huh”), is a homage to a Cash Money classic, Juvenile’s 2001 single “Set It Off”, as Juvy says “Mr. Officer, Mr. Officer, take these motherfuckin cuffs off of us” in the last verse.

That line itself is a homage to the Geto Boys' song “Crooked Officer”, but it’s fairly clear that Wayne and Kidd Kidd are referencing the Juvenile song because of 1.) the Cash Money/New Orleans connection and 2.) Kidd Kidd’s line is almost the same as Juvy’s.
