annotations.text: [Intro]
annotations.annotation: Originally “I’m Me” was supposed to be the first track on Tha Carter III. However, it leaked and ended up on The Leak, an EP of…well…leaked songs

annotations.text:
Yessir!
 They can't stop me
 Even if they stopped me...
annotations.annotation: Even if Wayne was pulled over, or “stopped” by the police, they would not be able to slow his success in the rap game. Even at the time Tha Carter III was released, Wayne had already made a permanent mark in hip-hop history.

annotations.text:
I'm on it, ooh, I'm on it
 I'm so on it, and however you want it
annotations.annotation:
Around the time that Wayne recorded this track somewhere around 2007/2008 he was the best rapper in the game. Hense he got a feature from Jay-Z and multiple beats from Kanye on his Grammy winning album as well as a late feature from Yeezy.

With this line he is highlighting his presence in it, it being the rap game.

annotations.text: I get the beat from (Maestro)
annotations.annotation:
Maestro is one of Lil Wayne’s hardest producers and, more generally, a major producer for Southern rappers.

Commenting on the beat for XXL, Maestro said:

Also, a lot of producers, they have to say, “Hey, put my [tag] on it,” but Wayne worked my name into his verse.

annotations.text:
What! What! I don't give a motherfuck
 Get your baby kidnapped and your baby-mother fucked
annotations.annotation: “Not giving a fuck” means not caring. Wayne uses a play on words with “motherfuck” and your mother getting fucked.

annotations.text: It's Tha Carter 3, bitch, better put your supper up
annotations.annotation:
Tha Carter III is the sixth studio album by Lil Wayne, released on June 10, 2008, on Cash Money Records. It follows a long string of mixtape releases and guest appearances on other hip-hop and R&B artists records, helping to increase his exposure in the mainstream.

The album’s cover art features a baby picture of Wayne and is similar to covers of hip-hop albums such as Illmatic and Ready to Die.

annotations.text: Hollygrove, I throw it up like I'm trying to lose my gut
annotations.annotation: Throughout Lil Wayne’s career, he has paid homage to Hollygrove, which is the sect of New Orleans in which he grew up. He even made a whole song about it. Using wordplay, he describes how he throws it up in order to represent his origins, much like one may throw up in order to try to lose weight.

annotations.text: Fuck is up? Beat him up like a million uppercuts
annotations.annotation: Wayne has a million uppercuts for his enemies, which are punches to the chin that frequently result in a knockout. He continues to use his Tha Carter III intro to insist that he has zero tolerance for his adversaries.

annotations.text: Got a million duffled up for the fuck of it, shit
annotations.annotation: Wayne talks about his wealth in more detail later in the album on “Got Money,” but for now, Weezy continues to bury his enemies by flexing his wealth. Because, why not?

annotations.text:
Get on my level? You can't get on my level
 You gon' need a space shuttle or a ladder that's forever
annotations.annotation: Wayne’s crazed, narcissistic rant continues by saying that people cannot reach his heights in the rap game. Also, Wayne refers to himself as other-worldly throughout his career. Therefore, you may need to catch a space ship to get to Wayne’s natural habitat.

annotations.text: Don't you ever fix your lips unless you 'bout to suck my dick
annotations.annotation: Wayne continues to talk about his zero tolerance for hate with this bar. He’s basically trying to say that if you are talking about me it better be something that pleases me.

annotations.text:
Two more inches, I'd have been in that casket
 According to the doctor, I could've died in traffic
annotations.annotation:
When Lil Wayne was 12, he was home alone playing with a gun and accidentally shot himself two inches from his heart. A heroic off-duty cop came to save him and Wayne nearly died on the ride to the hospital.

Listen to Wayne tell the story:

http://youtu.be/84U1I5e7I54?t=13s

annotations.text:
Bounce right back on them bitches, like Magic
 Abracadabra,
annotations.annotation:
“Magic” is being used here as a double entendre, referring to both Magic Johnson (a basketball player who’s done very well “bouncing back” from HIV) and actual magic (using the term “abracadabra”, a very famous phrase used by magicians).



FUN FACT: Lawrence Kushner writes in his book, The Book of Words: Talking Spiritual Life, Living Spiritual Talk (page 11) that the word “Abracadabra” is derived from an Aramaic phrase meaning “I create as I speak":

According to the Hebrew Bible, God made the world with words. God just spoke, and the world became reality. (The Armaic for “I create as I speak” is avara k'davara, or, in magician’s language, abracadabra.)

annotations.text: I'm up, like Viagra
annotations.annotation:
Viagra is used to treat erectile dysfunction (impotence) in men.



Upon taking it, a man’s penis will become erect, and rather than flailing downwards, will start to point up, which is exactly how Weezy feels.

annotations.text:
I just do this shit for my clique, like Adam Sandler
 I control hip-hop, and I'ma keep it on my channel
 Watch me!
annotations.annotation:
Wow, a double entendre executed so effortlessly.

Click is a movie starring Adam Sandler, in which Sandler’s character has a “Universal” television remote that he can use to control the world around him such as forcing you to watch Lil Wayne TV 24-hours a day

Lil Wayne also does things for his people (his “clique”), like Sandler, who has a proclivity for getting his friends cast in all his movies (think Rob Schneider)

annotations.text:
Bitch, watch me! Bitch, watch me!
 But they cannot-see me, like Hitler
annotations.annotation:
A play on words “cannot see” and “nazi”

This is also a nice little play on the meanings of the words “watch” and “see.” They “watch” (look to, obsess over) Wayne, but they cannot “see” (engage him on his level, understand him) him.

annotations.text: It's the New Orleans nightmare
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne is the “New Orleans Nightmare” meaning the “baddest” (but bad means good like how kids say it) motherfucker in New Orleans

Hitler would also be a Nightmare for New Orleans since New Orleans is full of minorities who Hitler would want to have killed (this Hitler reference did not come out of nowhere – when he says “not see” in the previous line, it sounds like “Nazi”)

This is also a reference to the Nazi takeover of the French city of Orleans in World War II.

annotations.text: Money so old, it's growing white hair
annotations.annotation: Wayne has been rich for so long that his money has white hair like an old person

annotations.text: Young Money, baby! Yeah, we right here
annotations.annotation: Young Money is the imprint of Cash Money Records that Lil Wayne started; this line follows the last, implying that Lil Wayne has old money, young money, borrowed money and blue money

annotations.text: I'ma make sure we ball 'til we fall like tears
annotations.annotation:
Possible quadruple entendre

– “Ball till we fall” is just another way of saying “shop till you drop”. He’s going to ball AKA spend money until he can’t anymore.

– Bawl means to cry, hence the “fall like tears”.

– “Fall” could refer to a friend/homie dying. If that were to happen, you would most likely drop tears and often people say they’re going to “ball in someone’s memory”. Also, a tear tattoo is supposed to represent a murdered loved one; peep Weezy’s tattoos here.

– In basketball, there’s a shot called a teardrop.

annotations.text:
When I was fourteen, I told my mom we would see better days
 And sure enough, I got Miss Cita in a better place
 When I was fourteen, I told my mom we would see better days
 And sure enough, we did exactly what I said
annotations.annotation:
The same line as one from his song “Rollers & Riders” with Juelz Santana, presumably made for their never-released collaborative project I Can’t Feel My Face:

When I was 14 I told my ma we will see better days
And sure enough I got Ms. Cita in a better place

Wayne also mentions “Cita” (his mom) on other contemporaneous songs “Playing with Fire” from Tha Carter III, before it got replaced by “Pussy Monster” for copyright reasons, and its lyrical twin “World of Fantasy”.

annotations.text: No sitting at the table if you bringing nothing to it
annotations.annotation: To “bring something to the table” is to have talents or skills that would benefit a group or organization. Wayne uses a metaphor for a literal table and the aforementioned figurative table.

annotations.text:
Yeah, I got game like Stuart
 Scott, fresh out the ESPN shop
annotations.annotation: Stuart Scott is a former SportsCenter anchor, who passed away after nearly defeating cancer. He had a lazy eye as a result of being hit in the eye by a football while participating in training camp.

annotations.text:
And when SportsCenter poppin', everything stoppin'
 But you can't fool me, I know what you watchin'
annotations.annotation:
For Lil Wayne, when SportsCenter is on, he stops everything and tunes in. But everyone else just watches Lil Wayne because he’s so compelling.

“When SportsCenter poppin'” is also a reference to when SportsCenter would play T.I.’s big hit, “Big Shit Poppin'” during the time Lil Wayne was recording this album (2007).

annotations.text:
You watch me!
 You watch me!
annotations.annotation:
We constant look up his name to see what he has been up to and to see if he has released any new stuff.

Also referencing Jay-Z’s “Watch Me”.

annotations.text: Must-see TV,
annotations.annotation: “Must see TV” was NBC’s self-applied description for its prime-time sitcom lineup in the 90s

annotations.text: C3
annotations.annotation: C3 stands for Tha Carter III, Wayne’s third installment of the Tha Carter series released in 2008.

annotations.text:
Nigga, that's me, and I'm me
 I'm me, times three
annotations.annotation:
This is a subtle reference to Wayne’s “I’m Me,” which is another song off of Tha Carter III.

Considering this is an opening song, the line is eluding the fact that Tha Carter III is the third work on the “Tha Carter” series. It also relates, obviously, to the track’s name.

Fun Fact: Three is a number surrounded by mysticism. There’s a lot of religious and esoteric symbolism surrounding repeating something three times, using triangles and etc. It’s found a bunch in Hebrew to draw emphasis as a powerful truth.

annotations.text: I'm back, 3-Peat!
annotations.annotation:
Three-peat is a contraction of the words three and repeat, and is used either as a verb or noun to refer winning three championships in a row. Lil Wayne tells us “Tha Carter III” is his third victory.



The term was first used when Michael Jordan won 3 straight NBA titles, this is where Lil Wayne got it from.

annotations.text: Woo! Roxanne!
annotations.annotation:
These lines are very similar to the pre-chorus of The Police’s 1978 hit “Roxanne”.

Roxanne
You don’t have to put on the red light

In the Police song, lead singer Sting attempts to convince a prostitute he is in love with to leave her work in the red light district. R. Kelly is parodying those lines, asserting that he doesn’t care what happens to the hooker he has sex with after he uses her services.

annotations.text: I be drillin' these chicks like Major Payne
annotations.annotation: R. Kelly is referring to the Damon Wayans character from the 1995 movie of the same name. Major Payne is a no-nonsense Marine Major placed in charge of a bunch of misfits at a junior ROTC programme who whips them into shape and turns them into winners through intense physical training. Kelly is saying he’s as tough on women sexually

annotations.text:
You see, I order one bottle, then I fuck with one model
 Then I order more bottles; now, I got more models
annotations.annotation:
R. Kelly is observing a correlation in the natural world: when he is at the club and purchases a single bottle, he usually has a single model to take home. However — as he observes — when he orders more bottles, he is able to obtain more models.

It is a logical fallacy to assume that correlation implies causation. However, in this case, we might assume that R. Kelly has an extensive sample size and is able to control for confounding variables (club quality, bottle quality, model quality, etc.) and therefore implying that the bottles are indeed leading to the models.



Note: R. Kelly does not explicitly imply that there is a linear relationship between models and bottles. In all likelihood there are decreasing returns to scale: at some point, each incremental full bottle ordered will result in less than an full additional model fornicated with.

annotations.text: I take a chick to my room like caveman
annotations.annotation:
Now we know, Kellz.
This didn’t age well.

annotations.text: "Skeet-skeet-skeet-skeet, weatherman 'bout to make it rain!"
annotations.annotation:
The phrase “make it rain” has two definitions; one of which is the more common usage, and, “less explicit.” Here, R. Kelly is using what is considered to be the “more explicit” definition: Ejaculating on a woman.

R. Kelly has also called himself a “weatherman” in his aptly titled song, “Weatherman.”

annotations.text: If the head right, Ricky there e'ery night
annotations.annotation: This line is an interpolation of The Notorious B.I.G’s “Hypnotize”. In the original song, the lyrics are “Dead right, if the head right, Biggie there e’ry night”. This line has also been interpolated by many other artists such as Ice Cube, Jeezy, Fabolous, and J. Cole.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Syleena Johnson & Kanye West]
annotations.annotation:
Kanye gets Syleena Johnson to interpolate Lauryn Hill’s line from “The Mystery of Iniquity,” the line being:

When it all, it all falls down, I’m telling you all, it all falls down

Kanye originally attempted to sample the recording but couldn’t obtain legal permission. West then called upon Syleena Johnson to re-sing the relevant vocal portions which ended up in the final track.

annotations.text: Oh, when it all, it all falls down
annotations.annotation:
The hook encourages people to think about what life would be like without material possessions, success, and all the external aspects of life that people lean on to sustain a sense of self worth. What will it feel like when it all falls down? Because one day it will.



This is a interpolation of the hook to Lauryn Hill’s “The Mystery of Iniquity”. Ye originally tried to sample the song directly, but Hill wouldn’t clear the sample for use.

annotations.text: Yeah, this the real one, baby
annotations.annotation:
From early references on Common’s “Southside” and his own “Homecoming” to later references on songs like “All Day,” he’s always shown love to the south side of Chicago.



When he says “We gon' set this party off right,” he wasn’t wrong. “All Falls Down” would go on to peak at #7 on Billboard’s Hot 100, serving as confirmation of the track’s mainstream success.

“This the real one” is likely a reference to this being the updated version of the original Lauryn Hill-sampling track.

 She has no idea what she doin' in college
annotations.annotation:
Even though the first verse refers to a troubled woman, these lines also apply to Kanye himself. After all the album’s title is The College Dropout and despite the grandiosity, it’s clear from his body of work and public utterances that Kanye’s a self-conscious and self-reflective person.

In the second verse, he turns the same “self-conscious” opening explicitly in on himself.

annotations.text:
That major that she majored in don't make no money
 But she won't drop out, her parents'll look at her funny
annotations.annotation:
Even though getting a college degree won’t help her, she doesn’t want to drop out because she knows her parents will be disappointed.

Ye touched on this subject in a more sarcastic manner on his “Lil Jimmy Skit”:

I’m going to get super smart, so I, too, can die without money
But I’ll be the smartest dead guy!

The way Kanye pronounces “her parents” can be interpreted as him saying “appearance”, alluding to the looks she receives from her parents.

annotations.text:
Now, tell me that ain't insecurr
 The concept of school seems so securr
 Sophomore, three yurrs, ain't picked a carurr
 She like, "Fuck it, I'll just stay down hurr and do hair"
 'Cause that's enough money to buy her a few pairs
 Of new Airs, 'cause her baby daddy don't really care
annotations.annotation:
While society paints a picture of going to college as a “secure” way to improve one’s future, the reality is that getting a higher education is not only rigorous—it’s costly and doesn’t always prepare you to pursue a fulfilling path.

Since her goal is to make money and going to school doesn’t seem like it will turn into a real job, she switched to her fallback: doing hair.

The “urr” pronunciation of “-ure” sounds is a reference to Chingy’s classic, “Right Thurr.”

annotations.text:
She's so precious with the peer pressure
 Couldn't afford a car, so she named her daughter Alexis
annotations.annotation:
She named her daughter “Alexis” so that she could still claim to own “a Lexus,” showing her materialistic desires outwinning her maternal love. In the seventh song of the album, “Jesus Walks” Kanye also talks about people stealing a Lexus.

You know what the Midwest is? Young and restless
Where restless (Niggas) might snatch your necklace
And next these (Niggas) might jack your Lexus

Saying she couldn’t ‘afford’ a car could be a reference to ‘a Ford,’ which is another popular car brand.

In Donda West’s book, Raising Kanye, she notes that this line is both about a cousin of Kanye’s named Alexis, and the woman he was dating at the time, Alexis Phifer.

annotations.text:
She had hair so long that it looked like weave
 Then she cut it all off, now she look like Eve
annotations.annotation:
Long hair has always been associated with beauty. Since she has grown it out to the point that it looks fake (weave), it ultimately defeats the purpose of growing it out in the first place. In spite of her attempt at self-security, she cuts it all off.

It’s important to note that Eve intentionally chose to wear a short hairstyle to go against standard beauty norms for women.

annotations.text:
And she be dealin' with some issues that you can't believe
 Single black female addicted to retail, and well
annotations.annotation: Clever rhyme off the 1992 movie title Single White Female. The line ties up a verse that has been about a self-conscious woman trying to fill the void in her life – with a college education, a clever baby name, and materialism in general.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Syleena Johnson & Kanye West]
annotations.annotation:
Kanye gets Syleena Johnson to interpolate Lauryn Hill’s line from “The Mystery of Iniquity,” the line being:

When it all, it all falls down, I’m telling you all, it all falls down

Kanye originally attempted to sample the recording but couldn’t obtain legal permission. West then called upon Syleena Johnson to re-sing the relevant vocal portions which ended up in the final track.

annotations.text: Oh, when it all, it all falls down
annotations.annotation:
The hook encourages people to think about what life would be like without material possessions, success, and all the external aspects of life that people lean on to sustain a sense of self worth. What will it feel like when it all falls down? Because one day it will.



This is a interpolation of the hook to Lauryn Hill’s “The Mystery of Iniquity”. Ye originally tried to sample the song directly, but Hill wouldn’t clear the sample for use.

annotations.text:
Man, I promise, I'm so self-conscious
 That's why you always see me with at least one of my watches
 Rollies and Pashas done drove me crazy
annotations.annotation:
Via MTV:


Sway: Do you admit to being self-conscious?

West: How could you be in this situation with this amount of pressure and this many people looking at you, waiting for you to show them a magic Houdini trick or a David Blaine, waiting for you to not make it out of your chains when the casket goes into the water, and not be self-conscious? How could you not be scared when you step out on that stage? How can I not be scared on the second album? How could I not be scared when I dropped “Diamonds” and there’s people who say, “I don’t like ‘Diamonds’ ”?


Brooke Crittendon, who dated Kanye for 2 and a half years, described him as “insecure” and “vulnerable”.

A Pasha is a luxury Cartier watch. Kanye feels he always has to wear expensive watches like Pashas or Rolexes in order to cover his insecurities. The fact that Kanye states “at least one of his watches” implies that he sometimes has more than one solely to validate him to himself and his friends.

annotations.text:
I can't even pronounce nothing, pass that Ver-say-see!
 Then I spent four hundred bucks on this
 Just to be like, "Nigga, you ain't up on this"
annotations.annotation:
“Ver-say-see” is a mispronounciation of the luxury brand Versace (pronounced “ver-SACH-eh” [verˈsaːtʃe]). Kanye emphasises how “so insecure” he is: to the point he buys ridiculously expensive things he can’t even pronounce, just so he can (maybe) feel like the rich people who also wear them.

It’s also important to note that Kanye self-consciously re-establishes a hierarchy (“Just to be like ‘Nigga you ain’t up on this’”) based on materialistic values (the watches). Instead of helping the community, Kanye contributes to the legacy of colonial violence on African Americans. He is aware he is doing this but he can’t stop himself.

Kanye seems to be imitating a line from Joe Ezterhas'  movie Showgirls, where main character Nomi says “Thanks. It’s a Ver-sayce” after being complimented on her dress.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2iM9Gav-G4c

annotations.text:
And I can't even go to the grocery store
 Without some Ones that's clean and a shirt with a team
annotations.annotation:
While “Ones” could be in reference to Nike’s Air Force 1, it’s most likely alluding to another Nike model: the Jordan 1. In an interview with Sway, Kanye claimed: “The Jordans are only popular at this point because of two people: me and Don C. Because Don C was ordering them vintage Jordans when the 4s used to break apart on the sole.”



Ye was also an avid wearer of throwback jerseys. Maybe he’s alluding to the Nolan Ryan jersey he wore in his “Through the Wire” video.

annotations.text:
It seem we livin' the American Dream
 But the people highest up got the lowest self-esteem
annotations.annotation: The American Dream is to be wealthy and successful, but the people that seem to achieve the dream are often left unfulfilled, perhaps because of the things they had to sacrifice to get there or the meaninglessness of an existence defined by the things you own.

annotations.text:
The prettiest people do the ugliest things
 For the road to riches and diamond rings
annotations.annotation:
Some innocent (pretty) people will do low (ugly) things to obtain fame and fortune. The line takes a portion of the chorus to “Real Niggas” by The Notorious B.I.G. (which was later used by Jay-Z for his own “Real Niggaz” and Nas on his song “N.I.G.G.E.R.”)

On the road to riches and diamond rings
Real niggas do real things

annotations.text: We shine because they hate us, floss 'cause they degrade us
annotations.annotation:
In the last few lines Kanye was referring to rich people, now he switches to African-Americans.

The best way to keep teeth “shinin'” is to floss, as your dentist would tell you. And if you don’t floss, your teeth will deteriorate.

“Flossing” can also mean exhibiting jewellery. Ye opines that African-Americans like to wear jewellery and show off money as a response to racism against them. Being flashy can help to heal a shattered self-esteem and it also sends a big “fuck you” to haters. The next verse expands on this theory in detail.

annotations.text: We tryna buy back our 40 acres
annotations.annotation: “40 acres and a mule” was the promise of compensation made to freed African American slaves after the Civil War. During Reconstruction, a lot of promises that the federal government had made to freed slaves were broken, so Kanye is saying that he has to be materialistic to get the socioeconomic benefits his ancestors were promised but never received

annotations.text: And for that paper, look how low we'll stoop
annotations.annotation:
Just meant as “will stoop” – as in, we’ll do really bad things for money

Also a reference to “a stoop” – porch with stairs. Stereotype dictates that it is a hangout spot for poor people in urban areas. The “a” in front of the word stoop not only fills out the length of this line, making it fit rhythmically better with the next, but also pre-emphasizes the message of the next line – to society at large, per Kanye’s view, any rich black man will be stereotyped as just some drug dealer who spends his time hanging out on a stoop.

annotations.text: Even if you in a Benz, you still a nigga in a coupe
annotations.annotation:
Even if a black person is successful in life and buys flashy things with the money they’ve earned, to the world at the end of the day to many they are just a “nigga in a coupe”.

Note the usage of “coupe.” On the surface level it refers to an expensive car, but doubles as “coop” continuing the interwoven themes of internalized racism, external racism, and materialism that lead to the line in the middle of the following verse:

“Cause they made us hate ourself and love they wealth”

annotations.text: [Chorus: Syleena Johnson & Kanye West]
annotations.annotation:
Kanye gets Syleena Johnson to interpolate Lauryn Hill’s line from “The Mystery of Iniquity,” the line being:

When it all, it all falls down, I’m telling you all, it all falls down

Kanye originally attempted to sample the recording but couldn’t obtain legal permission. West then called upon Syleena Johnson to re-sing the relevant vocal portions which ended up in the final track.

annotations.text: Oh, when it all, it all falls down
annotations.annotation:
The hook encourages people to think about what life would be like without material possessions, success, and all the external aspects of life that people lean on to sustain a sense of self worth. What will it feel like when it all falls down? Because one day it will.



This is a interpolation of the hook to Lauryn Hill’s “The Mystery of Iniquity”. Ye originally tried to sample the song directly, but Hill wouldn’t clear the sample for use.

annotations.text: I say, "Fuck the police," that's how I treat 'em
annotations.annotation: Kanye references the N.W.A song “Fuck tha Police” to express his feelings about law enforcement.

annotations.text: We buy our way out of jail, but we can't buy freedom
annotations.annotation:
This line disses the justice system, law enforcement, and the black American community.

“We buy our way out of jail” refers to the fact that a wealthy person is above the law in many ways since they can pay for very good legal defense to get them off the hook for most crimes.

“…but we can’t buy freedom” could be taken to mean that even outside of jail black people aren’t free from police harassment. However, the more significant interpretation is that black people aren’t free from themselves because they are too focused on materialism, an idea that Kanye introduced in the last verse and expands on in the rest of this one.

It also important to note that the entirety of this song is about internalized racism, about internalized white supremacy. “Self-consciousness” is a term eerily similar to the internalized Panoptic gaze, Foucault discusses. So, while you may not be in physical in prison, internally you are because you have internalized the white supremacist gaze and act on it by being materialistic.  The body is no longer disciplined or controlled externally, as during slavery, but internally.

annotations.text: Things we buy to cover up what's inside
annotations.annotation:
People often buy clothes and other items that are unnecessary and way too expensive. During the time this song was made, flexing jewelry and expensive watches were a common trend in hop hop and is still a continued practice today.



Kanye believes people do this to cover up their own insecurities and self-consciousness and to impress other people rather than make decisions they truly want to make themselves.

annotations.text:
Drug dealer buy Jordan, crackhead buy crack
 And the white man get paid off of all of that
annotations.annotation:
The crackhead buys crack from the drug dealer, then the drug dealer turns around and buys Jordans. The money in this economic food chain eventually ends up in the hands of a powerful white CEO who most likely doesn’t care about the detrimental effects of materialism.

The second bar was apparently a very controversial line for Kanye to spit, since “white man” is censored in the official music video.

While performing this song at Abbey Road, Kanye replaced ‘white man’ with ‘George Bush’.

annotations.text:
But I ain't even gon' act holier than thou
 'Cause fuck it, I went to Jacob with 25 thou
 Before I had a house and I'd do it again
annotations.annotation:
Kanye accepts that he is also guilty of being materialistic—before he even had a house he went to the renowned Jacob the Jeweler to purchase the would-be famed Jesus piece.



In a 2004 Rolling Stone interview with Kanye, journalist Touré wrote:

But the center of today’s outfit is the Jesus piece West picked up yesterday from Jacob the Jeweler, perhaps the top custom-jewelry man in hip-hop. About the size of a grown man’s palm, it has a cluster of clear diamonds for the crown of thorns, a river of yellow and light-brown diamonds making up Jesus' blond hair, aquamarines for his blue eyes and little rubies for the tears of blood on his face. It’s an ornate rendering, a $25,000 piece, and he’s very proud of it. “This is so fabulous it could be in the Robb Report,” he says.

This lyric was recycled from an earlier Kanye track: “Wow,” which he discussed recycling on “Last Call.”

annotations.text: ‘Cause I wanna be on 106 & Park, pushin' a Benz
annotations.annotation:
106 & Park was B.E.T.’s more commercial, pop-leaning rap show. Ye’s first appearance on the show came in the same month as “All Falls Down”’s release, performing “Slow Jamz” with Twista and Jamie Foxx.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rOXJ03ScMDQ

Side note: MTV censored this line in their broadcast of this video, considering it to be ‘advertisement’

annotations.text: Now, Syleena, you just like a safe belt, you saved my life
annotations.annotation:
In an interview, Syleena Johnson explained this line:

It was 6 o’clock in the morning and [Kanye] needed clearance for the Lauryn Hill sample and she wouldn’t give it to him.  And so, I came in to sing that hook for him and I ended up saving his deadline because he was going to have to push his album if he hadn’t gotten it done.

Kanye rapped in “Through the Wire” about the safety belt saving his life in his 2002 car accident.

annotations.text: [Produced by Kanye West]
annotations.annotation:
The original version  sampled vocals and guitar from Lauryn Hill’s “The Mystery of Iniquity,” before Kanye decided to have Syleena Johnson do the vocals.

http://youtu.be/BswphxnAibE?t=15s

In Billboard’s Kanye West’s ‘The College Dropout’: An Oral History, multiple collaborators unveiled the story behind the record:


‘All Falls Down’ was made on a fairly cheap Roland 18-track digital recorder and it wasn’t re-done in the studio. It was just put on the album. Things would be made in his apartment, and it’d sound amazing. A lot of times when then we’d do it in the studio it didn’t sound ‘good.’ So that first time would end up on the album. — Devo Springsteen

We were trying to get the sample cleared by Lauryn Hill, so Kanye and I flew to Miami and literally looked for Lauryn. We drove around Miami looking for Lauryn. I don’t know what we thought. That’s the kind of stuff that we were doing, we were so ‘by any means necessary.’ ‘Oh, she lives in Miami? We’ll just go find her.’ I don’t know who we thought we were or what we were doing. We bumped into Rohan [Marley], and ended up getting an email address but… (Sigh). — John Monopoly

We went as far as sending her a check to entice her to do it, but she didn’t do it. She didn’t actually write the record, so we were able to clear the words but not her. Syleena [Johnson] came in in the ninth inning and nailed it. — Shalik Berry

title.name: One More Chance / Stay With Me (Remix)

annotations.text:
First thing's first — I, Poppa, freaks all the honeys
 Dummies, Playboy bunnies, those wantin' money
annotations.annotation:
The song’s opening line (named #31 on Complex’s list of the 100 best opening lines in rap history) gets down to business immediately. Although he’s “black and ugly as ever,” Big has no problem getting freaky with all the women.

This isn’t the first time an artist opened a verse or song with the phrase “first things first” (that honor goes to Grand Puba in 1992 and then Ol' Dirty Bastard in 1993), but Big’s use here played a major role in popularizing the technique.

Some artists who’ve kicked things off with “first things first” include J. Cole, Nicki Minaj, Kid Cudi, Freeway, Iggy Azalea, The Game, Miguel, YG, T-Wayne, Ne-Yo, Saba, and Imagine Dragons.

A number of artists have more directly interpolated Big’s rhyme, including Joey Badass on 2015’s “Run Up On Ya”:

First thing’s first, I, Joey
Freaks all the honeys, mommies, the playboy bunnies

August Alsina on 2015’s “Been Around The World”:

First thing first, I’m Aug, freaks, all the honeys
Dummies, Playboy bunnies, hoes gettin' money

Slim Thug on 2013’s “Puttin In Work”:

First off, the boss
Freaks all the honeys
Stunning, playboy bunnies, those want money

Run-DMC on tktk’s “Ahhh”:

First things first I DJ, Run all the rappers
Actors, they want status, but they can’t have this

Tyga on 2015’s “God Talk”:

First things first I pop, sling all the honeys
Ain’t it funny? Angel, I got devils wanting money
Seems sacred but get nathin'
My penetration is all revelations

Rasheeda on 2007’s “Got That Good (My Bubblegum)”:

First things first, I Sheeda mess around wit no man who won’t eat her

annotations.text: Those the ones I like 'cause they don't get Nathan but penetration
annotations.annotation: Biggie likes women who have sex for money because that’s all they’re in for. They get nothing but money for sex, no feelings, no relationships. Fits his player persona better than saying they’re into penetrative sex.

annotations.text:
Unless it smells like sanitation
 Gar-bage, I turn like doorknobs
annotations.annotation: “Gar-barge” was used to rhyme with “debarge', the groups song "stay with me "was the sample used for the basis of the song

annotations.text: Girls pee-pee when they see me
annotations.annotation: Hopefully Big is referring to squirting.

annotations.text: As I lay down laws like I lay carpet
annotations.annotation:
Biggie is most likely referencing Island Carpet, a local Brooklyn business whose ads were all over New York radio in the 90s (according to legend.)

The line may often be confused, but the actual line is: “as I lay down laws like I lay carpet”, check the live versions of the song like his performance at the end of Martin (season 4 episode 3, “Blow, Baby, Blow”.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KugUQ9-Pn98

Some believe he may be speaking about  Allen Carpet, a better established chain of carpet stores.

Many believe Biggie is name-dropping an attorney named Alan Kopit, but that seems unlikely as Kopit has been practicing law in Cleveland, Ohio since 1977.

annotations.text: Don't see my ones, gon' see my guns — get it?
annotations.annotation:
If you don’t give Biggie his money (“ones,” as in one dollar bills), he’ll shoot you. Get it?

Junior M.A.F.I.A.’s Trife uses a similar motto on the group’s 1995 track “Murder Onze”:

Stashin' my guns to protect my ones
I see the cash flow—touch it, I blast
You know how it go

Perhaps inspired by Big’s line, Jay-Z uses a similar threat on 1999’s “Jigga My Nigga”…

Got a new motto this year:
Don’t fuck with my ones
Knock on your door, 3 in the morning,
“It’s just us and the guns!”

…And on 1999’s “More Money, Cash, Hoes”:

Cold with the guns
If he slow with my ones
Hit the floor when I come

annotations.text:
Now tell your friends Poppa hit it, then split it
 In two, as I flow with the Junior M.A.F.I.A
 I don't know what the hell's stoppin' ya
annotations.annotation:
Poppa (as in “Big Poppa”) is proud of his skills in the bedroom—by using the euphemism “hit it” and the image “split it in two,” he’s emphasizing the power of penis.

Big also shouts out his crew Junior M.A.F.I.A., whose debut album Conspiracy was released a few months after this song became a hit.



Junior M.A.F.I.A. members included Lil' Kim, Lil' Cease, MC Klepto, Trife, Larceny, Nino Brown, Chico Del Vec, Capone, and Bugsy.

annotations.text:
Once ya grin, I'm in — game begins
 First I talk about how I dress in this
 In diamond necklaces, stretch Lexuses
annotations.annotation: Big’s seduction begins. After seeing a woman smile in his direction, he slides over and talks about the finer things in life, like Lexus stretch limousines.

annotations.text:
The sex is just immaculate
 From the back, I get deeper and deeper, help you reach the
 Climax that your man can't make
annotations.annotation:
Big’s voice intonation on the words “deeper and deeper” mimics Barry White on his 1973 breakout hit “I’m Gonna Love You Just a Little More Baby”:

Deeper and deeper
In love with you I’m falling, yeah
Sweeter and sweeter
Your tender words of love keeps calling

annotations.text:
[Chorus: Faith Evans & The Notorious B.I.G.]
 Baby, here I am
 I got that good love girl, you didn't know?
 All I need is one more chance! One more chance
 I can help you find, yourself
 I got that good love girl, you didn't know?
 'Cause you don't need nobody else
 One more chance
annotations.annotation:
The original version of the song, sans Faith Evans, employs a slightly different hook:

“I got that good dick, girl, you didn’t know?”

The hook is a play on the verse on “Stay With Me” by DeBarge where the song is sampled.

annotations.text:
She's sick of that song on how it's so longgggg
 Thought he worked his until I handled my biz
annotations.annotation:
Watch out—Big might steal your girl. While you’re going on and on about size of your “long” penis and how well you “worked” it, Big will handle his business in bed like you never could.

This line was interpolated by Red Café on 2008’s “Paper Touchin’”:

She’s sick of that song
How it’s so long
Since she met a G like me
First it was Kane
Then it was B.I.G.
Then it was Jay
And she love the homey F.A.B.
Now meet me

annotations.text:
There I is! Major Payne like Damon Wayans
 Low Down Dirty, even, like his brother Keenan
annotations.annotation:
Biggie references two films from the Wayans family, 1995’s Major Payne (starring Damon Wayans) and 1994’s A Low Down Dirty Shame (starring Keenan Ivory Wayans).



Big’s using the film titles as a metaphor for his sexual skills—the size of his penis will cause major pain in his partner, and he’s not afraid to get down and dirty in bed.

It’s likely that Big’s 1997 hit “Mo' Money, Mo' Problems” is a reference to another Damon Wayans comedy, 1992’s Mo' Money.

This line was sampled by Eminem in 1997 on “Low, Down, Dirty.”

annotations.text:
Schemin', don't leave your girl 'round me!
 True playa for real, ask Puff Daddy
annotations.annotation:
Big’s scheming and ready to seduce your girl. This line was famously interpolated by Usher on his 2001 hit “U Don’t Have To Call”:

Don’t leave your girl around me
True player for real
Ask my nigga Pharrell

It’s also been interpolated and referenced by Bow Wow, Mac Miller, Fabolous, MF Doom, Bobby Valentino, Krizz Kaliko, Lil Mo, Murs, Kevin Cossom, Nick Grant, Ace Hood, Craig David, Smitty, and Travis Porter.

Why is Biggie calling in Puffy’s co-sign? Their wingman bond is further illustrated on 1997’s “Hypnotize”:

Girls walk to us, wanna do us, screw us
Who us? Yeah, Poppa and Puff

And again on 1997’s “My Downfall”:

Me and Sean Combs
Taking broads home

Puffy remembered Biggie’s game in 2011 interview:

Around women he was a charmer. He didn’t really make the first move, and a lot of times it just happened from, “Pleased to meet you.” He would get introduced to people and when he said “pleased to meet you” to a girl it rang a different way. I guess they was caught off guard by how much of a gentleman he was, how smooth he was and also how he didn’t try to continue on the conversation. That made her feel comfortable. They’d lay in the cut, something else would happen, and then they’d start laughing. They’d see the humor and it was a wrap.

annotations.text:
You ringin' bells with bags from Chanel
 Baby Benz, traded in your Hyundai Excel
 Fully equipped, CD changer with the cell
annotations.annotation:
In the first verse Biggie tried to impress a gold digger with his wealth, and here he switches to seducing a rich woman away from her man.

She’s “ringing bells,” an expression that means attracting attention, thanks to her Chanel handbags and luxury whip.

A “Baby Benz,” refers to the small class of Mercedes Benz sedans that came out in the the US in the early 1980s, starting with the 190E.

In 1995, Biggie was probably referring to the W202 body Mercedes C-class. A “fully equipped” car has all the optional accessories, which at that time included a multi-disc CD changer and car phone.



Quite an upgrade from the Hyundai Excel hooptie:

annotations.text: She beeped me "Meet me at twelve"
annotations.annotation:
Originally used by doctors, mobile pagers—also known as “beepers"—became extremely popular with the general public in the early 1990s, when they were seen as a cutting-edge technology.

In the time before cell phones, beepers fell into two categories: numeric pagers (which allowed you to send someone a phone number to call you at, sometimes with a short code) and alphanumeric pagers (which also allowed you to send a short text message).

Beeping someone “MEET ME AT 12” would require an alphanumeric pager, like the Motorola Wordline FLX model, which was introduced in 1995:



“Two-way” pagers, which allowed users to respond to text messages, weren’t introduced until 1996.

Biggie also raps about pagers on “Warning,” “Goin' Back To Cali,” “Another,” “Me & My Bitch,” “The Wickedest,” and “Why You Trying To Play Me,.

annotations.text: While I'm swimmin' in your women like the breast stroke
annotations.annotation:
This guy is a genius.

This is simultaneously a double entendre and an extended metaphor.



Let’s take ‘Breast stroke’ first–breaststroke is one of the four major swimming strokes. Right after claiming that he swims, he regales the listener with how he does it (breaststroke). On the other hand, if he’s ‘swimming’ in the other guy’s women, he’s doing super well with them.

And of course, breast/nipple stimulation is one of the most established acts of sensual gratification.

annotations.text: Nothin' left to do but send her home to you
annotations.annotation:
Intimacies are over,

The only thing she’s got to do is put her clothes, make-up and and pretty face on for her unsuspecting boyfriend.

annotations.text: I'm through, can you sing the song for me, boo?
annotations.annotation: This “boo” of his is Faith Evans. She actually married him before he was shot.

annotations.text:
[Chorus: Faith Evans & The Notorious B.I.G.]
 Baby, here I am
 I got that good love girl, you didn't know?
 All I need is one more chance! One more chance
 I can help you find, yourself
 I got that good love girl, you didn't know?
 'Cause you don't need nobody else
 One more chance
annotations.annotation:
The original version of the song, sans Faith Evans, employs a slightly different hook:

“I got that good dick, girl, you didn’t know?”

The hook is a play on the verse on “Stay With Me” by DeBarge where the song is sampled.

annotations.text: So what's it gonna be? Him or me?
annotations.annotation:
After attempting to woo a woman away from her man in the second verse, Big begins verse three with an ultimatum.

This phrase first appeared in Paul Revere & the Raiders' 1967 hit “Him or Me, What’s it Gonna Be?” In 1984, Prince used it in “The Beautiful Ones”:

Baby, baby, baby
What’s it gonna be?
Oh baby, baby, baby
Is it him or
Is it me?

Variations on the phrase have also been used by Next, Lil Wayne, Lover Boy, Fetty Wap, Jackie Jackson, Beat Happening, Capital STEEZ, and 2Pac.

In 2003, Puff Daddy interpolated this line—and the next three lines—on the remix to Beyonce’s “Summertime”:

So what’s in gonna be, him or me? (yeah)
We can cruise the world for pearls
And bare boots for girls
Summertime in the linen, fresh fruit

annotations.text:
We can cruise the world with pearls, gator boots for girls
 The envy of all women, crushed linen
annotations.annotation:
He’s not letting up in his quest to convince women of his worth through wealth.

In a sense, there is something poignant in the desperation inherent in having to use riches as bait for ‘love’. Biggie is almost Gatsby-esque in this regard, offering money and the freedom it brings (cruise the world) as a lure for… a relationship.

It’s also a slightly mixed juxtaposition of wealth images, that borders on incoherent. Word cruises and alligator skin bots? Ok then… He’s having a ‘throwing colourful shirts at daisy’ moment here. Confident and flashy yes, but also needy.

annotations.text: Cartier wrist-wear with diamonds in 'em
annotations.annotation:
Cartier is a French luxury fashion accessories brand best known for their jewelry and watches, including diamond-encrusted ones that Big might buy for that special lady.

This is the first time a rapper name-dropped Cartier in a song—the brand went on to become a popular reference in hip-hop lyrics.

It’s worth noting that Biggie pronounces the brand’s name “Car-tee-air” (perhaps in an attempt to rhyme with “wrist-wear”), rather than using the more accurate pronunciation “Car-tee-ay.”

annotations.text: Sexin' me while your man masturbates
annotations.annotation: Yes Biggie would take your chick and have you beat it off instead. Would hate to have my chick around him

annotations.text:
Isn't this great? Your flight leaves at eight
 Her flight lands at nine, my game just rewinds
annotations.annotation:
Big has his women scheduled perfectly—one’s getting on a flight that takes off at 8, and the next one lands an hour later at 9. Big rewinds his game and starts all over again when she arrives.

This is perhaps also a subtle suggestion to the listener to “rewind” the song since we’ve nearly reached the end.

Jay-Z interpolates this line on 2001’s “Girls, Girls, Girls, Pt. 2”:

Isn’t this great? My flight leaves at eight
Her flight lands at nine, my game just rewinds

annotations.text: Lyrically, I'm supposed to represent
annotations.annotation:
Big’s supposed to represent high-quality lyricism because (as he states in the next line), he’s a student of the game, in addition to being a creative leader.

This lyric was sampled by producer Rockwilder on the hook of Big Pun’s 1998 song “Super Lyrical.” The chorus of Bubba Sparxxx’s 2006 song “Represent” also seems inspired by the line, as does a line from Bizzy Bone’s 2006 song “It’s The Light”:

Lyrically, I’m supposed to represent this
I represent it properly, yes I’m God’s property

In 2016, Sprite printed this Biggie lyric on a soda can as part of their “Obey Your Verse” campaign:

annotations.text: I'm not only a client, I'm the playa President
annotations.annotation:
This is a reference to the popular Hair Club For Men commercials from the ’80s and ’90s. The ads ended with the company’s founder, Sy Sperling, showing a photo of himself before his hair transplant and saying, “Remember, I’m not only the Hair Club President, but I’m also a client.”



Big wasn’t the first rapper to flip the catch-phrase—that honor goes to Common, who references it on his 1994 track “Thisisme”:

Probably in about seven years
I won’t have no hair
But not only am I the Hair Club President
I’m also a client
I come off like a toupee

Shortly before Big released “One More Chance,” RZA also referenced the commercial on Ol’ Dirty Bastard’s 1995 song “Cuttin’ Headz”:

President of the Wu
But I’m also a client

Since “One More Chance” became a major hit, many rappers have continued to reference the Hair Club commercials, perhaps inspired by Big. Kanye references it on 2007’s “Big Brother”:

Have you ever walked in the shadow of a giant?
Not only a client, the Presidito, hola, Hovito

Other artists who have referenced the Hair Club For Men slogan include Lil Kim, Rick Ross, Pitbull, El-P, Buckshot, Chamillionaire, Red Hot Lover Tone, Dom Kennedy, and Cappadonna.

annotations.text: I spits the game for those that throw bricks
annotations.annotation:
“I speak for the hustlers” (i.e., people who toss around bricks of cocaine)

Also, a pun on the basketball term (in basketball, to “throw a brick” is to miss a shot)

Also, people who are frequently in and out of jail are said to “throw bricks,” i.e., they’d throw a brick through a store window just to go back to the pen because they cant handle life on the outside. Real street talk.

AND “those that throw bricks” can be a term for agitators and protesters, the proletariat… a quadruple entendre by Hov?

annotations.text:
That's life's enigma, long as life within us
 We gon' sin a lot and pray that Christ forgive us, fuck it
 Ice the wrist and raise the price on these niggas
annotations.annotation:
“Ethics”, by Jay-Z:

Step 1: Sin
Step 2: Repent
Step 3: Rescind repentance
Step 4: Raise the price on your drugs so you can buy diamond watches

Sinning and counting on being forgiven is reminiscent of Saint Augustine’s attitude in The Confessions of St. Augustine (Chap. 2)

annotations.text: When I go all the Harlem playas wall my picture (Uh-huh)
annotations.annotation:
On “Ride or Die”, earlier in the album, Jay takes multiple subliminal shots at Ma$e, over these specific bars Ma$e spat on 112’s “Love Me”:

What we hear is platinum that, platinum this
Platinum whips, nobody got no platinum hits

The previous 3 bars are direct replies to Mase’s diss. Jay also claims Harlem prefers Jay-Z to Mase, implying Mase’s neighbourhood doesn’t even rock with him. “Wall my picture” implies Harlem residents idolize Jay-Z and have his picture on their wall.

Speaking in an interview with Complex magazine in 2011, Swizz Beatz explained “[that the] hook was Jay’s idea but the concept of following the beat was my thing. I played him the joint and he was like, ‘Oh, that’s crazy. I’m trying to figure out what to do with it.’ I told him to just follow the keys.”

DMX’s infamous “What!” ad-libs heard in the track were taken from his live recordings, not laid down by X in the studio.

annotations.text: Yeah I rap now, fast money done slowed up
annotations.annotation:
The “fast money” relates to his income from dealing drugs. He referred to the proceeds from dealings drugs as “fast money” in Decoded.
During Decoded Jay also told this story, likely related to fast money slowing up:

Maryland ended badly, too – shootouts in clubs, major police investigations, whole crews arrested. I got out of there just in time. Some of my best friends weren’t so lucky.

annotations.text:
It's like New York's been soft
 Ever since Snoop came through and crushed the buildings
annotations.annotation:
He should have just shut the fuck up and minded his business. We went after him after that. Like, I fucking hit you in the head. I took it upon myself like, ‘You know what? This fucking bitch ass nigga popping shit about some shit that he wasn’t even around and his name was involved.’ Tupac was going at him. His name was all in that and he didn’t have nothing to say at that time.

– Prodigy


Even though Snoop Dogg is from Long Beach, he and Jay-Z are good friends. Snoop Dogg had beef with Mobb Deep and so, in a video for a diss song recorded with The Dogg Pound (Snoop’s little homies) called “New York, New York”, Snoop Dogg poses as a Godzilla-like creature stomping around and destroying buildings in New York.

https://youtu.be/9X_JJeVJLFc?t=1m28s

Here, Jay-Z is taking Snoop’s rebuke as an opportunity for self-criticism, and criticism of his hometown’s hardness.

annotations.text:
I know they gon' criticize the hook on this song
 Like I give a fuck...I'm just a crook on this song
annotations.annotation:
#Double Entendre


Above Jay perverts the moral found in Mo' Money Mo' Problems by making it vacuous. There is no redemption in the hook of ‘money, cash hoes’, which is why people won’t like it.
Jay-Z basically is poking fun at the fact that the hook in this song makes no sense because Money and Cash are the exact same thing. But he doesn’t care because he knows the fans will let him get away with this lyrical crime.

annotations.text: Bed-Stuy Brook-Nam
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z is from Bedford-Stuyvesant, the ghettoest neighborhood in Brookly(o)n

He says “Brook-Nam” because Brooklyn is (or use to be) so violent that it earned this nickname comparing the borough to Vietnam.

annotations.text:
Shit, I led a life you can write a book on
 Sex, murder and mayhem, romance for the street
 Man, and I tell ya, it'll be the best-seller, what!
annotations.annotation:
A repetition of a line from the first verse: Jay-Z is really trying to drive home the point that he lives in exciting life that is rich in narrative.

Sure enough, Jay-Z’s book Decoded ended up on the best seller list in 2010.
