And it was full of children, prob'ly couldn't see as high as I be
(So, what you sayin'?) It's like the game ain't the same
Got younger niggas pullin' the triggers, bringin' fame to their name
And claim some corners, crews without guns are goners
In broad daylight, stick-up kids, they run up on us
.45’s and gauges, MAC's in fact
Same niggas will catch you back-to-back, snatchin' your cracks
In black, there was a snitch on the block gettin' niggas knocked
So hold your stash 'til the coke price drop
I know this crackhead who said she gotta smoke nice rock
And if it's good, she'll bring you customers and measuring pots
But yo, you gotta slide on a vacation
Inside information keeps large niggas erasin' and their wives basin'
It drops deep as it does in my breath
I never sleep, 'cause sleep is the cousin of death
Beyond the walls of intelligence, life is defined
I think of crime when I'm in a New York State of Mind

[Chorus]
New York state of mind
New York state of mind
New York state of mind
New York state of mind

[Verse 2]
Be havin' dreams that I'm a gangsta, drinkin' Moëts, holdin' TEC's
Makin' sure the cash came correct, then I stepped
Investments in stocks, sewin' up the blocks to sell rocks
Winnin' gunfights with mega-cops
But just a nigga walkin' with his finger on the trigger
Make enough figures until my pockets get bigger
I ain't the type of brother made for you to start testin'
Give me a Smith & Wesson, I'll have niggas undressin'
Thinkin' of cash flow, Buddha and shelter
Whenever frustrated, I'ma hijack Delta
In the PJ's, my blend tape plays, bullets are strays
Young bitches is grazed, each block is like a maze
Full of black rats trapped, plus the Island is packed
From what I hear in all the stories when my peoples come back
Black, I'm livin' where the nights is jet-black
The fiends fight to get crack, I just max, I dream I can sit back
And lamp like Capone, with drug scripts sewn
Or the legal luxury life, rings flooded with stones, homes
I got so many rhymes, I don't think I'm too sane
Life is parallel to Hell, but I must maintain
And be prosperous, though we live dangerous
Cops could just arrest me, blamin' us; we're held like hostages
It's only right that I was born to use mics
And the stuff that I write is even tougher than dykes
I'm takin' rappers to a new plateau, through rap slow
My rhymin' is a vitamin held without a capsule
The smooth criminal on beat breaks
Never put me in your box if your shit eats tapes
The city never sleeps, full of villains and creeps
That's where I learned to do my hustle, had to scuffle with freaks
I'm a addict for sneakers, 20's of Buddha and bitches with beepers
In the streets I can greet ya, about blunts I teach ya
Inhale deep like the words of my breath
I never sleep, 'cause sleep is the cousin of death
I lay puzzled as I backtrack to earlier times
Nothing's equivalent to the New York state of mind

[Chorus]
New York state of mind
New York state of mind
New York state of mind
New York state of mind

[Outro: Sample]
"Nasty Nas—"

annotations.text: [Produced by DJ Premier]
annotations.annotation:
Here’s a fascinating step-by-step deconstruction of Premier’s beat.

The piano in the beat is sampled from Joe Chambers‘ instrumental jazz composition “Mind Rain”:

http://youtu.be/jVZNvcV_Wq0?t=1m6s

DJ Premier emphasized the lower tones of this sample, while complimenting them with an alternate higher toned melody. The drums are consistent to Preemo’s classic boom-bap sound, and the inclusion of bass throughout the beat provides a strong structure for Nas to flow on smoothly.

At the beginning of this song, there is a portion without the sampled piano and a synthesized, high-pitch sound, higher than any piano note. This sound came from another jazz track, Donald Byrd’s “Flight Time.”

Premier has said that this whole song was originally one verse, but he added the hook in the middle to give the audience a chance to digest the first verse and not be overwhelmed by one extremely long/complex verse.

DJ Premier told XXL:

Right at the beginning of the record, when he says, “Straight out the dungeons of rap, where fake niggas don’t make it back.” And then there’s kind of like a silence, where the music is building up, and you hear Nas go, “I don’t know how to start this shit.” He [had just written it], and he was trying to figure out how to format it, like when to come in. I’m waving at him in the control room like, “Look at me, go in for the count.” So right when he looks up and sees me counting, he just jumps in. He did the whole first verse in one take, and I remember when he finished the first verse, he stopped and said, “Does that sound cool?” And we were all like, “Oh my God!”

To this day, Nas ironically says “I don’t know how to start this shit” when he performs the song live – he claims {where?} that he keeps that part in the song to give the listener a more authentic experience, since he really didn’t know how to start the song at one point.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q81lInyFZfE&feature=youtu.be&t=47s

annotations.text: [Verse 1]
annotations.annotation:
On this first verse, Nas really display his complex lyricism.
His rhyme schemes and storytelling has been acknowledged throughout his carreer, and this song particularly has been argued to be One of the Best Songs in Hip-Hop History.

Rhyme Scheme: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=prSOHUswTJU

annotations.text:
Rappers; I monkey flip 'em with the funky rhythm
 I be kickin'
annotations.annotation:
The monkey flip is both a wrestling move and a breakdancing move. Nas' use lies in the word “flip” as he engages in lyrical battle with his opponents

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4AFrdGpg6Q

annotations.text:
I'm like Scarface sniffin' cocaine
 Holdin' an M16, see, with the pen I'm extreme
annotations.annotation:
There’s a famous scene at the end of the movie Scarface where its lead character Tony Montana stuffs his face in a mountain of cocaine and then comes running out of his office in a wild final attack with an M16 rifle:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HJUt_x0gwug

In a later song with Alicia Keys recorded days after Uday and Qusay Hussein’s 2003 assassinations, Nas updated this line to:

I’m like Saddam Hussein
Still alive, staring at my dead childrens' burnt remains

annotations.text: Now, bullet holes left in my peepholes
annotations.annotation: A poetic way of describing violence in his neighborhood – the bullet hole in his apartment door suggests that there is no escape from the chaos that surrounds him. And “peepholes” is a homophone for “peoples”, suggesting that urban violence has cut down some of his friends as well as damaging his property.

annotations.text: Y'all know my steelo, with or without the airplay
annotations.annotation:
“Steelo” is a corruption of the word “style” (from the Spanish estilo); prophetically, Nas is telling us that we will all know his rap style, whether or not he’s getting played on the radio (“airplay”).

At the time, Nas was alluding to the fact that he had an “underground” following; today, it is still true because Nas is not a rapper who gets crossover hits or radio play; yet the entire corpus of modern rap has sprung from his style, footprinted in the songs off Illmatic (like this one).

Fascinating coincidence: ‘stylo’, pronounced identically to ‘steelo’, translates from French as ‘pen’. The line is no less true abiding by this interpretation; Nas' pen-work could be spotted a mile off.

annotations.text: I keep some E&J, sittin' bent up in the stairway
annotations.annotation:
E&J Brandy is a relatively inexpensive liquor, and the fact that Nas mentions it here really says a lot about where he was when he wrote this.

“Bent” means “drunk;” the slang is derived from the imagery of drunk people bent over, throwing up after a night of drinking.

annotations.text: Or either on the corner bettin' Grants with the cee-lo champs
annotations.annotation:
Cee-lo is a very popular three-dice game in the ghetto; $50 a roll is relatively high stakes for a game of street cee-lo, but still low-stakes enough to brandish Nas' street thug credentials

“Grants” refers to the image of Ulysses S. Grant (18th US  president) on the US $50 note (one of the dead presidents mentioned elsewhere on Illmatic)

annotations.text: Laughin' at base-heads, tryna sell some broken amps
annotations.annotation:
He laughs at crack addicts desperately trying to sell broken stereo amplifiers because they are desperate for money to buy crack (I mean, it is pretty funny…)

“Baseheads” is slang for crack addict; they’re selling junk they may have stolen in their desperation for drug money. Of course “bass” ties into “amp”, so the wordplay here is pretty intricate.



Base is also known to refer to high quality amphetamine (often shortened to “amp”). Thus, to feed their addiction, a base head would sell broken amps, or amphetamine that’s been cut after they already used some. So there’s speed-freaks trying to sell broken amps. Nice pun/dual-meaning with ‘base’ and ‘bass’.

annotations.text: Reminiscin' about the last time the task force flipped
annotations.annotation: They sit around telling stories and laughing about the last time C.R.A.S.H (the Community Resources Against Street Hoodlums – often known as ‘The Task Force’) raided them looking for narcotics or other illegal items.

annotations.text: Time to start the revolution, catch a body, head for Houston
annotations.annotation:
Nas sardonically alludes to the political revolution advocated by 1960s/1970s Black Power groups and referenced by Gil Scott-Heron on “The Revolution Will Not Be Televised”. While the incident Nas is reminiscing about was a violent insurrection of sorts, it was a gang related response to a police drug raid (or an assault by thugs from other blocks), not a bona fide revolution

To “catch a body” is to murder someone (since now you’ve got a corpse to deal with)

Jay-Z later paid homage to this line in “Open Letter”

annotations.text:
Once they caught us off-guard, the MAC-10 was in the grass, and
 I ran like a cheetah, with thoughts of an assassin
annotations.annotation:
This section starts a more focused narrative; Nas is known for these “stream of consciousness” bits: he is ambushed by his enemies and runs towards his Mac which is on the grass (the Mac 10 is a fairly large semi automatic weapon. Pavements are not the best place to hide one). Alternatively, being “in the grass” might just be a metaphor for the gun being hidden or concealed.

The reference to grass paired with comparing himself to a cheetah makes his neighborhood seem like a savannah or other wild habitat where predators lurk about. This taps into a motif as old as hip hop itself.  The cheetah is the fastest running animal on Earth and also has its roots in Africa, just like the Afro-American poet.



The question of who Nas is shooting at is tough to sort out – who does the “they” in “they caught us off-guard” refer to? One possible antecedent is the Task Force, implying that Nas is shooting at cops.

On the other hand, in the next line Nas is shooting at “niggas”, not a typical way to describe New York’s predominantly-white police force. So he is referring to a battling a rival crew. He’s actually remembering an incident involving the same dudes who once caught them off guard and tellin what happened during that instance.

annotations.text:
Picked the MAC up, told brothers "Back up!" — the MAC spit
 Lead was hittin' niggas, one ran, I made him back-flip
annotations.annotation:
Once he gets his gun, Nas warns his enemies to back up before he opens fire. One of the enemies tries to run, so Nas shoots him in his back.

In movies, gun shots are usually dramatized and so often times when a character is shot in the back, the actor overacts by pushing his chest outward and arching his back, then finally falling to the ground.

An example of this is Drake in Degrassi: https://youtu.be/bV-K9CTQHhY?t=25s

annotations.text: Heard a few chicks scream, my arm shook, couldn't look
annotations.annotation:
This could be interpreted a number of different ways:


There were female bystanders but Nas was too nervous to look out for them since he’s busy just firing indiscriminately.
His arm is shaking from the recoil of the weapon he couldn’t look to see if he hit one of the “screaming chicks” – or perhaps just from nerves

annotations.text:
Gave another squeeze, heard it click, "Yo, my shit is stuck!"
 Tried to cock it, it wouldn't shoot, now I'm in danger
annotations.annotation:
With his highly narrative-oriented lyrical style, Nas was one of the first rappers to incorporate quotes and dialogues into his verses–see the final verse of “One Love”, which is largely a dialogue.

Note that as soon as Nas realizes his gun is jammed (Mac 10s are notoriously unreliable when not regularly cleaned and maintained) and he can’t shoot, he’s “in danger”–a subtle way of noting that in the projects of Queensbridge in the 90s, it was either shoot or be shot.

annotations.text: Finally pulled it back and saw three bullets caught up in the chamber
annotations.annotation: When one round of ammunition fails to eject from the chamber it becomes jammed. This is known as a “stovepipe” or a “failure to eject (FTE)” jam. When another is loaded from the magazine into the already jammed chamber, it makes the problem worse until the firearm fails to get back into battery and fire. When this happens to someone wielding a firearm and they open the action to see if they can clear the jam, the sight of a “stovepipe” is typically the sight of “…3 bullets caught up in the chamber.” The stovepipe or failure to eject jam is one of the worst possible jams, especially in automatic firearms like the Mac-10.

annotations.text:
So, now I'm jettin' to the buildin' lobby
 And it was full of children, prob'ly couldn't see as high as I be
annotations.annotation:
Nas introduces another defining feature of urban warfare: there are innocents everywhere.  He flees (“jetting”) inside a project building and in the lobby, only to find that it’s filled with “children” – i.e., the enemies he’s battling with are young enough to be considered kids.

This can also be a double entendre, as Nas probably couldn’t even see clearly because he was so high.

Word play – “jetting” and “couldn’t see as high as I be”, like he’s in the sky. This is an example of Nas’s beautiful, intricate rhymes. “building,” “children”; and “lobby,” “prob'ly,” “I be.”

There is also another double entendre, children aren’t as tall as adolescents/adults, so they naturally need to look up to see things while the taller people just can look straight ahead of them. So the children can’t see as high as an adolescent/adult/Nas.

annotations.text: (So, what you sayin'?)
annotations.annotation:
An interruption indicates that his stream-of-consciousness story is over.

This phrase might well be in reference to EPMD’s “So Was Cha Sayin'”

annotations.text:
It's like the game ain't the same
 Got younger niggas pullin' the triggers, bringin' fame to their name
annotations.annotation:
When you sleep on the street
Little motherfuckers with heat wanna leave a nigga six feet deep

This line is reminiscent of the general sentiment in “Things Done Changed” from Biggie’s classic album Ready To Die, an unofficial sort of sister album that came out the same year as Illmatic. 1994 was a good year for hip hop.

Nas is upset that this new generation of young men engage in violence out of vanity, not as a last resort. Examples are in City of God and The Wire where kids killed some of the most respected guys that nobody could touch.

This line is an explicit reference to the previous line “it was full of children.” The thugs who were trying to kill him were just kids – hence Nas’s comments about “younger niggas pulling the triggers.”

annotations.text: And claim some corners,
annotations.annotation:
To “claim a corner” is to establish your control over a street corner as an outpost for selling drugs

Fights break out over this sort of thing; Nas – a peaceable man – would probably advocate a simple “first come, first served” rule

annotations.text: Crews without guns are goners
annotations.annotation:
And I’m down with the shit, too, for the stupid motherfuckers want to try to use Kung-Fu
Instead of a MAC-10, he tried scrappin'
Slugs in his back and that’s what the fuck happens

You can’t fight to gain control of/keep control of territory if you don’t have any firepower. Hard reality and law of streets.

Don’t bring a knife to a gun fight!

Also, nice wordplay: if you dont have guns you are a gunless, but here you still are paradoxically “gunner” —> goner.

Guns and goners is a form of pararhyme.

annotations.text: In broad daylight, stick-up kids, they run up on us
annotations.annotation:
Indeed; NYC from the 70s to the late 90s (when Guiliani murdered all the homeless people) was indeed a scary place to be, if you were in the wrong neighborhood.

Here’s an article from Village Voice describing the crime rates back in the day.

A stick-up kid is generally a younger kid with a gun who could not give a fuck less who he robs. Think Biggie a la “Gimme The Loot.”

annotations.text: .45’s and gauges, MAC's in fact
annotations.annotation: He’s listing the various guns that “stickup kids” use to conduct their dirty business: .45 caliber guns, shotguns and the MAC-10.

annotations.text:
Same niggas will catch you back-to-back, snatchin' your cracks
 In black
annotations.annotation:
The same nigga who caught you during the day will catch you again that same night. They’re “snatching your cracks in black” because it’s nighttime, as opposed to running up on you “in broad daylight.”

“Back-to-back” may also refer to back-to-back sentences, often doled out for violent crimes with multiple victims.

annotations.text:
There was a snitch on the block gettin' niggas knocked
 So hold your stash 'til the coke price drop
annotations.annotation:
Nobody likes a snitch!

So, hang onto the product you’ve got left; when the price goes back down, it’ll be safer to re-up then because of less attention from the authorities. When the Narc Squad is busting the big dealers, the prices SKYROCKET. This could be seen as a worthwhile risk for someone looking for a comeup, but Nas is saying to play it smart and wait ‘til shit cools down.

Well said, Mr. Jones.

annotations.text:
I know this crackhead who said she gotta smoke nice rock
 And if it's good, she'll bring you customers and measuring pots
annotations.annotation:
Double Entendre…


If you please this crackhead with good crack rock, she will give you such good reputation with her fellow crackheads that you will need to use measuring pots to supply them all:






Nas is saying that the customers will be “in measuring pots” because it implies that they are trapped and ‘on a plate’, being completely controlled by the dealers, i.e they will be hooked and bring in regular revenue.



“Bring you costumers in measuring pots!” is a reference to how they cook crack. It’s like saying “Bring you customers by the dozen”.

annotations.text:
But yo, you gotta slide on a vacation
 Inside information keeps large niggas erasin' and their wives basin'
annotations.annotation: Nas suggests that you lay low (“slide on a vacation”) for a while, since there’s a snitch in the organization using “inside information” to send important (“large”) people to jail, thus causing their wives to smoke crack (“basin'” – viz. freebasing, aka smoking freebase cocaine or crack) in order to cope with the loneliness.

annotations.text: I never sleep, 'cause sleep is the cousin of death
annotations.annotation:
A truly classic rap line evoking ghetto drug dealers' “one eye open” sense of paranoia; perhaps inspired by the Talmud (which tells us sleep is 1/60th of death) or the Iliad (where Hypnos and Thanatos – i.e., “sleep” and “death” – are described as brothers)

This line’s 1st degree meaning is evident: sleep is a deathlike, inert state of consciousness

At the 2nd degree, “sleeping” is slang for being inattentive or negligent; a drug dealer who is robbed for lack of vigilance is said to be “caught sleeping”

Nas never “sleeps” – i.e., he’s never “caught sleeping” – because being an easy target could lead him to getting shot to death.

And, to top it all off, what’s New York City’s nickname?

annotations.text: Beyond the walls of intelligence, life is defined
annotations.annotation:
Similar to Aldous Huxley’s theory in The Doors of Perception – intelligence limits our vision, rather than creating it.

Walls of intelligence could also refer to surveillance, that people in the streets are living there beyond the walls of intelligence set up by law enforcement, hence life is defined beyond the grasp of the authorities.

Yet another interpretation could be to define the walls of intelligence as a metaphor for the cranium in that life is defined within the mind.

annotations.text: I think of crime when I'm in a New York State of Mind
annotations.annotation:
When he is thinking about New York he can only envision the crime and drug dealing in that city, while others may look at the bright lights and opportunities the city conveys.



Whenever Nas thinks of his origins in New York he is reminded of the crime that he grew up with. Shows the darker side of N.Y. City, while many artists like Sinatra brought light to the positives about N.Y. Nas shows N.Y. isn’t all “peaches and cream.”

annotations.text:
New York state of mind
 New York state of mind
 New York state of mind
annotations.annotation: The hook is from Rakim’s “Mahogany” – as Steve “Flash” Juon writes, it was the “Rakim sample on the chorus that provided the mental link for an analogy most rap heads had already made by now: Nas was the NEW Rakim on the block.”

annotations.text:
[Verse 2]
 Be havin' dreams that I'm a gangsta, drinkin' Moëts, holdin' TEC's
annotations.annotation:
The first four lines of this verse are taken from the opening to “Just Another Day in the Projects”, an unreleased song from his demo tape.

Here Nas narrates a fantasy sequence on being a “gangster” (used here to mean “baller with a lot of money”).

annotations.text: Investments in stocks,
annotations.annotation:
Illmatic was released in 1994, right before the (Clinton-inspired) 6-year stock boom, so Nas would have had some great buying opportunities. Moar like Nasty NAS-DAQ amirite?

But alas, it’s just a dream.

Also steppin it up, he invested ca$h into stock — inventory of drugs and guns — to have what he needed to be a large seller…big time dealer, a gangsta

annotations.text:
Sewin' up the blocks to sell rocks
 Winnin' gunfights with mega-cops
annotations.annotation:
Even if Nas were to go semi-legit, he would still want selling crack rocks and shooting police to be part of his routine

“Sewing up the blocks” means taking over territory to sell rocks, in other words owning blocks for the purpose of selling rocks, no one can sell on that territory if it aint his package

annotations.text: But just a nigga walkin' with his finger on the trigger
annotations.annotation:
In the preceding four bars, while Nas raps about his dream, producer DJ Premier takes the piano loop out and just plays the beep sound

When the beep sound goes off, Nas snaps back to reality by saying “but just a nigga walking with his finger on the trigger”

The ‘beep sound’ symbolises an alarm. Like in the morning where your alarm helps you make the transition out of sleep and in to reality.

annotations.text: Make enough figures until my pockets get bigger
annotations.annotation:
At this point he’s got to do all he can to make money, but perhaps once he got more cash, he can  stop having to do “small” dangerous things just to get by.

This “figure”/“bigger” rhyme was used in QB native Marley Marl’s posse cut song, The Symphony, where Big Daddy Kane says,

The trigger, ya figure, my pockets gettin' bigger

annotations.text: I ain't the type of brother made for you to start testin'
annotations.annotation:
As this song is about the rough way of life in New York, Nas is illustrating his mentality. You don’t want to challenge him because his environment forced him to be tough both physically and mentally.

This line – coupled with a preceding phrase in the song, “‘Cause sleep is the cousin of death” – would later be sampled in the song “The Message” on his 1996 sophomore album, It Was Written.

The line also has a great lyrical value. As the previous line ends with the word “bigger”, you would expect Nas to say “nigger” instead of “brother”.

This unique style is often used by MF DOOM.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KfwYpJToTYI&t=0m7s

annotations.text: Give me a Smith & Wesson, I'll have niggas undressin'
annotations.annotation:
As in Nas will use the gun to rob people, forcing them to strip to give him all their valuables (Biggie has a similar line on “Gimme the Loot”)

This line originates from a Nas' song “I’m a Villain” from his 1991 demo tape



For a visual representation…

annotations.text: Thinkin' of cash flow, Buddha and shelter
annotations.annotation:
The bare essentials of life: cash, weed, and a pot to piss in

Buddha might also refer to how Buddhists try to live ‘the middle way,’ which means they stick to the absolute necessities for survival.

annotations.text: Whenever frustrated, I'ma hijack Delta
annotations.annotation:
This line calls back to one of the earliest terrorism references in rap, from Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five’s “The Message”:

Sometimes I think I’m going insane
I swear I might hijack a plane!

Delta specifically suffered a dozen hijackings throughout the 1970s and 1980s.



Nas might be specifically referring to the hijacking of Delta Airlines 841 by the Black Liberation Army in 1972.

annotations.text:
Plus the Island is packed
 From what I hear in all the stories when my peoples come back
annotations.annotation:
Riker’s Island (“the Island”) is a major prison in NYC.

This line is also a callback to the previous line, as the prison, like the projects, is another place where “black rats” are trapped

annotations.text:
And lamp like Capone, with drug scripts sewn
 Or the legal luxury life, rings flooded with stones, homes
annotations.annotation: Lamp is slang for relax and chill. Nas would give up this life of crime he glamorizes for a legal luxury life. He would love to sit back with riches, legal or illegal. But living normally, he would only do it illegal.

annotations.text: I got so many rhymes, I don't think I'm too sane
annotations.annotation: It is a common experience of artists, especially those who work in an improvisational form, to experience periods of great creativity as akin to madness. The sheer volume of material – in Nas’s case, of lyrics – can feel as though it is coming from without, leaving the artist to suspect he may be mentally abnormal.

annotations.text: Life is parallel to Hell, but I must maintain
annotations.annotation:
There are different ways to interpret what “parallel” does here, but the best explanation is that Nas is using parallel to mean “roughly analogous” – that is, he must “maintain” even though life on the streets of Queens is so trying and violent as to border on the demonic.

Still from Jacob’s Ladder (1990)

annotations.text: It's only right that I was born to use mics
annotations.annotation:
This line has been subsequently referenced by Elzhi, and is sampled at the end of L-Fudge’s “Show Me Gratitude.”

This was used as the title of a collection of academic essays analyzing Illmatic.

annotations.text: And the stuff that I write is even tougher than dykes
annotations.annotation:
Two possible meanings:

[1] Dyke = slang for lesbian (from “bulldyke”). Lesbians are often thought to be more masculine — “tougher” — than other girls.



[2] Dyke = a man-made levee, essentially a wall that regulates water levels and prevents flooding in places that are at or below sea-level. These dykes are often made as stone, and tend to be pretty “tough” as they’re holding back the whole damn ocean.

Should have used a Nas verse homie

annotations.text: My rhymin' is a vitamin held without a capsule
annotations.annotation:
A vitamin “without a capsule” goes down more easily; it is also more pure, less adulterated. Nas is arguably advancing both ideas about his own style; it goes down more easily, meaning it is more accessible to the average listener, and it is more “raw,” thus closer to the streets than the rap of manufactured studio gangsters.

Nas also alludes to his stage name at the time, Nasty Nas, since chewing on a multi-vitamin produces a really nasty taste in your mouth.



A vitamin held without a capsule is just powder, which looks might look like cocaine or heroin, AKA dope. So his lyrics are dope…get it?

annotations.text: The smooth criminal on beat breaks
annotations.annotation:
Like Michael Jackson’s dance moves, Nas' raps syncopate with the rhythm of the music



Also, in a more literal sense, everything but the drums cut out for this line – a beat break in the classic sense.

annotations.text: Never put me in your box if your shit eats tapes
annotations.annotation:
Okay young ones, hop up on Grandpa’s lap and let me tell you a story about back in the day.

Ya see, before the mid/late 1990’s, we used to listen to music on Cassette Tapes. They came in a few forms: there was the LP Cassette which was the whole album, EP Cassettes (guess what those were?), and Cassingles, which usually contained one song and a few remixes or B-Sides.



Cassette players work by reading the long ribbon of tape spooled up inside the cassette, dragging it along the capstan/transport at the proper speed to reproduce audio. Usually they worked great; they could sound a little muddly, but for the most part they were nearly as good as Vinyl records and CDs.



HOWEVER, some cassette players just sucked ass, and the transport would malfunction causing the tape ribbon to get mauled and pulled through the gears. If you were lucky, you could gently pull it out and re-wrap the tape; if you werent, it could “pop” your tape, severing the ribbon. You could repair it with a piece of Scotch tape, but it would often just pop back out again, causing you to need to buy a new tape.



Kinda makes you grateful for MP3 and FLAC these days, eh?

annotations.text: I'm a addict for sneakers, 20's of Buddha and bitches with beepers
annotations.annotation:
Nas has moved on from the earlier essentials of money, drugs, and putting a roof over his head to sneakers, drugs, and women who are always available via pager for booty calls.

“20’s of buddah” means a $20 bag of weed.

Nas must have loved MySpace



There’s also an alliteration on the letter B: buddha, bitches, beepers.

annotations.text:
In the streets I can greet ya, about blunts I teach ya
 Inhale deep like the words of my breath
annotations.annotation:
Breathe Nas' words in deep. Listen closely because his words are as deep as his hits

It drops deep like it does in my breath

Every track on Illmatic alludes to Nas' love of cannabis at least once

annotations.text: I never sleep, 'cause sleep is the cousin of death
annotations.annotation:
A truly classic rap line evoking ghetto drug dealers' “one eye open” sense of paranoia; perhaps inspired by the Talmud (which tells us sleep is 1/60th of death) or the Iliad (where Hypnos and Thanatos – i.e., “sleep” and “death” – are described as brothers)

This line’s 1st degree meaning is evident: sleep is a deathlike, inert state of consciousness

At the 2nd degree, “sleeping” is slang for being inattentive or negligent; a drug dealer who is robbed for lack of vigilance is said to be “caught sleeping”

Nas never “sleeps” – i.e., he’s never “caught sleeping” – because being an easy target could lead him to getting shot to death.

And, to top it all off, what’s New York City’s nickname?

annotations.text: I lay puzzled as I backtrack to earlier times
annotations.annotation:
Double entendre:


“I lay puzzle as I backtrack to earlier times” means that when Nas thinks back on his life in Queens, he puts the pieces together like one would when laying out and putting together a jigsaw puzzle.
But there’s also a double meaning here, seeing as “lay puzzle” sounds close enough to “lay puzzled” – which would suggest that Nas is “puzzled” – confused at a difficult situation, when he thinks of his life in Queens, NY.

annotations.text:
New York state of mind
 New York state of mind
 New York state of mind
annotations.annotation: The hook is from Rakim’s “Mahogany” – as Steve “Flash” Juon writes, it was the “Rakim sample on the chorus that provided the mental link for an analogy most rap heads had already made by now: Nas was the NEW Rakim on the block.”

annotations.text: "Nasty Nas—"
annotations.annotation:
Three years prior to Illmatic in 1991, Nas uttered, “Nasty Nas is a rebel to America,” in Main Source’s “Live at the Barbeque.” DJ Premier isolated the sample to “Nasty Nas” and scratched it to conclude “N.Y. State of Mind.”

Sample origin

Sample usage

annotations.text:
You can be as good as the best of them
 But as bad as the worst, so don't test me (Get money)
 You better move over (Get money)
annotations.annotation:
The second half of the chorus contains an interpolation of “Don’t Test Me” by Shabba Ranks featuring Deborahe Glasgow. The same line had also been interpolated by Top Dog of O.G.C. in the song “The Worst”, which was released the same year.

O.G.C. performed “The Worst” for the first time at a concert at The Palladium in New York City, which was attended by The Notorious B.I.G. and Junior Mafia. In the days that followed, this “Get Money” remix by Junior Mafia was released with the same interpolation. Some members of O.G.C. and their collective, the Boot Camp Clik, felt that B.I.G. stole Top Dog’s idea, so they hired B.I.G. & Faith Evans lookalikes for the music video of their next single, “No Fear”. The video depicted B.I.G. being tossed off stage à la KRS-One at the P.M. Dawn concert in 1992.



The music video would eventually lead to Starang Wondah of O.G.C. being jumped by members of Junior Mafia at D&D Studios. According to Steele of Smif-n-Wessun, the beef was eventually squashed and chalked up to immaturity by members of his crew & their desire to make a name for themselves

annotations.text: [Produced by The Neptunes]
annotations.annotation:
Here’s a scene from the Jay Z documentary Fade to Black, where Pharrell introduces Hov to the fire beat he just made:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7JgrX0aC6hQ

annotations.text:
The allure of breaking the law
 Was always too much for me to ever ignore
annotations.annotation:
The allure JAY refers to in this song is more than the thrill of committing crimes for profit.  It is the idea of challenging the rules of establishment for the betterment of oneself.  Mr Carter’s occupation has always been outside of normal society’s standards, after all “a nigga never had a job.”



JAY still chases the allure to this day, challenging the way records are sold electronically and the recording industry sadly has yet to catch up to the #newrules.

It was also the allure that caused Jigga to come back after his botched retirement following The Black Album.  Kind of an ironic song to appear on his supposed last album.

annotations.text: In love with a V-Dub engine
annotations.annotation:
“V-Dub” can refer to either:


Volkswagen (the official European hoopty) or its subsidiary brands Audi, Lamborghini, Bugatti and Bentley
Alternatively, lots of motorcycles use a V-twin engine configuration

annotations.text: Bathing Ape kicks,
annotations.annotation: A Bathing Ape is a Japanese clothing company that specializes in streetwear. They also make sneakers, though it’s hard to imagine a grown man wearing them:

annotations.text: Without saying a word, the ghetto's got a mental telepathy
annotations.annotation:
The ghetto and the ghetto life that he used to lead as a dope dealer speaks to him and crosses his mind everyday. It’s not physically speaking to him with words, so it’s almost like telepathic communication.

His introduction to the dope game also wasn’t strictly outlined, it was just assumed that Jay would take after his brother. As he mentions on “Sweet”

If I would have grew up to be a doctor
My nephews would have grew up to do the same

annotations.text: Shit, I know how this movie ends, still I play
annotations.annotation: This is related to the “Carlito’s Way” movie reference in the next line: the film —just like many more notable ones— begins with its ending, showing the title character played by Al Pacino being shot point blank at New York’s Grand Central Station.

annotations.text: The starring role in "Hovito's Way"
annotations.annotation:
Play on the title of the Al Pacino mafia movie Carlito’s Way (“HOVA” is Jay-Z’s nicknames; he also goes by “El Hovito” when he’s feeling Latin)

Pharrell inspired this line : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tBErwXE-0Yo

annotations.text: It's just life, I solemnly swear
annotations.annotation:
Young Hov puts himself under oath.  It assures the listener that he is committed to telling the truth.

This album dropped in 2003, close to the time his relationship with Beyonce was becoming more public.  He is struggling with the idea of letting go of the street life. His days of “Big Pimpin'” and multiple relationships are coming to an end.

annotations.text: Put down the toast
annotations.annotation:
“Toast” can mean:


He’s going to stop “proposing toasts” and drinking champagne! (it’s just empty calories)
Could also refer to a gun
Jamaican MC “toasting” was an early form of rapping. Since Jay intended to retire from rapping after The Black Album, he would be putting down the “toast”

annotations.text: Cause I be doing the most (Oh no!)
annotations.annotation: I’m pretty sure he’s sayin Mos not “most” and is referring to https://genius.com/Yasiin-bey-oh-no-lyrics Mos Def, Nate Dogg and Pharaohe Monchs Lyricist Lounge Song “Oh no”

annotations.text: Until I'm under the field with Hoffa, it's real
annotations.annotation: Jimmy Hoffa, a union leader who mysteriously disappeared, possibly because of mob connections, is widely thought to be buried underneath Giants Stadium

annotations.text: Peel the top up like a toupée,
annotations.annotation: Someone explain?

annotations.text: All of y'all can get it like group-page on your two-way
annotations.annotation:
“It” refers to either the crack-cocaine from the previous line (viz. Jay has enough crack to sell to all the addicts), or the profits from selling the drugs (viz. Jay’s friends can all profit from his drug sales).

Jay then compares this cornucopia to multiple people receiving a page from a two-way pager, so-called because the original pagers could only receive a message (you would have to call back), while two-ways allowed the recipient of the message to send a page back.

Pagers were famously popular among drug dealers in the era before cell phones, which is likely how Jigga became familiar with them.



Jay-Z using a two-way pager

annotations.text: I'm living proof that crime do pay
annotations.annotation:
“I made money selling drugs without going to jail, then I made even more money rapping about my experience selling drugs”

Obviously he disagrees with the saying “crime doesn’t pay”. Cam'ron feels the same way  – his 2009 album is called Crime Pays.

annotations.text:
And all the broads
 Putting cars in their name, for the stars of the game
 Putting 'caine in their bras and their tomorrows on the train:
annotations.annotation:
He is thanking the girls who serve him by risking their futures (“tomorrows”) by smuggling cocaine on the Amtrak for him in exchange for him buying them cars (or putting Jay-Z’s cars in their name for tax reasons)

Also notice the reversed internal rhyme – cars/name – caine/bras

This is a topic Biggie was also fond of rapping about (see “Me and My Bitch,” “My Downfall”)

annotations.text:
But the allure of the game, keeps calling your name
 To all the Lauras of the world, I feel your pain
 To all the Christies in different cities and Tiffany Lanes:
 We all hustlers in love with the same thing
annotations.annotation:
His sympathy for “Tiffany Lane” is directed towards (female) rapper Charli Baltimore, whose real name is Tiffany Lane. She was dating Un Rivera aka “Uncle Paulie” (a tagalong to the Notorious BIG) and – as revealed by Cam'ron – cheated on him with Jay-Z (insulting!)



Ms. Lane

Jay-Z was later accused of stabbing Un Rivera over “bootlegging” his album so – as Cam'ron sagely explains – it was actually over Charli

More generally speaking, Jay-Z is subverting gender roles. “Laura”, “Christie” and “Tiffany Lane” sound like typical names for materialistic, daddy’s girl Upper East Side JAPs

His message to such girls is, “O Women: Behold! We are not so different, you and I…we like money, and the things we can buy with it”

Young Hov puts himself under oath.  It assures the listener that he is committed to telling the truth.

He’s going to stop “proposing toasts” and drinking champagne! (it’s just empty calories)

annotations.text:
I never felt more alive than riding shotgun
 In Klein's green 5, until the cops pulled guns
annotations.annotation:
A reference to Calvin “Klein” Bacote, a Brooklyn stick-up kid turned drug kingpin as pat of the Marcy Posse. Klein and a young Shawn Carter ran together in the ‘80s selling crack cocaine. The line is referring to when Hov and Klein were arrested together while driving in the Brooklyn Don’s green BMW E34 sedan.



In 1989 they were at a house party in Maryland when a fight broke out between their crew and the hosts. They were arrested and charged with attempted murder, attempted murder to maim, battery assault, and possession of a deadly weapon.

Klein paid the victim $50,000 in return for him dropping the charges on one of the two. Klein already had prior attempted murder convictions, so Jay offered to take the charges and stand trial in his place. Luckily for us, Klein recognized Hov’s rap potential and took the weight of the case. Hov was acquitted and released. He would later testify on Klein’s behalf and help his 40-year sentence be reduced to four years.



After being released on drug convictions in 2004 Klein claimed that Hov embellished his past in his raps:

I give him 10% of his life that he talked about. He is from Brooklyn, he lived in Marcy Projects, his name is Shawn Carter, he got that right. Calvin Klein, a Brooklyn Don, my legacy speaks for itself. Jay had to take parts of that in order to be who he is.

Later, in a 2014 interview with Complex, Klein recanted on his earlier statements:

You have to kind of look at his history. How many times have you caught him in a lie? You have to give him the benefit of the doubt … Was Jay-Z a good hustler? I’m a hell of a hustler too, but he’s a hell of a hustler. You gotta give it to him. He took nothing and turned it into something.

annotations.text:
I mean even James Dean couldn't escape the allure
 Dying young, leaving a good-looking corpse
 Of course...
annotations.annotation:
The quote “Live fast. Die young. Leave a good-looking corpse” is often misattributed to James Dean, probably because he died in a car accident when he was 24 (and in the prime of his acting career)

Jay-Z references Dean as an example of someone who, like Jay, cannot escape the “allure” of “living fast”, even though it leads to his ruin

Also the line “Die young, leave a good-lookin corpse” is in the opening monologue of the movie True Romance (Jay-Z has mentioned on twitter that this is his favorite movie).

annotations.text: And why them dudes ain't ridin' if they part of your set?
annotations.annotation:
If those guys are part of your set (in your gang/team) why aren’t they riding with you (have your back when fights/shootings/beef happen)

Or…“why aren’t you buying your closest guy friends cars like a baller is supposed to?” (Cf. Jay-Z’s “Nobody will fall cause everyone will be each others crutches” from “Feelin' It”)

annotations.text: And why they never get it poppin' but they party to death?
annotations.annotation: Jadakiss is pointing out how a lot of crew members don’t put in the work but celebrates the team’s success the most.

Good call, Jada. With stronger gun control laws, maybe we could prevent some killings. Otherwise, we’re letting would-be murderers out of prison in only 8 months. Now they’re free to go commit that murder!

annotations.text: Why they sellin' niggas' CD's for under a dime?
annotations.annotation: He questions why record stores sell the records at such a low price, giving the rappers less profit and making a life of drug dealing (selling dimes) more lucrative.

annotations.text: And if it's all love, daddy, why you come with your 9?
annotations.annotation:
People in dangerous neighborhoods (which Jada is no stranger to) can grow to be rather cynical and untrusting over time. Essentially, Jada is asking “if we friends, why do you arm yourself to come kick it with me?”

The reality of it is that this friend, “daddy”, feels he still can’t really trust Jada; and this makes Jada feel like he can’t trust him. The untrust just breeds more untrust and tension when there is none. This helps destabilize black communities which rich white people love to see.

A “nine” is a reference to a 9mm handgun

annotations.text:
Why is a brother up north better than Jordan
 That ain't get that break?
annotations.annotation:
A lamentation of how the imprisonment of so many young black males is leading to unrealized potential: why is there some guy who could’ve been a better basketball player than Michael Jordan up north (in prison) because he never got a break?



This could be a great example.

annotations.text: Why you don't stack instead of tryin' to be fly?
annotations.annotation:
“Why don’t you save rather than spend?” Ok Jadakiss you’re not my father, geez…

In all seriousness, this bar reflects on the materialistic mind-state of most people who get their hands on some money. Instead of burning a hole in your pocket, you could really put it towards good use such as savings & maybe later an investment. Instead of having good money management, most people blow through it.

annotations.text: Why they kill 2Pac and Chris?
annotations.annotation: Chris is a nickname for The Notorious B.I.G because his real name is Christopher Wallace

annotations.text: Why at the bar you ain't take straight shots instead of poppin' Cris?
annotations.annotation:
Everyone loves champagne, but this lyric has a double meaning which is made clearer by it being sandwiched between the lyrics about Christopher Wallace’s death.

Yes, if you wanna have a good night, shots are cheaper and more effective than champagne, but when he says poppin Chris he refers to killing Christopher Wallace, aka B.I.G., outside of an after-party in Los Angeles. Why didn’t you take some “shots” at the bar – i.e. shoot up the club – instead of leaving and then taking out your anger on a rap legend?

annotations.text:
Why did Kobe have to hit that raw? Why'd he kiss that whore?
 Why?!
annotations.annotation:
In July 2003, about a year before Jadakiss released this song, NBA superstar Kobe Bryant was arrested in connection with the sexual assault of a 19-year-old hotel employee. Bryant admitted to having sexual relations with the woman, but denied rape accusations—although he did later issue an apology wherein he acknowledged he understood how she “[felt] she did not consent”:

After months of reviewing discovery, listening to her attorney, and even her testimony in person, I now understand how she feels that she did not consent to this encounter.

Here, though, Jada seems less concerned with the well-being of the accuser and the facts of the case—instead, he cares about how the accusations affected Bryant’s basketball career.

Although the case was ultimately dropped because Bryant’s accuser refused to testify, it continued to damage his reputation, even popping back into the media spotlight over a decade-and-a-half later in a Washington Post article following his win at the 2018 Oscars for his animated short “Dear Basketball.”

annotations.text: Why did Bush knock down the towers?
annotations.annotation: Jadakiss apparently believes Bush was responsible for 9/11.  A truther! This accusation led to calls for this song to be banned from radio, which only added to Jada’s rebel appeal.

annotations.text: Why Aaliyah have to take that flight?
annotations.annotation: Former R&B star who died in a plane crash at the peak of her career

annotations.text:
Why my nigga D ain't pull out his Ferrari?
 Why he take that bike?
annotations.annotation:
Darrin “D” Dean, one of the co-founders of Ruff Ryders Entertainment (who Jada is signed to), was in a very serious motorcycle accident. Thankfully, he survived it

Jadakiss wishes he had played it safe by driving his Ferrari instead of his motorcycle

annotations.text:
Why they gotta open your package and read your mail?
 Why they stop lettin' niggas get degrees in jail?
annotations.annotation:
Prisoners forfeit their rights, it’s the point of incarceration, however, rehabilitation is what jail is supposed to afford, and acquiring a degree is a fine example of that, especially when the length of most incarcerations are longer than it takes to earn a 4 year college degree anyway.

Why they gotta open your packets, and read your mail?

annotations.text: Why you gotta do 85% of your time?
annotations.annotation:
In New York State, a person convicted and sentenced to a determinate sentence under Penal Law 70.00(6) is eligible for a 1/7 good time reduction in his/her sentence.  See Corr. Law §803(1)(c)

As a result, the default is that people on determinate sentences only serve 6/7 of the time they’re sentenced to (and 6/7=.857 or 85% rounding down).  So if you behave in prison you do 85% of your time (which, as Jadakiss points out, is still a lot and still really sucks!)

annotations.text: And why do niggas lie in 85% of they rhymes?
annotations.annotation:
There are certain rappers nowadays that rap about what they don’t live, or what they don’t have. Some lie about being a gangster, having money, etc.
Jadakiss is saying that we shouldn’t do that and we should stick to the truth, because at the end of the day, it will backfire.

annotations.text: Why a nigga always want what he can't have?
annotations.annotation: This is not at all specific to the inner-city black man, nor can hip-hop culture actually be cited as a reason for this. Greed, and coveting your neighbors possessions are original sins that go back to the bible. Even when bling was sheep, men could be found killing in order to get that fly new fleece.

annotations.text: Why I can't come through in the pecan Jag?
annotations.annotation:
The thought of really really wanting to ride in a pecan Jaguar but knowing people won’t approve of it is pretty funny

Similar to George from Seinfeld’s desire to drape himself entirely in velvet if it were socially acceptable

The Jaguar pictured below is actually more of a rich walnut

annotations.text:
Why they let the Terminator win the election?
 Come on, pay attention!
annotations.annotation:
He’s asking How did Arnold become governor, when the prior governor was ousted due to fiscal ineptitude. Arnold holds no degrees in finance, policy, or law. He’d also never held an elected office before this and was handed the highest office in the state of California. The second line criticizes the political apathy that made this travesty possible.

Actual Terminators seized power in a coup d'etat

annotations.text: Why I sell in the stores what you could sell in the streets?
annotations.annotation:
A reference to his low commercial sales; he’s only selling as many albums as he could sell via street mixtapes

He’s frustrated because one major advantage of signing to a record label is to get promotion to boost sales, but that doesn’t seem to actually be happening.  Also, rappers make more money per mixtape CD sold than per commercially released CD, so Jadakiss is probably losing money under his record deal

This could also be a double meaning, hinting that he’s selling dope music like dealers sell dope on the streets.

annotations.text: Why I say the hottest shit but be sellin' the least? why
annotations.annotation: Jada and his crew, The Lox, are not as commercially successful as he thinks they should be

annotations.text: [Verse 3: Jadakiss]
annotations.annotation:
Apparently, ‘Kiss has gotten a bit wiser as the song went by, because in the third verse he can finally answer some of his questions:

“Why rap? ‘Cause I need air time”

“Why all the young niggas is dyin'? ‘Cause they moms at work, they pops is gone, they livin' with iron”

“And you know why they made the new twenties?
‘Cause I got all the old ones—that’s why!”

annotations.text: Why Halle have to let a white man pop her to get a Oscar?
annotations.annotation:
Halle Berry didn’t win an Oscar until Monster’s Ball, in which she has a graphic sex scene with Billy Bob Thornton:



Incidentally, her character’s dead husband is played by Puff Daddy, who Jada hates, so maybe that influenced his perception of the movie

annotations.text: Why Denzel have to be crooked before he took it?
annotations.annotation:
Although Denzel won a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his role in “Glory” (1989), he didn’t win for Best Actor until “Training Day,” – in which he plays a crooked cop – which was nowhere near his best performance. Many fans thought he should’ve won in 1992 for Malcolm X where he played a more respectable yet anti-establishment role as the titular character. He became the second African-American to win the award, after Sidney Poitier’s 1963 win for “Lillies of the Field” (nowhere near his best performance, either).

Jadakiss is pointing out that blacks in the industry can get awards only if they either subjugate themselves to whites (by getting fucked), or conform to stereotypes (by playing criminals)

annotations.text: Why they didn't make the CL6 with a clutch?
annotations.annotation: Why isn’t there a version of the Mercedes Benz CL600 with a manual transmission?

annotations.text:
And if you don't smoke
 Then why the hell you reachin' for my dutch?!
annotations.annotation:
If you don’t smoke, why are you reaching for my blunt (Dutches are Dutch Masters, used for rolling blunts)?

(Probably because you told Jada you don’t smoke, but changed your mind when you smelled the potency of what he was rolling)

annotations.text:
Why all the young niggas is dyin'?
 ‘Cause they moms at work
 They pops is gone,
annotations.annotation: A lot of kids go without fathers, forcing the mother to compensate, which means they have to work more to support the household.  Thus, the children spend more time home alone.

annotations.text: They livin' with iron
annotations.annotation:
No, they’re not taking too many Flintstones vitamins. They have guns in the house

That Pepper Potts lifestyle

annotations.text: Why they ain't give us a cure for AIDS?
annotations.annotation:
Well, H.I.V. is a mutagenic virus so it’s really really hard to cure

Jada seems to be pushing the conspiracy theory that AIDS was created by the government to weaken the black community and that there is a cure being kept hidden. This is consonant with his 9/11 Trutherism.

A more charitable explanation is that Jada is suggesting that the government has not adequately invested in AIDS research because it affects mostly marginal communities (blacks and gays), which would have been a defensible point until the late 1990s.

annotations.text: Why my diesel have fiends in the spot on the floor for days?
annotations.annotation:
Jadakiss' product is so awesome that fiends fall out after shooting it up right after copping.

Diesel refers to high potency “gray uncut diesel” heroin.

annotations.text: Why you screamin' like it's a slug? It's only the hawk
annotations.annotation:
A “hawk” is a knife, so Jada is asking “why are you screaming like I shot you? I only stabbed you! Geez, drama queen.”

It’s only The Hawk

annotations.text: Why my buzz in L.A. ain't like it is in New York?
annotations.annotation:
Jadakiss has never really crossed over from famous New York rapper to famous rapper

Jada has nice buzz in New York, but…

annotations.text:
Why they forcin' you to be hard?
 Why ain't you a thug by choice?
annotations.annotation: The point he’s making here is that so many of these gangsta rappers are purely manufactured to project that image. Not because they actually have the hard luck stories they rhyme about in their songs, when there exists so many actual underground rappers who really do have those stories that could have that record deal instead.

annotations.text:
Why the whole world love my voice?
 Why? Try to tell 'em that it's the flow, son
annotations.annotation: Jada attempts to explain why people love his “voice” saying that it’s not the sound of his voice per se, but rather his “voice” as the means by which he espouses knowledge in a skillfully lyrical form.

annotations.text:
And you know why they made the new twenties?
 ‘Cause I got all the old ones — that's why!
annotations.annotation:
In 1998 the fed redesigned the $20 bill in order to make counterfeiting more difficult

Jadakiss suggests that the real reason they needed new twenties was not to stymie counterfeiters, but rather because he had all the old ones

Also notice that this is the only “why” in the song that is phrased as an explanation (“and you know why”) rather than a question (“why…?”). The idea being that, though the world is a confusing place, one thing is clear: Jadakiss has a lot of money

Old twenty:



New twenty:



If you like the old ones, Jada is selling some of his vintage $20 bills for $25 on his website.

annotations.text: It's late fall, dime season
annotations.annotation: Dimes of drugs are bags worth $10. Apparently demand goes up in late fall – probably the college students

annotations.text:
We bought the crib next to Bill Clinton' mother
 'Cause she fuck with the Chinese
annotations.annotation:
It is thought that during the 80s and 90s the biggest importers of cocaine and heroin to NYC were the Chinese. Now, inn this context, “Bill Clinton’s mother” means Virginia (Clinton Kelley). So, Raekwon and co. have bought a spot out in Virginia to be closer to Baltimore in Maryland (hence next to Bill Clinton mother) in order to have a steady access to a supply of “china white”, better known as heroin.

Interesting side note: China white also goes by the name of china cat, hence how we got this ridiculous scene…

annotations.text: [Verse 2: Ghostface Killah]
annotations.annotation:
In 2009 the website HipHopDX marked this verse as the verse of the year.

It wrote about it:

Ghost has never been a technical marvel on the mic, rarely has he ever conjured up images of Black Thought putting class in session. Tony’s genius has come in his emotive rhymes and his vivid and often hilarious storytelling. His show stealing verse on Rae’s “Gihad” is certainly one of his best; a father-son moment only Ghost could describe.

16 years after Only Built 4 Cuban Linx… being released, Ghost is still a beast.

annotations.text: But on the other side of town, it's Tony, laid up (Ugh)
annotations.annotation:
Ghostface is also known as Tony Starks/Pretty Toney (hence the name of his The Pretty Toney album)

He establishes the setting of his story in relation to the one Raekwon told in his verse – they are happening at the same time but in different parts of the same city – Rae and Ghost are excellent at little storytelling touches like this

annotations.text:
"Chill! She's a whore!
 You knew it from the time we ran trains on her
 And you still went and fucked her raw?
annotations.annotation:
When a bunch of people take turns with a girl, that’s called running a train.  He’s saying the girl was known to be a slut and his son still had sex with her without a condom, thus impregnating her.  He can’t really get mad at Ghost for hooking up with his baby’s mother, it’s his fault for getting attached to such a skank

There is a connection to Ghost’s song “Street Opera” here which features his biological son, rapper Sun God. The last line of that song is:

We ran trains for hours, up in the Days Inn
Hood rats and crack motels, we seen baking

Most dads just take their sons fishing or something…

annotations.text: Remember Vel' had her in the telly, taking the fist?
annotations.annotation: As additional evidence she was already a whore: we know a guy who fisted her in a hotel room! (telly is slang for hotel)

annotations.text: Bag this shit up, nigga. Word up. I don't give a fuck if you 25, nigga. You my son, nigga. Word up. That's why I let you slide
annotations.annotation:
Even though he’s 25, Ghost’s son still has to listen to what Ghost tells him (in this case, an order to bag up some of Ghost’s drugs for him). Ghost explains that the father/son bond he feels is the only reason why he didn’t kill his son, so his son should feel thankful

Strange thing is, at the time of this album’s release Ghost was 39 years old, meaning he would have fathered a son at age 14. For some this would be a clear indication that the man is not actually his son, but we wouldn’t be the least bit surprised to know Ghost was a father before some men hit puberty

annotations.text: What we have to do is deal with it when these individuals are young enough, if you will, to be saved, not in a religious sense, but not to constitute what this country at times calls (Yeah) their throwaway children
annotations.annotation:
This speech is sampled from the 2002 documentary Culture of Hate: Who Are We?, directed by Lee Harvey. The first part (occurring at 21:12 in the movie) is from Morris Casuto, the San Diego Regional Director of the Anti-Defamation League, while the second part (33:12 in the movie) is from Randy Blazak, Professor of Sociology at Portland State University.

Eminem allegedly asked for permission to use Casuto’s voice on the track, which the latter agreed to, providing Eminem sent two copies of the Encore album for Casuto’s sons.

annotations.text: We seem to be approaching (C'mon!) an age of the gross (*Burp*)
annotations.annotation:
This is a line spoken by former US Vice President Spiro Agnew in a speech condemning the approach of protesters who opposed the Vietnam War. In fuller context (emphasis ours):

Sometimes it appears that we are reaching a period when our senses and our minds will no longer respond to moderate stimulation. We seem to be approaching an age of the gross. Persuasion through speeches and books is too often discarded for disruptive demonstrations aimed at bludgeoning the unconvinced into action.

Em injects some irony into the track when he follows this line with a burp.

https://youtu.be/DUXSEVIVGIA?t=11

annotations.text:
All right, come on, let's cut the bullshit, enough
 Let's get it started, let's start addressin' this issue, and open it up
annotations.annotation:
Once The Source magazine leaked a tape of song by a teenage Marshall, entitled “Foolish Pride”; a song with racial themes, it lead to a lot of controversy and discussion, as you would expect considering it came from the first true white rap superstar. But Em is sick of everyone else’s opinion, and tells them to shut up and listen to how it really is.

Per Donald Harrison of jewishsightseeing.com (all sic):

A representative of Eminem’s told [the speaker of the first quote] that the “bullshit” to which the rap singer referred was the way society treats its children—and not, of course not, to either of the quotation preceding “The Yellow Brick Road” rap.

annotations.text: Let's take this shit back to the basement
annotations.annotation:
Em made “Foolish Pride” in a basement.

Bassmint Productions was the first group Eminem was in (and where he began working with Proof).

annotations.text:
And we can discuss
 Statements that's made on this tape and its whole origin of
 The music that we all know and love, the music we all enjoy
 The music you accuse me of tryin' to destroy
annotations.annotation:
The tape he is referring to is two songs he recorded in his teenage years, “So Many Styles” and “Foolish Pride”.

The Source dug up these tracks in 2003 during their beef with Eminem and his camp. They also included snippets on a CD in an issue of the magazine released in February 2004. Ray Benzino, who was trying to destroy Eminem’s career at the time, said:

“Don’t make this right now a double standard. We gotta treat this the same way you treat Mike Tyson, like you treat Kobe Bryant, like you treat R. Kelly, like you treat O.J. Simpson.”

Eminem addressed the latter track with the following statement

“Ray Benzino, Dave Mays and The Source have had a vendetta against me, Shady Records and our artists for a long time. "The tape they played today was something I made out of anger, stupidity and frustration when I was a teenager. I’d just broken up with my girlfriend, who was African-American, and I reacted like the angry, stupid kid I was. I hope people will take it for the foolishness that it was, not for what somebody is trying to make it into today.”

annotations.text:
Let's rewind it to '89 when I was a boy
 On the East Side of Detroit, crossin' 8 Mile into Warren
 Into hick territory; I'd like to share a story
annotations.annotation: Warren, Michigan, which at the time was made up largely of poor and blue collar whites, is a town where Eminem lived for part of his childhood (at his great-grandmother’s house in Warren’s rundown south side) and where he attended high school. It is right on the border of the city of Detroit.  He and his mother moved from Warren to the east side of Detroit (the house made famous on his album covers) when he was 12; in his book The Way I Am he said he continued going to school in Warren so he could be with his friends.  To do that he had to walk or ride his bike back and forth between Warren and Detroit.

annotations.text: This is my story, and can't nobody tell it for me
annotations.annotation:
The main incentive for this song was for Em to prove he was not racist, after being hung out to dry by Benzino and the Source magazine, after finding his “Foolish Pride” tape, with racist comments towards black women.



The whole thing was made public by Benzino, hence telling Em’s story for him, of how he was a racist, but without Em even telling his own story! But Em gets his back by telling the  full story with all the fine details Benzino could never get, explaining the hugely racial divide in his childhood and the settings that lead to the racist tape being made.

This could also be referring to Chaos Kid (An old friend of Em’s) telling MTV that him and Em were trying to be as “wack as possible.”

annotations.text:
You have well informed me, I am well-aware
 That I don't belong here: you've made that perfectly clear
annotations.annotation:
This applies to both music and location.

Growing up, some black people didn’t like seeing Eminem in certain “black” areas, as he details in the next lines.

And musically, one of the typical reactions to Em being white and rapping was, as he recounted for Rolling Stone:

Motherfuckers was like, ‘You’re a white boy, what the fuck are you rapping for? Why don’t you go into rock & roll?’

annotations.text:
I get my ass kicked damn near everywhere
 From Bel-Aire shopping center just for stoppin' in there
annotations.annotation:
No, not that Bel-Air.

The Bel-Aire shopping center in Warren, Michigan, was one of those places where the white boys couldn’t go.

From Rolling Stone:

When [Eminem] was sixteen, his ass was kicked fiercely. “I was walking home from my boy’s house, through the Bel-Air Shopping Center,” he recalls. “All these black dudes rode by in a car, flippin' me off. I flipped them off back, they drove away, and I didn’t think nothin' of it.” Evidently they parked the car. “One dude came up, hit me in the face and knocked me down. Then he pulled out a gun. I ran right out of my shoes, dog. I thought that’s what they wanted.” But they didn’t — when Mathers returned the next day, his shoes were still stuck in the mud. “That’s how I knew it was racial.” Em was saved by a white guy who pulled over, took out a gun and drove him home.

annotations.text: From the black side all the way to the white side
annotations.annotation:
Although it’s typical for big metropolitan cities in the U.S. to present a racial divide within neighborhoods, Detroit — the city where Eminem grew up — constitutes an extraordinary case when it comes to this matter. Here the population is markedly split between North and South by the 8 Mile Road, the same made famous by Eminem with the 2002 movie 8 Mile, with the North half being inhabited by the wealthier and predominantly white people, and the South half being predominantly black and poorer.



Dustin Cable/University of Virginia/Weldon Cooper Center for Public Service

Eminem is here making clear that the bullying was not exclusively racially motivated, but it could also occur in ‘white’ parts of the city, as suggested by his own words from the 2010 interview for 60 Minutes:

I would change schools two, three times a year and that was probably the roughest part. [I got] beat up in the bathroom, beat up in the hallways, shoved in the lockers, you know, for the most part, just for being the new kid.

annotations.text: Them good old notorious so well known tracks
annotations.annotation: Here Em’s referring to the expression “wrong side of the tracks”, a phrase richer people commonly use to describe rough neighborhoods.

annotations.text: So, let's go back, follow the yellow brick road
annotations.annotation:
The railroad tracks are being compared to the the yellow brick road in the Wizard of Oz; to get to Oz, all you have to do is follow the yellow brick road.



Eminem walked the railroads to go to the hip-hop clubs in order to pursue his dreams of making it in rap.

annotations.text: As we go on another episode
annotations.annotation:
“Yellow Brick Road” will be yet another in the series of autobiographical songs Em has made; another episode so to speak. This could tie in with his idea that since he got so much media coverage that his life was basically a show for the public to enjoy, hence the name of his previous album “The Eminem Show”. This “new episode” is about his Ole Foolish Pride tape and the context behind it.

This could also be a reference to the track “The Next Episode” from Doctor Dre’s 1999 album “2001”. Em didn’t feature on the song, but did feature on songs such as “What’s The Difference?” and “Forgot About Dre”.

PROPOSED SUGGESTION: More like a psychotic episode caused by a lot of trauma growing up in poverty, racism and hatred…

annotations.text: So, let's go back, follow the yellow brick road
annotations.annotation:
The railroad tracks are being compared to the the yellow brick road in the Wizard of Oz; to get to Oz, all you have to do is follow the yellow brick road.



Eminem walked the railroads to go to the hip-hop clubs in order to pursue his dreams of making it in rap.

annotations.text: That's about the time I first met Proof
annotations.annotation:
Proof was one of Eminem’s closest friends who passed away on April 11th, 2006.

After his death ABC News had this to say about Proof and Eminem’s relationship.

Mathers became serious about music when he was 14 but was rejected by most fellow rappers because of his race. His friendship with Proof was one of the turning points in his career, and it was Proof’s idea to form D12 – the rap group to which they both belong. They remained close friends, with Proof serving as best man at Eminem’s wedding three months ago

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dRpuE0d-suE

annotations.text: With Goofy Gary on the steps
annotations.annotation:
One of Em’s best friends from his childhood who Em talks about often in interviews such as this “Rolling Stone” article about Eminem.

Also the guy in The Eminem Show’s skit “The Kiss”.

annotations.text:
At Osborn, handin' out some flyers
 We was doin' some talent shows at Center Line High
 I told him to stop by and check us out sometime
 He looked at me like I'm out my mind
annotations.annotation:
This was how Eminem met his best friend Proof, as he later confirmed in a 2018 interview with LL Cool J:

[I met him] on the steps of Osborn High School, I was handing him a flyer to a talent show and he was like ‘You rap?’, and I’m like, ‘Yeah I rap’, he’s like, ‘Why don’t you say something?’, I’m like, ‘Okay’.

Both of them were fans of compound syllables rhyming, which consists of rhyming in-between sentences, not just rhyming the last word with the next sentence’s last word, but also the first one with the next first one and so on.

annotations.text: Shook his head like, "White boys don't know how to rhyme."
annotations.annotation:
White rappers were grossly underrepresented in hip-hop before Eminem burst onto the scene, with Beastie Boys arguably being the only notable Caucasians on the scene at the time Em met Proof.

Although a handful of Caucasians had been affiliated with rappers beforehand, they were usually not the ones doing the rapping.

annotations.text:
I spit out a line and rhymed "birthday" with "first place"
 And we both had the same rhymes that sound alike
 We was on the same shit, that Big Daddy Kane shit
 Where compound syllables sound combined
annotations.annotation:
Em would rhyme these same words in the last line of “Still Don’t Give a Fuck”:

I don’t know why the fuck I’m here in the first place
My worst day on this earth was my first birthday

Eminem is the master of matching up vowel sounds (“assonance” in AP English parlance)

This was ‘88 or '89, the age of N.W.A, in which rap typically consisted of very simple rhyme schemes and flows and this kind of slant rhyme would have been pretty unusual.  One of the only people doing this kind of stuff at the time was Big Daddy Kane.

For example, on “Ain’t No Half-Steppin'” he rhymed

And, stepping to me, yo that’s the wrong move
So what you on, Hobbs, dope or dog food?
