annotations.text: So, let's go back, follow the yellow brick road
annotations.annotation:
The railroad tracks are being compared to the the yellow brick road in the Wizard of Oz; to get to Oz, all you have to do is follow the yellow brick road.



Eminem walked the railroads to go to the hip-hop clubs in order to pursue his dreams of making it in rap.

annotations.text: My first year in 9th grade, can't forget that day at school
annotations.annotation:
Em has a “first year in 9th grade” because he failed it thrice before dropping out. All other days blend together, but this one stands out.

He said in an issue of Spin:

At Warren Lincoln High School […] there was a rule at the time: Anyone with more than ten absences would have to repeat the school year, so once he hit 11, he just stopped going. After flunking freshman year for the third time, he gave up entirely. I was like, ‘I wanna be a rapper, what do I need to go to school for?’ I didn’t think it was that ridiculous. I do now that I’m an adult, ‘cause I realize, what if I didn’t make it? I wouldn’t have been shit, and I’d be working at the same fucking job, flipping burgers and washing dishes.

Em also referred to this in “Bad Influence”:

And ain’t shit changed, I kept the same mindstate
Since the third time that I failed 9th grade

annotations.text:
It was cool 'til your man MC Shan came through
 He said that Puma's the brand ‘cause the Klan makes Troops
 It was rumors, but man, goddamn, they flew
 Musta been true, because man, we done banned they shoes
annotations.annotation:
MC Shan was a Queensbridge rapper who in his 1988 song “I Pioneered This” declared:

Puma’s the brand cause the Klan makes Troops

MC Shan simply said the line as a diss to LL Cool J, who had a shoe deal with Troop. The owners of Troop were actually Jewish and Korean, but people believed MC Shan and it contributed to putting Troop out of business.

annotations.text:
I had the new ones, the Cool J Ice Lamb, suede too
 But we just threw 'em in the trash like they yesterday's news
annotations.annotation:
For somebody stealing bikes, the cost of a sick new pair of sneaks is pretty high, but Em threw them out anyway.

Em’s idol LL Cool J had a deal with Troop, so it makes sense that Em wanted to wear them.

LL Cool J model:



Ice Lambs:

annotations.text:
Guess who came through next? X Clan debuted
 Professor X (Vanglorious!)
 "Exist in a state of red, black and green, with a key, sissies!"
annotations.annotation:
X Clan was an Afrocentric rap group from Brooklyn that emerged in the late 80s/early 90s.

These lines are taken from X Clan’s 1990 album To The East, Blackwards where some variation of the lines are rapped by Professor X all throughout the album, most notably as the intro to the lead track, “Funkin' Lesson”:

Vanglorious
This is protected by the red, the black, and the green
With a key, sissy!

Eminem told Rolling Stone:

I loved the X-Clan’s first album [To the East, Blackwards, 1990]. Brother J was an MC that I was afraid of lyrically. His delivery was so confident. But he also made me feel like an outcast. Callin' us polar bears. Even as militant as Public Enemy were, they never made me feel like, “You’re white, you cannot do this rap, this is our music.” The X-Clan kinda made you feel like that, talking [on “Grand Verbalizer, What Time Is It?”] about “How could polar bears swing on vines of the gorillas?” It was a slap in the face. It was like, you’re loving and supporting the music, you’re buying the artist and supporting the artist, you love it and live it and breathe it, then who’s to say that you can’t do it? If you’re good at it and you wanna do it, then why are you allowed to buy the records but not allowed to do the music? That was the pro-black era — and there was that sense of pride where it was like, if you weren’t black, you shouldn’t listen to hip-hop, you shouldn’t touch the mike. And we used to wear the black and green.

annotations.text:
Now with this bein' the new trend, we don't fit in
 Crackas is out with Cactus Albums,
annotations.annotation: The Cactus Album was released by 3rd Bass, a white rap group that was pretty positively reviewed. With this new Black Pride movement, Em and 3rd Bass and other white people were out of style.

annotations.text:
Blackness is in
 African symbols and medallions represent Black Power
 And we ain't know what it meant, me and my man Howard
 And Butter would go to the mall
 With 'em all over our necks like we're showin' 'em off
annotations.annotation:
Em wasn’t aware that whites and blacks were supposed to show their love for hip-hop differently at first; he just assumed that all fans of the genre could act the same. But he gets a rude awakening in his hometown of Detroit that there are certain aspects of the culture white people aren’t supposed to take part in.

Butta refers to DJ Buttafingaz, who worked with Em on one of his earliest tracks, “Biterphobia.”

Howard appears to be another white friend Em used to rap with as Em chides Howard during a diversion from the main topic on the infamous “Oh Foolish Pride” track itself.

annotations.text:
Not knowin' at all we was bein' laughed at
 "You ain't even half black!
 You ain't 'posed to have that, homie, let me grab that!
 And that Flavor Flav clock, we gon' have to snatch that!"
annotations.annotation:
Flavor Flav, before becoming a joke on VH1, was the hype man for Public Enemy, a black-power rap group.  He wore a big clock around his neck and Eminem wore a similar one.



As Eminem told Rolling Stone:

I remember I had the Flavor Flav clock. The clock was so big and ridiculous, it was the perfect Flavor Flav clock. It was fuckin' huge. And me and my boy are in matching Nike suits and our hair in high-top fades, and we went to the mall and got laughed at so bad. And kinda got rushed out the mall. I remember this dude jumpin' in front of my boy’s face and bein' like, “Yeah, boyyyeee! What you know about hip-hop, white boyyyeee?!”

annotations.text:
Which reminds me, back in '89, me
 And Kim broke up for the first time; she was tryin' to two-time me
annotations.annotation:
Eminem and his ex-wife Kim have broken up, made up, then broken up again constantly ever since the day they met each other. Eminem references this particular break-up in his song titled “Kim” where he raps:

Never knew me cheatin' on you would come back to haunt me
But we was kids then Kim, I was only eighteen
That was years ago, I thought we wiped the slate clean!"

So Marshall must have dealt with Kim cheating on him by cheating on her with another woman.

annotations.text:
And there was this black girl at our school, who thought I was cool
 ‘Cause I rapped, so she was kinda eyein' me
 And oh the irony, guess what her name was?
 Ain't even gonna say it, plus
 The same color hair as hers was and blue contacts
 And a pair of jugs, the bombest goddamn girl in our whole school
 If I could pull her, not only would I become more popular
 But I would be able to piss Kim off at the same time
 But it backfired
 I was supposed to dump her but she dumped me for this black guy
 And that's the last I ever seen or heard
 Or spoke to the "Ole Foolish Pride" girl,
annotations.annotation:
Eminem started his on and off relationship with Kim in 1989, when he was only 16 and she was 14. From these lines we learn that that same year they’d already broken up for the first time, which led Eminem to date another girl, who was African-American. Their relationship, however, didn’t last long and the day they broke up Eminem went on to record his highly racist “Ole Foolish Pride”. As he explained to Rolling Stones in 2004:

This is what we used to do. I’d go in my man’s basement and do goofy freestyles, and we’d call ‘em sucker rhymes, and the whole point of the rap was to be as wack as possible and warm up before we actually did songs that we wrote. And that ended up just happening to be the topic that day. I just broke up with a black girl […]

annotations.text:
But I've heard
 People say they heard the tape and it ain't that bad
 But it was: I singled out a whole race
 And for that I apologize, I was wrong
 ‘Cause no matter what color a girl is, she's still a—
annotations.annotation:
The “Ole Foolish Pride” tape was dug up by The Source magazine in 2003, along with another one called “So Many Styles”, the latter of which, Eminem stated, he’d never heard of before. The tape was filled with many racial slurs towards African-American girls in general, and Eminem apologized for its content shortly after the track was leaked:

The tape they played today was something I made out of anger, stupidity and frustration when I was a teenager. I’d just broken up with my girlfriend, who was African-American, and I reacted like the angry, stupid kid I was. I hope people will take it for the foolishness that it was, not for what somebody is trying to make it into today.

And again in another statement a few days later:

So while I think common sense tells you not to judge a man by what he may have said when he was a boy, I will say it straight up: I am sorry I said those things when I was 16. And I don’t want to let anybody turn this into an opportunity to promote their own bullsh—agenda.

Here he intends to apologize a third time. In particular, he apologizes for the “black girls are bitches” line he had rapped on “Ole Foolish Pride”, but does it sarcastically as he’s not taking back the insult, but rather extending it to all girls, regardless of color. The delivery is subtle as he doesn’t actually pronounce “ho”, but makes it obvious that’s what’s supposed to rhyme with “wrong” on the line above.

The discovery and release of the two songs by The Source was not an isolated shot at Eminem’s career, but part of an ongoing beef between Eminem and Ray Benzino, one of the owners of The Source at the time. This beef is the main topic of the next song on the album, “Like Toy Soldiers”.

annotations.text: So, let's go back, follow the yellow brick road
annotations.annotation:
The railroad tracks are being compared to the the yellow brick road in the Wizard of Oz; to get to Oz, all you have to do is follow the yellow brick road.



Eminem walked the railroads to go to the hip-hop clubs in order to pursue his dreams of making it in rap.

annotations.text:
[Outro: Debbie Mathers]
 Fuck out of my house, you fuckin' pieces of shit!
 Get the fuck out of my house, you stupid fucker!
 You son of a bitch!
annotations.annotation:
Considering that Eminem rapped the following in the second verse of this song:

To meet Kim had to walk
Back to her mama’s on Chalmers after dark
To sneak me in the house when I’m kicked out my mom’s

it’s very likely that the woman yelling in the background while the song is fading out is meant to be Eminem’s mother, Debbie Mathers-Briggs, in one of the many times she kicked him out of the house. As he detailed on the interview for Anthony Bozza’s Whatever You Say I Am:

I stayed with my mom until I was eighteen, but I kept getting kicked out. I was only there full-time really when I was thirteen and fourteen. My mother did a lot of fucking dope and shit, so she had mood swings. She took a lot of pills. She took two or three naps a day. She’d go to sleep cool and wake up and start yelling, ‘What the fuck’s wrong with this fucking house? This house is a fucking mess! Motherfucker, get the fuck out!’ My room was upstairs, so she’d come up and throw open the door and flip on me. I used to record her. I’ve got those tapes somewhere. I’d play them for my grandmother. She’s actually my great-grandmother — my mother’s grandmother. Those two never got along, but I liked her. I used to go over there when my mother would kick me out. She’s real old now, like ninety-two, I think.

So, given the existence of these tapes, there’s also a good chance that this background yelling is a recording of Debbie’s actual voice, rather than a simple reenactment of her kicking him out.

title.name: To Live and Die in L.A.

annotations.text: [Intro]
annotations.annotation: First, this intro was intended for the original 3 Day Theory cut {tracklist}, “Watch Your Mouth”. Second, this is an actual take from 92.3 The Beat’s “Street Science” segment hosted by Dominique Di Prima. The segment goes hand in hand with the song as Di Prima was all about unifying the hip hop community and uplifting the minorities in society. The Beat is shouted out along with KDAY and Power 106 also for keeping Tupac records in heavy rotation, especially DJ’s like Fat Dre and Ed Lover Julio G and Theo Mizuhara who you might recongize from here.

annotations.text: “Street Science, you’re on the air. What do you feel when you hear a record like 2Pac’s new one?”
annotations.annotation: The song starts with an interview originally performed on KKBT’s 93.2 Street Science  program.

annotations.text: ‘I had sex with your wife’ — and not in those words.
annotations.annotation:
The reporter is referring to 2Pac’s song “Hit Em Up” when 2Pac said:

That’s why I fucked your bitch

Claiming that he had sex with Biggie’s wife Faith Evans

annotations.text: But he’s talking about, ‘I wanna see you deceased’…"
annotations.annotation:
This is likely to be a rephrasing of the first verse of 2Pac’s song “Hit ‘Em Up,” where the rapper claims he wants Lil' Cease deceased:

Cut your young ass up, leave you in pieces
Now be deceased

annotations.text: To live and die in L.A
annotations.annotation: To Live and Die in L.A. was the name of a 1985 William Friedkin thriller film.

annotations.text:
Where everyday we try to fatten our pockets
 Us niggas hustle for the cash, so it's hard to knock it
 Everybody got they own thing, currency chasin'
 Worldwide through the hard times, worrying faces
 Shed tears as we bury niggas close to heart
 What was a friend, now a ghost in the dark
annotations.annotation:
These 6 lines in the beginning of the song are used as a juxtaposition to the street science interview that provides the introduction. Pac contrarily shows his empathy for the streets as opposed to the “Hit ‘Em Up” lyrics being paraphrased by the interviewer. Although Tupac is recognized for his duality of being both the boisterous, indignant, black revolutionary and the soft spoken, poetic, humanitarian it is ultimately his ability to paint a chilling mosaic of the deplorable condition of his people that has truly solidified his martyr legacy. In this verse Tupac genuinely portrays the struggle of the  daily “hustle”  to the listener.  The chase for currency, the seemingly universal hard times, worrying faces, and the black on black holocaust that continues to affect America today.  Even in 1996 the idea of burying friends who were “close to the heart” had became an all to prevalent conditioned reality. It is lyrical contributions such as this that make Tupac not only a hero to the community but truly a one of a kind human being. As the late great Dr. Kahlid Muhammad recognized just months before Pac’s death:

URL:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xH3Sg1IfoWU

annotations.text: Plea bargain ain't an option now, so I'm stressin'
annotations.annotation:
He was being charged with a crime, the D.A. won’t offer him a plea bargain since the case against him is too strong, and now he has to go to trial. He’s worried…

(Perhaps this is a reference to 2Pac’s real-life legal troubles which centered around an alleged gang-rape; 2Pac, who claims to have been asleep at the time of the rape, served under a year of a 1 ½ to 4 ½ sentence in Clinton Correctional Facility for the charges

annotations.text: Cost me more to be free than a life in the pen'
annotations.annotation:
Tupac was released on bail paid for by Deathrow Records. Tupac was already signed to Interscope records since his debut album. In the Defiant Ones documentary released in 2017, Interscope finally acknowledged based on Rap’s criticism at the time, The label bailing out Tupac wasn’t a good look for them. Interscope proceeded to front Deathrow the $2.1 million bail money and have him become part of the Deathrow roster. Also relevant is the fact when Tupac first went to jail, his album Me against the World debuted at #1 on the Billboard charts, so there was a vested interest for Interscope to have him out of jail and making music again. Down side was, Tupac was pressured into feeling he needed to recoup this money for the record label, in the end Tupac’s estate ended up owing this money to Deathrow.

https://ambrosiaforheads.com/2017/07/interscope-bailed-tupac-not-death-row/

annotations.text: My angel sing
annotations.annotation:
By this line Pac probably means Val Young (a.k.a. Lady V), the woman who sings the background vocals. She was a friend of 2Pac and his Outlawz. One of them said in an interview, Pac loved to work with Val Young.

Los Angeles is known as the city of angels and it’s name literally translates to “the Angels”.

annotations.text: [Verse 2: 2Pac]
annotations.annotation: handwritten paper

annotations.text: On the curb watchin' the ghetto bird helicopters
annotations.annotation:
The ghetto bird refers to police helicopters usually used at night to shine a light on criminal activity or fleeing suspects. Ice Cube brought the term to the mainstream with his 1993 track “Ghetto Bird”:

Run, run, run from the ghetto bird

annotations.text: I observe so many niggas gettin' three strikes, tossed in jail
annotations.annotation: In 1994, California became the first state to enact a “three strikes” law, meaning someone who committed a felony and has two more strikes/convictions would be sentenced to a prison term of 25 to life.

annotations.text: Better learn about the dress code, B's and C's
annotations.annotation:
Bloods wear red and Crips wear blue—that’s the dress code for Los Angeles, especially for out-of-towners who may not know what neighborhood they’re in where wearing the wrong color could be fatal.

Although Tupac was associated with Death Row Records and, via label head Suge Knight, was ultimately an affiliate of Suge’s MOB Piru Blood gang—an affiliation that possibly ended his life when he was allegedly shot by Crip Orlando Anderson in Las Vegas—Tupac supported both Crips and Bloods and sought gang unity.

annotations.text: [Verse 3: 2Pac]
annotations.annotation: 2pac handwritten paper

annotations.text: It wouldn't be L.A. without Mexicans
annotations.annotation:
Los Angeles is commonly said to home the second largest Mexican community in the world (after Mexico itself). According to Pew Research Center, in 2014, 45% of the Los Angeles area’s residents were Hispanic. 78.5% of the people in this population were Mexican. Reports from the ‘90s claim similar statistics.

The map below depicts the racial distribution in Los Angeles according to the 2010 U.S. Census. Each orange dot represent 25 Hispanic people.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Los_Angeles#/media/File:Race_and_ethnicity_2010-Los_Angeles(5560490330).png

annotations.text: Pete Wilson tryin' to see us all broke
annotations.annotation: Pete Wilson was the conservative Republican governor of California from 1991 to 1999. Around the time of recording, he unsuccessfully ran for president in the election of 1996.

annotations.text: I'm on some bullshit out for everything they owe
annotations.annotation:
Consider his song “Everything They Owe” to understand what he means.

Also, “owe” is pronounced like the letter O and in the following lines he mentions “K-day” and “MLK”. It all forms a literal association: O, K, MLK.

annotations.text: Remember KDAY? Weekends, Crenshaw, MLK?
annotations.annotation: Fond memories – it used to be all good on Crenshaw Boulevard and Martin Luther King Boulevard where people would party and show off their lowriders. 1580 KDAY was the hip-hop radio station that put N.W.A on the airwaves in the 1980s; it made a comeback in the 2000s as 93.5 KDAY.

annotations.text: Gang signs being shown, nigga, love yo' hood
annotations.annotation: Bloods, Crips, and Mexican gangs in L.A. use hand signals to show their affiliations to their gang and sets/neighborhoods.

annotations.text: Snoop Dogg in this mufucka permed out
annotations.annotation: Snoop Dogg was sporting a perm hairstyle at the time as shown in this photo

annotations.text: Dogg Pound in the Lex with a ounce to burn
annotations.annotation: Tha Dogg Pound is a rap group comprised of fellow Death Row artists Daz Dillinger and Kurupt. Multiple collaborations between the duo and 2Pac have been released, including “Got My Mind Made Up” from 2Pac’s last album released during his lifetime. 2Pac notes that they’re riding in a Lexus likely puffing on an ounce of the chronic.

annotations.text: Got them Watts niggas with me, O.F.T.B
annotations.annotation: O.F.T.B. (Operation From The Bottom) is a rap group from the Watts section of Los Angeles. They were once signed to Death Row along with 2Pac but the group never released an album on the label. They were featured on the Death Row-produced soundtracks for Murder Was The Case, Above The Rim and Gridlock’d. 2Pac collaborated with the members on multiple songs such a version of “Better Dayz,” “World Wide (Time After Time),” and “The Struggle Continues.”

annotations.text:
Neckbone, Tre, Heron, Buntry too
 Big Rock got knocked, but this one's for you
annotations.annotation:
Neckbone, Tre, Heron, Buntry and Rock were all members of the M.O.B Pirus and were Suge Knight’s close friends who Pac had also befriended.

All were present the night 2Pac died. Travon Lane pointed out Orlando and told Pac who he was. Buntry was present during the 2pac shooting and went after the Cadillac and exchanged gunfire with them. The others were at 662.

Big Rock and Tre went to the pen, Neckbone is in jail, Heron was murdered in 1997 and Buntry was murdered in 2002 due to a feud with the Fruit Town Pirus.

annotations.annotation: 92.3 The Beat, and Power 106 were the two biggest radio stations in Los Angeles for hip-hop and R&B at the time.

annotations.text:
L.A., "California Love" part mothafuckin' two
 Without gay ass Dre
annotations.annotation:
“California Love” was a single that was produced by and featured Dr. Dre, although “California Love” was initially a Dr. Dre solo song. After the release of his critically acclaimed double album, All Eyez On Me, Pac began to hate Dre and a beef was started (Dre never responded). It was caused by Pac thinking Dre wasn’t trustworthy due to incidents such as Dre not going to Snoop Dogg’s murder trial and Dre claiming to produce tracks that Daz Dillinger produced.

Although according to the documentary, Welcome to Death Row, 2Pac wasn’t mad at Dre like that. Death Row Records don, Suge Knight, was in his ear telling him to say this stuff because Dr. Dre didn’t want to be around the environment that Death Row had in the studio at the time.

annotations.text:
I ain't listenin' for shit but sirens
 I ain't tryna get to my ship sunk, fuck you pirates
annotations.annotation:
He doesn’t care that his speakers are drowned. He’s listening for cops, not music. He’s not trying to get his belongings taken (in an interesting inversion of authority, he casts the cops as outlaw pirates)



Also sirens were mythical creatures in Greek Mythology who would use their beautiful voices to lure sailors and sink their ships.  So Wayne is listening for sirens to steer clear of them, and keep his ship floating.

annotations.text:
I play hard for nine innings, dressed in fine linen
 ‘Cause pussy is the best next thing besides winnin'
annotations.annotation:
Aw, Ghost is such a sweetheart! The only thing better than vaginas are the women that come with them!  Incidentally, to get the women it helps if you wear nice clothing

Ghostface is referencing 2Pac’s line from “Hail Mary”:

Revenge is like the sweetest joy next to getting pussy



Ghost is referencing that he is often dressed in nice clothes despite his propensity for blue-collar hard work. In the next line, he is expressing that his love for women is only surpassed by the rush of “winning” – a general word for experiencing success in career.

annotations.text: All the positions I've been in couldn't explain how I'm livin'
annotations.annotation: I’ve done so much in my life, you wouldn’t even understand

annotations.text: You'll be missin' like them crazy Christians
annotations.annotation: I assume Ghost is talking about a suicide cult, but it could be he’s killed some Christians and happens to think Christianity is crazy:

annotations.text: And swimming with all the fishes
annotations.annotation: When they killed Luca Brasi in The Godfather movie, they said Luca Brasi sleeps with the fishes meaning he’s dead

annotations.text: Moving like Magic, but niggas ain't worthy
annotations.annotation: An allusion to James Worthy, one of Magic’s teammates on the 80’s Showtime Lakers teams

annotations.text: Like Michael Cooper; when I shoot I aim sturdy
annotations.annotation: Michael Cooper, another member of the 80’s Lakers teams, was an accurate jump-shooter.  Cormega claims similar prowess shooting at shooting guns (or at least similarly solid technique)

annotations.text: We can take it to the streets, like a game at the Rucker
annotations.annotation: Rucker Park in Harlem is arguably the most famous location for people to play streetball

annotations.text: I was dealing with 'caine like cold chilla
annotations.annotation: The old-school rapper Big Daddy Kane made his debut on Cold Chillin' Records.  Cormega plays on the double meaning of “kane” here; he’s saying he used to deal cocaine.

annotations.text: Back when lyricist reined and dope was killing 'em
annotations.annotation: Cormega evokes memories of the old school days, when people assigned more value to great lyricism (and when drugs devastated inner cities across the country)

annotations.text:
And I'm back with a vengeance
 Like Sprewell smashing the Knicks
 After they shipped him despite the fans resistance
annotations.annotation: Cormega often laments the fact that the Knicks traded Latrell Sprewell.  Sprewell was a fan favorite and I guess Cormega (a Brooklyn resident) really really liked him

annotations.annotation: Cam'ron is recounting his youth, when he still lived at home and had to fight with his mother for space and time to prepare drugs. He was a hard worker (10-9, in other words, all night) and hated cops (swine)

annotations.text:
"You out ya mind," nah, you don't know what's in my mind
 I'ma surpass crack, move on to NASDAQ
 But still my connects move anthrax on Amtraks
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron meditates briefly on the impossibility of knowing another person’s mental states. Then he describes his grand plans to reinvest crack money in the stock market, without losing his illegal contacts

annotations.text:
Ayo Cam before the cops rush, close the spot
 Load the Glocks they stunting, we control the block
 They frontin we throw 'em shots and laugh at 'em
 Shots from the .44 magnum, that's how we get back at 'em

annotations.annotation:
Juelz warns Cam to close the drug dealing spot and load up their guns before the cops descend. The cops do not have a legitimate claim to this block so our heroes will be opening fire to keep them away

44 Magnum revolver and Glock 9mm pistol.
Throw shots and clap both mean shoot.
Stuntin' here means the cops are heavily armed and mean business.
Frontin' here means pretending

annotations.text:
Thank you, thank you, thank you, you're far too kind
 Hold your applause, this is your song, not mines
annotations.annotation:
Jigga reprised this sentence from his song, “Encore”

This is also a homage to Biggie. At the end of Biggie Smalls' “Playa Hater” he states

Thank you, Thank you, You’re far too kind.

annotations.text:
Thank you, thank you, thank you, please hold your applause
 For I just applied logic—keys, keys open doors
annotations.annotation:
This line is a reference to the Clipse song “Keys Open Doors”.  He’s saying before he made it big he was just doing what made sense: selling kilograms of cocaine

Also referring to the software Logic which is used to produce instrumentals/beats digitally for cheap-that was a lot of producers used earlier in his career.

Now he often uses live instruments especially at his concerts thus it’s like being at the Opera, black tuxedos, binoculars in hand for those seated at the balcony.

annotations.text:
Now I'm balcony, opera, black tux, binocular
 Black Luxe, stop it, I shouldn't be so popular
annotations.annotation:
Imagine Jay-Z at an opera using a pair of binoculars.  Only he can brag about things like this without losing all credibility.



Blak Luxe is also a high end, obscure ladies fashion label… Jay is popular with women, after all.

annotations.text:
Name keep poppin' up, face keep poppin' up
 On the tube, I'm just watchin' Pacquaio box 'em up
annotations.annotation:
He keeps getting seen on TV when attending Manny Pacquaio’s boxing matches



Also,“watching Pacquiao box'em up” is a phrase, homophoned as “watching Pacqu(iao = and ya’ll) ‘box’ him up” tied in with being at a Pacquiao fight and “ya’ll ‘box’ him up”, as in the camera’s shot/TV = ‘box’ (double entendre) of him at the Pacquiao fight while the rest of us watch it at home on our 36" TV’s…

annotations.text: How would I know HBO would get a shot of us?
annotations.annotation:
Classic sarcasm from the Jiggaman, of course he knows that if he sits on the front row the camera’s are going to pick him up, for 2 reasons:

1) He’s going to appear naturally in the background of shots from the actual fight
2) The camera’s are going to pick Jay up anyway because he is so famous, and sitting in plain view, on the front row

He is also bragging about how close to the fight he is sitting, because these seats are the most expensive. he wants everyone to know that he is paying top dollar for his seats, because he can

annotations.text:
Who woulda thought by makin' birds migrate for the winter
 I be fly all summer? Might I say
annotations.annotation:
A bird is a kilogram of cocaine (sometimes stamped with a bird to indicate the origin of the package).  In the winter Jay would drive south to sell drugs (making the birds migrate)

The main interpretation; Jay is trying to say that by selling drugs during the winter, he’ll have lots of money so that he is fly during the summer, as in have lots of nice things; clothes, cars, jewelry, women…

A more poetic meaning could be; Jay made the BIRDS migrate during the WINTER – the coldest days of his life – when he was struggling to make his way up. Due to this, he’s earned the right to speak on it ad-infinitum in his music at no personal risk to himself and it brings him WAY more money, fame and privilege for him to enjoy the better days (SUMMER) of his life…

annotations.text:
Thank you, thank you, thank you, you're far too kind
 Hold your applause, this is your song, not mines
annotations.annotation:
Jigga reprised this sentence from his song, “Encore”

This is also a homage to Biggie. At the end of Biggie Smalls' “Playa Hater” he states

Thank you, Thank you, You’re far too kind.

annotations.text: We tip the waiter a hundred dollars to keep the ice cold, alright
annotations.annotation: In the movie Goodfellas, Henry Hill notes that that Jimmy Conway (Robert De Niro’s character) would “tip the waiter 100 bucks just for keeping the ice cold”.

annotations.text: We the last ones to keep the wise guys code alive
annotations.annotation:
“Wise guys” are people in the Mafia.  The term was probably first made famous by the movie Wise Guys.  He’s saying the code of honor in the mob (loyalty to your partners, willing to die for your family, etc.) is only still maintained by his clique

Also, the film “Goofellas”, mentioned in the previous line, is based on a book called “Wiseguys”.

annotations.text: 'Cept I put eight balls in corners without usin' pool sticks
annotations.annotation:
The main difference is that whereas in The Color of Money, which was about Tom Cruise and Paul Newman as pool players, the 8-balls he puts in the corner aren’t billiard balls, they’re 8-balls of cocaine and the corner he would put the 8-balls on were street corners from which he would distribute his drugs.

Jay made a similar pun 12 years earlier, on In My Lifetime, Vol. 1’s “Real Niggaz”:

“Right in front of your children, eightball in my side pocket”

annotations.text:
This way after the Ruger shoots through a few clips
 You can lay in your casket just as you is
annotations.annotation:
Here one could speculate that, he’s taking a shot at the Clipse: their album Till The Casket Drops was released a few months after Blueprint 3.  So he’ll unload some bullet clips on The Clipse and place them in a casket. Rap folklore lends some credence to this possibility due to some existing tension between The Clipse and Jay at some point. Jay has since appeared on tracks with Pusha T, he can’t possibly be still appalled with them…

However, it is more a continuation of the previous line when Jay asked Danger “what size suit you is?” Ruger is a common handgun used in the streets and by gangsters. When the Ruger shoots through a few clips(bullets) and hits Danger, Danger dies in his new suit. Now they can lay him in his casket just as he is, because men are usually buried in suits at their funerals.

annotations.text:
Thank you, thank you, thank you, you're far too kind
 Hold your applause, this is your song, not mines
annotations.annotation:
Jigga reprised this sentence from his song, “Encore”

This is also a homage to Biggie. At the end of Biggie Smalls' “Playa Hater” he states

Thank you, Thank you, You’re far too kind.

annotations.text:
I was gonna kill a couple rappers, but they did it to themselves
 I was gon' do it with the flow, but they did it with their sales
annotations.annotation:
“A couple of rappers” could refer to Jim Jones and Cam'ron. Neither “Crime Pays” or “Pray IV Reign” could even come up to half the sales of “Killa Season” or “Hustler’s P.O.M.E.”.

After dissing Jay in 06 Dipset ended up losing all commercial success.

Kendrick Lamar flipped this line in the record “King Kunta” from To Pimp a Butterfly.

annotations.text: I was gon' 9/11 'em,
annotations.annotation:
Both an obvious reference to September 11th and a reference to the fact that Blueprint came out on September 11th. On Blueprint, Jay went after Nas with “Takeover”, so 9/11ing somebody could be blowing up their building or just dropping another song. It is also worth noting that Blueprint 3 dropped on September 8th.

Possibly a shot at Killa Cam. Cam'ron at a press conference referred to his own diss as “running a plane into the towers” in the orignal dig a hole Jay says “fake Osamas we laugh when your plane hits”

annotations.text:
But they didn't need the help
 And they did a good job, them boys is talented as hell
annotations.annotation: This is almost definitely directed at Cam'ron – who went hard after Jay-Z on an album that flopped (Killa Season) – and probably 50 Cent.  This is the lead-in to how good his rivals are at ruining their own career and how they went above and beyond in doing so

annotations.text: 'Cause not only did they brick, they put a building up as well
annotations.annotation:
Bricking is having a dud album.  Putting up a building would involve a ton of bricks, so they super-bricked

This was alluding to Cam'ron and Dip-Set going off on their own. The building being their “Label” and then he describes their downfall in the next line.

annotations.text:
Then ran a plane into that building and when that building fell
 Ran to the crash site with no masks and inhaled
 Toxins deep inside their lungs until both of them was filled
annotations.annotation:
Extended 9/11 metaphor indicating that they were very thorough in killing themselves

At the time, Jay had so many different rappers trying to beef with him that it could refer to any rapper then. Most likely Cam'ron & 50 Cent, since they were heads of their respective camps. The other minion rappers can take the crumbs of these bars ..

annotations.text: 'Cause they heard that second hand smoke kills
annotations.annotation:
They wanted to make sure they would kill themselves so they retained the toxic fumes to reinhale them

After Jay’s epic battle with Nas, rappers started to get really confident in themselves going against Jay because they felt he now had chinks in his armor. They were thriving off of the Etheric fumes left behind by Nas but didn’t realize they were gassing themselves for disaster. A really clever play on the entire situation somehow praising Nas and reminding these other rappers that they are not that pedigree to come against him, they’ll die off their own futile attempts…

annotations.text:
Thank you, thank you, thank you, you're far too kind
 Hold your applause, this is your song, not mines
annotations.annotation:
Jigga reprised this sentence from his song, “Encore”

This is also a homage to Biggie. At the end of Biggie Smalls' “Playa Hater” he states

Thank you, Thank you, You’re far too kind.

annotations.text: Lucky Lefty,
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z’s nickname (very rarely used, almost never referred to in any rap song) is Lucky lefty (I assume he’s left-handed).

One rare reference to him being left-handed can be seen here

annotations.text: Kiss the wife goodnight for me, hehe
annotations.annotation:
This is likely a subliminal diss at Dame Dash as Jay and Dame have had a serious falling out and Dame is now getting divorced

For more on the Jay / Dame beef, go to the “Prominence and Split” section of this wiki page

lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Feelin' downtrodden, fresh kid turned rotten
I can't believe how naive that I've gotten
Over the years seems like I'm gettin' dumber
Reminiscing to a time when I was younger with a hunger
Full of dreams, determination, self-esteem
But now it seems they hesitate to be on my team
You know the routine, when you winnin' they're grinnin'
All up in your face, like they was wit' you from the beginnin'
But on the flipside, when you're washed up like a riptide
Fools clown 'bout how you slipped and let shit slide

annotations.text: Ain't got no homies that got my back
annotations.annotation: In 1996, Fatlip was kicked out of The Pharcyde, the rap group that gave him his start. He was not only the first one to leave the group, but the last one to join, so in that sense Fatlip was always kind of loner, doing his own thing regardless of friends or allies. He even titled his debut album The Loneliest Punk.

annotations.text: [KRS-One: What do you expect when you rhyme like a soft punk?]
annotations.annotation:
Sampled from Boogie Down Productions' classic “My Philosophy”
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DOaHLsNPM88

annotations.text: Goin' like a sucka almost every day
annotations.annotation:
A reference to Erick Sermon’s line in I’m Housin'.
http://rapgenius.com/1556694

annotations.text: In the back of your mind you're prob'ly thinkin' I was gay
annotations.annotation:
Probably because he once accidentally hooked up with a transvestite.
https://youtu.be/exT-1cYFHzM?t=23

He also tells this story in the song Oh Shit:

I got a funny feeling like something was real wrong
Looked at her shoes and her feets was real long
Then it hit me oh please god no
Don’t let this ho turn out to be a john doe

annotations.text: Type that tryna turn a ho into a housewife
annotations.annotation: Conventional wisdom and Dr. Dre alike suggest that this cannot be done, but here comes Captain Save A Hoe

annotations.text: On Pico Boulevard I was regarded as a retard
annotations.annotation:
In his verse on, “Oh Shit” by The Pharcyde, Fatlip explained how he once accidentally hooked up with a transvestite at Pico Boulevard, a neighborhood in Los Angeles. This caused him embarrassment and made him question his own masculinity and verbally self-deprecate himself in various ways which he does throughout this song.
https://youtu.be/exT-1cYFHzM?t=23

annotations.text: Has-been MC
annotations.annotation: A “has-been” is someone who used to be popular or influential, so a “has-been MC” would be a rapper used to be popular. Fatlip is referring to his career in The Pharcyde in the 90’s.

annotations.text: A label that's unstable
annotations.annotation: Delicious Vinyl is still is business as of this writing

"She keeps on"
 "She keeps on"

annotations.text: I get computers 'puting
annotations.annotation:
“‘Puting” is short for “computing”. Many rappers might be content to claim that their lyrics are so clever that they “get you thinking”, but Cam’s are on a whole 'nother level: they get COMPUTERS thinking! And that’s, like, their job.

This line is actually mad prophetic because Cam’s lyrics sparked the creation of the number one hip-hop lyric explanation site a computer can possibly take you to, rapgenius.com. Before Cam, computers didn’t “‘pute” nearly this much about the meaning of rap lyrics (first song up on the site was “Killa Cam”.



Need I say more?

annotations.text: Luger to Ruger,
annotations.annotation:
Luger is standard German service pistol, popular in rap. Ruger is an American brand producing some of the best heavy-caliber pistols. Cam rolls with all sorts of guns



Luger



Ruger

annotations.text: Hit from Roota to Toota
annotations.annotation:
“From the rooter to the tooter” is a hog farmer phrase meaning “from the snout to the tail”, i.e. “the whole hog”

It’s kind of like when indians say “the whole buffalo”; Cam is saying that he has enough guns to shoot you from your head to your toes (or, more specifically, your toot-hole)

annotations.text: I put two in producers
annotations.annotation:
If my producers try to fuck with my creative license, I’ll shoot them too. (Although I’ll only shoot them twice for liability reasons)

He may be talking about Darrell “Digga” Branch, the producer of his first two commercial releases, with whom he fell out

annotations.text: I'm the real ball story, the loser of "Hoosiers"
annotations.annotation:
The basketball movie “Hoosiers” is about how a plucky underdog can beat a powerful dynasty (Cam identifies more with the latter)

The losing team in Hoosiers is all black; the winning team is all white. Many blacks have expressed some unease with this subtext, including Spike Lee.

Keep in mind Cam'ron was a star basketball athelete who went to college for basketball and dropped out

annotations.text: I rock mostly dosey,
annotations.annotation: Cam wears mostly “Dolce” (pronounced with incorrect phonology to sound hetero) & Gabana clothes

annotations.text: I roll mostly dolie
annotations.annotation:
“Rock” (from previous clause) n' “Roll”
He rolls fat blunts with no filter (“dolies”)



(“Dolie” could is also pet-name version of “dolo”, which means solo, in which case maybe Cam is trying to tell us he’s lonely)

annotations.text: I'll leave you wholly-holey, you'll say holy moly
annotations.annotation: When Cam leaves holes in your body by shooting you, you’ll be like “Holy cow. How did you do that?”

annotations.text: I'll tell you true stories, how I coldly hold heat
annotations.annotation: Cam fearlessly wields a firearm; notice the hot/cold dichotomy (“heat” = gun/“coldly” = without fear)

annotations.text: When it's repping time, I get on extra grind
annotations.annotation: Lil Wayne sampled this line on “Dipset” off of his Da Drought 3 mixtape. Cam also delivers the most positive statement in the song here.  “When its time to deliver, i work very hard to achieve my goal”.

annotations.text: Fried to fricassee, Pepperseed to Pepperdine
annotations.annotation:
Cam cooks crack (which like fricassee, a popular Southern dish, is fried in a frying pan) from Puerto Rico (where the “Pepperseed” is a popular dance) to the West Coast

Pepperdine University – known for its law school – sits on the Pacific Ocean in sunny Malibu.

Alludes to Jay-Z’s famous fricassee line in the first verse of “Can I Live”.

annotations.text: Jeff Hamilton, Genesis, leather time
annotations.annotation:
Jeff Hamilton makes designer leather jackets popular with thugs; the “Genesis” is one of his popular styles

Genesis is also the name of a popular Midtown store where they sell Jeff Hamilton jackets

annotations.text: Stallion of the year
annotations.annotation: Cam refers to himself when he says “stallion.” Here, a stallion means an extremely handsome, well built man. Like a thoroughbred horse, he’s on his game.

annotations.text: Posters on the wall, posted on my balls
annotations.annotation: “Your wife has posters of me on her wall, and is posted up on my nuts”

annotations.text: Y'all faking the fizzle, I'm caking for shizzle
annotations.annotation:
Y'all are whack, while I’m “caking” (making “cake” i.e. “money”) fo shizzle my nizzle.

Jay-Z once rapped in “Dead Presidents II”:

We cakin', you niggas is fakin'

annotations.text: My ace boon coon
annotations.annotation:
“Ace boon coon” means best friend; the phrase is also used in Notorious B.I.G.’s “Another”

“Ace boon coon” was used earlier, in “Bitches 2” by Ice-T; a lot of these pigs are bitches too.

annotations.text: 7 to 8, zoom zoom, boom boom tune
annotations.annotation:
From 7 to 8 o'clock, driving around, making deliveries while listening to my stereo system really loud (Q: what does Cam listen to in the car?) (A: He’s a big fan of “This American Life” on NPR)

Shout out to Wreckx-N-Effect’s “Rump Shaker ”

annotations.text: 'Fore I get life, that boom boom room
annotations.annotation:
“Boom boom room” is the lap dance/prostitution room in a strip club.

The Boom Boom Room being a reference to the hypothetical club Eddie Murphy’s character “Ray” in the film ‘LIFE’ contrives he will open upon escaping jail and getting back to New York. There’s a whole scene in the film dedicated to this dream where each member incarcerated with him is theoretically there enjoying the good life.

http://www.anyclip.com/movies/life/the-boom-boom-room/

annotations.text: Wrecks 'n Effects: zoom zoom in poon-poon
annotations.annotation:
A reference to the ‘90’s pop/rap hit “Rump Shaker”, where the chorus is “All I wanna do is zoom-a-zoom zoom zoom and a boom boom! (Just shake your rump!)”, which is a euphemism for “All I wanna do is have sex”

Cam is describing his sex style: he goes hard and fast – zoom zoom, boom boom – in the punani (pussy)

annotations.text: Since the movie Cocoon, had my Uzi platoon
annotations.annotation: Cocoon is a Ron Howard classic that was released in 1985; Cam is saying that he’s been a leader of men (and girls) for a long, long time

annotations.text: My team is the Goonies,
annotations.annotation: Another classic 1985 release, the Goonies involves a crew of homies who stay close together (Cam is saying that he and his Dipset crew are close-knit)

annotations.text:
We were seen with buffoonies
 Toonies, best dressed, stay up in Neiman's and Bloomies
annotations.annotation: We hang out with girls who might seem silly at first…but well-dressed, certainly (Neiman Marcus, Bloomingdales)

annotations.text: Cam V.S. 1 and 2
annotations.annotation:
VS1 and VS2 diamond clarity.
VS1 diamond:



VS2:



BLING!

annotations.text: I'll help you get your son out of P.S. 22
annotations.annotation:
New York City public schools all have numbers; Cam is saying to the girl “if you stick with me, your son won’t have to go to a crappy public school anymore,” i.e. you won’t have to worry about money

These days, of course, the woman might well respond: “but Cam! If you pull my son out of the P.S. 22 Chorus then he’ll never make it on American Idol!”

annotations.text: Get him a Mauri flow, from the Mauri show
annotations.annotation: Cam will get your son enough “flow” (stream of income) to afford Mauri Italian gators on his feet, straight from the “show"room.

annotations.text: Fuck around, y'all gonna be up on the Maury Show
annotations.annotation: However, young lady, if you cross Cam you’ll end up on Maury Povich (a daytime talk show of the Jerry Springer era)

annotations.text: He in bootcamp
annotations.annotation:
Maury Povich sometimes sent troublemakers to “bootcamp” to straighten them out
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gs9OcANHjFI

annotations.text:
You on food stamps
 Welfare, no health care,
annotations.annotation: Cam is threatening this woman: if she betrays or dissatisfies Cam in any way (or if he grows tired of her), he will cut off his aid and support, abandoning her to America’s inadequate social safety net. The choice is between obeying Cam or being thrown on the mercy of a diminishing welfare state, a nice observation about the nexus of patriarchal power and neoliberalism.

annotations.text: A true tramp
annotations.annotation: Tramp here means 1) whore, 2) penniless hobo

annotations.text: Here's some weed, burn yourself a pound
annotations.annotation: Cam gives weed to one of his guys and tells him to keep a pound for himself but sell the rest

annotations.text: Whoadie
annotations.annotation: New Orleans slang for “homie” (a derivation of “Wardy”, since New Orleansites are divided into “Wards”)

annotations.text: Here's a map, go learn yourself the town, sporty
annotations.annotation: Back in the late 80’s and early 90’s, a lot of NYC rappers would leave town to go sell drugs elsewhere; Cam’s saying that if you do your research on untapped emerging drug markets and learn the intricacies of a small (usually Midwestern) town, you can make money like he did in Ohio

annotations.text: Buck 50
annotations.annotation: To “catch a buck 50” is to be cut with a razor from ear to mouth. It’s called a “buck 50” as in 150 because, on average, it takes 150 stitches to close such a cut.

title.name: Tha Crossroads (D.J. U-Neek's Mo Thug Remix)

annotations.text:
Bone, Bone, Bone, Bone
 Bone, Bone, Bone, Bone, Bone
annotations.annotation:
This is like Bone Thug’s version of that famous English language example of how homonyms and homophones can be used to create complicated linguistic constructs. “Buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo” is a grammatical sentence in American English that first appeared in 1967 in Dmitri Borgmann’s Beyond Language: Adventures in Word and Thought.

It means: “Bison from Buffalo that bully (in a style unique to Buffalo) bison from Buffalo are themselves bullied (in a style unique to Buffalo) by bison from Buffalo.”

The Bone Thugs intro means: “BONE!”

annotations.text:
When judgment comes for you
 When judgment comes for you?
 Now tell me, what ya gonna do
 (Now, tell me what...)
 When it ain't nowhere to hide
 When judgment comes for you
annotations.annotation:
This refrain alludes to the idea of “final judgement” found in many forms of Christian theology. Particularly, the idea of judgement at the end of all life from the biblical book of Revelation. For example: Revelation 20:11 – 15

https://biblia.com/books/esv/Re20.11

annotations.text: [Verse 1: Bizzy Bone]
annotations.annotation:
Bizzy recited the correct lyrics to this verse in a Periscope session.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2tULIUWN2Qk

annotations.text: Wally
annotations.annotation:
Wallace (Wally) Laird III was a friend of the Bones.

The song was originally dedicated to Wally—only named “Crossroad,” which can be heard on E. 1999 Eternal. With the death of Eazy-E, they remade it as “Tha Crossroads.”

annotations.text: Eazy,
annotations.annotation: Eazy-E of N.W.A., who died of AIDS in 1995, had a big part in getting Bone Thugs signed and starting their careers.

annotations.text: C's Uncle Charlie
annotations.annotation:
From a 2007 interview with Wish Bone for the Cleveland Free Times:

Uncle Charles was my mother’s brother. He had retired, but he’d worked for Ford so he had a little bit of change. He was real fly. He’d get up every day and put on a suit. He drove Lincolns and Cadillacs. He was the uncle who’d come around and take us to the movies; everybody got five dollars. But he was also the one that was really behind us in our music career, because that’s what he wanted to do too. He used to listen to our little mixtapes we’d bring home, just encourage us. All our talent shows he’d be in the front row, every one.

annotations.text: Little Boo,
annotations.annotation:
Referring to Lil Boo, the original fourth member of The Graveyard Shift (Part of the Mo' Thugs Family.)



He was killed on October 29, 1994 at age 16 after  diving in front of his infant nephew during a drive-by shooting at his mother’s house.

annotations.text: And I'm gonna miss everybody
annotations.annotation: When he is deceased and leave earth, he will miss all his loved ones that he is leaving behind.

annotations.text:
I done rolled with blows like AIDS
 Looked at him while he laid and prayed
annotations.annotation:
Eazy-E died of AIDS. Bone-Thugs-n-Harmony were very close with him and visited him in the hospital and also attended his funeral.

AIDS can be devastating for the friends and family of the patient as the patient is vulnerable to various diseases and they grow weaker after the fact.

annotations.text:
Lil' Layzie came to me
 Told me if he should decease, "well, then please
 Bury me by my Gran Gran
 And when you can, come follow me."
annotations.annotation:
Layzie wants to be buried with his grandma because she is his most beloved deceased relative. Because he is involved with thug life and gangster life, he worries that he will die early, meaning that other important family members may not be dead.

He also wishes for Bizzy, one of his really good friends, to meet him in afterlife.

annotations.text: We livin' our lives to eternal our souls,
annotations.annotation:
This is a popular religious idea that when you die your soul will leave your physical body and face judgement to decide if you will spend your afterlife in Heaven, or in Hell. In this context, “the crossroads” is a metaphor for the point where the physical word ends and the spiritual world beings.

Specifically, he’s living in a way that will earn God’s approval aka earn his soul eternal life.

annotations.text: Hey-o-ayo
annotations.annotation:
“Ayo” is like a form of Gregorian chant here

Agnus dei, quitolis peccata Layzie, miserere nobis

annotations.text:
Pray and we pray and we pray
 And we pray and we pray
 Every day, every day, every day, every day
 And we pray and we pray
 And we pray and we pray
 Still we lacin'
annotations.annotation: Prayer is something that most that are religious do. Every religion has a prayer. It is a common thing that those who believe in any God does.

annotations.text: Now follow me, roll stroll
annotations.annotation: Krayzie Bone says this in two other songs “Land of Tha Heartless” and “Thuggish Ruggish Bone” part of his style that everyone loves.

annotations.text: Wally,
annotations.annotation:
Krayzie told OkayPlayer:  “Wally was actually a part of Bone, but he didn’t rap or sing or anything. We all grew up together and he was with us all the time, so we considered him a part of the group.” He was shot and killed while breaking up a fight.

Krayzie Bone spoke on him in the following interview:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FdMEzxmSdKk#t=1301

The original version of Tha Crossroads, “Crossroad”, was entirely about Wally.

annotations.text: Eazy
annotations.annotation: Eazy E (Eric Wright) was crucial in the start off Bone Thugs-N-Harmony as he signed them to Ruthless Records he also died off AIDS in 1995 in this lyric they talk about greeting Eazy when they die.

annotations.text: Boo
annotations.annotation: Refers to Lil'Boo, one of the group’s friends who was murdered in a drive-by shooting

annotations.text: While you laughin' we're passin' passin' away
annotations.annotation: While people are having fun and passing their time, a lot of people are dying. He is saying that while time flies and we are having fun with our own little world, a lot of people are getting killed or dying and we are unaware of it. To us all those people who’ve died are meaningless and we don’t care because everybody has to die one day. Only death that is serious to us is the death of our relatives.

annotations.text:
Damn, man, I miss my Uncle Charles, y'all
 And he shouldn't be gone
annotations.annotation:
From a 2007 interview with Wish Bone for the Cleveland Free Times:

Uncle Charles was my mother’s brother. He had retired, but he’d worked for Ford so he had a little bit of change. He was real fly. He’d get up every day and put on a suit. He drove Lincolns and Cadillacs. He was the uncle who’d come around and take us to the movies; everybody got five dollars. But he was also the one that was really behind us in our music career, because that’s what he wanted to do too. He used to listen to our little mixtapes we’d bring home, just encourage us. All our talent shows he’d be in the front row, every one.

annotations.text: In front of his home, what they did to Boo was wrong
annotations.annotation: Boo was killed in 1995, at the age of 16, as he was attempting to protect his baby nephew from stray bullets.

annotations.text: And Ms. Sleazy set up Eazy to fall
annotations.annotation:
While “Ms. Sleazy” may simply refer to the woman Eazy contracted the HIV virus from, there is speculation that Suge Knight had a part to play. Not only does Eazy E’s son believe Knight had Eazy injected with the virus, but the Bone Thugs group believes it as well.

Suge brought more attention to himself, fueling the conspiracy theory with a strange remark he made on Jimmy Kimmel Live!:

So they got stuff where they get blood from somebody with AIDS, and they shoot you with it. So that’s a slow death—that Eazy-E thing.

Ms. Sleazy may also be referring to Eazy’s wife, Tomica Wright, whom the crew never really liked due to her business practices.
