annotations.text: [Produced by Large Professor]
annotations.annotation:
The production has an up-tempo vibe created by trumpets bass and tambourine that Nas rhymed over. It contains 3 samples:


Vocals and instrumentals from “School Boy Crush” by Average White Band

Bass from “Dead End” by Japanese Hair Cast

While the trumpets are from “Soul "Travelin' Pt. I (The G.B.E.)” by Gary Byrd




Funfact: Busta Rhymes was offered the beat, but passed on it even though he loved it (he just didn´t know what to write on it)

The sample choice of this song was possibly inspired by Eric B. & Rakim’s hit single, “Microphone fiend”, which just so happened to also heavily sample “School Boy Crush” by Average White Band.

annotations.text:
(Right… Right…)
 Check me out y'all
 Nasty Nas in your area
 About to cause mass hysteria
Before a blunt, I take out my fronts
annotations.annotation:
Fronts are jewelry for teeth, typically of gold or platinum. Nas takes out his before he smokes a blunt.



Removing fronts is essential before smoking, since the smoke tarnishes the metal.  This is especially the case with 10k gold but is less of an issue with higher carat gold (18-24). Jewellers advise wearers not to drink or smoke when wearing grillz or at least to buy a higher carat pair to minimise the damage.

annotations.text:
You couldn't catch me in the streets without a ton of reefer
 That's like Malcolm X catchin' the Jungle Fever
annotations.annotation:
“Jungle Fever” is being attracted to somebody from another race; it was a phrase in the ‘60s used by Black Power people to criticize (mostly male) blacks who went with white (women).

The thought of Malcolm X selling out and liking white women is preposterous (even though X did have white girlfriends before converting to The Nation of Islam), as is the thought of Nas being out and about without crazy amounts of weed.



“Jungle Fever” and “Malcolm X” are also the titles of films released consecutively by Spike Lee in 1991 and 1992, and it’s also worth noting that this song was recorded for soundtrack to Zebrahead, a movie that caught quite a bit of flack for being too similar to Jungle Fever in terms of content.

annotations.text: King poetic, too much flavor
annotations.annotation: “King poetic” refers to Martin Luther King, Jr., comparing Nas’s lyricism with the oratorical skills of the renowned civil rights leader.

annotations.text:
I'm major
 Atlanta ain't Brave-r
annotations.annotation:
This is not the last time Nas calls himself ‘major’. Here, he uses it to introduce a riff on a Major League Baseball team.

The Atlanta Braves are a baseball team. Even they are not more courageous than Nas.



Nas would later form a hip hop group called the Bravehearts

annotations.text: I pull a number like a pager
annotations.annotation:
Just as a pager (the proto-iphone; people could “beep” you their number, or use an alphanumeric code to send Stone Age BBMs) “pulls” (displays) numbers, Nas “pulls” (obtains) girls' telephone numbers

It is also possible that “Pulling a number” to killing someone, as in “Pull their card”

annotations.text: ‘Cause I'm a ace when I face the bass
annotations.annotation:
Triple Entendre here!


When the bass is a beat, he’s an ace at rapping
and when the base is crack cocaine, the freebase form of coke often referred to as BASE, he’s an ace at dealing.
and when the base is homeplate, he’s an ace at pitching



The Braves of the early 1990s were known for their ace pitching staffs (anchored by Maddux, Smoltz, Glavine).



Also a play on the name of Swedish mid-90s pop sensation Ace of Base

annotations.text: 40-side is the place that is givin' me grace
annotations.annotation: A 40-side is a ghetto in New York, specifically one in Queensbridge. Nas has referenced Queensbridge multiple times in his music. He moved there at a young age and started rapping there.

annotations.text: And I'm a Nike-head
annotations.annotation: “Nike-head” plays on the theme of addiction in the previous line (think coke-head or pot-head)—only Nas is a fiend for them Nike kicks.

annotations.text: I wear chains that excite the Feds
annotations.annotation: Nas' necklaces are so obviously out of his legitimate price range that when federal agents see them, they get excited, since they figure the only way he can have that kind of money is by doing something illegal (so now they know they can start building a case).

annotations.text:
I'm a performer, strange
 So the mic warmer was born to gain
annotations.annotation:
He’s a strange performer. Also note the older meaning of “strange” as “unique.”

Being a “Mic warmer” is a quite poetic and intimate way to embody his passion for rap. It’s as if he were breathing life into the microphone, or incubating it so it gives birth to something amazing.

annotations.text:
Nas, why did you do it?
 You know you got the mad-phat fluid when you rhyme
 It's halftime
annotations.annotation:
Nas shifts to the third person here, dropping more braggadocio, which fits with the theme of the track. The question is rhetorical an open ended; it could be, “Nas, why did you dominate the rap game? or "Nas why did you murder this track?

The second line is a poetic way of alluding to the fluidity and eloquence  of Nas’s verse.

“Mad-phat” is an expression which combines the street meaning of the words:


“Mad” – Something that is hyped or has a lot of energy
“Phat” – A word describing something that is cool

annotations.text:
(Right…) It's halftime
 (Right…) Ayo, it's halftime
 (Right…) It's halftime
 (Right…) Yeah, it's about halftime
 This is how it feel, check it out, how it feel
annotations.annotation:
Though “Halftime” dropped in ‘92 as a single, notably in the movie Zebrahead, it is halfway through Illmatic. (Track 5 of 10)

Additionally, if you own Illmatic on vinyl, you’re supposed to flip the record after this track. You’re forced to have a pause – halftime.

annotations.text: [Verse 2]
annotations.annotation:
The channel “Highlighted” also Highlighted The Rhyme Scheme from this Verse:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aRnVRGiK63Y

annotations.text: It's like that, you know it's like that
annotations.annotation:
A possible interpolation of Run D.M.C.’s It’s Like That, from 1984. Run D.M.C. hails from the borough of Queens, just like Nas.



Or the main  the hook of Live at the Barbeque by Main Source (1991)

annotations.text: I got it hemmed, now you never get the mic back
annotations.annotation:
This verse starts with “freestyle circle at a party” imagery – a lot of rappers standing around, arguing over the microphone.


“Got it hemmed” is probably a restatement of the more common “got it sewn up,” meaning fully under control and closed to outside influences. Usually, a drug dealer or influential neighborhood person is said to have a certain block or area “sewn up,” indicating his total dominance over that zone
But it could also mean that his style is Custom fit so no one else could wear it.

annotations.text: There ain't a army that could strike back
annotations.annotation: This line would later be sampled in the song “The Message” on his 1996 sophomore album, It Was Written.

annotations.text: So I react, never calmly on a hype track
annotations.annotation:
First of all, check out that rhyming

When I attack, there ain’t an army that could strike back
So I react never calmly on a hype track

Similar to what MF DOOM did 10 years later

Nas is saying that because he can destroy armies of MCs, he can’t hold the feeling of triumph in and goes wild on a beat like this one.

annotations.text: I set it off with my own rhyme
annotations.annotation: This could be a reference to Set It Off, where Cormega makes use of the term ‘Illmatic’ for the first time on a record

annotations.text: ‘Cause I'm as ill as a convict who kills for phone time
annotations.annotation:
There are only so many phones in prison, so if somebody’s hogging up the phone line and you want to make a call, sometimes you just have to shank the guy to get him out of your way.

Notice that Nas subtly claims to be as ill as his buddy in prison.

annotations.text: I flex like sex
annotations.annotation:
Nas' use of “flex” has multiple meanings. To “flex” means to show off. In this context, he is  showing off his rapping skills. Also, by “flex like sex”, Nas is referring to the muscle flexion during sex. So, he is flexing his rapping skills in the same way one flexes muscles.

A third possible meaning of “flex” is to bend a limb or joint.

annotations.text: In your stereo sets, Nas'll catch wreck
annotations.annotation:
Possible Triple Entendre


Catching wreck is to put on a superb performance when engaging in an activity that requires skill (such as sports or freestyle rapping); going hard in general.
The context (“max like cassettes”) suggests a play on words – Nas will catch “rec”, meaning he will be recorded off the radio onto Maxells because his music is so fly.
Could also mean he will “Catch rec”(ognition) from being in your stereo sets.



https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=8suHDcGpTEE

annotations.text: I used to hustle, now all I do is relax and strive
annotations.annotation:
The fiends fight to get crack I just max, I dream I can sit back
And lamp like Capone, with drug scripts sewn
Or the legal luxury life, rings flooded with stones, homes

In this context, hustling means selling drugs, which Nas has alluded to a number of times on this album. But now that he’s found his place as an MC, he finds himself able to live comfortably and pursue greater things.

annotations.text: When I was young, I was a fan of The Jackson 5
annotations.annotation:
Nas was a fan of the group the Jackson 5 child prodigy with lead singer Michael Jackson too, he even sampled a song from Michael Jackson in his song “It Ain’t Hard to Tell”, off the same album.

When Mike Jack was black:

annotations.text: I drop jewels, wear jewels, hope to never run it
annotations.annotation:
Rapping a good line – or any activity that expands knowledge – is often described as “dropping a jewel” (cf. 2pac)

Then, he talks about literal jewels

Continuing the “jewels” wordplay, to “run” your jewels is to get your jewelry taken from you, presumably at gunpoint.

On “Supa Ugly”, Jay-Z claims that Nas:

had to buy back your chain last time you got robbed–the nerve of this coward, oh my God!

annotations.text: With more kicks than a baby in a mother's stomach
annotations.annotation:
Kicks are slang for shoes, and babies often “kick” while moving around in the womb which can be felt by the mother or with a hand on the stomach.

Nas already stated his love for shoes in verse one with the “Nike-head” rhyme, and this is a clever way of flaunting his large shoe collection.

annotations.text:
Nasty Nas has to rise ‘cause I'm wise
 This is exercise 'til the microphone dies
annotations.annotation:
Nas' rhyme with words ending in /-ise/ both internally and externally in this concise couplet. This is testimonial to his commitment to refining his lyricism.

21-years-old at the time, Nas was confident that he would rise to stardom because of his intelligence.

When he states, “This is exercise,” Nas may have been describing the facility with which he can create clever rhymes. The novice Nas could have also been foretelling his endurance as a cultural icon.

annotations.text:
Back in '83 I was an MC sparkin'
 But I was too scared to grab the mics in the parks and
 Kick my little raps ‘cause I thought niggas wouldn't understand
annotations.annotation:
Nas was only 10 years old at the time; he was reticent to share his raps about Sesame Street, fearing that they would be considered “too intellectual” to attract a mass audience

But seriously, in his biography we learned that Nas would never rap outside in his projects because he felt more comfortable in his apartment with the people he knew well

annotations.text: And now in every jam, I'm the fuckin' man
annotations.annotation:
Nas went from being a relative nobody, to killing every track he was featured on

This began on Main Source’s “Live at the Barbeque”. After the release of the song, he began to be critically acclaimed, and people started to notice him. This lead to cultural prominence, even before Illmatic, and people began calling him the next coming of Rakim

annotations.text: I rap in front of more niggas than in the slave ships
annotations.annotation: Slave ships would have guaranteed a large but uncomfortable audience – the Middle Passage was so barbaric, and slaves had to be packed in so tightly to make a profit, that even the slaveholding South agreed to end the importation of slaves.

annotations.text: I used to watch "CHiPs", now I load Glock clips
annotations.annotation: He used to watch CHiPs, a ‘70s cop show which glorified policemen, but now he’s loading Glocks with ammo (to shoot at real police).  Jay-Z, years later, would have another take on this same idea

annotations.text: I got to have it, I miss Mr. Magic
annotations.annotation:
Every Saturday, Rap Attack, Mr. Magic, Marley Marl

Mr. Magic was the influential host of the first-ever exclusively hip-hop radio show on a major radio station, WHBI-FM (begun in 1979).

We now all miss Mr. Magic, because he died on Oct. 2, 2009 (RIP homie)

annotations.text:
Versatile, my style switches like a faggot
 But not bisexual, I'm an intellectual
annotations.annotation:
Nas' usage of “faggot” here is not only edgy (note him avoiding it in live shows) but also involves some wordplay, as some homosexual men do choose to walk like women, swaying their hips from side to side while walking i.e., switching.
Note that “versatile” also refers to a gay man who has roughly equal preference between being a “top” (giver) and “bottom” (receiver), and so this line may more likely refer to that.

BUT

Nas lets us know that he was talking about another type of “faggots” – Sticks. A switch is a stick of a particular width that was used for corporal punishment in the past.



This kind of shock and reveal type line is also employed (to greater effect) on “The World Is Yours”:

I’m out for presidents to represent me (say what)
I’m out for presidents to represent me (say what)
I’m out for dead presidents to represent me

annotations.text: These are the lyrics of the man, you can't near it, understand?
annotations.annotation:
Nas is patronizing his rap contemporaries by making a bold proclamation and then asking if they comprehended the unusually structured possessive. (“these are the lyrics of the man” rather than “these are the man’s lyrics”).

Nas positions himself as “the man,” a phrase used to describe a person who is exceptionally influential or especially dominant in a specific domain. Afterward, he eloquently emphasizes that his lyrics are peerless (you can’t near it) and innocuously asks, “understand?” This could be his way of demanding that his lyrical adversaries literally stand under him.

annotations.text: ‘Cause in the streets, I'm well-known like the number man
annotations.annotation:
“Number men” were the gambling entrepreneurs who would run the “numbers game”, a sort of underground lottery that was very popular, notably during the Harlem Renaissance

People in the streets are addicted to gambling, just as they are addicted to listening to Nas' music

annotations.text: Explore rap and tell me Nas ain't all that
annotations.annotation: Nas is telling the listener to listen to more rap and return to see if there is really any other rapper on Nas’s level.

annotations.text:
And next time I rhyme, I be foul
 Whenever I freestyle I see trial, niggas say I'm wild
annotations.annotation:
Words have power. That is why freedom of speech is very important. Nas says that his rhymes are so foul, they should be illegal. So everytime he tries to say something, he immediately sees the ramifications of it – a trial.

Nas spoke about this same topic previously on a Genius interview while talking about a similar line on It Aint Hard To Tell

https://genius.com/31369

annotations.text:
(Right…) It's halftime
 (Right…) Ayo, it's halftime
 (Right…) It's halftime
 (Right…) Yeah, it's about halftime
 This is how it feel, check it out, how it feel
annotations.annotation:
Though “Halftime” dropped in ‘92 as a single, notably in the movie Zebrahead, it is halfway through Illmatic. (Track 5 of 10)

Additionally, if you own Illmatic on vinyl, you’re supposed to flip the record after this track. You’re forced to have a pause – halftime.

annotations.text:
I got it goin' on, even flip a morning song
 Every afternoon, I kick half the tune
 And in the darkness, I'm heartless like when the NARC's hit
annotations.annotation:
Nas is rapping in the morning and afternoon, fine tuning his craft and building his legacy, but when night falls; Nas turns into “A Villain”

NARC’s usually raid a house late at night or early in the morning so they can catch the people inside by surprise. A heartless tactic.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EUbhX7xWvSI

annotations.text: Marcus Garvey
annotations.annotation:
Marcus Garvey was the father of the pan-African movement who, like many black leaders past and present, and like the narrator here, was persecuted by law enforcement

The mention of Garvey’s name, along with Malcolm’s, continues this song’s run of mentioning “key figures and sites of the black freedom struggle.”  Marc Lamont Hill writes about this in his great essay on the song:

Nas' references to Malcolm X, Martin Luther King, and Marcus Garvey also demonstrate his sustained commitment to political subject matter in spite of the culture’s shift from overtly political music…to the gangster rap sounds of Ice-T, NWA, and Snoop Dogg that had begun to dominate both hip-hop and American popular music

annotations.text:
‘Cause when I blast the herb, that's my word
 I be slayin' 'em fast, doin' this, that and the third
annotations.annotation:
EMINEM’s take on Halftime – spitting this BAR and why NAS is one of the greatest!

https://youtu.be/wADrxUI3OeI?t=522

annotations.text: But chill, pass to Andre, and let's slay
annotations.annotation:
Andre is a brand of cheap champagne.  Before going to go “slay” (make love to) some girls, Nas likes to prep with some bubbly

It’s worth noting that he uses “slay” again, here with a positive, sexual meaning, in stark contrast to “slayin” in the previous line, which had a negative, violent meaning (but positive in the sense that he’s killing NARCs!)

annotations.text: I bag bitches up at John Jay
annotations.annotation: Nas is not talking about John Jay College of Criminal Justice, an NYC-based city university.  As you can tell from the video above, he is talking about John Jay High School.  As of 2003, the school was broken up into four different high schools – The Secondary Schools for Law, Journalism and Research and Millennium Brooklyn.

annotations.text: And hit a matinée
annotations.annotation:
A matinee is an afternoon viewing of a performance in a theater or cinema. Nas picks up his shorty from John Jay High School and takes her to a cheap after school movie for some naughty in the dark.

There’s a good chance he was heading to the Park Slope Pavilion which is a few blocks away from the school.

annotations.text: Puttin' hits on 5-0
annotations.annotation:
The 5-0 is slang term for the police, made popular by the police drama, *Hawaii Five-0.  “5-0” is derived from Hawaii being the 50th state.

So, Nas is so hard and unafraid of death, that he is willing to put bounties on the heads of police officers he doesn’t like (probably because they were corrupt or overly brutal) – he is a hood warrior and will do anything to protect Queensbridge.

One of his possible targets may have been a policeman he referenced in this same track:

And yo: “go to hell” to the foul cop who shot Garcia

annotations.text: ‘Cause when it's my time to go, I wait for God with the .44
annotations.annotation:
Nas plans to face Jah with a .44 Magnum (gangsta!). I guess heaven really does have a ghetto

This line also suggests that Nas has some kind of beef with god about the world around him.

Speaking of whom, Nas says:

That’s one of Tupac’s favorite lines, he used to scream that line out to me in a rage back in ’93, Pac was feeling that line and that stuck with me

annotations.text: And biters can't come near
annotations.annotation:
A “biter” is somebody who copies what other artists are doing. An example would be if you copied the look of another artists album cover, or their style. Nas can’t be imitated.

Listen to the link below for further understanding.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nx3xcDmJ9dE

annotations.text: And yo, go to Hell to the foul cop who shot Garcia
annotations.annotation: In 1992, a riot broke out in Washington Heights, NY after Jose “Kiko” Garcia was shot by police. A grand jury refused to indict the “foul cop” Michael O'Keefe.

annotations.text:
I won't plant seeds, don't need an extra mouth I can't feed
 That's extra Phillie change, more cash for damp weed
annotations.annotation:
By not “planting seeds” (having unprotected sex and creating children), Nas assures that he won’t have to pay child support, which means he’ll have more money to buy weed and smoke blunts.

And we KNOW he’s not promoting abstinence.



“Damp weed” is  marijuana that  isn’t cured or ready to be smoked yet because it is still moist and fresh from being a live plant. This can possibly be seen as sarcasm as ironically, the money that he saves will only provide him with partially un-smokeable herbs.

annotations.text: The Boogie Down
annotations.annotation:
The “Boogie Down Bronx” is a song by Man Parrish from 1984.

It is also a nickname, for the Bronx immortalized by KRS-One’s Bronx-based group “Boogie Down Productions”.

annotations.text: Clout
annotations.annotation: Slang word for power, influence, fame

annotations.text: Ill Will, rest in peace, yo I'm out
annotations.annotation:
Nas' deceased childhood friend Willie “Ill Will” Graham, for whom Nas would later name his record label.

Nas has mad love for his deceased pal; he references him multiple times on this album alone and basically named the album after him.

He’s also referenced here and here.

annotations.text: Yo let's get ghost
annotations.annotation:
To get ghost is a slang expression for leaving/disappearing. In this line Nas says the police are there and could have said “yo let’s get out of here.”

Big L says it on “8 is Enuff” when he passes the mic to Terra and ends his verse with “Adios, ghost, I’m 5 thous” (5 thous as is Audi 5000)

annotations.text: [Produced by Pete Rock]
annotations.annotation:
Nas told XXL:

At the time, getting a beat from Pete Rock was like getting a beat from Kanye or Timbaland or fuckin’ Dre.

As for how Nas got hooked up, Pete Rock told Complex:


I met Nas through Large Professor because he was from Queens. When I was hanging out in Queens, he would take me all over meeting different people and different rappers. Once I met Nas, he brought Nas up to my house, and we were going through music, and I played him ‘The World Is Yours’ beat.

It wasn’t nothing at the time, it was just a beat that he heard that he liked. But it was a great piano riff, and he wanted to make the song.


And the hook comes from  “Its Yours” by T La Rock

Pete Rock made the beat in only 10 minutes.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Pete Rock + Nas]
annotations.annotation:
Pete Rock on the beat? ok. Rapping? Alright. But Pete Rock singing? How, you ask?:

[Nas had the idea of me singing in the chorus on it. He told me, ‘I want you to sing it.’ I told him, ‘Nah, I’m not singing, I’m not a singer.’ But he made me do it, and it came out the way it is now.

annotations.text: (It's yours)
annotations.annotation:
This comes from “It’s Yours” by T La Rock and Jazzy Jay.

https://youtu.be/nWkiIb6G9_8?t=27

Nas says:

I fought to get that [T La Rock] sample on there. Pete had a way of doing his beats, and he was Pete Rock, so I didn’t wanna interfere that much. But I had “It’s Yours” in my head, and I thought it would sound ill. At the last minute, he fit it in there, I think at the mix. I didn’t know how he was gonna fit it in there, but it was perfect how he did it.

annotations.text:
Whose world is this?
 The world is yours, the world is yours
 It's mine, it's mine, it's mine—whose world is this?
annotations.annotation:
This is a Scarface reference.  In the movie – which is an inspiration to many rappers – Tony Montana’s motto is “The World is Yours”, a reflection of his ambitious nature in spite of his humble beginnings



This attitude of owning the world is seen throughout all of hip hop like in Ice Cube’s ‘The World Is Mine’.

annotations.text: (It's yours)
annotations.annotation:
This comes from “It’s Yours” by T La Rock and Jazzy Jay.

https://youtu.be/nWkiIb6G9_8?t=27

Nas says:

I fought to get that [T La Rock] sample on there. Pete had a way of doing his beats, and he was Pete Rock, so I didn’t wanna interfere that much. But I had “It’s Yours” in my head, and I thought it would sound ill. At the last minute, he fit it in there, I think at the mix. I didn’t know how he was gonna fit it in there, but it was perfect how he did it.

Whose world is this?
 The world is yours, the world is yours
 It's mine, it's mine, it's mine—whose world is this?
annotations.annotation:
This is a Scarface reference.  In the movie – which is an inspiration to many rappers – Tony Montana’s motto is “The World is Yours”, a reflection of his ambitious nature in spite of his humble beginnings



This attitude of owning the world is seen throughout all of hip hop like in Ice Cube’s ‘The World Is Mine’.

annotations.text: I sip the Dom P, watchin' Gandhi 'til I'm charged, then
annotations.annotation:
As a pre-game, Nas likes to drink expensive Dom Perignon champagne and watch the movie Gandhi, starring Ben Kingsley. By watching the story of a man fighting against injustice, he gets charged up and ready for songwriting.



He talks a little bit about the line on Google Talks:

https://youtu.be/L_4tAafaUfs?t=2410

annotations.text: Writin' in my book of rhymes, all the words past the margin
annotations.annotation:
A lot of rappers carry around a book in which they jot down rhymes that come into their head. Nas must be a believer in this technique because he covers every single inch of the book with his rhymes, and even dedicates a song to his rhyme book years later.

The third line continues past its rhyme with an extra syllable (“charged”/“margin”), beautifully mirroring Nas' description of writing past the margin in his rhyme book. This stands out even more as the rest of the verse comes out in tidy couplets.

annotations.text: Understandable smooth shit that murderers move with
annotations.annotation: This line speaks to Nas being in tune with the criminals in his neighborhood. Illmatic attempted to bring the ghetto into the public’s eye, so Nas ended up obtaining new fans from the hood instead of ostracizing them. Because of this, the album became popular amongst gang-bangers who would bump his relatable lyrics rapped over jazzy beats while committing crimes.

annotations.text: The fiend of hip-hop has got me stuck like a crack pipe
annotations.annotation:
Unclear here whether Nas is claiming that fans are fiending for his music, or if he himself is compelled to write rhymes.

Also a subtle shout out to Nas' one-time mentor, Rakim who was known as the Microphone Fiend.

annotations.text:
React like I'm facin'
 Time like Pappy Mason, with pens I'm embracin'
annotations.annotation:
Famous drug lord Howard “Pappy” Mason was facing sentencing for murder when this album was released in 1994. Just as Pappy will be sitting in jail (“facing time”) Nas feels trapped knowing he only has a limited time to convert his gift into meaningful music for the people.

Some slick wordplay here. Pen has two meanings: the literal pen, and the pen referring to prison, thus the mention of Pappy Mason.

annotations.text: Suede Timbs on my feets makes my cipher complete
annotations.annotation:
In Five-Percenter Supreme Mathematics, cipher is symbolized by the number 0 and represents 360 degrees of knowledge. In this context, it can be interpreted as Nas saying that Suede Timberland boots bring his wardrobe “full circle”. This pays homage to an old KRS-One line.



The line has since been referenced and used multiple times since Nas has said it. Notable examples are:


Jay-Z:
“S. Dots on my feet make my cipher complete”

Mac Miller:
“And the Nikes on my feet keep my cypher complete”

Troy ave:
“Troy Ave make the Cypher complete”

annotations.text: Whether cruisin' in a Sikh's cab or Montero Jeep
annotations.annotation:
Sikhs are a religious and ethnic group with origins in the Punjab region. They can be identified by their covered, uncut hair, and by steel karas (bracelets) worn on their wrists. Queens has the largest Sikh community in New York, so Nas was likely being driven through Queens by Sikh cab drivers.



On the other hand, Nas also rode around Queens in a Mitsubishi Montero.

Continuing the previous line through a 5 Percenter lens, Nas is saying that no matter what he’s using to get around, his cipher is complete.

annotations.text:
I can't call it, the beats make me fallin' asleep
 I keep fallin', but never fallin' six feet deep
annotations.annotation:
Nas may be distracted by music’s siren song, but never to the point where he’ll actually be in jeopardy of getting caught slipping and putting himself in mortal danger – which shouldn’t come as a surprise considering he warned us that sleep is the cousin of death. “Falling six feet deep” is a euphemism for dying, as corpses are often buried six feet under the ground during burial ceremonies.

http://screencast.com/t/JtAZYcw1sx

annotations.text: I'm out for presidents to represent me
annotations.annotation:
Nas clarifies that he isn’t hoping to find a president that will represent his ghetto on a national stage, as he has given up hope on something like that ever happening. Instead, he hopes to one day have “dead presidents” (dollar bills) that represent his status and wealth. “Dead presidents” became popular hip-hop slang when Nas’s predecessor Rakim introduced the term on 1986’s “Paid in Full”. Here is his awesome explanation of what inspired him to say it.



This line has received more attention over the years for its role in the infamous Nas/Jay-Z beef. Hov sampled this as his hook to “Dead Presidents II”, and offered Nas an opportunity to spit a verse on the record. When Nas declined to show things got hostile, culminating in “Takeover” and “Ether”.

annotations.text: (Say what?)
annotations.annotation: People are surprised (“say what?”) when Nas says he believes in the current political system, especially considering he has been very critical of the American government’s mistreatment of the ghettoes.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Pete Rock + Nas]

annotations.text:
To my man Ill Will, God bless your life (It's yours)
 To my peoples throughout Queens, God bless your life
annotations.annotation:
Willie “Ill Will” Graham was a childhood friend that was shot and killed. Nas pays tribute to Graham on a number of his songs and named his record label after his late friend.

Nas knows Queens is rough enough for this to happen to anyone there.

annotations.text: I trip, we box up crazy bitches
annotations.annotation:
This whole verse is illuminating the amount of violence in his neighborhood.


Crazy bitches start beef with Nas and his crew.
Nas trips and fires back at them.
They get Boxed up either laid to rest in a coffin or beaten seriously.

annotations.text: Aimin' guns in all my baby pictures
annotations.annotation:
Makes sense. He did shoot his way out his Mom Dukes.



Although, as Hov would have it on “Takeover,” Nas was a newcomer to guns:

I showed you your first TEC, on tour with Large Professor

annotations.text: Yet I'm the mild, money-gettin' style, rollin' foul
annotations.annotation: Even though Nas is suffering from the troubles of the ghetto, to which many men before him have fallen prey, he still keeps his eye on the prize.  Nas has maintained, as he’s gotten to a point where he needs “No Introduction” for us to know Nas, as proved on Life is Good. http://youtu.be/9aRI2rl-gsc

annotations.text: The versatile, honey-stickin', wild, golden child
annotations.annotation:
A golden child is someone who everyone loves and never does anything  wrong



However, it’s possible that Nas is referring to the titular character in the 1986 Eddie Murphy vehicle The Golden Child, who is a young boy from Nepal with mystical abilities

annotations.text:
Dwellin' in the Rotten Apple, you get tackled
 Or caught by the devil's lasso, shit is a hassle
annotations.annotation:
Nas flips the common nickname for New York, the Big Apple. Getting “tackled or caught in the devil’s lasso” means getting caught by police.

The violence of Nas' lyrics on a motivational song like this give off an interesting message. While New York’s “Big Apple” image gives off the whole American Dream vibe, Nas says it’s the opposite – rough and unforgiving. In a way, he’s saying: New York is pretty bad, so make the most of it!

“Devil” is part of “The Nation of Gods and Earths" (or the five percenters) terminology, meaning white people. "Lasso” also make sense in this way as a reference a noose and the lynching of black people by racists similarly it may also represent a police officer since all sheriffs were white in the wild west. Other terms for white people in five percenter influenced songs are serpents, cave dwellers, or the Yakub crew.

annotations.text: There's no days for broke days
annotations.annotation:
Since “smoke” (marijuana) is less expensive than crack, it is less profitable to sell

However, the income is more dependable, especially during a hazy economic climate; they’re gonna get theirs no matter how tough time are.



as opposed to Cocaine selling for twice as much.

annotations.text:
When sellin' smoke pays
 While all the old folks pray to Jesús, soakin' they sins in trays
 Of holy water
annotations.annotation:
Nas pronounces Jesus as “Hay-Soos”, the way it is pronounced in Spanish. Possibly influenced by New York’s fairly large Hispanic population.

“Soaking” hints at Nas rejecting absolution and confession. The old folks are only able to soak their sins instead of washing them.

annotations.text:
Thinkin' a word best describin' my life to name my daughter
 My strength, my son, the star will be my resurrection
 Born in correction, all the wrong shit I did, he'll lead in right direction
annotations.annotation:
That word?  Destiny


A reverse take on the Biblical notion “The sins of the father shall be visited upon the son a thousand times”. The mistakes in Nas life will help his son grow.

“My son, the star, will be my resurrection” is a Five Percent reference. According to NGE teachings, the “star” (son or daughter) will be the resurrection of the “God” (man/father) when the “Earth” (women/mother) gives birth his son. Also worth noting is that Strength, Sun and Star are all Tarot cards.

Method Man knows this too.

Fifteen years after Illmatic was released, Nas ended up having a son, and named him Knight. “Night” and “knight” are homophones, and stars shine at night. On top of that, “son” is homophonic with “sun”, and the sun is a star. Wordplay!

annotations.text: You flippin' coke or playin' spit, spades, and strip poker?
annotations.annotation:
Three card games are mentioned:


Spit – In spit, the goal is to get rid of cards as quickly as possible. Spit is closely related to the game speed.
Spades – A partners game that involves making bids and counting points.
Strip Poker – The same as regular poker (of whatever variety), but with articles of clothing used to bet instead of chips.



These card games and others are frivolous in comparison with the all-important endeavor of selling cocaine.

annotations.text: I'm the young city bandit, hold myself down single-handed
annotations.annotation:
Nas is a legit thug and unlike a lot of guys who need a crew to protect them, he rolls all by himself – he attained success through his own hard work with no outside help.

Note that this doesn’t just apply to his street life, as we find out on Got Ur Self A… – he takes full credit for the success of Illmatic as well:

My first album had no famous guest appearances
The outcome: I’m crowned the best lyricist

annotations.text: Born alone, die alone, no crew to keep my crown or throne
annotations.annotation:
Nas suggests he has no one to pass on his legacy, on the lines before its implied he and only he can look after himself:


We are all alone, born alone, die alone, and – we shall all someday look back on our lives and see that, in spite of our company, we were alone the whole way. I do not say lonely – at least, not all the time – but essentially, and finally, alone. This is what makes your self-respect so important, and I don’t see how you can respect yourself if you must look in the hearts and minds of others for your happiness

― Hunter S. Thompson

annotations.text:
I need a new nigga for this black cloud to follow
 ‘Cause while it's over me it's too dark to see tomorrow
annotations.annotation:
Nas deliberately describes the cloud as “black” – in doing so, not only does he portray his own pessimism through pathetic fallacy, he’s implying that the struggles that are troubling him are endemic, almost exclusively, in the African-American population, hence he needs a “new nigga”, not just anyone.

Nas also openly acknowledges his depression on these lines, a rarity in a genre so often based in myth-making. He has the courage to temporarily break from the myopic glamorization of life on the street, fending for oneself through cutthroat means. It takes its toll, and while extolling fierce independence, Nas acknowledges the inevitable lonliness that accompanies it. So in that way, his problems ARE part and parcel of the socio-economic circumstances of the system where black males face odds that dwarf those of Sisyphus.

Peep the video below where Nas talks about the line in an interview on Google Talks at 23:50:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L_4tAafaUfs

annotations.text: Tryin' to maintain, I flip, fill the clip to the tip
annotations.annotation: Of course, even when he’s in a Deepak Chopra mood of positive feelings, Nas still has to “flip” (sell drugs) and “fill the clip” (carry a loaded weapon) in order to maintain a good standard of living.

annotations.text: Picturin' my peeps not eatin' can make my heartbeat skip
annotations.annotation:
We see some of Nas’s iconic and profound love for his crew here. Nas is expressing concern and frustration at the adversity his friends and family faced struggling against a system that only seems to bring them down. He expresses a similar frustration in his letter to Born on “One Love”:

Though incarcerated your mind dies, I hate it when your moms cries

He uses “not eating” as a metaphor for poverty here, and there is no doubt he helped his crew as much as he could once the Illmatic money started to trickle in (albeit slowly–the record struggled to be certified gold in its early years). Even before he was loaded, he was giving Born’s mom money for shoes. Nas takes care of his own.

annotations.text:
And I'm amped up, they locked the champ up, even my brain's in handcuffs
 Headed for Indiana,
annotations.annotation: Former heavyweight champion boxer Mike Tyson was convicted of rape in ‘92 and served three years in prison. The conviction and prison sentence both took place in Indiana.

annotations.text: Stabbin' women like the Phantom
annotations.annotation:
Ok, so Nas is getting a lot of ladies on his way to Indiana. But which Phantom is he talking about?


The Phantom of the Opera, a disfigured opera-lover who becomes obsessed with a female singer. Probably the most likely option even though he doesn’t actually stab any women in the story and is revealed to be a virgin at the end.
The Phantom Killer, a serial killer responsible for several murders in Texas and Arkansas in the forties. He didn’t stab any of his victims though and targeted couples rather than women specifically.
The Phantom, a comic book superhero from the fictional African country of Bangalia. He has guns for weapons rather than knives though. And he’s married so presumably only ‘stabbing’ the one woman.



We’re going with Phantom of the Opera. There are loads of versions – there’s bound to be one with a knife-wielding villain.

annotations.text: The crew is lampin' Big Willie style
annotations.annotation:
At the time, “Big Willie” was slang for bon vivant and/or baller and would later become the title of an album on which Nas would co-write several smash hits.



The phrase also recalls Ill Will.

annotations.text: Check the chip-toothed smile, plus I profile wild
annotations.annotation:
When he made this song he had a chip on his left front tooth. You can see it in many of his old music videos

Peep the video below where Nas´brother, Jungle, tells the story how Nas lost his chipped tooth

https://youtu.be/yi_dUhazzWs?t=345

annotations.text: Burnin' dollars to light my stoge
annotations.annotation: Burning a “Stoge” (A cigar) is a symbolic act to show how little money means because of your immense wealth. In this section of the song Nas is discussing the degree to which he and his crew have come up.

annotations.text:
Plus the games people play
 Bust the problems of the world today
annotations.annotation: Nas, being an old-school hip-hop head, is undoubtedly aware of the Fearless Four’s 1983 jam “Problems of the World” (often incorrectly called “Problems of the World Today,”) which was a hit when he was 10.

Yeah, aight
 To everybody in Queens, the foundation (It's yours)
 The world is yours
 To everybody uptown, yo, the world is yours (It's yours)

 To everybody in Brooklyn
 Y'all know the world is yours (It's yours)

 Everybody in Mount Vernon, the world is yours (It's yours)

annotations.annotation:
Nas reps Queens and calls it “the foundation”, but that doesn’t stop him from shouting out half just about all of NYC.

Staten Island a borough closest to New Jersey.

annotations.text: [Hook: Shatasha Williams]
annotations.annotation:
The hook is sung by local Cleveland singer, Shatasha Williams, who also sang on Candyman’s 1990 hit, “Knockin’ Boots”. She was introduced to Eazy-E through a friend at the same time he was seeking female vocalists to work with Bone Thug.

Shatasha was brought to the studio where the track was played for her and she was asked by Bizzy Bone to sing the hook.
After getting exposure from the song, she signed with Eazy-E’s Ruthless Records, and released one single. This was the last time she was heard by mainstream media. XXL Magazine was able to get in contact with her and interview her.

It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
 It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
 It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
 It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
annotations.annotation: This is describing the thug life nature of the group. Thuggish because of course they were from the hood and came up doing thug shit and they also considered them selves thugs. Ruggish meaning rough, they came up from the mean streets of Cleveland so it was only right they took on that. And lastly is bone because of course that was there group.

annotations.text:
You're feelin' the strength of the rump, step up
 Hear the funk of the jump that the thugstas feel
annotations.annotation: Layzie Bone opens the track by informing his listeners that what they are about to hear is some straight Bone Thugs style music—prepare your ears if you will—almost inviting his listeners to feel what it is like to be a Bone Thug through their music.

annotations.text:
Just be thuggin', straight buzzin'
 Lovin' your peoples cause we so real
annotations.annotation: A braggadocios line about how their fans love them. They are real people who rap about a true lifestyle that they live, which entails “thuggin” and “buzzin,“ the latter referring to getting high.

annotations.text:
Chill, better bring your weapon when steppin'
 Bring on that ammunition, trip and don't slip
 Not to mention, never knew no competition
annotations.annotation: With a quick switch of subject, he moves from his fans to his haters and enemies, telling them to “chill” and that if they are going to “step” to the Mo' Thug family, they better have their weapons ready with plenty of ammo. He goes on to mention that Bone Thugs are always tipsy as the Mo' Thugs never knew anyone who was competition against them anyway.

annotations.text: So scream out "Mo'!" and let me hear ya holla
annotations.annotation: Layzie is telling you to scream out 1) “More!” as in “More money! More Bone Thugs!” etc. 2) “Mo'” as in Mo' Thugs Family, which – according to their publicist – is a “Bone-related Thug Unity Coalition.”

annotations.text: Roll with the Bone, Mo' Thugs will follow
annotations.annotation: If you are seen rolling with Bone Thugs-N-Harmony, other thugs will start to respect you more because of the reputation of the group.

annotations.text:
Chain gang remaining the same
 Flaming my dank and drinking brew
annotations.annotation:
Despite their success in the music industry, they’re still that same old dank smoking and brew drinking gang.

“Flaming my dank and drinking my brew is simply Cleveland’s version of of “smoking endo, sippin on gin and juice.”

annotations.text:
Thinking about that hanging, clocking my bank
 And thuggin' with trues
annotations.annotation: His plan today is to “hang” (hang out), “clock [his] bank” (make money selling drugs) and “thug trues” (self-explanatory)

annotations.annotation:
All members of Bone Thugs have “bone” names. Dr. Seuss would have demanded that another member be named “Fishbone” but alas, no luck

There is a mediocre blipster rock/rap group called Fishbone, but…it’s not the same

annotations.text: You know me as a hustla
annotations.annotation: Wish Bone, like many other indiviuals from the hood makes his ends meet by selling drugs.

annotations.text:
Try to creep and get beat
 Maybe six feet, peep, gotta put them under
annotations.annotation:
In this instance, to “creep” is to betray Wish Bone or to do him wrong in some other sense. He warns of what may happen if one attempts this.

6 Feet Deep, or one fathom is the traditional depth for burial, meaning you are going to be killed. This phase has been used frequently in hip-hop and in the names of tracks/albums, including the 1993 single by Geto Boys and the debut album by Gravediggaz released later in 1994.

annotations.text:
Straitjackets, gotta make that money, man
 It's still the same now
 Bailin' in my black trench vest
annotations.annotation: The “gotta get that money, man” is sing-songy; Wish – whose nickname is “Straitjacket” because he’s kind of loony – seems to be trying to convey how much he resembles a schizophrenic obsessed with making money in his black trenchcoat: capitalism personified

annotations.text:
Come and get this teaching
 You soldiers how thugstas must stack
 Me drinkin' me brew 'til me skull crack
 Wig blew all the way back
annotations.annotation:
So as to say “Let me teach you all how to stack money like me (a thugsta).” He’s drinking until he is past drunk, then reiterates by saying “wig blew all the way back”.

He’s uses “me” instead of “I’m” and “my” to sound Rastafarian. Bone does this a lot in various songs (see here)

At this time in the 90s there was a lot of reggae resurgence that really brought that patois back into American culture in a way we hadn’t seen since Bob Marley.

annotations.text:
It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
 It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
 It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
 It's the Thuggish Ruggish Bone
annotations.annotation: This is describing the thug life nature of the group. Thuggish because of course they were from the hood and came up doing thug shit and they also considered them selves thugs. Ruggish meaning rough, they came up from the mean streets of Cleveland so it was only right they took on that. And lastly is bone because of course that was there group.

annotations.text: Now follow me now, roll, stroll off deep in the land
annotations.annotation:
So as to say “imagine this or picture this,” giving insight into his world: taking straight shots of alcohol to the head and continues with a wild night of fun by smoking strong weed and running from the police

Krayzie Bone repeats this line several times over the entirety of E. 1999 Eternal, including “Tha Crossroads” and “Land of Tha Heartless”.

Based off the other uses of this line, we can assume that “the land” refers to Cleveland.

annotations.text: Creep if you can
annotations.annotation:
Earlier in the song, “creep” was used to mean “be dishonest”

Here, it is used to mean “chill out”

annotations.text: Take another swig to the brain rose
annotations.annotation: Krayzie is partaking in his favorite drink (see other references), Irish Rose.  Rose is a type of cheap yet potent wine, similar to MD 2020 and Night Train.

annotations.text: Loc'in, steady chokin' off that potent smoke
annotations.annotation:
Locs are those sunglasses that Eazy-E wore in just about every picture you can find of him. The most famous use of the term comes from 2Pac’s “California Love”.

Dressed in locs and khaki suits, and ride is what we do.

Krayzie Bone and 2Pac give locs a more sinister purpose by hinting at activities they would engage in while “loc'in,” or, in 2Pac’s case, “dressed in locs.” While “loc'in,” Krayzie Bone would also be “steady chokin'” and “running from the po-po.” Similarly, 2Pac, “while dressed in locs,” announces, “ride is what we do,” and while he’s “flossin',” have “caution,” as “we collide with other crews.”

Before they were sunglasses, the word was used by the infamous Crip gang to identify themselves, it can also mean getting angry, going nuts, or drinking/smoking a lot of weed.

Here, it may mean “smoking a lot of weed.” Alternately, it could mean that he’s smoking while wearing the Locs.

annotations.text:
And running from the po-po now
 Gotta get up with my thugstas
 Right turn to the double Glock
annotations.annotation:
“Double Glock” is the nickname for the corner of E99 & St. Clair, which is basically the thuggest corner in Cleveland. While others avoid the area, perhaps even the police, Krayzie and his crew feel safe in the area.

They would go on to name their next album after this location.

annotations.text:
Pull to the curb, smoke with my hustlas
 Puff puff to the brain, shot
annotations.annotation: Once he returns back to his block (known as the Glock Glock or Double Glock in this case [E. 99]) to rejoin his homies, he feels secure. Once on his block, he pulls up to the curb where his family and friends are and lights up some marijuana to get ridiculously high.

annotations.text: Love P-O-D'd and tweeded
annotations.annotation:
P.O.D. stands for “Past Overdose”. In “1st of the Month” Krayzie Bone brags that he has the weed that gets you P.O.D.‘ed (see here)

Tweeded means “weeded” but with a T

annotations.text:
Gotta get another case for my trunk
 Olde English, really don't need it
 But in case my trues wanna get drunk
annotations.annotation: While smoking weed and chilling with his mates, Krayzie is going to make a quick liquor run to fill up his car’s trunk with a case of Olde English 40 ouncers.

annotations.text:
They pump Bone
 So leave 'em alone, you don't wanna get shut down
 Thug runnin' the nine-quad
 And you better believe they be running this thug style
annotations.annotation:
Their hearts pump the blood of the “Bone” gang so if you interfere with one, you’re stirring up trouble with all of them. This sort of reckless action will get you “shut down.”

He goes on to elaborate that Bone Thugs are running the nine (9)-quad (4). Being that the song is from 1994, they claim to be taking over the rap game.

annotations.text:
So what now? See the Bone Thug clank
 Thug never gonna change so flame up
 Sit back and just smoke to the same cut
 Leatherface on the creep and I came up
annotations.annotation:
This is a challenge to others in the rap industry, as to say, “Who can mess with us? We’re on top.” He goes on to state that Bone Thugs will never stop dominating and that the listeners may as well accept it and smoke some weed with their music on repeat.

He ends his verse by stating his nickname, Leatherface, and referencing the name of the album the track was originally on: Creepin' On Ah Come Up.

annotations.text: [Verse 4: Bizzy Bone]
annotations.annotation: Bizzy Bone, AKA Li'l Ripsta, is an American rapper and the youngest member of the Cleveland rap group Bone Thugs-n-Harmony.

annotations.text: Gotta give it on up to the Glock-Glock
annotations.annotation: Bizzy is praising the “Glock-Glock”, as the corner of East 99th and St. Claire avenue in Cleveland – known for it’s crack dealers.

annotations.text: Pop-pop, better drop when them
annotations.annotation: This line refers to local drug dealing, which often ends up with gun fire so he is telling you to duck when you hear the gunshots.

annotations.text: Buckshot
annotations.annotation: A buckshot is an (especially powerful) shotgun lead subcategory

annotations.text: The Bone in me never no hoe
annotations.annotation: The Bone in me never no hoe

annotations.text: No creepin' up outta the Ziplock
annotations.annotation: After Bizzy gives it on up to the glock-glock with the pop-pop you will not be able to escape the body bag–Zipped and locked.

annotations.text:
So Sin sip gin
 And Lil Mo Hart run up, nut up
annotations.annotation:
Sin & Lil Mo Hart are members of the Mo' Thugs Family, the Bone Thugs extended family

Bizzie tells Sin to sip gin and Lil Mo Hart to “run up” (rob people) and “nut up,” which is to say grow a pair, man up, or just go nuts.

annotations.text: Ever to test nuts, to the chest and put 'em to rest and
annotations.annotation: Bizzy makes an unusual comparison of nuts to bullets in that they both have shells. “Nuts to the chest” then means to bullets to the chest. The nuts also take on a double meaning here: If anyone wishes to test their courage (nuts), the result will be him killing them with a bullet (nut) to the chest.

annotations.text:
But I won't test bucks
 Put a hole up into me vest and
 Gotta get through my soul
annotations.annotation: Even though he’s wearing a (bulletproof) vest, Bizzy doesn’t want to put it to the test by getting hit with some buckshot, lest it penetrate to his soul

annotations.text:
Mug, drug, me picked em
 The blood in me running my mental
 The thug in me stuck in me keeping it simple
 The Thug in me running with thugs so
annotations.annotation: He is making a conscious decision for the drugs to take him over and cloud his judgement. He claims that he will forever be a thug and that the same drugs that are controlling him are controlling the way he writes his lyrics. It’s only when he’s high that he can come up with such rap lyrics and flow; it sparks his creativity.

annotations.text:
To the temple, buck when you duck
 To the thuggish ruggish T's
 St. Clair P's to appeal to the G's
 And a buck to all my enemies
annotations.annotation:
Bizzy concludes the song by giving a shout out to all the thugs (thuggish ruggish t’s), his people on his block (St. Claire), to killing, to G’s (either money or gangstas), then ending with a buck (fuck you) to all of his enemies.

Saint Clair Avenue is the main thoroughfare in East 90’s Cleveland; a lot of drug dealers post up on Saint Clair

Apparently, Saint Clair’s P(laya)s get along well with the Saint Clair G(angsta)s

Shatasha Williams, the hook singer, was scouted by Bone Thugs-N-Harmony during their first record sessions with Eazy-E in Cleveland, Ohio, and was later signed in to his label Ruthless Records to drop her first and only single “Free” in 1995.

There are two versions of “Free”, a rap and a R&B version.

annotations.annotation:
Cleveland is where Bone Thugs-N-Harmony are from. This wasn’t the first and definitely not the last time they gave a shout out to their hometown.

Nigga wuz born and brought up in Cleveland

 If you can't swallow, shut up bitch, gargle
annotations.annotation: This is also a sexual reference. Referring to swallowing cum

annotations.text: Straight up out that water with my Marc Jacobs goggles
annotations.annotation:
In Wayne’s world “the water” means the hood in New Orleans, (which was underwater after Katrina, built on top of water etc.). So he’s sayings he is straight out of the N.O. hood wearing expensive sunglasses

Wayne in Marc Jacobs “goggles”:

annotations.text: Sittin' in a cell,
annotations.annotation:
As far as we can tell, Birdman has spent all of 1 night in jail, for (what else) marijuana possession

Incidentally, the “Birdman of Alcatraz” is one of the most famous prisoners of all time (which makes it very difficult to Google this Birdman’s jail history)

annotations.text: So I scratch, and yes, Junior is the best
annotations.annotation:
Clever pun here with scratch: scratch-off lottery tickets make you rich (if you win). “Scratching” is also synonymous with “hustling”

However, it also means “from scratch” as in “making something from scratch”. “Jr.” (Lil Wayne) – who Birdman is claiming to have “scratched”, i.e. made from scratch – became more successful than Birdman ever was. Weezy is ultimately Birdman’s greatest venture

annotations.text:
So many niggas from my hood on they back
 So many niggas from your hood on they back
 That's why we so paid and it be like that

Birdman is like Gandhi; so many people from all of our hoods are now dead, and Birdman knows that these dead men have enabled his rise

He doesn’t want to increase the death toll needlessly, so he prefers to celebrate life by popping champagne rather than to propagate death by shooting guns

annotations.text: Choppers for companions
annotations.annotation: Birdman’s “chopper” (gun) is his only friend..

 No lie, we don't even drive no Aston

The DBS – Aston Martin’s most baller model – doesn’t come in automatic, so even though it’s a nice car, he’s not interested

(Birdman likes to have a free hand while driving to give thigh massage, wave to friends, and – most importantly – play with his iPhone)

Producer Ty-Tracks sampled the Hill Street Blues theme song for this beat (which might be a joke in itself since Hill Street Blues was a cop show and Cam'ron hates the police.)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Je2fGzKiqRM

annotations.text: We tie dynamite to the rhino type
annotations.annotation: “Rhino-type” is someone who does a ton of cocaine, just vacuuming that shit down rhinoceros-style. Cam blows these types away with his bomb-ass yayo

annotations.text:
Wino might find yo' sight
 Sell the information for a dime of white, that China-China
annotations.annotation: A wino might discover some incriminating information about you (where you pitch or stash for example, sight/site) and exchange it (with the police, e.g.) for $10 worth of white heroin (“that China China” = “China white” = a very pure form of heroin)

annotations.text:
I'm behind the diner, selling marijuana to a minor-miner
 Elder fella; looking for that shine? I'll shine ya
annotations.annotation:
He’s selling the little kid marijuana and offering this old (presumably white) man


A shoeshine, which is a historical reference to the time when Manhattan had a (usually black) shoeshine boy on every block
Some “shine” (cocaine)

annotations.text: My mind designer.
annotations.annotation:
Either he’s saying “I’m so smart you could say I’ve got a designer brain!” or he’s saying “The ‘mind’ (aka ‘brain’ aka ‘blow jobs) I get are top-notch”

When you see any references in rap to above-the-neck body parts: THINK BLOW JOB

annotations.text: You a dime? I'll dine ya
annotations.annotation: Are you a “dime” (pretty girl)? If so, then I’ll 1) take you to dinner (wine and dine), or 2) give you some Camcock to eat

annotations.text: Body bottled,
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron either means prefers bottle-shaped girls that are thick on the bottom, or that he likes this:

annotations.text: I hymen-grind her
annotations.annotation: Cam seems a little too world-wise to want to bed virgins, no? Wouldn’t that be a lot of needless drama?

annotations.text: Her mom remind her
annotations.annotation: “Now honey, remember not to let Cam hymen-grind you until he puts a ring on your finger!”

annotations.text:
Diamonds blind her; vision's gone, kiss her palm
 Turn her arm, lift her arm, notice that her wrists is raw
annotations.annotation: Cam'ron’s diamond bracelet blinds the young lady. “I’m sorry girl” – he kisses her hand, trying to make her feel better – and then he realizes she has no diamonds of her own! Now that’s just wrong…

annotations.text: "Gotta get it right ma, we gon' get along"
annotations.annotation: Cam lures the young lady by implying that he’ll “right” her wrist by buying her the diamonds it’s missing

annotations.text: Said "how?" "don't trip," but, yo, the trick is wrong
annotations.annotation: He feels bad about this (because he knows he’ll never actually spend any money on her)

annotations.text:
First visi-on, day job tick-a-tron
 Nighttime, Mr. Mom, bootleg Cris' and Dom
 Brother Chris and Don, and their sister Carm
 They sell yay', you'll say "yay, this shit's the bomb"
annotations.annotation: Tick-a-tron is way to buy concert tickets so Cam'ron is saying his day job is selling music. At night time he has to take care of the home and kids a la' Mr. Mom. He doesn’t have enough money to buy champagne Crystal or Dom Perignon so he has to buy the cheap bootleg versions of them. His brothers Chris and Don and his sister Carm are selling yay as in yayo as in cocaine. The cocaine is so good people will scream out in excitement saying, “Yay this coke is really good!”

annotations.text:
You my pick upon
 The rest, so yes, you'll be blessed to hit the intercom
 You know, kiss his mom,
annotations.annotation: “I love you girl. I’ll take you to Encino, introduce you to my parents…just remember to kiss my mom on the cheek! For Persians it’s a sign of respect…”

annotations.text: Wisdom
annotations.annotation:
Q: Is “wisdom” above the neck?

A: Yes

So what do you think this line refers to?

annotations.text: I cop bricks like sneakers
annotations.annotation:
I buy a lot of cocaine and a lot of Nikes

(Cam does too)

annotations.text: And if the cops come, I just hit amnesia
annotations.annotation:
The old Reagan Trick: if the cops question him about his drug business, Cam “does not recall”

Jay-Z has a similar line in “Can I Live”

annotations.text: "be careful"
annotations.annotation: At his therapist’s behest, Cam included a lot of motherly advice in this verse

annotations.text: Why I feel like I'm losing weight?
annotations.annotation: This line means a variety of things (for an explanation, see Cam’s Losing Weight II)

annotations.text: Why I ain't got no money if I'm moving weight
annotations.annotation:
“Moving weight” means “selling drugs”

Working at a law firm, you’re always asking yourself “I make 12K/month…where does it all go?!” (A: Taxes, yeyo, expensive shoes etc.)

annotations.text: My life's based upon what I'ma do this year
annotations.annotation: A reference to the hook from Losin' Weight, his collaboration with Prodigy (which was also echoed in Losing Weight (Part 2) and Movin' Weight

annotations.text: Cop a boat, cop a Lear
Now the army suit's cute with my chocolate Airs
annotations.annotation:
He’s wearing a captain’s jacket – an “army suit” – while flying his new Lear jet and remarking how cute it looks with the chocolate-colored Nikes he has on

“Chocolate airs” is also a pun; Cam – a handsome black man – is strutting around, putting on “chocolate airs” in his fancy flight uniform

annotations.text:
I made sure my mother and girl is smothered in pearls
 When a nigga under the world
annotations.annotation:
This could mean one or more of these four things, from most likely to least likely:


Cam’s lives in the dangerous underworld of drugs and violence. To keep his women from getting hysterical about it, he covers them in pearls
Cam launders money through cash purchases of jewelry (that he can take back at any time!). By under the world, he means under the radar of the taxman
Even when he’s feeling depressed (or having a bad fiscal quarter), he still treats his ladies to lavish jewelry
He’s saying that he’s stacked so much money in order to guarantee that when he’s dead and buried (“under the world”), his moms and girl will still have plenty to get by or even live well off of. It’s like Freddie Gibbs says, gotta stack as much drug money as possible:

Is my music gonna take care of my momma if I flop?
Is a nigga gonna depend on that? I think not.

annotations.text:
Everybody like, "Cam got the recipe now!"
 Not them 3 girls, I got to be Destiny's Child (gotta be me)
 Specially equities, reckon we smile
 Interfere,
annotations.annotation:
Cam knows what he’s doing! He turned those three know-nothing young ladies into Destiny’s Child (heard of them?*)

He’s also good at picking stocks (“equities”) which is why he’s all smiley even while other investors are scurred

note: Cam is just joking…he didn’t ACTUALLY promote Destiny’s Child. He’s just pretending!*

annotations.text:
Tech to tech and use the TEC that we wile
 Detective deceptive, receptive of fouls
annotations.annotation:
He used his Tec-9 (gun) to “wile out” (go nuts) and commit foul play

Also a pun on “technical fouls” in basketball

annotations.text: Heckler & Koch
annotations.annotation: Heckler & Koch is a German gun manufacturer

annotations.text: Helicopters on the set of my sales
annotations.annotation: Cam keeps helicopter guns on him for protection while selling drugs

annotations.text:
Nah, I ain't gonna be embedded in jail
 Talking to a cellmate in a bed in a jail, dog
annotations.annotation: Cam doesn’t plan to be placed in prison with only a cellmate for company.  He raps “embedded in” and “in a bed in” to sound like near-homophones.

annotations.text: I broke bread with the whale, fled from some seals (what else?)
annotations.annotation:
A “whale” is a big-money baller – in this case probably Cam’s coke supplier who Cam has lunch with to keep it cozy

Continuing the aquatic imagery, Cam mentions the Navy S.E.A.L.S. who were chasing him down on a drug bust

annotations.text:
And the house, I was the head of the hills, shit
 You get a dumb ho, and get dumb-happy
 Go to the gun show, get gun-happy
annotations.annotation:
This seems to be a standard “house on the hills” bourgeois fantasy – his (not so bright) lady friend is “dumb” (meaning “very”) happy with Cam’s fancy residence

Meanwhile, for his own material enjoyment, Cam prefers guns (and electronics!)

annotations.text:
Stuck, killed, mugged, milled
 Tone, flint, sticks, bo, Chub's milk
annotations.annotation: This seems to be an inventory of fugitive remembrance

annotations.text: Pucci baba, but I got the hardest shells
annotations.annotation:
Sure, Cam’s a fan of the Italian designer Emilio Pucci (“baba” means “daddy” in Persian)

But don’t get the wrong idea! Just because he’s a fashionista doesn’t mean he doesn’t have bullet shells that can do damage

annotations.text:
Ya, we'll just clap up your brains, snatch up your chains
 See dog? Rap is my aim
 But I'm a hustler, in my heart, trapped is the game
 Attached to my frame, tapped to my brain, the fact still remains:
 It wasn't rap, it was crack that got the racks on the Range
annotations.annotation:
Though Cam is primarily a rapper now, he won’t hesitate to shoot you in the head (“clap up your brains”) and take your jewelry should the opportunity arise. Although he aims to transform himself into a full-time rapper, the drug game is “trapped in his heart” (a sentiment echoed by Jay-Z in “Allure”)

This is underscored by the fact that it was dealing drugs, not rapping, that allowed him to add a chrome grill to his Range Rover

annotations.text:
Don't be asking for Dame, see
 Playboy, I don't own that man
annotations.annotation:
People keep asking Cam'ron where baller rap financier Damon Dash is so that they can ask him for a record deal

Cam'ron’s response: “Am I my Dash’s keeper?”

annotations.text:
And when I rap it ain't no punchline (not at all)
 I be on the highway dirty, crunch time
annotations.annotation:
“Punchline rap” is an epithet denoting clever wordplay that is devoid of content beyond each discreet joke or pun (think “Rappers Delight”)

Cam'ron insists his raps are meaningful. Furthermore – it’s no joke! – he really does transport drugs on the highway (since Cam is constantly joking around, hard to tell if he’s being sarcastic)

annotations.text:
No timeouts homeboy, just one time
 If they find that stash box just one time
 Shit, they'll put the dogs in the truck
 Side of the road, holding you up, you cold as a fuck
annotations.annotation: Cam is under pressure–like the clock is running down and his team is out of timeouts; there are no second chances. If the cops pull him over, they’ll have police dogs sniffing his truck, while he’s standing on the side of the road freezing

annotations.text:
They want that button, lunge it and push it
 Soon as they lunge it and push it, I run in the bushes
annotations.annotation: The cops want to know where the button that pops open the trunk is (Cam “can’t remember”). They find it and lean into the car to push it, and – woosh! – Cam seizes the moment and escapes into the woods by the highway

annotations.text: That's how I play mine, jump over the grapevine
annotations.annotation: “The grapevine” is a stylized reference for the bushes he has leaped into; it also refers to the rumor mill (I Heard It Through The Grapevine), i.e. snitching or loose talk which tipped the cops off

annotations.text: Steel and a clip for anyone squealing they lips
annotations.annotation: “Stealing a clip” / “saving a clip” is to put aside some bullets reserved for use on “snitches” (police informants)

annotations.text: Why I feel like I'm losing weight?
annotations.annotation: This line means a variety of things (for an explanation, see Cam’s Losing Weight II)

annotations.text: Why I ain't got no money if I'm moving weight
annotations.annotation:
“Moving weight” means “selling drugs”

Working at a law firm, you’re always asking yourself “I make 12K/month…where does it all go?!” (A: Taxes, yeyo, expensive shoes etc.)

annotations.text: My life's based upon what I'ma do this year
annotations.annotation: A reference to the hook from Losin' Weight, his collaboration with Prodigy (which was also echoed in Losing Weight (Part 2) and Movin' Weight

annotations.text: Cop a boat, cop a Lear
Now the army suit's cute with my chocolate Airs
annotations.annotation:
He’s wearing a captain’s jacket – an “army suit” – while flying his new Lear jet and remarking how cute it looks with the chocolate-colored Nikes he has on

“Chocolate airs” is also a pun; Cam – a handsome black man – is strutting around, putting on “chocolate airs” in his fancy flight uniform

annotations.text:
I made sure my mother and girl is smothered in pearls
 When a nigga under the world
annotations.annotation:
This could mean one or more of these four things, from most likely to least likely:


Cam’s lives in the dangerous underworld of drugs and violence. To keep his women from getting hysterical about it, he covers them in pearls
Cam launders money through cash purchases of jewelry (that he can take back at any time!). By under the world, he means under the radar of the taxman
Even when he’s feeling depressed (or having a bad fiscal quarter), he still treats his ladies to lavish jewelry
He’s saying that he’s stacked so much money in order to guarantee that when he’s dead and buried (“under the world”), his moms and girl will still have plenty to get by or even live well off of. It’s like Freddie Gibbs says, gotta stack as much drug money as possible:

Is my music gonna take care of my momma if I flop?
Is a nigga gonna depend on that? I think not.

annotations.text: Gotta rewind it (Beep-beep)
annotations.annotation:
A common brag is that one’s lines are either so hot or so complex that – before the advent of Rap Genius – the listener had to constantly rewind a rapper’s verse to understand/appreciate what he’s saying

See also J Cole’s “Water Break”:

I bet you never seen me coming
Like a blind bitch you fucking from behind
It’s that motherfucking dime, bitch
I’m fucking up rewind buttons

As well as Kanye West in “Barry Bonds”

Top 5 MCs you ain’t gotta remind me
Top 5 MCs you gotta rewind me

annotations.text: From ghetto to ghetto to backyard to yard
annotations.annotation:
This line interpolates a Rakim line from Eric B. & Rakim’s “My Melody”:

Rock from party to party, backyard to yard
I tear it up, y'all, and bless the mic for the gods

Pusha T also uses this line to start his verse in the original version.

annotations.text: I'm great in the kitchen like Corning cookware
annotations.annotation:
“CorningWare” is good for cooking crack:

CorningWare was originally a brand name for a unique pyroceramic glass cookware resistant to thermal shock. It is notable for the fact that it can be used directly on the stovetop

annotations.text: Coke price through the roof, SL, blew the coupe
annotations.annotation:
Pusha bought a Mercedes SL with the money he made selling cocaine (whose price has been “through the roof” recently since commodities are booming)

To “fly the coop” is to quickly escape (like chickens from a chicken coop); in this case, it was Pusha’s SL that “escaped” (from the dealership lot when he bought it)

There’s also a coop / coupe pun. i.e., Pusha’s also describing how he blows past coupes in his SL

annotations.text:

annotations.annotation:
Birdman and Mannie Fresh make up the duo Big Tymers; Big Tymers look for distinguishable headlight shapes in their cars (be it bubble-eye or frog-eye), cf. “Number one Stunna”:

That Lexus – the new one – that come out in 2001
With the frog eyes
And that Yu- the new Yukon, that’s bubble-eye
And that Mercedes Wagon, with the kit, that’s kitted out
Look like it got frog eyes

annotations.text: The guitar's cryin' right now

annotations.text: So 'bout it (Yeah), like Master P (Who?)

a fellow New Orleans Rapper.

annotations.text:
But no coward (Uh-uh)
 No, I am no Howard the Duck, duck (Baow)
annotations.annotation: ‘Howard the Duck’ is a movie released in 1986 about a cowardly duck who has to save the world from an alien invader.

annotations.text:
Lead showers (Yeah), black flowers (Yeah)
 Black dresses (Yeah), two hours (Yeah)
 Closed casket, uh (Aw)
annotations.annotation: Here Wayne is referring to a funeral. Black is commonly worn at funerals, and if the death is gruesome (which it would be from lead showers) the funeral will have a closed casket, which generally shortens the length of the funeral.

annotations.text: My dough tactics is so crafty (Yes)
annotations.annotation: As a savvy businessman, Lil Wayne and his millionaire father have a whole bunch of different creative ways of gettin that money.

annotations.text:
Like, oh, Nancy, the four's plastic, automatic, I'm (Ow)
 More drastic, you're no-names compared to me (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
Weezy is so popular that almost everyone seems miniscule in comparison, but Wayne said on this exact album (Tha Carter II) that he is the Best Rapper Alive.



Another similar line where Wayne shows other rappers no compassion is on Stuntin' Like My Daddy

Bitch I’m paid, that’s all I gotta say; Can’t see you lil' niggas, the money in the way

annotations.text: I'm fucking your sis, nigga, it's Weezy (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
At the time of the ‘Tha Cater II’ (2005), his alias as ‘Weezy’ was still fairly underground (compared to now-a-days)



This song certainly added fuel to propel this moniker into the mainstream.

annotations.text:
Sick as a Prozac (Yeah), and Tha Carter I was the (Hah)
 Dick for you hoes' trap, and (Ah) this is Tha Carter II and (Yeah)
annotations.annotation: In this context “ya hoes trap” would refer to some girls mouth. Wayne is stating that if his albums were looked at from a sexual standpoint, Tha Carter would just be seen as foreplay, or would just be considered to get your girl warmed up.

annotations.text:
Quick if I blow back, I (Yeah), got it, gone, Rabbit (Oh)
 Fast, my daddy Rabbit's at home, what up, pa? (What up?)
annotations.annotation: Rabbit was Wayne’s deceased stepfather, who Wayne has said to have considered his real father. Rabbit was murdered before Weezy became a star, and after his death, Wayne went to get “Rabbit” tatted, giving him his first tattoo at only 14. In the next lines he mentions deceased rappers, so “home” means Heaven here, where his father now is.

annotations.text: As the streets get colder, I get chillier (Yeah)
annotations.annotation: In this context the streets getting “colder” refer to them getting more dangerous, and when they get more dangerous, so does Wayne (he becomes “chillier”.

annotations.text: I ain't talkin' fast, you just listenin' too slow (Yeah)
annotations.annotation:
This verse’s opening line may have been inspired by Lil Wayne’s future collaborator, Eminem, who on “Bitch” off of D12 World, said,

“And if I’m talking too fast it just means you’re listening too slow
And if you listen a little faster maybe you’ll catch up, bitch”

annotations.text: Hollygrove triggerman, guns in a knapsack, yeah
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne is sending a shout-out to his hometown, where he and other artists like Mack Maine grew up.

Wayne could also be referring to a song known as Drag Rap- The Showboys, but in this interview Wayne says people from New Olreans always referred to it as “Trigga Man”

annotations.text: I am Nino fuckin' Brown and this is Tha Carter, ho (Woah)
annotations.annotation:
Nino Brown is a character from the movie New Jack City.



Lil Wayne references this movie all the time, he even had a documentary about himself called The Nino Brown Story.
