annotations.text: Press one button, let the wind fall
annotations.annotation:
Drop the roof on his car with one button, feel the wind.

Also, it could be a brag about how easily he makes money (as in “windfall profits”).

annotations.text: Seein' my life through the windshields of choppers
annotations.annotation:
This is actually a double entendre.

As further evidence that selling drugs pays off: Pusha T now spends a lot of his time riding around in helicopters, surveying the world from a bird’s-eye view.

Choppers are also very common in the hood – police helicopters often scan drug/gang infested neighborhoods in search of trouble or dead bodies.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=LGFLLEudiRQ

I would risk it and say it’s a triple entendre – Push could mean an AK-47 by choppas, and so he rolls around ready to shoot at anytime, either lyrically or physically.

annotations.text: I ain't spent one rap dollar in three years, holla
annotations.annotation:
He spends his ample drug money and saves his rap money. Also, during the two year gap in rapping, they did not tour nor make records during that time. Hence, they did not get a single dollar out of rap and actually could not spend “rap money.”



As Dickens says: “Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure nineteen six, result happiness. Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure twenty pound ought and six, result misery”

annotations.text:
Money's the leash, drag the bitch by a dog collar
 Now, ho, follow
annotations.annotation: Pusha’s hoes are just behind him for money. Therefore he uses the money as the leash and drags his girls everywhere he goes. They follow him, because if they do, they get their needs satisfied too (they get paid or are given expensive gifts).

annotations.text: So much white you might think your holy Christ is near
annotations.annotation:
Double entendre: there’s so much “white” (cocaine) it’s as if you’re witnessing the blinding white light of Jesus' divinity. Alternatively, Jesus is traditionally depicted as white, contradictory to logic.”

This could also be seen as a jab or sacrilegious pun at Clipse’s white listeners; note that Pusha says ‘your’ Holy Christ, not his.

annotations.text: Throw on your Louis V millionaires to kill the glare
annotations.annotation:
Pusha sports Louis Vuitton “Millionaire” sunglasses to stay incognito, defeat the glare from the cameras, and most of all, to keep the bright whiteness from his coke supply from blinding him.



Would be pretty awkward if he showed up to the BET Awards in the exact same sunglasses as Fabolous

annotations.text:
At you make-believe rappers, I smile, hah
 Canal Streeting my style
 Like you internet sharin' my files, you MySpace niggas
annotations.annotation:
You can buy knock-offs of designer gear on Canal Street in NYC (there are always tons of stands with fake Gucci bags everywhere)

2nd-rate “make-believe” rappers are like knockoff, pirated Pushas since they copy his style. They all have gaudy self-promotional MySpace pages, no record deals, no cred, etc.

Also, saying “You MySpace niggas” is sort of like saying “You’re in my space (get out!)”

Fake bags for sale on Canal Street:

annotations.text:
Coke money clean through Merrill Lynch
 Accountant just gasp at the smell of it
annotations.annotation:
Pusha launders coke money through his investment account at Merrill Lynch.  The accountant gasps when he smells Pusha’s money, either because there’s so much of it or because it is “dirty money” gained through dealing.

Merrill Lynch is a pretty boring, traditional bank which is why Pusha probably picked it for his laundering front (UBS has “coke money” written all over it)

annotations.text:
Word on the street is you gon' love how it melt
 And I don't come with a pitch neither, the shit sell itself
annotations.annotation: Malice knows his product is well known on the streets, the fiends know his cocaine is top quality. For this reason, Malice does not have to put in any smooth sales talk to sell the dope, it will simply sell itself.

annotations.text: I yell, "Re-up," 'til I'm locked like Mumia
annotations.annotation:
He keeps calling for more coke to sell until he gets imprisoned like Mumia Abu-Jamal (real name Wesley Cook), a man on death row that many people think was unjustly convicted



Note: the Re-Up Gang is also the record label/ group headed by Clipse and consists of Pusha, Malice, Ab-Liva, and, formerly, Sandman.

annotations.text: And get it cross-state with the grace of Maria
annotations.annotation:
Malice traffics his cocaine across all states with the blessings of Maria (mother of Jesus Christ).

Get it cross state can also be interpreted as getting the drugs into United States, as the production usually is carried out in countries such as Mexico and Colombia and is smuggled across from the border.

annotations.text:
Bitch tell me she love me, but I know she's a whore
 Shit could get ugly should she talk to the law
 And that's just what I get, it's the Roses of War
annotations.annotation:
“The War of the Roses” is:


The British dynastic civil war memorialized in Shakespeare’s Histories; Henry Tudor ascended to the English Throne after the War of the Roses and he had a lot of problems with his wives – he even had to cut Anne Boleyn – just as Malice is having with this girl
A novel by Warren Adler who also co-wrote the screenplay for the film adaptation directed by Danny Devito. It is about a wealthy couple, the Roses, who share two children, a dog and a love for expensive objects (they meet at an antiques auction). Their ostensibly perfect marriage is actually fraught with resentment and eventually descends into violent conflict



Malice is comparing his relationship to the Roses' relationship: She says she loves him but he doesn’t believe her; there is a web of mistrust because she knows so much of his drug info and could go to the police (the “Law”)

He concludes that his love life is a consequence of his lifestyle (hence the inversion “the roses of war”)

annotations.text: We get fed grapes, fuck hoes in plurals
annotations.annotation:
“Fuck hoes” – as in fuck working for a living using a hoe, the farming instrument,  to work the land. Especially clever considering he’s being “fed grapes” which is an agricultural product.
“Fuck hoes” – fornicate with women who have loose morals.



Malice is set to kick back and be pampered by the finest European women.

annotations.text: What a peace of mind when you cop you some Shapiros
annotations.annotation:
When you get bomb-ass attorneys like Robert Shapiro, who helped get O.J. Simpson off, you breathe a little easier

Shapiro, Johnny Cochran, and Orenthal James:

annotations.text:
The cars are big, the cribs are bigger
 The kids are happy, the perfect picture
annotations.annotation: The meaning is simple; this lifestyle has bought malice big and expensive cars and even bigger and more expensive houses. Thus, his kids are happy and that makes up a perfect picture for him, making him happy.

annotations.text: Gemstar razor, the fruit of my labor
annotations.annotation:
Gemstar Razors are high-quality single-blade razors.  Malice uses razor blades to chop up cocaine into smaller quantities for sale. The fruit of his labor is having the best tools for his craft

Based on the previous line and pronunciation, this is a double entendre with “gym star raiser”. Malice loves selling cocaine but he also loves his family and he’s proud of how athletic his child is.

annotations.text: Carolina blue kicks, pedal to the metal
annotations.annotation:
Shoes the same color as the UNC Tarheels' “Carolina Blue” blue



Like always, J is paying homage to his boss Jay-Z, as “Carolina blue kicks” had been part of a Hov bar in Mya’s “Best of Me (Remix).” Even “petal to the metal”, while a fairly common idiom, might be another Jay reference given that Jay used the similar line of “Bounce on the devil, put the pedal to the floor” in “99 Problems”.

annotations.text: Feeling like a puppet and the Devil is Geppetto
annotations.annotation:
Cole makes a clever allusion to childhood story The Adventures of Pinocchio by referencing Mister Geppetto, the woodcarver and puppeteer who created Pinocchio.

He feels as if he’s a puppet with no control of himself and that the devil is “Geppetto” or the puppeteer; the devil is controlling him.

annotations.text:
My world a little darker like a fuckin' tan line
 Go on look for a better nigga, girl you can’t find
annotations.annotation:
Cole often tells us how his world is filled with turmoil. A tan line is always darker from the sun-rays that have baked it

Side Note: I’m sure Cole wouldn’t mind making love to a girl with a tan line (not the tan line itself; he’s being reductive). But something also tells me he wouldn’t mind having sex with a girl with no tan line… or a light-skinned girl… or some Kelly Rowlands

annotations.text: Fine young man with an old man mind
annotations.annotation:
When this song released Cole was 25 years old but still as wise as if he was 80.

Wisdom comes from experiences not age.

annotations.text: No time for the chick who fucked the whole mankind
annotations.annotation: He referenced and compared the “chick” to Eve from the Bible. Eve ate the forbidden fruit and led to her and Adam being kicked out of the Garden of Eden.

annotations.text:
Aw, no ma'am, I’m an old land mine
 I been waiting to blow up for a long damn time
annotations.annotation:
A landmine is a bomb that is triggered when it is stepped on.
Cole compares himself to an ‘old landmine’ as they have both been waiting a long time to blow up. The land mine blowing up as an explosion and Cole blowing up as a rapper and making it big

annotations.text:
Now I’m armed and I’m, Fayettenam’s finest
 Carolina’s savior
annotations.annotation:
J. Cole is from Fayetteville, N.C., home to Fort Bragg, a large Army base (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Cole);  “Fayette” sounds like “Viet” so people from Fayetteville call it “Fayetnam” to sound thug/warzone-ish.

It also connects to the landmine references above, since the Vietnam War was known for that sort of treacherous warfare.

annotations.text:
Marijuana blazer
 Only on occasion 'cause my mind be racin'
 Lost in my thoughts so my eyes be Asian
annotations.annotation:
Hearkening back to the “Fayetnam” theme above, J. Cole also notes that weed makes his eyes squinty like an Asian’s.

This is a rap meme, as seen in other songs like Eminem’s “Bad Meets Evil”:

we hit the trees till we look like Vietnamese people

Also some potential wordplay around the fact that cannabis can make your mind race and Asian is a race classification.

annotations.text: Thinking how these rap niggas gotta be fakin
annotations.annotation:
A lot of rappers give up marijuana as a way to focus more on their music, but J. Cole just isn’t into the lifestyle. In an interview with Hip-Hop-N-More, the “Crooked Smile” rapper said that although he was into the cannabis world in college, he stopped smoking in 2011. But that didn’t stop him from rapping about it. Knowing the popularity and love for all things marijuana in the genre, J. Cole admitted that he kept rapping about weed to keep his fans interested.

It’s a stereotype that all rappers smoke weed, especially when the fathers of Hip Hop music were looked up to for the amount of marijuana they smoked. During the start of the booming Hip Hop industry in 1988 a span of legendary albums were dropped during the summer of that year. This included, but was not limited to, Run-D.M.C.’s Tougher Than Leather, EPMD’s Strictly Business, Public Enemy‘s It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back, Eric B. & Rakim‘s Follow the Leader, Salt-n-Pepa’s A Salt With a Deadly Pepa, 2 Live Crew’s Move Somethin’, Ice-T’s Power, and both Eazy-E’s Eazy-Duz-It and N.W.A‘s Straight Outta Compton, etc. The marijuana use increased as it came to light through rap.

annotations.text: Whole style obviously copied, pasted
annotations.annotation: Computer wordplay. On Microsoft word you can copy and paste words, photos etc.

annotations.text: Plagiarized swag,
annotations.annotation:
“Swagger” is literally a kind of gait but it has come to mean a rapper’s general comportment / lyrical style

Side note: Did you know that at some colleges you could be one semester away from your degree, murder an entire orphanage, go to jail for 65 years, get out and still get your remaining few credits to get your degree, but if you are expelled for plagiarism, you would have your credits revoked and have to start over? Plagiarism… worse than murder!

annotations.text:
May arrive last
 But when it’s all said and done, I’ma be ahead of them
annotations.annotation:
This could be referring to J. Cole arriving 8 hours late to the XXL Freshmen shoot in 2010 which included artists such a Wiz Khalifa, Jay Rock, Nipsey Hu$$le and Big Sean.

There is a double meaning as Cole is saying although he was literally late to the photoshoot, in terms of the rap game he will be ahead of all the XXL Freshman 2010.

This is also documented by Kendrick Lamar in the Heart Part 1, who was also at the photo shoot with his TDE friend Jay Rock.

https://genius.com/300825

annotations.text: What that I be fly, I be higher than the Jet-a-sons
annotations.annotation: Another common rap conceit: the dual meaning of “fly” (also means good); J. is so “fly” that he’s floating in outer space, past The Jetsons, a cartoon from the 80’s, about a family living in the future, with flying cars, houses, etc. The connection to television continues in the next line when Cole talks about the Jeffersons.

annotations.text: Moving on up, nigga higher than the Jeffersons
annotations.annotation:
“Moving On Up” by Ja’net Dubois was the theme song for The Jeffersons.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FHDwRECFL8M

J. Cole plans on doing even better than a “de-luxe apartment in the sky” (as mentioned in the theme song).

annotations.text: Hatin’ niggas, chalk 'em out, go on, get the coffin out
annotations.annotation:
Classically, a chalk outline is used to denote the location of a corpse at a crime scene after it has been removed. In addition, people are placed in coffins after they die.



The line implies Cole intends to kill his haters. Knowing Cole, he means he will do so via his rhymes, as he later says on Rise and Shine:

Let these words be my bullets, nigga, I don’t rhyme, I shoot, bang!

annotations.text: I’m ill enough to kill cancer, baby, I’m chemo
annotations.annotation:
Chemotherapy–usually shortened as “chemo” like it is here–is a method in which chemicals are used stop the growth of disease cells, typically cancer.



However, Cole’s raps are so lyrically sick that they’re equally as powerful as any chemotherapy chemical.

annotations.text: Down in Miami and I'm throwed like Marino
annotations.annotation:
Referring to the slang “throwed”, meaning going crazy, going wild, partying, getting drunk, etc.

Also a reference to former Miami Dolphins quarterback, Dan Marino.

annotations.text:
Get a whole lot of you know and she bald like an Eagle
 No, not on top but down there
annotations.annotation:
“You-know” refers to pussy (in case you didn’t know), and this particular “you-know” is shaved i.e. bald?

It could also be that Cole is “killing that you-know” so bad that she literally starts to i.e. “bawl”

“Bald like an Eagle” plays on the reference to chemo-therapy – which makes your hair fall out – 2 lines up
(see also Drake in “Forever”)

You know I balled, chemo

The word Eagles also connects to the previous line where he mentions Dan Marino, a past QB for the Miami Dolphins. The Philadelphia Eagles are a football team.

annotations.text:
If you a freak, I can take you to your peak
 Girl, I do it to the maximum, Nissan
annotations.annotation: If she’s down for it, Cole can give his girl the most exceptional sex, the maximum level of pleasure. He makes a clever play on words, as “maximum” sounds much like Maxima, a branch of Nissan vehicles.

annotations.text:
And I hope you a believer
 I’m quarterbacking, tryna get you open like receivers
annotations.annotation:
An obvious tie-in to the earlier bar:

Down in Miami and I’m throwed like Marino

Additionally, when losing late in a football game, a quarterback may have to throw a “Hail Mary” pass to a receiver in the end zone. The name of this desperation play is in reference to the traditional Catholic Hail Mary prayer– hence the preceding “And I hope you a believer” bar.

annotations.text:
I’m picturing that body like a camera phone would
 Something like Rihanna while I’m up in that V-gina
annotations.annotation:
As J. Cole drives around, he starts feeling sexual, and mentally “picturing” his girl (much like a camera phone engaged in sexting would do); if she looks Rihannesque then she must be sexy…

He’s also talking bout “going hard” while fucking, like the title of Rihanna single featuring Young Jeezy.

There is also a Chris Brown domestically abuse your vagina with my penis reference going on.

annotations.text: And I’m ghost, nigga, yeah
annotations.annotation: To “ghost” is to leave.

[Verse 1 - Pill]
Every morning I wake up, I'm thanking God for the day

Instead the reality of me serving several jays

I seen him bleeding on the ground and I said a prayer

Why we hustle and people struggle, you ain't made that clear

I got these dimes on my mind, and I'm all in the zone

[Verse 2 - Pill]
There's been times I don' cried cause I was down on my luck

And I remember my momma told me, gotta be strong

And you see twelve every moment trying to run up on ya
It's kinda hard cause it's a liqour store on every corner
And you see twelve every moment tryin to run up on ya

annotations.text:
Every morning I wake up, I'm thanking God for the day
But then it's back to the trap slangin the hardest of yay
annotations.annotation:
He wakes up optimistic–another beautiful day–but his mood darkens when he remembers he has to get back to work selling drugs.

“The trap” is southern slang for drug dealing, “yay” is cocaine

annotations.text:
A vision of having better days
Instead the reality of me serving several jays
annotations.annotation: A reiteration of the opening sentiment–“serving” is selling drugs

annotations.text:
I ask for help, please
Get me up off these corners, I can't see myself leave
Stuck in this world of crack smoke and hoes on they knees
annotations.annotation: Without divine intervention he will remain on the corner surrounded by crack heads turning quick tricks for a wisp of smoke

annotations.text:
And so its back off to the streets, and I'm callin them home
I black out all the people preachin, callin my phone
annotations.annotation: Lacking an answer to his previous question he finds himself back out on the street, ignoring the good advice of people who care about him (i.e. have his phone number)

annotations.text:
I got these dimes on my mind, and I'm all in the zone
Cause when you broke motherfucker, yes you fallin alone
annotations.annotation: He is completely focused on dealing, because he needs money and can’t depend on anyone but himself

annotations.text: I'm rollin' stones, that's the only way I see a profit
annotations.annotation: Rolling stones, i.e. slanging rock, i.e. selling crack / cocaine

annotations.text: Convicted felon, but there's something heavy off in my pocket
annotations.annotation: He may be a convicted felon, but he’s got a gun in his pocket.

annotations.text:
So stop it, I see him watching, I'm keeping on
You go to your 9 to 5, I'm trapping; to each his own
annotations.annotation:
Stop judging me, you do your job and I’ll do mine. Money is the object in either case – we are all effects of capitalism

“I see him watching” is an important line: throughout this song Pill is hyper-aware of being judged. In the video, the “him” is a young boy who’s eyes go wide at Pill’s exploits – this complicates things even further, implicating him in the very cycle that he laments in the following lines

annotations.text:
The things I feel, I think god should know
Why I couldn't be one of those kids on the Cosby Show
It's ugly, you see them thuggin, they pushing buggies, collecting cans
If he could apply himself he might be a better man
It's kinda hard when there's a liquor store on every corner
And you see twelve every moment trying to run up on ya
It's kinda hard cause it's a liqour store on every corner
And you see twelve every moment tryin to run up on ya
annotations.annotation:
The Cosby Show portrayed an upper-middle class black family. The Cosby kids studied hard, stayed out of serious trouble and became successful professionals. Pill didn’t turn out like them; they were not surrounded by thugs and homeless junkies. Still, he devil-advocates, if he applied himself he could be a better man. Maybe, but it’s hard when there is a liquor store on every corner in your neighborhood and the cops (“twelve”) harass you constantly: why not just give up (alcoholism) or play your assigned role (criminal)?

“Only god can judge me” is a rap cliche. So Pill is taking a rather traditional line at the end of the song by explaining himself to God. Or is he? Typically “only god can judge me” has been invoked by rappers to avoid explaining themselves. But this whole song is an explanation: circumstances prevent Pill from escaping his moral dilemma. By spending so much breath justifying not his thug but his humanity we have to wonder if Pill cares as much about judgment on earth as in heaven

annotations.text: Like Bobby had Whitney, we was cooking up crack
annotations.annotation: Cole refers to the early 2000’s celebrity couple Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston. Though it was more-so a result of Whitney’s drug habits, both in the couple were notorious for their cocaine addictions.

annotations.text:
But them fifteen credits had a nigga off track
 Picture that, best rapper since Lil Wayne in classes
annotations.annotation:
Jermaine graduated from St. John’s University as magna cum laude with a degree in communications in 2007—the same year Cole’s first mixtape, The Come Up was released.

In songs from the mixtape like “College Boy”, Jermaine details the struggles of balancing his academics with his fast life:

Fighting hangovers, on my way to my internship
And I forgot to study for my midterm, shit

With talent and potential comparable to that of the iconic Lil Wayne, the only thing stopping Cole was the stress of earning enough college credits to graduate.

annotations.text:
The best bachelor since Bruce Wayne with his bachelor’s
 But mastered this rap shit
annotations.annotation:
Cole compares himself to the fictional Bruce Wayne, the real-life moniker of DC Universe superhero Batman.



This is also something Cole boasts about in “College Boy” from 2007’s The Come Up:

Eligible bachelor, finna get my Bachelor’s
And if this rap shit don’t work, I’m going for my Master’s

Fun fact: This is a pretty bold comparison, as Batman is shown to have a vast number of college degrees including Chemistry, Physics, Computer Science, Engineering, and Mathematics.

annotations.text:
You hear the words coming from my lips bastards
 I never crack, I got that Chapstick
annotations.annotation:
Chapstick is a brand (and product in general) of small sticks of substance that keep the lips moisturized; hence not cracking. Cole figuratively extends this to express how he’ll never “crack” or show weakness.



This may also be a subtle nod to “Black don’t crack”, a comedic phrased used to emphasize how Black people don’t wrinkle and show age as much as other races.

annotations.text:
Now where’s the ladder?
 Cause either you gonna whine or you climb; I chose the latter
annotations.annotation:
Cole’s a firm believer in succeeding no matter how hard the circumstance, he’s got no time to sit around and complain. This line is quite similar to the closing line of his first verse in “Dead Presidents II”:

Now if I had a ladder or now even if I had a rope
I’d climb that motherfucker to the top and never let it go

annotations.text:
Know you haters is pissed, hold your bladder though
 ‘Fore you get tossed like a forward lateral
annotations.annotation:
Cole creates wordplay out of the word “pissed”, connecting it to literal pissing. Though his haters may be “pissed off” or angry, he suggests them keep it to themselves, which would be holding their bladder in the technical sense.

In football, a “lateral” is a backwards or completely sideways pass.



Therefore, a forward lateral would just be a regular toss forward. Basically, Cole is saying to keep your problems to yourself if you don’t want to get tossed in a fight.

annotations.text: One for the money, yes, sir, two for the show
annotations.annotation:
This references the phrase made famous by Elvis on the intro to “Blue Suede Shoes”. It originated from a Mother Goose rhyme that went:

One to make ready
And two to prepare
good luck to the rider
And away goes the mare."

Page 259 of “The Annotated Mother Goose” states that this was intended as a “race starting jingle”, and eventually evolved into the “one for the money, two for the show, three to get ready, and four to go!” line we know today.

http://screencast.com/t/DNAdBTbKimFq

annotations.text:
A couple of years ago on Headland and Delowe
 Was the start of something good
annotations.annotation: Headland and Delowe is a commercial intersection in East Point, near André and Big Boi’s hood. And this “something good” was the formation of OutKast.

annotations.text: Where me and my nigga rode the MARTA through the hood
annotations.annotation: André used to ride the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority (MARTA also known jokingly as “Moving Africans Rapidly Thru Atlanta”) with his homie Big Boi to get around back in the day.

annotations.text: Just tryna find that hookup
annotations.annotation: The “hook up” could be referring to two possible things here. First off, they could be driving around searching for dealer to hook them up with some weed, as the duo was known to puff the magic dragon back in the day. Alternatively, they could be riding all around town trying to find someone to give their music a chance.

annotations.text:
Now, every day, we looked up at the ceiling (Yuh)
 Watching ceiling fans go 'round, tryna catch that feeling off instrumentals
 Had my pencil, and plus, my paper
annotations.annotation: André locks himself in his recording studio, stares up at the ceiling while listening to beats (aka “instrumentals”), and waits for inspiration to strike so he can write those thoughts in his rhyme book. Dre might also be looking up to the ceiling/sky in hopes that God helps him out. He has claimed that God speaks to the masses through his rhymes on this record, so it’s plausible.

annotations.text: We caught the 86 Lithonia, headed to Decatur
annotations.annotation:
Big Boi and Dre rode the 86 Lithonia/ 86 L bus into Decatur, an Atlanta suburb with a fairly sizable black population. It’s one of the hoods the duo frequently reps in their lyrics, see their song “Decatur Psalm” for an example.





There is also historical significance behind Decatur that influences the meaning here. It has always been divided by Memorial Drive into a “black” and a “white” side. On the Northeast side is “white Decatur”, filled with prosperous white churches and high quality schools and hospitals (including Dekalb Medical Center). On the other side is “black Decatur”, which extends from Candler Road, Glenwood Road, and Snapfinger Road all the way down to Rainbow Drive. Historically, this side has more of a hood reputation, and is filled with flea markets, prostitution, nightclubs, liquor stores, and one of Atlanta’s most “ghetto malls”: South Dekalb.

Taking the 86L will take you from Lithonia into the black part of Decatur, specifically the East Lake train station. Though it has since been gentrified and now has high property values, the area of East Lake used to be a notorious government housing project called “Lil Vietnam” and accounted for many murders and violence in the 80s and 90s. It is in this transition state between the hood and the nicer parts of Atlanta that OutKast writes these lyrics.

annotations.text:
Writing rhymes, tryna find our spot off in that light
 Light off in that spot, knowing that we could rock
annotations.annotation:
André plays on the word “spotlight”, a symbol for fame, to describe his early attempts to make it big. He and Big Boi used to go on stage and try to “light it up” (do really well), so that they would have a chance to make it into the spotlight as up-and-coming rappers.

Andre 3000 also might want to find his spot in the world by writing rhymes, and want to to stand out (light off) in that spot which could be Decatur and/or Atlanta.

annotations.text:
Doing the hole-in-the-wall clubs, this shit here must stop
 Like, "Freeze!" We making the crowd move, but we not making no G's, and that's a no-no
annotations.annotation:
“Hole in the wall clubs” are small, off-the-beaten-path places where aspiring performers can play. They get experience, but not notoriety and money.

The Hole in the Wall is a popular club in Atlanta, and the duo was able to make the crowd move with their awesome music when they performed there, but only performing at local clubs doesn’t bring in much money. André and Big Boi aspire to perform on a national stage, and thus have to stop what they are doing and reevaluate their lives, similar to how everyone on the dance floor in a club stops dancing when someone yells “Freeze!”



This is also a reference to the late 80’s and early 90’s under-the-radar Atlanta rap act Success-n-Effect, one of the first political hip-hop groups. They had minor success with the single “The Freeze”, but never achieved financial success despite making a good buzz in the ATL. OutKast knows that they have to take measures to make sure this doesn’t happen to them.

annotations.text:
Check it, a-one-two, a-one
 "Two dope niggas in the Cadillac," they call us
annotations.annotation:
“One-two one-two” is a classic mic check that many rappers (such as Lupe Fiasco) imitate to start off their verses. Additionally, it is a reference to another song on the album titled “Two Dope Boyz in a Cadillac”, which is also a nickname he and Dre have adopted over the years.

http://screencast.com/t/3TKSREF91QV

annotations.text: Went from "Player's Ball" to ballers
annotations.annotation: Outkast’s previous hit song “Player’s Ball” elevated them to “baller” status.

annotations.text: Putting the South up on the map was like Little Rock to banging
annotations.annotation:
Like Gang War: Bangin' in Little Rock, an HBO special in the early 90’s which chronicled the more-thug-than-you-might-imagine gang life of Little Rock, Outkast takes the Dirty South thug mentality nationwide.

Crack cocaine is typically in the form of little rocks. During the crack epidemic of the 80’s, crack cocaine elevated the gang violence in the United States, putting the issue of gang banging on the map.

annotations.text: Niggas say, "Motherfuck that playin'," they payin', we stayin', layin' vocals
annotations.annotation:
Outkast has done too much and come from a too rough of a neighborhood to give up on the chance that has come from their music.

They aren’t “playing” around, because someone’s finally “paying” them money, so they will be “staying” true to their craft.

annotations.text:
"OutKast, yeah, them niggas, they making big noise"
 Over a million sold to this day; niggas, they take it lightly
 '96 gon' be that year that all y'all player-haters can bite me
 I'm out this bitch
annotations.annotation: Despite the fact that Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik went platinum, there were many people that viewed the duo as a gimmick that would not have any staying power in this industry. But once ATLiens dropped in 1996, people realized that Dre and Big Boi were here to stay.

They no longer have to pray for a breakthrough to make it big, they have finally arrived and can afford to be seen stunting in nice cars and putting it down for all of Atlanta.

annotations.text:
Back in the day, when I was younger, hunger
 Looking to fill me belly with that Rallys, bullshit
annotations.annotation:
Rally’s and Checkers are two different names of the same burger chain; eat too much of them and you will actually become a “big boy”

RALLYS BULLSHIT (shitty ass cheap hamburgers) is a distinctly local Georgia thing.

annotations.text: Pull shit off, like it was supposed to be pulled
annotations.annotation: To pull something off is an idiom, meaning to make something happen or to accomplish.

annotations.text: Full as a tick, I was stoned like them white boys
annotations.annotation:
Big Boi is full of smoke like a tick full of blood.

OutKast played the colleges (frats in particular) a LOT: Emory, Georgia Tech, Georgia State.  Bunch of guys from the Dungeon Family playing for (and later usually partying with) white, white frat boys.

annotations.text: Smoking them White Golds
annotations.annotation: White girls is slang for joints of weed. The nickname comes from the white rolling paper that is used instead of a brown cigarillo.

annotations.text:
Before them blunts got crunk
 Chunky asses,
annotations.annotation: Big Boi used to smoke joints (“white girls”), but that was before he discovered that you could fit more weed into a blunt. Once he figured this out he began smoking blunts. Since he is comparing his means of smoking marijuana to females, saying that they got “chunky asses” means that more weed was packed into them.

annotations.text: Passes getting throwed like Hail Marys
annotations.annotation:
The blunt is being passed around amongst the members of Big Boi’s smoking circle. He then uses some wordplay to compare this to the football pass known as the Hail Mary.

Also, when you make a “pass” you are hitting on a female, so it continues the “white girl,” “Mary,” and “Halle Berry” metaphors

annotations.text:
And they looking like Halle Berrys
 So, so fine, intertwined,
annotations.annotation: The pun is that in 1996 everyone thought Halle Berry was one of, if not the, finest black women in America. Since Big Boi has been comparing his smoking apparatus to women in the last few lines, this can be interpreted as saying that he really nice, well-packed blunt on deck.

annotations.text: But we ain't sipping wine
annotations.annotation:
They made it clear many times that we were sober while recording ATLiens unlike their previous debut album: Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik. They mention this earlier on the title track of this album:

God works in mysterious ways so when he starts
The job of speaking through us we be so sincere with this here
No drugs or alcohol so i can get the signal clear as day

annotations.text:
We's just chilling, I'm the rabid villain, and I'm so high
 Smoking freely, me, Lil B, Reek, Mone and Shug
 And my little brother, James,
annotations.annotation:
Big Boi is getting stoned with his buddies. Reek refers to Rico Wade, a member of the Dungeon Family and producer for Organized Noize, and little brother James actually refers to Big Boi’s younger brother James Patton who goes by the rap name Lil' Brotha.

And no, it’s not that Lil B.

annotations.text:
Things changed in the hood
 Where I live at, them rats know,
annotations.annotation: Due to the success of OutKast’s last album, all of the unsavory members of Big Boi’s neighborhood now know where he lives. So he has to remain extra cautious or risk getting caught slipping by one of these rats.

annotations.text:
"Momma, I want to sing
 But, momma, I want to trick (Trick), and momma, I'm sucking dicks, now"
annotations.annotation: Big Boi alludes to the 1983 musical “Mama, I Want to Sing!” to describe the hopes and aspirations of most girls in his hood. Where he comes from, girls start life out with a boatload of dreams, but when those dreams come to naught, those same girls often end up with a mouthful of dick.

annotations.text: We moving on up in the world like elevators
annotations.annotation: Big Boi clarifies the theme of the song and why they chose to title it “Elevators” here; just like elevators that take you from the basement of the building to the top floor, OutKast started from the bottom and now they’re here.

annotations.text: Me and the crew,
annotations.annotation: Dungeon Family!

annotations.text: Me and you like Tony! Toni! Tone! (Yeah, yeah)
annotations.annotation:
Tony!Toni!Tone! had a song called “Just Me and You”

East Point is the ATL neighborhood that both Big Boi and Dre call home.

annotations.text:
Got stopped at the mall the other day
 Heard a call from the other way that I just came from ("Ayy")
 Some nigga was saying something
 Talking 'bout smoke something
 "Hey, man, you remember me from school?" "No, not really"
annotations.annotation:
This guy walks up to André as he’s leaving the mall with a friendly smile and the typical 1990’s Atlanta greeting of “smoke something”, then starts up a conversation about their time in school together. But Dre’s reaction makes it clear that he didn’t actually go to school with this guy, he probably just wants a handout or an excuse to talk to someone famous.



New Orleans rapper Curren$y later made a track over this beat titled “Smoke Something” in reference to this line.

annotations.text: But he kept smiling like a clown, facial expression looking silly
annotations.annotation: André either realizes that this man is trying to play him, or actually doesn’t remember him from high school; either way he has no clue who he is and why he decided to come up to talk. But this man continues to put on a fake smile and act friendly. It’s amazing how far some people will go for a free handout.

annotations.text:
And he kept asking me, "What kinda car you drive?
 I know you paid, I know y'all got beaucoup hoes
 From all them songs that y'all done made"
annotations.annotation:
This man assumes that André is fucking loaded because Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik went platinum. But as he alludes to later on the album, record labels take a large percentage of the profits from the sales, so the artists don’t make as much money as you think. But the hoe part is probably true, just look at the guy.



“Beaucoup” is a French word for many. So Dre has many bitches.

annotations.text:
And I replied that I'd been going through the same things that he has
 True, I've got more fans than the average man
 But not enough loot to last me to the end of the week
annotations.annotation:
Dre emphasizes that fame is not always equivalent to prosperity. Everyone who walks by him in Atlanta sees him as the rap mogul with millions of dollars to blow just because he put out a popular album, but that is far from the reality.

While it is true that putting out a platinum album has made him richer than your average cashier or bag boy, it isn’t like he is set for life. André has no other job, so his entire well-being depends on continuing to put out quality albums. So despite the fact that his popularity is much higher than the common man, their responsibilities and work ethic are actually quite similar.

annotations.text: I live by the beat like you live check-to-check
annotations.annotation:
Two meanings:


He lives by making rhythmic music
His life consists of a metronymic rigidity of economy

annotations.text: If it don't move your feet, then, I don't eat, so we like neck-to-neck
annotations.annotation: André has no fallback plan. Rap is a business, and his music is his only product. So while rappers do have more potential to be incredibly prosperous, if their shit isn’t selling then they are on the same level (“neck and neck”) as the average person trying to pay their bills.

annotations.text:
Yes, we done come a long way like them slim-ass cigarettes
 From Virginia, this ain't gon' stop, so we just gon' continue
annotations.annotation: André alludes to the femicigarette Virginia Slims slogan of “You’ve come a long way, baby!” to emphasize how far he and Big Boi have come from their modest days in East Point.

annotations.text: I ain't playing nann day
annotations.annotation: “Nann day” means “any day”; Dirty Mouth is never fooling around

annotations.text: I got that chrome
annotations.annotation: Chrome = gun in this case (can also mean “car” or “rims”)

annotations.text: Most these niggas playing chief will put you straight to the test
annotations.annotation: Like Homer did with the valiant Hector, here Dirty celebrates his enemies: although they are merely “playing chief” (pretending to be the boss), they prove formidable opponents

annotations.text:
Look at my Benz, look at my Ac
 Look at my Navi and my Lac
annotations.annotation:
A reference to Khia’s hit single “My Neck, My Back” where the chorus goes “[lick] my neck, my back, my pussy and my crack”

Glossary:

Benz = Benz
Ac = Acura
Navi = Lincoln Navigator
Lac = Cadillac

annotations.text: Always slizzle-making
annotations.annotation: “Slizzle” is anything – including crack, pancakes and grits, obviously – that makes a “SSSsssSSSss” when you cook it

annotations.text: Trying to get with me is like naps through a comb
annotations.annotation: It’s hard to get nappy hairs (“naps”) through a comb…he’s saying he plays “hard to get”

annotations.text: Don P aka "Corleone"
annotations.annotation:
Nobody calls him “Corleone”; Don P comes up with different made-up nicknames in every song (in “Damn” he starts his verse with “They call me Don P aka Ashanti”)

I understand why he would want to be called “Corleone” – Godfather fan, sounds thug – but I don’t quite understand “Ashanti”…

annotations.text: Don't know if I'm high, drunk, or getting my roll on
annotations.annotation:
“Gettin' my roll on” refers to taking an ecstasy pill, although it is also a play on the Big Tymers song “Get Your Roll On”

Not clear what he means here: either he doesn’t remember which drugs he’s done or he thinks others can’t tell

annotations.text: He on the cell "Can ya hear me?"
annotations.annotation: An obvious reference to Paul on the Verizon commercials always asking, “Can you hear me now?” And ends with “Good!”

annotations.text: Trillville, ATL swanging, swanging, throwing bows
annotations.annotation: “Swanging” and “throwing [el]bows” are dance moves; the latter also refers to rapper Ludacris' “Throw dem Bows”

annotations.text: [Produced by Cool N Dre]
annotations.annotation:
The beautiful production for ‘'Hate It Or Love It’‘ has a Jazz/Soul influence and features a female vocal backing on the hook to contrast 50’s voice. A key aspect of the song is how they cleverly removed the drums at key intervals in the opening seconds and before game’s verses.

The main body of the beat is from “Rubberband” by The Trammps.

annotations.text: [Verse 1: 50 Cent]
annotations.annotation:
During a 2013 MTV interview, 50 Cent revealed that he had held off on putting this verse on his album, unsure of whether his audience was ready for him to, saying:

When I wrote for “Hate It or Love It” I wasn’t sure I wanted to put it on my album, because I was talking about, when I was growing up, that my mum [was kissing] a woman. So I put it on Game’s record, because I wasn’t sure the public was ready to hear that from me, ‘cause we only offered a certain style of content to 'em. So that was me putting my toes into the tub, to comfortably make that transition [to more personal content.]

“Hate It or Love It” was received extremely positively, which prompted 50 to give it a G-Unit Remix, which he included on his sophomore album, The Massacre.

annotations.text: Coming up I was confused, my mommy kissing a girl
annotations.annotation:
50 has mentioned in interviews that his mother might have been gay or bi. She was a part-time prostitute, so whether she was with this girl for business or pleasure is unclear.



50’s mother, Sabrina Jackson

annotations.text: Confusion occurs coming up in the cold world
annotations.annotation:
Growing up is confusing, at times, for every child. Kids in lower income areas are exposed to more realities at a younger age, which can lead to more confusion earlier on.

Suburban parents try to prevent their kids from growing up too fast, but parents in the hood don’t have the luxury of hiding things from their kids – everything is out in the open.

annotations.text: My favorite rapper used to sing, "Check, check out my melody"
annotations.annotation:
Referencing the classic Eric B. & Rakim song “My Melody.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5iVrHLC_4AM

annotations.text:
Nana told me if I passed I'd get a sheepskin coat
 If I can move a few packs I'd get the hat, now that'd be dope
annotations.annotation:
50 Cent’s Grandma is very important to him – he has stated this in many interviews – including a famous one on The Oprah Winfrey Show.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uyV6p3yiQeo

He explains one of his youthful dilemma – that is either to go to school – pass his exams and make his grandma happy and get the sheepskin coat she promised him – or move a few packs (deal drugs) which can afford him that coat and things like a hat and gold chains?

P.S. he plays on the word dope which also means cool.

annotations.text:
Tossed and turned in my sleep that night
 Woke up the next morning, niggas had stole my bike
 Different day, same shit, ain't nothing good in the hood
 I'd run away from this bitch and never come back if I could
annotations.annotation:
Usually, when rappers talk about their rough childhoods, they embrace the “poverty factor” and brag about how tough it made them.  Here, 50 complains that he hated hood-life so much, he couldn’t even sleep at night. Instead of claiming his hood and saying he won’t ever change, 50 is being a bit more honest and admitting that there’s nothing awesome about growing up in fear and poverty.

Stemming from the previous line, 50 racks his brain that night whether to sell dope or get an education (choosing between good and bad). When he awakens to find his bike gone, he realizes that “good” won’t get him out of the hood – so he embraces the “bad.”



In 50 cents book, From Pieces to Weight, Fif says on page 9, “When I was six,she got me a children’s dirt bike.” He then says on page 16, “Someone had even stolen the bike she had given me”.

annotations.text: Hate it or love it, the underdog's on top
annotations.annotation: The Game stated in an interview that 50 Cent felt this way about The Game and was speaking about him when creating these vocals.

annotations.text:
Go 'head envy me, I'm rap's M.V.P
 And I ain't going nowhere, so you can get to know me
annotations.annotation:
M.V.P. is the Most Valuable Player, Game is saying is that he is the greatest, and you can be jealous if you like, that won’t change anything.

This is also a nod to Big Daddy Kane (famously used by Big L in his single, “M.V.P.”). Kane used it in his song, “Just Rhymin' with Biz” as quoted below:

And if rap was a game, I’d be MVP
Most Valuable Poet on the M-I-C

annotations.text: The gold wires
annotations.annotation: Gold wire spoke wheels, particularly those made by Dayton Wire Wheel, are a famously beloved accessory to lowriders.

annotations.text:
10 G's will take your daughter out her Air Forces
 Believe you me, homie, I know all about losses
annotations.annotation:
This is reminiscent of an Eminem line:

I have the money to have you killed by somebody who has nothing

Being from Compton, Game has experienced crippling losses. He lost 2 brothers at a young age.

This could also have a secondary meaning relate to the force of gravity, measured in G’s, and the fact that Air Force pilots must make maneuvers that subject them to high G-forces.

annotations.text:
I'm from Compton, wear the wrong colors, be cautious
 One phone call'll have your body dumped in Marcy
annotations.annotation:
Los Angeles gangs have long identified themselves by the color of their clothing, most notably the red of the Bloods and the blue of the Crips, and would attack someone wearing an opposing gang’s colors, or someone wearing their own color whom they thought did not have the right, e.g., Crips attacking a non-gangmember for wearing their blue. You need to be careful of what you have on and know which neighborhood you’re at when you’re in Compton.

Game has East coast connections as well. The Marcy Projects are located in Bed-Stuy, where our main man Jigga hails from.

This could be an early attempt at impressing Hov

annotations.text:
I stay strapped like car seats
 Been bangin' since my lil' nigga Rob got killed for his Barkleys
annotations.annotation:
Infant car seats are strapped into the backseat and the child is strapped into the seat.

Staying strapped is a euphemism for always carrying a gun.



Game’s friend Rob was killed around 1992, when Game says he started bangin'. This makes sense since Nike’s Godzilla VS Charles Barkley commercial debuted in 1992, at the height of the shoes' popularity.

annotations.text: That's 10 years, I told Pooh in '95
annotations.annotation:
Game may have written this verse in ‘02, which would have been 10 years after he started bangin'.

Game references DJ Pooh who played “Red” in the 1995 movie Friday. He also references the movie in “Westside Story”.

annotations.text: I'll kill you if you try me for my Air Max 95's
annotations.annotation:
The Game is a member of the Bloods. Their signature shoe is the Air Max 95’s; The Air Max 98’s are the chosen shoe of the Crips (their main rivals).



This connects with his history of learning that his friend Rob got killed for a pair of shoes; he’s not letting someone bring him down… whether it’s for a pair of shoes, or because he’s a member of the Bloods.

annotations.text: Told Banks when I met him I'ma ride
annotations.annotation: Game immediately clicked with Lloyd Banks and vowed to stay loyal no matter what. Game stayed true to his words and reunited with Banks in Dubai, after over a decade of feuding with G-Unit.

annotations.text: And if I gotta die, I'd rather homicide
annotations.annotation:
Game is a true G, so he doesn’t plan on going out quietly through natural causes.

Instead, he plans to go out like Scarface, guns blazing, until he is murdered by his enemies. He will be thugging until the very end.

annotations.text: I ain't have 50 cent when my grandmama died
annotations.annotation:
A typical Game move – reference a rapper in order to make some point that plays on his name/album title. For a similar move, check the chorus on his song “Documentary”

Game had less than 50 cents when his grandma passed, was poor as hell back in the day, and he didn’t obviously have 50 Cent hanging with him.

annotations.text:
Now I'm going back to Cali
 With my Jacob on, see how time fly?
annotations.annotation:
Game is going home and references B.I.G.’s Going Back to Cali.

The watch (from Israeli superjeweler Jacob) is a reminder of his wealth, which makes him think of how poor he was when his grandmother died. The change in his status is so quick that he’s reminded of how time flies.

The phrase has a double meaning here: he’s looking at his watch while on a plane, so his time(piece) is literally flying. Also the watch (time) is fly!

annotations.text: The cold world that we in is full of pressure and pain
annotations.annotation: This world of ours is cold because for someone to win, others have to lose. Not everybody can win. Our society glorifies winners and shits on losers. This puts tremendous pressure on people to succeed and the losers feel the sharp pain of failure.

annotations.text:
Used to see Five-O, throw the crack by the bench
 Now I'm fuckin' with 5-0, it's all starting to make sense
annotations.annotation:
Five-O is slang for ‘police’ (from the police show “Hawaii Five-O”).

In his younger years, Game would have to ditch his drugs when he saw cops coming to avoid suspicion or arrest. (As explained by Jay Rock here)

Now he’s dealing with a different ‘5-0’ – 50 Cent.  Things are starting to work out for him, as he’s alongside the then Rap Superstar recording songs. The different associations he now has with the police reflect his changed lifestyle and wealth – he used to be a street drug dealer just grinding, being picked on by cops, and now he’s rich and they can’t touch him.



“Sense” is also a play on words for “cents”. As well as representing his relationship with 50 Cent, this also refers to the fact that he has “started to make cents” – he is making money off rap.

annotations.text: Waiting on Sha Money to land, sitting in the Range
annotations.annotation:
Sha Money XL is G-Unit’s manager/producer. Game is picking him up at the airport in his Range Rover.

Game likes to mention his Range Rover.

annotations.text: Pac is gone and Brenda still throwing babies in the garbage
annotations.annotation:
2Pac had a classic song “Brenda’s Got a Baby” in which he told the story of a girl named Brenda and her plight as an impregnated teenager whom society had neglected. In the song she wanted to kill her child because it was too burdensome.

Game’s point here is pessimistic: Pac raised awareness of many issues, but in the end, he’s gone and we’re (society) still making the same stupid mistakes.

Pac, being the genius that he was, knew this would happen:

But some things will never change

annotations.text: I wanna know what's going on like I hear Marvin
annotations.annotation: Reference to Marvin Gaye’s “What’s Going On”,“ which discussed social issues such as drug addiction, poverty, and the Vietnam War.  Game wonders how society could be so apathetic towards the problems he’s rapping about

annotations.text: No schoolbooks, they used that wood to build coffins
annotations.annotation: Again, Game claims that society is misallocating its resources: we spend money on airplanes instead of on feeding kids and the paper we need for schoolbooks is unavailable because we’re killing too many people and using the wood for coffins.  Of course, this isn’t actually true and there’s no shortage of paper, but his point is contrasting a constructive use of resources with the use of resources in pursuit of death and destruction

annotations.text:
Whenever I'm in the booth and I get exhausted
 I think, "What if Marie Baker got that abortion?"
annotations.annotation:
Game is inspired to keep working by thinking about how lucky he is to be alive.

His mom (Lynette Marie Baker) could have had an abortion, which would be understandable as she was facing the frightening reality of being a single mother.



This line also ties into the Tupac reference where he mentions that Brenda is still throwing baby’s in garbage, referencing the Tupac song, Brenda’s Baby, which talks about the struggles of a single mother and her eventual abandonment of her child.

annotations.text: I vowed to never stop winnin', 'til the earth stop spinnin'
annotations.annotation:
A line that proved prophetic. Jay would reflect on his career of wins in 2016’s “I Got The Keys” and 2017’s “Shining”:

I’ve been winnin' so long it’s like alchemy

annotations.text: My motto is, simply "I will not lose!"
annotations.annotation:
Jay’s famous catchphrase “I will not lose”, first spoken in two bars time, and repeated again in “Change The Game”, “U Don’t Know”, “Blueprint 2”, “9/11 Freestyle” and, most importantly, on 2016’s “I Got The Keys”:

Case y'all ain’t notice, I ain’t lost yet

annotations.text:
May these words find a spot on your brain and burn
 Then I recycle my life, I shall return
annotations.annotation: Jay-Z seems to be casting himself in an almost Nietzsche-esque light: his words will be forever remembered, emblazoned in your mind.  On top of that he seems to be claiming not only that he will be resurrected, but that he will be resurrected as a complete recreation of his past self.  This is remarkably similar to Nietzsche’s theory of eternal recurrence

annotations.text:
You dudes is too soft, why I don't fuck with you all
 I might bark at X, or spit at The LOX
 But, other than that, I don't be fuckin' with cats
annotations.annotation:
Aside from JAY-Z’s proteges and label, DMX and The Lox might be the top two acts associated acts with JAY-Z during the late 90’s.

They collaborated on multiple occasions:
Blackout, Reservoir Dogs, Money, Cash, Hoes & Why We Die.

JAY supports his fellow rappers who were considered to be the hardcore at the time, expressing his disdain of others for being too soft.

annotations.text: B-High
annotations.annotation: B-High is Jay’s cousin and he co-produced the song “Holla” off of The Dynasty

annotations.text: E
annotations.annotation: “E” is Jay’s dear friend Emory Jones. About a year after this song came out, Emory was sentenced to 16 years in prison for cocaine trafficking. During Emory’s time in prison, Jay wrote the song “Do U Wanna Ride" for him and eventually wrote a letter to a federal judge offering Emory employment at Roc Apparel Group upon his release, in a successful effort to get E’s sentence reduced.

annotations.text: Y'all can never diss Jigga, get nothin' for that
annotations.annotation: This time in the late 90’s, Jay was being dissed all the time by guys like Mase, Meeno, Nas and some other dudes, and here he is saying that he won’t respond to none of these disses, which is weird since he did respond to Mase on Ride or Die.

annotations.text:
Lord, accept this offerin' here's somethin' for your crown (please)
 I meant no malice, I just met his challenge and won
annotations.annotation:
Jay’s trying to justify his actions. “God I know I killed that guy, but he challenged me and I won. Self defense, your honor. Oh, and here’s something for your collection plate.”

This might be a subliminal shot aimed at Nas. Especially the “crown” part, since Jay and Nas contended for the title “King of NY”

annotations.text: Gangsta Music, part two
annotations.annotation:
Sequel to the original Gangsta Music, “Dipset Anthem”.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eCvxC8rofjs

“Dipset Anthem” was the first single from the classic “Diplomatic Immunity Vol. 1”.

annotations.text: Say I walk around like I got a S on my chest
annotations.annotation:
Meaning: as if he were Superman.

This is a fairly common reference point for rappers – cf. 50 Cent, Kurupt, and Ice Cube.

annotations.text: I bang with the five (Ayy!),
annotations.annotation: A double meaning because Juelz both carries a 5 (.45 caliber pistol) and reps the 5 (Bloods gang)

annotations.text:
... I'm a better child
 You's a pedophile (Ayy! Ayy! Ayy! Ayy!)
annotations.annotation: A metaphor that the fans need him, like a pedophile uses children. Santana uses “pedophile” as an insult despite Cam'ron having made throwaway references to having sex with children.

annotations.text:
Killa! I'm on the south side of Chicago
 Looking for a real hoe (Real hoe)
 I don't see a touchdown; arms up, field goal (Field goal)
annotations.annotation:
Cam is referencing his own verse on 2003’s posse cut “Dipset Anthem”:

I’m on the westside of Chicago, lookin' for a bust-down
To make me put my two arms up, touchdown!

He’s moved his quest from the West to South sides (both of which consist of predominantly black neighborhoods). Even though he didn’t “score” as plentifully as before, the referee’s signal is the same for both touchdowns and field goals.

annotations.text: Ask you: tattoos on they hand (Who?)
annotations.annotation: Cam has “Diplomats” tatted on his hand:

annotations.text: Yellow on his ear (Who?)
annotations.annotation: Cam is very fond of his canary-yellow diamond earrings

annotations.text: Get the R. Kelly tape, and see how we piss on you
annotations.annotation: “Piss on You” is Dave Chappelle’s parody of the R. Kelly sex tape (via the “playas wanna play, ballers wanna ball” hook of “Feelin' on Yo' Booty”)

annotations.text:
[Produced by Infamous and Drew Correa]
 
 [Intro: Lil Wayne]
 Yo, yo Drew and Inf
 This-this, this right here is crazy
annotations.annotation:
As Drew Correa told XXL:

My friend Sha-ron Prescott helped me write the hook and sang the chorus. I sped him up and purposefully made it sound like a sample. We told [Wayne] it was a sample that we found. I think Wayne still thinks it’s a sample. Me and Infamous went to the studio and as soon as [Wayne] heard it, he absolutely lost his mind. That’s the reason he shouted us out in the beginning because we were right there with him.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Sha-Ron Prescott & Lil Wayne]
annotations.annotation:
As producer Drew told XXL:

My friend Sha-ron Prescott helped me write the hook and sang the chorus. I sped him up and purposefully made it sound like a sample. We told [Wayne] it was a sample that we found. I think Wayne still thinks it’s a sample.

annotations.text: Yeah, to you forever, from me to you
annotations.annotation: “To you forever” is a classic part of wedding vows, which Weezy elucidates in the next line: “I heard somebody say Church, I'ma need a suit”. This may be directed toward the rap game as an entity, rather than a woman.

annotations.text: I heard somebody say "Church!" I'ma need a suit
annotations.annotation:
This is a play on the word “church”, it is commonly used in slang as a showing of strong agreement similar to the usage of “preach”


Tha Carter III is hot

Church!




In addition, when people attend church they normally dress up or wear a suit.

annotations.text:
I'ma need a coupe, I won't need a roof
 Flyer than Beetlejuice, Beetlejuice, Beetlejuice
annotations.annotation:
In the movie Beetlejuice, saying the main character’s name 3 times immediately summons him so fast that it’s almost as if he flew there. Similarly, Wayne’s 2 door convertible is extremely “fly” (awesome).



Not to mention that Beetlejuice’s suit is pretty damn fly.

Beetle Juice also drives an open-top coupe and so Lil Wayne’s wordplay of saying “I’m a need a coupe, I won’t need a roof / Flyer than Beetlejuice, Beetlejuice,Beetlejuice”, is an allusion of he; Lil Wayne driving his Coupe like Beetlejuice and looking equally fly.

annotations.text: I got the flow, I'm tryin' to see the roof
annotations.annotation:
Wayne plans on using his impressive flows to reach the top of the rap game (represented by the roof). Though that may no longer be good enough for him ever since he released his mixtape No Ceilings.

Also note that Wayne slurs “flow” to make it sounds like floor, thus playing on the floor/roof dichotomy.

annotations.text: Didn't wear a bulletproof so I got shot and you can see the proof
annotations.annotation:
Weezy shot himself at age 12 with a 9mm handgun and has the scars to prove it.

This is the second time on the album that Wayne mentions the acident, being the first time this line on first track “3 Peat.”

annotations.text:
Blind eyes could look at me and see the truth
 Wonder if Stevie do?
annotations.annotation:
Even blind piano legend Stevie Wonder could see that Wayne is the truth:



This is also a play on words. Wayne is wondering what Stevie Wonder thinks of him, or if he sees the truth.

annotations.text: But I'ma leave it to God, not Beaver, neither you
annotations.annotation: A reference to the late 50’s show “Leave It To Beaver”, Here Wayne is saying only God can judge him not “you”, the “you” he is referring to in this verse is clarified at the end as being anyone hating on him for no reason.

annotations.text: Cause I'ma murder Y, kill O, and even U
annotations.annotation:
Some clever wordplay from Wayne, spelling YOU out while mixing in the words between. Final sentence reads “Cause I'ma murder and kill even you.”

This is reminiscent of the chorus from Nas’s famous Jay-Z diss track “Ether,” which states:

(I) Fuck with your soul like ether
(Will) Teach you – the king – you know you
(Not) God’s Son across the belly
(Lose) I prove you lost already

annotations.text: Man, I got summer hatin' on me cause I'm hotter than the sun
annotations.annotation:
Wayne finishes his opening verse with wordplay based around the four seasons.

Wayne has had a similar lines to this. On his 2004 song “Go DJ” he opens his verse with:

Murder 101
The hottest nigga under the sun

This line from “Go DJ” was sampled on “I’m Me” which was originally intended to be the previous track on this album before it was leaked and replaced with “3 Peat”.

In 2009 Wayne also released a complilation mixtape titled Hottest Nigga Under The Sun.

annotations.text: Got spring hatin' on me 'cause I ain't never sprung
annotations.annotation:
“Sprung”, in addition to being the past-tense of spring, means “to be in love”. Wayne would never fall in love with a girl like a silly man! (an especially interesting pun since Spring is the meme “lovey-dovey” season).

“Never sprung” is a term Jay Z used on his 1997 track “Who You Wit”. Wayne has proven he’s a fan of this period of Jay’s career, getting words from Jay’s 1997 track “Lucky Me” tatted on his face.

annotations.text: And I will never, I will never, I will never fall
annotations.annotation: Wayne completes his extended metaphor by punning on “fall” – both the season Autumn and the idea of slipping in the rap game.

annotations.text: I'm being hated by the seasons
annotations.annotation: This is another play on words; he is being hated both by the seasons (literally the four seasons of the year) and hated by the seasons in same sense as being hated by the years.

annotations.text: [Chorus: Sha-Ron Prescott & Lil Wayne]
annotations.annotation:
As producer Drew told XXL:

My friend Sha-ron Prescott helped me write the hook and sang the chorus. I sped him up and purposefully made it sound like a sample. We told [Wayne] it was a sample that we found. I think Wayne still thinks it’s a sample.

annotations.text:
Yeah, I been in and out the bank, bitch
 While y'all asshole niggas been on the same shit
 I flush and watch 'em go down the drain quick
annotations.annotation: While other people are wasting time, Lil Wayne has been making money. He’s not afraid to challenge himself, try new things, and work hard. As a result, he has grown and changed for the better, leaving all his haters behind. People who are just there to cause trouble are a waste of time to deal with. Much like discarded feces, they are out of his system and he’s ready to move on.

annotations.text: Two words you never hear: "Wayne quit!?"
annotations.annotation: Here, Weezy references his incredible work ethic. Throughout his entire career, he’s released a total of 12 studio albums, 25 mixtapes, and 2 EPs. Tha Carter III, while being recognized as the album that gave him wide mainstream success, was already his sixth full length LP.

annotations.text: I call 'em April babies, cause they fools
annotations.annotation:
April Fool’s day is a holiday celebrated every year on April 1st by playing practical jokes and spreading rumors. The jokes and their victims are called April fools.



Wayne uses a play on words with this holiday, suggesting that his opponents in the rap game are fools, so they must’ve been born on this holiday.

annotations.text:
I parallel park
 In that red-and-yellow thing; old school Atlanta Hawk
annotations.annotation: Wayne’s car is the same color as the “old school” (pre-2007) colors of the NBA’s Atlanta Hawks basketball team

annotations.text: Like I'm from College Park, but I'm from Hollygrove
annotations.annotation: College Park is a town south of Atlanta, GA (tieing into the Hawks line) and one of Lil Wayne’s close friends, 2 Chainz, is from there. 2 Chainz and Lil Wayne released a collab album in early 2016, titled Collegrove.

annotations.text: Now all my Bloods scream "Soo-woo"
annotations.annotation: “Soo-woo” is a call used by the Bloods gang to acknowledge each other (some speculate that it’s an onomatopoeiac reference to the sound of a police siren)

annotations.text: "Da-da-doe"
annotations.annotation: “Da da do” is another “the police are coming” warning system

annotations.text: And I weigh it well, on my Libra scale
annotations.annotation:
Lil Wayne, born September 27th, is a Libra (which means “scale” in Latin)

He claims that his Libra-demeanor is what allows him to stay focused amidst the temptations of fame and fortune

annotations.text: I am him
I'm right here in my chair with my crown
annotations.annotation: Jay-Z often refers to himself as the “King of New York”, a title with a storied rap history: the legendary Notorious B.I.G. also referred to himself in monarchic tones

annotations.text:
And my dear
 Queen B,
annotations.annotation: Jay’s wife, Beyonce Knowles, who would be the “queen” to his king (also a pun on “Queen Bey”, which fits her image as a diva)

annotations.text: As I share, mic time with my heir
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z is naming Wayne as his “heir to The Throne” as the King of Rap, and also as the next great Carter.

Wayne explained his reaction this line to Rolling Stone:

That line right there was hard! Unbelievable. I didn’t even realize it at first. My homie had to tell me “You know what he said, right?” I didn’t even get it. I was like, “Why is he saying ‘air’? Is he just talking about the air?” But I’m smart enough to know that he’s smart enough not to just be talking about the air. I felt real dumb, but then I felt so good. It was an incredible compliment.

annotations.text:
Young Carter, go farther, go further, go harder
 Is that not why we came? And if not, then why bother?
annotations.annotation: Jay is requesting Wayne, the younger of the Carters, to carry on his legacy and take rap places even “Young Hov” couldn’t take it. This made sense at the time, Wayne was the new hotness and Jay seemed on the brink of retirement, but these days it looks like Jay might outlast Weezy.

annotations.text: Show no mercy in Murcielagos
annotations.annotation:
Jay Z drives his Lamborghini Murcielago mercilessly (slow down!)



Murcielago’s were named after a famous bull. It survived so many times in the ring, that it was pardoned by the crowd. This was a rarity in bull-fighting circles. In this light, the line seems like it may have another level of entendre…

Also, Mercy and Murcie- is a form of pararhyme.

annotations.text: The bastard that Marcy had fathered
annotations.annotation:
Jay-Z grew up in Marcy Houses, a public housing project in Brooklyn’s Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood.



Jay-Z’s father, Adnis Reeves, walked out on his family when Jay-Z was only 12.

annotations.text: Now my name's been mentioned with the martyrs
annotations.annotation: An interesting line, as neither Bob Marley nor Marcus Garvey (see below) died violently, though Garvey faced government harassment, arrest, and imprisonment

annotations.text: The Biggies and the Pacs
annotations.annotation: Christopher “Biggie Smalls” Wallace and Tupac Amaru Shakur were both legendary rappers who died mysterious violent deaths

annotations.text: And the Marleys
annotations.annotation: Bob Marley died of cancer that started in his foot and spread to his other lungs and organs. Not really a martyr, but definitely a legend that Jay-Z chooses to align himself with

annotations.text:
And the Marcuses
 Garvey;
annotations.annotation:
Marcus Garvey was an early Pan-Africanist leader.



Jay-Z is saying that he’s being mentioned with the two greatest rappers ever, influential artist Bob Marley, and the great Marcus Garvey.  Braggadocio at its finest.



Fun fact: 3 of the 4 people he compared himself to are either Jamaican or of Jamaican Descent.

annotations.text:
Got me a molotov-cocktail flow
 Even if you box well, can't stop the blows
 Kaboom!
annotations.annotation: Jay’s flows are as firey and impactful as a molotov. “Blows” is slang for punches in the boxing ring, but even Muhammad Ali wouldn’t be able to dodge a molotov.

annotations.text: The Roc Boy in the room
annotations.annotation:
Jay Z often referrers and makes references to “Roc” (Short for Roc-A-Fella) in many of his songs. This is because he was the founder (or original “Roc Boy”) of Roc-A-Fella records (established in 1995).



This may also be some clever lyricism and preparation to his following line as “The Roc Boy” could be perceived as his former job as a crack dealer (“Dope boy”) as “rock” is a common slang word for crack

annotations.text:
Also, I'm so fly I'm on auto-
 Pilot,
annotations.annotation:
What rhymes with SPOON and follows auto?



Jay cleverly plays on our expectation he is about to say auto-tune, since Jay and AT was a controversial mix at the time. The literary name for this stylistic device is called par'hyponoian.

annotations.text: I see Euros, that's right: plural
annotations.annotation:
In Continental Europe, the plural of Euro is still Euro rather than Euros. Analogously, few would claim to have lots of Yens (Japan), Yuans (China), Wons (Korea), etc.

Jay-Z is aware of this fact (unlike most rappers as is evident from a quick search on Genius). He emphasizes that his use of Euros is not a grammatical faux pas, but rather an expression of the huge amount of “Euros” he actually sees.



This can also be interpreted in the following way: as a young business man on the streets, Jay-Z made his income in USD. By stating that he now earns Euros, Jay-Z’d be indicating that he now accepts multiple forms of currency.

annotations.text: It's my go, yeah
annotations.annotation: This kind of sounds like “ It’s Michael”, Wayne’s middle name.

annotations.text: Off the richter,
annotations.annotation:
The Richter scale is used to measure the intensity of earthquakes.



Wayne is saying here his rhymes are more intense than even the most devastating quake

annotations.text: Hector, Camacho Man, Randy Savage
annotations.annotation: Wayne is running the names of boxer Hector “Macho” Camacho and wrestler “The Macho Man” Randy Savage… together.

annotations.text: I know, I ride slow, and when I pass
annotations.annotation:
Weezy alludes to the way he likes to ride in Jody Breeze’s song “Dippin' (Catch Me If You Can)”:

I’m coming around the loop
I’m in the Bentley Coupe
In the 35 doing 22
Don’t honk your horn, don’t flash your lights
Cause me and Jody passing blunts like we pass the mic

annotations.text: They say, "What up, killa?" Man, stop bringin' up my past
annotations.annotation: When Wayne passes by, they holler “what up, killa?” in a casual sense, “killa” holding a similar connotation to “bro”, “homie”, etc. However, in Wayne’s response,  “stop bringing up my past”, he insinuates that he really was a killer. So while it may be casual slang for them, it’s quite literal to him.

annotations.text:
And next time you mention Pac, Biggie, or Jay-Z
 Don't forget Weezy, Baby!
annotations.annotation: Pac, Biggie, and Jay-Z are all legends in the rap game that come up in the discussion for best ever.  Weezy is demanding to be put in the discussion, as he also did on “A Milli”.

annotations.text:
[Outro: Lil Wayne]
 And I swear to everything, when I leave this Earth
 It's gonna be on both feet, never knees in the dirt
 And you can try me, fucker, but when I squeeze, it hurt
 Fine, we'll lose two lives; yours and mine
 Give me any amount of time, don't let Ms. Carter grieve
 At the funeral parlor, drippin' tears down my sleeve
 Give me any amount of time, don't let Ms. Carter grieve
annotations.annotation:
Despite their odd “off & on” friendship, Lil Wayne is still a huge fan of Jay-Z’s. In People Magazine’s “Four Albums That Changed My Life” interview, Wayne says reveals that his love for VOL 1 (“Lucky Me” in particular) was so great that he now has the words “Lucky Me” tatted on his neck as well as a verse from the song on his leg.

“Lucky Me” is my favorite song of all. Period. I actually have “Lucky Me” tattooed on my neck. And I have a verse of that song tattooed on my leg.
